site_title: Wilmar Q3 net profit rises 20% to US$536.6m; proposes special dividend for successful YKA listing
summary: Wilmar International, a Singaporean agri-business group, reported a 20% increase in net profit to US$536.6 million in its third fiscal quarter, driven by strong demand for food products and higher crushing activities. The company's core net profit rose 19.6% to US$501.4 million, its highest third-quarter figure since listing. Wilmar also proposed a special dividend of around US$300 million to shareholders following the successful listing of its Chinese unit Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA).

site_title: Revamping classic cocktails
summary: Revamp, a Tanjong Pagar Road bar, serves creative twists on classic cocktails under the guidance of bartender Boo Jing Heng. The bar offers 10 signature drinks with clear naming and a dual axis guide, making it easier for customers to choose. Revamp also serves traditional classics, spirits, wine, and mocktails, as well as bottles of pre-made cocktails. The bar has collaborated with China Whampoa Home Made Noodle to offer casual hawker-style food, including ban mian and spring rolls.

site_title: Lendlease to manage New Shaw Tower
summary: Lendlease has been appointed to manage the redevelopment of New Shaw Tower on Beach Road, set for completion in 2024. The 200-meter-tall building will offer 450,000 square feet of Grade A office space, retail, and F&B outlets, along with lifestyle amenities and sustainable design features. The project aims to revitalize the Ophir-Rochor corridor as a work, live, and play destination, complementing nearby Raffles Place and Marina Bay. The redevelopment follows a review of the project timeline, prioritizing safety and pandemic considerations.

site_title: Growth in China's services sector accelerates in Oct: official PMI
summary: China's services sector activity accelerated in October, with the official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 56.2 from 55.9 in September. This marks a growth from the previous month, indicating a recovery in the economy from the coronavirus-induced slump. The October composite PMI also rose to 55.3, suggesting a continued expansion in both manufacturing and services sectors.

images.alt_text: Activity in China's services sector accelerated in October, official data showed on Saturday, as demand across the economy continues to recover from a coronavirus-induced slump.

site_title: A checklist before exercising to prevent sudden cardiac death
summary: A checklist before exercising to prevent sudden cardiac death can significantly reduce the risk of this life-threatening condition. SCD affects about 1,000 individuals in Singapore each year, with a median age of 47 for males and 50 for females. The US experiences about half of heart-related deaths due to SCD, with a one-year survival rate of 10% if sudden cardiac arrest occurs outside a hospital. Identifying those at risk of coronary artery disease is crucial to preventing SCD, and a pre-exercise check can help minimize this risk.

site_title: US jury tells Apple to pay US$503m in patent case
summary: A US jury in Texas has ordered Apple to pay $503 million for infringing on virtual private network technology patented by VirnetX, a software security firm. The technology, used in devices such as iPhones, iPads, and iPod Touches, was found to be infringed upon by Apple. The company has expressed disappointment with the verdict and plans to appeal.

site_title: Without a stimulus uplift ahead of Nov 3, gold prices drift down on a stronger dollar
summary: Gold prices drifted down throughout the week due to a lack of progress in US pandemic stimulus talks and a stronger dollar. The European Central Bank maintained its policy unchanged, despite hints of further easing at its December meeting. In the US, investors are cautious ahead of the presidential election, with a disputed outcome potentially pressuring gold prices. A Biden victory is expected to be more favorable to gold prices due to the potential for a larger fiscal stimulus package.

site_title: Fed in holding pattern amid tense US election
summary: The US Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee is set to meet amid the uncertainty of the presidential election, but analysts expect minimal policy changes. The Fed has already kept borrowing rates zero and expanded credit facilities during the coronavirus downturn. The committee will convene at a time when the US economy is showing signs of recovery, with GDP growth expected to slow in China, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: First international, Chinese expert meeting on virus origin: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) held its first virtual meeting with Chinese experts to investigate the origins of the novel coronavirus pandemic. The meeting, led by WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, aims to establish the origins of the virus to prevent future outbreaks. Despite criticism from the US administration, the WHO emphasized the importance of scientific accuracy over political pressure. The meeting follows an advance team sent to Beijing in July, and experts believe the virus originated from bats, with an unknown intermediate animal host.

site_title: Biden, Trump barnstorm heartland in election home stretch
summary: US President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden engaged in intense campaigning in the Midwest, a region that Trump won in 2016. With four days left in the election, Trump held rallies in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota, while Biden campaigned in the same states. The pandemic overshadowed the election, with the US surpassing 9 million coronavirus cases. The intense campaigning highlights the differences between the two candidates as the election enters its final stretch.

site_title: Ronaldo recovers from coronavirus after 19 days
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo, Juventus star, has tested negative for coronavirus after 19 days of self-isolation. He first tested positive on October 13 while playing with Portugal and had been in isolation since returning to Italy. Ronaldo has recovered and is no longer under home isolation. His return to Juventus is a boost for the team, which is fifth in Serie A and has been struggling with draws in their last three league games. Ronaldo's comeback comes after a surge in Covid-19 cases in Italy, with over 31,000 people testing positive in a 24-hour period.

site_title: Trump, Biden hit key states on final weekend before vote
summary: US President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden made key stops in crucial states on the final weekend before the presidential election. Trump warned of "bedlam" if no clear winner emerges quickly, while Biden urged Trump to "pack his bags" and go home. With a record 90 million early votes cast, the election takes place in a deeply divided country ravaged by the coronavirus pandemic. Biden leads in key battleground state Pennsylvania by nearly seven points, while Trump hopes to pull off a surprise result in traditionally conservative Texas.

site_title: Employment-related claims, new default notices emerge at Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) faces fresh troubles with the emergence of employment-related claims and new default notices. The trust has discovered pending claims related to the Queen Mary Long Beach hotel and has issued a notice of acceleration for a mortgage loan at the Crowne Plaza Dallas. Additionally, a notice of default has been issued for a mortgage loan at the Hilton Houston Galleria Area. EHT is consulting its advisers on the claims and liabilities, and an EHT master lessor is also involved in litigation proceedings.

site_title: China's factory activity slows slightly in October
summary: China's factory activity expanded at a slightly slower pace in October, with the manufacturing PMI falling to 51.4 from 51.5 in September. This was slightly above analysts' expectations, indicating a continuing economic recovery. The slowdown is seen as a sign of a solidly on-track broader recovery, suggesting China's economy is rebounding from the coronavirus shock.

site_title: Why the future of our city requires a rethink
summary: As the world marks World Cities Day, city planners must rethink urban living in the post-Covid era. The pandemic has reshaped urban living, with remote working and social distancing becoming the "new norm". To create sustainable cities, planners must accelerate digitalization and engage with communities. Key building blocks of community building, urban planning, and sustainability must be reevaluated. This includes harnessing community power through better understanding of needs, aspirations, and capacities, leveraging technology to build local communities, and enabling smart transportation to reduce emissions. Collective effort from governments, businesses, and individuals is needed to build a healthy and sustainable city for future generations.

site_title: Protesting Thai students boycott royal graduation day
summary: Thai students boycotted graduation ceremonies led by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, showing anger at the monarchy amid growing calls to reform it. The ceremonies, a rite of passage for graduates, were disrupted by protesters who defied lese majeste laws. This marks a taboo-breaking moment, as protests since mid-July have openly criticized the monarchy. The boycott highlights the growing discontent with the monarchy's power, sparking calls for reform.

site_title: Huawei plans to build chip plant without US technology: FT
summary: Huawei plans to build a chip plant in Shanghai without using American technology, as the company seeks to overcome US sanctions. The fabrication facility will start with low-end 45nm chips and aim to produce 28nm chips for IoT devices by 2021 and 20nm chips for 5G equipment by 2022. Huawei has no experience in chip fabrication, but will be run by Shanghai IC R&D Center, a research company backed by the city's government. This move is part of China's efforts to increase economic self-sufficiency and build its own core technology.

site_title: Russian hackers targeted California, Indiana Democratic parties
summary: Russian hackers, nicknamed "Fancy Bear," targeted the email accounts of California and Indiana Democratic parties, as well as influential think tanks in Washington and New York. The attempted intrusions, which were internally flagged by Microsoft, provide insight into Russian intelligence's efforts to meddle in the US presidential election ahead of the November 3 election. This incident highlights ongoing cybersecurity threats and the ongoing efforts to counter Russian interference in the US electoral process.

site_title: US personal income up by more than forecast
summary: US personal income rose 0.9% in September, exceeding forecasts, driven by employment gains and boosting consumer spending. This follows a 2.5% decline in August. The personal saving rate fell for a fifth month to 14.3%, but remained elevated. Household outlays advanced 1.4% and exceeded forecasts.

site_title: Three Thai pro-democracy leaders in hospital
summary: Three prominent Thai pro-democracy leaders, Panupong "Mike" Jadnok, Panusaya "Rung" Sithijirawattanakul, and Parit "Penguin" Chiwarak, were hospitalized after chaotic scenes outside a Bangkok police station. They were ordered released on sedition charges but police sought to question them over outstanding arrest warrants. The student-led protests demand reforms, including the monarchy and Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha's resignation. The leaders were subjected to physical altercations, with Panupong appearing unconscious and Parit having shards of broken glass in his skin. They are expected to stay in hospital for 2-3 days.

site_title: Four ride-hailing firms bag operating licences from LTA
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded operating licences to four ride-hailing firms - Grab, Gojek, TADA, and ComfortDelGro - under the Point-to-Point (P2P) Passenger Transport Industry Act. The licences have a three-year validity period, with Grab also receiving a car-pool service operator licence. Existing taxi operators have been transitioned to the new street-hail service operator licence, and drivers must now attend a vehicle safety and maintenance course starting January 1, 2022. The new regulations aim to ensure higher safety standards and a fair market for ride-hailing services.

site_title: AirAsia says US$72m loan was obtained in appropriate manner
summary: AirAsia Group has secured a $72-million loan from Sabah Development Bank, which began an investigation into the loan. The airline claims all discussions and negotiations were conducted in an appropriate manner. The loan will be used to establish a digital food supply chain and expand AirAsia's operations in Sabah, with the projects having a solid commercial basis. The airline asserts the loan was obtained in accordance with laws, policies, and procedures.

site_title: Four ride-hailing firms bag operating licences from LTA
summary: The Singapore Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded operating licences to four ride-hailing firms: Grab, Gojek, TADA, and ComfortDelGro. The licences have a three-year validity period and come with conditions to meet safety standards and ensure non-exclusive partnership arrangements with drivers. Existing taxi operators have been automatically transitioned to the new street-hail service operator licence. The new regulations require operators to publish booking charges and fares for commuters, enabling the Public Transport Council to enforce against fare evasion and overcharging.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust DPS falls 68.3% for FY20
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 68.3% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for FY20, to 1.3982 Singapore cents, from 4.4129 Singapore cents in the previous year. Gross revenue fell 40.9% and net property income dropped 46.4% year-over-year. The trust attributed the decline to exceptional lockdown measures and border closures due to the pandemic. FHT's Malaysia portfolio saw the greatest decline in gross operating profit, falling 92.1% year-over-year.

site_title: PUB enhances water efficiency fund with more funding areas, shorter payout periods
summary: The Public Utilities Board (PUB) has enhanced its Water Efficiency Fund with expanded funding areas, including a new category for water-efficient equipment, where companies can receive up to S$300,000. Existing categories now offer co-funding up to half of qualifying costs, capped at S$30,000. The enhanced fund aims to promote water efficiency and reduce consumption. Shorter disbursement periods are also introduced, providing more support for businesses and households to adopt water-efficient practices.

site_title: Resident employment rebounds, but retrenchments still rising
summary: Singapore's resident employment levels recovered to near pre-pandemic levels in September, with 2.34 million residents employed, close to the 2.36 million seen in December 2019. However, total employment excluding foreign domestic workers declined by 26,900 in the third quarter, largely due to the continued contraction in non-resident employment. Retrenchments rose to 9,100 in Q3, exceeding the quarterly peak of previous recessions. Economists predict a slow recovery, with unemployment rates expected to peak at around 4% in the full year, and some experts warning of a "substantial economic slack" remaining.

site_title: Euro zone economy surges in Q3 before expected blow from new lockdowns
summary: The euro zone economy rebounded 12.7% in the third quarter after contracting 11.8% in the second quarter, exceeding expectations. However, new lockdowns in countries like France and Germany may cut short the recovery. Despite this, Germany's economy grew 8.2% quarter-on-quarter, and year-on-year euro zone economic output was 4.3% lower, beating market expectations. Economic growth in the final three months of the year is expected to disappoint, according to European Central Bank Vice President Luis de Guindos.

site_title: Sabana Reit renews 58% of leases expiring in 2020
summary: Sabana Reit renewed 58% of leases expiring in 2020, with portfolio occupancy rising to 80.2% in Q3. The Reit signed 304,622 sq ft of new leases and expects rental contributions from its New Tech Park asset enhancement initiative to start in Q2 2021. Despite the challenges posed by COVID-19, the Reit achieved positive rental reversion and improved portfolio occupancy.

site_title: Miss Victoria Peak? HK return fare prices taking flight
summary: Singapore Airlines has seen a significant increase in round-trip airfares to Hong Kong, rising by up to 40% following the announcement of an air travel bubble between the two cities. Despite a work-in-progress air travel bubble, ticket prices continue to rise, indicating a one-way trend. This surge in fares is attributed to the news of a potential quarantine-free travel arrangement between Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Philippines orders evacuation as world's strongest 2020 typhoon approaches
summary: The Philippines has ordered evacuation of thousands of residents in the southern part of Luzon island due to Typhoon Goni, the world's strongest 2020 typhoon, which is expected to make landfall on Sunday. Category 5 Typhoon Goni has sustained winds of 215 kmh and gusts of up to 265 kmh, posing a significant threat to coastal and landslide-prone communities. Authorities are taking precautions, including imposing social distancing in evacuation centers, while also preparing relief goods and equipment.

site_title: FirstEnergy fires CEO Jones in wake of Ohio bribery scandal
summary: FirstEnergy, an Ohio-based utility, fired CEO Charles Jones and two senior executives following a board review into a federal corruption scandal. The scandal involved Energy Harbor, where a former unit was accused of accepting bribes tied to a $1 billion bailout. Two associates, including a lobbyist for a FirstEnergy subsidiary, pleaded guilty. The firings are FirstEnergy's strongest response to the scandal, with President Steven Strah taking over as acting CEO.

site_title: India's ICICI Bank posts record profit on expected dip in bad loans
summary: ICICI Bank reported a record quarterly profit of 42.51 billion rupees, a 48% increase from the previous year. The bank set aside 29.95 billion rupees for bad loans, lower than expected, and its gross bad loan ratio decreased to 5.17%. Net interest income rose 16% from last year, driven by higher home loan disbursements. The bank's CEO expects a "more normalised" financial year starting April 1, with no additional provisions for COVID-19 induced bad loans.

site_title: US: Wall St drops as tech stocks slide, Covid cases up
summary: Wall Street's main indexes fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 86.84 points, or 0.33%, to 26,572.27, amid a selloff in tech stocks following underwhelming business updates. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the Nasdaq dropping 82.12 points, or 0.73%, to 11,103.47. The decline was also attributed to a record rise in coronavirus cases and nerves over the presidential election.

site_title: UK restricts flu vaccine exports during Covid outbreak
summary: The UK government has restricted the export of flu vaccines to protect the domestic supply during the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. The move aims to ensure that flu vaccinations are prioritized for the 30 million people targeted, amid concerns about hospital overcrowding. Health Minister Matt Hancock stated that the UK will prioritize its own medicine and vaccine needs, protecting the supply of flu vaccinations.

site_title: Legendary British actor Sean Connery dead at 90
summary: Legendary British actor Sean Connery, famous for playing the original James Bond, has died at 90. He passed away peacefully in his sleep in the Bahamas, where he had been "unwell for some time". Connery's son, Jason Connery, confirmed the news, calling it a "sad loss for all people around the world who enjoyed his gift as an actor." Tributes have poured in for the film hero, who was known for his iconic roles in movies such as the James Bond series and "The Untouchables".

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MNACT acquired a 50% stake in Pinnacle Gangnam in Seoul for S$276.4 million, fully funded by debt. CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported 25.8% quarter-on-quarter sales recovery and 34.7% shopper traffic growth. Qian Hu appointed Yap Kok Cheng as new CEO, replacing Kenny Yap.

site_title: Personal information of 1.1 million RedMart accounts stolen in Lazada data breach
summary: A data breach at Lazada has exposed the personal information of 1.1 million RedMart accounts, including names, encrypted passwords, phone numbers, and partial credit card numbers. The breach occurred from a RedMart-only database that had not been updated since March 2020. Lazada's cybersecurity team discovered the breach and has taken immediate action to block unauthorized access. The company is investigating and informing affected customers to change their log-in details as a precaution. Lazada has reported the breach to the Personal Data Protection Commission.

images.alt_text: The personal information of 1.1 million RedMart users was stolen from a customer database and put up for sale in an online forum, including names, phone numbers and partial credit card numbers.

site_title: US judge sets up fresh roadblock in Trump bid to ban TikTok
summary: A US federal judge has issued a temporary injunction blocking President Donald Trump's executive order aimed at banning TikTok, throwing a roadblock in the president's bid. The order, set to take effect on November 12, would have cut off the Chinese-owned app from US businesses. A separate injunction issued in September prevented the government from removing TikTok from mobile application download platforms. Judges cited the app's status as a film, photograph, and news wire as having legal protections, and questioned the administration's need to ban the app due to national security concerns.

images.alt_text: A US federal judge on Friday issued an injunction temporarily blocking an executive order by President Donald Trump aimed at banning TikTok, throwing up a legal roadblock ahead of a November 12 deadline.

site_title: US: Stocks end worst week, month since March
summary: US stocks ended their worst week and month since March on Friday, falling 0.6% to 26,501.60 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with the Nasdaq tumbling 2.5% to 10,911.59. Investors fretted over rising coronavirus cases and the presidential election, with tech giants like Apple, Amazon, and Facebook experiencing significant drops. The earnings period is winding down, highlighting concerns about the growth outlook amid the pandemic.

site_title: Macau's gambling revenues dive 72.5% in Oct
summary: Macau's gambling revenue plummeted 72.5% in October to 7.3 billion patacas ($1.25 billion), a slower decline than previous months but still significant. The drop is attributed to ongoing coronavirus travel restrictions and muted demand from VIP high rollers. China's resumption of tourist visas in September did not boost demand, and fears of a broader crackdown on offshore gambling have led to a rush to withdraw billions of dollars from Macau, threatening the economy's recovery.

site_title: Singapore firms don't see skies clearing in next two quarters
summary: Singapore firms expect business conditions to worsen in the next two quarters, with a net-weighted balance of 5% in the services sector expecting worse conditions. However, the gap between pessimists and optimists is narrowing. The services sector is more optimistic, with recreation and personal services sectors expecting better times ahead. In manufacturing, the miscellaneous industries segment is the most optimistic, while the electronics cluster expects a poorer outlook. Overall, firms expect employment levels to remain similar, but net-weighted balances still point to hiring fewer workers.

site_title: Oil falls on demand concerns, posts second monthly decline
summary: Oil prices fell for a second consecutive month due to concerns over fuel consumption amid rising COVID-19 cases in Europe and the US. Brent crude dropped to $37.46 a barrel and WTI crude fell to $35.79 a barrel. The US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 11% for the month. Opec+ is set to hold a policy meeting, with top producers considering maintaining output reductions due to lockdowns and rising Libyan oil output. The outcome of the meeting has the potential to impact oil prices by $10 per barrel.

site_title: Free speech has limits, Canada's Trudeau says
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau defended free speech, stating it's "not without limits" and should not "arbitrarily and needlessly hurt" certain communities. He emphasized the importance of using freedom of expression "with respect for others" and avoiding actions that could "injure those with whom we are sharing a society and a planet." Trudeau condemned recent terrorist attacks in France, which killed three people, and expressed solidarity with France. He urged a "careful" use of freedom of expression in a diverse and respectful society.

site_title: Australia sees zero local Covid cases for first time since June
summary: Australia reported zero local Covid cases on November 1, the first time since June, as the nation eases domestic travel restrictions. State governments are lifting lockdowns, and Western Australia plans to allow travelers to enter from November 14. This milestone comes as other countries, such as Vietnam, impose renewed measures to combat the resurgent pandemic. The easing of restrictions is a result of the country's successful containment efforts, marking a significant step forward in managing the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: "We need to talk about promotions."
summary: During the current pandemic, employees should scale back expectations but not give up on promotions, according to experts. While some companies have implemented increment freezes, others are promoting employees and then increasing pay later. Employees should take the initiative to update their superiors on their work progress and demonstrate adaptability and new solutions to thrive in a rapidly evolving business landscape. If passed over for a promotion, employees should do a self-assessment and seek feedback to find out what more is needed. Experts caution against overemphasizing what could have been done differently to prevent missing a promotion.

site_title: Fears of transition 'chaos' if Biden defeats Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump has expressed concerns about a "chaotic transition" if he loses the upcoming election to Joe Biden. Trump has questioned the legitimacy of mail-in ballots and has been vague about accepting election results. His ambiguous comments have raised doubts about a smooth transition, potentially leading to controversy and instability.

site_title: Nanofilm advances 12.4% in heavy volume on debut
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a Singapore-based company, made its debut on the mainboard with a share price of S$2.91, up 12.4% from its initial public offering (IPO) price of S$2.59. The company traded on high volume, with 106.5 million shares changing hands. The stock reached an intraday high of S$3.02 before closing at S$2.91.

site_title: Melbourne enjoys first weekend out of lockdown as Covid-19 cases dwindle
summary: Melbourne residents enjoyed their first weekend out of lockdown as Covid-19 cases continued to dwindle. Victoria reported just one new case and no deaths, down from average daily new cases of around 700 in July. Chief health officer Brett Sutton said residents should enjoy their lives after three months of constrained activity. The move marks a significant step towards easing restrictions in Australia's second-largest city.

site_title: ESR-Reit Q3 DPU drops 20% to 0.798 Singapore cent
summary: ESR-Reit's Q3 DPU dropped 20.2% to 0.798 Singapore cent, down from 1 cent in the same quarter last year. The company released S$3.5 million in distributable income from Q1 2020, previously retained due to Covid-19 uncertainties.

site_title: Two of four new imported Covid-19 cases are Singapore PRs
summary: Singapore reported four new imported COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 58,019. Two of the cases are Singapore permanent residents, a 37-year-old man from India and a 51-year-old woman from the UK, who had onset of symptoms on October 23. The remaining two cases are employed individuals, a Dutch work pass holder from the Netherlands and a Filipino work permit holder from the Philippines. No community cases were reported, and the number of new cases in the community has remained low.

site_title: With Robinsons closing, what lies ahead for its peers?
summary: Singapore's department store market is facing challenges due to the pandemic, with sales expected to fall by 1.7% annually from 2019 to 2024. Operators like BHG Singapore and Isetan Singapore have struggled, with BHG recording a loss of S$2.3 million and Isetan reporting a net loss of S$317,000. However, those with diversified businesses, such as property, may weather the decline better. Operators like Metro Holdings, which has a portfolio of 29 properties across Singapore and internationally, have seen their property segment contribute significantly to their topline.

site_title: Reits (Oct 31- Nov 01, 2020)
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Realty news includes S-Reits, property prices, and global market trends. The S-Reits market saw a significant increase in prices. A Q3 condo launch wave in Singapore may test demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf. In the US, mortgage rates rose after five straight weeks of declines. Manhattan rents hit a record high, with further increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. Meanwhile, New World sold China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay, filling more space after its bankruptcy.

site_title: Indonesia eyes increased US investment, trade after preference extension
summary: Indonesia aims to double US trade to $60 billion in the next five years, with vice-foreign minister Mahendra Siregar stating that the country is seeking to increase investment from the US. This follows over two years of negotiations, with the US Trade Representative's Office confirming Indonesia's eligibility for the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) facility without losing previous benefits. The move is expected to boost trade and investment between the two countries.

site_title: US cuts tariff benefits for Thailand in pork dispute
summary: The US has announced it will eliminate tariff benefits for Thailand, worth $817 million, due to the country's failure to allow US pork imports. This decision, made by the US Trade Representative, is the result of 12 years of discussions and demonstrates the Trump Administration's commitment to monitoring and enforcing trade preference programmes. The suspension of duty-free access will take effect on December 30.

site_title: Hong Kong Q3 GDP down 3.4% y-o-y, grows 3% q-o-q
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 3.4% in the third quarter compared to the same period last year, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on consumer spending, trade, and tourism. However, on a quarterly basis, the economy grew 3% from the previous quarter, showing a slight improvement. This marks the fifth consecutive quarter of year-on-year contractions for the city.

site_title: Inspire Brands says to buy Dunkin' Brands donut company for US$8.8b
summary: Inspire Brands, the parent company of Arby's, Buffalo Wild Wings, and Sonic Drive-In, has announced the acquisition of Dunkin' Brands, the owner of Dunkin' donuts and Baskin-Robbins ice cream, for US$8.8 billion, including debt. The deal will expand Inspire Brands' total restaurants to over 31,600 and combined sales to $26 billion. The transaction is expected to be finalized by the end of the year, with Dunkin' shares selling for US$106.50 per share in cash.

site_title: A blueprint to turn China into tech superpower?
summary: China's latest five-year plan, set to run through 2026, focuses on technological independence, boosting domestic consumption, and remaining attractive for high-end foreign investment. The plan aims to boost domestic production of semiconductors, dominate AI and 5G sectors, and achieve a carbon-neutral economy by 2060. China's GDP growth target for the next 15 years is 3.5%, with a goal to raise per capita output levels to that of "moderately developed countries" by 2035. The plan's release comes as President Xi Jinping consolidates his grip on the Party and China's economy shifts from quantity to quality.

site_title: Robinsons Singapore says goodbye after 162 years
summary: Robinsons Singapore, a department store operator, is closing down after 162 years in business due to losses in recent years. The company's last two stores at The Heeren and Raffles City Shopping Centre may remain open for final sales in the coming weeks. Approximately 175 employees will be affected by the closure.

site_title: Honeywell profit falls 53% as aerospace unit sales slump
summary: Honeywell International reported a 53% decline in quarterly profit to $758 million, or $1.07 per share, in the third quarter due to a pandemic-driven slump in air travel affecting its aerospace business. This represents a significant drop from the same period last year, when the company earned $1.62 billion, or $2.23 per share. The decline is attributed to reduced demand for aircraft and related services.

site_title: Singapore September bank lending falls further on prolonged weakness in business loans
summary: Singapore's bank lending in September fell 0.3% to S$421.28 billion, marking the seventh consecutive decline, primarily due to a contraction in business loans, which dropped 0.3% from August. This is the sixth straight month of decline in business loans. The data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore suggests prolonged weakness in business loans outweighing the rise in consumer loans.

site_title: China starts once-a-decade census of world's largest population
summary: China has begun its once-a-decade census, gathering data from millions of community workers and volunteers to determine population growth and trends. The census, which will take two years to compile, is expected to update the population to 1.42 billion, a 5.99% increase, but a research institute has questioned the government's estimate, suggesting the actual number could be lower. The census is also sparking concerns about data protection, as most citizens will enter their information via a smartphone app, raising worries about privacy and security.

site_title: Marriott fined £18.4m for failing to secure customer data
summary: Britain's data watchdog fined Marriott International £18.4m for failing to secure 339 million guest records after a 2014 cyber attack on Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide. The ICO stated the attack remained undetected until September 2018, when Marriott was acquired. The company failed to implement adequate security measures, resulting in the data breach. This is the largest data breach fine imposed by the ICO.

site_title: Britain considering imposition of new national lockdown measures: Times
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson is considering new national lockdown measures amid a surge in Covid-19 cases, with potential restrictions set to remain in place until December 1. The new measures, which could include closing everything except essential shops and educational settings, are still under discussion and no final decision has been made. The UK reported 24,405 new cases and 274 deaths on Friday, with hospitals facing increased pressure. Johnson is expected to announce the new measures in a news conference on Monday.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is considering imposing new national lockdown measures next week, amid concerns that hospitals across the country are overwhelmed by a resurgence in Covid-19 cases, The Times newspaper reported on Friday.

site_title: Chevron posts profit on deep cost cuts, improved oil prices
summary: Chevron reported a surprise third-quarter profit of $201 million, or 11 cents per share, driven by deep cost cuts and improved oil prices. The company's spending on new projects was reduced by 48% and expenses by 12% compared to the previous year. Despite lower oil volumes, Chevron posted modest operating profit in oil and gas production and refining. The company expects to reduce its workforce by up to 15% due to a year-long restructuring. Chevron's shares rose 1% to $69.52.

site_title: Covid-19 tips balance further in favour of shareholders over creditors
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has further shifted the balance in favor of shareholders over creditors, as laws and regulations have weakened insolvency laws and made it harder for creditors to prove a company's insolvency. This has allowed companies to prioritize shareholder interests over long-term strategic considerations, leading to increased share buybacks and dividend payments. The raised bar for proving insolvency and relaxed rules against financial assistance have exacerbated this trend, with creditors facing higher interest rates and reduced trust from suppliers. A new balance between creditors and shareholders is needed to prevent a global crash.

site_title: How a century of real estate tax breaks enriched Donald Trump
summary: Donald Trump, 25 years before becoming president, testified to Congress that the demise of real estate tax shelters was "an absolute catastrophe for the country." The real estate industry has since enjoyed tax breaks for a century, including deductions for depreciation, which allow investors to deduct a portion of the cost of an asset over time. Trump has taken hundreds of millions of dollars in depreciation deductions, mostly for his golf courses and luxury hotel. The 1986 tax overhaul reined in depreciation benefits but restored them in 1993, and the 2017 tax overhaul expanded and enhanced lucrative tax breaks for real estate developers, benefiting Trump.

site_title: Hong Kong media boss distances himself from contentious Hunter Biden-China report
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai denied involvement in a US report alleging China business links of Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden. Despite admitting his private firm funded the research, Lai claimed he was unaware of the project. Apple Daily, Lai's newspaper, published two articles on Hunter Biden, but stated they were separate from the 64-page report. Lai's senior executive, Mark Simon, resigned after the incident and apologized for any damage to Lai's reputation.

site_title: Qian Hu appoints new CEO; Kenny Yap remains as executive chairman
summary: Qian Hu appoints Yap Kok Cheng as its new CEO, replacing Kenny Yap, who will remain as executive chairman. Yap, 42, was part of Qian Hu's succession program and underwent rigorous assessments. He will start as CEO on Jan 1, 2021.

site_title: China's CNOOC and Sinopec issue first LNG tenders on Shanghai gas exchange
summary: China's state-owned oil companies, CNOOC and Sinopec, have issued the first liquefied natural gas (LNG) tenders on the Shanghai Petroleum and Natural Gas Exchange, marking the exchange's launch of LNG trading. CNOOC has issued a buy tender for 65,000 tonnes of LNG to be delivered in March 2021, and multiple companies, including Total and Mitsui & Co, have been invited to participate in the tenders. This move aims to meet the growing demand for LNG in China, which is expected to grow by 10% this winter.

site_title: MNACT acquires 50% stake in Seoul office building
summary: MNACT, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, has acquired a 50% stake in Seoul's Pinnacle Gangnam office building for S$276.4 million. The acquisition, funded by debt, is expected to increase MNACT's distribution per unit (DPU) by 0.4% and raise net property income (NPI) yield. The 20-storey building has an occupancy rate of 89.6% and a weighted average lease expiry of 2.8 years. Completion is slated for the end of the year, with MNACT's managers citing the deal as an "attractive value proposition".

site_title: The last mile in unlocking sustainable development
summary: Investor education in sustainable investing is crucial to achieve progress in sustainable development. Financial institutions must equip bankers and investment advisers to engage in meaningful conversations about environmental and social considerations. A two-year-old client's request for sustainable portfolio adjustments highlighted the need for a shift in traditional investment proposals. To unlock capital for sustainable development, investor education and awareness are essential, particularly for those at the "last mile" of under-served and excluded communities.

site_title: Football: Wolves boss Nuno wants better pay-per-view solution
summary: Wolverhampton Wanderers manager Nuno Espirito Santo has criticized the Premier League's current pay-per-view (PPV) model for matches outside regular broadcast slots, citing low fan engagement. The model, which charges £14.95 for matches like Wolves vs Crystal Palace, is being reviewed ahead of the international break. The Premier League has extended the PPV scheme to matches on Nov 6-8, but Nuno believes a better solution is needed to increase fan participation and engagement.

images.alt_text: Wolverhampton Wanderers manager Nuno Espirito Santo has called on the Premier League to ditch its current pay-per-view (PPV) model for matches outside regular broadcast slots amid widespread criticism from fans.

site_title: Investors drawn to S-E Asia's warehouses in wake of pandemic
summary: Investors are shifting their focus to Southeast Asia's warehouses as manufacturing shifts away from China due to the pandemic. The region's high mobile penetration, growing middle class, and young population have fueled the e-commerce boom, leading to a surge in demand for warehousing options. Investors have raised over $7 billion to target logistics assets, with industrial deals making up nearly 20% of real estate investment activity in the first half of 2020. Established and new investors are expected to increase their allocation to the logistics sector, with a focus on modern facilities and tech-enabled warehouses.

site_title: US passes nine million reported coronavirus cases: Johns Hopkins
summary: The US has surpassed 9 million reported coronavirus cases, according to Johns Hopkins University, amid a resurgence of the pandemic since mid-October. This milestone comes days before the presidential election, with President Trump facing criticism for his response to the virus. Meanwhile, other global news includes Vietnam reacting to a US tariff announcement, Malaysia seizing assets from Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth expected to slow.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide on the week as lockdowns dull recovery hopes
summary: European stocks ended the week with their sharpest declines since March, slipping 5% due to new coronavirus lockdowns and fears of a cut short economic recovery. Despite strong earnings from energy major Total and some Spanish banks, the Stoxx 600 index lost 0.2% on Friday. The European economy rebounded more strongly than expected, but restrictions in Spain, Germany, and France kept gains in check. The ECB is expected to ease policy in December to help the economy.

site_title: Busy agenda for Biden's first 100 days if elected president
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden has outlined a busy agenda for his first 100 days in office, focusing on battling the coronavirus pandemic, rejoining the Paris climate agreement, and implementing immigration reforms. Key priorities include implementing a nationwide mask mandate, boosting US medical equipment manufacturing, and making COVID-19 vaccines free to everyone. Biden also plans to invest in renewable energies, convene a climate summit, and reverse Trump's rollbacks of environmental regulations. Additionally, he aims to appoint a bipartisan national commission to study the judicial system, implement sweeping criminal justice reform, and provide a pathway to citizenship for over 11 million undocumented people.

site_title: Airport transfer startup Blacklane bets on intercity trips to revive Covid-hit business
summary: Blacklane, a German chauffeur service specializing in airport transfers, is adapting to the pandemic by offering intercity trips. The startup, which operates in over 300 cities in 50 countries, has seen revenue decline but is now rebounding, with sales between 30-50% of pre-crisis levels. Blacklane advertises its intercity rides as a safer and more comfortable alternative to train travel, with prices comparable to train tickets. The company aims to reach last year's revenue of around 100 million euros and is seeking fresh funding and a future stock market listing.

site_title: Keppel shares gain 5.4% on Q3 return to profitability
summary: Keppel Corp's shares gained 5.4% after the conglomerate reported a Q3 return to profitability, marking a significant turnaround from a net loss of S$697.6 million in the previous quarter. Analysts now focus on the offshore and marine business, which is under strategic review. Keppel's Vision 2030 roadmap is expected to be accelerated, with a 100-day plan to drive results across all segments, and potential rerating catalysts include a clearer roadmap and capital recycling.

site_title: STI tumbles 1.10% as investors remain spooked by lockdowns, US election uncertainty
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index tumbled 1.10% to 2,423.84, marking a five-day losing streak, amid renewed Covid-19 concerns, US election uncertainty, and risk-off sentiments. Regional bourses fell sharply, with Japan and China down 1.5%, Hong Kong down 2%, and Malaysia and Taiwan down 1.9% and 1%, respectively. US stocks rallied overnight, but volatility remains high, with the VIX fear gauge above 40, driven by a disputed election and stimulus impasse.

site_title: Philippine casino sees 'thrill' factor attracting Asian gamblers
summary: Philippine casino PH Resorts Group expects its $465 million Emerald Bay casino in central Philippines to break even within seven years. The casino is counting on a strong recovery in the local market and a gradual return of international high rollers. With a unique location and facilities comparable to Manila and Macau, the casino aims to surpass pre-pandemic gaming industry levels in 2022. Access to local players and international clients will be key to its success, with talks underway with junket operators in Asia.

site_title: Total cuts investment target, keeps dividend amid pandemic
summary: Total, a French oil and gas producer, trimmed its 2020 investment target to $13 billion, down from $14 billion, while maintaining its dividend amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company reported a 93% drop in third-quarter net profit to $202 million. Despite a rebound from a loss in the second quarter, Total's adjusted net income fell 72% to $848 million. The company cited uncertain market conditions and maintained a dividend of 0.66 euros per share.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 28.31 points lower at 1,466.89 on Friday, with 1,033 losers outweighing 202 gainers. The index saw a volume of 5.906 billion lots worth RM3.907 billion.

site_title: Nanofilm closes 12.4% up on trading debut
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a Singaporean company specializing in advanced materials and nanoproducts, made its trading debut on the mainboard, closing 12.4% above its IPO price of S$2.59, at S$2.91. The company raised S$470.1 million, with proceeds allocated to capital expenditure, research, and development. Its market capitalization is estimated at S$1.7 billion, based on its earnings per share. The IPO was oversubscribed, with cornerstone investors taking up more than 50% of the offering.

site_title: UK house prices accelerate again, but slowdown likely: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 5.8% in October, the largest annual increase in nearly six years, according to Nationwide. This is slightly faster than forecasted 5.2% and follows a 0.8% monthly increase. The housing market is expected to slow in the coming quarters due to a potential weakening labor market and the end of the stamp duty holiday in March. Despite this, demand for homes with more space continues to drive the market.

site_title: MAS bans two former UOB, OCBC employees for fraud, dishonest conduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders against two former bank employees, Lu Chor Sheng and Timothy Tan Swee Thiam, for fraud and dishonest conduct. Lu was convicted of abetting cheating and unauthorized system modification, causing OCBC a loss of S$3.1 million, while Tan was convicted of unauthorized Internet bank transfers, amounting to S$263,500. Both are prohibited from performing regulated activities for 17 and 9 years, respectively, and cannot engage in financial advisory services or hold directorships.

site_title: Air France-KLM slashes year-end capacity on pandemic surge
summary: Air France-KLM is slashing its year-end capacity by over 65% due to a resurgence of Covid-19, with Air France offering less than 35% of year-ago capacity. The carrier cites a failure of demand and the French government's lockdown measures as reasons for the drastic reduction. The airline expects "substantially lower" results than its third-quarter loss of 442 million euros and is working on a recapitalisation plan to raise new equity. Other European airlines, including British Airways and Deutsche Lufthansa, are also cutting back on schedules.

site_title: STI tumbles 1.1% to cap bruising week
summary: Singapore shares extended losses, capping a bruising week amid Covid-19 concerns, US election jitters, and lockdown fears. The Straits Times Index (STI) tumbled 1.1% to 2,423.84, logging a five-day losing streak. The key index has fallen nearly 114 points or 4.5% week on week, and 25% for the year. Only one STI constituent, Keppel Corp, rose 3% to S$4.39, while Nanofilm Technologies debuted with a 12.3% gain.

site_title: Wilmar Q3 net profit rises 20% to US$536.6m; proposes special dividend for successful YKA listing
summary: Wilmar International, a MAINBOARD-listed agri-business group, reported a 20% rise in net profit for the third fiscal quarter ended September to US$536.6 million. Core net profit reached US$501.4 million, a 19.6% increase, and was the group's highest third-quarter core net profit since its listing. Revenue rose 19.3% to US$13.32 billion, driven by strong demand for food products and higher crushing activities amid easing African Swine Fever in China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the week sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted at the end of a volatile week, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.95% to 24,107.42. This decline follows concerns over the economic recovery amid rising virus infections in Europe and the US. The Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 1.47%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange fell 2.29%. The declines are attributed to fears of economic recovery, with the US-EU trade talks and new Trump threats adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets declined on Friday, extending weekly losses, amid soaring coronavirus cases and tighter restrictions. The London FTSE 100 fell 0.7%, Paris CAC 40 dropped 0.9%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 1.2%. Investors are spooked by the fresh lockdowns and tighter restrictions, which are dragging on bank and healthcare stocks. The decline follows a recent rally and raises concerns about the impact of US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts' Q3 NPI shrinks 57.4%
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts' Q3 net property income (NPI) decreased 57.4% to S$15.2 million due to low occupancies and the absence of rental income from Novotel Singapore Clarke Quay. Despite this, the group saw a rebound in performance compared to the second quarter, with gross revenue rising 58.2% and NPI growing 49.4% on a quarter-on-quarter basis. Occupancies improved in Singapore, with an average of 92.4% occupied, driven by staycation business and travel bubbles. Average daily rates fell 61.5% due to the pandemic, resulting in lower overall income contributions.

site_title: Norway wealth fund says it's hard to find right green energy projects
summary: Norway's US$1.1 trillion sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, is struggling to find suitable unlisted renewable energy projects to invest in due to limited availability and strong competition. The fund's new CEO, Nicolai Tangen, stated that investing in these projects poses similar risk and return requirements as existing investments, but finding projects meeting these requirements may be challenging. Despite this, the fund remains committed to investing in North America and Europe, with a focus on wind parks and solar farms.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Robinsons Singapore, a 162-year-old retailer, will close down due to losses. Bank lending in Singapore declined for the seventh consecutive session in September. Total employment contracted at a slower pace in Q3, with resident employment near pre-pandemic levels. Firms expect business conditions to worsen from October to March, but the gap between pessimists and optimists is narrowing. Nanofilm debuted on the SGX mainboard at a 7.7% premium to its IPO price. Ride-hailing firms Grab, Gojek, TADA, and ComfortDelGro received operating licences from the LTA. The STI fell 1.10% due to investor concerns over lockdowns and the US election.

site_title: Fleet size at biggest A320neo customer IndiGo will shrink for two years
summary: IndiGo, Asia's largest budget airline, will reduce its fleet size for two years due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on air travel. The airline's CEO, Ronojoy Dutta, stated that its fleet count will remain stagnant and decrease slightly in 2022 before increasing in 2023. IndiGo plans to return 40 older jets per year, including 117 A320 models, which will be replaced by newer A320neo jets. This move is part of the airline's strategy to maintain a younger fleet with lower fuel consumption.

site_title: Singapore's Q3 total employment contraction slows, but retrenchments continue: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment contracted by 26,900 in Q3 2020, slowing down from the previous quarter, with resident employment rebounding to near pre-pandemic levels. Retrenchments rose to 9,100, exceeding the peak of previous recessions. Unemployment rates continued to rise, with overall unemployment at 3.6% and resident unemployment at 4.7%. Despite a rebound in resident employment, non-resident employment continued to decline, and the government warns that the recovery may not be sustainable without continued efforts.

site_title: Glencore trims coal guidance as strike continues at Colombia mine
summary: Glencore trimmed its 2020 coal production guidance to 109 million tonnes, a 5.7% decrease, due to a 60-day strike at the Cerrejon mine in Colombia. The strike, involving the largest union, has seen significant progress in negotiations. Glencore's year-to-date coal production stands at 83.5 million tonnes, 20% lower than the same period last year.

site_title: Jem, Westgate, ICA and Mustafa among places visited by Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by Covid-19 patients while they were infectious, including Jem, Westgate, Mustafa Centre, and the ICA building. The list is available on Gov.sg, and close contacts have been notified. Nine new cases were confirmed, bringing Singapore's total to 58,003, with one asymptomatic community case and seven imported cases. The average number of new daily cases in the community has increased, with 10 cases discharged and 57,894 patients fully recovered.

site_title: Singapore firms pessimistic about next six months, but less than before: surveys
summary: Singapore firms expect business conditions to worsen from October to next March, with a net-weighted balance of 5% in the services sector and 3% in manufacturing. However, the gap between pessimists and optimists has narrowed compared to previous surveys. The electronics cluster is the most pessimistic, while the precision engineering and miscellaneous industries segments are more optimistic. Most firms expect employment levels to remain similar, but overall, they expect to hire fewer workers.

site_title: Gold firms as US dollar dips, coronavirus concerns grow
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,875.76 per ounce, tracking a weaker US dollar amid growing coronavirus concerns and uncertainty over the US presidential election. The dollar index fell 0.2% against a basket of currencies, making bullion cheaper for holders of other currencies. Despite a third consecutive month of declines, gold remains up nearly 24% this year due to unprecedented stimulus measures boosting its appeal as a hedge against inflation and currency debasement.

site_title: Toyota to invest 52.2b yen in KDDI to deepen ties for 'connected car'
summary: Toyota Motor is investing 52.2 billion yen (S$682.3 million) in KDDI to deepen their partnership in the "connected car" era. This investment will boost Toyota's stake to 13.74% as part of a new business alliance focused on research and development of telecommunication platforms connecting cars, homes, and users. The partnership aims to counter competition from tech giants like Tencent, Alphabet, and Samsung Electronics in the auto industry.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor and KDDI said on Friday that Japan's biggest automaker would invest 52.2 billion yen (S$682.3 million) in the mobile carrier to deepen their partnership in the age of the "connected car".

site_title: Berlin's US$7b airport finally opens in the depths of a crisis
summary: Berlin's long-awaited $7 billion airport, the Berlin Brandenburg Willy Brandt Airport, finally opens on Saturday, eight years after its planned launch in 2012. The airport's soft opening comes as the coronavirus hammers travel demand, with a second terminal on hold due to the crisis. Despite construction delays and cost overruns, the facility is designed to handle 40 million passengers a year and features a modern interior, shops, and restaurants. The opening marks a new beginning for the airport, which has been plagued by defects and delays, and is seen as a signal for a new awakening for the city.

site_title: Chinese fintech raises US$2.4b ahead of US listing
summary: Chinese fintech firm Lufax raised US$2.4 billion ahead of its Wall Street debut, one of the best US IPOs by a Chinese company this year. The listing comes as tensions between Beijing and Washington continue, with other Chinese firms turning to Hong Kong and China to raise cash due to US market volatility. Lufax's listing is set to precede Ant Group's world record IPO, also taking place in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

site_title: Julius Baer plans wealth management joint venture in China: sources
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer plans to establish a majority-owned joint venture in China with a local financial firm, aiming to tap the rapidly growing wealth in the world's second-largest economy. The plan comes as China opens its financial sector to bigger foreign participation. The joint venture is part of Julius Baer's strategy to boost growth in Asia.

site_title: US firms giving perks to get workers back to their offices
summary: US companies are offering various perks to encourage employees to return to their offices, despite the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Companies like SL Green, JPMorgan Chase, and L'Oréal have implemented measures such as paid commuting costs, expanded childcare offerings, and free lunch to bring employees back to the office. However, many employees remain at home, with around 85% of office workers still working remotely, according to recent real estate executives and a survey of large business owners. The return to the office has been slower in New York City compared to other major cities like Dallas and Los Angeles.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday due to profit-taking among shares with sound earnings, amid lingering concerns over the global coronavirus pandemic. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.52% to 22,977.13, while the Topix index dropped 1.96% to 1,579.33. This move comes as investors weigh the impact of the US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic on the market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, extending a four-day losing streak, despite a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.21% to 24,535.90, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.18% to 3,278.63. Investors brushed off rising virus cases in key economies and new US threats to extend stocks rally. The slump is attributed to concerns over the ongoing pandemic and its impact on global markets.

site_title: Robinsons Singapore throws in the towel after 162 years
summary: Robinsons Singapore, a 162-year-old retailer, has closed down due to significant losses in recent years. The company's senior general manager attributed the decline to the changing consumer landscape and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite efforts to adapt, Robinsons was unable to sustain operations and has been put under a creditors' voluntary winding-up. The company's employees will be paid in line with the next payment cycle, and liquidators will work with unions and government schemes to support them.

images.alt_text: The exit puts an end to the at least six years of losses that Robinsons has chalked up against declining revenues.

site_title: Brooklyn Museum reaps US$19.9m from Sotheby's art sale
summary: The Brooklyn Museum sold a collection of artworks for $19.9 million at a Sotheby's auction, with a mid-century dining table and a Claude Monet landscape leading the sales. The sale also featured a monumental abstract painting by Helen Frankenthaler that surpassed estimates, selling for $4.7 million. The museum is seeking to raise $45 million to create a fund to care for its collection, and has already sold $6.8 million worth of art at Christie's. The sale comes as the pandemic has disrupted traditional auction formats, with live auctions giving way to live-streaming spectacles.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest weekly drop in six months on mixed cues
summary: Australian shares ended 0.6% lower on Friday, posting their worst week since April, due to concerns over fresh lockdowns and the US presidential election. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 3.9% for the week, with tech stocks tumbling 2% and healthcare stocks declining 1.2%. Financial stocks bucked the trend, rising 0.4% after AMP's 19.5% surge. Global coronavirus cases rose over 500,000, and the US election outcome and potential stimulus delay remain market focus.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post sharpest monthly fall since March on virus, US election worries
summary: South Korean shares plummeted 2.56% on Friday, marking their sharpest monthly decline in seven months due to concerns over the US presidential election and rising coronavirus cases globally. The Kospi index dropped 59.52 points to 2,267.15, its lowest closing point since March. Global coronavirus cases surged over 500,000 for the first time, while France and Germany implemented fresh lockdowns. The monthly decline is the sharpest since March, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Autohome unveils takeover proposal for iCar Asia at A$0.50 per share
summary: Autohome Inc has proposed a takeover of iCar Asia at A$0.50 per share, worth approximately A$215.7 million, with the deal subject to negotiations, regulatory approvals, and shareholder consent. The acquisition could take the company private and is contingent on the approval of iCar Asia's largest shareholder, Catcha Group. iCar Asia's shares jumped 31.8% following the announcement, and the company reported a widening net loss of A$6.1 million in the first half of 2020.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant IPO lures US$3t of bids in retail frenzy
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Group has received record-breaking bids of at least $3 trillion from individual investors in Hong Kong and Shanghai, exceeding the initial supply by more than 870 times. The IPO, valued at $35 billion, is the largest of all time and has fueled predictions of a first-day pop. Retail investors, including big-name money managers, have driven demand, with institutions and strategic investors expected to take up about 96-97.5% of the offering. Despite concerns over valuations and risks, some investors believe Ant can rise 30-40% on its first day.

images.alt_text: The biggest initial public offering of all time has unleashed an investor frenzy for the record books.

site_title: Online education startup Udemy in talks to raise US$100m in funding: sources
summary: Online learning platform Udemy is in talks to raise US$100 million in funding, valuing the company at over US$3 billion. This comes after a 425% spike in enrollments for individuals between February and March, driven by the COVID-19 pandemic. The new funding round follows a US$50 million Series E round in February, and private funding in the edtech sector has surpassed 2019 levels. Udemy's corporate learning service, Udemy for Business, has achieved US$100 million annual recurring revenue, with notable customers including PayPal, Apple, and Unilever.

site_title: Mistry seeks US$24b of shares in Tata firms to sever ties
summary: Billionaire Pallonji Mistry is seeking to swap his US$24 billion stake in the Tata Group for shares in listed companies, including Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), in a bid to sever ties with the conglomerate. The offer, made to the Supreme Court, would ease pressure on Tata to raise debt and eliminate valuation disputes. The proposal comes after a four-year-old dispute over Mistry's removal as chairman in 2016. The Tata Group has declined to comment on the offer, which could lead to a pro-rata split of listed assets and a reduction in their stake in TCS.

site_title: Volvo-backed Polestar in talks to raise US$500m
summary: Polestar, an electric car maker backed by Volvo and Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, is in talks to raise at least $500 million, seeking a valuation of $6 billion. The automaker aims to fund further production and expand its operations. Polestar's sales have been soaring in Europe and recovering in China, making it a potential rival to Tesla. The funding round has not been finalized, and terms could still change, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Starbucks sees hotter-than-expected earnings for 2021
summary: Starbucks reported hotter-than-expected earnings for 2021, with adjusted profit per share between $2.70 and $2.90. The company attributed the recovery to strong online orders and a rebound in demand following the Covid-19 pandemic. Comparable sales rose 18-23% globally, including a 27-32% growth in China. However, the company's recovery is lagging behind other restaurant chains, and it plans to open 1,100 new locations globally in 2021, down from 1,400 this year.

site_title: LG Chem shareholders approve plan to split off battery business: source
summary: LG Chem shareholders have approved a plan to split off its battery business into a new company. Over 82% of shareholders voted in favor of the proposal, paving the way for the battery business to potentially raise funds and go public to finance its high-cost capacity expansion. The move is expected to allow the business to potentially increase its capital and expand its capacity.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares fall at Friday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.2 points or 0.8% to 1,484 at 9:35am on Friday, with 533 losers outnumbering 158 gainers. Trading volume reached 1.05 billion lots worth RM535.8 million.

site_title: Facebook anticipates tougher 2021 even as pandemic boosts ad revenue
summary: Facebook reported a 22% increase in quarterly revenue to $21.47 billion, beating analyst estimates, despite facing "significant uncertainty" due to impending Apple privacy changes and a possible reversal in pandemic-driven online commerce. The company's user base grew to 2.74 billion monthly active users, but user numbers declined in North America. Total expenses rose 28% to $13.43 billion, leading to a margin decline. Despite concerns over content moderation, Facebook remains a go-to platform for advertisers, but its reliance on the platform may be reevaluated in 2021.

site_title: Chatterbox: A Singapore dining icon
summary: Chatterbox, a Singapore dining icon since the 1970s, continues to draw food lovers with its signature chicken rice and local fare. Fifty years after its introduction, the restaurant has retained its appeal with updates to its menu, including lobster laksa and king prawns in fried Hokkien noodles. Chatterbox has received numerous awards, including the Singapore Prestige Brand Award and TripAdvisor Travellers' Choice Winner. Master chef Liew Tian Heong has been instrumental in maintaining the restaurant's legacy, adding new dishes and protecting its DNA as the 'home' of Singapore food.

site_title: Bank lending in Sept down for seventh straight session: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending declined for the seventh consecutive session in September, falling 0.3% to S$421.28 billion, primarily due to weaker business loans. Loans to financial institutions also dropped 1.9% to S$99.38 billion. This marks the second straight month of decline in this sector.

site_title: Shaw Tower redevelopment works to commence later this year
summary: Shaw Tower redevelopment works are set to commence later this year, with a planned completion date of 2024. The integrated development will feature 450,000 square feet of Grade A office space, retail, and F&B offerings. Designed to meet sustainable building standards, the new Shaw Tower will include lifestyle amenities, indoor community facilities, and end-of-trip cycling facilities. The project is aimed at revitalizing the Ophir-Rochor precinct, aligning with the Urban Redevelopment Authority's vision. Lendlease, appointed by The Sir Run Run Shaw Charitable Trust, will manage the redevelopment.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel rises 5.4% on return to profitability
summary: Keppel Corp's share price rose 5.4% on Friday after the conglomerate reported a return to profitability for the July-September period, with a net profit of S$697.6 million compared to a S$697.6 million net loss in the previous quarter. The company's offshore and marine (O&M) business is under strategic review, with analysts predicting a potential rerating catalyst if the review concludes by the end of the year. Keppel has embarked on a recovery path, with improving property sales and picking up O&M activity, and analysts expect the group to unlock S$3-5 billion from identified assets over the next three years.

site_title: BP to shut Australian oil refinery, switch to fuel import terminal
summary: BP plans to shut its Kwinana oil refinery in Western Australia and convert it into a fuel import terminal due to tough competition in the Asian market. The move affects 650 jobs and is expected to take six months to complete. Despite government incentives to keep the plant open, regional oversupply and low refining margins make the operation economically unviable. This decision follows similar moves by domestic rivals Viva Energy and Ampol, with BP also considering developing the site as a clean energy hub to produce lower carbon fuels.

images.alt_text: BP plans to stop producing fuel in Australia and will convert its Kwinana oil refinery, the biggest of the country's four, into a fuel import terminal, thanks to tough competition in the Asian market, the global major said on Friday.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% on Friday, with 160.7 million securities worth S$343.6 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 71 to 63, with Nanofilm, Singtel, and Sembcorp Marine being among the heavily traded counters. Banking stocks declined, with DBS and UOB down 0.6% and 0.4%, respectively. The decline followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Canada judge sides with Huawei CFO on some claims
summary: A Canadian judge has ruled that parts of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou's arguments against extradition to the US can proceed, siding with her on claims that the US misrepresented evidence. The judge agreed that Meng's arguments have an "air of reality" and that she is entitled to introduce some additional evidence in the case record. However, the judge also noted that Meng's arguments are not strong enough to warrant immediate dismissal of the case. The extradition hearings are scheduled to wrap up in April 2021.

site_title: Apple's late iPhone launch temporarily wiped US$100b off its stock value
summary: Apple reported its lowest quarterly iPhone sales in two years, with a 20.7% drop to $26.4 billion, due to a delayed launch of new 5G phones. The company's stock value dropped $100 billion in after-hours trade, despite strong sales of Macs and AirPods. CEO Tim Cook expressed optimism about the iPhone 12 cycle, citing early sales data and the potential for 5G to boost sales in China. Analysts expect iPhone revenue to rise 6.45% in the first quarter, but warn that the 5G upgrade cycle may be disappointing.

images.alt_text: The late launch of new 5G phones caused Apple's customers to put off buying new devices, leading the company on Thursday to report the steepest quarterly drop in iPhone sales in two years.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust to pay clean-up distribution of 2.56 S cents on Nov 19
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) will pay a clean-up distribution of 2.56 Singapore cents per unit on Nov 19 for the July 1 to Oct 20 period. The distribution includes 2 cents for July-Sept and 0.56 cents for Oct 1-20. Unitholders must return forms by Nov 2 to receive the distribution. CCT will be delisted on Nov 3 as part of its merger with CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT), which will be renamed on the same day.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit bags three large leases in France, Poland and Denmark
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has secured three large leases totaling 25,000 square meters of office and light industrial/logistics space in France, Poland, and Denmark. The leases include a 15,444 sq m light industrial/logistics space in France, a renewal in Poland, and a new lease in Denmark, with the largest space leased to a major postal service and logistics company largely owned by the French government.

site_title: CDLHT third-quarter revenue drops 38.7% to S$30.1m
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 38.7% year-on-year decline in total revenue to S$30.1 million for its third quarter, with net property income (NPI) decreasing 57.4% to S$15.2 million. Despite this, the group saw a rebound in performance compared to the second quarter, with gross revenue rising 58.2% and NPI growing 49.4%. The Singapore portfolio achieved an average occupancy rate of 92.4%, while the average daily rate fell 61.5% due to the impact of border closures and postponed events.

site_title: ESR-Reit posts 20.2% drop in Q3 DPU to 0.798 S cent
summary: ESR-Reit reported a 20.2% drop in Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.798 Singapore cent, down from 1 cent a year ago. Gross revenue fell 8.2% to S$56.9 million and net property income (NPI) declined 10.8% to S$40.4 million, mainly due to lease conversions, non-renewals, and rental rebates. The company released S$3.5 million in retained distribution, reflecting the resilience of its portfolio. The Reit's capital structure remains balanced, with a well-staggered debt expiry profile and strong banking support.

site_title: Apple's Asian suppliers slip as market awaits iPhone 12 boost
summary: Apple's Asian suppliers saw their shares drop after the company reported iPhone sales that missed analyst estimates and revenue in China slumped. The iPhone 12 line, launched earlier this month, received a "tremendously positive" response from customers, according to CEO Tim Cook. Shares of Lens Technology, Alps Alpine, Flexium Interconnect, and ASM Pacific Technology fell 6.2%, 5%, 4.1%, and 3.6%, respectively, in the days following the announcement. The decline was attributed to anticipation of the new iPhone models, which arrived later than usual this year.

site_title: Sabana Reit renews 58% of leases expiring in 2020
summary: Sabana Reit renewed 58% of leases expiring in 2020, with 586,043 sq ft of renewals, and signed 304,622 sq ft of new leases in Q3 2020. Portfolio occupancy rose to 80.2% from 77.3% in June 2020. The Reit expects rental contributions from its New Tech Park asset enhancement initiative to start in Q2 2021, with more than half of retail units leased. The company will pass government rental reliefs to tenants by Q4 2020 and assess additional relief.

site_title: Singapore's Accounting Standards Council to get new chairman and member
summary: Singapore's Accounting Standards Council (ASC) has appointed Quek See Tiat as its new chairman, effective November 1, replacing Kevin Kwok. Desmond Chin will join the council as a new member. The appointments were made by the Minister for Finance.

site_title: MSCI launches climate indices so investors can align with Paris Agreement
summary: MSCI has launched eight climate indices to help investors minimize exposure to climate risks and identify green opportunities, aligning with the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C global warming target. The indices incorporate data on greenhouse emissions and green revenues, and are weighted to reduce average carbon intensity and maximize exposure to clean-technology solutions. The move aims to support the decarbonization of the economy and reduce portfolio risks from a transition to a greener economy.

site_title: Xiaomi grabs smartphone marketshare in Q3 as Huawei wobbles: data
summary: Xiaomi surpassed Huawei in the global smartphone market share in Q3, driven by a 45% surge in sales to 47.1 million units. Despite the growth, the global smartphone market contracted 1% year-on-year. Samsung regained the top spot, while Apple took the fourth position. Huawei's dominance slipped due to US sanctions, and its shipments slumped by a quarter in Europe. Xiaomi's success was attributed to its high production targets and ability to fill channels with high-volume devices, such as the Redmi 9 series.

images.alt_text: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi grabbed market share in China and Europe in the September quarter as rival Huawei Technologies' dominance slipped due to US sanctions, market data showed.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article content provided for the "The smart car buying guide" to summarize.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower in cautious trade
