summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.2% at 23,276.31, due to cautious trade amid US presidential election uncertainty and economic stimulus. Investors are watching earnings reports and the dollar fetched 104.56 yen. Japan's unemployment rate stood at 3%, beating market expectations. On Wall Street, the Dow ended 0.5% higher at 26,659.11.

site_title: Nanofilm debuts on SGX mainboard at 7.7% above IPO price
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a spin-off company from Nanyang Technological University, made its mainboard debut on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) at S$2.79, 7.7% above its IPO price of S$2.59 per share. The company specializes in advanced materials and nanoproducts, with a market capitalization of approximately S$1.7 billion. The IPO raised S$470.1 million, with 57.4 million shares changing hands during early trading, and 104.3 million shares subscribed by cornerstone investors.

site_title: Oil at lowest in months as new virus cases hurt recovery hopes
summary: Oil futures fell to multi-month lows, with US crude prices reaching their lowest since June, amid record growth in coronavirus cases in the US and Europe, raising concerns of tighter lockdown measures and demand destruction. Despite a record surge in US economic growth, prices settled above session lows, and European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde signaled new monetary stimulus. The demand outlook remains bleak, with European nations imposing month-long movement restrictions and a US stimulus boost unlikely before the election.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust's net property income falls 36.4% for Q3
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust's (FEHT) net property income (NPI) fell 36.4% to S$17.9 million for Q3, down from S$28.7 million in the same period last year. Gross revenue decreased 33.2% to S$20.6 million, primarily due to a decline in master lease rental from hotels amid the Covid-19 outbreak. Despite this, the trust's portfolio occupancy improved to 97.3% and serviced residences performed better, with average daily rates (ADR) at S$69 and revenue per available room (RevPAR) at S$67.

site_title: Ascott Residence Trust sees long stays, domestic markets leading recovery
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported a 27% increase in portfolio revenue per available unit (RevPAU) to S$47 in the July-September period, despite a 70% year-on-year decline. Long-stay properties and domestic markets, particularly China and Singapore, drove the recovery. Occupancy rates improved to 40% in the third quarter, up from 30% in the second quarter. ART has sufficient liquidity to cover two years of fixed costs and has received "healthy enquiries for long stays" and strong demand for leisure travel.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi kicks off advance voting for elderly in Myanmar election
summary: Myanmar's civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi cast her ballot ahead of the Nov 8 general election, marking the first in the country to vote on Thursday. Thousands of elderly voters, including 73-year-old Kyaw Goke, took advantage of advance voting to reduce the risk of COVID-19. The NLD is widely expected to return to power, but experts warn that the election's credibility is compromised due to logistical issues and alleged discrimination.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Nanofilm, Sheng Siong, ESR-Reit, Japfa, ART
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singapore-listed companies saw new developments on Friday, affecting their trading. Keppel Corp posted record losses in the third quarter but revenue reached S$4.82 billion for the first nine months. Nanofilm Technologies made its Singapore public debut, with retail investors applying for 30.6 times the available shares. Sheng Siong Group's net profit rose 54.4% to S$31.8 million, while Japfa's net profit jumped to US$130 million. ESR-Reit's distribution per unit fell 20.2%, and Japfa shares rose 0.8%. Other stapled securities, such as Ascott Residence Trust and Far East Hospitality Trust, also reported significant changes.

site_title: Nanofilm's IPO 30.6 times subscribed
summary: Nanofilm Technologies' initial public offering (IPO) received 30.6 times more applications than available shares in the public portion, with over 8,000 applications for 118 million shares. The international placement attracted indications of interest for over 1.7 billion shares, approximately 22.9 times subscribed. The company specializes in advanced materials and nanoproducts.

site_title: Times are bad, putt golf membership prices are teeing off
summary: Golf club membership prices in Singapore have surged by an average 13% since March, with some clubs experiencing 30% increases. This is attributed to high demand from island-bound enthusiasts and the appeal of golf's social distancing benefits. The rich have been able to weather the pandemic's economic impact, allowing them to maintain their luxury lifestyle and invest in golf memberships. The trend is also seen as a sign of confidence among those who can afford to ride out the crisis, with many having diversified investments and a stable financial foundation.

images.alt_text: Travel curbs coupled with a greater demand for golf flight times have driven up golf club membership prices, some by 30 per cent or more since the "circuit breaker" began in March.

site_title: Europe: Stocks erase gains as ECB warns growth is losing steam
summary: European stocks erased earlier gains, closing little changed, after the European Central Bank chief warned that European economies are losing momentum more quickly than expected due to new Covid-19 lockdowns. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropped 0.1% in London, following a five-month low. Nokia plunged 18% after lowering its 2020 outlook. The warning comes as new restrictions in France and Germany threaten the recovery.

site_title: 'Efficiency through scale' now seems outmoded. Here's what to do about it
summary: The traditional "efficiency through scale" approach to global businesses is being challenged by the complexities of the Covid-19 pandemic and evolving local regulations. Large organisations are struggling to balance global complexity with local agility, and the key to success lies in empowering those at the edges to take ownership and responsibility. This shift in approach is crucial for organisations' viability in today's complex business landscape, where local autonomy is increasingly important. By giving autonomy to those closest to customers and partners, businesses can thrive in uncertain times.

site_title: US: Wall Street rebounds as market eyes tech results, strong economic data
summary: US stocks rebounded on Thursday, with technology heavyweights rallying ahead of major earnings reports and upbeat domestic economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.5% higher, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 1.2% and 1.6% respectively. Strong results from tech companies such as Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, and Facebook, as well as positive earnings surprises, fueled the rally. The US economy grew at a record pace in the third quarter, but concerns about the pandemic's impact on the fourth quarter persisted.

site_title: NUHS, ARIA to launch S$50m fund for medtech startups
summary: National University Health System (NUHS) and Asia Research & Innovation Alliance Limited (ARIA) have launched a S$50 million venture capital fund to invest in medtech startups. The fund, managed by Shenton Ventures and ICH Capital, will focus on software-as-a-service and digital healthcare platforms, telehealth, and digital therapeutics. It aims to deploy up to 20% of its capital to seed-stage startups and 40% to Series A investments, with a target internal rate of return of 20%. The fund will be operational for 5-7 years and aims to help Singapore's medtech startups gain market entry to healthcare sectors in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Style tips for the sartorially clueless
summary: Tan France's new Masterclass.com course, "Style For Everyone," offers a clear and helpful guide to creating a personal style for those with little knowledge of fashion. The 12-lesson course, taught by the Queer Eye host, starts with basic colors and builds a capsule wardrobe of essential pieces, including easy-to-wear shirts, trousers, and footwear. France provides practical tips, such as choosing colors that fit well and experimenting with oversized pieces, to create a stylish look. The course is praised for its accessibility and helpfulness, making it a valuable resource for those looking to improve their fashion sense.

site_title: Will adapting to Covid-19 change urban life for good?
summary: A second coronavirus wave is hitting cities worldwide, prompting urban dwellers to adapt to a new normal. From home to office, parks to pubs, cities are undergoing a reboot with increased parkland, cycle lanes, and redesigned flats for remote working. Researchers warn that the pandemic has exacerbated existing economic and social divides, with rising unemployment and inequalities. Cities are also repurposing vacant spaces into makeshift shelters, and businesses are exploiting technology to promote local life, such as apps for remote working and immunity passports. Many changes are expected to be permanent, helping cities plan for future shocks like climate change and economic downturns.

site_title: Samsung Electronics expects profit to decline in Q4
summary: Samsung Electronics expects its fourth-quarter profit to decline due to weak server chip demand and rising smartphone competition. The company's mobile chip demand is forecast to rise in Q4, driven by Chinese customers boosting orders following US restrictions on Huawei. However, server chip demand remains weak due to large customer inventories. Despite this, Samsung's operating profit jumped 59% in the third quarter, driven by its highest quarterly smartphone profit since 2014. The company expects smartphone shipments to drop 5% in the current quarter due to competition from Apple's iPhone 12.

site_title: Mapletree to hire up to 30 fresh grads for work-study traineeship
summary: Mapletree Investments has launched a 12-month work-study programme to employ up to 30 trainees from local universities, providing full funding to support fresh graduates struggling to find employment in Singapore amid the pandemic.

site_title: Keppel Corp turns corner in Q3 from record Q2 losses
summary: Keppel Corp reported a sequential improvement in Q3, turning a corner after record losses in Q2. Despite a significant year-over-year decline in net profit, all key business units except Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) generated profits. Keppel O&M remained the firm's weakest spot due to the ongoing pandemic's impact on energy demand and oil prices.

site_title: US growth in Q3 highest in decades
summary: The US economy experienced its highest growth rate in decades, with a 33.1% annualized GDP rebound in the third quarter, fueled by over $3 trillion in pandemic relief measures. However, output remains below pre-pandemic levels, and the growth spurt is fading. Layoffs persist, with only half of the 22.2 million jobs lost during the pandemic recouped. New COVID-19 cases are rising, and government funding for relief measures is depleted.

site_title: Singapore shares slide after Dow's 900-point overnight dive
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.3% to 2,450.68, marking its fourth consecutive day of losses, as investors reacted to a rise in coronavirus cases and looming lockdowns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 3.4%, while regional markets, such as the Hang Seng Index and Nikkei 225, also closed lower. Only six stocks out of 30 ended the day in the black, with glove makers experiencing gains. The sell-off was attributed to a disquieting rise in coronavirus infections and renewed threats of lockdowns.

site_title: GIC unit to acquire 33 retail logistics assets in Germany
summary: GIC's wholly-owned unit, P3 Logistic Parks, has agreed to acquire 33 retail logistics assets in prime urban locations across Germany, spanning over 650,000 square meters of space. The deal, valued but undisclosed, is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2020 and will strengthen P3's presence in Europe's logistics market. The acquisition comes after P3 doubled its portfolio in Germany in the last year, and it is one of the largest real-estate investment deals in Europe this year.

site_title: Shell increases dividend after beating Q3 forecasts
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has increased its dividend after beating third-quarter profit forecasts, despite warning of "significant uncertainty" due to the pandemic. The company's adjusted earnings fell 80% to US$955 million, but exceeded analyst forecasts. Shell's marketing division saw a 10% increase in earnings, while the company wrote down the value of its LNG portfolio by US$1 billion. The move is seen as a sign of renewed confidence, with Shell planning a major restructuring to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2050.

site_title: US dollar stabilises, riskier currencies remain subdued
summary: The US dollar stabilised slightly, rising 0.1% against a basket of currencies, while riskier currencies, such as the euro and Australian dollar, remained subdued. Markets are cautious due to Europe's second wave of coronavirus infections and the European Central Bank's upcoming meeting. The ECB is expected to hold off on new stimulus measures but may signal more action in December.

site_title: Colonial charm and classic Chinese cuisine
summary: Chef Wong, a former protege of Chef Chan Hei, has opened a pop-up restaurant in a colonial bungalow in Scotts Road, Singapore, serving classic Cantonese dishes. The restaurant, called Chef Chan's, offers a customized menu priced from S$128 per person, featuring dishes such as crispy roast chicken, suckling pig skin, and Swatow-style deep-fried tofu. The food is prepared by Chef Wong, who is the only chef in the kitchen, and served in private dining rooms with a retro charm. The restaurant's quality is promising, but Chef Wong needs to assert his own identity to stand out from his predecessor's legacy.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: A Virtual Voyage Through Masterpieces is a highlight of the vOilah! France Singapore Festival, presented by the Embassy of France in Singapore, featuring offline and online events. The event allows visitors to view French masterpieces, including Monet's water lilies painting, using VR goggles, and travel back in time to meet the artists. This is part of the festival's line-up, which covers culture, education, science, and lifestyle events.

site_title: SoftBank attempted to delay WeWork's US$3b share purchase: US court filing
summary: SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son allegedly told WeWork's executive chairman Marcelo Claure to "use whatever excuse" to delay a US$3 billion payout to WeWork's shareholders, including founder Adam Neumann. The delay was part of SoftBank's decision not to complete the tender offer due to various reasons, including US investigations and the pandemic. A court filing revealed the text exchange between Son and Claure, where Son expressed willingness to postpone the payment. SoftBank maintains that it had no obligation to complete the tender offer under the terms of their agreement.

images.alt_text: Mr Son (above) told Marcelo Claure, WeWork's executive chairman, to "use whatever excuse" to delay the payout.

site_title: Corporate Digest
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singapore supermarket operator, reported a 54.4% increase in net profit to S$31.8 million for its third quarter, driven by strong revenue growth of 28.9% to S$327.3 million. Japfa, an industrial agri-food company, saw its net profit jump five-fold to US$130 million for the first nine months, driven by strong momentum from its China dairy unit and swine business in Vietnam.

site_title: Singapore businesses must pay attention to ESG
summary: Singapore businesses must prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns to mitigate litigation and regulatory risks. The Singapore Exchange's "comply or explain" regime and upcoming plans to make ESG reporting more consistent are increasing scrutiny on companies. With Goldman Sachs' $750 billion commitment to sustainable finance and global ESG investments totaling $30 trillion, Singapore regulators are expected to enforce rigorous ESG reporting and disclosures. Companies must diagnose their structures, cultures, and practices to mitigate these risks and ensure long-term sustainability.

site_title: Singapore reopens to China and Australia visitors from Nov 6
summary: Singapore will fully reopen to visitors from mainland China and Australia starting November 6, marking a significant step in reviving tourism. However, tour operators emphasize the need for reciprocity and more details on testing regimes to fully revive local tourism. The move is seen as a positive development for the country's biggest sources of arrivals last year.

images.alt_text: From Nov 6, Singapore will fully reopen to visitors from mainland China and Australia, two of its biggest sources of arrivals last year.

site_title: StanChart beats profit estimates as loan losses ease
summary: Standard Chartered reported adjusted pretax profit of $745 million in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates of $502 million. Loan losses eased, with credit impairments at $353 million, and earnings from investment banking operations surged. The bank cited ample capital headroom to fund growth and dividends in 2021, and plans to resume paying dividends pending UK regulator approval. The company's financial markets unit reported a 4% gain in operating income, with businesses in China and Asia holding steady, while profits declined in Africa, Europe, and the Americas.

images.alt_text: The banks's adjusted pretax profit slid 40 per cent in the third quarter to US$745 million.

site_title: Holidaying without your passport
summary: Trafalgar has launched a 2-day, 1-night guided staycation series, "Near Not Far," exploring Singapore's heritage precinct, including Victoria Theatre, Victoria Concert Hall, and The Arts House. Led by blogger Jerome Lim, the tour offers a unique perspective on the city's history and landmarks. Visitors can climb the 54-meter clock tower of Victoria Theatre, learn about the national anthem's origins, and explore the Malay Heritage Centre and Kampong Glam. The tour concludes with dinner at Violet Oon's National Kitchen and accommodations at Parkroyal or Kempinski. The staycation series makes local heritage more alive and kicking, reinventing the concept of a traditional history tour.

images.alt_text: Trafalgar's staycation tour lets you climb to the top of the clock tower of Victoria Theatre and Victoria Concert Hall, as well as explore the theatres when they are empty.

site_title: DBS sees shades of 'green premium' in Asian project bonds
summary: DBS sees a resurgence in demand for project bonds in Asia, driven by the growing awareness of sustainability and the need for infrastructure financing. The bank has been making inroads in the Asian project bond space, with its latest deal, a $1.1 billion dual-tranche green project bond for Indonesia's Star Energy Geothermal, seeing demand of $2.8 billion from investors globally. The deal's "green premium" helped tighten funding costs and lifted credit ratings to investment-grade, paving the way for more green project bonds in the region.

site_title: Umno held meeting to decide on deputy PM nominee: sources
summary: Malaysia's Umno party held a meeting on Thursday to discuss who should be nominated for deputy prime minister in the Perikatan Nasional (PN) government. The meeting, chaired by Umno president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, was attended by all Supreme Council members. The decision comes after a "commotion" between Umno and Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia (Bersatu) ministers during a Cabinet meeting on Wednesday. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is under pressure to name a new deputy prime minister ahead of the 2021 budget on November 6, amid calls for his resignation and infighting within Umno.

site_title: Local jewellers lament cost, margin pressures
summary: Singaporean jewellers face financial pressure due to higher precious metal prices, reduced consumer spending, and border restrictions. Sales have declined by 20% since the Covid-19 pandemic restrictions on event sizes, with retailers hoping for "slight increases" in sales during festive seasons. To cope, local listed company Aspial Corporation is streamlining operations to achieve higher productivity, while smaller retailers like The Jewel Box are adjusting production costs and improving digital presence to maintain margins. Despite weak demand, some customers are seeking higher-priced items for gifting, driving demand for gold.

site_title: Airbus stems cash outflow in Q3
summary: Airbus successfully stemmed a significant cash outflow in the third quarter, generating 600 million euros and on track to meet its break-even adjusted free cash flow target in the fourth quarter. The company's confidence in a swift recovery from the pandemic is boosted by its strong financial performance. Despite burning through 4.4 billion euros in the second quarter, Airbus is well-positioned to emerge from the pandemic well-placed for a swift rebound.

site_title: KTL Global's ex-CEO charged with cheating and false trading
summary: Former KTL Global CEO Wilson Tan Kheng Yeow was charged with cheating and false trading in Singapore's State Courts, with two cheating charges and one of false trading. He allegedly cheated KTL Offshore out of S$1.5 million between 2014 and 2015, and conspired with others to create a false appearance of active trading in KTL Global's shares. Tan faces up to 10 years in prison and fines if convicted.

site_title: Q3 Apac fintech funding hints at nascent recovery
summary: Fintech funding in the Asia-Pacific region has seen a slight recovery, with Q3 Apac fintech companies raising US$3.9 billion, down 46% from the same period last year. Singapore-based fintechs drew in US$167 million, up 56% from the previous quarter, while China saw a resurgence in private fintech investments after a decline in the second quarter. The report suggests that investors are seeking regional opportunities, particularly in the payments subsector and early-stage fintechs, with 15 out of 23 large funding rounds still having participation from new investors.

site_title: Ikea says malls' expansion plans intact as customers return
summary: Ikea's expansion plans for its shopping malls remain on track despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with occupancy rates at 95% and footfall falling by almost a quarter. The company plans to nearly double the number of malls in the coming years, shifting focus to smaller inner-city locations. Ingka Centres, which owns 45 malls across Europe, Russia, and China, reported tenant sales of €5.4 billion (S$8.6 billion) and plans to enter the US market in 2021. Despite mall closures, around 500 stores opened in Ingka Centres' malls during the year.

site_title: Scientists identify prolific coronavirus strain
summary: Scientists have identified a prolific coronavirus strain that emerged in Spain in June and has spread across Europe, making up a large proportion of infections in several countries. The strain, which has not been found to be inherently more dangerous, has accounted for 90% of new infections in Spain and 40-70% in Switzerland, Ireland, and the UK. Researchers believe the strain's success may be due to its transmission advantage and the people who first caught it being mobile and sociable. The strain's rapid rise highlights the importance of genomic surveillance of the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.

site_title: Homes are still selling like it's summer across much of the US
summary: US homes are selling rapidly, defying seasonal norms, due to historically low mortgage rates. Average listing times are down, and prices in select areas are up over 20% from last year. The surge is driven by buyers racing to snap up homes, with bidding wars common in suburban areas and affordable cities. Despite a 38% decrease in available homes nationwide, demand remains high, with some areas experiencing inventory shortages of over 70%.

site_title: How income inequality has erased your chance to drink the great wines
summary: The prices of top wines, such as grand cru Burgundy and Bordeaux, have skyrocketed over the past few decades, making them inaccessible to most people. A 1991 grand cru Burgundy can now cost $800, while a 1990 Domaine de la Romanée-Conti La Tâche can cost $5,000. This trend is not unique to wine, with luxury goods like handbags also experiencing significant price increases. Economists attribute this to supply and demand, as the production of high-quality wines is limited and cannot keep pace with rising demand. This phenomenon is a microcosm of broader issues of income inequality and wealth concentration.

site_title: Sustainability and green finance to be factors in Singapore's new infrastructure
summary: Singapore is focusing on building sustainable infrastructure to support its post-Covid-19 economy, with a focus on green financing and alternative funding sources due to economic contraction. The country aims to upgrade its logistics infrastructure, including a new automated port and expanded airport terminals, to handle growing demand for food, pharmaceuticals, and e-commerce. Experts estimate that investments in sustainable infrastructure could add up to billions of dollars per year. Singapore is well-positioned to pursue business opportunities in the green economy, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore launching a green finance action plan and a $2 billion green investments program.

site_title: Co-ops connect with partners to do well and do good
summary: Co-operatives, often contrasted with corporations, share a similar goal of "doing well" to "do good." Unlike corporations, co-operatives prioritize community building, collaboration, and social networks. They facilitate bonding social capital, bridging social capital, and connecting with a larger public. Co-operatives like Silver Horizon Travel, NTUC LearningHub Co-operative, and FairPrice Co-operative showcase their unique role in community development. By forging networks, sharing ideas, and promoting social responsibility, co-operatives demonstrate that "doing well" and "doing good" are intertwined. Their success relies on "doing community," connecting with partners to make a positive impact.

site_title: Sinopec posts record quarterly profit as refining margins jump
summary: Sinopec Corp, Asia's top oil refiner, reported a record quarterly profit of 46.39 billion yuan in July-September, nearly quadrupling from the same period last year. Refining margins jumped 68% to US$9.80 per barrel, while fuel sales rose 0.4% to 45.44 million tonnes. The company's pipeline assets spin-off contributed 30.8 billion yuan to the profit. This marks the highest quarterly profit for Sinopec since Refinitiv Eikon data began tracking in 2003.

site_title: Mahathir says Muslims 'have right to kill French'
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad sparked outrage with a tweet stating that Muslims "have a right to kill millions of French people" in response to a recent jihadist attack in Nice. He claimed that the French have a history of violence against Muslims and that freedom of expression does not include insulting other people. Mahathir's comments were widely condemned, and he was criticized for drawing parallels between the French and Muslims, echoing past remarks that drew controversy for his anti-Semitic and anti-LGBT views.

site_title: Preserving architectural icons
summary: Singapore's Golden Mile Complex, a 47-year-old iconic landmark, may be saved from demolition due to a proposed conservation plan. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced incentives for developers to retain the main building with its signature terraced facade. The plan aims to preserve the building's historical and architectural significance, and could lead to adaptive reuse and regeneration of the complex. This move has been praised by heritage groups, and could set a precedent for conservation efforts in Asia.

site_title: Publishing a travelogue in a pandemic
summary: Singaporean writer Clara Chow's self-published travelogue "New Orleans" has become a bestseller among local titles. The slim volume, 103 pages long, chronicles Chow's journey to self-renewal and healing during a four-day trip to the city. The book, which combines descriptions of New Orleans' unique attractions with Chow's personal struggles and emotional turmoil, has been well-received. Chow, a former journalist, credits her writing experience with Iowa Writers' Workshop with helping her process her emotions and embark on a journey of self-healing. The book's success has provided a perspective for readers who feel trapped by their circumstances, offering a message of hope and happiness.

images.alt_text: Written during the circuit breaker, Clara Chow's New Orleans tells her story of self-discovery against the backdrop of a strange city.
Written during the circuit breaker, Clara Chow's New Orleans tells her story of self-discovery against the backdrop of a strange city.

site_title: Shopify earnings beat Wall St estimates as more merchants use its platform for online reach
summary: Shopify reported third-quarter earnings that beat Wall Street estimates, with gross merchandise volume more than doubling to US$30.9 billion, the highest since its initial public offering in 2015. Revenue nearly doubled to US$767.4 million, driven by a 47% increase in monthly recurring revenue. The company's e-commerce platform saw increased adoption by brick-and-mortar retailers amid the coronavirus crisis, supporting strong growth prospects.

site_title: Rocky road for firms in race for Covid-19 test
summary: Singapore companies are racing to develop cheaper and less-invasive Covid-19 testing methods, with demand expected to surge globally. Breathonix, a spin-off from the National University of Singapore, aims to commercialize its 60-second breathalyser test at a price of US$20 per test, 70% cheaper than traditional PCR tests. However, intense price competition and regulatory hurdles may hinder success, with industry experts citing the need for speed and scale to gain market share.

site_title: Robust Singapore housing market sparks fears of more curbs
summary: Singapore's housing market is sparking concerns of government intervention, with 19.2% of senior real estate executives surveyed believing tighter controls will be imposed in the next six months. The market sentiment improved in the third quarter, but worries over job losses, economic slowdown, and high construction costs are growing. About 76.9% of respondents also see high construction costs as a potential risk factor, while nearly half expect more residential units to be launched in the next six months.

images.alt_text: 19.2% of respondents in Q3 - up from 5.8% in Q2 - fear government intervention to cool the private housing market in the next six months.

site_title: Thai protesters target royal spending at Bangkok rally
summary: Thai protesters in Bangkok criticized the royal family's spending, holding a "fashion show" parodying royalty and denouncing wasteful spending at a time when Thailand's economy is struggling. The protests, which began as anti-government demonstrations, now call for reforms of the monarchy and the reversal of changes that increased the king's powers. Protesters also demand a new constitution and the removal of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, who they accuse of engineering last year's elections to keep power. The king's palace has not commented on the protests.

site_title: A new breed of alternative investments
summary: A new breed of alternative investments has emerged, offering investors options to invest in cryptocurrencies, apps, businesses, crowdsourced loans, and even celebrities. However, these investments come with high risks due to lack of regulation and poor understanding. Experts warn that some of these investments are passing fads, while others have long-term potential for growth. To navigate this landscape, investors need accelerated education and a clear understanding of the risks involved.

site_title: How tech leaders won the platform transition
summary: Tech leaders have successfully transitioned to platform dominance by either repositioning their core businesses or extending their capabilities into new domains. Companies like Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Facebook have established successful platforms, while others like Adobe and Alibaba have adapted to changing markets by refocusing their businesses. Successful transitions require a deep understanding of the sector's evolution, strategic investments in product and service expansions, and effective partnerships and mergers and acquisitions. By doing so, companies can create attractive economics, network effects, and a winner-takes-most dynamic, ultimately driving growth and value creation.

site_title: Malaysia-US trade likely to gain from Biden in White House: analysts
summary: Malaysia's trade relations with the US are unlikely to be significantly affected by the upcoming US presidential election, analysts say. A Joe Biden presidency is expected to create a more trade-friendly global environment, benefiting Malaysian exporters, particularly in value-added goods such as electronics. The US is Malaysia's third-largest export market, accounting for about 10% of its total shipments. Analysts expect Biden to maintain a tough stance on China, but his administration is likely to focus on repairing international relations with other countries, potentially increasing Malaysian exports to the US.

site_title: Aspen's volume jumps after getting green light for glove production
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings in Singapore saw a significant uptick in volume after receiving approval from the Malaysia trade ministry to produce medical-grade examination gloves. The company was the fifth most traded counter at the market's close on Thursday, bucking the trend of declines. This development is expected to boost the company's volume, but no further details on the impact on revenue or operations are provided.

site_title: ECB signals December stimulus coming on new virus lockdowns
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) signaled that it will likely boost its emergency bond-buying program in December to stabilize the euro-area economy amid new coronavirus lockdowns. The current $1.6 trillion program will run until June 2021, but a new assessment in December will allow the ECB to reassess the economic outlook and potentially add more support. The euro barely budged on the announcement, indicating that the ECB's signal of future action was in line with expectations.

site_title: China pushes domestic economy, tech power in latest five-year plan
summary: China's Communist leadership unveiled a five-year plan to develop the country into a domestic powerhouse, focusing on strong domestic spending and tech self-reliance. The plan, announced amid intense international pressure, did not include an overall economic growth target amid the US trade war. China's GDP is estimated to exceed 100 trillion yuan this year, with leaders stressing "high-quality development" over fast-paced growth. The plan aims to become a "moderately developed" economy by 2035, with a focus on low-carbon development and resource efficiency.

site_title: Tripartite group to study how to raise wages of low-income workers
summary: A tripartite work group in Singapore, chaired by Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad, will study ways to increase wages of low-income workers and improve their well-being. The group aims to provide an update by mid-2021 and recommendations by early 2022, with goals including increasing the number of low-income workers covered by the mandatory progressive wage model and offering progressive wages in non-covered sectors. The study will examine issues faced by low-income workers and look beyond the progressive wage model to find solutions.

site_title: TSH Corp issues net loss warning for FY2020
summary: TSH Corp, a Singapore-based operator of cocktail and whisky bars, has issued a net loss warning for FY2020 due to a more than 50% fall in revenue for the nine months ended Sept 30. The company is unable to determine the extent of the financial impact on its earnings per share and net asset value per share. Despite expected losses, TSH Corp believes it can continue as a going concern and fulfill its obligations. The company has taken cost-saving measures, including pay cuts for key management, and has resumed dine-in services at some of its bars.

site_title: Has the 'America First' republic collided with 'decline and fall'?
summary: US politics are polarized as the presidential election approaches, with "America First" policies clashing with the country's decline and fall. The US, once a sole superpower, is now a divided nation struggling with opioid crises, income inequalities, and racial discrimination. President Donald Trump's policies have exacerbated these issues, and his re-election could lead to an isolationist and protectionist economy. Alternatively, a Biden victory may be limited by the country's internal divisions and inability to stem the decline. The outcome could have significant implications for US foreign policy, including a potential war with China and internal unrest.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq rise at open on upbeat data
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising after upbeat economic data eased concerns about surging coronavirus cases. The S&P 500 gained 0.20% to 3,277.57, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.54% to 11,064.47. In contrast, the Dow Jones fell 0.15% to 26,480.98. The gains were partly driven by technology heavyweights ahead of quarterly earnings reports.

site_title: US economy surges 33.1% in Q3, biggest gain on record
summary: The US economy experienced its largest annual growth rate on record, expanding at a 33.1% annual rate in the third quarter, following a 31.4% drop in the April-June period and a 5% drop in the first quarter. This recovery comes after the worst downturn on record, with the economy contracting 2.9% compared to the same period in 2019. The strong growth is attributed to the full-year result of the third quarter's 33.1% expansion.

site_title: Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble important test for leisure travel, says Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung says the country's air travel bubble with Hong Kong, set to launch next month, will be a crucial test for leisure travel arrangements with other governments. Travelers will need to have been in either Singapore or Hong Kong for 14 days and undergo Covid-19 swab tests with negative results. Ong notes that the quota of travelers may increase as operations stabilize, but cautions against raising expectations, saying much depends on confidence from various countries and the competence level of local people.

site_title: Japfa net profit surges to US$130m for first nine months
summary: Japfa's net profit for the first nine months of 2020 surged to US$130 million, driven by strong momentum from its China dairy unit and swine business in Vietnam. Despite a 2.5% drop in revenue to US$2.8 billion, group operating profit grew 28.4% to US$236.8 million. The company's dairy segment saw a 13.8% revenue growth and 44% operating profit increase, while its beef operations in China boosted revenue and profit. Japfa plans to "forge ahead with growth plans" for its China dairy unit and Vietnam swine business.

site_title: Hong Kong teen activist Tony Chung charged with secession
summary: Hong Kong teen activist Tony Chung, 19, has been charged with secession, money laundering, and conspiring to publish seditious content under the city's new national security law. The law, imposed by Beijing, targets acts deemed as secession, subversion, terrorism, and colluding with foreign forces. Chung, a former member of Student Localism, faces a possible life prison sentence if convicted. Amnesty International and the US have condemned the charges, calling them "politically motivated" and "reprehensible."

site_title: No Covid-19 cases in community or in migrant worker dormitories for 2 days in a row
summary: Singapore reported no new Covid-19 cases in the community or migrant worker dormitories for the second consecutive day, according to the Ministry of Health. However, the number of community cases increased to an average of three cases per week. Seven new imported cases were confirmed, with all being Singaporeans or dependants. The total number of patients remains at 57,994, with 57,884 fully recovered and 37 in hospital.

site_title: Vestas to take on offshore wind with US$832m deal
summary: Vestas Wind Systems, the world's largest wind turbine manufacturer, will acquire Mitsubishi Heavy Industries' 50% share in their offshore joint venture for $832 million in an all-share deal. The acquisition aims to integrate the offshore business into Vestas' onshore wind operation, with the goal of dominating the industry by 2025. This move is part of Vestas' strategy to play a larger role in the offshore wind market, which has become increasingly competitive as governments transition away from fossil fuels.

site_title: Women seen needing at least 60 years to get equal with men in EU
summary: A report by the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE) found that European women are at least 60 years away from achieving equality with men, despite some progress in the past year. Women still do most of the unpaid work at home and face greater economic risks from the pandemic. The report noted that the pandemic has increased domestic pressure on women, with more caregiving, cleaning, and cooking responsibilities. This further slows progress towards achieving gender equality.

site_title: Exxon to cut 14,000 from global workforce after energy slump
summary: Exxon Mobil will cut 14,000 global jobs, 1,900 in the US, over the next two years to improve cost competitiveness amid market conditions. The 15% workforce reduction affects employees and contractors worldwide. This move follows similar job cuts by major oil companies, including BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Chevron, in response to the pandemic-induced demand slump. Exxon's financial position has weakened since its peak as the S&P 500's biggest company, with its stock plummeting 54% this year and dividend yield increasing to over 10%.

site_title: India's top airline IndiGo posts record quarterly loss on pandemic hit
summary: India's top airline, IndiGo, reported a record quarterly loss of 11.95 billion rupees (S$219.5 million) due to travel curbs and the ongoing pandemic. This is a 12% increase from the previous year's loss of 10.66 billion rupees. Revenue from operations plummeted 66% to 27.41 billion rupees. The airline's struggles highlight the impact of the pandemic on the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Interglobe Aviation, the operator of India's largest airline IndiGo, reported its biggest quarterly loss on Thursday as travel curbs still in place to control the spread of the coronavirus hammered the aviation industry.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's National University Health System (NUHS) and ARIA, a healthcare investment firm, are launching a $50 million fund to support medtech startups in adoption and commercialization. The Shenton Healthtech Venture Capital Fund will provide funding to companies developing innovative medical technologies. This investment aims to promote the growth of Singapore's medtech industry, enhancing healthcare services and improving patient outcomes.

images.alt_text: From left: Viveka Kalidasan, founder of medtech startup WiSe; Raymond Lim, chief financial officer of ARIA; Timothy Chen, co-founder and executive director of ARIA; Prof Lawrence Ho, director of NUHS' Centre for Innovation in Healthcare; and Amrish Nair, chief executive of medtech startup Biorithm.

site_title: New Silkroutes plans independent review of deals signed with China entity
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a Singapore-based healthcare and energy firm, plans an independent review of two agreements with a Chinese entity, Shanghai Minlin New Textile Materials Sales Centre. The review will assess the commercial substance of these agreements and potential tax exposures. The move comes after Deloitte & Touche, the company's external auditor, issued a disclaimer of opinion on its financial statements due to insufficient audit evidence on the agreements' business rationale and structuring. The review aims to ease cash flow concerns and address regulatory compliance issues.

site_title: Social e-commerce platform Webuy bags US$6m in Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based social e-commerce platform Webuy has secured US$6 million in Series A funding led by Wavemaker Partners. The funding, bringing the startup's total funding to US$9 million, will be used to expand its regional footprint into Vietnam and the Philippines, and improve its platform across three markets: Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Webuy's platform mimics social media influencer-driven interactions to increase visibility for small merchants and offer customers discounts on bulk purchases.

site_title: MNACT's H1 DPU falls 26 per cent to 2.88 Singapore cents
summary: MNACT's distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half fell 26% to 2.88 Singapore cents, down from 3.887 cents a year ago. Distributable income also declined 21.8% year-over-year to S$96.8 million. Rental reliefs granted to tenants at its Hong Kong mall and lower average rental rates contributed to the decline. However, acquisitions in Japan partially offset the impact. Despite a challenging first half, the trust's manager plans to continue diversifying its portfolio and protecting occupancy levels to mitigate the impact of Covid-19 and the slowing economy.

site_title: MNACT's H1 DPU falls 26% to 2.876 Singapore cents
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 26% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the first half to 2.876 Singapore cents, down from 3.887 cents a year ago. The Reit's distributable income and gross revenue fell 21.8% and 9.6% year-on-year, respectively, due to rental reliefs and lower average rental rates. Despite a challenging first half, MNACT's strategy of diversification and yield-accretive acquisitions mitigated the impact of Covid-19 and the slowing economy.

site_title: Sheng Siong's Q3 net profit up 54.4% on Covid-19 demand
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket operator, reported a 54.4% increase in net profit to S$31.8 million for its third quarter, driven by strong revenue growth due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue rose 28.9% to S$327.3 million, while gross profit margin remained flat. Administrative expenses increased, mainly due to higher staff costs, but rental decreased. The company has opened two new stores and has a healthy balance sheet with S$179.8 million in net cash. Despite the strong performance, the company acknowledges potential risks from supply chain disruption and increased competition from e-commerce platforms.

site_title: Keppel posts 'significantly lower' net profit for Q3
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a "significantly lower" net profit for the third quarter, falling to a loss of S$697 million in the preceding quarter. The company's revenue declined 10.5% year-over-year to S$4.8 billion, mainly due to decreased contributions from its offshore and marine arm. However, other business units such as Keppel Infrastructure and Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation performed resiliently, with the former securing S$2.1 billion worth of contracts.

site_title: Ant Group's US$34.4b dual listing is 872 times oversubscribed
summary: Ant Group's US$34.4 billion dual listing has reached 872 times oversubscription, with investors scrambling to buy into the Chinese fintech firm. The offering includes a US$17.2 billion Shanghai leg and roughly the same in Hong Kong, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record US$29.4 billion listing. The oversubscription equates to US$596.76 billion in investment interest, driven by Ant's fast-growing financial services and payments platform, despite increased scrutiny at home and abroad.

images.alt_text: The domestic retail book of Ant Group's US$34.4 billion dual listing was 872 times oversubscribed as individual investors in China scrambled for a slice of the world's largest initial public offering (IPO), a company filing showed.

site_title: Tanah Merah plot under GLS Programme receives 15 bids; Yishun EC site at draws 7 bids
summary: Tenders for two 99-year leasehold sites under the Government Land Sales Programme closed, with 15 bids for a Tanah Merah plot and 7 bids for a Yishun EC site. MCC Land secured the Tanah Merah plot with a S$248.99 million bid (S$930 psf ppr), while Sing Holdings topped the Yishun EC site with a S$373.5 million bid (S$576 psf ppr). The lowest bids were S$161 million for Tanah Merah and S$268 million for Yishun EC.

site_title: NUHS, ARIA to launch S$50m fund for medtech startups
summary: A new S$50 million venture capital fund, the Shenton Healthtech Venture Capital Fund, will be launched by National University Health System (NUHS) and Asia Research & Innovation Alliance Limited (ARIA) to invest in medtech startups. The fund will focus on software-as-a-service, digital healthcare platforms, telehealth, and digital therapeutics, with investments across Asean and North Asia. The fund aims to achieve a 20% internal rate of return and has a life span of five to seven years, targeting market entry for Singapore's medtech startups into the Asia-Pacific healthcare sector.

site_title: Americans plan widespread protests if Trump interferes with election
summary: US activists plan widespread protests if President Donald Trump interferes with the vote counting or poll results after the Election Day, with over 400 events planned by a coalition of over 130 groups. The "Protect the Results" coalition, including Planned Parenthood and Republicans for the Rule of Law, aims to demonstrate if Trump tries to manipulate election results or pressure officials to stop counting ballots. Activists warn that Trump's refusal to accept a peaceful transfer of power could lead to a coup-like situation, citing lessons from other countries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with losses on Thursday, following a Wall Street rout fueled by concerns over US and European coronavirus cases. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.49%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.11%. The losses come as investors weigh US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Singapore opens borders to mainland China and Australian visitors from Nov 6
summary: Singapore will open its borders to visitors from mainland China and Australia's state of Victoria starting Nov 6. Travelers must have been in either country for the last 14 days and undergo a PCR test upon arrival, with negative results allowing them to proceed without a Stay-Home Notice. Singapore citizens and residents returning from these areas will also be subject to the same conditions. The decision follows successful control of the virus in both countries and aims to boost tourism.

site_title: Premium cars drive Volkswagen back to profit on China boost
summary: Volkswagen returned to profit in the third quarter, driven by a 3% surge in Chinese demand for luxury cars, including Audi and Porsche sportscars. The company's premium vehicle sales offset a 1.1% drop in vehicle deliveries due to the Covid-19 crisis. Volkswagen implemented cost-cutting measures, which contributed to its improved financial performance. The automaker expects to post a profit for the full year, despite a "severely lower" profit compared to 2019. Its net liquidity improved to 24.8 billion euros.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen (VW) returned to profit in the third quarter as surging Chinese demand for luxury cars helped offset a 1.1 per cent drop in vehicle deliveries due to the Covid-19 crisis.

site_title: Australia: Shares close lower as spiralling pandemic stokes recovery fears
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest level in over three weeks, falling 1.6% to 5,960.30, amid concerns over the global economic recovery due to surging Covid-19 cases worldwide. The decline was driven by a decrease in gold and energy stocks, with the Australian energy index falling 2.9% and gold stocks shedding 4.2%. The market remains uncertain due to the US election outcome and the fading hopes of a stimulus deal, with investors seeking clarity before making further moves.

site_title: ByteDance launches education technology brand Dali for China
summary: ByteDance, a Beijing-based tech company, launched a standalone education technology brand Dali for the Chinese market. Dali, meaning "forceful strength" in Chinese, will host all of ByteDance's education business, with 10,000 employees. The move follows the growing demand for education technology in China, driven by the Covid-19 pandemic. ByteDance founder Zhang Yiming stated that Dali Education is just the beginning of a long journey, indicating the company's commitment to the sector.

site_title: Marvell to buy Inphi in US$10b chip deal to bolster data centre, 5G business
summary: Marvell Technology has agreed to buy Inphi Corp in a US$10 billion cash-and-stock deal, aiming to expand its presence in data centers and 5G network infrastructure. Inphi's chips, which move data over fiber-optic cables, are used by major tech companies such as Amazon and Google for optical connections in massive data centers. The acquisition will broaden Marvell's capabilities and compete with Broadcom in the market for chips that move data on copper-based cables. The deal is expected to bolster Marvell's data center and 5G business.

site_title: Fast cash is key to small businesses' survival during Covid-19 in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's small businesses, particularly micro, small, and medium enterprises (MSMEs), are struggling to survive during the COVID-19 pandemic due to liquidity provision issues. Despite the government's allocation of $11.5 billion in stimulus packages, only 38% has been disbursed, largely due to bureaucratic hurdles and administrative complexity. MSMEs are not bankable, making it difficult for banks to verify their status, and many lack cash or savings, with over half saying they don't have enough to cover a month. The researchers suggest expediting stimulus measures and encouraging MSMEs to go digital to strengthen their resilience.

site_title: Pinterest projects 60% sales growth for Q4 as ad sales rebound
summary: Pinterest projects 60% sales growth for Q4, exceeding analyst forecasts of 35%. The rebound in ad spending by businesses follows the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's shares rose 28% to $63.05 in extended trading, surpassing third-quarter sales estimates. This informal forecast marks a significant improvement from previous predictions, highlighting the company's resilience in the industry.

site_title: Ralph Lauren misses revenue estimates, sees more pandemic pain ahead
summary: Ralph Lauren reported a 30% decline in net revenue to $1.19 billion in the second quarter, missing estimates due to reduced consumer spending during the Covid-19 pandemic. The company expects continued earnings impact from the pandemic, which has dulled demand for its high-end apparel and accessories. This marks the second consecutive quarter of revenue decline for the luxury retailer.

site_title: GIC unit expands presence in Germany with acquisition of retail logistics assets
summary: GIC's wholly-owned unit P3 Logistic Parks has agreed to acquire 33 retail logistics assets in prime locations across major German cities and towns, spanning over 650,000 sq m of space. The acquisition is expected to close in the fourth quarter of this year, subject to necessary conditions and approvals. P3 will manage the portfolio, further expanding GIC's presence in Germany.

site_title: Regional markets track Wall Street rout amid renewed virus fears; STI falls 1.3%
summary: Global markets plummeted on Wednesday amid rising coronavirus cases and looming lockdowns, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.4% and the S&P 500 losing 3.5%. Regional markets, including Singapore, Hong Kong, and Japan, also closed lower, with the Straits Times Index down 1.3%. Tech giants and glove makers rose, while banks and real estate investment trusts fell. Experts warn that the pandemic poses a threat to the economic recovery, with a vaccine and Brexit deal providing potential tailwinds.

site_title: JPMorgan backs UK payments technology company Icon Solutions
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has made a strategic investment in UK-based payments technology company Icon Solutions, a move to help banks digitize their digital payments systems amid a global acceleration in digital payment volumes. The investment will aid Icon's growth and expansion, allowing it to help banks cut costs and stay competitive in the face of increasing competition from digital-savvy companies. Icon's clients include major banks such as HSBC, Wells Fargo, and Citigroup.

site_title: AirAsia X to revise US$15.3b debt reform plan to expedite talks with creditors
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia X plans to revise its US$15.3 billion debt restructuring plan to expedite talks with creditors after dropping a local airport operator from the plan. The airline has less than six months of cash left and is seeking to reconstitute its debt into a principal amount of RM200 million. The move comes after Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd filed a lawsuit to claim RM78 million owed by AirAsia X, which could delay the restructuring process. The airline aims to complete the restructuring by January or February to avoid liquidation.

site_title: India gold demand could recover during Q4 on festival shopping: World Gold Council
summary: India's gold demand is expected to recover in the fourth quarter due to pent-up demand and festivals, according to the World Gold Council. Demand fell 49% in the first three quarters, with jewellery demand plummeting 48% to 52.8 tonnes. However, investment demand rose 51% and scrap gold supplies jumped to 41.5 tonnes, the highest in seven years. Despite this, demand is still expected to be lower than last year's 194.3 tonnes due to near-record high prices.

images.alt_text: India's gold demand in the fourth quarter is expected to recover after falling 30 per cent in the previous quarter as festivals are expected to strengthen retail jewellery purchases, the World Gold Council (WGC) said on Thursday.

site_title: Gold firms on US election, economic uncertainty
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,881.16 per ounce after a decline in the previous session, driven by concerns over the US presidential election and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. A strong US dollar limited gains. Investors took advantage of Wednesday's fall to buy gold, citing US political uncertainty and low-interest rates.

site_title: Mapletree to hire up to 30 fresh grads for work-study traineeship
summary: Mapletree Investments has launched a 12-month work-study programme for up to 30 fresh graduates, providing a fully funded opportunity to gain skills and knowledge in the real estate industry. The programme, set to start in December, offers a combination of work and study components, including rotations across various business functions and access to curated real estate courses. Upon completion, trainees may be offered jobs with the Mapletree group. The programme aims to support graduates struggling to find employment in Singapore amid the pandemic. Applications can be submitted by November 30.

site_title: Panasonic Q2 profit beats estimates on boost from Tesla battery business
summary: Panasonic reported a 11% increase in Q2 operating profit to 92.8 billion yen, beating analyst estimates, driven by a solid performance from its Tesla battery business. The company's automotive components business turned profitable, with battery sales for Tesla generating profits. Panasonic maintained its profit forecast for the year, citing a 48.9% decline from the previous year. This result follows Tesla's recent report of its fifth consecutive quarterly profit on record revenue.

site_title: BT's Q2 result shows demand holding up amid pandemic
summary: BT Group reported adjusted earnings of £1.91 billion in Q2, exceeding analyst estimates. Revenue was £5.36 billion, slightly below consensus. The company set Ebitda guidance of at least £7.9 billion for 2022/23. CEO Philip Jansen said restructuring efforts are on track, delivering £352 million in savings. BT faces challenges from the pandemic, Brexit, and the UK's ban on Huawei, which has impacted business clients and 5G wireless technology. The company's shares have fallen 47.2% since 2020.

site_title: Nokia cuts full-year profit forecast, announces new strategy
summary: Nokia cuts its full-year profit forecast by 0.02 euros, lowering the midpoint to 0.23 euros per share. The company announces a new strategy with four business groups, effective January 1, 2021. Quarterly revenue fell 7% to 5.44 billion euros, below consensus. Nokia's underlying earnings were flat year-over-year at 0.05 euros per share. The company also lost a contract to Samsung Electronics for 5G equipment to Verizon in the third quarter. This move follows increased competition from Nokia and Ericsson as telecom operators roll out 5G networks.

site_title: Ad group WPP says client wins help trading to improve
summary: WPP, the world's largest advertising company, reported an improvement in third-quarter underlying trading due to client wins from Uber, Alibaba, and HSBC. Despite a 7.6% like-for-like net sales decline, the company is on track to hit its £700-800 million cost reduction target. Analysts expect a full-year underlying net sales decline of -8.5% to -10.7% and a headline operating margin of 11.4% to 12.5%. The company attributed the improvement to a steady increase in North American media ad spending.

site_title: Lloyds posts Q3 net profit of £688m
summary: Lloyds Banking Group reported a net profit of £688 million in the third quarter, rebounding from a £461 million loss in the second quarter due to the coronavirus crisis. Lower impairments contributed to the improvement. The bank's profit after taxation hit £688 million, a significant increase from the previous quarter. This positive result is a result of the bank's efforts to mitigate the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: Airbus sets quarterly cash goal, takes heavy restructuring charge
summary: Airbus reported a quarterly cash goal, aiming to reach cash breakeven in the fourth quarter, despite a 49% drop in underlying operating profit to 820 million euros. The company took a 1.2-billion-euro restructuring charge, driving it to a loss, and shed 135 aircraft from its backlog due to reduced demand. Airbus aims to continue deliveries, with talks with customers and unions over 15,000 job cuts progressing, and has reset loan terms with French and Spanish governments to smooth a trade row with Boeing.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher after lockdowns
summary: Europe's major stock markets rose on Thursday, reversing the previous day's losses, amid new lockdowns in France and Germany to combat rising coronavirus cases. The Paris CAC 40, Frankfurt's DAX 30, and London's FTSE 100 indices gained 0.5%, 0.6%, and 0.2% respectively, respectively. Investors digested the news while focusing on US-EU trade talks and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: KTL Global's former CEO charged with cheating and false trading
summary: Former KTL Global CEO Wilson Tan Kheng Yeow was charged in Singapore State Courts with cheating and false trading between 2014 and 2015. Tan allegedly cheated the company's subsidiary KTL Offshore of S$1.5 million to fund trades in KTL Global's shares. He faces two cheating charges and one false trading charge. Tan's accomplice, Mr. Tang, was accused of creating a false impression of active trading in KTL Global's shares, while Tan Chun Yong, a former OCBC trading representative, was charged with abetting. Both Tan and Chun Yong were offered bail.

site_title: More execs now concerned about cooling measures for Singapore private homes
summary: Singapore's real estate market sentiment improved in the third quarter, with the composite sentiment index increasing to 5.4, but concerns about government intervention to cool the market grew, with 19.2% of respondents worried about such measures. High construction costs and job losses were also seen as potential risks. However, about half of developers surveyed expect more residential units to be launched in the next six months, and nearly 70% believe prices will stay at current levels. The work-from-home trend is expected to have a slight influence on homebuyers' preferences.

site_title: Credit Suisse Q3 profit falls 38%, misses estimates
summary: Credit Suisse Group reported a 38% fall in third-quarter net profit to 546 million Swiss francs (S$818.5 million), missing analyst estimates. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in wealth management, despite a surge in investment banking. A one-off boost from last year's sale of the InvestLab fund platform left this year's figure flat. The bank's new investment banking unit saw pre-tax profit rise to 370 million francs, with increased trading activity.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall on coronavirus worries; upbeat earnings outlook limits losses
summary: Japanese stocks fell to a one-month low on Thursday due to concerns about fresh coronavirus lockdowns in Europe and the upcoming US election. The Nikkei 225 Index ended down 0.37% to 23,331.94. However, an improving earnings outlook and smaller coronavirus infections in Japan limited losses. Some Japanese companies raised their forecasts, including Sony and Hitachi, which rose 6.69% and 4.29% respectively. Analysts expect Japanese companies to weather another dip in global economic activity.

site_title: Shell increases dividend after beating Q3 forecasts
summary: Royal Dutch Shell increased its dividend after beating Q3 profit forecasts, despite warning of significant uncertainty due to the pandemic. The company's adjusted earnings fell 80% to $955 million, but exceeded analysts' forecasts. Shell plans a major restructuring to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2050 and will cut its oil refineries from 14 to six "energy and chemical parks". The move aims to boost confidence after the company cut its dividend in April for the first time since the 1940s.

site_title: Seoul: Shares hit lowest close in over a month on pandemic lockdown worries
summary: South Korean shares closed at their lowest in over a month, falling 18.59 points or 0.79% to 2,326.67, amid worries over surging coronavirus infections and economic fallout from new lockdowns in Europe. The decline follows a 1.9% drop earlier in the session, marking the third session of losses in five.

site_title: Quantifeed completes Series B+ funding round led by Franklin Templeton
summary: Quantifeed, a Hong Kong-based digital wealth management solutions provider, has completed a Series B+ funding round led by Franklin Templeton. The undisclosed funding will support growth in existing markets and expansion into new ones, including China's Greater Bay Area and Malaysia. The startup aims to enhance its platform capabilities with new machine learning technology and develop solutions such as retirement planning platforms. With the investment, Quantifeed plans to service increasing demand for investment advice from affluent individuals and financial institutions in Asia.

site_title: Australian scientists find huge new healthy coral reef off northern coast
summary: Australian scientists have discovered a massive, detached coral reef off the northern coast of the Great Barrier Reef, exceeding the height of the Empire State Building and the Eiffel Tower. Measuring 500 meters tall and 1.5 kilometers wide, the reef is thriving with marine life, despite being 40 meters below the surface. The discovery, made by a team from James Cook University, is the first of its size in over 100 years and offers hope for the reef's recovery after losing more than half its coral in the last three decades.

site_title: Linde names Singaporean Sanjiv Lamba as global COO
summary: Linde appoints Singaporean Sanjiv Lamba as global COO, effective January 1, 2021. Lamba will oversee regional operating segments in the Americas, Asia-Pacific, Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, as well as Linde Engineering and global functions. He will report to CEO Steve Angel and relocate to Danbury, Connecticut. The appointment reflects confidence in Lamba's ability to drive growth through digitalization and capitalizing on opportunities in healthcare, electronics, and clean energy.

site_title: TikTok escalates patent fight with Triller amid sale talks
summary: TikTok and its parent ByteDance sued rival Triller in a US federal court, seeking to clear up a patent dispute after Triller accused TikTok of stealing technology. ByteDance is in talks to sell parts of its TikTok unit worth tens of billions of dollars amid President Trump's national security concerns. Triller claims TikTok infringed on its 2017 patent for music video technology, while ByteDance disputes this, citing a lack of evidence. The case comes as ByteDance faces a potential ban in the US and a possible merger with Triller.

site_title: Breathonix targets HSA approval for Covid-19 test in Q1 2021, US$20 price point
summary: Breathonix, a Singapore-based startup, aims to receive provisional HSA approval for its 60-second Covid-19 breath test by Q1 2021. The test will be priced at US$20 per test, targeting a service model for mass screening in high-traffic areas like air and sea ports. Chairman Kok Beng Neo emphasized the test's advantages, citing its 60-second duration. This move could potentially increase the efficiency of Covid-19 screening and control measures.

site_title: Marriott, Grab to tie up on food delivery, payments, loyalty programmes
summary: Marriott International and Grab are teaming up to integrate their services in South-east Asia, offering food delivery, payment, and loyalty programs across six markets. Starting in November, GrabFood customers can order from 600 Marriott hotels, while GrabPay can be used at select hotels. Loyalty programs will also be linked, allowing points to be converted between GrabRewards and Marriott Bonvoy. The partnership aims to boost hotel earnings amid the Covid-19 pandemic and promote targeted marketing.

site_title: Equinor in US$2.93b asset write-off as oil price hit
summary: Norway's Equinor wrote off $2.93 billion from asset value due to low oil prices and the pandemic's lasting impact on markets. The company reported a net loss of $2.12 billion in the third quarter, with adjusted EBIT falling to $780 million. Equinor now expects Brent crude to average $64 a barrel for 2021-2050, higher than previous forecasts. The company's long-term price forecast has been revised downward, with Brent expected to decline to $64 by 2040.

images.alt_text: Norway's Equinor wrote off US$2.93 billion from the value of its assets after cutting its long-term oil price forecast on Thursday, betting the pandemic and a shift away from fossil fuels will have a lasting impact on markets.

site_title: ECB under pressure to bolster Covid-19 response at meeting
summary: The European Central Bank faces pressure to bolster its Covid-19 response amid spiking cases and new restrictions in the eurozone. ECB chief Christine Lagarde is expected to signal possible action, with analysts predicting a possible easing of monetary stimulus. The eurozone economy has begun to slump, with deflationary trends threatening future investment, and inflation has dropped below the ECB's target of 2%. The ECB is expected to make a decision on its pandemic response at its December policy meeting, with observers closely watching for any hints of possible action.

site_title: Bank of Japan trims growth forecast but keeps upbeat view on outlook, signals policy pause
summary: The Bank of Japan trimmed its economic and price forecasts for the current fiscal year, but maintained an upbeat outlook for a moderate recovery. It kept monetary policy steady, including a -0.1% target for short-term interest rates, and made no changes to its package of steps to ease corporate funding strains. The BOJ expects the economy to fall 5.5% in the current fiscal year, but revised up its forecast for the next fiscal year to a 3.6% increase. The central bank signaled a policy pause, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda set to hold a news conference to explain the decision.

site_title: Blowout US GDP report will obscure troubling slowdown
summary: The US economy is expected to post a 30-35% growth rate in the third quarter, driven by consumer spending and government aid, but economists warn this rebound is not strong enough to repair the damage caused by the pandemic. The growth is not sustainable and is largely dependent on aid that has since expired. Economists predict a deteriorating fourth quarter and warn of a potential "financial cliff" for millions of households.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall again after lockdowns spark Wall Street, Europe rout
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday after a US and European economic downturn sparked by France's nationwide lockdown to combat a new wave of COVID-19 infections. The lockdown, coupled with US lawmakers' failure to pass a stimulus package and election uncertainty, dampened investor sentiment. European markets plummeted, with Frankfurt and Paris falling over 4% and 3%, respectively. Analysts say while the economic recovery is stuttering, vast central bank support and eventual US stimulus may mitigate the damage, but downside risks remain high.

site_title: MSCI launches climate indices for investors to align with Paris Agreement
summary: MSCI launched eight new climate indices, designed to minimize investors' exposure to climate risks while identifying green opportunities, aligning with the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C target. The indices incorporate climate metrics and exclude high-carbon emitters, while targeting a 50% reduction in weighted average carbon intensity and maximizing exposure to clean-technology solutions. The move aims to support decarbonization and systemic global change, responding to growing investor demand for climate-focused strategies.

site_title: 5Qs with Ubisoft Singapore on gaming and Assassin's Creed Valhalla
summary: Ubisoft Singapore's Director of Operations, Matthew Thorpe, discussed the evolution of the video gaming industry in Southeast Asia and the company's role in the region. The industry has grown significantly, with the APAC region generating over $140 billion in 2018. Ubisoft Singapore, established in 2008, has become a key contributor to the Assassin's Creed franchise, pioneering innovative gameplay elements and naval battles. The studio is now developing its own IP, Skull & Bones, and is working to create a robust talent pipeline for the region. With the rise of cloud-based gaming and 5G technology, Ubisoft aims to make gaming more accessible to everyone, while building strong communities around its games. Assassin's Creed Valhalla, the latest installment in the franchise, promises an immersive Viking fantasy experience with meaningful dialogue and gameplay choices, and a focus on exploration and player progression.

site_title: Fidelity Digital crypto pact aims at rich Asians wanting Bitcoin
summary: Fidelity Investments has partnered with Stack Funds, a Singapore-based firm, to provide secure custody services for its clients in Asia. The partnership aims to cater to the growing interest in cryptocurrencies among high net worth investors and family offices in the region. Fidelity's involvement is expected to offer risk mitigation and appeal to investors seeking a deeper understanding of the digital asset space. The partnership follows Fidelity's earlier move into digital assets, including a passively managed Bitcoin fund for wealthy investors.

images.alt_text: A new partnership for Fidelity Digital Asset Services (FDAS) aims to facilitate the growing interest in cryptocurrencies among Asian investors.

site_title: Taiwan chipmaker UMC pleads guilty to trade secret theft, fined US$60m
summary: Taiwanese chipmaker United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) pleaded guilty to trade secret theft and agreed to pay a US$60 million fine. The US Department of Justice alleged state-owned Fujian Jinhua Integrated Circuit Co. stole trade secrets from US peer Micron Technology, which UMC received and possessed but did not transfer. As part of a plea deal, UMC's financial obligations were limited to the fine, and allegations of conspiracy and economic espionage were dismissed. UMC will also serve a three-year term of non-supervised probation.

site_title: Semiconductor play Micro-Mechanics' earnings grow 42.3% in Q1
summary: Micro-Mechanics, a mainboard-listed semiconductor manufacturing company, reported a 42.3% increase in net profit to S$4.7 million in Q1, driven by a "record" quarterly revenue. Revenue rose 18.3% year-over-year to S$18.1 million, with sales growth in Singapore, China, and the US. The company is automating operations to improve efficiency and scalability. No dividend was declared for Q1, but a final dividend of S$0.05 per share and special dividend of S$0.02 are planned for FY2020.

site_title: StanChart Q3 profit slumps 40% on higher credit impairment
summary: Standard Chartered reported a 40% decline in third-quarter profit to US$745 million due to higher credit impairment from the coronavirus pandemic and lower interest rates. Despite this, the bank beat analyst expectations and cited cost-cutting measures to remain on track with financial targets. The bank's focus on Asia, Africa, and the Middle East has helped it navigate the challenging global banking environment, with CEO Bill Winters stating the company is well-positioned to meet its targets, albeit with some delay.

site_title: US: Dow ends 3.4% lower as coronavirus worries rout stocks
summary: US stocks plummeted 3.4% on Wednesday due to rising coronavirus concerns, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 940 points to 26,519.95. France and Germany announced tough new lockdown restrictions, and US cases continue to climb, weighing on the economy. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 3.5% and 3.7%, respectively. Investors are concerned about the potential for additional stimulus and economic uncertainty in the final quarter of the year.

site_title: Vietnam's Oct exports up 9.9%, industrial output up 5.4%
summary: Vietnam's October exports rose 9.9% to $26.7 billion, while imports increased 10.1% to $24.5 billion, narrowing the trade surplus to $2.2 billion. Industrial output increased 5.4% and consumer prices rose 2.47%. For the first 10 months, exports rose 4.7% and imports rose 0.4%, resulting in a trade surplus of $18.72 billion.

site_title: Hurricane Zeta slams into Louisiana coast
summary: Hurricane Zeta made landfall in Louisiana as a Category 2 storm, bringing strong winds and heavy rains to the southern US.
