The storm weakened as it moved into southeastern Mississippi, but still posed a threat of life-threatening surges and strong winds. New Orleans residents scrambled to prepare, with power outages reported and flooding appearing less likely due to the storm's fast movement. The city's emergency services reported one electrocution fatality, and officials urged residents to stay indoors and have emergency supplies ready.

site_title: Hot stock: Aspen sees higher trading after Malaysia trade ministry approves glove production
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings shares rose 3.9% after the Malaysian trade ministry approved the company's glove production. The approval, granted to Aspen Glove, a joint-venture between Aspen and CMY Capital, allows the production of nitrile and natural rubber medical-grade examination gloves. Heavy trading occurred on the Singapore Exchange, with 3.7 million shares changing hands. The approval boosts Aspen's visibility in the market, potentially aiding future fundraising efforts.

site_title: 'Anonymous' no longer: former Trump administration official reveals identity
summary: A former US Department of Homeland Security official, Miles Taylor, has revealed his identity as "Anonymous", the author of a series of critical columns and a book about the Trump administration. Taylor, a Republican, served as chief of staff to Kirstjen Nielsen and wrote about dysfunction and leadership failures within the administration. Taylor expressed disappointment in Trump's actions, saying he was a man without character, and has since endorsed Democratic candidate Joe Biden for president. Trump responded with insults, calling Taylor a "sleazebag" and "absolute loser".

site_title: Asia-Pacific fintech funding in Q3 hints at nascent recovery: S&P
summary: Asia-Pacific fintech funding in Q3 rose to $1.3 billion, 8.7% higher than the previous quarter, suggesting a cautious recovery from the pandemic. Private fintech companies raised a combined $3.9 billion for the first three quarters, down 46% from last year. Payment companies, particularly those in Singapore, led the funding, with cross-border payments startup Thunes raising $60 million in a Series B round. China saw a resurgence in fintech investments after a decline in the second quarter, accounting for a third of APAC's fintech funding value in Q3.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares follow global markets lower as virus cases surge
summary: Shares in Australia and New Zealand plummeted to three-week lows as global markets fell due to a surge in COVID-19 cases worldwide, sparking fears of prolonged lockdowns. The Australian S&P/ASX 200 index declined 1.1%, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index fell 1%. Global equities dropped, with European and US stocks also falling, as concerns over infections outweighed news of economic recoveries. The Australian dollar weakened, and gold prices slumped to a two-month low.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.69% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 418.79 points to 24,290.01, amid fears of a global economic rebound due to new virus infections and strict containment measures. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined, with losses of 1.07% and 1.34%, respectively. The downturn was fueled by concerns over the US-EU trade talks and the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Euro dips on French lockdown fears
summary: The euro dropped 0.4% to $1.1753 due to fears of a potential French lockdown amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Implied volatility gauges for the euro and yen rose to nearly seven-month highs, signaling investors are preparing for sharp price moves. The US dollar rose against the euro, while the yen rose 0.2% to a multi-month high. Market sentiment was also influenced by the US presidential election, with investors cautious about the outcome and potential for disputed results.

site_title: UK September car production lowest in 25 years
summary: The UK's car manufacturing industry produced 114,732 cars in September, the lowest in 25 years, with a 5.0% decline compared to the same period in 2019. Domestic demand increased 14.5% but export figures to the US and EU dropped 30.0% and 3.3% respectively. The industry faces a tough 2021 if a trade deal with the EU isn't reached, which would allow tariff-free exports. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders warned of devastating consequences for the sector and its workers if a deal isn't secured.

site_title: Singapore shares tumble at Thursday's open tracking global rout; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore shares plummeted 0.8% at Thursday's open, tracking a global rout amid rising Covid-19 worries, lockdown fears, and economic gloom. The Straits Times Index (STI) slumped 19.26 points to 2,464.22. This marks the third consecutive day of declines, following tough new restrictions in France and Germany and rising US cases.

site_title: New Silkroutes plans independent review into agreements signed with China entity
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a healthcare and energy firm, will conduct an independent review into two agreements with a Chinese entity, Shanghai Minlin New Textile Materials Sales Centre, due to concerns raised by its independent auditor Deloitte & Touche. The agreements include a management agreement and a management service agreement, which Deloitte had difficulty auditing due to insufficient evidence. The review aims to address Deloitte's concerns over the commercial substance and structuring of the agreements, as well as potential tax exposures and regulatory compliance.

site_title: UOI nine-month profit tumbles 42% to S$15.2m
summary: UOI, the general insurance arm of UOB, reported a 42% decline in nine-month net profit to S$15.2 million, from S$26.1 million last year. The decline was due to lower business activities caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. Gross premium fell 6.6% to S$77.9 million, while underwriting profit rose 0.9% to S$12.4 million. Non-underwriting income plummeted 69.5% to S$5.8 million, and total comprehensive income dropped 91.7% to S$3.4 million.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q3 operating profit jumps 59% on strong smartphone sales
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 59% rise in quarterly operating profit to 12.35 trillion won, driven by strong smartphone sales boosted by US restrictions on Huawei. Net profit rose 49% to 9.36 trillion won, while revenue climbed 8% to 66.96 trillion won. The results beat the company's estimate of 12.3 trillion won. This growth is attributed to the increased demand for Samsung's phone and chip products, solidifying its position as the world's top maker of memory chips and smartphones.

site_title: Bank of Canada says global approach needed on digital currencies, working with G-7
summary: The Bank of Canada is working with its G-7 partners on a globally coordinated approach to digital currencies, aiming to prevent surprises and prevent tools from being used by criminals. Governor Tiff Macklem stated that while there is no compelling need for a digital loonie now, the central bank wants to be prepared in case other countries introduce digital currencies. This comes as China continues to experiment with its digital renminbi and other major central banks have laid out key principles for issuing central bank digital currencies (CBDCs).

site_title: New Zealand business mood brightens as Covid-19 contained
summary: New Zealand business sentiment improved in October, with a 12.8 percentage point decrease in the net percentage of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead. The ANZ Bank survey found a 0.7 percentage point increase in those expecting their businesses to improve, with construction being the most optimistic sector. This marks a marked turnaround from September, when 5.4% of respondents expected conditions to worsen. The improved mood is attributed to the success in containing the Covid-19 outbreak and the subsequent re-opening of the economy.

site_title: Grubhub sales beat estimates with more Covid takeaway diners
summary: Grubhub reported third-quarter revenue of US$494 million, beating analysts' estimates of US$436.6 million. Sales rose 53% due to the Covid-19 pandemic boosting delivery orders, with a 41% increase in regular delivery orders. The company posted a profit of US$15.2 million, excluding some costs, beating analyst projections of a loss. Grubhub's shares jumped 3.7% in extended trading after the report, with gains of over 50% this year. The company's pending merger with Just Eat Takeaway.com is expected to close in the first half of 2021.

site_title: Pandemic prompts tumult in UK commercial property: RICS
summary: The UK commercial property market has experienced a downturn during the third quarter, with 78% of chartered surveyors viewing the market as being in a downturn, up from 76% in the second quarter. Demand for retail and office space has contracted sharply, with a less severe decline than in the second quarter. However, industrial sites, such as warehouses, have seen a pick-up in demand due to the shift to online shopping. The outlook for the year ahead has worsened due to changing working and shopping patterns during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon's case mention for alleged false trading, market rigging adjourned again
summary: Indonesian oil-and-gas tycoon Kris Wiluan's court case, alleging false trading and market rigging, has been adjourned to Nov 25, marking the second time the court has granted an adjournment. Wiluan faces 112 charges related to violating the Securities and Futures Act, stemming from share purchases between 2014 and 2016. The case involves allegations that Wiluan directed trades to push up KS Energy's share price, with Wiluan claiming his intentions were to help smaller shareholders.

site_title: Ikea's malls arm says expansion plans intact as customers return post-lockdown
summary: Ikea's shopping malls arm, Ingka Centres, has reported robust performance despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with footfall down by almost a quarter and tenant sales dropping 16% to 5.4 billion euros. Occupancy remained stable at 95% and expansion plans remain on track, with nearly doubling the number of malls in the coming years. Ingka Centres is shifting focus to smaller inner-city locations and has inked acquisitions in London and San Francisco. Despite challenges, the company believes it is well-positioned to handle near-term challenges and adapt to changing consumer behaviors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on renewed coronavirus worries
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on October 29, 2020, due to rising coronavirus worries. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.94% to 23,199.49, while the Topix index fell 0.91% to 1,597.87. The falls followed similar declines on Wall Street, with France and Germany announcing new restrictions and US cases continuing to climb.

site_title: Macron imposes new virus lockdown as French hospitals engulfed
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron announced a new coronavirus lockdown, effective Thursday, to combat a rapidly spreading outbreak that's overwhelming hospitals. The lockdown will last until at least December 1, with measures including closing bars, restaurants, and non-essential businesses, while allowing essential services and online classes. Macron warned that if the measures aren't implemented, the death toll could reach 400,000, with nearly 9,000 people in intensive care by mid-November.

site_title: US Q4 growth could be even weaker than projected, likely to hit Canadian exports: bank governor
summary: Canada's exports may be hit if US growth in the fourth quarter is weaker than predicted, according to Bank of Canada Governor Tiff Macklem. The US is Canada's largest export market, accounting for 75% of its goods exports. Macklem stated that if US growth slows, Canadian exports will likely suffer, despite the Canadian dollar performing better than expected since July. This could affect the competitiveness of Canadian exports.

site_title: SoftBank attempted to delay WeWork's US$3b share purchase: US court filing
summary: SoftBank's CEO Masayoshi Son instructed Marcelo Claure to delay a $3 billion US tender offer to repurchase WeWork shares, citing "buyer's remorse" amid the coronavirus outbreak. A court transcript reveals Son's text exchange with Claure, in which Son told Claure to "use whatever excuse" to delay the payment. WeWork's founder Adam Neumann and employees sued SoftBank over the decision, accusing it of improperly withholding documents. SoftBank maintains that it had no obligation to complete the tender offer, citing unmet conditions.

site_title: Gilead Sciences reports almost US$900m in Q3 remdesivir sales
summary: Gilead Sciences reported a 17% increase in third-quarter revenues to $6.6 billion, driven by nearly $900 million in sales of its remdesivir medication, sold under the brand name Veklury. Remdesivir has been shown to shorten recovery time for patients hospitalized with Covid-19. This marks a significant boost to the company's sales, with remdesivir sales contributing to the overall revenue growth.

site_title: Alibaba co-founder Lucy Peng to get US$5b richer on Ant IPO
summary: Alibaba co-founder Lucy Peng is set to become US$5 billion richer following Ant Group's record-breaking IPO, which values the fintech firm at US$320 billion. As Ant's former CEO and current executive chairman of Lazada Group, Peng has played a key role in guiding Alibaba's growth over the past two decades. She is one of the wealthiest women in the world and part of an elite group of 15 female billionaires created by Alibaba, with a combined stake value of US$14.5 billion. Peng's success is attributed to her behind-the-scenes work, particularly in human resources, and her ability to earn and retain the trust of Alibaba's founder, Jack Ma.

site_title: Banks don't want to lend to Australia coal miners any more
summary: Australia's largest bank, ANZ, will end almost all investment in thermal mines and power stations by 2030, further limiting financing options for coal miners. This move aligns with global financial institutions' shift away from coal investments due to shareholder and lobby group pressure. Despite this, Australia's mining lobby forecasts a 35% increase in Asian demand for thermal coal over the next decade, exacerbating the challenge faced by miners in securing funding for new operations or expanding existing assets.

images.alt_text: Financing options open to Australia's coal operators dwindled further after another of the country's largest banks said it would end almost all investment in thermal mines and power stations by 2030.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Keppel, Starhill Global Reit, UOI, Del Monte
summary: Key stocks to watch on Thursday include DBS, which is developing a digital currency exchange backed by Singapore's largest lender, and Keppel Corp, which clinched a S$300 million contract for a district cooling system plant. Starhill Global Reit reported a 10.3% drop in revenue and 19.2% drop in net property income for the first quarter. UOI saw its net profit shrink by 42% year on year to S$15.2 million for the first nine months. Del Monte Pacific raised S$182.3 million from fixed-rate bonds.

site_title: Petrobras cuts losses to US$236m in Q3
summary: Brazil's state-run oil giant Petrobras reported a net loss of US$236 million for the third quarter of 2020, its third negative result due to the coronavirus pandemic. This is a significant improvement from the company's losses of US$417 million in the second quarter and US$9.7 billion in the first quarter. Despite the pandemic, Petrobras' operational and financial performance improved, with higher oil and natural gas production, capacity utilization of refineries, and strong cash flow generation. The company attributed the losses to financial expenses, with higher sales volumes of oil and oil by-products and Brent oil prices.

site_title: Is Trump or Biden a win for commodities?
summary: Commodity prices are expected to rise in 2021 regardless of the outcome of the US presidential election, driven by low interest rates, trillions in US fiscal stimulus, and growing vaccine optimism. Experts predict higher prices for industrial metals, such as fuel, copper, and zinc, under a Biden presidency, while a Trump win could also benefit gold and silver. However, the outcome may also lead to increased volatility in oil prices, with a Biden victory potentially dampening demand due to green energy investments.

site_title: Regeneron announces more positive results for Covid-19 treatment
summary: Regeneron announced positive results from its ongoing clinical trial for Covid-19 treatment REGN-COV2. The study found that the treatment significantly reduced viral load and the need for medical attention in non-hospitalized patients. The trial involved over 500 patients and showed a 57% relative risk reduction in Covid-19 related medical visits. The treatment also reduced medical visits by 72% in patients with underlying conditions. Regeneron has already applied for emergency use authorization for its drug.

site_title: US plays down China sanctions over Taiwan arms
summary: The US has downplayed China's threats to impose sanctions on US companies involved in selling arms to Taiwan, with a top State Department official stating that Beijing's actions are jeopardizing regional stability. China has threatened sanctions on Lockheed Martin and Boeing over a nearly $2 billion missile sale to Taiwan, but US officials say this is not the first time Beijing has made such threats. The US is obligated to provide defense weapons to Taiwan, and officials claim China's provocations are the real issue, not Taiwan's self-defense efforts.

site_title: Melbourne opens up dining, shopping as lockdown lifts
summary: Melbourne lifts its four-month coronavirus lockdown, allowing shops, restaurants, and hotels to reopen. The state of Victoria has seen a significant decrease in cases, with only two new cases and two deaths reported overnight. The reopening is seen as a major achievement for the state, with around 180,000 workers able to return to work on site. The city's residents are enjoying outdoor dining and shopping, with many expressing excitement about the return to normalcy.

site_title: ANZ full-year profit plunges on expected virus fallout
summary: ANZ Bank reported a 40% plunge in post-tax profit for the full year ending September 30, 2020, to A$3.58 billion, due to A$2.74 billion in credit impairment charges and A$815 million for virus-related lending losses in Asia. About 119,000 home loans were deferred, with 40,000 frozen and 11,000 requesting extensions. The bank also announced a new climate change policy, excluding finance for new thermal coal mines or coal-fired power stations from 2030, drawing criticism from the conservative government.

site_title: Europe: FTSE 100 dives to 6-month low on lockdown fears, Brexit uncertainty
summary: London's FTSE 100 index fell to a 6-month low, closing 2.6% lower due to fears of more lockdowns and Brexit uncertainty. Investors dumped riskier assets amid concerns over a potential new lockdown to tackle a second wave of infections. The mid-cap FTSE 250 index also slid 1.9% to a 3-week low. The FTSE 100's decline was attributed to losses in mining, personal goods, and bank stocks. Investors await the UK government's one-year plan on November 25, which will focus on tackling the pandemic and protecting jobs.

site_title: As Manila's online casinos flounder, their workers vacate homes, cooling property market
summary: Manila's online casinos are exiting the city, causing a decline in property values and rents. Vacancies from the industry are contributing to a decrease in occupancy rates, with nearly 47,800 square meters of vacated work spaces in the third quarter. Rents in residential condominiums are expected to fall 10% on average by year end, with some areas potentially seeing a 25% decline. The Philippine online gaming industry, worth $8 billion, is struggling due to higher taxes and weaker demand, leading to a decrease in property prices and rents.

site_title: Huawei executive's lawyers accuse Canada federal police of lying
summary: A defence lawyer for Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou accused a Canadian policeman of giving a "not honest" reply during a hearing on her extradition to the US. Meng is wanted on fraud charges related to US sanctions in Iran. Defence lawyer Richard Peck questioned Constable Winston Yep's testimony about delaying her arrest in December 2018, claiming "safety reasons" were not the actual reason. The defence alleges Canadian authorities conspired with the US to delay Meng's arrest and obtain information, violating her rights. The extradition case is set to wrap up in April 2021.

site_title: Government's operating revenue down S$12.6b in H1
summary: The Singapore government's operating revenue decreased by S$12.6 billion in the first half of 2020 compared to the same period last year, primarily due to lower corporate income tax collections. This was largely attributed to corporate income tax deferment and rebates granted in the Budget. The government's total expenditure rose by S$4.9 billion, with an increase in operating expenditure offsetting a decline in development expenditure. The primary deficit widened to S$18.8 billion, or 8.3% of GDP, due to increased spending on health and manpower.

site_title: Airbnb's choice of IPO venue a big win for Nasdaq over NYSE
summary: Airbnb has chosen to list its shares on the Nasdaq Global Select Market, marking a win for the exchange over the New York Stock Exchange. The home-rental company will seek to raise up to $3 billion in an IPO, with its valuation estimated at around $22 billion. This decision comes after the company split its shares, increasing their value from $31 billion to $34.88 per share. The listing is a significant milestone for Airbnb, which has seen a rebound in bookings after the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Iata renews calls for goverment relief measures to sustain airlines
summary: The International Air Transport Association (Iata) has reiterated its call for government relief measures to sustain airlines financially, citing severe cash burn and reduced revenues due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Airlines' revenues are expected to be 46% lower than 2019 levels in 2021, with median airlines having just 8.5 months of cash left. Iata director-general Alexandre de Juniac warned that massive job losses are at risk, with 1.3 million airline jobs and 3.5 million additional jobs in the broader economy potentially affected if governments do not act quickly.

site_title: Exxon Mobil keeps quarterly dividend flat for first time since 1982
summary: Exxon Mobil has kept its quarterly dividend flat at 87 cents per share, marking the first time since 1982 that the US oil producer has not raised its shareholder payout. The decision, made as the company is expected to announce cost and jobs cuts, suggests that it expects the cost-cutting measures to allow it to maintain the dividend. Exxon shares traded at their lowest point in over two decades, down 3.8% on the day. The company is projected to report a full-year loss of $2 billion, excluding asset sales or write downs.

images.alt_text: Exxon Mobil Corp on Wednesday kept its fourth-quarter dividend flat at 87 cents a share, signaling 2020 will be the first year since 1982 that the US oil producer has not raised its shareholder payout.

site_title: Ford shares jump after strong Q3 profits
summary: Ford reported a 5x increase in Q3 profits to $2.4 billion, driven by strong sales in North America, particularly for the F-Series pickup truck and revamped Explorer. Revenues rose 1% to $37.5 billion, with pre-tax profit margins reaching 12.5% globally. Newly-installed CEO Jim Farley said the company has a clear turnaround plan, despite acknowledging manufacturing stumbles and strategy questions. Ford shares jumped 2.8% to $7.70 in after-hours trading.

images.alt_text: Ford reported a big jump in third-quarter profits on Wednesday, pointing to strong sales in North America where large vehicles commanded generous prices amid tight inventories.

site_title: The pessimist's guide to Jack Ma's record-breaking Ant IPO
summary: Ant Group Co.'s record-breaking IPO has sparked concerns about the company's long-term viability. Despite a strong demand for the US$34.5 billion listing, Ant faces numerous risks, including regulatory scrutiny in China, competition from rivals like Tencent and JD.com, and potential restrictions from the US government. The company's dominance in China's payments infrastructure is under threat, and its lending business may be impacted by changes in the country's financial regulations. With a valuation of at least US$315 billion, investors will need to carefully consider these risks when evaluating Ant's stock price.

site_title: Relief, not celebration, as Berlin's new airport finally gets ready for take-off
summary: Berlin's new airport, Berlin Brandenburg Airport (BER), will finally open on Saturday, nine years late and over budget, amidst a global pandemic that has crippled air travel. The airport, set to replace Germany's ageing Tegel and Schoenefeld airports, has been plagued by failures and is expected to see only 20% of usual air traffic in November due to the pandemic. Lufthansa and EasyJet will be the first two airlines to operate, but the opening is marked by relief rather than celebration, with many shops and restaurants closed due to low traffic.

site_title: Deutsche Bank lifts outlook after Q3 results beat estimates
summary: Deutsche Bank raised its outlook after beating estimates in Q3 with a 47% increase in income from trading fixed-income securities and currencies, surpassing Goldman Sachs' 49% increase. The bank posted an unexpected profit of €182 million, driven by a market rally that started late last year. Despite rising provisions for bad loans, the bank said it's on track to meet financial and strategic targets. CEO Christian Sewing attributed the results to cost discipline and market share gain, easing concerns about the bank's performance.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q1 revenue down 10.3%
summary: Starhill Global Reit's revenue for the first quarter ended Sept 30 fell 10.3% to S$43.1 million, with net property income dropping 19.2% to S$29.8 million. The decline was mainly due to rental assistance for pandemic-affected tenants. The Reit's Singapore properties contributed 62.4% of total revenue, while its Australian properties contributed the rest. The Reit manager also unveiled a distribution reinvestment plan and secured new committed revolving credit facilities.

site_title: Oil plunges over 5% to four-month low as pandemic surges, US crude output soars
summary: Oil prices plummeted over 5% on Wednesday, reaching a four-month low, due to surging COVID-19 cases in the US and Europe, prompting renewed lockdowns and reduced fuel demand. US crude stockpiles also rose unexpectedly as production surged, further pressuring prices. Brent futures fell $2.08, or 5.1%, to $39.12 a barrel, while US WTI crude fell $2.18, or 5.5%, to $37.39. The decline mirrored downturns in other risk-asset markets, with the US dollar rising as investors sought safe-haven assets.

site_title: Mercedes rescues Aston Martin with bigger stake, partnership
summary: Mercedes-Benz is increasing its stake in Aston Martin to up to 20% as part of a technology partnership aimed at shoring up the struggling luxury carmaker's finances. Aston Martin will raise £1.3 billion through new bond and stock offerings and refinancing debt. The partnership will give Mercedes access to Aston Martin's technology in exchange for new shares. Mercedes CEO Ola Kallenius stated that the company has no intention to acquire Aston Martin but aims to generate economies of scale by supplying electric car technology.

site_title: SingPost has limited rating headroom after FMH deal: S&P
summary: SingPost's debt-to-Ebitda ratio is expected to rise to 2.5 times in 2021 and 2.3 times in 2022 due to its acquisition of a 38% stake in Australian logistics firm Freight Management Holdings (FMH). Although the deal is earnings accretive, it coincides with weakened earnings and heightened operating costs during the Covid-19 pandemic. S&P Global Ratings expects SingPost's near-term earnings outlook to remain subdued, with the benefits of business integration and synergies taking time to materialize.

site_title: Singapore-Hong Kong travel may start next month
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are set to launch their air-travel bubble in November, allowing travelers to visit without quarantine requirements. The arrangement, which will enable travel between the two cities, will require travelers to have been in either city for 14 days, take Covid-19 tests, and have a negative result. A quota will be in place to manage the number of travelers, which may be adjusted based on case numbers. The bubble aims to revive air travel between the two aviation hubs in a safe manner.

site_title: Data protection and privacy in three dimensions
summary: A flaw in consent-driven frameworks for personal data collection and use has been highlighted, with the Netflix documentary "The Social Dilemma" and new provisions in the Personal Data Protection Act emphasizing a three-dimensional approach. This approach considers the interests of individuals, companies, and society as a whole, recognizing that data use extends beyond personal data and that purpose, unsurprisingness, respect, and explainability are essential. The new provisions also introduce business improvement, legitimate interests, research, and contractual necessity exceptions, while tightening data breach notification requirements and enhancing penalties for misuse.

site_title: JustCo to open co-working space at Razer HQ in 2021
summary: JustCo, a Singapore-based co-working space provider, will open its 19th facility at Razer's Southeast Asian headquarters in 2021. The 2,787 sqm space will cater to gaming hardware and consumer electronics companies, as well as corporate members seeking decentralised workspaces. The location near one-north's key districts is expected to provide strategic proximity for Razer and JustCo's members. This expansion follows recent openings at OCBC Centre East and The Centrepoint, and JustCo currently has over 25,000 members across five countries.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: TikTok to hire 3,000 engineers as it expands globally
summary: TikTok plans to hire approximately 3,000 engineers globally over the next three years, primarily in Europe, Canada, and Singapore, to support its rapid expansion despite lingering uncertainty over its ownership. The US engineering hub will continue to grow, with nearly half of the current 1,000 engineers based in California. This move comes amid ongoing discussions about the app's ownership and potential US ban on downloads.

site_title: Ant Group's public tranche for accredited investors
summary: Ant Group, part of Alibaba group, is set to raise approximately US$34.5 billion through its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong and Shanghai. Accredited investors in Singapore can subscribe to the public portion of its shares through online broking platforms, with a minimum subscription amount of HK$4,040.31 (S$712). Retail investors, however, will have to wait and buy on the open market, requiring a minimum investable amount of S$200,000.

images.alt_text: Ant Group - which is part of the Alibaba group - is set to raise about US$34.5 billion when its shares begin trading in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

site_title: CDL: Financial performance goes beyond Return on Equity
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) has responded to criticism of its weaker Return on Equity (ROE) in recent years, citing a structural shift in the Singapore real estate market and a strategy to increase recurring income and enhance business sustainability. The company's Growth, Enhancement and Transformation (GET) strategy, unveiled in 2018, aims to address these challenges through fund management, new partnerships, and value creation. CDL has also taken steps to improve its cost structures and efficiencies, such as privatising Millennium & Copthorne Hotels, and has invested in Sincere Property Group to tap into China's large population.

site_title: Delve into architecture, heritage, history
summary: The Golden Mile Complex in Singapore has been spared from demolition, marking a breakthrough in preserving iconic buildings for future generations. Conservation experts will discuss adapting these spaces for modern uses, bridging history and younger generations. Meanwhile, travel company Trafalgar offers an in-depth history tour, while local writer Clara Chow shares a travelogue. Additionally, a new Masterclass teaches personal style, and a private dining Chinese restaurant offers customized meals. These stories highlight the importance of preserving heritage sites and engaging with history in innovative ways.

site_title: China's Sinopec flips to quarterly profit on robust refining business
summary: China's Sinopec Corp reported a record quarterly profit of 46.39 billion yuan in July-September, nearly quadrupling its level a year earlier, driven by a robust refining business and earnings from the spin-off of pipeline assets. The firm's refinery crude throughput rose 2% year-on-year to 63.5 million tonnes, while domestic fuel sales increased 0.4% to 45.44 million tonnes. This marks the highest quarterly profit since Refinitiv Eikon data began tracking in 2003.

site_title: Vintage Alfa Romeos auctioned at Sotheby's
summary: Alfa Romeo's three iconic BAT cars, designed by Franco Scaglione, were auctioned at Sotheby's in New York, with a predicted hammer price of $14-20 million. The vehicles, built in 1953-1955, represent "possibly the best examples of cars as works of art" and feature aerodynamic attributes comparable to modern-day cars, including the Tesla Model 3 and Porsche's Taycan Turbo. The cars are being sold as a united group for the first time, alongside works by postwar Italian artists and designers, and will be displayed alongside paintings by notable artists.

site_title: Jaguar posts its first profit in three quarters
summary: Jaguar Land Rover Automotive Plc has posted its first profit in three quarters, with a £65 million profit before tax for the three months ended September 30. The company's Indian owner, Tata Motors Ltd, reported a wider quarterly loss, but shares jumped as Jaguar's improving performance helps cushion Tata Motors from the crisis. Sales are expected to pick up in the third quarter, but risks include the resurgent virus in Europe and the US, and Brexit uncertainties. Analysts rate Tata Motors a buy, with 19 out of 28 tracked by Bloomberg.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical shares see heavy trading after completing share placement
summary: Jiutian Chemical completed a share placement, raising S$10.3 million through a non-underwritten placement of 170 million new shares at 6.03 Singapore cents apiece. The company's shares saw heavy trading, with 118.5 million shares changing hands, reaching an intraday high of 8.7 Singapore cents. The placement shares represent about 8.55% of the enlarged issued share capital. Net proceeds will be used for general working capital and potential investments in asset enhancement and improvement. The company's non-executive chairman stated the firm will focus on maximizing returns from its stable assets while exploring expansion opportunities.

site_title: China's growth is 'virtually unstoppable', says George Yeo
summary: Former Singapore foreign affairs minister George Yeo predicts China's growth will be "virtually unstoppable" despite the global economic downturn, with the country potentially surpassing the US and Europe as the world's biggest economy by the end of the decade. Yeo attributes China's resilience to its dual circulation strategy, effective containment of Covid-19, and increasing interest in local content. He warns that populist movements and potential conflicts over Taiwan pose significant concerns for South-east Asia, but emphasizes the importance of regional cooperation and Singapore's role as a hub for arbitrage.

site_title: Federal Reserve is really running out of firepower
summary: The US Federal Reserve is nearing its limit of firepower to support the economy, and additional monetary policy measures may not provide significant additional support. Despite low interest rates and accommodative financial conditions, the economy's growth is already strong, and further rate cuts may not have a substantial impact. The stimulus from lower interest rates wears off over time, and prolonged low interest rates can become counterproductive, potentially leading to lower future returns and reduced consumer spending. The government's spending plans will be crucial in supporting the economy, and policymakers should focus on fiscal stimulus to address the economy's needs.

images.alt_text: Even if the Fed did more - much more - it would not provide much additional support to the economy.

site_title: S&P 500 tumbles in worst rout in almost two months
summary: The S&P 500 plummeted 3% in its worst rout in almost two months, amid rising coronavirus infections and tougher lockdowns. Energy shares sank as oil prices declined, while technology stocks also fell. Boeing slumped to a one-month low after announcing job cuts, and Microsoft declined despite a profit report. Analysts warn of increased market volatility ahead of the US presidential election, citing concerns about a contested outcome and harsh lockdowns.

site_title: DBS creates buzz with its plans for crypto currency exchange
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, is developing a digital currency exchange backed by the bank, pending regulatory approval. The exchange will list four top cryptocurrencies against multiple fiat currencies and allow companies to raise capital via security tokens tied to actual assets. The exchange will not hold any crypto assets but will use an institutional-grade custodian. Industry observers see this as a significant step in institutional endorsement of crypto assets, potentially reinforcing trust in the asset class.

site_title: Fortuna Hotel up for sale with S$98.8m guide price
summary: The 7-storey Fortuna Hotel in Singapore's Owen Road area has been launched for sale by tender with a guide price of S$98.8 million, according to CBRE. The freehold site has a gross plot ratio of 3.0 and is zoned for hotel use. The property features 106 rooms, a restaurant, and retail shops, and is expected to appeal to investors with a long-term investment horizon. The sale will not incur additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty, and foreigners are eligible to buy.

images.alt_text: The guide price of S$98.8 million for Fortuna Hotel works out to about S$932,000 per key, or S$2,060 per square foot on the current gross floor area.

site_title: US firms splurge on insurance to protect against post-election chaos
summary: US retailers, pharmacies, and other businesses are buying insurance to protect against potential damage from post-election chaos. Despite double-digit premium hikes, they are purchasing the insurance to avoid potential losses. The sales of commercial policies covering damage from societal unrest have doubled in October from September levels. This is partly due to insurers removing "strikes, riots and civil commotion" coverage from general property policies, forcing businesses to buy separate insurance. The uncertainty surrounding the presidential election and potential violent protests is driving this surge in insurance sales.

site_title: Can Trump do a 'Dewey defeats Truman' (2020 edition)?
summary: US President Donald Trump may not replicate his 2016 surprise victory, as the populist surge is fizzling. Unlike in 2016, when Trump rode a wave of opposition to immigration and free trade, the COVID-19 pandemic has reduced immigration concerns. Trump's handling of the pandemic, including mocking healthcare doctors, has alienated women, suburban, and college-educated voters. Additionally, his nativist policies have led to a decline in support from these groups. The article suggests that the Trumpists are making the same mistake as the Clintonites in 2016, relying on an outdated narrative of a major political realignment.

site_title: Cities must reassess what is needed post-pandemic
summary: Cities must reassess their needs post-pandemic, focusing on managing water, harnessing technology, investing in R&D, and prioritizing people. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for urban planners and municipalities to rethink public infrastructure and services. Smart cities, which incorporate digitalization into urban planning, have demonstrated greater effectiveness in handling the pandemic. Cities like Singapore, which have successfully implemented digital solutions, are leading the way in building resilient and sustainable communities. Investing in water management, research and development, and education are key to transforming cities and preparing them for future challenges.

site_title: Labour market recovery likely to be weak, uneven, gradual: MAS
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to gradually recover as the economy re-opens, but the recovery is likely to be weak, uneven, and long-drawn. Unemployment is forecast to decline more gradually than it did after the Global Financial Crisis. Retail and F&B sales staged a "V-shaped" recovery, and construction activities have resumed. However, sectors such as travel-related and transport equipment sectors are expected to remain subdued, and consumption patterns may persistently dampen labour demand.

site_title: LVMH, Tiffany agree on lower price in takeover deal: sources
summary: LVMH has agreed to pay US$131.50 per share to acquire Tiffany, a US$3.50 reduction from the initial deal agreed in November. The two companies had been involved in a Delaware court dispute, with Tiffany seeking US$135 per share. The revised price is a result of negotiations between the two sides.

site_title: Fashion's past and present commune at New York's Met Museum of Art
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute in New York has opened an exhibition titled "About Time" to celebrate the museum's 150th anniversary. The show, which runs until February 7, 2023, explores 150 years of fashion from 1870 to the present, presenting past and present in a disrupted timeline. The exhibition highlights how fashion captures time and spirit, with modern designers reinterpreting and reusing elements from the past, such as the iconic Chanel jacket. The show also includes a contribution from Black American designer Stephen Burrows, following the museum's decision to include diversity efforts in all future exhibitions.

site_title: STI posts third consecutive day of declines amid economic gloom
summary: Singapore shares posted their third consecutive day of losses, closing at a near five-week low of 2,483.48 after falling 29.39 points or 1.17 per cent. The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 15.3 index points due to losses from three banking stalwarts DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The losses were attributed to economic gloom, the Covid-19 surge, and risks tied to the US election, with Wall Street experiencing a wobbly session overnight.

site_title: MPA to issue up to two more LNG bunker supplier licences
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) plans to issue up to two additional LNG bunker supplier licences to support growing demand for LNG bunkering in Singapore. MPA has launched a request for proposal for parties seeking to supply LNG bunker to the Port of Singapore, requiring an end-to-end solution with details on LNG supply and delivery model. This move aims to enhance the Port's LNG bunkering capabilities and meet increasing demand for the fuel.

site_title: Microsoft cloud business gathers steam as pandemic boosts growth
summary: Microsoft's cloud business saw a boost in growth during the pandemic, with Azure revenue increasing 48% and daily users of its Teams messaging software rising to 115 million. The company's commercial cloud gross margins improved to 71% due to sales of lucrative software such as Dynamics 365. Revenue from its personal computing division, including Windows software and Xbox gaming consoles, rose 6%. Net income increased to $13.89 billion, beating analysts' expectations, with Microsoft forecasting continued strong growth for Azure.

images.alt_text: The pandemic has helped Microsoft's latest quarterly earnings beat expectations by about 30 per cent.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler returns to profit
summary: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) reported a net profit of 1.2 billion euros in the third quarter, exceeding expectations after a massive loss in the previous quarter. Sales fell 6.0% to 25.8 billion euros, with total vehicle sales down 3.0%. The company cited its presence in new market segments and a 10% increase in Europe-Middle East unit sales. FCA and PSA reiterated their merger plans by the end of the first quarter next year. This marks a significant turnaround for the Italian-American auto giant after a downturn sparked by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Heathrow airport loses European crown during pandemic
summary: Heathrow Airport has lost its title as Europe's busiest airport to Paris Charles de Gaulle during the pandemic, blaming the UK government for its slow response to introducing airport testing and quarantine rules. Heathrow's passenger numbers have plummeted 84% in three months, leading to a £1.5 billion loss for the first nine months of the year. The airport expects 37 million passengers in 2021, 41% lower than forecast. CEO John Holland-Kaye urges the government to take action to revive the UK's global trade ambitions and secure quarantine-free travel to the US.

site_title: Japan PM Suga to announce plan for fresh stimulus package
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga will announce a fresh stimulus package next week to help the recession-stricken economy recover from the coronavirus crisis. The package size is yet to be decided, but some lawmakers have called for around 10 trillion yen (S$130.8 billion) to cushion the blow. This move comes amid a slowdown in China's GDP growth, which may put pressure on policymakers. The announcement is expected to provide relief to the Japanese economy, which has been impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Merkel eyes tough new curbs to tame virus before Christmas
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel is proposing new, strict COVID-19 restrictions in Germany, including limiting contact outdoors to two households, closing bars, cafes, and restaurants, and shutting hotels except for essential purposes. The measures aim to halt surging infections and save the Christmas holiday season. Some states, like Thuringia, oppose the plan, citing economic concerns, while Bavaria's premier calls for tougher, nationally applicable rules. Merkel aims to "break the infection momentum" and avoid restricting personal contact and economic activities over Christmas.

images.alt_text: Bars, cafes, restaurants would have to shut, although takeaways and delivery services can keep going.

site_title: The US' global role is at stake in this election
summary: The US presidential election is crucial, as the country's role in the world is at stake. A Trump re-election would undo much of the legacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt, including the US's status as a model of liberal democracy and leader of global challenges. Trump's presidency would reject these values, and his defeat would not necessarily resolve the issue, as American politics needs transformation. The world relies on the US's unique role, and a change in leadership is necessary to address global challenges, including climate change and rising autocratic powers like China.

site_title: SIA Engineering to book impairment against base maintenance unit's assets
summary: SIA Engineering Co, the aircraft maintenance arm of Singapore Airlines, will recognize a non-cash impairment provision against its base maintenance unit's assets due to a significant decline in hangar revenue projections caused by lower flight hours and parked aircraft. This is expected to have a material impact on the group's financial results for the first half of its fiscal year. The impairment is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic's adverse impact on the aviation industry. SIAEC is finalizing its unaudited consolidated financial results and expects to release them in early November.

site_title: AMD's US$35b deal pushes 2020 towards a record for chip M&A
summary: AMD's US$35 billion acquisition of Xilinx Inc pushes 2020 towards a record year for chip mergers and acquisitions, with US$110 billion in deals announced this year. The semiconductor industry is experiencing increased competition as companies like Apple and Nvidia design their own chips and established players expand into new areas. The deal gives AMD access to programmable chips for wireless networks and expands its presence in the data-centre market. If acquisitions continue at the current pace, 2020 is likely to top the 2016 record of US$122 billion in semiconductor deals.

site_title: Malaysia's anti-graft agency probes AirAsia's RM300 million bank loan
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, MACC, has launched an investigation into a RM300 million (S$98.5 million) loan from Sabah Development Bank to AirAsia Group Bhd. The loan, approved on July 2, was used to establish a digital food supply chain and cold chain facilities in Sabah. The investigation was initiated after Sabah's new Chief Minister Hajiji Noor ordered a forensic review of the bank's decision. AirAsia has declined to comment on the matter, while former Chief Minister Shafie Apdal has welcomed the investigation, stating that the loan was approved after thorough consideration.

site_title: Singapore's recovery to take longer than past recessions: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has forecast that the pace of Singapore's recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic will moderate in the quarters ahead, with the economy likely to take longer to recover than in past recessions. Unemployment is expected to edge down gradually in 2021, and some pockets of the economy, such as travel-related and contact-intensive services, may not recover to pre-pandemic levels until health risks abate. The MAS also expects growth momentum to slow in Q4 and remain modest in 2021, with a forecast range of a 5 to 7 per cent contraction for the economy this year.

images.alt_text: In past recessions, Singapore's economy took about four quarters to fall from peak to trough. In this Covid-19 crisis, the trough occurred by Q2 and was much deeper.

site_title: In a battered New York office market, life science is flourishing
summary: The New York office market, battered by the pandemic, is experiencing a resurgence in life science real estate. Developers are investing heavily, with rent for labs averaging US$105 per square foot in Manhattan. Funding from investors is pouring in, driven by government initiatives and a flood of private venture capital. The city's life science cluster is expected to grow, with several projects underway in Manhattan, West Harlem, and Long Island City. However, experts caution that the sector's growth is still limited, and it may take 25 years for the sector to mature.

site_title: STMicroelectronics, A*Star unit, Ulvac in Singapore R&D tie-up
summary: STMicroelectronics has formed a research and development (R&D) line at its wafer fab in Singapore with A*Star and Ulvac, marking a three-way public-private tie-up. The 1,300 sq m cleanroom is expected to produce its first wafers in Q2 2021 and scale up production by end-2022. The facility will focus on piezoelectric micro-electromechanical system (piezo Mems) technology, bridging the gap between prototyping and high-volume production, and will employ "several tens" of new and redeployed Mems R&D personnel.

site_title: Revisiting the 'unknowns' - known and unknown alike
summary: The US presidential election, set to take place in a week, is a "known unknown" due to uncertainty in polls and past election outcomes. A Biden win could lead to increased corporate taxes and less fractious trade policy, while a Trump win would boost US stocks but add to geopolitical risks. Markets tend to react negatively to a Democratic win and positively to a Republican victory. Despite this, equity strategists believe stocks would still be a "buy" due to central banks' support for economies. A global debt crisis could also emerge from unprecedented monetary and fiscal support, posing a "known unknown" risk.

site_title: Smart-cities lab opens in Singapore Science Park
summary: Singapore's Smart Urban Co-Innovation Lab, the first industry-led smart cities solutions development lab in South-east Asia, has opened in the 55-hectare Singapore Science Park. The lab, powered by 5G connectivity, aims to bring together leaders in the smart cities space to co-create and test innovations in six industry verticals. It will benefit 200 companies in Singapore over the next three years and is supported by CapitaLand, the Infocomm Media Development Authority, and Enterprise Singapore, with a committed investment of up to S$10 million.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q1 revenue down 10.3%
summary: Starhill Global Reit's Q1 revenue fell 10.3% to S$43.1 million, mainly due to rental assistance and rebates for affected tenants during the pandemic. Net property income dropped 19.2% to S$29.8 million. Revenue from Singapore properties (62.4%) and Australia properties (24.3%) contributed to the decline, while appreciation of the Australian dollar offset the variance.

site_title: Malaysia's anti-graft agency probes AirAsia's bank loan
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft agency, the Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC), is investigating a RM300 million ($98.6 million) loan from Sabah Development Bank to AirAsia Group, a budget airline. The loan was approved on July 2 and disbursed quickly after the installation of the new state government. The investigation will look into whether there were any violations in the loan approval process. AirAsia has declined to comment on the matter, while the airline's former Chief Minister, Shafie Apdal, welcomed the investigation, stating that the application was thoroughly reviewed before approval.

site_title: Malaysia summons French diplomat over alleged anti-Islam speech
summary: Malaysia has summoned France's charges d'affaires over alleged anti-Islam speech, with the Southeast Asian nation strongly condemning remarks defending the display of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammad in a French school classroom. Malaysia's foreign minister stated that the nation upholds freedom of speech while also protecting the rights of others, and the French embassy defended French President Emmanuel Macron's remarks as not targeting the Muslim community at large but rather radical Islamism. The dispute follows the beheading of a French teacher who showed the cartoons to his pupils.

site_title: US: Wall St slumps as rise in virus cases dims economic outlook
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 361.05 points, or 1.31%, to 27,102.14. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 down 61.54 points, or 1.81%, to 3,329.14. Rising coronavirus cases in the US and Europe dimmed hopes of a global economic recovery, contributing to the market downturn.

site_title: Swiss enact new restrictions, mask rules to slow Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Switzerland has introduced new restrictions to slow the spread of Covid-19, including closing dance clubs, halting in-person university classes, and limiting sporting and leisure activities. Masks are required in offices, schools, and outdoors when people come too close together. The measures, which include capping events to 50 people or less, are indefinite. Sporting and cultural activities with more than 15 people are banned. The goal is to contain the country's rising wave of Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Record US Q3 growth assured as goods trade deficit falls, inventories rise
summary: The US economy is expected to experience record growth in the third quarter due to a narrowed goods trade deficit and rising inventories. The data, released by the Commerce Department, follows reports of strong retail sales, durable goods orders, and housing growth. The economic surge is attributed to the $3 trillion government rescue package, which has since been exhausted, leaving the outlook for the fourth quarter uncertain amid the resurgence of new coronavirus cases.

site_title: Mastercard shares fall as profit drops on virus-led travel slowdown
summary: Mastercard's quarterly profit fell short of analyst estimates due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on global travel and related spending. The company reported a 36% drop in cross-border volume and a 1% increase in gross dollar volume to $1.6 trillion. Mastercard's shares dropped over 4% as a result. The pandemic has led to reduced spending power and a decline in cross-border card transactions, affecting Mastercard's earnings.

site_title: GE reports smaller loss as business recovers from pandemic lows
summary: General Electric reported a smaller quarterly loss of $1.2 billion, down from $9.5 billion a year earlier, due to cost cuts and revenue improvements in its power business. The company expects industrial free cash flow to be at least $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter and positive in 2021. Revenue at GE's aviation unit fell 39% in the quarter, while the power business saw a 3% increase. GE plans to cut $2 billion in costs, primarily in its aviation unit.

site_title: Second Chance Properties posts 66% fall in H2 profits to $914,000
summary: Second Chance Properties reported a 66% year-over-year decline in H2 profits to $914,000, but a 6% year-over-year decline in full-year profits to $4.45 million. The group's apparel segment experienced a 65% decline in revenues, while rental revenue from properties fell 35%. The COVID-19 pandemic and changing consumer preferences contributed to the decline. However, the group's gold business saw a 53% year-over-year increase in profits, and government support measures boosted its bottom line. The company expects to continue adapting to new challenges to ensure long-term sustainability.

site_title: Boeing to cut 7,000 more jobs as it reports another loss
summary: Boeing announced additional job cuts of 7,000 employees through the end of 2021, bringing the headcount down to around 130,000, as the company adapts to a prolonged downturn in the aviation industry. The planemaker reported a third-quarter loss of $449 million, with revenues falling 29.2% to $14.1 billion, due to a sharp drop in commercial plane travel and the ongoing grounding of the 737 MAX. The company aims to transform its enterprise to be "sharper, more resilient and more sustainable for the long term."

images.alt_text: Pressured by another quarterly loss, Boeing announced Wednesday additional job cuts as it adapts to a prolonged downturn in the aviation industry.

site_title: Hummingbird gets green light for Covid-19 antibody clinical trial study
summary: Biotech startup Hummingbird Biosciences has received approval from Singapore's Health Sciences Authority for a clinical trial of its experimental antibody therapy, HMBD-115, against SARS-CoV-2. The therapy has shown significant therapeutic benefit in pre-clinical data and is undergoing Phase I and II trials with early read-outs expected in December. This marks a significant milestone for the company, entering the clinic for its first pipeline asset. The trials aim to understand the optimal mechanisms of action and effective treatment strategies for Covid-19 patients.

site_title: EH-Reit trustee to remove management following MAS notice
summary: The trustee of Eagle Hospitality Reit's (EH-Reit) manager, DBS Trustee Limited, intends to comply with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) direction to remove EH-Reit Management and appoint a new manager. The MAS issued a Notice of Intention (NOI) following breaches of the Securities and Futures Act and concerns over the manager's ability to comply with rules and regulations. A new manager will be announced "imminently" and will be chosen based on their focus on long-term rehabilitation and alignment with EH-Reit's objectives.

site_title: Egypt collector accumulated over 100 vintage cars
summary: Egypt collector Sayed Sima, known as "Sima," has accumulated over 100 vintage cars, many of which he keeps in Egypt's Media Production City. Sima, 25 when he started collecting, was drawn to their beauty and rarity. His oldest car, an Auburn from the 1980s, features a wooden frame and steel coating. Sima's son, Ayman, shares his passion, having grown up seeing their cars in movies. Notably, former Egyptian president Anwar El Sadat once rode in one of Sima's cars, a black 1975 Chevrolet Impala.

site_title: Del Monte's Philippine unit raises 6.5b pesos from bond offering
summary: Del Monte Pacific's Philippines unit has raised 6.47 billion pesos (S$182.3 million) from a maiden bond offering to lower borrowing costs and lengthen debt maturity. The 3-year and 5-year bonds were 1.29 times oversubscribed and will be listed on the Philippine Dealing & Exchange Corporation on October 30. Proceeds will be used to refinance existing short-term loans and convert them into long-term liabilities.

site_title: DBS plans crypto exchange
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, is planning a digital currency exchange that will list four top cryptocurrencies against multiple fiat currencies. The exchange, called DBS Digital Exchange, will allow companies to raise private capital through security tokens tied to actual assets, but will not hold any crypto assets. The bank is still seeking regulatory approval, which has not been received yet. The move is seen as part of Singapore's growing crypto scene, which has ranked among the world's top three markets for initial coin offerings since 2017.

site_title: Three-line MRT fault: Alstom to replace 150km of power cables on Tuas West Extension
summary: A three-line MRT fault on the Tuas West Extension in Singapore led to a massive disruption, leaving 6,700 passengers stranded for up to three hours. Alstom will replace 150km of power cables by end-2021, with tougher insulation and replace 113 trip coils by the end of the year. The fault was caused by a faulty trip coil and human error, prompting SMRT to suspend staff and enhance procedures for power recovery.

images.alt_text: All electrical power cables along the Tuas West Extension will be replaced following a massive three-line breakdown which left more than 6,700 passengers stuck on stranded trains for up to three hours on Oct 14.

site_title: Infrastructure investment to lead South-east Asia's recovery
summary: A joint report by Deloitte and Infrastructure Asia (IA) suggests that infrastructure investment will be crucial in South-east Asia's recovery from the pandemic. Infrastructure development has a strong multiplier effect, boosting economic activity and creating jobs, and is essential for creating a sustainable and resilient future. The report proposes a three-phase approach to recovery: "respond" to immediate disruptions, "recover" by accelerating infrastructure spending, and "thrive" by ensuring sustainability and a low-carbon future. Investments based on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria have shown promising results during the pandemic.

site_title: Malaysian king calls for support of 2021 budget
summary: Malaysia's King urged lawmakers to support the government's 2021 budget, expressing "full confidence" in Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's leadership amid a crisis. The monarch's statement comes ahead of a key parliament vote, where Muhyiddin's majority will be tested. The opposition Democratic Action Party has offered to back the budget on equal treatment conditions. The king's intervention signals a shift in the monarch's role in the country's volatile politics, with some analysts warning of the Council of Rulers' increasing influence and power.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda to issue US$2.3b sukuk to finance restructuring plans
summary: Malaysia's Felda has received approval to issue a US$2.38 billion sukuk with a government guarantee to finance its restructuring plans. The move is expected to see Felda achieve positive cashflow by 2023, according to Economic Minister Mustapa Mohamad. The sukuk issuance is aimed at restructuring the firm's debt and improving its financial stability.

site_title: WTO panel recommends Nigeria's candidate for top post
summary: The World Trade Organization's effort to name a new leader hit a roadblock after the US refused to support Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala's appointment as director-general, citing disagreements with the process. Okonjo-Iweala, a Nigerian former finance minister, received a key endorsement from the WTO selection committee, but the US veto may disrupt the process. The US has pushed for South Korea's candidate, Yoo Myung-hee, citing concerns about Okonjo-Iweala's ties to pro-trade internationalists. The WTO's leadership race may proceed to a vote if a consensus cannot be reached.

site_title: Labour market expected to rebound amid weak, uneven recovery: MAS
summary: Singapore's labour market is expected to rebound before the end of the year, driven by the reopening of the economy and government subsidies for hiring locals. However, recovery is likely to be weak, long-drawn, and uneven, with elevated levels of resident unemployment lasting into 2021. Labour market improvements are expected to be stronger in domestic employment, while foreign employment is expected to rebound more gradually. Wage growth is expected to remain dampened, and the labour market may be affected by shifts in consumption patterns and uncertainty over government interventions.

site_title: UPS quarterly profit beats expectations as pandemic spurs home deliveries
summary: UPS reports a 13.8% increase in average daily US volumes, driven by strong residential demand during the pandemic. The company's net income rose to $2 billion, or $2.24 per share, beating analyst estimates. Revenue increased to $21.24 billion, with the company also planning to hire over 100,000 workers for the holiday season to meet growing demand. CEO Carol Tomé attributes the results to continued strong outbound demand from Asia and growth from small and medium-sized businesses.

site_title: Keppel unit wins contract for cooling system plant in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Keppel's infrastructure arm has secured a S$300 million contract to build, own, and operate a district cooling system plant in Jurong Innovation District for 30 years. The plant, expected to be completed by 2022, will provide chilled water supply to developments in a 28ha area, increasing Keppel's installed cooling capacity by nearly 20%. The contract is not expected to impact Keppel's earnings per share or net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei slips on global virus woes, caution ahead of US elections
summary: Japanese shares fell for the third consecutive session, declining 0.29% to 23,418.51, amid concerns over the global economy's impact from surging coronavirus cases in Europe and the US. Investors remained cautious ahead of the US presidential elections, with US stock futures falling 0.4%. However, some stocks like Shimano and ANA Holdings received support from upbeat earnings reports, with Shimano rising 17% and ANA Holdings forecast a record operating loss.

site_title: STI falls 1.2% for third straight day on macro gloom, Covid-19 surge, US election risk
summary: Singapore shares fell 1.2% for the third straight day due to macroeconomic gloom, a Covid-19 surge, and US election risks. The Straits Times Index closed at a near five-week low of 2,483.48, with three banking stalwarts DBS, OCBC, and UOB leading the losses. Despite this, some Asian markets, such as Australia, China, and South Korea, advanced between 0.1 and 0.6%. Experts warn of a broader economic downturn in 2021 if the euro zone imposes new curbs due to the Covid-19 surge.

site_title: New Oriental seeks up to HK$11.9b in Hong Kong listing
summary: New Oriental Education & Technology Group, a Chinese tutoring and education operator, plans to raise up to HK$11.9 billion (S$2.09 billion) in its second Hong Kong listing. The company is selling 8.51 million shares at a maximum price of HK$1,399, representing a 7% premium over its US$168.81 closing price. The listing is part of a trend of US-listed Chinese firms seeking to broaden their investor base amid deteriorating US-China relations. New Oriental plans to use the funds for business expansion and acquisitions.

site_title: White Restaurant, Nam Ho Travel among SMEs in new leadership programme
summary: The Enterprise Leadership for Transformation (ELT) programme, launched in October 2020, aims to train 900 SME leaders in Singapore over three years. The programme targets businesses with at least S$5 million revenue and local shareholdings of at least 30%. The first run of the programme involves 60 business leaders from 38 SMEs, marking a significant step towards enhancing Singapore's global competitiveness through leadership development.

site_title: Heineken to cut office costs as Covid-19 surge clouds outlook
summary: Heineken plans to cut 20% of personnel expenses at headquarters and regional offices due to the Covid-19 resurgence, which clouds its outlook. The company reported a better-than-expected 1.9% decline in beer volume in the third quarter, driven by its namesake brand's strong sales performance. This move comes as Heineken shares have lost 16% this year. The company's decision to streamline office functions is part of its efforts to adapt to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.15 points lower at 1,495.20 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 4.661 billion lots worth RM3.439 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 737 to 291.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares ended with losses on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.32% to 24,708.80. The losses were driven by fears over the global economic recovery due to a spike in virus infections across Europe and the US. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index in China rose 0.46% and 0.68% respectively. The losses in Hong Kong stocks were the latest in a series of declines, highlighting ongoing concerns over the region's economic recovery.

site_title: Peugeot maker PSA's car revenue returns to growth after lockdowns
summary: PSA Group, the maker of Peugeot cars, reported a 0.8% decline in third-quarter sales to 15.5 billion euros, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. However, revenue from its core auto division returned to growth, rising 1.2% to 12 billion euros. The company attributed the increase to higher prices and the launch of new models. PSA maintained its target of reaching an adjusted operating margin of over 4.5% for the 2019-2021 period. The company is set to merge with Fiat Chrysler, creating the world's fourth-largest carmaker.

site_title: VW's Traton, Toyota's Hino agree electric truck venture
summary: Volkswagen's Traton and Toyota's Hino have agreed to create a joint venture to develop electric trucks, targeting battery-electric and fuel-cell models. The partnership aims to reduce global CO2 emissions and follows previous collaborations between the companies. Traton, which has made electrification a strategic priority, will invest €1 billion in electric vehicles by 2025. The joint venture will be launched in Sweden and Tokyo, with a team of advanced specialists working on the project.

site_title: Malaysia's king urges fractious lawmakers to back budget
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah urged federal lawmakers to support the 2021 budget, set to be unveiled next week, amid the country's ongoing challenges from the coronavirus pandemic and a leadership challenge. The king called for an end to political disagreements to pass the budget without disturbance. Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faces pressure from coalition partners and a resurgence in COVID-19 infections, which is battering the economy. The king's decree comes after he rejected Muhyiddin's request for a declaration of emergency rule.

site_title: Delivery Hero raises 2020 revenue guidance as quarterly sales double
summary: Delivery Hero raised its 2020 revenue guidance to 2.7-2.8 billion euros, up from 2.6-2.8 billion euros, driven by a strong performance in Asia and increased demand for home deliveries during the coronavirus pandemic. Quarterly sales nearly doubled year-on-year to 776.4 million euros. The company still expects to complete its takeover of Woowa Brothers by the end of the year.

site_title: SP Group, Chinese utility to develop sustainable energy solutions in Shanghai
summary: SP Group, a Singapore national utility, has signed a memorandum of understanding with State Grid Shanghai Integrated Energy Services to jointly develop and invest in integrated energy projects in Shanghai. The partnership aims to bring sustainable energy solutions to customers, leveraging each other's resources and strengths in branding, technology, and services. This collaboration underscores SP Group's commitment to delivering sustainable energy solutions to consumers in China, with the companies set to study the feasibility of the projects.

site_title: JustCo to open co-working space at Razer HQ in 2021
summary: JUSTCo, a co-working space provider, will open a new 30,000 sq. ft. facility near Razer's headquarters in Singapore's one-north district in Q2 2021. The space is part of the company's 19th location in Singapore and aims to cater to tech, media, and biomedical firms and startups. The new location provides a strategic opportunity for gaming hardware and consumer electronics companies to be near Razer, while also targeting corporate members looking to decentralize their workforce or implement remote working.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, plans to launch a cryptocurrency exchange, listing Bitcoin, Ether, Ripple, and Bitcoin Cash against multiple fiat currencies including the Singapore dollar and US dollar. The platform will allow users to buy, sell, and trade cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Unlike most digital exchanges, the DBS Digital Exchange will not hold any of the crypto assets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit mid-June low on report France mulling national lockdown
summary: European stocks hit a mid-June low on October 28, 2020, after a report suggested France was considering a month-long national lockdown to combat a surge in coronavirus infections. The Stoxx 600 index fell 1.6%, while Germany's DAX, UK's FTSE 100, and France's CAC 40 plummeted 2.2%, 1.5%, and 2.5% respectively. Economically sensitive sectors led the decline, with Deutsche Bank falling 3.6%. The French government will address the issue later, amid pressure for new lockdowns in Germany and the UK.

site_title: Chipmaker STMicroelectronics, A*Star unit and Japan's Ulvac in Singapore R&D tie-up
summary: STMicroelectronics has partnered with A*Star's Institute of Microelectronics and Japan's Ulvac to establish a cutting-edge R&D facility in Singapore focused on piezoelectric micro-electromechanical system (piezo Mems) technology. The 1,300 sqm cleanroom is expected to produce its first wafers in Q2 2021 and scale up production by end-2022, with the potential to cut across various market segments such as smart glasses, healthcare, and 3D printing. The collaboration aims to bridge the gap between prototyping and high-volume production, with the facility expected to double in size if needed.

site_title: Fortuna Hotel next to Farrer Park MRT station up for sale with S$98.8m guide price
summary: The Fortuna Hotel in Singapore's Farrer Park area is up for sale with a guide price of S$98.8 million. Located on a freehold site, the 8,332 sq ft property has 106 rooms and a gross floor area of 47,990 sq ft. Foreigners are eligible to buy, and the sale will not incur additional buyer's stamp duty or seller's stamp duty. The new owner can immediately carry out asset enhancement initiatives to transform the property into a hotel or other development, with potential for a long-term investment horizon.

site_title: SunMoon Food obtains 34.9m yuan interest-free loan, proposes placement
summary: SunMoon Food Co, a fruit and seafood distributor, has obtained a 34.9 million yuan (S$6.9 million) interest-free loan from Jiangzhong Shiliao (Hubei) Technology (JSHT) to address its financial issues. The company has also proposed a share placement to raise funds, with an issue price of 3.2 Singapore cents per subscription share. SunMoon's board has formed an executive committee to oversee the company's day-to-day management, following the bankruptcy reorganisation of three entities including its parent.

site_title: Smart-cities lab opens in CapitaLand's Singapore Science Park
summary: The Smart Urban Co-Innovation Lab, the first industry-led smart cities solutions development lab in South-east Asia, has opened in CapitaLand's 5G-enabled Singapore Science Park. Backed by up to $10 million from CapitaLand and industry partners, the lab aims to co-create and test smart cities innovations in six industry verticals, including advanced manufacturing and smart mobility. The lab will support 200 companies in Singapore over three years and facilitate partnerships between local and overseas firms, with 30 industry players already on board.

images.alt_text: The lab was initiated by CapitaLand and supported by the Infocomm Media Development Authority and Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Exodus of online casinos empties Manila's residential towers
summary: The Philippine capital Manila is experiencing an exodus of online casinos, resulting in empty residential towers and lower rents. The industry's decline, driven by higher taxes and weaker demand, is expected to continue, with property broker KMC Savills estimating a 10% average rent drop by year-end. Office space vacancy in Metro Manila has risen to 7.3% as the pandemic affects businesses, but outsourcing companies are absorbing the glut. The industry's exposure to the residential market is 1.8 million sq m, and rent declines will vary by district.

site_title: Seoul: Retail investors lift shares; caution on virus, US election uncertainties
summary: South Korean shares jumped 14.42 points or 0.62% to close at 2,345.26 on Wednesday, boosted by retail investors despite concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic and US election uncertainty. Retail investors bought 150.79 billion won worth of shares, while foreigners were net buyers of 11.03 billion won. Heavyweights Naver and Kakao soared 5.3% and 3.7% respectively, while Samsung Electronics fell 1.3% following the death of its chairman. The won weakened 0.45% to 1,130.6 per US dollar.

site_title: Japan not considering new reactors to help reach 2050 carbon-neutral goal
summary: Japan is not planning to build new nuclear power plants to achieve its goal of becoming carbon-free by 2050.
