Chief Cabinet Secretary Katsunobu Kato stated that the government is reviewing energy policy and focusing on reusable energy sources and existing nuclear plants that can be operated safely. Japan aims to reduce its carbon emissions from utilities, which account for about 4/5ths of its carbon dioxide output, to meet the European Union's 2050 carbon-neutral target.

site_title: Japan PM Suga to announce plan for fresh stimulus package to ease pandemic pain
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga will announce a fresh stimulus package to ease the pandemic's economic impact, with a likely size of around 10 trillion yen (S$129.94 billion). The package will consist of 7 trillion yen from existing funds and new spending, aiming to cushion the recession-stricken economy. The measures will focus on putting a floor on growth, rather than stimulating the economy, with analysts expecting limited effects on boosting growth.

site_title: JLL appointed marketing consultancy for Jurong Lake District
summary: Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL) has been appointed as the marketing consultancy for Jurong Lake District (JLD) with a one-year contract worth S$130,000. The consultancy aims to promote JLD as an attractive place to live, work, and play, and to attract real estate developers and investment funds to participate in Government Land Sales. Key stakeholders, including developers, investors, and end-users, will be consulted to understand their needs and requirements. The goal is to transform JLD's image and position it as a sustainable and attractive area for growth, with the potential to create over 100,000 new jobs and 20,000 new homes.

site_title: Australia: Shares end string of losses as gold, tech stocks rise
summary: Australian shares ended a four-session losing streak, rising 0.1% to 6,057.7 on Wednesday, driven by gains in gold miners and technology stocks following Afterpay's strong earnings. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.7% on Tuesday.

site_title: Swire Properties in talks to sell Hong Kong office tower; trading resumes
summary: Swire Properties is in discussions to sell its office tower in Taikoo Shing, eastern Hong Kong Island, with no agreement finalized yet. The decision may lead to the disposal of the multi-storey office building. Trading of Swire Properties and Swire Pacific shares was suspended pending an announcement, with shares easing 0.7% and 0.5% respectively after resuming trading.

site_title: Deutsche Bank swings to profit in Q3
summary: Deutsche Bank has posted a 182 million euro net profit in the third quarter, surpassing expectations after a year-ago loss of 942 million euros. This is the bank's first quarterly profit in two years, following a restructuring effort to shed staff, exit unprofitable businesses, and cut costs. The bank's shares are expected to benefit from the better-than-expected results, which mark a significant turnaround from the bank's losses over the past five years.

site_title: GSK, Sanofi to make 200m doses available for Covid-19 vaccine alliance
summary: Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) plan to produce 200 million doses of their Covid-19 vaccine candidate, available through the Covax vaccine allocation plan. The partnership aims to deliver 2 billion doses globally by the end of 2021, with deals also signed with the US and European Union. The companies expect early stage study results in December 2020 and plan to file for regulatory approval in 2021.

site_title: Mary Chia to buy 80% of Monsoon Hairdressing from celebrity hairstylist Addy Lee
summary: Mary Chia Holdings has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to buy an 80% stake in Monsoon Hairdressing group for about S$3 million. Celebrity hairstylist Addy Lee will sell the stake, and the deal will be partially funded by a subscription agreement with I Concept Global Growth Fund, which will raise S$800,000. The acquisition aims to expand Mary Chia's reach in the Chinese market and achieve cost savings through joint resources and shared premises.

site_title: Vintage Alfa Romeos to be auctioned at Sotheby's
summary: Alfa Romeo's iconic BAT cars, designed by Franco Scaglione, are set to be auctioned at Sotheby's in New York City, with estimated hammer prices ranging from $14 million to $20 million. The three vehicles, produced in 1953-1955, are considered "possibly the best examples of cars as works of art" and will be displayed alongside works by renowned postwar Italian artists and designers. The BAT cars, known for their aerodynamic design, achieved impressive wind drag performance for their time, and their sale is expected to demonstrate the power of forward-thinking design.

images.alt_text: Arguably among the most flamboyant designs in automotive history, Alfa Romeo's three BAT cars - for Berlina Aerodinamica Tecnica - are to be auctioned at Sotheby's in New York City on Wednesday.

site_title: Hot stock: Jiutian Chemical sees heavy trading after completing share placement
summary: Jiutian Chemical completed a share placement, raising S$10.3 million by issuing 170 million new shares at 6.03 Singapore cents apiece. The company saw heavy trading on Wednesday, with 118.5 million shares changing hands, reaching an intraday high of 8.7 Singapore cents. Institutional investors accounted for the majority of the placement amount, with non-executive chairman Han Lianguo stating the company will focus on maximizing returns from existing assets while exploring expansion and synergistic investment opportunities.

site_title: Tata Group to buy majority stake in BigBasket for about US$1b: Economic Times
summary: The Tata Group is in talks to buy a majority stake in BigBasket, an Indian online grocery startup, for around $1 billion. The talks come as BigBasket competes with Amazon and Reliance Industries in India's booming e-commerce market. China's Alibaba, which holds a 26% stake in BigBasket, is expected to sell its entire shareholding. The deal may not be finalized, but could be worth $500 million to $700 million, according to separate reports. The Tata Group aims to launch a "super app" that ties together its consumer businesses.

site_title: Gym in Jurong West, ice cream shop in Upper Thomson among places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore has added six new locations to its list of places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients, including an Anytime Fitness gym in Jurong West and an ice cream shop in Upper Thomson. The new cases were all imported, with no community or dormitory cases reported. People who visited these locations on the same day should monitor their health closely for two weeks. There were also 7 new imported cases, bringing Singapore's total to 57,987.

images.alt_text: There were seven new coronavirus cases confirmed as of Wednesday noon, taking Singapore's total to 57,987.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars outperform as economies escape lockdown
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars outperformed the euro as economies in the region continued to recover from the COVID-19 recession, while Europe faced the risk of lockdowns. The Aussie and kiwi dollars held steady against their US counterparts, with the Aussie expected to outperform other major OECD economies in recovering. Soft inflation figures in Australia supported expectations of near-term policy easing, including a potential interest rate cut and quantitative easing by the Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending losses from the previous day, amid concerns over a US virus resurgence and its impact on global markets. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.06% to 24,773.54. In contrast, China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.06% to 3,256.22. The losses come as traders focus on US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Rejigged Tiffany deal would be face-saving truce
summary: Luxury conglomerate LVMH and US jeweller Tiffany are negotiating a revised deal for LVMH's planned $16 billion acquisition of Tiffany, potentially at a lower price tag of around $130 per share. The deal would save LVMH's CEO Bernard Arnault $600 million and allow both companies to avoid delays and potential losses. The talks come after the deal faced antitrust hurdles and a court battle, with a quick settlement potentially benefiting both parties before the Chinese New Year.

images.alt_text: A bling takeover row may end with a face-saving truce. French behemoth LVMH and its target Tiffany are negotiating a price cut on the US jeweller's pre-pandemic US$16 billion price tag, Reuters reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan's Nomura second-quarter profit slumps 51%
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 51.2% slump in second-quarter net profit to 67.6 billion yen (S$878.4 million) from 138.6 billion yen last year, due to a stake sale in its research-focused unit. Pretax income for the wholesale segment and retail division also declined, with the wholesale segment at 65.5 billion yen and the retail division at 22.8 billion yen. The company has been in a cost-cutting mode since last year, targeting 140 billion yen in cuts by March 2022.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings, Japan's biggest brokerage and investment bank, on Wednesday posted a 51.2 per cent slump in second-quarter net profit from last year, which was swelled by the stake sale in its research-focused unit.

site_title: Airbnb fights its 'party house problem'
summary: Airbnb is struggling to address the "party house problem" - a growing issue where guests hold raucous gatherings in properties, posing risks to the company's reputation and business. The problem has increased during the pandemic, with complaints about party houses soaring 250% between July and September last year. At least 27 shootings have been linked to Airbnb rentals in the US and Canada. In response, Airbnb has introduced new policies, products, and technologies to combat large gatherings, but critics say the company has prioritized growth over safety concerns.

site_title: Airlines running out of cash, need more govt aid to avoid layoffs, bankruptcies: Iata
summary: Airlines worldwide face severe cash burn, with median airlines having just 8.5 months of cash left, according to the International Air Transport Association (Iata). Revenues are expected to fall 46% in 2021 compared to 2019, with no indication of significant improvement if borders stay closed. Iata urges government aid to prevent bankruptcies and layoffs, with 1.3 million airline jobs at risk, affecting 3.5 million jobs in the broader economy.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend losses as virus surges in US, Europe
summary: Asian markets extended losses on Wednesday due to a surge in coronavirus cases in the US and Europe, with investors wary of a new stimulus package from Washington. The Dow and S&P 500 fell, while the Nasdaq edged up as tech firms are expected to benefit from the lockdown. European leaders have been forced to implement strict measures to control the virus, and some experts warn of a double-dip recession. A Pfizer vaccine is expected to be filed for emergency use authorization in November, providing some optimism for investors.

site_title: Pace of Singapore's rebound to slow, recovery to take longer than past recessions: MAS
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a slower-than-anticipated recovery, with growth momentum slowing in Q4 and remaining modest in 2021. Unemployment rates will edge down gradually, and some sectors may not return to pre-pandemic levels until the end of 2021. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) forecasts a 5-7% contraction in 2020 and above-trend growth in 2021, with global growth expected to return to trend in 2022 but at a lower level than pre-Covid-19.

site_title: Malaysia's Jaya Grocer owners weighing stake sale: sources
summary: Malaysia's Jaya Grocer, the country's largest high-end supermarket chain, is weighing a stake sale worth over US$200 million. The Teng family, who founded the supermarket, and Asean Industrial Growth Fund (AIGF), backed by Japan's Mitsubishi, are working with an adviser on the deal. Non-binding bids are expected next month, with deliberations ongoing and no certainty of a deal. The family may decide to retain part of their stake, and Jaya Grocer operates 35 outlets across Southeast Asia with online shopping and delivery services.

site_title: MPA to issue up to two more LNG bunker supplier licences
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) will issue up to two additional LNG bunker supplier licences to support growing demand for LNG bunker in Singapore. A request for proposal has been launched for parties to supply LNG bunker, with a closing date of Dec 15, 2020. The new licences will complement existing holders FueLNG and Pavilion Energy Singapore, and the award is expected to be announced by February 2021.

site_title: 70% of SMEs have not adopted data analytics, with most only familiar with spreadsheets: poll
summary: Nearly 70% of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) have not adopted data analytics, with most familiar with spreadsheets and databases. A study found that about half of these SMEs have no intention to adopt data analytics, citing data protection, limited financial resources, and lack of infrastructure support. Only 30% of those surveyed have an annual turnover of over S$25 million. To encourage data analytics adoption, the study suggests sharing success stories, providing real-life examples, and offering a shared services platform with consultants offering different levels of data analytics capabilities.

site_title: Australia, Japan, US to fund cable for Pacific island of Palau
summary: Australia, Japan, and the US have agreed to fund a $30-million undersea telecoms cable project for the Pacific island of Palau, valued at $10 million from Australia. This project is the first financed under an infrastructure investment partnership among the three nations. The cable will link Palau to a new Indo-Pacific cable spanning Singapore to the US west coast, strengthening Palau's global internet connectivity. The project aims to counter rising Chinese influence in the region and follows Australia's increased engagement in the Pacific Island region.

site_title: Gold steady as coronavirus, US elections uncertainty loom
summary: Gold prices remained steady above the $1,900-mark on Wednesday, driven by uncertainty surrounding the US elections and surging global Covid-19 cases. Despite a firmer US dollar and fading hopes of an immediate US stimulus package, investors are waiting for policy signals to buy more gold. The US gold futures were down 0.3% at $1,907.10, but spot gold stayed above $1,900. Investors are seeking a reason to buy gold, with chief global market strategist Stephen Innes stating that policy signals will be key.

site_title: Sony seeing 'very considerable' PS5 demand ahead of launch
summary: Sony is experiencing "very considerable" demand for its PlayStation 5 console ahead of its Nov 12 launch, with pre-orders surpassing those of its predecessor PlayStation 4 in its first 12 weeks. CEO Jim Ryan stated that the demand has been "very, very considerable" and that the company is working to ensure supply for the year-end shopping season. This surge in demand is attributed to the pandemic, which has boosted gaming revenue and disrupted retail networks. Sony aims to persuade users to upgrade to the PS5 to play enhanced titles like Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales.

images.alt_text: Sony is seeing "very considerable" demand for its PlayStation 5 (PS5) console via pre-orders, its gaming chief said on Wednesday, as users rush to secure the next-generation device ahead of its Nov 12 launch.

site_title: Teckwah suspends trading after close of privatisation offer
summary: Teckwah Industrial Corp suspended trading of its shares on October 28, 2020, after its voluntary cash offer to take the company private at 65 Singapore cents per share closed with 95.9% of shares accepted. The offeror and its concert parties received valid acceptances, making the bid unconditional and resulting in the company losing its free float.

site_title: Trudeau tells Canadians pandemic 'really sucks' as toll rises
summary: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau acknowledged the COVID-19 pandemic's toll on Canadians, saying it "really sucks" as the nation's death toll surpassed 10,000. Trudeau expressed growing frustration with lockdowns and public health rules, noting a surge in people flouting rules. The country's case count reached 220,670, with most deaths concentrated in Ontario and Quebec. Trudeau warned of a tough winter ahead, with potential restrictions on Halloween and Christmas gatherings. Authorities have fined individuals for violating pandemic precautions, with Manitoba Premier Brian Pallister urging citizens to "get with the programme" and stay safe.

site_title: UOB manages nearly S$200m in ESG product transactions in year to date
summary: UOB has managed nearly S$200 million in ESG product transactions as of September 30, 2020, exceeding the full-year 2019 value. The bank has integrated ESG considerations into its investment solutions, including unit trusts, bonds, and structured products. UOB has developed a structured due-diligence framework to select solution providers committed to addressing ESG risks and opportunities. The bank plans to roll out more ESG-focused products to enable customers to contribute to social and environmental well-being. This growth is attributed to increasing consumer interest in sustainable investing.

site_title: Cash builds for property debt funds with crisis delayed for now
summary: Real estate debt investors, including Blackstone Group, are stockpiling cash, raising US$14.1 billion from April to September, despite a delayed crisis. However, deals have been scarce, with loan extensions expiring on struggling properties such as malls, hotels, and offices. Competition is building to put cash to work, but borrowers are growing desperate, motivating lenders to take on higher risks. A thaw in the market may be imminent, driven by both increased competition and borrower desperation.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 2,502.04 at open on Wednesday, following overnight losses on Wall Street and weaker index counters. Banking stocks were in the red, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC declining 0.9%, 0.7%, and 0.8% respectively. Other active counters included Venture and the Singapore Exchange, which advanced 0.7% and remained unchanged. The decline follows US stocks, which finished mostly lower on Tuesday amid economic and Covid-19 concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, up 1.82 points, or 0.12%, to 1,502.17. The market saw 223 gainers for every 89 losers, with a trading volume of 200.88 million lots worth RM139.24 million.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong travel bubble expected to launch in November
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are set to launch their air travel bubble in November, allowing for travel without quarantine requirements, according to Minister for Transport Ong Ye Kung and Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam. The bubble, which enables travel between the two cities without restrictions, requires travellers to have been in either city for 14 days, take Covid-19 swab tests, and produce a negative result. The quota for travel under the bubble will be initially set, but may be increased as operations stabilize.

images.alt_text: The ministry hopes to be able to share the bubble's launch date and other implementation details soon.

site_title: Australia's big IPOs split investors between tech growth seam and coal-powered dividends
summary: Australia's two largest IPOs, a coal terminal and a technology firm, will highlight the country's polarized investment landscape. Brookfield Asset Management's coal terminal listing in November could be valued at A$3.5 billion with a 5.5% dividend yield, while Macquarie Group's technology stake aims for capital gains. This contrast reflects the strong appeal of high-growth tech and the enduring demand for coal-linked assets offering steady dividends. The IPOs will likely split investors between these two opposing investment strategies.

site_title: AMD's US$35b deal pushes 2020 towards a record for chip M&A
summary: AMD's US$35 billion acquisition of Xilinx pushes 2020 towards a record year for chip deals, with US$110 billion in deals announced this year. This surpasses the 2016 record of US$122 billion. The semiconductor industry is experiencing increased competition as companies design their own chips and established players branch out into new areas. The deal gives AMD access to programmable chips for wireless networks and expands its presence in the data-centre market. This is part of a trend of rivalries driving M&A in the industry, which is otherwise experiencing a slowdown globally.

images.alt_text: Advanced Micro Devices' (AMD) US$35 billion purchase of semiconductor maker Xilinx pushes 2020 towards a record year for chip deals, as large tech companies rush to consolidate the increasingly competitive industry.

site_title: FCT completes AsiaRetail Fund stake buy; Bedok Point sale to close on Nov 9
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has completed the purchase of the remaining 63.11% interest in AsiaRetail Fund (ARF) from Frasers Property, becoming the sole owner of ARF. The existing portfolio management agreements will be terminated, and ARF's five malls will be converted into limited liability partnerships (LLPs) for tax transparency treatment. The deal, which raised S$1.02 billion, includes the sale of Bedok Point mall to Frasers Property's subsidiary, set to be completed on Nov 9.

site_title: TikTok to hire 3,000 engineers globally; over 150 ByteDance openings in Singapore
summary: TikTok plans to hire approximately 3,000 engineers globally over the next three years, with a focus on Europe, Canada, and Singapore. The move aims to support the app's rapid global growth despite uncertainty over its ownership. ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, also has 158 entry-level and experienced positions available in Singapore, including research and development roles. The US will remain a key engineering hub for TikTok, with plans to hire more staff. The company's expansion plans come amid ongoing uncertainty over its ownership and a potential ban on TikTok downloads in the US.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Industrial Trust, SIA Engineering, SingPost, Aspen, FCT
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch include Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) with a Q2 distribution drop, SIA Engineering (SIAEC) recognizing a non-cash impairment provision, and SingPost potentially facing limited rating headroom due to industry troubles. Aspen shares surged 25% after plans to transfer its listing to the mainboard. Frasers Property completed a stake sale to Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT), and Revez Corp acquired PGK Digital Networks. Mary Chia Holdings agreed to buy an 80% stake in Monsoon Hairdressing companies. These developments may impact trading of these securities on Wednesday.

site_title: Defence questions Canada policeman who arrested Huawei executive
summary: A Canadian federal policeman, Constable Winston Yep, testified at the extradition hearing of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou, explaining the three-hour delay before her arrest. Yep stated that the Canadian Border Services Agency (CBSA) rejected immediately detaining Meng upon her arrival, and he feared an arrest on the plane could endanger officer and public safety. Yep also admitted an error in his affidavit stating Meng had no ties to Canada, and denied that high-ranking officials influenced his sworn affidavit and arrest warrant.

site_title: SIAEC to book impairment for H1, dragged by lower hangar revenue, parked aircraft
summary: SIA Engineering Co (SIAEC) plans to book a non-cash impairment provision against its base maintenance unit's assets, primarily due to lower hangar revenue and parked aircraft. The move is expected to have a material impact on the group's financial results for the first half of its fiscal year. The impairment is attributed to the Covid-19 pandemic's adverse impact on the aviation industry and low flight activities. SIAEC is working to finalize the quantum of the impairment provision.

site_title: Ant Group to close HK institutional book early
summary: Ant Group will close its Hong Kong institutional order books for its record-setting dual IPO ahead of schedule due to strong demand. The initial closing deadline was Thursday, but it has been accelerated to Wednesday at 5:00 pm in each region. This decision comes as the company seeks to capitalize on the high interest in its IPO.

site_title: Funeral send-off held for late Samsung chairman Lee Kun Hee
summary: Samsung Electronics chairman Lee Kun Hee's family held a private funeral ceremony on October 28, 2020, after his death on Sunday at 78. The ceremony was followed by a procession to sites significant to Lee, including his home and chip-production facilities. Lee's passing raised concerns about the control of Samsung and its largest conglomerate, with expectations for potential stake sales and restructuring. The family is also grappling with a nearly 10 trillion won inheritance tax bill.

site_title: Prices in UK shops fall more slowly in October: BRC
summary: Prices in UK shops fell 1.2% annually in October, a slower decrease than September's 1.6% drop. Non-food prices slowed to 2.7% from September's 3.2%, while food prices rose 1.2% in both months. Despite this, BRC chief executive Helen Dickinson expects continued pressure on retailers' profit margins. Official data showed purchases of non-food items exceeded pre-pandemic levels in October.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch lower on virus, US stimulus worries
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 6,047.6 on Wednesday due to concerns over a US stimulus deal and rising global COVID-19 cases. The benchmark index was weighed down by financials and energy sub-indexes, with Australia's third-largest lender, ANZ, falling 2.7% after revealing a US$376 million hit to second-half earnings. The healthcare and tech indexes firmed, with shares of medical device maker Resmed Inc jumping 4.3%.

site_title: Afterpay Q1 sales more than double on US growth
summary: Afterpay's Q1 sales more than doubled, driven by strong growth in the US, where the company added nearly 1 million new customers. US underlying sales tripled to A$1.6 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. Afterpay now has 11.2 million active customers, up 1.3 million from three months ago. The company's shares rose 8.2% despite a broader market dip. The US market is seen as a key growth area for Afterpay, but intense competition from firms like Klarna and PayPal remains a challenge.

site_title: ASX delays blockchain transition until 2023
summary: The Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) has delayed its blockchain-based clearing system launch until April 2023, pushing back the original target of April 2022 due to increased trading volumes during the COVID-19 pandemic. The system aims to provide post-trade processing capacity and access to distributed ledger technology. ASX cited industry requests for more capacity and the extreme trading volumes in March as the reason for the delay. The new system will replace the Clearing House Electronic Subregister System (CHESS) on the ASX platform.

site_title: Early Covid-19 vaccines may be imperfect: UK Vaccines Taskforce chair
summary: UK Vaccines Taskforce chair Kate Bingham stated that the first generation of Covid-19 vaccines is likely to be imperfect, potentially reducing symptoms rather than preventing infection, and may not work for everyone or for long. Bingham emphasized the importance of guarding against complacency and over-optimism in the face of vaccine uncertainty.

site_title: S&P expects SingPost to have limited rating headroom after Australian logistics firm deal
summary: S&P Global Ratings expects Singapore Post to have limited rating headroom after acquiring a 38% stake in Australian logistics firm Freight Management Holdings. The acquisition coincides with heightened earnings weakness due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has raised operating costs for cross-border delivery. S&P forecasts SingPost's debt-to-Ebitda ratio to increase to 2.5 times in 2021 before subsiding to 2.3 times in 2022. The deal is expected to be immediately earnings accretive but will take time for business integration and synergies to materialize.

site_title: Mercedes bets on evolution as Tesla touts revolution in automated driving
summary: Mercedes-Benz has developed a highly automated driving system, similar to Tesla's Full Self Driving software, but with a more conservative approach. Unlike Tesla, which allows public testing on urban roads, Mercedes will first validate its system with its engineers. This step-by-step approach aims to reduce accidents, as computers have faster reflexes than humans. The goal is to push highly automated driving onto public roads, a move that could significantly reduce accidents. Mercedes' approach contrasts with Tesla's more radical approach to testing its technology.

site_title: Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy asks other firms to take on idle workers: sources
summary: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) has asked several Japanese companies to temporarily employ idle workers from its central Japan factories for up to three years to cut costs amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The move aims to adjust workforce levels and cope with a downturn in the aviation industry. MHI, Japan's biggest heavy machinery maker, has also been hit by technical problems and reduced air travel demand, forcing it to delay deliveries of its SpaceJet regional jet. The company is expected to release its results on Friday, which may include a new business plan to address the challenges.

site_title: US senators to quiz Big Tech CEOs on legal protection
summary: US senators will quiz Big Tech CEOs on legal protection, particularly Section 230, a law shielding them from liability for third-party content. The Senate Commerce Committee hearing follows growing criticism of the law's role in enabling abusive content and incitements to violence. CEOs, including Jack Dorsey and Mark Zuckerberg, argue that proposed reforms could lead to more harmful content and limit free expression. A bill aiming to limit the immunity shield by requiring platforms to show "objective reasonableness" when removing content is also being considered.

site_title: Australian inflation stays muted amid Covid-induced noise
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 1.6% in the September quarter, mainly due to one-off rebates and petrol price rebounds, but annual inflation remained below the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target at 0.7%. The surge was largely attributed to temporary statistical noise caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. With the economy still recovering from recession, inflation is expected to remain subdued for a long time, prompting the RBA to consider cutting interest rates to 0.1% and possibly quantitative easing to support the economy.

site_title: US presses Suu Kyi for inclusive Myanmar election
summary: The US has urged Myanmar's civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi to promote an inclusive election on November 8, amid concerns over the marginalization of the Rohingya minority. Nearly two million people, mostly Rohingya, have been disenfranchised due to security concerns, and electoral authorities have excluded minority-heavy areas from the vote. The US also pressed Suu Kyi to end conflict across the country and secure the voluntary return of Rohingya refugees. The call comes as Suu Kyi has lost her iconic status in the West due to her equivocal statements on the Rohingya campaign.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares lower on Wall Street losses, higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following Wall Street losses and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.47% to 23,374.28, while the Topix index lost 0.68% to 1,606.61. The losses were attributed to a weaker US dollar, which led to a rise in the yen, and concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday following losses on Wall Street, with the yen's appreciation also weighing on the market.

site_title: Trump website defaced, campaign working with law enforcement: statement
summary: The Donald Trump presidential campaign's official website was defaced earlier this week, displaying a bogus message seeking cryptocurrency donations in exchange for access to purported "internal and secret conversations" with Trump family and associates. The campaign stated it is working with law enforcement to investigate the source of the attack, but no evidence was provided by the hackers. The website appeared to be fully functional after the incident.

site_title: Pfizer says Covid-19 vaccine still possible in 2020 despite data lag
summary: Pfizer executives expressed optimism about a potential Covid-19 vaccine in 2020, with CEO Albert Bourla stating the company could supply 40 million doses in the US if clinical testing proceeds as expected. However, Bourla noted that key data on vaccine efficacy has not been reached, and the company expects to file for emergency use authorization in November. Pfizer's quarterly earnings dropped 71% due to the pandemic, but the company cited strong sales of other medications.

site_title: Visa's deal to buy fintech startup Plaid faces antitrust scrutiny: WSJ
summary: Visa's planned $5.3 billion acquisition of fintech startup Plaid faces antitrust scrutiny from the US Justice Department, which may decide to block the deal due to concerns it could limit competition in the payments sector. The department has been examining the deal for much of the year, citing concerns about the potential impact on nascent competition in the industry. A decision on whether to sue to block the deal is expected soon.

site_title: Melbourne reopens after months of hard Covid-19 lockdown as cases ease
summary: Melbourne, Australia's coronavirus hotspot, has reopened after over three months of lockdown due to a decline in cases. The city's restaurants and cafes reopened on Wednesday, and social gatherings at homes have been eased. Victoria state, where Melbourne is located, reported two new Covid-19 cases, with no infections in the previous two days. The state has accounted for 90% of Australia's 907 deaths from the virus.

images.alt_text: Australia's coronavirus hotspot of Victoria state reported two new Covid-19 cases on Wednesday after posting no infections in the previous two days, as state capital Melbourne emerged from more than three months of a hard lockdown.

site_title: TikTok moves into ecommerce with Shopify partnership
summary: TikTok has partnered with Canadian e-commerce company Shopify to allow its merchants to sell products through shoppable video ads on the platform. The deal comes amid scrutiny of TikTok's China-based parent firm ByteDance and a pending US court hearing on its future in the US. The partnership will enable over 1 million Shopify merchants to promote their products on TikTok, with plans to test new commerce features. The move may alleviate concerns over national security and data transfers, but the US court's decision on TikTok's US presence remains uncertain.

site_title: Biden insists he'll tackle virus as Trump pushes 'super-recovery'
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized his rival Donald Trump for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic, accusing Trump of surrendering to the virus. Biden, who is leading in national polls, said Trump's chief of staff admitted that the US would not control the pandemic. Biden vowed to take action on the virus if elected, promising to "get Covid under control" on his first day in office. Meanwhile, Trump maintained his campaign pace, holding rallies in the Midwest and claiming to be leading in the polls, despite Biden's narrow lead in key battleground states like Georgia and Michigan.

site_title: What will Biden's blue wave of change bring?
summary: US President Joe Biden is expected to win the election, with a solid lead in polls, 50.8% to 42.8% for Donald Trump. Biden is also leading in key battleground states like Wisconsin, Michigan, and Pennsylvania. However, the election's outcome can be unpredictable, as seen in the 2016 election. A Biden win may bring sweeping economic and policy changes, but a contested outcome and congressional gridlock could hinder progress, especially with rising coronavirus cases in the US.

site_title: A forgotten, shameful piracy milestone
summary: Somali pirates freed the last three of 3,639 hostages held captive over five years, with the trio, who were working on an Iranian fishing vessel, expected to return home after completing COVID-19 tests and medical checks. The hostages were hijacked in March 2015 off the coast of Hobyo, Somalia.

site_title: Insurance sector highlights markets' hidden role in supporting Singapore's carbon pledge
summary: Singapore's insurance sector is playing a crucial role in reducing carbon emissions, despite its global reputation as a business-friendly hub. The sector is increasingly offering to underwrite the risk of low-carbon alternatives, making it more attractive for traditional energy companies to transition to green power. This shift is driven by market forces, including shareholder and public pressure to deliver more carbon-friendly operations. As a result, the cost of operating and underwriting carbon-producing traditional energy infrastructure is becoming more expensive, while insuring low-carbon alternatives is becoming relatively cheaper, making a carbon-neutral future more feasible.

site_title: Logistics industry creates over 2,100 openings; 1,500 jobs to come in next 5 years
summary: Singapore's logistics industry has over 2,100 job openings, with 1,500 expected to be created in the next 5 years. The industry is described as "one of the most open and welcoming" with ease of entry for individuals from other occupations. Between April and September, 710 individuals were placed in jobs, and 250 mid-career individuals switched to logistics through career conversion programs. Large logistics companies plan to create new jobs through digital transformation investments, with the government supporting the industry through initiatives such as the SGUnited Jobs Initiative.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit one-month low as virus fears dominate
summary: European stocks fell 1% to a one-month low on Tuesday, driven by concerns over the economic impact of tighter coronavirus restrictions and fading hopes for a US stimulus package. The Stoxx 600 index hit a low due to rising US and European infections and limited gains from a 3.4% jump in HSBC's shares. The European Central Bank's meeting on Thursday is expected to provide clues on monetary stimulus, with many predicting no changes. Germany's DAX and France's CAC 40 also fell, with Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel planning a "lockdown light" to combat a second wave of infections.

site_title: Trump says will pass 'best stimulus' after election
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Republicans will approve a pandemic rescue package after the November 3 election, conceding defeat on current efforts. He predicted Republicans would regain control of the lower house of Congress and blamed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi for the impasse. Trump also claimed that after the election, a "best stimulus package" would be passed, despite remaining divisions over provisions to combat the coronavirus and aid struggling state and local governments.

site_title: Oil rises 2% on US Gulf shutdowns, outlook weak
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Tuesday as companies in the US Gulf of Mexico shut down production ahead of a storm, but gains were limited by surging coronavirus infections and rising Libyan supply. Brent crude closed at $41.21 per barrel, up 75 cents, while US oil gained $1.01 to $39.57 per barrel. However, the storm-induced bump in prices may be short-lived, with demand expected to weaken anew due to rising coronavirus cases and a contested US election. Libya's production is also expected to rebound in coming weeks, complicating efforts by OPEC to restrict output.

site_title: Used car exports drives pollution to developing world
summary: The European Union, Japan, and US exported around 3 million used vehicles to developing countries between 2015 and 2018, with most going to Africa. A UN report warns that these vehicles significantly contribute to air pollution in developing nations. The report calls for stricter rules on exporting and importing old, polluting vehicles, citing vehicles averaging 18 years old and 200,000km on their odometers. Two-thirds of countries with used vehicle import rules are weak, and some have no pollution standards. The UN urges developed countries to stop exporting non-roadworthy vehicles and importing countries to strengthen quality standards.

site_title: Microsoft rides cloud to higher earnings
summary: Microsoft reported a 30% increase in profit to $13.9 billion in the recently ended quarter, driven by a surge in demand for its cloud computing offerings, which rose 31% to $15.2 billion. Revenue also increased 12% to $37.2 billion. The company attributed the growth to the pandemic's shift to online shopping, learning, and work, with businesses under pressure to engage customers online. Microsoft's Azure platform and Office 365 online software are positioned to benefit from this trend, according to analysts.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly fall on worries over economy, Covid-19
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones shedding 0.8% and the S&P 500 falling 0.3%, amid concerns over the economy and Covid-19. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6% despite a surge in new coronavirus cases in the US and Europe. President Trump announced that Congress will approve a pandemic rescue package after the election, while consumer confidence in the US lagged analyst expectations. Individual companies, including Pfizer, Merck, and Marriott International, fell after earnings reports.

site_title: Melbourne eases restrictions after second day of zero Covid-19 cases
summary: Melbourne achieved two consecutive days of zero new coronavirus cases, marking the end of a months-long lockdown. Bars in the city will reopen at midnight, with stay-at-home orders and non-essential business closures set to end. This comes as Europe and North America prepare for restrictions, contrasting with Melbourne's decision to ease restrictions.

site_title: Singapore shares fall on US election jitters, macro pain concerns
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% to 2,512.87 on Tuesday, weighed down by US election jitters, rising Covid-19 cases globally, and overnight Wall Street losses. The Straits Times Index traded underwater all day, with UOB, OCBC, and Singtel leading the losses. However, Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust outperformed, adding 1.7% to S$3.08, driven by its strong business update and favourable ratings from brokers. The market's overall trading volume stood at 1.17 billion shares worth S$937 million.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to temporarily cut benefits, close factories
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc plans to temporarily close factories, reduce working hours, and cut employee benefits as part of new cost-cutting measures due to the collapse in aircraft demand following the Covid-19 pandemic. The company will also ask shareholders for £2 billion in a bid to offset the financial impact. A strike is planned at the Barnoldswick factory in the UK, protesting proposals to shift production to Singapore. The company aims to cut management costs by a third without new job cuts beyond the 9,000 announced earlier this year.

site_title: Art auctions embrace a future of socially distant bidding
summary: Art auctions have adapted to the pandemic by embracing socially distant bidding through livestreaming and online platforms. Major auction houses such as Christie's and Sotheby's have implemented hybrid models, combining in-person and online sales. These changes have led to increased engagement, with Christie's reaching 100,000 online viewers and Sotheby's selling a Francis Bacon triptych for $84.6 million via online bid. The future of auctions is expected to be a hybrid between traditional and virtual sales, with technological advancements such as augmented reality and personalized suggestions becoming more prevalent.

site_title: US dollar gives up early gains, euro rises slightly
summary: The US dollar gave up early gains, and the euro rose slightly due to rising COVID-19 concerns and investor caution ahead of the US presidential election. Despite a steep stock market sell-off on Monday, foreign exchange market activity remained muted. The euro rose 0.1% to US$1.1818, while the dollar index edged slightly lower to 92.959. Analysts expect a potential Biden victory and stimulus spending to boost investor sentiment and drive demand for riskier currencies.

site_title: Biden has economic edge over Trump
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden is projected to have an economic edge over incumbent President Donald Trump, according to recent polls and analysis. Since World War II, annual GDP growth averaged 4.3% under Democratic presidents, compared to 2.5% under Republicans. Biden's economic plan focuses on restoring economic prosperity, investing in infrastructure, and pursuing progressive taxation. His proposals, such as a federal plan to combat the coronavirus and environmental protection, are expected to have a positive impact on the economy. A recent estimate by Moody's Analytics suggests that Biden's spending plans would outweigh the dampening effect of his tax increases, resulting in a 4.5% higher real GDP by 2024.

site_title: US new home sales drop; but record low mortgage rates still underpinning demand
summary: US new home sales dropped 3.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 959,000 units in September, despite record low mortgage rates and demand for more space. This decrease followed four straight monthly increases. Home sales are concentrated in single-family segments and higher price ranges, with bidding wars reported in some areas. Despite the slowdown, economists expect the housing market to support economic growth in the next couple of quarters due to strong demand and new construction.

site_title: JTC, URA launch sites in Tampines, Sembawang, Farrer Park
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) launched a residential-commercial site in Tampines and two industrial land plots in Sembawang and Farrer Park. The URA site, spanning 8,732.9 sq m, is zoned for residential use with commercial space on the first floor. JTC launched two industrial plots, one through tender and the other open for application.

site_title: Reading financial news: top 10 avoidable distractions
summary: Financial news can be distracting and misleading, with many stories serving no redeeming value or providing shallow insights. Top 10 distractions include: market movements that are historical and rarely tell us anything about the direction of the market; coverage of ultra-rich individuals' wealth changes; stories about past investment decisions that make readers regret their choices; pundits with inconsistent track records; indicators that have no value due to sampling bias; reports on billionaires' strategies that may not be applicable to retail investors; opinions on market movements without representative samples of investors; coverage of economic concepts that are not paradoxes; stock picks based on shallow analysis; and earnings reports that fail to provide context on share buybacks and financial engineering.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz to increase stake in Aston Martin
summary: Mercedes-Benz is increasing its stake in Aston Martin to up to 20% through a technical cooperation deal. The German firm will provide Aston Martin with next-generation hybrid and electric powertrains, as well as vehicle components and systems. Mercedes-Benz currently holds 2.6% of Aston Martin and could see its stake rise to £286 million. The deal marks a significant move by Mercedes-Benz to expand its presence in the luxury car market, following the appointment of Tobias Moers as Aston Martin's new CEO earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz maker Daimler announced on Tuesday it was stepping up its technical cooperation with Aston Martin that could see the German firm take a stake of up to 20 per cent in the James Bond carmaker.

site_title: US sex cult leader jailed for 120 years
summary: US sex cult leader Keith Raniere, 60, has been sentenced to 120 years in prison for coercing women into having sex with him as the charismatic leader of Nxivm. The cult-like organization, which attracted rich and famous devotees, was found guilty of financially and sexually exploiting its members. Raniere, known as "Vanguard," exerted control over his followers, who signed up for $5,000 self-help courses, and forced them to follow a restrictive diet.

site_title: Consolidation in Indonesia's e-wallet war could reshape Grab-Gojek dynamics
summary: Indonesia's e-wallet market is poised for consolidation as reported merger discussions between Ovo and Dana may reshape the dynamics between Grab and Gojek. A merger between the two e-wallets could give Grab a negotiating advantage in potential talks with Gojek, potentially dividing the payments market in Indonesia. The move could also enable the creation of value-added fintech services, such as loans or buy-now-pay-later services. However, the complexity of the deal and potential complications with existing players, including LinkAja and Bukalapak, remain to be seen.

images.alt_text: Signs displaying the cashback rewards for Ovo and Dana at a mall in Indonesia.

site_title: Why Evergrande's investors cannot afford to force a default
summary: China Evergrande Group's strategic investors, including interior decorator Grandland Group Holdings and door maker Beijing Jiayu, agreed to a $13 billion lifeline to avoid default. The investors, who receive 58% and 26% of their sales from Evergrande, waived their $13 billion repayment. The deal includes keeping shares and not requiring a buyout, and Evergrande remains in talks with investors owed $6 billion. The agreement does not include put options, and Evergrande's largest strategic investor, Shandong Hi-Speed Group, is leaning towards demanding repayment.

site_title: HSBC to revise business model as lower interest rates hit profit
summary: HSBC reports a 35% decline in Q3 profit to $3.1 billion, citing lower interest rates as a major factor. The bank plans to shift its main source of income from interest rates to fee-based businesses, including charging for basic banking services. This change is expected to help the bank reduce costs and increase revenue. HSBC also accelerated plans to shrink in size and slash costs further than previously suggested. The bank's Hong Kong-listed shares jumped 5% following the announcement.

site_title: Rare 117,000 sq ft Dist 9 site up for sale after passing of matriarch
summary: A rare 117,000 sq ft freehold landed site in District 9, Singapore, owned by the Cheong family, is expected to be put on the market in a few months. The site, located at 5 Oxley Rise, has a land area of 117,230 sq ft and can be redeveloped into bungalows, semi-detached or terrace houses, or mansions. Industry watchers estimate the asking price to be above S$250 million, with a possible maximum of 21 bungalows, 42 semi-detached homes, or over 50 terrace houses.

site_title: Day of the Dead Barbie splits opinion in Mexico
summary: Mattel has released a new Barbie doll inspired by Mexico's Day of the Dead festival, featuring a skeletal Catrina character. While fans see it as a respectful tribute to the country's traditions, critics argue it's cultural appropriation. The doll, priced around $72, has sparked debate about the commercialization of Mexico's heritage, with some comparing it to Disney's commercialization of the festival in movies like Coco. The doll's creator aims to raise awareness about the celebration, which UNESCO has named an Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.

site_title: Prospects for RMB assets in a multipolar world
summary: China's RMB assets are gaining internationalisation, with its use in foreign transactions rising to 40% and its share in global reserves doubling to 2% since 2016. Amid geopolitical tensions, China aims to promote RMB internationalisation, driven by its need for capital imports due to a structural current account deficit. The additional yield offered by RMB assets in a low-rate environment also makes them attractive, turning the RMB into a "must-have" in a dollar-centric global financial system.

site_title: US election unlikely to tip scales for Asian stock markets, say analysts
summary: Asian stock markets are unlikely to be significantly impacted by the US presidential election, with experts advising investors to avoid making knee-jerk reactions to unfolding political developments. A Biden win is expected to bring a "modest bounce" to the region, but the impact is likely to be limited. Investment strategists recommend sticking to diversified and long-term investment strategies, rather than shifting portfolios in anticipation of the election results. Investors are advised to prepare for potential volatility and focus on quality names in their portfolios, rather than making emotional decisions based on the election outcome.

site_title: Sembcorp, SP to create platform with renewable energy certificate marketplace
summary: Sembcorp Industries and SP Group are collaborating to develop an environmental sustainability platform, which includes a marketplace for trading renewable energy certificates (RECs) and carbon credits. The platform, set to launch in the first quarter of 2021, aims to provide carbon consulting services and support corporates in achieving their carbon emission reduction targets. This move follows Singapore's pledge to reduce its emission intensity by 36% by 2030 and aims to halve emissions by 2050, with a goal of achieving net zero emissions.

site_title: SOR-linked financial products to stop by April 2021 as Singapore gears up for Sora
summary: Singapore's financial industry is set to phase out the Swap Offer Rate (SOR) benchmark by April 2021, with loans and securities linked to SOR expected to cease. The Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) is expected to become the de facto floating rate benchmark after April. All major banks, including Citibank, DBS, and HSBC, must offer Sora-based products by end-February, with the rest of banks having until April 2021 to do so. The move aims to prepare for the discontinuation of the US dollar London Interbank Offered Rate (USD Libor) and SOR.

images.alt_text: Samuel Tsien, SC-STS chairman, says that the committee has "largely completed" the key technical preparation work and laid the foundation for widespread adoption of Sora in a full range of financial products.

site_title: EH-Reit to 'assess implications' of MAS notice
summary: The manager of Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) is assessing the implications of a Notice of Intention (NOI) from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to remove its manager and appoint a new one. The MAS issued the NOI following breaches of the Securities and Futures Act (SFA) and concerns over EH-Reit's compliance with rules and regulations. The Reit manager claims it took enhanced monitoring measures and repeated efforts to comply, but MAS has serious concerns about its ability to comply. The Reit's board will continue to act in the best interest of shareholders.

site_title: Riding on the momentum to move backwards
summary: Singapore's Loss Carry-Back Relief (LCBR) system, introduced in 2005, has a cap of S$100,000 on losses. The system allows businesses to carry back losses to previous years, resulting in a timing difference in tax collection. However, this cap is considered insufficient for larger businesses facing significant cash-flow problems. Liberalizing the LCBR system could provide a more significant tax refund, aligning with international trends. The government has expressed intention to pivot to targeted support, including a liberalized LCBR system, which could be revenue-neutral if not overly relied upon.

site_title: Time to binge on Asian-flavoured chips
summary: Singapore's semiconductor production rose 10.2% year-on-year in the first nine months of 2020, outpacing the electronics cluster's 7% growth and the manufacturing sector's 5.7% increase. The sector is expected to benefit from a cyclical upswing in the global electronics sector, driven by 5G-ready handsets. Analysts predict a positive impact on equities, with Venture Corp's year-to-date price increase surpassing the Straits Times Index. However, threats remain, including travel curbs and component shortages, which could delay shipments and product launches.

site_title: More research funding to be allocated to develop digital economy: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that Singapore will allocate more national research funding to develop its digital economy, citing its critical role in the future. The government plans to adopt a dual approach to growing the talent pool, partnering with companies to make it possible. Heng emphasized the importance of science and technology in education and the government's partnership with the private sector through the TechSkills Accelerator programme.

site_title: Adelson cashing out of Vegas would come at trying time for city
summary: Billionaire Sheldon Adelson is considering selling his Las Vegas casinos, marking a difficult time for the city. Adelson, who has owned properties like the Venetian, has been a major force in Las Vegas for decades. His departure would be a significant loss for the city, which relies heavily on the casino industry for revenue. The exact terms of the potential sale are not disclosed, but it's unclear what impact it would have on the city's economy and job market.

site_title: Sustainable free trade crucial to collective recovery
summary: The pandemic has highlighted the importance of sustainable free trade in facilitating global recovery. Despite calls for protectionism, experts argue that continued globalization with equitable distribution is crucial for economic prosperity. Reshoring, or bringing supply chains closer to home, may not be efficient, as it ignores the benefits of clusters of specialization and lower costs in emerging economies. Instead, countries like Singapore are promoting digital trade and innovative platforms to drive a sustainable recovery. Policymakers and financial institutions must ensure access to capital, infrastructure, and a favorable regulatory environment to tap into global trade opportunities and minimize supply chain risks.

site_title: Hong Kong police detain three under national security law
summary: Hong Kong police detained three individuals, aged 17-21, under the national security law on suspicion of publishing content to incite others to secede from China. The detainees, including Tony Chung, a former leader of pro-independence group Studentlocalism, were taken into custody without naming them. Authorities are conducting an investigation into the suspects. This latest arrest is part of ongoing efforts to crack down on pro-independence activities in Hong Kong under the contentious national security law.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ezion Holdings' joint venture, Terasea, has been placed under creditors' voluntary winding-up following a resolution at an extraordinary general meeting. BDO Advisory has been appointed the joint and several liquidators. The winding-up is not expected to impact Ezion's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the financial year ending December 31.

site_title: Malaysia's Supermax considers listing on SGX
summary: Malaysia's Supermax Corp Bhd has proposed listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to expand its shareholder base and pursue growth opportunities. The plan, still in its initial stages, aims to diversify the company's funding channels. This comes after rival Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove maker, announced plans to list on Hong Kong's stock exchange last month. If successful, the listing could provide Supermax with additional channels to raise funds.

site_title: AIMS Apac Reit cuts Q2 DPU by 20% on lower net property income
summary: AIMS Apac Reit reported a 20% decline in second-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2 Singapore cents due to lower net property income and management fees paid in cash. Gross revenue fell 0.3% to S$30.5 million, while net property income declined 5.2% to S$21.3 million. The Reit's resilient performance was attributed to its logistics and warehouse sector, which saw high occupancy rates.

site_title: Indonesian flag carrier Garuda lays off 700 staff
summary: Indonesian flag carrier Garuda Indonesia plans to lay off 700 workers, representing nearly a tenth of its workforce, due to the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic. The airline has already put about 800 workers on unpaid leave since May, and has laid off 146 staff and adjusted nearly 6,000 workers' salaries or workloads. Garuda aims to issue convertible bonds to raise up to $789.2 million to stay afloat, amid a 57% drop in domestic air passengers and 72% drop in international air travelers.

images.alt_text: Garuda posted a net loss of US$728.15 million in the first six months of this year, down from a profit of US$78.76 million a year earlier.

site_title: Novavax delays US trial start of Covid-19 vaccine to November
summary: Novavax has delayed the start of its US trial for its Covid-19 vaccine by roughly one month, now expected to begin by the end of November. The company previously planned to start the trial this month. The company also expects interim data from its ongoing UK trial in the first quarter of next year, with an expanded enrollment target of 15,000 volunteers. This could help assess the vaccine's safety and effectiveness in a shorter time period.

site_title: Airbnb looks to list on Nasdaq
summary: Airbnb plans to list its shares on the Nasdaq, following a confidential IPO filing in August. The company's services have seen demand recover from the pandemic, setting the stage for a potential blockbuster listing. No timeline was given for the IPO completion. This move comes after several tech companies have listed on US stock exchanges, indicating a strong market for tech IPOs.

site_title: Cross-border tax cooperation on the cards for Singapore
summary: Singapore's legislative changes pave the way for participation in multilateral tax compliance programs, such as the International Compliance Assurance Programme (Icap), which aim to increase tax certainty for companies. The proposed amendments allow for the disclosure of information to authorized government officials with consent, facilitating cooperation with other countries. Singapore's participation in Icap could enhance its appeal as an international business hub, but challenges and concerns regarding resource impact, legal certainty, and trust remain. The OECD's 2021 Icap initiative is expected to be announced, and Singapore's joining of the program could strengthen its taxpayer-friendly image.

site_title: Orders for US core capital goods beat expectations in September
summary: US core capital goods orders rose 1.0% in September, beating expectations, as the economy potentially reached record growth in business spending due to fiscal stimulus from the Covid-19 pandemic. Data was revised higher for August, showing a 2.1% increase instead of 1.9%. This is a positive sign for the economy, with economists attributing the growth to government stimulus and business spending plans.

site_title: Tiffany, LVMH in indirect talks to settle dispute over US$16b deal
summary: Tiffany & Co. and LVMH are in indirect talks to settle their US$16 billion takeover deal. The two parties may lower the deal price or move to a tender offer. Tiffany's shares rose 2% after receiving European Commission approval for the deal's completion. The companies had been at odds over the deal, with Tiffany alleging LVMH had stalled and renegotiated terms, while LVMH claimed Tiffany's mismanagement during the pandemic. A settlement is seen as a possible resolution to the dispute.

site_title: European airports risk going bankrupt
summary: Nearly 200 European airports risk insolvency due to the lack of passenger traffic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. These regional airports, which support over a quarter of a million jobs and $15.6 billion in GDP, are facing insolvency unless traffic recovers.

site_title: Aspen surges 25% following plans to transfer to mainboard
summary: Aspen's shares surge 25% after the Malaysian property developer and glove maker announces plans to transfer its listing to the Singapore Exchange's mainboard. The move aims to boost visibility and tap capital markets for future growth. Aspen has entered a joint venture with CMY Capital to manufacture rubber gloves and has submitted an application to SGX for mainboard listing. The transfer is subject to in-principle approval and shareholder approval, with the company expecting to update shareholders on material developments.

site_title: Green power to draw US$11t investment by 2050
summary: Green power investments are projected to reach around $11 trillion by 2050, driven by plummeting renewable energy costs. By 2050, renewables are expected to account for 56% of global electricity, leading to emissions peaking in 2027 and a 0.7% annual decline until 2050. However, this still falls short of the 2°C warming goal, with fossil fuels expected to remain a significant part of the energy mix, with gas increasing its share due to heat pump costs not reaching parity until 2040.

site_title: Americans will soon pass judgement on Trump's Covid approach
summary: The US has reached a record high of over 83,000 new Covid-19 infections, with public health officials warning of a surge in cases as winter sets in. President Donald Trump has described the country as "turning the corner" on the pandemic, despite contradicting medical experts' advice to wear masks and practice social distancing. Trump's approach has been criticized for being cavalier, dismissive, and dishonest, and has led to over 230,000 deaths in the US. Americans will soon be able to judge whether they are ready to accept Trump's Covid-19 approach.

site_title: A rocky road to economic recovery
summary: Singapore's economy is slowly recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic, but progress is threatened by ongoing geopolitical risks, including US-China tensions. The country's nascent economic resurgence is expected to be gradual, with sectors like aviation, hospitality, and construction still facing challenges. However, the technology sector is expected to lead the recovery, with higher demand for digital tools and solutions. Analysts recommend investing in sectors like renewable energy, industrials, and value stocks in real estate and consumer goods, which are expected to benefit from longer-term global megatrends.

site_title: Pandemic reinforces importance of being diversified
summary: During the pandemic, a diversified investment portfolio has become crucial to navigate economic losses. Unlike legendary investors like Warren Buffett and George Soros, who can focus on a few winning positions, retail investors need a more diversified approach. This involves investing in companies or industries that are well-understood and avoiding those outside one's circle of competence. Diversification can also capture opportunities, such as the shift to digitalization, and balance growth and dividends. Ultimately, long-term discipline and patience are essential to ride out market fluctuations and achieve significant wealth growth.

site_title: MIT's DPU down 1% for Q2; rental reliefs to hit FY20/21 distributable income
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 1% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.10 Singapore cents for the second quarter, despite a 14.8% increase in distributable income to S$72.9 million. The decline was mainly due to rental reliefs extended to tenants, which will impact MIT's distributable income for FY20/21. The company's gross revenue and net property income grew 1.5% and 2.0% respectively, driven by new revenue from US data centres.

site_title: ShopBack sells personal finance community Seedly
summary: ShopBack, a cashback rewards player, has sold its full stake in Seedly, a personal finance community platform, to Hong Kong-based CompareAsiaGroup. The sale comes two years after ShopBack acquired Seedly to venture into the personal finance space. Seedly will continue to operate independently, while CompareAsiaGroup will help scale the platform and expand its presence in Asia. The deal marks a strategic shift for ShopBack, which is now focusing on "providing smarter shopping solutions" and enabling Seedly to realize its aspirations.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Chevron to lay off about 25% of Noble Energy employees after merger
summary: Chevron plans to lay off about 25% of Noble Energy's employees, approximately 575 people, following its US$4.1 billion acquisition of the company. This move, combined with a previously announced 10-15% workforce reduction, aims to lower operating expenses by US$1 billion. The layoffs, mostly occurring this year, will impact Noble's 2,300 employees, boosting Chevron's investments in US shale and Israel's Leviathan project. Chevron has also been cutting costs by reapplying employees for positions and laying off over 50 employees starting December 14.

site_title: US consumer confidence falls as outlook turns gloomy
summary: US consumer confidence fell in October due to a worsening outlook for the months ahead, with the Conference Board's Confidence Index at 100.9. Rising coronavirus cases and a lack of economic stimulus are contributing factors. Despite improvements in current business conditions, consumers are concerned about the economic forecast, particularly ahead of the November presidential election. This decline in confidence is a setback for the US economy, which is struggling with renewed Covid-19 outbreaks.

site_title: Japan's ANA to shrink fleet as it skids toward record US$4.8b loss
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings will retire over 35 planes and delay aircraft orders to cut costs amid a record $4.82 billion operating loss forecast for the year. The airline will also temporarily transfer workers and implement pay cuts or unpaid leave. ANA expects domestic travel to remain subdued for two years, with international routes unlikely to recover until 2024. To adapt, the airline plans to launch a low-cost airline brand in 2022 and secure $3.8 billion in subordinated loans from state-backed and private lenders.

site_title: HKMA sells HK$25.4b as currency hits strong end of trading band
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) sold HK$25.42 billion into the market to weaken the Hong Kong dollar, which hit the strong end of its trading band. The aggregate balance is expected to increase to HK$443.257 billion on October 29. This is part of the HKMA's efforts to keep the currency within its narrow range of 7.75-7.85 to the US dollar.

site_title: Nanofilm's small public tranche 'a hedge against uncertainty'
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International is offering a small public tranche of its initial public offering (IPO) to shield itself against market uncertainty. The small public offer is warranted due to the lack of local benchmarks to gauge the IPO's success. Institutional and private capital are dominating the offer, squeezing out retail investors.

images.alt_text: Nanofilm is offering 77.2 million shares at S$2.59 each for placement in its IPO. The shares comprise around 73.4 million placement shares and 3.9 million public offer shares.

site_title: Travellers from more countries allowed to serve stay-home notices at own place of residence
summary: Travellers from 9 countries, including Estonia, Fiji, and South Korea, will be allowed to serve their stay-home notices at their own residence when arriving in Singapore from Nov 4. To opt out, they must have not travelled to other countries in the last 14 days, stay alone or with household members, and have the same travel history and duration. Starting Jan 1, 2021, the government will no longer waive stay costs for Singaporeans and permanent residents who last left before March 27.

site_title: MIT's DPU down 1.0% for Q2; rental reliefs to hit FY20/21 distributable income
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) reported a 1.0% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the second quarter, to 3.10 Singapore cents, despite a 14.8% increase in distributable income to S$72.9 million. The decline was attributed to rental reliefs extended to tenants, which will partially offset distributable income for FY20/21. MIT's average portfolio occupancy rose to 92.3% and gross revenue increased 1.5% to S$103.4 million, driven by new revenue from US data centers.

site_title: Singapore market slips 0.4% amid US pre-election jitters, worries of prolonged macro pain
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.4% to 2,512.87, weighed down by pre-election jitters and rising Covid-19 cases. The US stock market also posted its sharpest loss in a month, with investors favoring bonds amid dimmed recovery prospects. Key constituents like Singtel and UOB declined, while Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust outperformed, adding 1.7%. The market's trading volume stood at 1.17 billion shares worth S$937 million, with institutional investors favoring rebalancing flows towards bonds.

site_title: GDS poised to raise US$1.67b in Hong Kong listing
summary: GDS Holdings, a Shanghai-based data centre company, has raised HK$12.9 billion (S$2.26 billion) in its Hong Kong second listing, priced at HK$80.88 each. The move follows other US-listed Chinese firms seeking a trading foothold closer to home amid US-China tensions. GDS plans to use the proceeds to expand its data centre platform and innovate in data centre design and operations. This is the latest in a series of second listings in Hong Kong, with over US$13.5 billion raised this year, including deals by JD.com and NetEase.

site_title: Rolls-Royce rescue plan flies as shareholders back £2b rights issue
summary: Rolls-Royce has successfully completed a £2 billion rights issue, backed by shareholders, to inject cash into the company's finances following the pandemic's impact on the airline industry. The approval boosts the group's total liquidity by £5 billion, allowing for debt options and enabling CEO Warren East's plan to cut 9,000 jobs and adjust to lower demand. The move is seen as a crucial step in helping the company ride out the crisis and adjust to the new market reality.

site_title: Ping An insurance quarterly profit rises amid stock rally
summary: Ping An Insurance, China's largest insurer, reported an 8% increase in third-quarter profit to 34.4 billion yuan, driven by a stock-market rally and recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. This contrasts with a 30% slump in first-half profit. The company's efforts to focus on higher-value products and trim less-productive agents have weighed on its recovery, with new business value dropping 27% in the first nine months. Investment income jumped 46% in the September quarter.

site_title: Malaysia's Supermax considers listing on Singapore Exchange
summary: Malaysia's Supermax proposes listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to expand its shareholder base, with the plan still in its initial stages. The move follows rival Top Glove's announcement to list on Hong Kong's stock exchange. Supermax, the third largest rubber glove maker in Malaysia, has not provided a timeline for the listing. If successful, the listing would increase the company's visibility and potentially attract new investors.

site_title: 3M profit beats estimates on healthcare product boost
summary: US industrial conglomerate 3M Co reported a beat on quarterly profit estimates, driven by strong demand for its healthcare products during the Covid-19 pandemic. Sales in its healthcare unit jumped 25.5% to over a quarter of total sales, while net income fell to $1.41 billion. The company's transportation and electronics division saw a 7.4% decline in sales. Despite this, net sales rose 4.5% to $8.35 billion, beating analyst expectations.

site_title: Tata Motors' loss widens as pandemic hits car sales
summary: Tata Motors, owner of Jaguar Land Rover, reported a wider loss of 3.14 billion rupees (S$57.8 million) in Q3 2020 due to weak demand in the coronavirus-hit Indian economy. Jaguar Land Rover, however, expects to be profitable in the second half of 2021 with a cost-reduction plan and new model launches. The company aims to cut its debt to "near zero" in the next three years, citing over £3 billion in cash reserves. The outlook remains uncertain due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: AMD agrees to buy chipmaker Xilinx in US$35b all-stock deal
summary: AMD agreed to acquire chipmaker Xilinx in a US$35 billion all-stock deal. The acquisition values Xilinx at US$143 a share, 35% above its previous price. The deal will expand AMD's research-and-development budget and product offerings, taking on Intel Corp. The acquisition needs shareholder and regulatory approval, estimated to take 18 months. AMD CEO Lisa Su's strategy to reduce debt and develop powerful processors has led to revenue and profit surges, bolstering confidence in the deal. The acquisition will also bring in steady cash flow from Xilinx's complementary products.

site_title: First 10 double-decker electric buses begin plying Singapore roads
summary: Singapore has launched its first 10 fully electric double-decker buses, which will operate on select bus routes, marking a step towards reducing the city-state's carbon footprint. The buses, supplied by the Chinese Yutong-Nari consortium, are more environmentally friendly, quieter, and user-friendly than conventional diesel buses, despite costing up to twice as much. The goal is to have all 5,800 public buses run on cleaner energy by 2040, with the government allocating no fixed sum for the replacement of diesel buses, instead setting a goal and aiming to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 8,000 tonnes annually.

site_title: Toyota-Panasonic battery JV to boost efficiency to catch up with Chinese rivals
summary: Toyota and Panasonic's joint battery venture, Prime Planet Energy & Solutions, aims to boost efficiency by 10 times to compete with Chinese rivals, primarily CATL. Currently, Prime Planet holds a 3% share in the high-capacity battery market for electric vehicles, lagging behind CATL's 20%. The venture plans to standardize battery designs and streamline operations to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This move is part of Toyota's goal to electrify half of its global sales by 2025.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
