summary: Singapore's logistics industry is set to create over 1,500 new jobs, with 2,100 openings. The majority (64%) of these jobs are in non-PMET roles, including transport clerks, material handlers, and freight coordinators.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq rise as earnings take centre stage
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose on Tuesday, driven by corporate earnings, despite the Dow Jones' decline. The S&P 500 opened 0.16% higher at 3,406.56, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.44% to 11,409.34. Investors were cautious ahead of the presidential election, but earnings reports were seen as a positive factor.

site_title: Indonesia central bank governor sees room for further rate cuts
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Perry Warjiyo, expressed willingness to lower interest rates further, citing low inflation and weak economic growth. The decision was made to support the rupiah, and the bank will consider factors such as inflation, exchange rates, and economic contraction at its next meeting in November. Warjiyo emphasized the effectiveness of quantitative easing as a measure to support the economy, rather than further interest rate cuts.

site_title: EH-Reit to 'assess implications' of MAS notice
summary: The manager of Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) is working with professional advisers to assess the implications of a notice from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to remove its manager due to numerous breaches of the Securities and Futures Act. The MAS cited concerns over EH-Reit's ability to comply with rules and regulations, despite enhanced monitoring efforts. The Reit manager may appeal the direction, with a written statement and supporting documents to be submitted to MAS. Trading in EH-Reit stapled securities has been suspended since March 24.

site_title: Lilly profit hit by Covid-19 drug development costs, weak demand
summary: Eli Lilly and Co reported a profit shortfall in the third quarter due to increased costs for Covid-19 therapies and lower demand for its diabetes treatment Trulicity. The company's antibody treatment, bamlanivimab, is being studied in non-hospitalized patients, and while other trials remain on track, its Covid-19 trial for hospitalized patients was paused due to safety concerns. The company expects $400 million in Covid-19 research and development expenses for 2020, sending its shares down 4%. Revenue rose 5% to $5.74 billion, but fell short of estimates.

site_title: Revez Corp acquires PGK Digital Networks for S$4m
summary: Revez Corp has acquired PGK Digital Networks for S$4 million, boosting its technological capabilities. PGK, owner of the YOUTV network, will become a wholly-owned subsidiary. The deal aims to offer clients and partners full value-chain digitalisation, leveraging PGK's media networks and Revez's creative solutions. The partnership aims to transform digital advertising and out-of-home media landscapes globally, with plans for interactivity and programmatic advertising.

site_title: Spain's Banco Santander returns to profit
summary: Banco Santander, a Spanish banking giant, has returned to profit in the third quarter after suffering massive losses in the second quarter due to the coronavirus pandemic. The bank reported a net profit of 1.75 billion euros, beating analyst estimates. Despite this, the bank still reported a net loss of 9.0 billion euros for the nine months to September, largely due to bad loan provisions. Banco Santander aims for full-year 2020 earnings of around 5.0 billion euros.

site_title: Li Ka-shing cuts Husky oil risk with US$2.9b Cenovus deal
summary: Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's richest man, is selling a portion of his stake in Canadian oil-sands player Husky Energy to Cenovus Energy in a US$2.9 billion all-stock deal. This move reduces his group's stake in the new entity to 27% and aims to mitigate losses from the coronavirus pandemic. Husky has reported US$3.3 billion in losses in three quarters, with its shares plummeting 85% over the past decade. The deal is part of Li Ka-shing's efforts to unwind a bet on oil that he made over three decades ago.

images.alt_text: Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's richest man, is unwinding a bet he placed on oil more than three decades ago by paring his group's stake in Husky Energy, a Canadian asset dealing with mounting losses.

site_title: Global shippers surf demand wave heading into Covid economy
summary: The world's major shipping companies are experiencing a surge in demand for goods, with record-breaking container loads being achieved. The 400-meter-long vessel CMA CGM's Jacques Saadé, carrying 20,723 containers, has taken the title of largest load, beating HMM Co's Algeciras. This shift in consumer preferences is forcing shipping companies to balance short-term demand with long-term capacity adjustments, as the industry tries to anticipate economic turns. Experts predict that the rebound in goods demand is uneven globally, and may be short-lived, but some companies are enjoying the increased revenue.

site_title: Indonesia says 'Jurassic Park' project no threat to Komodo dragon
summary: Indonesia's environment ministry has sought to calm outrage over a "Jurassic Park" tourism project on Rinca Island, where Komodo dragons are found. The project, which includes an elevated deck and information centre, will be completed in June. Despite concerns about the impact on the natural habitat of the vulnerable species, rangers will ensure the safety of dragons roaming near the construction site. The ministry claims measures will be taken to protect the dragons, but environmentalists say the construction must stop to preserve their living spaces. Indonesia's Komodo population is approximately 3,000.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened steady on Tuesday, following losses from the previous session due to rising coronavirus cases. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.1% to 5,796.53 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 edged up 0.1% to 12,192.39 points. Monday's losses were driven by a 3.7% plunge in Frankfurt and a 1.2% drop in London. The steady start is attributed to a focus on US-EU trade talks and sector-specific gains in mining and healthcare shares.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day with losses, closing 0.53% lower due to a sell-off on Wall Street fueled by concerns over a resurgence in coronavirus cases. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 24,787.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.10% to 3,254.32. The sell-off on Wall Street followed a similar trend in Europe, with stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector concerns.

site_title: Garuda lays off 700 workers to stay afloat
summary: Garuda Indonesia, the national carrier of Indonesia, is laying off 700 workers, or nearly 10% of its workforce, due to the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic. The move is aimed at cutting costs as demand for air travel continues to plummet. The airline has already put 800 workers on unpaid leave since May, and has reported a net loss of $728.15 million in the first six months of this year. To stay afloat, Garuda plans to issue convertible bonds to gain fresh funds.

site_title: Hong Kong to further relax restrictions on bars and restaurants, reopen beaches
summary: Hong Kong is relaxing COVID-19 restrictions, allowing six people to sit together in restaurants and four in bars, starting Friday. Dining facilities will now be open until 2am, up from midnight. The moves are part of the city's efforts to unwind strict rules put in place in July. The changes aim to boost the local economy and improve the quality of life for residents, as the city continues to navigate the pandemic.

site_title: BP swings back to small profit, refining weighs
summary: BP reported a small profit of $86 million in the third quarter, beating analysts' expectations of a loss. The company attributed the profit to a slow recovery in oil prices, but weak refining profit margins due to low fuel demand. BP's refining margin was $6.20 per barrel, less than half of what it was a year earlier. The company is reducing its headcount by 10,000 and expects a further decline in debt in the fourth quarter due to asset sales.

site_title: Pandemic pummelling foreign investment: UN
summary: The coronavirus pandemic is expected to significantly impact foreign direct investment (FDI), with a potential drop of 30-40% this year and a recovery not expected until 2022, according to a UN report. FDI worldwide declined by 49% in the first half of 2020 compared to 2019, with every major form of foreign investment taking a hit. Developed economies, particularly in Europe and North America, were hit hardest, with FDI in these regions falling by 75% and 56% respectively.

site_title: Novartis lifts 2020 forecast as drugmaker counters Covid impact
summary: Novartis AG has lifted its 2020 forecast, citing improvements in new products such as a gene therapy that sells for US$2.1 million, which is helping counter the disruption caused by COVID-19. The company expects earnings to increase by a low double-digit to mid-teens percentage, surpassing its prior forecast. CEO Vas Narasimhan attributed the improvement to the return of doctor visits for most therapies to pre-COVID levels and the company's ability to adapt to changing patterns in hospital admissions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Tuesday, up 5.74 points to 1,500.35. The index saw 4.713 billion lots traded worth RM4.106 billion, with 620 gainers and 374 losers.

site_title: Japan's Eneos to close Chita petrochemical plant in Oct 2021
summary: Japan's Eneos Holdings Inc will stop production at its Chita petrochemicals plant in central Japan next October due to a drop in local demand and fierce competition in Asia. The plant, which produces paraxylene, a raw material for plastic bottles and synthetic fibers, will be closed to avoid loss-making conditions. The halt will reduce Eneos' paraxylene capacity by 400,000 tonnes a year, but the company will retain all employees and explore transferring production facilities to rival Idemitsu Kosan. This move aims to boost overall competitiveness in the refining sector.

site_title: Champagne and donuts: Virus-beating Melbourne readies reopening party
summary: Melbourne, Australia, has achieved two consecutive days of no new coronavirus cases, marking the "double donut" milestone. The city is set to reopen its bars, restaurants, and retail stores at midnight Tuesday, with visitation rules and travel restrictions to follow. The city's lockdown has been in place for months, with the state recording a peak of over 700 daily cases in August. With 87 active cases and a handful of hospitalizations, the state is preparing for a reopening celebration, with some businesses expressing concerns about operating at a loss under strict rules.

site_title: HSBC got its lions back. Can the bank roar again?
summary: HSBC Holdings, the bank in limbo, reported a 21% drop in adjusted pre-tax profit to $4.3 billion in its third quarter, beating consensus estimates. Despite lower-for-longer interest rates and a UK regulatory ban on paying dividends, the bank's credit impairment charges fell sharply, and it expects full-year bad loan costs to be at the lower end of its previously announced range. The bank's CEO, Noel Quinn, must show the road to normal profitability in 2022 and beyond, while navigating challenges in the US-China conflict, the fintech challenge in South-east Asia, and a worsening of Covid infections in the US and Europe.

site_title: For Chinese consumers, Ant Group app is part of the fabric of life
summary: Ant Group's Alipay app is deeply ingrained in daily life for Chinese consumers, as seen in the usage by Tao Rui during a recent outing in Shanghai. He used Alipay to make purchases, donate, and access health codes, showcasing its widespread adoption. The app's ubiquity is a testament to its significance in Chinese consumers' lives, particularly in a post-COVID-19 era where digital payments have become increasingly essential.

site_title: Australian regulators to 'closely monitor' financial system risks - RBA's Bullock
summary: Australian regulators plan to closely monitor financial system risks amid the coronavirus pandemic-induced recession. Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) assistant governor Michelle Bullock stated that the country's A$2 trillion economy is facing its worst downturn in a generation, putting pressure on banks' profits and capital. Risks are rising, particularly in non-performing loans, with business failures and household balance sheet pressures expected to increase. Despite the challenges, Australian banks are well-capitalized and highly profitable, but regulators will keep a close eye on them over the coming months.

site_title: Seven new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 7 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 57,980. One case is from the community, while the remaining 6 are imported and placed on stay-home notices. The Ministry of Health identified several malls and eateries visited by infectious patients, advising people who visited these places to monitor their health closely for two weeks. The number of community cases has decreased from 4 to 2 in the past week, while globally, the virus has infected over 42.9 million people and killed over 1.15 million.

site_title: Hong Kong leader to visit Beijing to discuss plans to revive economy
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam plans a three-day visit to China next week to discuss economic revival plans. The visit comes as the global financial hub's economy has been battered by the coronavirus crisis and anti-government protests. Lam will travel to Shenzhen before heading to Beijing to meet with Chinese officials and discuss strategies to boost the economy. The trip aims to strengthen economic ties between Hong Kong and China, amid concerns about the city's economic future.

site_title: EMA awards S$23m to three firms for energy efficiency projects
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) has awarded S$23 million to three power generation companies - Senoko Energy, Tuas Power Generation, and YTL PowerSeraya - to implement energy efficiency projects by 2024, aiming to reduce carbon emissions by over 30 kilo tonnes per annum. The grants are part of the Genco Energy Efficiency Grant Call, co-funding up to 50% of the projects' costs. EMA's CEO, Ngiam Shih Chun, emphasized the importance of energy efficiency in fighting climate change, while a separate partnership between Engie Factory and the Singapore Economic Development Board aims to establish Singapore as a hub for sustainability innovation in Asia.

site_title: Vietnam PM urges Trump to take objective view in trade dispute
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc urged US President Donald Trump to take an objective view in the ongoing trade dispute between the two countries. Phuc stated that Vietnam's exchange rate policy is not aimed at creating a competitive advantage in international trade, and that a devalued dong currency would seriously hurt the economy. The US Trade Representative had initiated an investigation into Vietnam's alleged currency manipulation, which Vietnam denies. Phuc asked US officials to reassess the reality in Vietnam, amid a widening trade surplus between the two countries.

site_title: Seoul: Shares slide on coronavirus worries; strong Q3 GDP limits fall
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.56% on Tuesday, closing at 2,330.84, due to rising coronavirus cases globally. Despite this, strong domestic third-quarter GDP growth data limited losses. The country reported 88 new Covid-19 cases, fewer than 119 a day earlier. The benchmark Kospi fell for a second straight day, while the won and bond yield rose.

site_title: Dubai in talks on London air-travel agreement to boost demand
summary: Dubai is in talks with the UK government to establish an air travel agreement, which could boost demand and revive the global economy. The agreement, if approved, would allow for easier journeys between Dubai International Airport and London. Testing and quarantine requirements have been agreed upon by hubs and airlines, and securing final agreements is a priority for Dubai Airports. The move is part of Dubai's efforts to control the spread of the virus and revive the travel and tourism industry.

site_title: China plans to simplify structure of Shenzhen bourse: Caixin
summary: China's securities regulator plans to simplify the structure of the Shenzhen Stock Exchange by merging the main board with the SME board. The main and SME boards currently have identical listing and regulatory rules, so the merger will not require separate treatment. The move aims to streamline the exchange's operations and improve efficiency. The Shenzhen Stock Exchange is home to 469 listed firms on the main board and 982 on the SME board, with total market capitalization of 8.8 trillion yuan and 13 trillion yuan, respectively. The ChiNext board for tech start-ups has also undergone reforms this year.

site_title: JTC, URA launch land plots at Farrer Park, Sembawang, Tampines
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) launched a residential site near Farrer Park and two industrial land plots in Sembawang and Tampines. The URA site spans 8,732.9 sq m and could yield 405 residential units, while the JTC sites have a 20-year tenure and are zoned for heavy industrial use. The URA site is available for public tender with a six-month extension, while the JTC sites are available for tender and application, respectively. This move aims to replenish developers' land banks amid the Covid-19 situation and offer more choices for industrial development.

site_title: easyJet raises US$398.6m from further sale and leaseback deals
summary: British airline easyJet raised US$398.6 million from the sale and leaseback of nine aircraft to boost its pandemic-hit finances. The airline signed two deals, one with Wilmington Trust SP Services for five Airbus 320 aircraft and one with Sky High 112 Leasing company for four A320s. EasyJet plans to review its liquidity position and could seek more sale and leaseback deals, following the £608 million of aircraft sales it has already done during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: British airline easyJet said it raised US$398.6 million from the sale and leaseback of nine aircraft to boost its pandemic-hit finances.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as global virus cases climb, US stimulus deal stalls
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.7% to a near three-week low on Tuesday, as global virus cases rose and US stimulus deal talks stalled. Record daily cases in the US, Russia, France, and other countries, along with fading hopes on a timely US stimulus deal, fueled fears of prolonged global economic pain. Energy stocks were the top losers, with Santos and Woodside Petroleum falling nearly 3% each, while miners and financials also declined. The US stimulus deal is now expected to be delayed until February 2021, according to market expert Brad Smoling.

site_title: Grab and Microsoft to help some drivers transition to tech careers
summary: Grab and Microsoft are partnering to help Singaporean drivers transition to tech careers through a training program. 250 students will be groomed in AI skills and computer science fundamentals over 8 months. The program aims to boost digital literacy for 5,000 drivers and delivery riders by 2021. Grab plans to hire top performers into full-time roles. The partnership is part of Grab's SGUnited Skills program and Microsoft's e-learning initiative, GrabAcademy.

site_title: Hong Kong drafts law to make Covid tests mandatory for some
summary: Hong Kong is drafting a law to make COVID-19 tests mandatory for individuals with symptoms and specific high-risk groups. The move follows a voluntary city-wide summer testing program that uncovered few positive cases, amid public skepticism. The city's leader, Carrie Lam, stated that mandatory testing is necessary for public health despite Hong Kong's free society status. The plan aims to address concerns about the government's motives, which some have linked to DNA harvesting.

site_title: Dell looks to cloud for next chapter amid VMware talks
summary: Dell Technologies unveiled Project Apex, a software that enables customers to manage information and applications across public clouds and data centers. The product aims to bolster Dell's hybrid-cloud aspirations and reduce its reliance on VMware, a majority-owned subsidiary. Talks between Dell and VMware continue, with Dell exploring the possibility of distributing its shares to shareholders, potentially simplifying its capital structure and unlocking value. Any divestment is expected to occur after September 2021, when the transaction could be tax-free.

site_title: China's NEV sales to account for 20% of new car sales by 2025
summary: China's new energy vehicle (NEV) sales are expected to reach 20% of overall new car sales by 2025 and 50% by 2035, according to the China Society of Automotive Engineers. The industry predicts 95% of NEV sales in 2035 will be battery electric vehicles. NEV sales are expected to jump from 5% currently. China aims to peak carbon dioxide emissions from its auto industry by 2028 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The prediction aligns with China's Paris climate accord target.

site_title: Lyon's cure for virus blues? A morning of wine and sausage
summary: In response to France's Covid-19 curfew, some Lyon restaurants are reviving the traditional "machon," a boozy breakfast featuring hearty dishes, to bring in business. The meal, which dates back to the 19th century, typically includes sausage, mashed potatoes, and wine. While some restaurants are adapting to the new format, others are concerned that it may not fully compensate for lost dinner business. The machon is being served on Fridays and Saturdays, with prices starting at 25 euros, but its success remains uncertain.

site_title: Australian hard rock lithium producer Altura enters administration
summary: Australian hard rock lithium producer Altura Mining has entered receivership due to a prolonged period of low prices for battery materials exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. Administrator KordaMentha has begun assessing Altura's financial position and plans to move the Pilgangoora operations in Western Australia into care and maintenance in the coming week. This move is aimed at preserving the company's assets.

site_title: Four strata office units in Paya Lebar Square up for sale with S$23.5m guide price
summary: Four strata office units in Paya Lebar Square are up for sale with a guide price of S$23.5 million, averaging S$2,179 per square foot. The units, located on the ninth storey of the 2014-built building, offer sheltered access to Paya Lebar MRT station. The sale follows the completion of a Q3 wave of condo launches, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: HSBC Q3 profit tumbles 35% as bad loan provisions rise
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 35% drop in quarterly profit to $3.1 billion, beating analysts' estimates of $2.07 billion. The decline was attributed to higher loan loss provisions due to the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. Despite this, the bank's expenses were reined in, and it resumed plans to cut 35,000 jobs. Asia-focused HSBC expects losses from bad loans to be at the lower end of its $8 billion to $13 billion range.

site_title: Brokers' take: Singtel may commit over S$600m to Grab digital-bank venture
summary: Singtel may invest over S$600 million in its joint venture with Grab Holdings to establish a digital full bank in Singapore. The venture, which holds a 60% stake, is a strong candidate for a full digital banking licence, which could be awarded by the Monetary Authority of Singapore by the end of the year. DBS analysts estimate the venture could win 2-4% of the Singapore consumer market and achieve breakeven in four to five years. The partnership could leverage high-frequency real-time data to create a reliable internal credit model, targeting Grab drivers and small businesses for unsecured loans.

site_title: With new tools, Facebook aims to avoid election fiasco repeat
summary: Facebook is taking measures to prevent a repeat of the 2016 election fiasco, including delivering voter registration reminders, removing posts discouraging people from voting, and fact-checking false information. The social network has also banned posts from state-controlled media groups and taken down a video from Donald Trump Jr. calling for poll station protection. Facebook has also invested in rooting out "inauthentic coordinated behavior" and has developed contingency plans for a disputed election result, including labeling premature victory declarations and restricting the spread of misinformation.

site_title: Kweichow Moutai's charitable turn will be real market drag
summary: China's state-owned liquor maker Kweichow Moutai reported mediocre third-quarter results, with net profit growing 6.9% to 11.2 billion yuan, missing analyst forecasts. The company's market value took a hit, shaving nearly US$14 billion, as major Chinese indices declined. Moutai's charitable efforts, including donating 800 million yuan to local governments, may be a sign of the economic struggles of its home province of Guizhou, which is heavily leveraged and facing fiscal challenges. The company's third-biggest shareholder, Guizhou State-Owned Capital Management, sold over US$4 billion worth of shares, further exacerbating the situation.

site_title: Gold prices gain as coronavirus cases surge
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,908.02 per ounce on Tuesday, boosted by concerns over a global economic recovery amid a surge in coronavirus cases, particularly in the West. The US presidential election outcome and uncertainty over fresh US stimulus are expected to keep gold prices near the $1,900 level. Gold has gained 26% this year, supported by unprecedented stimulus measures and a decline in the US dollar. Other precious metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium, also saw gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes flat as upbeat earnings offset coronavirus woes
summary: Japanese shares ended nearly flat on Tuesday, with the Nikkei share average closing at 23,485.80, despite strong earnings from Canon. The airline index dropped 3.7% due to growing worries over a second wave of Covid-19 infections. Japan Airlines reported a potential record net loss of 230 billion yen and is seeking 300 billion yen in funding. Real estate companies and railway operators also struggled, with Mitsubishi Fudosan and Sumitomo Realty falling 2.4% and 1.75%, respectively.

site_title: Hedge fund LIM focusing more on distressed trading in Asia
summary: Hong Kong-based hedge fund LIM Advisors is shifting its focus to distressed trading in the Asia-Pacific region due to the pandemic's impact on markets. The firm, founded by George Long, is now prioritizing buying high-yield and distressed bonds and loans. This change comes after the COVID-19 shock led to an increase in distressed debt in Asia. LIM Advisors will still engage in opportunistic lending but is more focused on trading, particularly in secondary markets. This move is in response to signs of strain in the region, including China Evergrande Group and Vedanta Resources.

site_title: ShopBack sells personal finance community Seedly to CompareAsiaGroup
summary: ShopBack has sold its stake in personal finance community Seedly to CompareAsiaGroup. The sale includes nearly S$3 million in paid-up capital. Seedly will continue to operate independently, with CompareAsiaGroup helping to develop the platform in Singapore. The transaction is part of ShopBack's strategy to focus on its core e-commerce business.

site_title: Over 2,100 openings in Singapore logistics industry; 1,500 new jobs to be created
summary: Singapore's logistics industry has over 2,100 job openings, with 1,500 new positions to be created in the next five years, according to the Ministry of Manpower and the Economic Development Board. The majority of these jobs are in non-PMET roles, with salaries ranging from S$1,600 to S$7,250. The industry is expected to grow due to investments in digital transformation, automation, and data analysis, supporting the government's goal of strengthening the country's hub status.

site_title: Susan Hendl, ballet master and dancer, dies at 73
summary: Susan Hendl, a renowned ballet master and dancer, died on Oct. 12 at 73 from renal failure. She joined New York City Ballet in 1963 and became a principal dancer, staging numerous works by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins. Hendl worked closely with Balanchine and Robbins, and after Balanchine's death, she became assistant ballet master and staged a wide range of ballets for 25 years. A trustee for the George Balanchine Trust, Hendl was praised for her perceptive and intuitive approach to selecting companies and dancers for Balanchine's works.

site_title: Canadian energy deal creates Midwestern refining giant amid uncertain demand
summary: A Canadian energy deal creates a Midwestern refining giant, Cenovus Energy and Husky Energy merging to form a 660,000-barrel-per-day refining capacity. However, the deal comes at a time of weak demand due to pandemic travel restrictions, leaving the market oversupplied and squeezing margins. The combined company aims to lower operating costs and make it more resilient to low prices, but analysts question the rationale for the deal, citing weak growth prospects for the region.

site_title: Why Evergrande's investors can't afford to force a default
summary: China Evergrande Group's strategic investors waived their US$13 billion repayment rights due to strong ties with the developer, including 58% of sales from a listed unit and significant revenue from suppliers. Evergrande warned of a potential default if the payment was missed by January 31. The company remains in talks with investors owed US$6 billion. Suppliers' willingness to waive repayment rights was likely driven by concerns that a default could harm their own businesses. Evergrande's crisis of confidence has far-reaching implications for the global real estate market.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte wants government-to-government deal for Covid-19 vaccines
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte announced plans to secure COVID-19 vaccines through a government-to-government deal, aiming to prevent corruption and ensure timely access to vaccines. The Philippines has allocated $400 million for 40 million doses, and is evaluating late-stage trials for several vaccine candidates from China, Russia, and the US. Duterte emphasized that the country will not beg for vaccine access, instead opting for a direct deal with the manufacturer.

site_title: China launches crackdown on mobile web browsers, decries 'chaos' of information
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) is launching a crackdown on mobile web browsers, citing "chaos" of information online. The crackdown, set to conclude on November 9, aims to address social concerns over the spreading of rumors, sensationalist headlines, and content violating socialist values. Firms operating mobile browsers must conduct a "self-examination" and rectify problems. This move is part of China's ongoing efforts to tighten internet censorship rules, further restricting online content and freedom of expression.

images.alt_text: China's top cyber authority said on Monday it would carry out a "rectification" of Chinese mobile internet browsers to address what it called social concerns over the "chaos" of information being published online.

site_title: China ramps up imports from US as trade deal target looms
summary: China increased US imports in September, reaching a monthly record high of $9.9 billion, driven by surging oil, soybean, and car imports. This still falls short of the $170 billion annual target under the Phase One trade deal. China's purchases of US energy goods jumped 75% and agricultural goods 60%, with soybean imports increasing over 600%. The country has made significant progress in meeting its trade deal targets, but still has a long way to go to reach its full-year goal.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop after virus woes hammer Wall Street, Europe
summary: Asian markets fell on Tuesday after a sharp sell-off in New York and Europe due to concerns over a potential coronavirus resurgence and a lack of a new US stimulus package. The Dow dropped 2% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also suffered sharp losses. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Shanghai, and Hong Kong, fell 0.3-0.4%, while Seoul edged up slightly after a strong third-quarter growth report. Economists expect a record US growth in the third quarter but warn of an irreversible economic damage from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Asian markets fell on Tuesday following a sharp sell-off in New York and Europe that was fuelled by fears a coronavirus resurgence will force fresh economically painful containment measures.

site_title: JC Penney lenders say they're facing 'economic terrorism'
summary: JC Penney's lenders claim they're facing "economic terrorism" as they try to extract a premium from the retailer's real estate in a proposed sale. The lenders, led by Aurelius Capital Management, have submitted a competing proposal to buy the retailer's real estate while allowing mall owners to take over operations. However, the proposal is deemed infeasible, and the lenders are instead trying to "extract a premium" from the sale, according to Andrew Leblanc of Milbank.

site_title: Starbucks, Yum sales likely recovered, but new costs may weigh
summary: US restaurant chains, including Starbucks and Taco Bell, are likely to show sales recovery as consumers resume normal activities, but higher wages, commodity, and Covid-19-related costs may weigh on earnings. Despite investing in staff, cleaning supplies, and delivery, companies are facing rising commodity costs and higher expenses. Domino's Pizza and Chipotle Mexican Grill reported underwhelming earnings due to high beef and cheese prices. Starbucks' earnings report on Thursday will focus on its top line recovery and margin growth.

site_title: Japan Airlines to post record 230b yen net loss this year: Nikkei
summary: Japan Airlines is expected to post a record net loss of approximately 230 billion yen (S$2.98 billion) in the business year ending March 2021, due to a significant decline in demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. This is in line with analysts' expectations and marks a significant contrast to the airline's net profit of 53.41 billion yen in the previous year. The company has not provided guidance for the current year and will announce its first-half results on Friday, which may further impact its shares.

site_title: Second-hand site Vinted happy to scare clothing retailers
summary: Vinted, a second-hand clothing site, has completed a takeover of Dutch competitor United Wardrobe, bringing together 34 million users. The acquisition is seen as a threat to traditional fashion retailers, with Vinted's CEO stating that the industry "needs to change" to be more circular and reduce waste. With over 1.3 billion euros in sales last year, Vinted aims to accelerate growth in Europe and promote sustainable fashion practices. The deal is part of the company's strategy to capitalize on long-term trends driven by environmentally conscious consumers.

site_title: SOR-linked financial products to stop by April 2021 as Singapore gears up for Sora
summary: Singapore aims to phase out Swap Offer Rate (SOR) financial products by April 2021, shifting towards the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) as the new benchmark. Domestic systemically important banks must offer new Sora-based products by end-February, while the rest of the banks have until end-April 2021. By September 2021, all banks must substantially reduce their gross exposures to SOR derivatives. The move is part of Singapore's transition from SOR to Sora, which will become the de facto floating rate benchmark for all institutional SGD financing activity after end-April 2021.

site_title: Japan's government lays out plan to prod carriers to cut cellphone charges
summary: Japan's government has proposed a plan to reduce cellphone charges by promoting competition in the telecoms market. The internal affairs ministry called on carriers to offer easy-to-understand fee plans and services, including making it easier to switch providers and lowering costs associated with switching. The plan aims to create an environment favorable for consumers, with the goal of reducing fees to near zero when switching providers. This move is part of Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's efforts to shake up Japan's highly protected telecoms industry and reduce cellphone charges in line with other major nations.

site_title: Brokers' take: Ascendas Reit upgraded to 'add', analysts note strong fundamentals
summary: Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) has been upgraded to 'add' by analysts, citing strong fundamentals, including a robust balance sheet, diversified portfolio, and tenant base. The brokerage has increased its dividend discount model-based target price to S$3.20, up from S$3.12 previously. This upgrade follows a better portfolio occupancy achieved in the third quarter.

site_title: Cabbies and office workers: Meet Singapore's ordinary royals
summary: In Singapore, several ordinary people claim to be descendants of Sultan Hussein Shah, who ceded control of the island to the British in the 19th century, making them "ordinary royals." Seventy-nine descendants, including 14 living in a dilapidated palace, received payouts as part of a colonial-era deal. However, gaining recognition is a challenge, with many descendants focusing on their current lives rather than their royal heritage. Some claimants, like Tengku Shawal, still visit the palace and attend traditional events, while others, like Indra, downplay the importance of their royal status, emphasizing the need for meritocracy.

site_title: US EPA considering E15 labelling changes at petrol pumps: sources
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency is considering changes to labels for petrol containing E15, a higher blend of ethanol, to address concerns that current labels discourage its use. The changes aim to appease the biofuel industry, which has long sought to expand the market for E15. The proposal, which could be announced soon, would likely alter the current warning labels that advise against using E15 in older vehicles. The move is seen as part of the Trump administration's efforts to support farmers and biofuel producers ahead of the election.

site_title: Ant Group closes US$17.2b Hong Kong IPO book early amid strong demand: sources
summary: Ant Group has closed its Hong Kong institutional book building one day early, raising about $17.2 billion, amid strong demand. The book was initially set to close on Thursday but was accelerated to Wednesday 5pm. The order book was oversubscribed one hour after its launch on Monday. The Chinese fintech giant aims to raise up to $34.4 billion in a dual listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

site_title: Hong Kong leader to visit Beijing to discuss plans to revive economy
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam is set to visit Beijing next week to discuss plans to revive the city's economy, which has been severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and anti-government protests. Lam will travel to Beijing on November 3 to meet with Chinese officials and seek support measures to boost Hong Kong's economic recovery. She plans to deliver her annual policy address by the end of November and has emphasized the importance of the Greater Bay Area in providing economic benefits to Hong Kong. The visit comes amid concerns over the impact of Beijing's national security law on Hong Kong's freedoms.

site_title: Malaysia's PM Muhyiddin gets reprieve from key ally UMNO in political crisis
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin received a reprieve from his key ally UMNO, the largest party in the ruling coalition, amid a political crisis. The party declared its support for Muhyiddin, who has a thin majority in parliament, after he faced calls to resign following a failed bid to impose a state of emergency. The decision comes after the king rejected Muhyiddin's request for emergency rule, citing a leadership challenge. The move provides some relief for Muhyiddin, who has been under pressure from coalition partners due to the pandemic and economic crisis.

site_title: Hot stock: Aspen shares surge 13.6% on plans to transfer to mainboard
summary: Aspen shares surged 13.6% after the Malaysian property developer announced plans to transfer its listing to the Singapore Exchange's mainboard, aiming to boost visibility and tap capital markets for growth. The company plans to leverage the move to maximize its growth potential through future fundraising efforts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a decline on Wall Street due to fading hopes for economic stimulus and COVID-19 concerns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.72% to 23,324.30, while the Topix index lost 0.98% to 1,603.05. The lower opening was attributed to global market worries, including US-EU trade tensions and the ongoing pandemic.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday following a rout on Wall Street due to fading hopes for economic stimulus and mounting worries over the coronavirus.

site_title: ANA signs up for jet fuel made from renewable materials in Singapore
summary: All Nippon Airways (ANA) has signed a preliminary agreement to buy sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from a Singapore refinery run by Finland's Neste, marking a small step towards environmentally friendly travel. The deal will be expanded from 2023, when Neste will produce 1.5 million tonnes of SAF a year. The move comes as airlines face higher fuel costs due to the coronavirus pandemic and a growing focus on reducing aviation's environmental impact. However, the industry's shift to SAF is hampered by scarce supply and high prices, with SAF trading for several times the price of regular jet fuel in regions outside Asia.

site_title: US appeals court rejects immediate WeChat ban
summary: A US appeals court rejected a Justice Department request to immediately ban Apple's and Google's WeChat from US app stores, citing lack of imminent, irreparable injury. A US judge in San Francisco had previously blocked the ban, citing concerns over the impact on WeChat users. The decision allows WeChat to remain available in US app stores until the appeal is resolved.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street due to concerns over a coronavirus resurgence. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.32% to 24,839.97, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.32% and 0.28% respectively. The losses were attributed to investors' return from a long weekend and worries about the US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower, tracking Wall Street tumble; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower, tracking a sharp decline on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 0.4% to 2,513.94. The decline follows US stocks' worst session in weeks, driven by fading hopes for a stimulus package and rising coronavirus cases. Local banks also lost ground, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 0.3%, 0.9%, and 0.6% respectively.

site_title: China's industrial profit growth slows as factory-gate deflation weighs
summary: China's industrial profit growth slowed in September, rising 10.1% year-on-year to 646.43 billion yuan, as factory-gate deflation and rising raw materials costs hindered a manufacturing sector recovery. The slower growth followed a 19.1% increase in August and marked the fifth month of profit growth. Industrial firms' cumulative operating income and profit growth remain negative, and growth rates of accounts receivable and inventory are still high. The data highlights pockets of weakness in China's economic rebound, which has been driven by strong exports and government stimulus.

images.alt_text: Profits at China's industrial firms rose for a fifth straight month in September, but at a slower pace as factory-gate deflation and rising raw materials costs undercut a recovery in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.79 points, or 0.12%, to 1,492.82. The market saw a slight increase in volume, with 240.31 million lots traded worth RM113.76 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 184 to 121.

site_title: Sembcorp, SP to create platform with renewable energy cert marketplace, carbon consulting
summary: Sembcorp Industries and SP Group are collaborating to develop an environmental sustainability platform, featuring a renewable energy certificate marketplace and carbon consulting services. The platform aims to help corporates and consumers offset greenhouse gas emissions and achieve green targets. The launch is planned for the first quarter of next year. The move follows Singapore's pledge to reduce emission intensity by 36% by 2030 and aims to tap expertise in physical and digital solutions across energy, water, and waste management to achieve carbon reduction targets.

site_title: Resurgent pandemic pushes back air travel's recovery
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is pushing back air travel's recovery, with airlines urging governments to introduce more testing and travel bubbles to boost demand. The industry is expected to burn through $77 billion in cash in the second half and several carriers are retrenching and reducing capacity. Exceptions include China, where domestic flights have surged, and the US, where airlines carried one million passengers on a single day for the first time since March. Industry experts stress the need for government support and caution that the pace of recovery will depend on how other markets follow China's model.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near three-week low as global virus cases resurge
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.1% to a near three-week low, hurt by global concerns about the economic health amid surging COVID-19 cases in Europe and the US. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with tech and energy sub-indices diving 2% and 1.5% respectively. Zip Co and Adore Beauty Group were the biggest losers, with losses of 5.8% and 5% respectively. The decline follows record daily jumps in infections in the US, Russia, and France, weighing on Asian markets.

site_title: Jack Ma becomes richer than Walmart heirs with mega Ant IPO
summary: Jack Ma's 8.8% stake in Ant Group is valued at $27.4 billion, making him the world's 11th richest person with a fortune of $71.6 billion. Ant Group's record IPO, priced at 68.8 yuan and HK$80, will raise almost $35 billion, surpassing Saudi Aramco's $29 billion sale last year. The IPO will also boost the fortunes of early investors and employees, with at least 18 people becoming billionaires. Ant's market value could reach $320 billion, making it more valuable than JPMorgan Chase & Co and four times bigger than Goldman Sachs Group.

site_title: Trump, Biden make pitches to voters in pivotal Pennsylvania
summary: US President Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Joe Biden made final pitches to voters in Pennsylvania, a crucial battleground state, with the US election just eight days away. Trump held rallies in Martinsburg, while Biden met with volunteers in Chester, near Philadelphia. Biden criticized Trump's handling of the coronavirus pandemic and Trump defended his administration's efforts. Despite Biden's lead in national polls, the contest appears tighter in Pennsylvania, where a majority of voters can swing to either party.

site_title: Barrett confirmed to US Supreme Court in Trump pre-election triumph
summary: The US Senate confirmed Amy Coney Barrett as the Supreme Court's newest justice, delivering a landmark win for President Donald Trump eight days before the election. The 52-48 vote, largely along party lines, cemented a six-to-three conservative majority. Barrett is the third Trump nominee to reach the high court, and Republican lawmakers applauded the confirmation. The White House is expected to celebrate the win in the final run-up to the November 3 election.

site_title: Bank of China to boost debt team by 40% amid offshore deal surge
summary: Bank of China plans to expand its offshore bond team by 40% to 90 staff over the next five years, seeking to win more dollar bond deals from Chinese technology giants and euro notes from mainland borrowers. The move aims to capitalize on the surge in Chinese borrowers in the market, which has seen a doubling of dollar bond segment to $864 billion since 2016. The bank aims to improve its debt capital market-related services, including settlement, market-making, and credit research, to compete with top international investment banks.

site_title: AIMS Apac Reit cuts Q2 DPU by 20% on lower net property income
summary: AIMS Apac Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 20% to 2 cents for its Q2, due to lower net property income and management fees. Gross revenue declined 0.3% to S$30.5 million, while NPI dropped 5.2% to S$21.3 million. The Reit's portfolio, anchored in the logistics and warehouse sector, has shown resilient performance amid global uncertainties.

site_title: In fight with Amazon, India's Future Retail sees liquidation if Reliance deal fails
summary: India's Future Retail Ltd may go into liquidation if its deal to sell assets to Reliance Industries fails after Amazon won an injunction to halt the deal. The dispute centers around FRL's decision to sell its businesses for $3.38 billion, including debt, which Amazon alleges FRL breached in a separate contract. If the deal falls through, FRL's creditors could be left with significant losses. The company's shares have plummeted since the deal was announced in August.

site_title: Washington announces US$2.4b sale of 100 Harpoon coastal defence systems to Taiwan
summary: The US State Department announced a $2.4 billion sale of 100 Harpoon coastal defense systems to Taiwan. The sale aims to improve Taiwan's security, maintain regional stability, and balance military forces. This move is expected to anger Beijing, following a recent US$1 billion missile deal with Taiwan. The proposed sale has significant implications for the region, particularly given the ongoing tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Facebook takes mobile games into the cloud
summary: Facebook has launched a cloud gaming service allowing players to access a range of mobile games without downloading apps, but only on Android and web platforms. The move is a departure from console-quality cloud gaming services like Google Stadia and Microsoft xCloud, and comes amid a dispute with Apple over the App Store's 30% cut of transactions. Facebook will initially offer Asphalt 9: Legends and PGA TOUR Golf Shootout, and says it plans to increase cloud gaming options without replacing console and PC gaming.

site_title: Asymptomatic Covid-19 sufferers lose antibodies sooner: study
summary: A study by Imperial College London and Ipsos Mori found that asymptomatic Covid-19 sufferers lose detectable antibodies sooner than those with symptoms, with a 26.5% decline over three months. The prevalence of virus antibodies fell by over a quarter nationwide, from 6.0% to 4.4%, coinciding with the decline of the virus's prevalence. The loss of antibodies was slower in 18-24 year-olds compared to those aged 75 and over, and the study highlights the need for continued guidance to reduce the risk of reinfection.

site_title: AIG names new CEO, breaks up its insurance business
summary: AIG names new CEO Peter S Zaffino, who will lead the company starting March 1, 2021. Current CEO Brian Duperreault will become executive chairman of the board. The company also announced plans to separate its Life & Retirement business from the General Insurance unit, aiming to simplify its corporate structure and increase profitability. AIG expects a third-quarter pre-tax loss of $790 million, with $185 million related to Covid-19.

site_title: Huawei's Meng back in Canadian court to fight extradition to US
summary: Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou returned to a Canadian court to fight extradition to the US. She was arrested in 2018 on charges of bank fraud related to US sanctions against Iran. Meng's lawyers will argue that Canadian authorities violated her rights during questioning and device searches, and that a US conspiracy to delay her arrest and obtain evidence for prosecution. If proven, the allegations could result in a stay of the extradition proceedings. The case is set to wrap up in April 2021.

site_title: South Korea's economy returns to growth amid global virus struggle
summary: South Korea's economy rebounded in the third quarter, growing 1.9% seasonally adjusted from the previous quarter, marking the fastest expansion since 2010. This reverses a 3.2% decline in the second quarter and beats a Reuters poll's 1.7% expansion. The economy shrank 1.3% from a year earlier, after a revised 2.7% decline three months prior. The growth is attributed to major trading partners lifting pandemic restrictions.

site_title: Siglap Shopping Centre goes on collective sale with S$120m reserve price
summary: Siglap Shopping Centre, a 39,635 sq ft mixed-use site in Singapore, is going on collective sale with a reserve price of S$120 million. The site, completed in 1980, comprises eight commercial and eight residential units. The sale will be conducted via public tender.

site_title: Oil drops 3% as virus infections, Libyan oil output rebound
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% on Monday, extending last week's losses, amid surging US and European coronavirus cases and Libya's rebound in crude production. The US reported its highest new infections in two days, while Italy and Spain imposed restrictions. Libya's National Oil Corp ended force majeure on closed facilities, potentially complicating OPEC's efforts to restrict supply. OPEC's secretary general warned of a longer oil market recovery due to rising coronavirus cases worldwide.

site_title: Google, Temasek agree to invest US$350m in Indonesia's Tokopedia
summary: Google and Temasek Holdings have agreed to invest approximately US$350 million in Tokopedia, a major Indonesian online mall, to fund its post-Covid-19 expansion. The Alphabet unit and Singapore's state investment firm are set to sign an agreement for the funding soon. This significant investment will support Tokopedia's growth and expansion plans, marking a major cash infusion for the company.

site_title: Compass, SingNet in copyright fight over alleged Singtel TV infringement
summary: Singtel subsidiary SingNet is embroiled in a copyright dispute with collecting society Compass over alleged infringement of musical works since 2013. Compass is seeking 1.5% of SingNet's annual pay-TV net revenue from 2013 to 2019, while SingNet argues it should not pay licence fees based on all revenue. The dispute is ongoing, with the High Court recently ruling that the tribunal has no power to grant retrospective orders. The case is part of a wider review of collecting societies in Singapore's copyright regulatory regime, with the government proposing a licensing scheme to regulate these organisations.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands mulling US$6b sale of Vegas casinos: source
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp is exploring a potential US$6 billion sale of its flagship Las Vegas casinos, including the Sands Expo Convention Centre, the Venetian Resort Las Vegas, and the Palazzo. The move comes amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, which has heavily impacted the gambling industry. The company, led by Chairman and CEO Sheldon Adelson, has been working with an adviser to solicit interest from potential buyers. The sale could help reduce Las Vegas Sands' US$13.82 billion total outstanding debt, excluding finance leases.

images.alt_text: Casino operator Las Vegas Sands Corp is exploring a sale of its flagship casinos in Las Vegas in a deal that may bring in US$6 billion, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Monday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA Engineering, Singtel, Sembcorp, Ascendas Reit, AIMS Apac Reit
summary: SIA Engineering agreed to buy out Cebu Air's interest in SIA Engineering Philippines Corporation and sell its stake in Aviation Partnership (Philippines) Corp. to Cebu Air. Singtel is involved in a legal dispute over music royalties for its pay-TV service. SIAEC shares rose 0.6% to S$1.73, while Singtel shares closed unchanged at S$2.12.

site_title: In proactive move, Twitter aims to 'pre-bunk' election falsehoods
summary: Twitter is introducing "pre-bunks" to alert users to potential election falsehoods ahead of the November 3 US election. The move aims to prevent baseless claims from spreading. The platform will display notices warning of potential misinformation about voting by mail and delayed election results. This proactive step is part of Twitter's efforts to stem misinformation, following similar moves by other online platforms. The goal is to build resilience against misinformation and promote accurate information.

site_title: 'We cannot give up,' WHO chief says of pandemic fight
summary: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urged leaders not to give up in the fight against Covid-19, despite a surge in cases and pandemic fatigue. He emphasized the importance of suppressing transmission and controlling the virus, contrasting with US President Trump's administration, which is focusing on mitigation rather than stamping out the virus. Tedros warned that giving up on virus controls is "dangerous," while WHO emergencies chief Michael Ryan stressed the need to continue efforts to suppress transmission.

site_title: Zimbabwe mining boss arrested for alleged gold smuggling
summary: Zimbabwean mining federation president Henrietta Rushwaya, 53, was arrested at Harare's international airport for allegedly smuggling 6.09kg of gold worth around US$366,000. The gold was found in her hand luggage as she prepared to board a flight to Dubai. Authorities say the arrest is a suspected smuggling case, as the country loses nearly US$100 million worth of gold illicitly taken out each month. Rushwaya is expected in court on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore SMEs tap digital tools amid pandemic
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have adopted digital tools at a higher rate compared to their peers in Australia, New Zealand, North America, and Canada, according to a study by Xero. The study found that 62% of Singapore SMEs used online business solutions during the pandemic, resulting in a 30% increase in overall cloud adoption from 2019, the largest increase among the five markets surveyed. This digitalization enabled SMEs to manage operations more efficiently and better engage with customers.

site_title: US: Wall Street tumbles, Dow ends down 2.3%
summary: US stocks plummeted, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.3% to 27,685.38, amid fading hopes for US stimulus, coronavirus worries, and election jitters. The S&P 500 dropped 1.9% to 3,400.97, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.6% to 11,358.94. The decline marked the worst session in weeks, with investors uncertain about the November 3 elections and the ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: 9 in 10 Singapore SMEs open to digital banks: Visa
summary: Almost 90% of Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are open to switching to digital banks, according to a Visa study. SMEs prefer digital banks for lower costs and greater convenience, but also want control over their banking needs and trust. To win over SMEs, digital banks need to establish partnerships, build trust, and provide personalized services. Experts suggest that digital banks should focus on addressing SMEs' pain points, such as lack of trust in relationship managers and limited access to corporate banking products.

site_title: Nomura seeks M&A bankers as Japan deals surge
summary: Nomura Holdings is hiring bankers for its mergers and acquisitions (M&A) business in Japan as the country experiences a sharp rebound in domestic deal-making, driven by a recovering economy and companies seeking to reshape themselves post-pandemic. Consultations on local deals are up 30-40% from usual levels, with clients seeking advice on various transactions. This surge has vaulted Nomura to the top ranks of global advisers, putting it on track to end the year among the world's top 10 advisers for the first time.

site_title: Goldman Sachs attempted to cover up sexual misconduct, lawsuit claims
summary: Goldman Sachs is accused of covering up workplace sexual misconduct allegations made by former associate general counsel Marla Crawford. Crawford claims the bank's global head of litigation, Darrell Cafasso, used his power to "romantically prey" on a younger colleague, leading to Crawford's firing after 10 years of exemplary performance. The bank hired an investigation firm to quickly "sweep it under the rug," and Cafasso returned to work after just two weeks, while the alleged victim left the bank. Goldman Sachs denies the claims, stating they found the allegations "completely without merit."

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc attempted to cover up allegations of workplace sexual misconduct by the bank's global head of litigation, a lawsuit filed on Monday in New York State Supreme Court claimed.

site_title: Singapore-Denmark tie-up spurs innovation for greater good
summary: Singapore and Denmark have strengthened their five-year commitment to green and environmental collaboration, despite the economic setbacks caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The partnership aims to promote sustainable development, climate adaptation, and green infrastructure. Denmark has committed S$60 billion to build two energy islands, which could expand to 12 gigawatts of renewable energy. The collaboration seeks to drive innovation through public-private partnerships, with a focus on green technologies and sustainable growth, and serves as a model for other countries to follow in building a low-carbon future.

site_title: Saddam's right-hand man dead: dictator's daughter
summary: Izzat Ibrahim al-Duri, a key figure in Saddam Hussein's regime and a long-time fugitive, has died, according to the executed dictator's daughter and the Baath party. A 78-year-old general, Duri was known as the "Iceman" for his humble origins and had a US$10-million bounty on his head after Saddam's capture in 2003. He had previously been reported dead or captured, only to resurface in audio or video messages, and was linked to insurgencies after the invasion. The cause and location of his death are unknown.

site_title: Xi's carbon neutrality vow to reshape China's five-year plan
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has pledged to make the country "carbon neutral" by 2060, prompting policymakers to set radical climate targets in the upcoming five-year national development plan. The 2021-2025 plan must include ambitious climate goals, with experts recommending an absolute emissions cap and enhanced support for technology like carbon capture. China needs to reduce its reliance on coal, aiming to bring the share of coal in its energy mix from 58% to less than 50% by 2025, and increase renewable energy capacity. The country faces significant challenges in achieving carbon neutrality, with analysts warning of a social transition and the need for systemic change.

site_title: US stimulus talks slow but continue, prospects dimming
summary: US policymakers held talks on a new spending package to aid the virus-hit economy, but negotiations have stalled, dimming hopes of an agreement before the November 3 election. The need for stimulus has increased due to rising Covid-19 cases, expiring support programs, and looming foreclosures and business loan deadlines. After months of talks between Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, time is running out to reach a deal before President Donald Trump's reelection. The prospects of a stimulus package appear to be dwindling.

site_title: STI falls 0.6% on virus resurgence, US election uncertainty
summary: The Singapore bourse fell 0.6% on Monday, led by the resurgence of coronavirus cases in the US and Europe, and uncertainty ahead of the US presidential election on Nov 3. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 14.08 points to 2,523.31. Key regional markets, including Japan, China, and Australia, also closed in the red. Trading volume in Singapore was 1.27 billion shares worth S$885.60 million. Banking stocks DBS, UOB, and OCBC led the losses, while SIA bucked the trend with a 1.12% gain.

site_title: Training staff and fighting fire: both vital for survival
summary: Firms must balance training staff and fighting to stay afloat during the pandemic, as stagnation can lead to competitors overtaking them. Experts from Singtel, Rajah & Tann, and RSM discuss the importance of re-training and up-skilling staff, as well as job re-design, to ensure firms remain competitive. Firms should not see training and layoffs as an "either-or" situation, but rather as both critical for survival and growth. With the pandemic adding urgency to adapt to new norms, SMEs need to invest in workforce capabilities to deliver sustainable growth.

site_title: Battlelines drawn
summary: Key events and conclusions: Japan's succession crisis and Alibaba's turf war are fueling stock gains. Alibaba's stock rose 6,000% due to the crisis, while Alibaba risks a $100 billion US rout. China's Xi signals a possible end to deflationary price wars, and Huawei seeks AI chip customers in the Middle East and South-east Asia. The US stock market reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher. US President Trump unveiled new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil.

site_title: Biggest Malaysian party meets as support for PM hangs in balance
summary: Malaysia's largest party, Umno, met to discuss its support for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, who faces a crucial leadership test next month as the government prepares for a federal budget presentation. The meeting, held after the king rejected Muhyiddin's request for emergency powers, saw many BN leaders reject the possibility of working with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. Umno supreme council leader Puad Zarkashi urged Muhyiddin to step down, questioning his credibility as prime minister. The government's support is now hanging in the balance, with a vote of no confidence potentially looming.

site_title: With vacation rentals empty, European cities see a chance to reclaim housing
summary: European cities are seizing the opportunity to reclaim housing as the pandemic has reduced the flow of tourists, allowing cities to push short-term rentals back onto the long-term housing market. Lisbon is becoming a landlord itself by renting empty apartments and subletting them as subsidized housing, while Barcelona is threatening to take possession of empty properties. Other cities, such as Amsterdam and Paris, are enacting or planning laws to curb the growth of short-term rentals. This shift is expected to increase the supply of affordable housing, with Lisbon aiming to attract 1,000 apartment owners and Paris planning a referendum on Airbnb-type listings.

site_title: Hotels roll with the punches to keep rooms occupied
summary: Singapore hotels are seeing high occupancies on weekends as residents take on staycations due to the global pandemic. As of October 15, 223 hotels were approved for staycations, up from 80 in July. Occupancies at hotels offering staycations range from 70-90% on weekends, with luxury hotels like The W Singapore-Sentosa Cove and Capella commanding high prices. The industry is also seeing improved occupancy rates, with the average occupancy rate for Singapore hotels reaching 62% in August. Analysts predict that the staycation trend will continue as the year-end peak season approaches, but warn that the recovery for the hospitality industry may still be slow.

site_title: UBS's Ermotti says reviving payouts best part of reign as CEO
summary: UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti is stepping down on November 1, leaving behind a bank that has grown to a $2.5 trillion asset base under his leadership. Ermotti, who took over in 2011, has overseen a pivot from volatile investment banking to wealth management, stabilizing the bank and improving its capital strength. He leaves behind a potential $5 billion fine over tax evasion allegations and challenges in navigating Europe's ban on payouts. Ermotti hopes to be remembered for stabilizing the bank and reinforcing its culture, and has expressed a desire to see more women in leadership positions within the industry.

site_title: Hyundai reports quarterly loss of 336b won
summary: Hyundai Motor Co reported a net loss of 336 billion won (S$404.5 million) for the July-September quarter, missing market estimates by a wide margin. The loss was primarily due to costs related to engine-quality issues and recalls, which totaled 2.1 trillion won. Excluding quality costs, Hyundai would have reported a profit of 1.8 trillion won. Revenue rose 2.3% to 27.6 trillion won, and the company's stock rose 4.2% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Costs related to engine-quality issues and recalls smashed what would otherwise have been strong earnings.

site_title: It's time to change the Asian mindset about corporate restructuring
summary: In Asia, corporate restructuring is often viewed as a procedure ending in liquidation, but a shift in mindset is needed to recognize it as a potential gateway to business rescue. Historically, insolvency laws and ecosystems have been underdeveloped, but countries like Singapore, Malaysia, and India are modernizing their laws to facilitate cross-border insolvency. As the COVID-19 pandemic forces companies to confront debt restructuring needs, the stigma associated with insolvency may be reduced, and the value of restructuring processes will be better recognized. The next few years will be crucial in developing a sea change in the cultural perception of restructuring and insolvency in Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore has positioned itself as Asia's leading debt restructuring hub by enhancing its legal framework to make it relatively easy to rescue struggling companies.

site_title: Europe: SAP drags down German shares, Covid-19 worries weigh on stocks
summary: Germany's DAX index fell 3.7% on Monday as SAP's worst trading day in 24 years, citing a 22% slump and abandoning medium-term profitability targets. Europe's tech sector also declined, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index closing at a one-month low. Fresh Covid-19 restrictions in Italy and Spain weighed on the region, with the euro zone blue-chip index falling nearly 3%. The Stoxx 600 index is now expected to reach 340 points by year-end, about 4.5% below its current level, according to UBS.

images.alt_text: German shares closed at their lowest in nearly four months on Monday as Europe's most valuable tech firm, SAP, experienced its worst trading day in 24 years after cutting its 2020 outlook.

site_title: More hotels jumping on staycation wagon
summary: Singapore hotels are shifting focus to staycation packages as the year-end peak season approaches, with attractive deals luring holiday-starved families and young couples. The Parkroyal Collection Pickering reopened on November 1, offering staycation guests and business travelers. Other hotels, such as Far East Hospitality and Andaz Singapore, are also seeing strong demand for staycations. Analysts expect demand for alternative business, such as stay-home-notice facilities, to gradually decline as Singapore contains Covid-19 cases. Lifestyle and boutique hotels offering unique experiences and wellness packages are expected to have an edge in the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings, a Malaysian developer listed on the Catalist, plans to transfer its listing to the mainboard to boost visibility and access capital markets for growth. This move aims to maximize the group's growth potential.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty, while investors weighed tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. In the Singapore stock market, NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Singapore, Germany deepen support for local, German SMEs
summary: Singapore and Germany have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to deepen business ties and technical exchange between the two countries. The MOU supports enterprise development in sectors such as advanced manufacturing, digitalization, and innovation, with a focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The agreement also includes a refreshed version of the Germany Singapore Business Forum (GSBF) called GSBF Connect, which aims to facilitate more frequent collaborations between companies in the two countries.

site_title: Ant set to raise almost US$35b in biggest-ever IPO
summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant led by billionaire Jack Ma, is set to raise approximately $34.5 billion through its initial public offerings (IPO) in Shanghai and Hong Kong, the largest IPO in history. The IPO will value Ant at $315 billion, surpassing JPMorgan and four times that of Goldman Sachs. The company has attracted interest from top money managers and individual investors in China, with institutional investors subscribing for over 76 billion shares in the Shanghai IPO.

site_title: MAS issues notice to remove manager of EH-Reit
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a Notice of Intention (NOI) to remove the manager of Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit), marking the first time such a notice has been issued. The trustee of EH-Reit will be required to remove the manager and appoint a new one.

site_title: Asean moves one step closer to power integration
summary: Asean is set to sign a memorandum of understanding with Laos, Thailand, and Malaysia to advance cooperation on cross-border power trading, known as the Lao PDR-Thailand-Malaysia-Singapore Power Integration Project. The project aims to reduce costs and integrate variable renewable energy resources, with the goal of creating a more sustainable energy future. The agreement is expected to be signed at an Asean meeting in mid-November, following discussions on lower energy intensity and growing the renewable portfolio in Asean's energy mix.

site_title: Safe-haven US$ up as Covid-19 surges, US stimulus hope fades
summary: The US dollar rose as Covid-19 cases surged in the US and Europe, making it a safe-haven currency. Despite a lack of progress on a US stimulus package, the dollar gained 0.1% against a basket of currencies, while the euro fell 0.3%. The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen. US Treasury yields fell to their lowest since Wednesday, while the Chinese yuan hit a one-week low against the US dollar.

site_title: Thai protesters march on German embassy to seek probe of king
summary: Protesters in Thailand marched on the German embassy, demanding an investigation into King Maha Vajiralongkorn's activities in Germany. The protests, led by students, also call for the removal of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha and a new constitution. Critics accuse the monarchy of enabling military rule and criticize spending on the king's European visits. German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas stated that investigating the king's behavior would be unacceptable. The protests have broken a taboo on discussing the monarchy, with critics facing up to 15-year jail sentences for criticism.

site_title: Giacometti sculpture in sealed bid auction with US$90m starting price
summary: A Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti's nearly 2.7-metre tall bronze sculpture "Grande femme I" is being auctioned by Sotheby's with a US$90 million starting price. If sold for over US$100 million, Giacometti will equal Pablo Picasso as only the second artist with four works beyond that threshold. The hybrid auction, with sealed bids, closes at midnight on Tuesday, and the winning offer will remain secret. The sculpture, cast in 1960, is part of a series intended for a New York plaza, and its sale will be the culminating example of Giacometti's exploration of the female standing figure.

site_title: Large SE Asian listings have mixed debuts on outlook concerns
summary: Southeast Asian listings Converge ICT Solutions and MR DIY Group had mixed debuts on Monday, with Converge's shares falling 11.2% and MR DIY's shares rising 9.4%. Analysts cite expansion concerns in pandemic-hit markets as the reason for the mixed performance. Despite underperforming stocks and currencies, the region has raised $7.1 billion in IPOs so far this year, led by Thailand's 21% growth from the same period last year.

site_title: Coca-Cola European goes global with US$6.6 billion Australia deal
summary: Coca-Cola European Partners agreed to acquire Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd in Australia for A$9.23 billion, creating a global packaged beverage producer. The deal values Sydney-based Coca-Cola Amatil at a 19% premium to its last week's share price, and would double the European company's market potential, reaching almost 300 million consumers in the Southern Hemisphere. The acquisition aims to withstand industry slowdowns and shifting consumer preferences towards non-sugary drinks, and is seen as a strategic move to expand the company's geographic footprint.

site_title: 24.2% factory output jump in Sept raises Singapore GDP hopes
summary: Singapore's factory output surged 24.2% year-on-year in September, exceeding economists' expectations, and boosted third-quarter GDP growth. The surprise increase was driven by a near-doubling in biomedical manufacturing output, with pharmaceuticals and medical technology segments leading the way. Economists now expect final Q3 GDP growth to be between -5.6 and -5.4%, up from the official advance estimate of -7%. The strong showing has raised hopes for full-year performance, with some economists revising their estimates.

site_title: Green energy drive: Singapore plans trial import of Malaysian electricity
summary: Singapore plans a two-year trial to import 100 megawatts of electricity from Malaysia, aiming to share clean-energy sources and eventually expand to other countries. The trial will assess technical challenges and assess the impact on wholesale electricity prices. The government is also setting aside S$50 million for low-carbon energy research, including hydrogen and carbon capture utilization. Singapore aims to accelerate solar adoption, aiming for 1.5 GWp by 2025 and 2 GWp by 2030, and develop better energy storage systems to address the intermittency of solar energy.

site_title: ARA Logos to buy Australia properties, invest in sponsor's funds
