summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (Reit), plans to buy five Australian properties and invest in two funds for S$404.4 million. The acquisition includes a cold storage facility in Brisbane and properties in New South Wales and Victoria, increasing the Reit's deposited property value by 28.2% to S$1.7 billion. The portfolio's weighted average lease expiry will improve to 4.6 years, and the blended net property income yield is about 5%. The Reit manager aims to fund the acquisition through equity fundraising and external bank borrowings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's industrial production surged 24.2% in September, driven by strong pharmaceutical output, which may cushion the third quarter's GDP contraction. The country is also launching a trial to import electricity from Malaysia over two years. Keppel O&M and EMA have awarded a grant for Singapore's first floating energy storage system, set to be completed in 2023. Meanwhile, the Singapore shares fell 0.6% due to triple factors, including the coronavirus, US election, and earnings.

site_title: US, India double down on Asia-Pacific alliance
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Defence Secretary Mike Esper are in New Delhi for the third annual 2+2 ministerial dialogue with Indian counterparts, Defence Minister Rajnath Singh and External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar. Key agreements expected include access to sensitive US satellite data for missile targeting and cooperation in the Asia-Pacific region. The meeting aims to strengthen the alliance between the world's two largest democracies.

site_title: Nanofilm IPO a play on growth stocks in tech space
summary: Nanofilm Technologies International, a spin-off from Nanyang Technological University, is set to list on the Singapore Exchange with a S$470.1 million IPO, making it the first tech unicorn on the local bourse. The company's advanced materials business unit generates 77% of its revenue, with a market capitalization of around S$1.7 billion post-listing. Despite high pricing, Nanofilm's fundamentals are attractive for investors seeking growth stocks in the tech space, driven by a growing advanced materials market and a strong patent portfolio.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as virus cases surge, stimulus doubts
summary: US stocks began the week on a downward note, with the Dow Jones falling 0.53% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropping 0.69% and 0.93%, respectively. The decline was attributed to surging coronavirus cases and a stalemate in Washington over the next fiscal aid bill ahead of the November 3 presidential election.

site_title: US new-home sales fell slightly in September
summary: US new-home sales decreased 3.5% in September to 959,000 annualized pace, contrasting economists' median forecast of 1.03 million. Despite this, sales remain elevated and lean inventory is restraining demand, which is partly due to record-low mortgage rates. The median selling price rose 3.5% to $326,800, while the supply of new homes ticked up slightly and would take 3.6 months to exhaust at current sales pace. Existing home sales strengthened to the highest level in 14 years.

site_title: Ant Group set to raise US$34b in record IPO
summary: Ant Group, a Chinese financial technology company, is set to raise around $34 billion in its record-breaking initial public offering (IPO), priced at $10.30 per share. This would make it the largest IPO on record, surpassing Saudi Aramco's $29.4 billion IPO last year. The company's valuation would be around $310 billion, comparable to that of JPMorgan Chase. Ant's Alipay mobile payment service has over 730 million monthly users, making it a significant player in the global financial technology market.

images.alt_text: The IPO is attracting interest from some of the world's biggest money managers, and sparking a frenzy among individual investors in China clamouring for a piece of the sale.

site_title: Keppel Charity Golf raises S$1.57m for charity
summary: Keppel Charity Golf raises S$1.57 million for charity, exceeding expectations. The event took place on October 24 and 25, 2020, with guest-of-honour President Halimah Yacob attending the afternoon kick-off. The funds raised will support various charitable causes. This marks the successful conclusion of the Keppel Club's annual charity golf event.

site_title: SIA Engineering announces deals involving investments in the Philippines
summary: SIA Engineering Company has entered into two agreements with Cebu Air, acquiring its 35% stake in SIA Engineering Philippines Corporation (SIAEP) for US$7.74 million and selling its 51% stake in Aviation Partnership (Philippines) Corp (APP) for US$5.61 million. SIAEP is a Clark-based provider of airframe maintenance services for B737, A320, and A330 aircraft, while APP offers line maintenance services at various airports in the Philippines. The deals aim to strengthen SIA Engineering's core competencies and enhance its status as the group's centre of excellence for narrow-body aircraft maintenance.

images.alt_text: SIA Engineering Company, the engineering unit of Singapore Airlines, announced on Monday that it will pay US$7.74 million for Cebu Air's 35 per cent shareholding in SIAEP.

site_title: Why the US election matters to Singapore
summary: The outcome of the US presidential election has implications for Singapore, which has good relations with both the US and China. Even if Joe Biden wins, the US-China trade war is unlikely to end, with China easing market access and tariffs only as part of negotiations. A Biden administration may be more amenable to negotiations, but a reset to zero tariffs is unlikely. Singapore may benefit from a rules-based trading order and a more diplomatic US approach, but a Biden tax increase and stricter human rights policies could be detrimental. The outcome could lead to protracted uncertainty, affecting market sentiment and business confidence.

site_title: Moon richer in water than once thought
summary: Scientists have found that the moon may be richer in water than previously thought, with two studies published in Nature Astronomy suggesting there could be more water trapped in the surface, including ice stored in permanently shadowed "cold traps" at lunar polar regions. Researchers used data from the Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy to distinguish the spectral fingerprint of molecular water, and found that water might be trapped in glass beads or other substances that protect it from the harsh lunar environment. The discovery raises the possibility that astronauts on future space missions could find refreshment and fuel on the lunar surface.

site_title: China gives six US media outlets a week to report on operations
summary: China has ordered six US media outlets, including ABC and the Los Angeles Times, to report on their operations in the country within seven days. This comes after the US announced it would designate the US arms of six China-based media firms as foreign missions. The move is seen as a response to the US actions, with China's foreign ministry stating it will monitor the situation. The deadline for reporting is set to expire on October 31, 2020.

site_title: Trust us, we are really independent
summary: Singapore's corporate world faces scrutiny over questionable independence of directors. The Governance Index for Trusts (GIFT) 2020 found 14 independent directors re-designated as non-independent due to tenure exceeding nine years or close relationships with the sponsor or controlling shareholder. The rules are often circumvented, with companies using loopholes to deem directors as independent despite having relationships that could compromise their judgment. Examples include family relationships and employment ties that can lead to directors being perceived as non-independent. Other countries, such as Hong Kong and the US, have stricter listing rules for director independence, and some countries, like India, are considering adopting similar practices.

site_title: Aspen to move listing to SGX mainboard
summary: Aspen, a Malaysian property developer, plans to transfer its listing to the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to boost market visibility and facilitate future fundraising efforts. The move is subject to in-principle approval from SGX and shareholder approval. The company has submitted an application to SGX and will update shareholders on any material developments.

site_title: WTO gives EU final nod for tariffs on US$4b of US exports
summary: The World Trade Organization has authorized the European Union to impose tariffs on approximately $4 billion worth of US exports annually in retaliation for the US government's illegal subsidies to Boeing. This marks the final procedural hurdle before the EU can legally retaliate against US goods. The US has urged the EU not to impose duties, citing Washington state's termination of its illegal subsidies to Boeing on April 1. The EU still needs to narrow down its draft retaliation list, which targets politically sensitive US industries.

site_title: UOB's value chain financing sees doubling of clients in H12020
summary: UOB reported a doubling of clients in value chain financing (VCF) loans for construction firms in the first six months of 2020, compared to 2019. The growth was driven by sub-contractors and suppliers obtaining loans under VCF, mainly due to Covid-19's impact on the construction sector. The bank's VCF supports firms in obtaining loans by assessing the project and parties involved, enabling financing support for previously ineligible sub-contractors and suppliers. This move aims to ease cash-flow pressures faced by smaller construction firms.

site_title: Liam Neeson thriller Honest Thief tops quiet US box office again
summary: Liam Neeson's thriller Honest Thief topped the quiet US box office with a weekend total of $2.4 million at 2,502 locations. This marks one of the lowest-winning weekend totals amid the ongoing pandemic. The film has taken in $7.5 million in its first 10 days in North America, declining 44% from its opening frame.

site_title: Fiat, PSA to win EU approval for US$38b merger
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) and PSA Group are set to win EU approval for their $38 billion merger, creating the world's No 4 carmaker, Stellantis. The deal aims to fund the development of zero-emission vehicles in Europe and China. To address EU antitrust concerns, PSA will strengthen its joint venture with Toyota and allow dealers to repair rival brands. The EU decision is expected by the end of the year, ahead of the official deadline, and the companies aim to complete the merger in the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: Forget pre-election fiscal stimulus; set sights on post-Nov 3 package
summary: US financial markets face uncertainty as a pre-election fiscal stimulus package remains elusive. Despite optimism for a post-election relief package, concerns over a divided government and logistical hurdles persist. A stimulus bill worth between $1.8 trillion to $2.2 trillion is estimated to be necessary to repair the ravaged economy, regardless of the election outcome. Expectations have shifted to a lame-duck session or early 2021, with a critical 9-10% GDP aid package needed to combat the ongoing Covid-19 resurgence.

site_title: Asean energy demand to grow 70% between 2020 and 2040
summary: ASEAN energy demand is expected to grow 70% between 2020 and 2040, prompting cooperation on cross-border power trading among member states. Singapore and its neighboring countries, Laos, Thailand, and Malaysia, are set to sign a memorandum of understanding for the Lao PDR-Thailand-Malaysia-Singapore Power Integration Project, aiming to tap into regional power grids and reduce costs. The project will also promote the use of cleaner energy sources, such as natural gas, and integrate variable renewable energy resources.

site_title: Conservation shophouses in Joo Chiat on sale
summary: A block of five conservation shophouses in Joo Chiat, Singapore, is on the market for S$21 million through private treaty. The freehold site has a land area of 8,969 sq ft and an existing total built-up area of 15,682 sq ft. Potential buyers can expand the existing units by 1,500-2,200 sq ft, and the site also features a courtyard and space for a garden. The property is located near amenities such as Katong V mall and educational institutions, and is about an 8-minute drive from Tanjong Pagar and Raffles Place.

site_title: Malaysia extends partial lockdown in capital amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysia has extended a partial lockdown in Kuala Lumpur and Selangor for two weeks, from October 26 to November 9, amid a surge in COVID-19 cases. The health ministry reported 1,240 new cases, the highest daily rise on record. The lockdown includes curbs on movement, school closures, and worship places, but other economic activities remain open. This is the country's largest jump in cases since the pandemic began, with 27,805 total infections and 236 deaths.

images.alt_text: Malaysia on Monday extended a partial lockdown on its capital Kuala Lumpur and the surrounding state of Selangor for another two weeks, as the country recorded the biggest jump in coronavirus cases since the start of the pandemic.

site_title: Najib seeks support for opposition leader's premiership bid
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak sought support from coalition lawmakers to back opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's premiership bid, deepening turmoil for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin. Najib's backing marks a striking turnaround in their relationship, with Anwar previously jailed during Najib's administration. Najib suggested his party, Umno, push for fresh elections once the Covid-19 outbreak is under control, or work with Anwar's party under certain conditions if the ruling coalition rejects the idea. This move could lead to a shift in support for Muhyiddin, who faces calls to resign amid a leadership challenge from Anwar.

site_title: Ant Group prices Shanghai IPO leg at 68.8 yuan per share
summary: Ant Group priced its Shanghai IPO leg at 68.8 yuan (S$13.96) per share, with 1.67 billion shares to be sold, setting the stage for the largest initial public offering (IPO) in China. The Hong Kong tranche is priced at HK$80 (S$40.03) per share. This follows a massive dual-listing plan, surpassing Agricultural Bank of China's 2010 US$10.1 billion float.

site_title: Impossible Foods' burgers to be launched in Canadian grocery stores
summary: Impossible Foods' plant-based burgers will be launched in nearly 600 Sobeys Inc stores in Canada starting this week, with the exclusive retailer carrying the company's flagship Impossible Burger until February 2021. The burgers are already available in over 450 restaurants across the country.

site_title: A US$50b housing bond market is stuck in regulatory limbo
summary: A US$50 billion housing bond market, known as credit-risk-transfer (CRT) securities, has been stuck in regulatory limbo since the start of the coronavirus crisis. Proposed changes by Federal Housing Finance Agency (FHFA) director Mark Calabria could reduce the capital relief Fannie and Freddie receive from issuing CRT, making it uneconomic for them to continue. Investors worry that they will be left holding the bag if the market dwindles, and Fannie has not issued any CRT since the pandemic began, citing concerns over the market's long-term viability.

site_title: ByteDance in early talks to list Chinese short video app Douyin in Hong Kong -sources
summary: ByteDance, owner of TikTok, is in preliminary talks to list its Chinese short video app Douyin in Hong Kong. The company has discussed the possibility internally and met with investment banks to explore a standalone IPO. Douyin, with 600 million daily active users, is a popular platform in China, but ByteDance faces pressure to address US national security concerns over its US arm. This move could provide an alternative for Douyin's growth and potentially reduce tensions with the US.

site_title: How has Covid-19 hit Singapore's less well-off?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately affected Singapore's less well-off population, with a wider job loss disparity and significant income deterioration. According to a DBS report, 49% of lower-income earners saw a drop in salary, with half experiencing an income fall of over 50%. Additionally, 4 in 10 of these customers had less than a month's emergency funds. Meanwhile, the better-off continue to invest in assets such as stocks, property, and cars, exacerbating the wealth gap.

site_title: 'Well-diversified' portfolio, tenant base will help mitigate challenges: Ascendas Reit
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 91.9% portfolio occupancy for the third quarter, driven by a 88.8% occupancy rate in its Singapore portfolio. The real estate investment trust (Reit) also has a diversified tenant base, with over 1,450 tenants across 20 industries. Despite a challenging economic outlook, the Reit's manager believes its well-diversified portfolio and tenant base will help mitigate potential problems. The Reit's aggregate leverage remains healthy at 34.9%, and its debt-maturity profile is well-spread.

site_title: China to sanction Boeing, Raytheon, Lockheed over Taiwan arms
summary: China plans to impose sanctions on Boeing's defense unit, Lockheed Martin, and Raytheon Technologies over US$1.8 billion in arms sales to Taiwan, citing a need to uphold national interests. The sanctions follow the US State Department's approval of the arms deals amid rising tensions between the US and China ahead of the US election. The deals include 135 land attack missiles, mobile artillery rocket systems, and surveillance sensors. The move comes after China previously condemned similar US arms sales to Taiwan, considering the island part of its territory.

site_title: China: Stocks finish with losses
summary: Mainland Chinese shares closed in negative territory on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.82% to 3,251.12. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.52%. Hong Kong's market was closed due to a public holiday. The decline in China's stock market follows losses across Asia and comes ahead of a Communist Party policy meeting this week.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine produces immune response among elderly and young, AstraZeneca says
summary: AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine, developed with the University of Oxford, has shown an immune response in both elderly and young people, with lower adverse reactions among the elderly. The vaccine triggers protective antibodies and T-cells in older age groups, offering a promising breakthrough in the fight against the novel coronavirus, which has killed over 1.15 million people.

site_title: German government warns Thai king not to conduct politics from Germany
summary: Germany has warned Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn that breaking the law on its soil will have "immediate consequences" amid protests calling for changes to the monarchy. Thousands gathered outside the German embassy in Bangkok, submitting a letter questioning the king's legal status and requesting an investigation into royal authority. The protests, led by pro-democracy groups, seek reforms to the monarchy and Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha's resignation. The king spends much of his time in Germany, and the protesters are also seeking clarification on his potential inheritance tax liability and human rights record.

images.alt_text: Germany is continuing to look into the behaviour of Thailand's king, who tends to spend long stretches of time in Bavaria, German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said on Monday, as opposition protests in Thailand gain speed.

site_title: Rolls-Royce seeks US$2.6b in make-or-break share issue
summary: Rolls-Royce, a 100-year-old UK-based aircraft engine maker, is seeking $3.54 billion in a rights issue to survive the Covid-19 pandemic. The company aims to cut 9,000 jobs and close factories to adjust to lower demand from airlines. Investors are expected to back the proposal, which offers a 41% discount to the theoretical ex-rights price. The UK government has guaranteed a $1 billion loan, and the company faces a cash crunch by the end of 2021 when $3.2 billion of debt needs to be repaid.

images.alt_text: Aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce will ask shareholders on Tuesday for 2 billion pounds (S$3.54 billion) in a make-or-break attempt to survive the Covid-19 pandemic, which has stopped planes flying and hammered its finances.

site_title: SIA Engineering announces deals involving its investments in the Philippines
summary: SIA Engineering Company has entered into two agreements with Cebu Air. The company will buy out Cebu Air's 35% stake in SIA Engineering Philippines Corporation (SIAEP) for US$7.74 million, making it a wholly-owned subsidiary. Additionally, SIA Engineering will sell its 51% stake in Aviation Partnership (Philippines) Corp (APP) to Cebu Air for US$5.61 million. The deals aim to strengthen SIA Engineering's core competencies and enhance its status as the group's centre of excellence for narrow-body aircraft maintenance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.03 points lower at 1,494.61 on Monday, with 790 losers outnumbering 256 gainers. The index saw a volume of 5.794 billion lots worth RM4.706 billion.

site_title: Bayer to acquire Biotech AskBio for as much as US$4b
summary: Bayer agreed to acquire US biotech company AskBio for up to $4 billion, bolstering its pharmaceutical division before patents expire on key therapies. The deal includes a $2 billion upfront payment and potential milestone payments. AskBio is developing gene therapies for diseases such as Parkinson's and congestive heart failure. The acquisition aims to bolster Bayer's position in the gene and cell therapy market, which is expected to close later this year.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 0.6% on triple factors - coronavirus, US election and earnings
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.6% to 2,523.31 on Monday, driven by a triple threat of coronavirus cases, the US presidential election, and corporate earnings season. The US election is set to take place on November 3, with betting odds favoring Joe Biden. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to provide more stimulus amid rising Covid-19 cases and economic uncertainty. Trading volume in the Singapore market stood at 1.27 billion shares worth S$885.60 million.

site_title: MAS issues notice to remove manager of Eagle Hospitality Reit
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) issued a Notice of Intention to remove the manager of Eagle Hospitality Reit (EH-Reit) due to numerous breaches of the Securities and Futures Act, including minimum base capital and financial resources requirements. Since its licensing in May 2019, EH-Reit Management has committed multiple breaches, raising serious concerns over the manager's ability to comply with rules and regulations. MAS will appoint a new manager to ensure compliance.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on virus fears
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Monday due to concerns about the spread of coronavirus cases in Europe and the US. The Nikkei 225 edged down 0.09% and the Topix index fell 0.39% amid worries over new measures being implemented in countries such as Spain and Italy, including overnight curfews and closures of theatres and gyms.

site_title: South Korea urges people to get flu vaccinations despite death tolls
summary: South Korea has urged citizens to get flu vaccinations despite recent deaths linked to the shots, with at least 48 fatalities reported this month. Authorities have found no direct link between the deaths and the flu vaccines, and Health Minister Park Neung-hoo has reassured the public of their safety. The country has ordered 20% more flu vaccines to prevent a "twindemic" of concurrent major flu and coronavirus outbreaks. Over 9.4 million people have been inoculated since September, with 1,154 reported adverse reactions.

images.alt_text: South Korea urged citizens to get vaccinated against influenza and reduce the chances of an outbreak that coincides with the battle on the coronavirus, as it kicked off free inoculations for the last eligible group.

site_title: Geely's new EV plant will build premium Polestar cars: sources
summary: Geely, a Chinese automaking group, plans to build an electric vehicle (EV) factory in Chongqing, China, with an annual capacity of 30,000 premium EVs under the Polestar marque. The plant will be run by a wholly owned company and is part of Geely's expansion of EV production in the world's largest market. The move comes as foreign automakers like BMW and Tesla increase their presence in China, and follows Geely's existing production of low-volume Polestar cars in Chengdu and Taizhou.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Evolving your investment portfolio for risk and liquidity (Ep 82)
summary: In the latest episode of BT's Money Hacks, experts discuss evolving investment portfolios for risk and liquidity. The episode addresses the changing global economic landscape, including the potential for dollar devaluation and shifting safe havens. With Asia expected to drive dollar asset diversification, investors are advised to reassess their portfolios. Productivity gains and retail investor growth are also highlighted as key factors in unlocking wealth creation. The episode concludes by emphasizing the importance of adapting investment strategies to navigate the evolving market environment.

site_title: Tampines Mall, Ion Orchard and 313@Somerset visited by infectious Covid-19 patients
summary: Several Singapore malls visited by infectious Covid-19 patients while still contagious, including Tampines Mall, Ion Orchard, and 313@Somerset. The Ministry of Health (MOH) released a list of locations and times visited by the patients. MOH stated that close contacts were notified and the areas were cleaned if necessary, with no need for people to avoid these places. Three new Covid-19 cases were confirmed, bringing Singapore's total to 57,973.

site_title: With vacation rentals empty, European cities see a chance to reclaim housing
summary: European cities are seizing the opportunity to reclaim housing by pushing short-term vacation rentals back onto the long-term housing market, following the decline in tourism due to the pandemic. Cities like Lisbon, Barcelona, and Paris are implementing or planning laws to curb the growth of short-term rentals, with Lisbon renting empty apartments to subsidize housing and Barcelona threatening to take possession of empty properties. The European Commission is also taking steps to regulate the industry through a new Digital Services Act.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slump at open on virus resurgence
summary: Europe's stock markets plummeted at the start of trading on Monday due to soaring cases of coronavirus. The eurozone's DAX 30 index dropped 2.6% to 12,314.99 points, while the Paris CAC 40 shed 1.1% to 4,855.02 points. London's FTSE 100 index lost 0.6% to 5,825.53. The slump is attributed to bank and healthcare sector drag, with US-EU trade tensions also on investors' minds.

site_title: Airlines face winter survival test on recovery delayed by virus
summary: Airlines face a "survival test" this winter as the COVID-19 pandemic delays air travel recovery. Airlines are urging governments to introduce testing and travel bubbles to boost demand, with many retrenching and shoring up finances. The industry is expected to burn through $77 billion in cash in the second half. Despite some exceptions, such as China, where domestic flights have surged, air travel is at a level not seen in over three decades. Airlines are preparing for a potential spring rebound, with some, like Airbus, ramping up production of key jets.

site_title: Samsung Group shares jump on speculation over dividend increases
summary: Shares of Samsung Group companies jumped amid speculation that the family-controlled conglomerate may raise dividends to help heirs pay inheritance tax. Samsung C&T Corp surged 13%, its largest gain since 2015, while Samsung Life Insurance Co and Samsung SDS Co rallied 3.8% and 5.5%, respectively. Lee Kun-hee's heirs are estimated to pay 10.9 trillion won in inheritance tax, prompting analysts to suggest that Samsung Life may consider raising dividends to meet this obligation.

site_title: Paint startup gush raises S$4.7m pre-Series A funding for R&D, expansion
summary: SINGAPORE-BASED startup gush has raised S$4.7 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by TNB Aura, to enhance R&D and expand into local and overseas markets. The funds will be used to improve production capabilities, distribution breadth, and R&D, as well as develop new advanced-materials solutions. The startup plans to target markets with environmental and sustainability issues, where consumers are willing to pay a premium for its products, including its flagship air-purifying paint and anti-thermal coating.

site_title: Hyundai Motor swings to net loss in Q3 as costs of engine issues weigh
summary: Hyundai Motor Co reported a net loss of 336 billion won (S$404.59 million) in the July-September quarter, missing analyst estimates by a large margin due to a charge related to engine issues. The company attributed the loss to quality-related costs of 3.36 trillion won, with provisions totaling nearly $5 billion. Revenue rose 2.3% to 27.6 trillion won, but the operating loss was 314 billion won. The results reflect efforts to ensure customer safety and cover potential future quality-related expenses.

site_title: Singapore government launches S$49m fund for low-carbon energy solutions
summary: The Singapore government has launched a S$49 million research fund to support low-carbon energy technologies over the next five years. The initiative, co-driven by the Economic Development Board and Energy Market Authority, aims to develop and demonstrate projects that capture and convert carbon dioxide from industrial and power sectors into useful products. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing sees hydrogen and carbon capture technologies as promising solutions to transform Singapore's energy landscape and achieve long-term emissions reduction goals.

site_title: CapitaLand, Shopee start shopping campaign; IMM to launch as virtual mall
summary: CapitaLand and Shopee have launched a shopping campaign, with CapitaLand's IMM outlet mall debuting as Shopee's first virtual shopping center from Singapore. Participating retailers will receive marketing subsidies and incentives to drive online sales and engage with customers digitally. The campaign also includes a CapitaLand x Shopee 11.11 campaign, offering gamification and rewards for shoppers. The partnership aims to help Singapore retailers digitalize and diversify revenue streams, as part of the Alliance on Facilitating Smart Commerce in Singapore.

site_title: Giacometti sculpture in sealed bid auction - starting price US$90m
summary: A sealed bid auction for Alberto Giacometti's nearly nine-foot bronze sculpture "Grande femme I" is underway at Sotheby's, with a starting price of US$90 million. The work, created in 1960, could sell for over US$100 million, making Giacometti the second artist to have four works surpassing this threshold. The buyer's identity will remain secret, and the sale will be concluded by the highest bid that is at least five percent higher than the second-highest bid.

site_title: Seoul: Shares dip as surging global coronavirus cases dent sentiment
summary: South Korean shares declined 0.72% on Monday as rising coronavirus cases globally dampened investor sentiment. The Kospi index closed at 2,343.91 points, with domestic cases nearly doubling to 119. Foreigners sold $105.36 million worth of shares, while shares of Samsung Electronics jumped after Chairman Lee Kun-hee's death sparked hopes for stake sales and restructuring. The market is sensitive to the second wave of coronavirus and awaits US election results, corporate earnings, and third-quarter GDP data.

site_title: Singapore embarks on trial to import electricity from Malaysia over two years
summary: Singapore is embarking on a two-year trial to import 100 megawatts of electricity from Malaysia through regional power grids, aiming to reduce reliance on liquefied natural gas and increase green energy adoption. The trial will also test the feasibility of low-carbon solutions, including hydrogen and carbon capture utilization and storage. The government has set aside $50 million for research and development, with a goal of achieving 1.5 gigawatt-peak of solar deployment by 2025.

site_title: Malaysian PM faces calls to quit after failed bid for emergency rule
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faced calls to resign after the king rejected his request for emergency rule to fight the coronavirus epidemic. The request was seen as a pretext to suspend parliament and avoid a test of his razor-thin parliamentary majority. Critics accused Muhyiddin of using the emergency rule to maintain power, and opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim claimed majority support in parliament to form a new government. The king's refusal further eroded Muhyiddin's grip on power, with leaders from his coalition and opposition calling for him to step down.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faced calls to resign on Monday as doubts swirled over the support that he commands, after the king rejected his request to declare a state of emergency to fight the coronavirus epidemic.

site_title: Keppel O&M, EMA award grant for Singapore's first floating energy storage system
summary: Keppel O&M and the Energy Market Authority (EMA) have jointly awarded a research grant for Singapore's first floating Energy Storage System (ESS), valued at S$10 million. The project, set to be completed in 2023, will deploy a 7.5 megawatts/7.5 megawatt-hour lithium-ion battery ESS on Keppel O&M's floating living lab. The system will utilize an innovative liquid-cooling solution and explore a "first-of-its-kind battery-stacking solution" to enhance energy efficiency and reduce land requirements.

site_title: Google, Temasek agree to invest US$350m in Indonesia's Tokopedia
summary: Google and Temasek Holdings have agreed to invest approximately US$350 million in Tokopedia, an Indonesian online mall, to support its post-Covid-19 expansion. The deal falls short of the initial goal of US$500-1 billion reported in July. Despite this, Tokopedia may still be seeking additional investors. The funding will help the company navigate its growth plans in the Indonesian e-commerce market.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as US and Europe Covid-19 cases jump
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 6,159.20 on Monday as US and European coronavirus cases surged, raising concerns about a global economic recovery. The US reported its highest ever number of new Covid-19 cases, while France registered a record rise in infections. Investors are worried about the impact on economic activity and the potential for more restrictions. The US coronavirus relief package remains uncertain, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and President Donald Trump in a deadlock over negotiations.

site_title: Singapore's industrial production up 24.2% in September on strong pharma output
summary: Singapore's industrial production surged 24.2% in September, far exceeding economists' expectations, driven by strong growth in the biomedical cluster, particularly pharmaceuticals and medical technology. This boost is expected to cushion the third quarter's GDP contraction. Biomedical manufacturing output more than doubled, while electronics output rose 30.1% and semiconductors segment grew 37.4%. The manufacturing sector is expected to continue outperforming in Q4, with economists revising their GDP forecasts to -5.7% for 2020 and 4% for 2021.

site_title: New tie-up to promote mediation for intellectual property, tech disputes
summary: The Singapore International Mediation Centre (SIMC) has partnered with the World Intellectual Property Organization's Arbitration and Mediation Center (Wipo Center) to promote international mediation in intellectual property and technology disputes. The collaboration aims to address high-value, cross-border disputes in the sector, which have emerged due to technology's pervasiveness. The partnership seeks to leverage mediation as a cost-effective, confidential, and speedy alternative to court litigation, with a settlement rate of 85.7% at the Wipo Center this year. The tie-up aims to minimize delays and protect long-term relations in high-value technology projects.

site_title: UOB's value chain financing posts twofold growth in H1 2020
summary: UOB reported a twofold increase in value chain financing (VCF) loans in H1 2020, compared to 2019. The growth was driven by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) obtaining loans through tie-ups with main contractors or project owners to ease financing challenges brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Sashimi with spaghetti? Yes, please. And a slice of mango on top..
summary: Brazil's "quilo" restaurants, inspired by the Swedish concept of smorgasbord, offer a unique blend of communal and individual creativity, featuring a variety of hot and cold dishes. These restaurants are a vital part of Brazil's culinary culture, characterized by their workaday yet luxurious approach to food. However, the pandemic threatens to disrupt and potentially destroy this tradition, which is deeply ingrained in the country's gastronomic identity. The quilo restaurants' adaptability and resilience will be crucial in navigating the challenges posed by the pandemic.

site_title: Liam Neeson thriller 'Honest Thief' tops quiet US box office again
summary: Liam Neeson's thriller "Honest Thief" topped the quiet US box office for the second week, earning $2.4 million at 2,502 locations. The film's 44% decline from its opening frame still demonstrates its appeal, with senior media analyst Paul Dergarabedian attributing it to the desire for a "big screen escape" from the pandemic. Other releases, including "The War With Grandpa" and "Tenet", also showed solid holding power, despite the ongoing pandemic and reduced theater capacity.

site_title: Malaysia's Mr DIY recoups sharp early losses in market debut
summary: Malaysia's home improvement retailer Mr DIY Group successfully completed its market debut, with shares initially falling 6.25% but later rising above the IPO price of RM1.60. The company raised RM1.5 billion, giving it a market value of RM10 billion, and was oversubscribed 3.91 times. CEO Adrian Ong stated the company aims to add 307 new stores in the next two years, driven by a positive growth outlook for the home improvement sector.

site_title: In 2020, homegrown US disinformation surpasses Russian effort
summary: US disinformation has surpassed Russia's efforts, according to a report by the FBI and other American security officials. Americans are now playing a leading role in spreading false or misleading comments, memes, and videos online, with Facebook and Twitter removing impostor accounts and fact-checking thousands of false posts. Experts warn that US disinformation has evolved rapidly, with conspiracy theories like QAnon and Pizzagate spreading rapidly, and that the country's social media algorithms are exacerbating the problem.

site_title: China eyes more corn imports as shipments surge, set to become top buyer
summary: China is considering permits for millions of tonnes of additional corn imports, aiming to become the world's top importer for the first time. The surge in animal feed demand and damage to domestic supplies due to storms and droughts have led to a shortage, prompting Beijing to review market supply-demand situations and potentially issue more lower-tariff quotas. This could drive up global corn prices and amplify food inflation, exacerbating the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US stimulus remains elusive
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as traders lost hope of a US stimulus package before the election. Despite months of talks, lawmakers appear unlikely to reach a deal, with analysts betting on a Democratic sweep that could lead to a bigger spending package. The surge in coronavirus cases and World Health Organization's record new infections globally added to the negative sentiment. Markets were affected, with Tokyo, Sydney, and Singapore barely moving, while Shanghai, Seoul, and Manila dropped into negative territory.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.13% higher on Monday, at 23,547.33, amid cautious trade following a mixed US stock close. The broader Topix index rose 0.02%. Market eyes are on the US stimulus and presidential election.

site_title: Dunkin' Brands says it's in talks to be acquired by Inspire
summary: Dunkin' Brands, parent company of Dunkin' and Baskin-Robbins, is in talks to be acquired by private equity-backed Inspire Brands for US$8.8 billion. The deal, valued at US$106.50 per share, is a 20% premium over Friday's closing price. The acquisition would take Dunkin' private and comes as the US coffee shop industry faces a decline in sales and number of outlets for the first time in nine years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.33 points, or 0.09%, to 1,495.97. The index saw a gain of 281 to 91 gainers to losers. Volume reached 286.02 million lots worth RM156.46 million.

site_title: ARA Logos to buy Australia properties and invest in sponsor's funds for S$404.4m
summary: ARA Logos Logistics Trust has proposed to spend S$404.4 million to buy five Australian properties and invest in two of its sponsor's funds. The acquisition includes a logistics property in Brisbane and two funds with a combined portfolio of five properties in New South Wales and Victoria. The deal aims to increase ALog's deposited property value by 28.2% to S$1.7 billion and its portfolio value attributable to Australia by 47.6%. The Reit plans to fund the acquisition through an equity fundraising and external bank borrowings, with a blended net property income yield of about 5%.

site_title: Row of five freehold shophouses in Joo Chiat up for sale with S$21m asking price
summary: A block of five conservation shophouses in Joo Chiat, Singapore, is up for sale at S$21 million via private treaty. The freehold site spans 8,969 sq ft, with an existing built-up area of 15,682 sq ft, potentially expandable to 23,601 sq ft.

site_title: 'Please resign,' Thai opposition tells PM at protest debate
summary: Thailand's opposition party, Pheu Thai, called for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha to resign during a parliamentary session, amid ongoing protests that have turned to demands for monarchy reforms. Protests, led by students, initially sought Prayuth's departure and a new constitution but have now focused on curbing the king's powers. The opposition party's leader, Sompong Amornvivat, stated that Prayuth's resignation would bring an end to the crisis. The parliamentary session, called by Prayuth, is seen as unlikely to resolve the crisis, with protesters planning to march to the German embassy to petition for an investigation into the king's powers.

site_title: Packed bars and mask-less catwalks: With Covid curbs fading, China set for consumption rebound
summary: China's economy is showing signs of a consumption rebound, with sales of consumer goods rising across the board, led by auto purchases, as household incomes returned to positive growth and employment conditions improved after the COVID-19 pandemic. The recovery is expected to propel the next stage of economic growth, with the hospitality sector poised to accelerate its recovery as social distancing rules are lifted. Retail sales growth is still a third of pre-COVID-19 levels, but economists expect the overall consumer market to stage a sharp rebound in coming months.

images.alt_text: Over the weekend, crowds packed a former industrial warehouse in Beijing as the China Fashion Week got underway, with models strutting mask-less on a square runway and guests oblivious to social distancing norms.

site_title: Australia's second-wave epicentre records zero new virus cases
summary: Australia's Victoria state reported zero new coronavirus cases and deaths, marking the first 24-hour period without new cases since July's lockdown. The state, which has been under restrictions for months, has seen a significant decline in cases, allowing for a potential easing of restrictions.

site_title: Samsung affiliates' shares rise after death of Samsung Electronics chairman
summary: Samsung affiliates' shares rose 20% and 15% following the death of Samsung Electronics chairman Lee Kun Hee, who died at 78. The shares of Samsung C&T and Samsung Life Insurance increased due to potential succession issues for his children. The wider market rose 0.5%.

site_title: Siglap Shopping Centre collective sale to carry S$120m reserve price
summary: Siglap Shopping Centre, a freehold mixed-use site, will be put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$120 million. The site, spanning 39,635 sq ft, is zoned for residential with commercial use and has a gross plot ratio of 3.0. Developers are expected to show interest due to its freehold tenure and location in District 15, with easy access to MRT stations and major roads. The tender will close on Dec 9 at 3pm.

images.alt_text: Located at 883 - 903A East Coast Road, the shopping centre comprises eight commercial units and eight residential units.

site_title: Oil falls more than 1% as surging Covid-19 cases stoke demand fears
summary: Oil prices fell 1.3% on Monday as surging Covid-19 cases in the US and Europe raised concerns over crude demand, while increased supply from Libya and Opec+ also hurt sentiment. Brent crude dropped to $41.24, and US West Texas Intermediate fell to $39.32. The US reported its highest number of new Covid-19 infections in two days, while Libya's National Oil Corp resumed exports from two key ports and Opec+ plans to increase output by 2 million barrels per day in January.

site_title: Early US voting surpasses 2016, nine days before election
summary: Early voting in the 2020 US election has surpassed 2016 totals, with over 59 million people voting as of Sunday, nine days before the election. This surpasses the 57 million who voted early or by mail in 2016. Democrats have led the way in early voting, but it remains to be seen if this trend will translate to Election Day. With coronavirus cases spiking, turnout is predicted to top 150 million, breaking records set in 2016.

site_title: Arabs favour Biden over Trump in US election: poll
summary: A poll by YouGov and Arab News found that 39% of Arabs in 18 Middle East and North African countries favouring Democratic nominee Joe Biden over Republican candidate Donald Trump in the upcoming US presidential election. Trump, who is widely preferred by Arab governments due to his stance against Iran, received only 12% support. The poll also showed that many Arabs are unconcerned with Trump's policies, with 49% believing neither candidate would be suitable for the Arab world.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on easing virus worries, Coca-Cola Amatil deal
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,190.10 on Monday, driven by gains in healthcare and tech stocks following Victoria's first zero new Covid-19 cases in four months. Coca-Cola Amatil received a $6.6 billion US buyout bid, also contributing to the gains. The milestone in Victoria has raised hopes that a Melbourne lockdown may be eased, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: China: Markets open lower on Monday
summary: China's markets opened lower on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.15% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropping 1.12%. The declines come ahead of the Chinese Communist Party's policy-making meeting this week. Hong Kong's market is closed for a holiday.

images.alt_text: Markets in China ticked lower at the open on Monday as investors keep tabs on the Chinese Communist Party's policy-making meeting this week.

site_title: Singaporeans stuck on island turn to private jets, daycations
summary: Singaporeans are seeking alternative ways to alleviate cabin fever due to the COVID-19 pandemic, including chartering private jets and luxury yachts for domestic island-hopping excursions. With travel restrictions in place, residents are exploring local attractions, staycations, and daycations, with some hotels and resorts offering packages and amenities to encourage domestic tourism. The government is cautious in easing border restrictions, prioritizing public health and economic survival, while international organizations push for scalable and affordable COVID-19 testing to facilitate travel.

site_title: Keppel to explore use of LNG, hydrogen to power floating data-centre park
summary: Keppel Data Centres Holding, City Gas, and City-OG Gas Energy Services have signed a memorandum of understanding to jointly explore using liquefied natural gas (LNG) and hydrogen to power Keppel DC's floating data-centre park in Singapore. The park, in its exploration phase, aims to achieve optimal energy efficiency and reduce carbon emissions. The collaboration is part of Keppel's Vision 2030 strategy, which prioritizes sustainability in data-centre solutions. The companies will evaluate LNG procurement strategies, energy transition to hydrogen, and harness cold-energy for the park.

site_title: German software giant SAP trims outlook on virus woes
summary: German software giant SAP has downgraded its 2020 outlook due to the resurgence of coronavirus cases, citing "hard hit" customers and economic uncertainty. Group revenues fell 4% year-on-year in the third quarter to 6.5 billion euros, driven by a decline in software license income. Cloud sales, however, rose 10%. SAP now expects full-year revenue of 27.2-27.8 billion euros and adjusted operating profits of 8.1-8.5 billion euros, down from earlier estimates. The company attributes the downgrade to lockdowns, uneven recovery, and increased business uncertainty.

site_title: Lower-income hit hardest by Covid-19, as better off still buying stocks, homes, cars
summary: Singapore's COVID-19 pandemic has led to an uneven recovery, with lower-income workers bearing the brunt of job losses and economic hardship. The "K-shaped" recovery, where different parts of the economy recover at different rates, has seen technology, financial services, and advanced manufacturing sectors charge ahead, while hospitality, aviation, and construction sectors lag behind. Despite the recession, wealth has been concentrated among the upper-income earners, who have invested in stocks, property, and luxury goods. Meanwhile, lower-income workers have struggled to make ends meet, with many relying on government support measures to stay afloat.

site_title: Coca-Cola European agrees to buy Coca-Cola Amatil for A$9.23b
summary: Coca-Cola European Partners agreed to buy Coca-Cola Amatil for A$9.23 billion, creating a global packaged drinks producer worth over US$24 billion. The deal values Sydney-based Coca-Cola Amatil at a 19% premium to its last traded share price. Coca-Cola European Partners offered A$12.75 cash per share, expanding its international footprint and scale in the Southern hemisphere. The deal is expected to be recommended by Coca-Cola Amatil's board.

site_title: US insists on need to ban TikTok
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is pushing to ban TikTok due to national security concerns, citing ties to the Chinese government through parent firm ByteDance. A court filing supports the administration's plan to make the app unavailable on November 12. The filing argues that the president should be able to regulate national security threats despite a foreign adversary hiding within a media company. TikTok has defended itself, stating its user data is stored in the US and Singapore, and a tentative deal is underway to restructure ownership and address national security concerns.

site_title: Westpac flags A$1.22b hit to second-half cash earnings
summary: Westpac Banking Corp announced a $1.22 billion hit to its second-half cash earnings due to write-downs in its life insurance business and increased costs from a record fine. The bank also reported provisions for customer refunds and litigation, as well as a write-down for capitalized software. The charges reduce Westpac's common equity tier 1 ratio by 24 basis points, leaving the bank with one of the weakest capital positions among Australia's major banks. Westpac will report full-year results on November 2, amid uncertainty about its ability to resume investment payouts.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Oxley, Top Glove, GL, Q&M Dental
summary: Keppel Corp and Keppel Infrastructure Trust announced a joint exploration of using liquefied natural gas and hydrogen to power Keppel DC's floating data-centre park in Singapore. Oxley Holdings delayed construction completion due to the Covid-19 pandemic, while Top Glove improved its efforts to reverse an American import ban. GL Limited recorded a net loss of US$22.5 million for its first quarter, and Q&M Dental Group announced nine dentists have signed 10-year service agreements.

site_title: China reports surge in symptomless Covid-19 infections
summary: China reported 137 asymptomatic Covid-19 cases in the Xinjiang region, the highest number in nearly seven months. The cases were linked to a 17-year-old female garment factory worker who tested positive, prompting a testing drive for 4.75 million people in the Kashgar area. The source of her infection remains unclear. This surge in asymptomatic cases raises concerns about the spread of the virus in China, particularly in regions with large populations and limited testing capabilities.

images.alt_text: China reported the highest number of asymptomatic Covid-19 cases in nearly seven months, following a mass infection of an unknown origin in the northwestern Xinjiang region.

site_title: Yinda Infocomm management in early talks regarding 'potential transaction'
summary: Yinda Infocomm's management is in early talks with a third party regarding a potential transaction, according to the company's board. The discussions are ongoing, and no definitive terms have been agreed upon. The company's shares rose 8.8% on Friday, with 14% of its monthly trading volume. There is no certainty that a transaction will arise from these talks, and the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat amid cautious trading
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Monday, following a mixed close on Wall Street last Friday. The Straits Times Index dropped 0.02% to 2,536.79 as trading volumes reached 79.5 million securities worth S$41.1 million. Banking stocks were down, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 0.3%, 0.2%, and 0.1% respectively. In contrast, stocks like Jiutian Chemical and Yinda Infocomm rose 2.4% and 13.8% respectively.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index dipped 0.02 per cent or 0.6 point to 2,536.79 as at 9.04am.

site_title: Australia's corporate watchdog deputy chair resigns amid expenses scandal
summary: Australia's deputy chair of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), Daniel Crennan, resigned amid an expenses scandal. Crennan received a $70,000 rental allowance when relocating from Melbourne to Sydney in 2018, exceeding the limits to which he was entitled. ASIC chairman James Shipton also faced scrutiny for claiming $118,000 for tax advice related to his relocation from the US in 2018. An investigation by the Australian National Audit Office is underway, and Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has ordered a review of the payments.

site_title: Spain declares virus emergency as global cases soar
summary: Spain declares a national state of emergency to tackle a second coronavirus wave, as the World Health Organization reports record new infections worldwide. The WHO warns that some countries are on a "dangerous track" and calls for decisive action to curb the spread of the disease. Global cases have surpassed 42 million and 1.1 million people have died from the virus. France sets a daily record of over 50,000 Covid-19 cases, while the US experiences a surge in new cases, with nearly 89,000 reported on Saturday.

site_title: Singapore's Energy Week conference to test reopening strategy
summary: Singapore is hosting its first large-scale business conference since the pandemic, the Singapore International Energy Week, starting Monday with 250 in-person participants and hundreds more joining virtually. The event, a key step in reopening the city-state's economy, requires attendees to take a Covid-19 test and download a contact-tracing app. The conference, which usually attracts 60,000 participants, features prominent speakers including Saudi Arabia's oil minister Abdulaziz bin Salman and CEOs from Citigroup and Microsoft. The event aims to test Singapore's reopening strategy and pave the way for future large-scale conferences.

site_title: Airbnb tells shareholder group board approves share split
summary: Airbnb has approved a 2-for-1 share split, reflecting a 10.4% increase in the value of shares since its last valuation, according to an email to shareholders. The company plans an initial public offering, and the split will be reflected in accounts on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysian king says 'no' to state of emergency sought by premier
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah rejected a request by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to declare a state of emergency due to the coronavirus crisis, citing confidence in the government's handling of the pandemic. The king also called for politicians to end politicking, which could affect the administration's stability. This move is a blow to Muhyiddin, who is facing a leadership challenge and infighting within his ruling coalition.

site_title: With everything to lose, Trump barrels into final stretch
summary: US President Donald Trump is intensifying his campaign efforts with a frenetic pace of three rallies a day, covering over 3,000km in a single day. Despite trailing in the polls, Trump believes his high-energy approach will secure another shocking win. He often mocks Democratic rival Joe Biden's Covid-19 warnings and touts a return to normalcy, despite the virus's ongoing spread. Trump's strategy, which was novel in 2016, may be less effective this time as an incumbent with power in the midst of a crisis, but experts say it's not a futile exercise.

site_title: 'We're not going to control pandemic': Trump aide
summary: US Chief of Staff Mark Meadows said on Sunday that the US will not control the COVID-19 pandemic, likening it to the flu. This statement drew criticism from the Biden campaign, with Kamala Harris saying "they are admitting defeat." The US is experiencing a sharp resurgence of the virus, with daily case numbers setting records and a death toll approaching 225,000. Meadows defended the administration's handling, stating they are making efforts to contain the virus, but the Biden campaign accuses them of failing to control it.

site_title: US election key to market outlook for Dow
summary: US presidential elections are key to market outlook for the Dow, with approximately a week to spare. Negotiations on a $2 trillion economic relief package may drag on until after the election on November 3, contributing to recent price corrections in US indices. Investors are also weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, which may impact oil prices and global stocks.

site_title: What does Kwek Leng Peck's resignation mean for CDL's share price?
summary: CDL's share price has dropped 8% after the company revealed divisions within its board over investments in Chinese real estate firm Sincere Property Group and management of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels. The shares now trade at 0.6 times the company's net asset value, a steep discount. This follows a decline in returns on equity (ROEs) over the past decade, from higher levels a decade ago.

site_title: IMF urges bank regulators to extend curbs on dividends, buybacks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommends that bank regulators extend curbs on dividends and buybacks to protect the financial system in case of a slow global economic recovery. The IMF cites an adverse economic scenario where banks would fall $420 billion short of regulatory capital requirements, but the current temporary measures reduce this shortfall to $110 billion. Regulators should also roll back temporary relief measures that undermine financial statement reliability and tweak global capital rules, according to the IMF.

site_title: Two-speed recovery in services trade expected: HSBC
summary: HSBC predicts a two-speed recovery in services trade, with digital services recovering more quickly due to travel restrictions. International travel is likely to remain suppressed, while digitally-enabled and R&D services may see a post-Covid boost. However, growth in digital services may not fully offset the collapse in travel, suggesting services trade will remain below pre-pandemic levels for some time. Tackling barriers to digital trade and improving infrastructure could support greater digital flows and speed up the recovery in global services trade.

site_title: Boeing's early concept for all-new jetliner tempts Rolls-Royce
summary: Boeing has reached out to Rolls-Royce to gauge interest in providing engines for a new, mid-range jetliner, which could fill a gap in Boeing's product lineup and compete with Airbus's A321neo. The concept, which is still in flux, aims to seat between 200 and 250 passengers and feature a carbon-composite frame. Rolls-Royce has expressed interest in participating, but the project's chances depend on emerging new engine technology, the financial health of aerospace manufacturers, and the recovery of the jetliner market.

site_title: Ant may raise up to US$17b in Shanghai IPO leg, say sources
summary: China's Ant Group may raise up to $17.3 billion in the Shanghai leg of its dual listing, surpassing the previous largest IPO, Saudi Aramco's $29.4 billion float. Ant shares are priced at 68-69 yuan per share, valuing the company at up to $2.1 trillion. The Shanghai tranche would be the largest IPO on the STAR Market, with strategic investors accounting for 80% of the sale. The listing is seen as a boost to the Shanghai exchange's status as a major capital markets centre amid rising Sino-US tensions.

site_title: Pandemic hastening conglomerate break-up: Bain & Co
summary: A COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating the break-up of conglomerates in South-east Asia, as these multi-industry corporations aim to slim down and overcome underperformance. According to a study by Bain & Company, conglomerates averaged 24% annualized total shareholder return from 2010 to 2013, but underperformed pure-play companies by 6 percentage points from 2014 to 2018. Experts predict that conglomerates will need to cut costs, reengineer supply chains, and invest in digitalization to survive and lead in a post-Covid world, with those with strong balance sheets getting "on the offensive" to reinforce their leadership position.

site_title: Transcorp unit director stops legal action to recover S$2.6m without consulting company
summary: A director of Regal Motors, a Transcorp Holdings subsidiary, has stopped legal action to recover S$2.64 million from a supplier without consulting Transcorp. The company had filed a police report and a Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) investigation was underway. Transcorp may pursue a legal review of the director's fiduciary obligations. The director had instructed external legal counsel to stop the action without Transcorp's knowledge or consultation.

site_title: China's rebound from Covid-19 slump driving Asia-Pac wealth growth
summary: China's economic rebound from the COVID-19 slump has driven growth in Asia-Pacific household wealth, the only region to record a gain in the first six months of 2020. China's wealth rose 4.4% to $81.4 billion, while India's wealth grew 1.6% to $15.6 billion. This has contributed 42% to the global total household wealth of $400 billion by the end of June. The tech boom has also seen increased business and strong rises in stock prices, with billionaires in tech and other "new economy" sectors pulling ahead of their peers.

site_title: Despite positive indicators, stock strategists urge patience
summary: Stock strategists advise clients to remain patient despite positive market indicators, citing factors such as US dollar weakness, reflationary policies, and technological innovation. They expect a "clean sweep" of Democratic wins in the US presidential election, which could lead to higher fiscal spending and support for equities and emerging markets. Despite concerns over higher taxes, strategists believe the benefits of technological innovation and central bank easing outweigh the risks, making a "constructive" view of risk assets such as equities and credits advisable.

site_title: Covid-19 and Singapore's wealth gap
summary: A Covid-19 pandemic has exacerbated Singapore's wealth gap, with low-skilled workers hit hard while professionals have adapted to remote work. Blue-collar workers have continued to work on the frontlines, risking infection, while many were laid off. The "K-shaped" recovery suggests a divided economy, with some groups benefiting from the crisis, such as those in the stock market and property market. A Credit Suisse report notes that the worst is yet to come for low-skilled workers, who are likely to be disproportionately affected.

images.alt_text: The Covid-19 virus has, in just months, unleashed an unprecedented crisis for countries and disrupted the lives of millions around the world.

site_title: ANA to cut 3,500 jobs in 3 years on anticipated prolonged virus woes: report
summary: ANA Holdings plans to cut approximately 3,500 jobs in three years as part of its business restructuring plan due to a prolonged downturn in travel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The job losses will be achieved through outplacement programs and a hiring freeze, with the goal of reducing fixed costs. ANA also considers temporarily dispatching staff to other firms and selling 30 wide-body aircraft as short-term measures. The airline is forecast to suffer a net loss of around 500 billion yen (S$6.5 billion) for the fiscal year ending in March 2023.

images.alt_text: ANA is considering temporarily dispatching some of its workforce to several other firms including Toyota, and selling 30 of its costly wide-body aircraft, the Yomiuri daily reported.

site_title: Big Tech's quarterly results expected to show resilience
summary: Big Tech companies, including Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google, are expected to report quarterly results showing resilience despite the pandemic and increasing scrutiny from lawmakers. The combined value of these companies has surpassed $7 trillion, and they have become integral to modern life. Analysts warn that regulators may rein in the companies, and advertisers may cut spending due to concerns over content moderation. Despite this, some analysts believe that companies providing solutions for remote work and entertainment may perform well.

site_title: VibroPower founder rebuts shareholder's claims
summary: VibroPower founder Benedict Chen has responded to shareholder Alex Chng's claims, stating that the company's generators business is highly competitive with thin margins, and a strategy shift to supplying power solutions provides healthier margins. Chen denies claims that the company can do better with Chng's experience and network in the real estate sector, citing intense market competition and no concrete plans from Chng on how he will utilize his experience. An extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on November 9 will vote on withdrawing VibroPower's general share issue mandate.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange reported a positive turn in the Capesize market, stemming mounting losses and offering hope for a year-end rally. This development brings relief and optimism to the tanker and dry bulk market.

site_title: Katrina Group to trim fat in F&B arm
summary: Katrina Group, owner of So Pho, Streats, and Bali Thai restaurants, plans to trim its underperforming F&B outlets in Singapore and Indonesia, with a focus on expanding its hospitality segment. The company aims to double down on expansion efforts in the next three years, targeting markets in China, Vietnam, Jakarta, and Korea. With a cash balance of S$7.6 million, Katrina Group will raise funds through various options, including equity, notes, or convertibles, to support its expansion plans. The company's F&B business had suffered significant losses before the pandemic, with profits declining from S$2.37 million in 2016 to a net loss of S$3.99 million in 2019.

site_title: Apple, Google and a deal that controls the Internet
summary: The US Justice Department has filed a landmark antitrust lawsuit against Google, focusing on its partnership with Apple to feature Google's search engine as the preselected choice on Apple's iPhone and other devices. The deal, worth billions of dollars, has raised concerns about Google's monopoly and its impact on smaller companies. Apple receives an estimated $8-12 billion in annual payments for building Google's search engine into its products. The Justice Department argues that the arrangement unfairly prevents competition and could lead to Google losing significant traffic and revenue.

site_title: Banning Christmas glitter won't save the oceans
summary: Three British retailers, John Lewis Partnership plc and Wm Morrison Supermarkets plc, have banned Christmas glitter from their products, citing the environmental threat posed by tiny pieces of plastic. However, experts argue that banning glitter alone is insufficient to address the issue, as primary microplastics, which account for 31% of ocean plastic, come from other sources such as synthetic clothing fibers and worn tire treads. Retailers must rethink their manufacturing and marketing practices to effectively reduce plastic pollution.

site_title: Relieved to be back at the gym, but is it safe?
summary: New York gyms reopened on September 2 after a long closure due to the coronavirus, but many are struggling to stay afloat due to lingering concerns and strict safety regulations. Gyms must adhere to health screenings, mask mandates, reduced occupancy, and increased cleaning. Despite these measures, some fitness enthusiasts are hesitant to return, opting for virtual workouts or exercising outdoors. The industry faces uncertainty, with at least a quarter of US gyms potentially closing by the end of the year, and major chains like Planet Fitness and LA Fitness facing financial challenges.

site_title: US$ lower on polls, Covid-19 aid concerns
summary: The US dollar weakened against major currencies amid uncertainty over a new round of COVID-19 aid ahead of the US elections. US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said aid was still possible, but President Trump and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said significant differences remained between parties. The market expects a stimulus package by the end of the year, and the dollar is likely to remain in a holding pattern due to election uncertainty. Eurozone business surveys showed the impact of COVID-19 infections, while the euro edged higher against the dollar.

site_title: Time to reset expectations for world economy with virus untamed
summary: Investors must temper their expectations for a coronavirus vaccine to save the world economy in 2021, as scientists warn of a long and difficult road ahead. While progress is being made in finding a cure, questions remain about vaccine effectiveness, distribution, and public acceptance. Even a successful immunization system won't be an instant economic panacea, with some experts predicting it could take more than a year for the economy to recover. The pandemic's impact on global growth, including lost jobs and rising inequality, will persist, and the risk of re-infection and ongoing virus transmission will continue to pose obstacles.

site_title: Riding out the storms
summary: The article discusses the impact of political and social unrest in the region on businesses. CEOs, including J Heinrich Jessen, emphasize that the world's most diverse region is not new to such challenges. The region's economic uncertainty poses risks to businesses, particularly those considering going regional. Meanwhile, China urges South-east Asia to support openness as US tariffs loom, and Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Oct 19)
summary: Money FM released podcasts discussing the bull run for silver and debunking myths about the TraceTogether programme. Market Focus Weekly covered Asia's markets reacting to various factors, including the US dollar. WealthBT discussed unlocking structured notes' potential. BT Money Hacks explored private equity's accessibility for regular investors and the resurgence of gold's appeal. Additionally, Money FM reported on CEO salaries, Singaporeans' retirement needs, and notable business developments such as NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed public offer and Singapore's ranking as the world's top port.

site_title: Japan's ANA to cut 3,500 jobs in three years due to virus woes
summary: Japan's ANA Holdings plans to cut approximately 3,500 jobs in three years due to a significant decline in air travel demand caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The airline aims to achieve this target through outplacement programs and a hiring freeze. ANA expects to report its biggest-ever annual loss, estimated at around 500 billion yen (S$6.48 billion), for the fiscal year ending in March 2023. As a short-term measure, ANA is considering dispatching staff to other firms and selling some of its wide-body aircraft.

site_title: Protesters back on Bangkok streets after PM snub
summary: Hundreds of protesters gathered in Bangkok's Ratchaprasong intersection on Sunday, renewing calls for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-O-Cha to resign. The student-led pro-democracy movement, which has organized massive demonstrations for months, regards his hold on power as illegitimate. The protesters, who include drag queens, young people, and older citizens, are demanding Prayuth's resignation, a rewrite of the 2017 military-scripted constitution, and an end to harassment of political opponents. Despite Prayuth's refusal to step down, the movement remains united in its demands, with some calling for reform to the monarchy.

images.alt_text: Pro-democracy protesters making the three-finger salute during a protest in Bangkok on Sunday. The movement is largely leaderless though the different groups are united when it comes to their demands for an overhaul to Mr Prayuth's government.

site_title: MMA champion Nurmagomedov in shock retirement
summary: MMA champion Khabib Nurmagomedov has announced his shock retirement from the sport after his win over Justin Gaethje. The 32-year-old Russian, who won by technical knockout, had promised his mother that this fight would be his last. With a 13-0 record in the UFC and 29-0 in his professional MMA career, Nurmagomedov cited his father's passing as a factor in his decision to retire. Longtime rival Conor McGregor congratulated Nurmagomedov on his career, offering condolences to his family.

site_title: VibroPower founder hits back ahead of potential ouster
summary: VibroPower Corporation's founder, Benedict Chen, has responded to a shareholder's attempt to oust him and appoint a new board. The shareholder, Alex Chng, claims he can do better in the power generator business by leveraging his real estate experience. However, Chen points out that VibroPower already supplies power solutions to various customers, providing "healthy margins," and does not directly supply to developers. An extraordinary general meeting is set for November 9 to vote on withdrawing the company's general share issue mandate. Chen currently holds 18% of the company's shares.

site_title: SoRealProp seeking up to S$5m to fund growth
summary: Digital platform SoRealProp, backed by ERA, Huttons, and PropNex, is seeking up to S$5 million in funding to expand into the consumer market and partner with more banks and agencies. The capital will be used for research and development, product innovation, and to make the platform cheaper for agents. SoRealProp aims to capitalize on its emerging position in the proptech scene and unlock value for its ecosystem of subscribers and partners. The company has partnered with major banks and real estate firms, and plans to go beyond the agent market to consumers and other advisory firms.

site_title: China reconsiders its global strategy for the yuan
summary: China is reconsidering its global strategy for the yuan, planning to remove existing obstacles and liberalize the capital account to promote its internationalization. The move aims to increase the yuan's exchange rate flexibility and liquidity in the bond market, following a recent rally to its strongest level in over two years. The government will also improve bilateral currency swap agreements and promote trade and investments. This strategy is seen as a response to the US dollar's weakness and China's economic recovery, as well as the prospects of a potential Joe Biden victory in the US election.

images.alt_text: Although China has promoted offshore yuan trading and the yuan has won official reserve-currency status, it is still a small player on the global stage with 2 per cent market share.

site_title: Leader of India's biggest bank rescue girds for Covid-19 impact
summary: Yes Bank CEO Prashant Kumar is preparing for the potential impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the lender's loan book. Despite progress in addressing governance and fund-raising challenges, Kumar acknowledges the difficulty in estimating the pandemic's effect. To mitigate risks, Yes Bank returned to profit in the September quarter, with provisions made for potential COVID-related losses. The bank has also raised additional equity capital and strengthened governance. Kumar sees the current situation as a "partial victory," aiming to control costs and create a cash cushion to absorb any unforeseen deterioration in asset quality.

site_title: Five new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including two in dorms
summary: Singapore reported five new COVID-19 cases, including two locally transmitted cases in dormitories and three imported cases, bringing the total to 57,970. Two cases were linked to Changi Airport Terminal 3, but no connection between them was found. All T3 staff who may have interacted with travelers are being tested. The number of new community cases has decreased, but three unlinked cases were reported in the past week. 12 patients were discharged, and 53 remain in hospital.

site_title: Canary Islands reopens for tourism even with virus surging in Spain
summary: The Canary Islands in Spain have reopened for tourism despite a surge in virus cases in Spain, with the UK and Germany lifting travel restrictions to the islands.
