The move is expected to boost the islands' winter tourism industry, which has been devastated by travel restrictions and foreign visitor numbers have slumped by almost three-quarters in the year through August. The islands have recorded relatively low Covid-19 cases, with 44 cases per 100,000 inhabitants in the last seven days, and local hoteliers are hopeful for a recovery in business.

site_title: What will New York real estate look like next year?
summary: New York City's real estate market is expected to face significant challenges in the next year, with rents and sale prices continuing to drop due to the ongoing pandemic and affordable housing shortage. The median rental price in Manhattan has fallen 11% from the same period last year, and citywide rents are projected to drop 7.7-11.3% by mid-2021. The industry's political clout is also waning, with progressive challengers gaining momentum in local elections. Affordable housing funding has been cut, potentially delaying or derailing projects. A new mayor will need to address urgent land use and housing issues, with the city's next primary election set for June 22, 2021.

site_title: Tycoon who helped Evergrande has debt challenges of his own
summary: Tycoon Zhang Jindong, founder of Suning Appliance Group, provided a financial lifeline to struggling China Evergrande Group by waiving his right to force repayment by January. The deal, worth $120 billion, is critical for Evergrande's long-term development, according to Maggie Hu, an assistant professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. Zhang's company has faced financial challenges, including a 13% revenue drop and a loss of $33.8 million in the first half of 2020. As a result, Zhang has lost over 30% of his wealth this year, bringing his net worth to $5.1 billion.

site_title: First Resources leads the week's share buybacks
summary: First Resources led the share buybacks among local stocks, accounting for 900,000 shares worth S$1.1 million. The company's share price has declined 36% year-to-date, but its CEO maintained that the palm oil industry's supply-demand dynamics will be supported. Meanwhile, EC World Reit saw a 5.41% stake disposed of by BOCOM International Global Investment Ltd, and Dasin Retail Trust's chairman increased his deemed interest to 53.3%. Other notable transactions include GuocoLand's non-independent director acquiring 71.95% stake, and UOB-Kay Hian Holdings' chairman increasing his interest to 30.7%.

site_title: Sabic Q3 net profit up 47% as sales volumes rise, some impairments reversed
summary: Sabic, the world's 4th-biggest petrochemicals firm, reported a 47% rise in Q3 net profit to 1.09 billion riyals, beating estimates due to higher sales and output. The result follows three straight quarters of losses, attributed to impairment charges and declining sales. Despite the profit increase, Sabic warned that supply exceeds demand for its key products, pressuring product prices and margins for the foreseeable future.

site_title: Australia's Covid-19 epicentre delays decision on lifting lockdown restrictions
summary: Victoria, Australia's Covid-19 epicentre, delayed an expected announcement on lifting lockdown restrictions due to a recent outbreak in Melbourne. The state's premier, Daniel Andrews, said the delay would allow for test results to show whether all infections are linked, pushing the reopening date to November 1. Industry leaders and the federal government have been urging Andrews to fully reopen the city, warning residents are at a "financial and mental breaking point."

site_title: Ahead of RM1.5b IPO, Mr DIY sets sights on growing Malaysia footprint
summary: Mr DIY Group, Malaysia's largest home improvement retailer, is set to list on the stock market with an initial public offering (IPO) of RM1.5 billion. The company plans to expand its physical footprint, opening at least 132 new stores in 2020 and 175 in 2021, to tap into the under-penetrated home improvement retail sector. With a market value of RM1.60 per share, the IPO is the largest in Malaysia since 2017. Mr DIY aims to grow its business through brick-and-mortar expansion and e-commerce, despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Ant may raise up to US$17.3b in Shanghai IPO leg: sources
summary: China's Ant Group is set to raise up to $17.3 billion in its Shanghai IPO leg, with a possible valuation of $2.1 trillion, after large investors submitted bids at 68-69 yuan per share. The simultaneous listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai would be the world's largest IPO, surpassing Saudi Aramco's $29.4 billion float last year. Ant's shares could start trading after the US presidential election, potentially fueling market volatility.

site_title: Financial services firms in UK may face costly, damaging Brexit
summary: The UK's Brexit strategy has failed to achieve a workable deal for the financial services sector, a key exporter and tax generator. Despite a goods trade deal with the EU, the sector is expected to lose revenue and jobs. The sector's failure is attributed to the UK government's inability to secure favorable terms for the financial services industry. This has significant implications for the UK economy, with potential long-term damage to the sector's growth and competitiveness.

site_title: Apple 5G iPhones arrive with an alphabet soup of abbreviations
summary: Apple has released its first 5G iPhones, featuring service indicators that display either 5G, 5G E, 5G UW, or 5G+. Carriers have responded by creating their own unique symbols to brand the 5G experience, with various logos and abbreviations used to measure signal strength. The move reflects the growing competition in the wireless industry, as mobile-service providers seek to differentiate their offerings and create a distinct 5G experience for consumers.

site_title: Can US stocks keep rising without stimulus bill?
summary: US stocks are expected to continue falling unless a $2 trillion stimulus bill is passed before the November 3 presidential election. Despite talks breaking down, traders remain optimistic about a last-minute compromise. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note reached its highest levels since May, indicating confidence in a bill's passage. Meanwhile, the Covid-19 situation worsens in the US, with a record 85,085 new cases reported, and vaccine trials continue, potentially influencing market reactions.

site_title: Coca-Cola European Partners in talks to buy Coca-Cola Amatil
summary: Coca-Cola European Partners is in advanced talks to acquire Coca-Cola Amatil, Australia's largest Coca-Cola bottler, for an undisclosed amount. The deal, advised by Rothschild & Co and UBS Group, could be announced within days. Coca-Cola Amatil has a market capitalization of A$7.76 billion. The acquisition would be the largest of an Australian company this year, with US-based Coca-Cola owning a 19.11% stake in Coca-Cola European Partners. The deal's details are yet to be finalized, but it is expected to be announced soon.

site_title: Ant IPO pricing was determined on Friday, Alibaba founder Jack Ma says
summary: Ant Group, backed by Alibaba, has determined its IPO pricing, which could be a world record at $35 billion, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record. The dual-listing will occur in Hong Kong and Shanghai's Star Market in the coming weeks. Alibaba founder Jack Ma criticized the global financial system, calling for a new, inclusive, and universal financial system that benefits small companies and individuals. The IPO would be the first simultaneous listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai, and shares are expected to start trading after the Nov 3 US presidential election.

site_title: AIG settles foreign tax-credit suit for more than US$400m
summary: AIG settles a case involving cross-border transactions, agreeing to pay a 10% penalty and disallow over $400 million in foreign tax credits. The insurer was accused of generating phony tax credits to reduce US taxes. The settlement resolves a US investigation into improper tax shelters. AIG will keep some income expense deductions and subtract amounts from taxable income, but all foreign tax credits from seven transactions will be disallowed.

site_title: Airbus to keep A320 output at 40 per month
summary: Airbus announced it will maintain its A320 production at 40 aircraft per month until mid-2021, when the aviation industry is expected to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. The company has asked suppliers to manage their capacity to support a production rate of 47 aircraft per month, but this is not a decision to increase production. The goal is to prepare for an eventual market recovery in the summer of 2021.

images.alt_text: European aircraft giant Airbus said Friday it will maintain production of its workhorse A320 plane at 40 per month to mid-2021 when it expects the aviation industry to have recovered from the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Mike Pence's chief of staff tests positive for coronavirus
summary: Vice-President Mike Pence's chief of staff, Marc Short, has tested positive for coronavirus, along with at least one other key adviser, Marty Obst. Despite Pence's negative test result, the two are considered close contacts and Pence will continue to campaign for President Donald Trump's re-election. The infections raise concerns about another outbreak within the White House, particularly with the US experiencing a surge in new cases.

images.alt_text: Vice-President Mike Pence's chief of staff, Marc Short, has tested positive for coronavirus along with at least one other key adviser, raising the prospect of another outbreak within the White House less than two weeks before the election.

site_title: JC Penney lenders led by Aurelius seek to slow property sale
summary: JC Penney's creditors, led by Aurelius Capital Management, are seeking to delay the sale of the retailer's real estate to another group of lenders, citing an "undeserved windfall" and "abhorrent bad faith." The objecting creditors submitted a competing bid worth $750 million, which would provide $600 million more to the bankrupt estate and more evenly distribute proceeds among creditors. They are asking the US Bankruptcy Court to order a separate process for the property sale, while proceeding with the sale of the retailer's operations to its two biggest landlords.

site_title: Samsung chairman Lee Kun-hee dies at 78
summary: Samsung chairman Lee Kun-hee, 78, died on Sunday after six years of hospitalization for a heart attack. He co-founded Samsung Group, a $375 billion conglomerate with affiliates in electronics, insurance, and more. Lee's son Jay Y Lee, facing legal troubles, will likely face thorny succession issues. Lee's death prompts investor interest in a potential restructuring of Samsung, with his 20.76% stake in Samsung Life and 5% stake in Samsung Electronics to be redistributed among his family. Lee's legacy as a visionary leader and innovator will be remembered.

site_title: Singapore's Energy Week conference to test reopening strategy
summary: Singapore is set to host its first large-scale business conference since the pandemic, the Singapore International Energy Week, with 250 participants and hundreds more joining virtually. The event, held at Marina Bay Sands, will test the city-state's reopening strategy and assess the effectiveness of its COVID-19 measures. The conference will feature prominent speakers, including Saudi Arabia's oil minister, and is seen as a pilot for larger events. It marks the city-state's gradual return to normalcy, with new daily cases dwindling to low single digits or zero.

site_title: Upper East Side Gallery quietly opens as estate queries pour in
summary: Glenn Spellman's Upper East Side Gallery quietly opened last month, defying the trend of shuttered small businesses in pandemic-stricken New York City. His antique and art appraisal business has flourished, with calls pouring in from seniors' families to appraise and collect items left behind after Covid-19 deaths. With over 33,000 deaths in the state, Spellman's business has seen a significant recovery since July, with clients including family members of Covid-19 victims. His store has become a hub for estate appraisals, with clients eager to liquidate assets to pay bills and divide proceeds.

images.alt_text: "I've never been busier," says Glenn Spellman, who opened a gallery in New York after running an antique and art appraisal business online for a few months.

site_title: What will New York real estate look like next year?
summary: New York City's real estate market is expected to face significant challenges in the coming year, with one in five tenants not paying rent in September and an "eviction tsunami" looming. Apartment vacancies are climbing, leading to falling sale prices and rents, but the industry's tax revenue and employment numbers are still substantial. Experts predict that rents will continue to drop, with a 7.7-11.3% decline in the New York metro area by the middle of next year. The industry's clout is waning, with progressive challengers winning city and state legislative seats, and the city is considering measures to discourage speculative investment. The fate of affordable housing is uncertain, with funding cuts and a backlog of stalled projects.

site_title: Malaysia's king to consult with rulers amid talk of emergency
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah plans to consult with other rulers amid a proposal by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to declare a state of emergency, which includes suspending Parliament. The move comes as the country faces a resurgence in coronavirus cases and a leadership challenge from opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. The proposal, which includes a suspension of Parliament, is seen as an attempt by Muhyiddin to cling to power. The Council of Rulers will deliberate on the proposal, and a meeting is scheduled for Sunday.

site_title: China will improve yuan flexibility: central bank governor
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang announced plans to improve the flexibility of the yuan currency and reduce restrictions on cross-border use. This move aims to promote the country's financial services industry and internationalise the yuan. China also plans to expand outbound investment schemes to meet onshore investors' need to allocate assets globally. The goal is to let exchange rates play a better role as an automatic stabiliser in the macro economy and international balance of payments.

site_title: France becomes seventh country with more than 1m Covid-19 cases
summary: France has surpassed 1 million confirmed Covid-19 cases, becoming the seventh country to reach this milestone. Over 42,032 new cases were reported in the past 24 hours, bringing the total to 1,041,075. The United States has the highest number of cases at 8.4 million, followed by India with 7.8 million.

site_title: Football: UK businesses, councils promise free school meals after Rashford campaign
summary: Marcus Rashford's campaign to end child food poverty in the UK has led to at least 100 organizations promising free school meals during half term. Inspired by Rashford's efforts, local businesses and councils have pledged support, including McDonald's UK's partnership with FareShare UK to provide one million meals. Councils in Liverpool and several London boroughs have also pledged support. Rashford, who was awarded an MBE for his work in helping vulnerable children during the Covid-19 crisis, will continue to push the government to reconsider its policy on free school meals.

site_title: IMF urges bank regulators to extend curbs on dividends, buybacks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommends that bank regulators extend curbs on dividends and buybacks to protect the financial system in case of a slow global economic recovery. The IMF suggests regulators act faster to roll back temporary relief measures that undermine financial statement reliability. Under an adverse economic scenario, the world's banks would fall $420 billion below regulatory capital requirements, but this shortfall drops to $110 billion with temporary measures in place. Regulators may need to extend restrictions on capital distributions, particularly for large lenders.

images.alt_text: Regulators should extend limits on banks' capital distributions to help protect the financial system in case the global economic recovery proves slow, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said, a recommendation that comes just as some large lenders are itching to resume repurchasing stock and paying dividends.

site_title: US housing market heats up ahead of election but not all feel the glow
summary: The US housing market has seen a surge in existing home sales in September, with sales reaching levels not seen in over 14 years. However, the benefits of this boom are not evenly distributed, with higher-end homes seeing significant gains while first-time buyers and those looking for affordable homes are priced out of the market. Median home prices have risen nearly 15% from last year, and many current homeowners who lost jobs during the pandemic are struggling to make mortgage payments. The impact of the housing market on the presidential election remains uncertain, with no clear lift for incumbent President Trump.

site_title: US breaks daily record for coronavirus cases with nearly 84,000 new infections
summary: The US broke its daily record for new coronavirus infections, reporting 83,948 cases on Friday. This marks a spike in cases in virtually every part of the country, particularly in battleground states ahead of the presidential election on November 3. The previous record was set on July 16 with 77,299 new cases. The surge in cases comes as hospitalizations and deaths are also increasing, raising concerns about the country's response to the pandemic.

site_title: Even in his final days, Samsung's 'hermit king' remained shrouded in mystery
summary: Lee Kun-hee, the 78-year-old "hermit king" of Samsung, has died. He transformed Samsung into a global industrial powerhouse, turning the company into the world's largest maker of smartphones and memory chips. Despite living a reclusive existence, Lee's pronouncements on business had significant impact. He was twice convicted of criminal offenses, including bribery, but his far-sighted leadership style was widely credited with turning Samsung into a leading developer and producer of semiconductors, mobile phones, and LCDs.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee rarely spoke to the media, but was closely watched whenever he broke his long silences, often with doom-laden New Year corporate addresses.

site_title: Arnold Schwarzenegger says feeling 'fantastic' after heart surgery
summary: Action star Arnold Schwarzenegger, 73, has undergone heart surgery at the Cleveland Clinic and is feeling "fantastic" after receiving a new aortic valve and pulmonary valve. The former California governor, who was born with a heart defect, had emergency open-heart surgery in 2018. Schwarzenegger thanked medical staff and posted a picture of himself giving a thumbs up from his hospital bed. He is expected to continue his recovery and return to his normal activities.

site_title: EU adopts 'life insurance' biodiversity plan
summary: The European Union has adopted a biodiversity strategy, aiming to protect ecosystems and tackle climate change. The strategy involves protecting at least 30% of EU land and maritime areas under special protection. The goal is to be reached with all member states participating. This move is deemed essential to reducing the risk of future pandemics. The EU Commission's strategy is a joint effort among member states to address biodiversity loss and promote sustainable development.

site_title: Mercedes drops more hints about its sports cars going electric
summary: Mercedes-Benz is hinting at its plans to introduce electric sports cars, aiming to challenge brands like Porsche. CEO Ola Kallenius stated that plug-in performance models will be introduced, while CFO Harald Wilhelm confirmed that sports cars will go electric in the coming years. Mercedes plans to electrify its sports cars to compete with customers and comply with stricter emissions standards. The automaker will deliver an all-electric EQS sibling to the S-Class sedan and a plug-in hybrid supercar, the Mercedes-AMG One, next year. This move follows Tesla's success in popularizing electric vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia rulers to meet to consider PM Muhyiddin's emergency proposal
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is set to meet with the country's rulers to discuss a proposal to impose a state of emergency, which would suspend Parliament and grant the prime minister extra powers. The move comes amid a leadership crisis, with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim claiming a parliamentary majority to form a new government. The king will consult with senior royals on the proposal, which could impact the country's democratic process and governance. The proposal's implications for the economy and equity markets are also being closely watched.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's rulers are set to meet on Sunday to discuss what sources have said is a proposal by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin to impose a state of emergency amid a political crisis.

site_title: Wells Fargo does U-turn on cutting perk for high-earning workers
summary: Wells Fargo reversed its decision to stop matching 401(k) plan contributions for high-earning employees, who earn more than $250,000 a year, following backlash from affected workers. The company had initially rolled out changes to focus on lower-paid employees, but later decided to continue offering the 6% company matching contribution to all eligible employees. The move comes as the bank undertakes a years-long cost-cutting initiative under CEO Charlie Scharf.

site_title: Oil industry expresses concern, not alarm, about Biden comments
summary: US oil and gas executives express concern, not alarm, about President Biden's promise to transition the country away from oil and natural gas. They acknowledge the shift towards renewable energy, but argue their industry will continue to provide cheap energy for decades. The industry's focus is on how fast the transition will happen and whether they'll be allowed to offset environmental impact by capturing and storing greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Top Glove 'making improvements' in effort to reverse import ban: US customs
summary: US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) reported that Top Glove, the world's largest medical glove producer, is making improvements in addressing signs of forced labor in two of its subsidiaries. The US agency has been engaging with Top Glove since July, when it imposed an import ban on the two units. Top Glove has submitted an audit report and increased repayment for migrant workers' recruitment fees. While there's no timeline for revoking the ban, CBP assesses that Top Glove is taking the matter seriously and making improvements.

site_title: McDonald's urges dismissal of Black former franchisees' discrimination lawsuit
summary: McDonald's has urged a US judge to dismiss a lawsuit by 52 Black former franchise owners who claim the company discriminated against them by selling them underperforming stores. The plaintiffs, who operated over 200 stores, seek up to $1 billion in damages. McDonald's argues that its franchise agreements clearly outline the risks and obligations of owning a restaurant, and that many of the plaintiffs' claims are too old or lack evidence to support their claims of company-wide discrimination. The company denies treating Black franchisees differently and says success is not promised to any.

site_title: Tesla to recall 30,000 cars from China over suspension defects
summary: Tesla is recalling 30,000 Model S and Model X cars imported to China from 2013 to 2018 due to suspension defects that may increase the risk of accidents. The recall affects vehicles manufactured by Tesla's Shanghai factory, which is set to begin exporting the Model 3 to Europe this month. The move follows a statement by the State Administration for Market Regulation, which cited defects in the suspension system. Shares in Tesla fell sharply in New York following the announcement.

site_title: US may file antitrust charges against Facebook as soon as November: Washington Post
summary: The US may file antitrust charges against Facebook as soon as November, according to the Washington Post. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and state attorneys general, led by New York's Letitia James, have been investigating the company for potential threats to competition. Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg was interviewed by the FTC as part of the probe, which also looks at prior acquisitions and business practices. This could be the latest development in the company's history of facing similar probes and a record-breaking $5 billion fine for privacy practices in 2019.

site_title: Apple and Netflix discussed acquiring 'Bond' movie for streaming
summary: Apple and Netflix were in talks with MGM to acquire the streaming rights to the James Bond film "No Time to Die". The film, originally scheduled for a theatrical release in April 2020, was delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic and may have fetched hundreds of millions of dollars in a potential streaming sale. MGM stated that the film is not for sale and will be released in April 2021 to preserve the theatrical experience. Both Apple and Netflix declined to comment on the discussions.

site_title: T Anthony, retailer of US$17,000 luggage to stars, goes bankrupt
summary: Luxury luggage retailer T Anthony filed for bankruptcy in October 2020 due to a decline in demand for high-end travel goods amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company, which has been a fixture in Manhattan since 1946, listed assets of $1.2 million and liabilities of $3.4 million. T Anthony's business was significantly impacted by the closure of businesses globally and curtailed personal travel. The company plans to use bankruptcy proceedings to obtain fresh capital for its internet business and new store.

site_title: Australia explores lifting state border closures by Christmas
summary: Australia is considering lifting state border closures by Christmas, with all states except Western Australia agreeing to a framework to end regional border closures by December 25. The country is also exploring alternative quarantine options for returning citizens, such as quarantining at home or in university housing. With COVID-19 cases dwindling, Australia is taking steps to kick-start its economy, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison stating that the country has done well on both the health and economic fronts compared to most countries.

images.alt_text: Australia is considering reopening state borders in time for Christmas and is also weighing plans to create alternative options to hotel quarantine so that more of its citizens can return from abroad.

site_title: China's purchases of US farm goods at 71% of target under trade deal: US
summary: China has increased purchases of US farm goods to 71% of its target under the Phase One trade deal, buying over $23 billion in US agricultural goods since January. This includes record sales of corn, soybeans, sorghum, pork, and beef to China. The US Trade Representative's office and USDA stated that China has implemented 50 of 57 technical commitments to lower structural barriers to US imports. Despite progress, experts question whether China will meet its overall targets this year due to lockdowns and ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Microsoft-backed Databricks plans IPO next year
summary: Databricks, a data analytics company backed by Microsoft, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) in the first half of 2021, according to people familiar with the matter. The company aims to go public at a significantly higher valuation than its last funding round, which valued it at $6.2 billion in 2019. Discussions with banks have begun, but the company has yet to hire underwriters, and the plans could still change.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: Titleist has released its new TSi2 and TSi3 drivers, part of their two-year release cycle. The new drivers feature improvements in technology and design, aiming to enhance performance and accuracy for golfers. No specific details on the new features are provided in the article.

site_title: Oil falls about 2% on Libyan output, Covid-19 demand concerns
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Friday, finishing the week lower, due to concerns over Libyan crude supply and demand worries caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Libya's National Oil Corp lifted force majeure on exports, expected to reach 1 million barrels per day in four weeks. US crude settled at $39.85 a barrel, down 1.9%, and Brent crude at $41.77 a barrel, losing 1.6%. The uncertainty about demand and vaccine timelines is holding back prices, with Opec+ expected to increase production by 2 million barrels in January 2021.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound with banks in the lead
summary: European stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, led by banks and Airbus, despite a monthly decline in economic activity and surging Covid-19 cases. Barclays jumped 7% on strong results, lifting regional banks and considered economically sensitive sectors. Analysts expect the European Central Bank to signal policy support in December, but worry about the economic impact of surging cases, with Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire predicting a likely contraction in GDP in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Italy vetoes 5G deal between Fastweb and China's Huawei: sources
summary: Italy has vetoed a deal between telecoms group Fastweb and China's Huawei to supply equipment for its 5G core network, according to sources. This marks the first time Italy has taken such a stance, amid concerns over national security. US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo previously warned of Chinese mobile telecoms technology posing a threat to Italy's security during a visit in September. The decision reflects Rome's growing cautious approach towards Huawei.

site_title: Eat Just, maker of plant-based eggs, eyes US$2b valuation
summary: Eat Just, a plant-based egg maker, is seeking funding in its final capital raising before an initial public offering (IPO), aiming for a valuation of US$2 billion or more. The company, valued at US$1.2 billion last year, plans to raise at least US$200 million to achieve operating profitability and expand its Just Egg sales and capacity. Eat Just has raised over US$300 million in funding and has sold over 50 million plant-based eggs equivalent to date, with plans to build its first plant protein facility in Singapore.

site_title: Thai king's praise for defiant loyalist draws controversy
summary: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn praised a loyalist who held up a royal portrait during anti-government protests, drawing controversy. The king's comments, recorded on video, were seen as a clear intervention in the crisis, with some monarchists hailing it as a sign of the king's strength, while protesters and their supporters interpreted it as a recognition of their demands for reform. The incident has sparked a heated debate on social media, with #VeryBraveVeryGoodThankYou trending alongside sarcastic comments. The king's silence on the protests for over three months has been marked by his intervention.

images.alt_text: Thai King Maha Vajiralongkorn's praise for a man who held up a royal portrait at a protest site in Bangkok has drawn controversy in Thailand, winning acclaim from monarchists and scorn from protesters.

site_title: Japan mulls 10t yen extra budget to counter coronavirus
summary: Japan's government is considering a 10 trillion yen ($95.5 billion) extra budget to counter the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The budget would extend a labour subsidy program and fund the distribution of a coronavirus vaccine. The government has $7 trillion in reserves from an earlier aid package and may issue bonds to cover the remaining amount. The decision is expected to be made early next month, with lawmakers calling for increased spending. The government has ruled out direct cash handouts to households, but may extend a domestic travel subsidy scheme.

images.alt_text: Japan's government is considering compiling an extra budget worth around US$95.5 billion to offset the economic drag caused by the coronavirus pandemic, the Mainichi newspaper reported on Saturday.

site_title: AstraZeneca resumes US Covid-19 vaccine trial; J&J prepares to do the same
summary: AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson (J&J) have resumed their US Covid-19 vaccine trials after regulatory approval. AstraZeneca paused its trial in September due to a report of a serious neurological illness, while J&J paused its trial after a participant became ill. Both companies are working to provide vaccines to the US and other governments if cleared by regulators. Resuming trials comes ahead of the US presidential election, amid concerns about vaccine hesitancy in the US.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter CEOs to testify post-election: US Senate panel
summary: The US Senate Judiciary Committee voted to subpoena the CEOs of Twitter and Facebook to testify on November 17 about their decision to block stories claiming Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's son was involved in a scandal. The CEOs will also testify before the Senate Commerce Committee on October 28 about a key law protecting internet companies. The hearings aim to discuss allegations of anti-conservative bias and the issue of tech companies stifling conservative voices.

images.alt_text: The US Senate Judiciary Committee said on Friday the chief executive officers (CEO) of Twitter and Facebook will testify before the panel on Nov 17 over their decision to block stories that made claims about Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's son.

site_title: Malaysian PM seeks king's nod to declare state of emergency, sources say
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has reportedly asked the king to declare a state of emergency, according to two sources. The announcement was initially expected but later denied, with no timeline provided for the announcement. The move is seen as a possible response to the country's ongoing political crisis and economic challenges.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq close higher as stimulus talks in spotlight
summary: US stocks closed modestly higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq gaining, while the Dow fell. Investors are focused on stimulus talks, with uncertainty over the timeline of a potential aid package weighing on the market. Despite this, analysts believe a stimulus deal will be reached, with the only question being its size and timing. The market also saw mixed results from major companies, including Intel's 10% drop and American Express's 3.6% fall.

site_title: Singapore, Germany to start green lane for business travel
summary: Singapore and Germany have agreed to start a reciprocal green lane for business travel, allowing residents to travel for official reasons while following virus prevention and public health measures. This move comes as coronavirus cases ease in Singapore, with the city-state seeking to reboot its economy and aviation industry. The agreement, which includes operational details and application processes, could serve as a model for future ones between Singapore and other countries in Europe. This is the latest step by governments to open borders largely sealed by the coronavirus.

site_title: Much talk is about whether Tiger can retain his Masters title
summary: There is no relevant article to summarize as the provided content appears to be a list of news articles and does not mention the US Masters or Tiger Woods.

site_title: Gold prices drift with no US stimulus agreement
summary: Gold prices drifted during the week, reacting to US stimulus package news, with sentiment shifting according to progress on pandemic relief. The US Food and Drug Administration cleared Gilead Sciences' antiviral therapy remdesivir, potentially bearish for gold. Investors will watch for the US presidential election and Senate contests, with a Democratic sweep potentially leading to a larger stimulus package. Demand for gold from jewellers and central banks is expected to remain lower in 2021, but investors may stockpile bullion as an asset perceived to hold value.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GL Limited, a UK hotel sector player, reported a net loss of US$22.5 million in its first quarter due to the Covid-19 outbreak, reversing a net profit of US$12 million from the previous year. Revenue fell 91% to US$9 million, and occupancy rates remained subdued. The company has implemented cost-cutting measures, leaned on government support, and deferred non-business-critical projects. GL Limited expects its UK hotels to face a difficult operating environment in the near term, with seven of its hotels reopening in phases.

site_title: US judge denies new government bid to remove WeChat from US app stores
summary: A US judge in San Francisco rejected the Justice Department's request to remove Chinese-owned WeChat from US app stores, citing no new evidence that would change her opinion about the app's threat to national security. WeChat, with 19 million daily active users in the US, will continue to be available for download. The decision follows a similar ruling on TikTok, with the Justice Department arguing that both apps pose a national security risk due to their ties to China. The ruling allows WeChat to remain in US app stores, including Apple and Google's platforms.

site_title: Nanofilm IPO shares priced at S$2.59; subscribed 19 times
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a spin-off company from Nanyang Technological University, has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at S$2.59 per share, with 77.2 million shares to be offered. The company will raise S$470.1 million, with S$190.9 million going to the company itself. The IPO is expected to be one of the largest non-Reit mainboard listings in recent years, with a market capitalization of approximately S$1.7 billion post-placement. The shares have been subscribed 19 times, with cornerstone investors taking up over 50% of the offering.

site_title: Singapore shares track Wall St gains, end week in the black
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 2,537.39, following Wall Street's gains. The benchmark index ended the week in the black, with 213 decliners outnumbering 177 advancers. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices also rose, while the Nasdaq Composite inched up 0.2%. Jardine Group companies were top gainers, with Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings leading the way.

site_title: Goldman recast as villain of Wall Street with damning 1MDB pact
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay over US$5 billion in penalties after a year-long investigation into its role in the 1MDB scandal, a Malaysian investment fund plundered by corrupt officials. The bank admitted to conspiring to pay over US$1.6 billion in bribes to win business in Malaysia. CEO David Solomon and predecessor Lloyd Blankfein will also forfeit their pay. The deal includes the highest penalty ever under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, and comes as the bank faces mounting criticism over its success during an economic slump and widening income disparity.

site_title: Construction works on Oxley's projects may take up to six weeks more to complete due to Covid-19
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a possible four to six week delay in completing construction works due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Construction sites have resumed operations in Singapore and overseas after progressively restarting in June. The group attributed the delay to varying degrees of activity at its development sites.

site_title: WeWork default is a real possibility, Fitch Ratings warns
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded WeWork's long-term issuer default rating to CCC, indicating "substantial credit risk" and warning that default is a "real possibility". The downgrade is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on WeWork's business model, which has struggled to adapt to remote work. WeWork may burn through $1.5 billion in cash in 2021 and 2022, forcing it to seek additional liquidity, which is uncertain. SoftBank Group Corp, WeWork's largest investor, has provided substantial support, but further funding is uncertain in a distressed scenario.

site_title: A restrained telling of the rise and fall of WeWork's Neumann
summary: WeWork co-founder Adam Neumann's rise and fall are recounted in Reeves Wiedeman's book "Billion Dollar Loser." Despite initial criticism, Neumann's innovative approach to repurposing office space for freelancers worldwide gained traction, earning him the nickname "capitalist kibbutz." However, his lavish lifestyle and disregard for profit margins led to a spectacular fall in 2019, when WeWork postponed its IPO and Neumann left the company. Wiedeman's restrained narrative highlights Neumann's confidence and self-delusion, as well as the unsustainable business model that ultimately led to his downfall.

images.alt_text: Billion Dollar Loser: The Epic Rise and Spectacular Fall of Adam Neumann and WeWork By Reeves Wiedeman 352 pages Little, Brown and Co

site_title: Developing a winning mentality
summary: Tracey Woon, a passionate sports enthusiast, shares her journey of developing a winning mentality. She initially wanted to be an engineer but eventually became a banker after studying law. Woon's experiences in various sports demonstrate the importance of perseverance and adaptability in achieving success. Her story highlights the need to cultivate a winning mindset, which involves embracing challenges, learning from failures, and staying focused on goals. By adopting this mentality, individuals can overcome obstacles and achieve their aspirations, regardless of their initial intentions or career paths.

site_title: The hidden dragon of 2020
summary: China's onshore fixed income market has experienced significant growth, driven by a weak dollar, stronger-than-expected yuan, and widening yield spreads between Chinese and US bonds. Despite US-China tensions, China has opened its financial markets to foreign investors, with Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) schemes and the Connect programs facilitating trading. Foreign participation is rising, and global index compilers are adding Chinese government bonds to their indexes, marking a potentially seismic shift in the global fixed income landscape.

site_title: Making a new start in a business of their own
summary: A growing number of older Americans are turning to entrepreneurship as a career path, with many citing the pandemic as a catalyst. Research from the Kauffman Foundation found that over 25% of new entrepreneurs are ages 55-64, up from 15% in 1996. This shift is driven by both necessity and choice, with many retirees seeking a new challenge and others looking to supplement their income. Experts say that starting a new business can be a fulfilling and purposeful endeavor, especially for those nearing retirement age, providing a sense of freedom and autonomy.

site_title: Singapore hits Goldman Sachs with US$122m payment, warning over 1MDB scandal
summary: Goldman Sachs Singapore has agreed to pay US$122 million to settle its involvement in the 1MDB scandal. The company will also pay US$61 million to Malaysian authorities as part of a coordinated resolution. This payment is part of a larger settlement worth over US$2.9 billion with authorities in the US and Singapore. The resolution aims to resolve criminal and civil charges related to the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Laguna National launches new clubhouse
summary: Laguna National Golf & Country Club has launched its new clubhouse after three years of development. The new clubhouse offers a brand-new experience for members and guests.

site_title: Born deaf, Diksha has a point to prove in pro golf
summary: Diksha Dagar, a 19-year-old golfer, is breaking barriers in the sport despite being born deaf. She has shown remarkable skill and determination, aiming to prove that her deafness is not a hindrance. Diksha has been training for several years and is now ready to take on professional golf, seeking to make a name for herself in the competitive world of golf.

site_title: Trump's disappearing populism goes on full display
summary: Donald Trump's recent answer on raising the minimum wage was seen as a conventional and non-populist stance, marking a departure from his 2016 campaign rhetoric. He expressed skepticism about the idea, citing concerns about small businesses and employee firings. This response contrasts with his earlier populist persona, which aimed to shake up the system and challenge special interests. The evidence on the issue is contested, but Trump's answer reflects a shift towards a more traditional Republican stance, leaving many wondering about the point of his current populism.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's answer to the moderator's question on raising the minimum wage during Thursday night's presidential debate was incredibly conventional.
The overall moral of the story is that the Republican Party has changed Mr Trump at least as much as Mr Trump has changed the GOP.

site_title: iFast eyes expansion in Malaysia, China as Q3 profit more than doubles
summary: iFast Corporation, a Singapore-based financial services provider, reported a net profit of S$6.2 million for the third quarter, more than doubling from the same period last year. Revenue climbed to S$45.0 million, with Malaysia and China accounting for 6.3% and 1.1% of the company's net revenue, respectively. iFast plans to launch new products and services in both countries by early 2021, following regulatory approvals in August and September. The company also declared an interim cash dividend of 0.8 cent per share.

site_title: Reits (October 24-25, 2020)
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (Reits) saw a mixed performance in October 2020, with some Reits experiencing declines while others rose. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates climbed after five weeks of declines, affecting the market. In the Singapore property market, a Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. International markets also saw significant developments, including record Manhattan rents and a rebound in UK homebuyer demand.

site_title: Office rents fall in Q3 amid cutbacks, work-from-home ops
summary: Office rents in Singapore declined 4.5% in Q3 amid the pandemic, with prices in the Central Region falling for the first time in a year. Occupiers sought to right-size and cut costs, while landlords lowered rents to attract replacement tenants. Construction disruptions to new supply are expected to spread to 2022, affecting the market.

site_title: Ditch your basic bookshelf speakers and stream in high-fidelity instead
summary: A new generation of high-fidelity speakers, known as "active" speakers, combines amplification, digital processing, and streaming capability in a compact and wireless design. Six speakers were tested, including KEF LS50 WIRELESS II, BLUESOUND PULSE FLEX 2i, DEVIALET PHANTOM REACTOR, BOWERS & WILKINS FORMATION DUO, KII THREE, and DUTCH & DUTCH 8C. These speakers offer simplicity and convenience, with setup times ranging from under 15 minutes to several hours. The speakers were found to produce high-resolution sound with impressive bass and room correction capabilities, with prices ranging from $299 to $14,995.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang's pivot to recurring income will boost dividends: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Bukit Sembawang Estate with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$5.44. The property developer's pivot to a recurring income base is expected to boost dividends, generating S$11 million annually. With a large land bank valued at S$12.10 per share, Bukit Sembawang has potential debt-funded headroom of S$360-750 million. The stock offers compelling value, trading at a price-to-book ratio of 0.7 times near -2 standard deviations of historical means.

site_title: The sustainable debt market has become unsustainable
summary: The European Union's 17 billion euro social bond sale, the first of its kind, was oversubscribed 14 times, exceeding 233 billion euros in orders. The offering, which carries the EU's AAA credit rating, is a sign of high demand for sustainable debt. However, experts warn that this oversubscription may lead to unsustainable prices, potentially pricing out asset managers and creating a structurally underserved market. With sustainable debt issuance already reaching $460 billion in 2020, a larger market could lead to securitization and a wider range of credit ratings, but also raises concerns about over-securitization.

site_title: Growth stock rally leaves even more room for disappointment
summary: A rally in global growth stocks has left room for disappointment, as valuations have outpaced earnings growth since 2002. The MSCI AC World Growth Index has doubled its value counterpart, yet relative earnings expectations have stagnated. Recent disappointing earnings reports from companies like Netflix, IBM, and Citrix Systems have shown that investors are becoming increasingly skeptical. Strategist Albert Edwards warned that companies that fail to meet expectations will be severely punished, leaving growth stocks vulnerable to a sharp valuation correction.

site_title: Music lessons are the best investment for your kids
summary: Learning to play a musical instrument can have cognitive benefits for children, making them smarter. According to a growing body of academic literature, music lessons can improve cognitive skills, memory, and even boost IQ. This investment can provide a lifelong enjoyment of music and other artistic pursuits, as well as a valuable skill that can benefit children in various aspects of life. Parents are encouraged to consider enrolling their children in music lessons, which can lead to a more well-rounded and intelligent individual.

site_title: Decline in retail rents accelerates in Q3
summary: Retail rents in Singapore's central region declined 4.5% quarter-on-quarter in Q3, reaching a new low, with a 10% decline for the first nine months of the year. Secondary spaces and corridors were most affected. Despite this, prices of retail space rose 2.2% in Q3, and the islandwide vacancy rate remained flat at 9.6%. Experts predict a tough operating environment for the retail market, with potential for rent declines to ease in 2021 as economic growth and consumer confidence recover.

site_title: Football feast to savour in Europe as top teams collide
summary: Top European football teams face off in a busy weekend of matches. Bayern Munich, the current German and European champions, take on Eintracht Frankfurt in a highly anticipated Bundesliga match. In Spain, Barcelona and Real Madrid clash in the highly competitive "El Clasico" match, while Manchester United and Chelsea face off in a highly anticipated Premier League match at Old Trafford. AC Milan, undefeated in Serie A, host Roma in a tight battle. Predictions include Bayern Munich 3-1 Eintracht Frankfurt, Barcelona 2-2 Real Madrid, Manchester United 1-0 Chelsea, and AC Milan 2-1 Roma.

site_title: Philippine stocks top the world this week as foreigners return
summary: Philippine stocks surged, topping global peers this week, driven by economic reopenings and declining Covid-19 cases. Foreign investors turned net buyers of local stocks after 28 days of selling, with overseas funds buying $16.4 million in shares on Friday. The Philippine Stock Exchange Index (PSEi) climbed 10% this week, its largest gain among 90 global equity indexes tracked by Bloomberg. However, market watchers are wary of the sharp ascent, citing concerns about corporate earnings and valuation, with the PSEi trading at 17.6 times its 12-month estimated earnings.

site_title: Q3 private home prices up; new home sales double over previous quarter, but rents are down
summary: Singapore's private home market saw a rebound in Q3 2020, with private home sales doubling over the previous quarter. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's benchmark private home price index rose 0.8% quarter-over-quarter, driven by buying demand in both developers' sales and resale markets. However, private housing rents fell 0.5% quarter-over-quarter, and net absorption of private residential properties remained in negative territory, reaching an all-time low of minus 2,605 units. The vacancy rate of completed private housing units rose to 6.2% as at end-Q3.

images.alt_text: With the acceleration of launches in Q3, new private home sales also doubled to 3,517 in Q3 2020 from 1,713 units in Q2 2020.

site_title: Will airline bailouts fly?
summary: Airline bailouts are being considered by governments worldwide, but experts question their economic viability. Nationalist fervor often drives these decisions, prioritizing prestige over profit. Airlines have had a profitable run pre-Covid, with many enjoying super profits, but this has not translated to better service or lower fares. Bailouts can encourage dysfunction, and firms must go through bankruptcy to emerge lighter and more efficient. Governments have already provided significant aid to airlines, including US$50 billion for seven major US airlines, and US$13.27 billion for Cathay Pacific. The effectiveness of these bailouts remains uncertain.

site_title: Presidential hopefuls square off over Covid-19, climate, racism
summary: In the final presidential debate, President Donald Trump delivered a more composed performance than his first debate with Joe Biden, contrasting his outsider stance to Biden's 47 years in public life. Biden resisted taking the bait on corruption allegations, but made mistakes on energy policy, stating he'd transition from the oil industry. Despite Trump's efforts to tarnish Biden, a CNN instant poll showed 53% of respondents thought Biden prevailed, with the former vice president leading Trump by 7.9% nationally in the RealClearPolitics polling average.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump (right) and Mr Biden traded charges of secretly taking money from foreign interests, after the former vice-president addressed head-on Mr Trump's efforts to portray him as corrupt.

site_title: Chief Justice grants leave to probe DPPs for misconduct in former maid Parti Liyani case
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon granted leave to investigate two Deputy Public Prosecutors, Tan Yanying and Tan Wee Hao, for misconduct in the former maid Parti Liyani's theft trial. Parti Liyani was acquitted of all charges after a faulty DVD player was found to be a key piece of evidence. The trial court was misled into believing the device was fully functional, leading to Parti Liyani's acquittal. Reviews by the police and AGC are expected to conclude this month, with Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam to address the questions raised in a ministerial statement next month.

site_title: Inflation could return to positive territory before year end: economists
summary: Singapore's core inflation is expected to turn "mildly positive" in 2021, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry, after remaining in negative territory for eight consecutive months. Core inflation inched up to -0.1% year-on-year in September, while headline inflation remained at zero percent year-on-year. Economists expect the country's transition to Phase Three economic reopening to spur more consumer spending, with some predicting a return to inflation before the end of the year.

site_title: HDB resales jump to 10-year high in Q3 as prices rise 1.5% over quarter
summary: The Housing Board (HDB) resale market in Singapore saw a 10-year high in Q3 2020, with 7,787 flats transacted from July to September. This represents a 127.3% rise from Q2 and a 24.3% increase from the same period in 2019. The rebound is attributed to the end of the two-month circuit breaker in June, which had previously led to a 40% decline in sales.

images.alt_text: HDB resale prices may continue to climb in the coming quarters because of lower supply from the longer completion period for BTO flats and ABSD relief.

site_title: AirAsia secures US$72m loan from Sabah Development Bank
summary: AirAsia Group has secured a US$72 million loan from Sabah Development Bank, a portion of its goal to raise up to RM2.5 billion (S$815.8 million) by the end of the year. The loan is not backed by a government guarantee, a condition AirAsia has been seeking. The airline aims to raise RM1.5 billion of the funds through bank loans. This move is part of AirAsia's fundraising efforts to support its operations amidst the ongoing pandemic and industry challenges.

site_title: US existing home sales rise to 14-year high
summary: US existing home sales rose 9.4% to 6.54 million in September, the highest level in 14 years, driven by a desire for more space and record-low mortgage rates. The median selling price increased 14.8% to a record $311,800, while available inventory declined 19.2% to 1.47 million units, the fewest for any September on record. This supports a booming housing market, with single-family home sales outpacing condominium purchases, and home prices rising due to insufficient supply and strong demand.

site_title: The relentless pursuit of better investment options
summary: A Singaporean wealth manager's relentless pursuit of low-cost index funds for retail investors has been thwarted by Vanguard's decision to close its Singapore office and consolidate its Asia HQ in Hong Kong. Despite initial interest, Vanguard ultimately decided to only offer its funds to accredited investors, limiting access to low-cost options. This decision may lead to investors buying expensive funds, resulting in a poor investment experience. The wealth manager vows to continue its search for better, low-cost investment options for clients' retirement plans.

site_title: Hong Kong connection opens China ETF market to global investors
summary: China's $157 billion ETF market is now directly accessible to global investors, four years after the plan was first proposed. Four feeder ETFs launched in Shenzhen and Hong Kong, allowing for cross-border trading and settlement. The move is expected to increase ETF connectivity, with Bloomberg Intelligence analyst Sharnie Wong noting it's the "very start" of ETF connectivity. Turnover for the feeder ETFs was significant, with combined trading of 97 million yuan for Hong Kong assets and 1.9 million yuan for mainland stocks. The development is expected to drive growth in the ETF market, with analysts predicting a 5% contribution to mainland China's ETF turnover within six years.

site_title: Ming dynasty scroll sells for record US$77m
summary: A handscroll painting from the Ming dynasty by artist Wu Bin titled "Ten Views of Lingbi Rock" sold for a record-breaking US$77 million at an auction in Beijing. This sale broke the world record for ancient Chinese calligraphies and paintings. The auction, held by Poly Culture Group Corp, also featured around 8,000 items and generated a total turnover of 4.1 billion yuan. The sale price included commission.

site_title: US early vote total crosses 50 million, signaling a record-smashing turnout
summary: More than 50 million Americans have cast ballots in the presidential election, exceeding a record-smashing turnout prediction. This marks one-third of the estimated 150 million ballots that could be cast on November 3. According to Michael McDonald of the University of Florida's Elections Project, early voting has accelerated the turnout, signaling a potentially historic election.

site_title: Freed on bail, prominent Thai protest leader pledges to keep up campaign
summary: A prominent Thai protest leader, Jatupat "Pai" Boonpattararaksa, was released on bail and vowed to continue his campaign against Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha. Boonpattararaksa was arrested on October 13 for his role in a protest that called for reforms to the monarchy and the removal of the prime minister. Despite his release, he pledged to keep up the fight, stating that he will "drive out Prayuth in any way we can."

site_title: OKP's subsidiary to purchase Kreta Ayer property for S$11.3m
summary: OKP Holdings' subsidiary Raffles Prestige Capital will purchase a freehold shophouse in Singapore for S$11.3 million. The three-storey property, with a total floor area of 4,240 sq ft, is intended for investment and funded by internal resources and bank borrowings. The purchase price is valued independently at S$11.3 million, with minimal impact on OKP's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31.

site_title: US: Wall St rises at open on hopes of progress in stimulus talks
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.16% to 28,409.65, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.33% and 0.26% respectively. Investors are optimistic about progress in bipartisan talks over the next coronavirus aid bill ahead of the November 3 presidential election.

site_title: China to launch long-awaited international copper futures on Nov 19
summary: China's securities regulator has approved the launch of an international copper futures contract on Nov 19, set to be traded on the Shanghai International Energy Exchange (INE). This move will allow foreign investors to hedge exposure in China, the world's top copper consumer. The contract will be quoted in yuan, excluding tax and customs duty, and is seen as a step towards China becoming a commodities pricing power. The launch is welcomed by the London Metal Exchange, which has a copper contract denominated in dollars.

images.alt_text: China's securities regulator said on Friday it had approved an international copper futures contract for launch on Nov 19, in a move that will give foreign investors access to trading in the world's top consumer of the metal.

site_title: American Express reports 40% slump in quarterly profit
summary: American Express reported a 40% slump in quarterly profit, with net income falling to $1.07 billion, or $1.30 per share, for the third quarter ended Sept 30. This decline is attributed to lower spending by users. The company also set aside $665 million for potential defaults.

site_title: 10 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were 10 new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. No community cases were reported. The total number of cases in Singapore rose to 57,951, with 57,814 patients fully recovered and 45 patients remaining in hospital.

site_title: Covid-19 could add up to six weeks to construction works on Oxley's projects
summary: Oxley Holdings expects construction delays of 4-6 weeks due to the Covid-19 pandemic, affecting its projects globally. The group has restarted operations in June and signed government contracts for its hotels, enabling cash flow positivity. Despite sales delays, Oxley remains on track to complete projects in Ireland and Cambodia within the next 12 months, with 79% of its 2.5-year-old projects sold. Construction on its Oxley KLCC project in Malaysia is ongoing, with 66% of launched apartments sold.

site_title: GL Limited in the red for Q1, as pandemic ravages UK hospitality segment
summary: GL Limited, a UK hotel sector player, recorded a net loss of US$22.5 million in Q1 due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the UK hospitality segment. Revenue fell 91% to US$9 million, with occupancy and room rates remaining subdued. Seven hotels reopened after the UK lockdown lifted, but the group expects a difficult operating environment in the near term. To mitigate losses, GL Limited has implemented cost-cutting measures, leaned on government support, and deferred non-business-critical projects.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore's private home price index rose 0.8% in Q3, with landed homes increasing 3.7% and non-landed homes 0.1%. Nanofilm's IPO shares were priced at S$2.59, valuing the company at S$1.7 billion. The government narrowed its inflation outlook range and expects core inflation to turn mildly positive in 2021. Goldman Sachs was fined US$122 million for corruption related to the 1MDB scandal. ST Engineering and Montran signed a partnership to digitalize payments and settlements systems. The Straits Times Index ended the week up 0.4% at 2,537.39.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in the black, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week up 0.4% or 8.98 points at 2,537.39, tracking Wall Street gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 indices each gained 0.5%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.2%. Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings were the top gainers, with JMH rising 2.3% and JSH adding 3.4%. The market sentiment was boosted by Joe Biden's comments on a US$2 trillion "clean-energy plan" and hopes of a stimulus package.

site_title: Euro zone business activity contracts in Oct as Covid-19 resurges
summary: The Euro zone's economic activity has contracted in October due to renewed COVID-19 restrictions, with the Composite Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 49.4 from 50.4 in September. The service industry's PMI sank to 46.2, below expectations, while factories saw a 26-month high of 54.4 in their PMI. Economists predict a high risk of a double-dip downturn, with the job market likely to be chilled by the uncertain outlook.

site_title: David Hockney work sold by Royal Opera House fetches £12.9m
summary: A painting by British artist David Hockney, "Portrait of Sir David Webster", sold at an auction in London for £12,865,000, exceeding its estimated value of £11-18 million. The Royal Opera House, which sold the painting to raise funds, announced it was forced to sell due to the pandemic, with the proceeds to support the institution's recovery efforts and ensure artists can return to stages. The opera house faces significant financial challenges, with income falling by over half since the pandemic began.

site_title: Stars are aligned for cheap hedging costs to drive yen gains
summary: Japanese investors are benefiting from low hedging costs, potentially driving the yen higher in the coming quarters. As global bond yields slump, the cost to hedge foreign-exchange risk has decreased, encouraging Japanese institutions to buy more yen. This trend, combined with the yen's historical tendency to gain during times of stress, could see the yen rise to around 105-120 per US dollar. Analysts predict a 7% gain for the yen within the next year, with some forecasting a "drip feed" of yen buying from Japanese investors.

site_title: US business activity picks up in October
summary: US business activity reached a 20-month high in October, with the IHS Markit flash US Composite PMI Output Index rising to 55.5, the highest since February 2019. The manufacturing and services sectors showed growth, but at a slower pace than expected, amid the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and pre-election uncertainty. The reading above 50 indicates growth in private sector output, but some companies noted the coronavirus crisis weighing on demand and clients holding back on orders until after the presidential election.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 4.16 points lower to 1,494.64 on Friday, with 894 losers outnumbering 311 gainers. Volume reached 6.925 billion lots worth RM4.103 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the week on a positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week with gains, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.54% to 24,918.78, driven by traders monitoring US stimulus talks. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.04% to 3,278.00, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 1.90% to 2,200.56. The positive sentiment in Hong Kong shares contrasts with the recent market downturn in Europe and Asia, where mining and healthcare stocks led gains.

site_title: Hitler's speech cards auctioned in Munich
summary: A collection of Adolf Hitler's speaking notes, memorabilia, and personal items were auctioned off in Munich, Germany, on October 23, 2020. The collection includes notes from his speeches on the "Jewish problem" and "work, sacrifice," as well as initialled pots from his personal tea service and presentation copies of his books. The sale attracted attention due to its historical significance and connection to one of the most notorious leaders in history, responsible for World War II and the genocide of 6 million European Jews.

site_title: Ping An-backed China fintech Lufax seeks up to US$2.36b in IPO
summary: Chinese fintech firm Lufax, backed by Ping An Insurance Group, is seeking up to $2.36 billion in an initial public offering (IPO) on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, which offers wealth management and retail lending services, is marketing 175 million American depositary shares at $11.50 to $13.50 each. Lufax's assets under management dropped by 6.1% in 2019, but it reported a net profit of over $1 billion for the six months ended June 30. The IPO is part of a surge of Chinese companies raising funds in the US this year, despite tensions between Washington and Beijing.

site_title: Private equity firm to split PetSmart, Chewy in US$6b recap deal
summary: A private equity firm, BC Partners, is splitting PetSmart and Chewy in a US$6 billion recapitalization deal. PetSmart will receive US$1.3 billion in equity and US$4.65 billion in debt, while Chewy will be operated as a separate, wholly-owned business. This move aims to reduce debt and improve PetSmart's financial structure, allowing it to focus on its brick-and-mortar locations. The deal is seen as a favorable outcome for creditors, following a previous controversy over the distribution of Chewy's equity.

site_title: Huawei ekes out third-quarter revenue growth as US restrictions bite
summary: Huawei reported a third-quarter revenue gain, despite US restrictions and supply-chain difficulties exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's latest flagship smartphone, potentially its last in the high-end Android segment, was announced. Huawei has dismissed US suspicions of its relationship with China's communist government. The telecommunications equipment maker also faced a ban on its 5G network infrastructure in Sweden, following similar restrictions in other countries. Despite these challenges, Huawei managed to eke out revenue growth in the third quarter.

site_title: Ant's record strategic allocation in Shanghai IPO fuels small investor scramble
summary: Chinese fintech giant Ant Group has allocated 80% of its US$35 billion dual-listing for Shanghai to strategic investors, fueling a scramble among smaller investors to secure shares in the Hong Kong float. Smaller Chinese investors are bidding for Ant shares in Hong Kong, with a 50-70% chance of securing IPO shares compared to the mainland. The move underscores strong demand for the float, despite market volatility concerns and a US election. Ant's strategic investors, including Alibaba, face longer lock-up periods than typical.

site_title: Europe: Stocks wobble at the start of trading
summary: European stock markets wobbled at the start of trading on Friday, with London and Paris experiencing gains while Frankfurt fell. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.5% to 5,812.60 points, driven by Barclays' upbeat third-quarter results. The Paris CAC 40 rose 0.3% to 4,865.82 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index declined marginally, 0.1% to 12,533.96 points. The losses were attributed to bank and healthcare stocks.

site_title: 250 allowed at MMA show as fans return in Singapore
summary: Singapore is set to allow 250 mask-wearing fans at a One Championship MMA fight card next week, marking the first time fans will attend a large-scale event in months. The event, "One: Inside the Matrix," will feature six fights at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, with attendees undergoing antigen tests for Covid-19. This pilot programme aims to gradually ease curbs and travel restrictions as the country's outbreak slows. The event follows a closed-door show held in Singapore this month, its first major international show since the pandemic.

site_title: Muhyiddin seeks king's assent to declare emergency, according to sources
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin met with King Al-Sultan Abdullah on Friday to request a state of emergency, a move that opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim denounced as an attempt to cling to power. The proposed emergency would suspend parliament in November, but spare public restrictions beyond coronavirus curbs. Muhyiddin, with a two-seat majority, faces pressure from Anwar's declaration of enough votes to oust him and a resurgence in coronavirus cases. The king can declare a state of emergency if he believes national security, economy, or public order are threatened, and this would grant the executive powers to make rules and approve public security measures.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is seeking the king's assent on Friday for the monarch to declare a state of emergency, two sources with direct knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Singapore, Germany to set up reciprocal green lane
summary: Germany and Singapore have agreed to establish a reciprocal green lane, allowing essential travel between the two countries for business or official purposes via direct flights. The arrangement, the first for Germany, will require adherence to Covid-19 prevention and public health measures mutually agreed upon by both countries. This model is expected to be used as a basis for future arrangements between Singapore and other European countries.

site_title: Flipkart to buy 8% stake in Aditya Birla's fashion unit for 15b rupees
summary: Flipkart, a subsidiary of Walmart, will purchase a 7.8% stake in Aditya Birla Fashion and Retail for 15 billion rupees. The investment comes as the company and Amazon compete for market share in India's growing online market. Aditya Birla plans to use the funds to strengthen its balance sheet and scale up its businesses. The deal sent Aditya Birla Fashion and Retail's shares up 6% to 163.45 rupees, their highest since March 30.

site_title: Indonesia president orders ministers to target lower exports of raw coal
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo ordered his Cabinet ministers to reduce exports of unprocessed coal and develop domestic industries for processing coal. The goal is to shift away from being a raw materials' exporting nation and increase value from Indonesia's rich mineral resources. The president aims to process 50% of coal into gas, petrochemical products, and to replace liquefied petroleum gas with dimethyl ether produced from coal. A coal gasification plant is already under construction to start commercial operation in 2025.

site_title: Stocks hold tight ranges as US election caution sets in
summary: Global stocks remained stable on Friday as investors awaited the US presidential election and a potential stimulus deal in Washington. The US S&P 500 futures barely budged, while Asian shares were flat, despite a slight increase in Japan's Nikkei. The final US presidential debate reinforced investor caution, with a Biden presidency and "blue sweep" expected to lead to concerns about tech policy and limited policy changes. US borrowing costs rose, with the 10-year Treasuries yield reaching a 4 1/2-month high.

site_title: ST Engineering, Montran sign MOU to digitalise payments and settlements systems
summary: ST Engineering and Montran Corporation have signed a memorandum of understanding to digitalize payments and settlements systems in the Asia-Pacific region. The partnership will establish a Centre of Excellence in Singapore, focusing on ISO 20022-compliant real-time gross settlement, central securities depository, and payment system solutions. This aims to meet the evolving financial services space in Singapore and the region. The collaboration will support ST Engineering's growth strategy in critical information systems and digitalization of user-centric payment systems.

site_title: Citigroup says private bank chief set to depart
summary: Citigroup announced that Peter Charrington, global head of private banking, will depart to spend more time with family and pursue new opportunities. Charrington, a 26-year veteran of the bank, has been leading the private banking division since 2014. He will assist in ensuring a smooth transition before his departure, which is expected to occur in the coming months.

site_title: Nanofilm's IPO shares priced at S$2.59, promising market cap of S$1.7b
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a spin-off company of Nanyang Technological University, has priced its initial public offering (IPO) at S$2.59 per share, offering 77.2 million shares. The shares will be listed on the mainboard, with a market capitalisation of approximately S$1.7 billion post-IPO. The public offer opens on October 23 and will close on October 28.

site_title: Australia's biggest mining royalty firm Deterra debuts with A$2.57b market value
summary: Deterra Royalties, Australia's largest mining royalty firm, debuted on the Australian Securities Exchange with a market value of A$2.57 billion. The company, spun off from Iluka Resources, issued 528 million shares trading at A$4.87, with shares rising 1.6% to A$4.95 before falling to A$4.80. Deterra's key asset is an iron ore royalties stream from BHP Group's South Flank operations. The company plans to diversify its portfolio and pay out all net profit as dividends, with Iluka holding a 20% minority stake.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain on upbeat US data, stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.24% on Friday, following overnight US economic data that showed jobless claims fell more than expected and existing home sales surged to a 14-year high, boosting stimulus hopes. The Kospi closed at 2,360.81, up 5.76 points. Despite rising domestic coronavirus cases, gains were capped.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares rose on Friday, tracking overnight Wall Street gains on upbeat US economic data and stimulus hopes, though rising domestic coronavirus cases capped gains.

site_title: Hyflux unit's former employee sentenced to 10 days' jail in bribery case
summary: A former Hyflux subsidiary human resource manager, Khoo Chen Ee, was sentenced to 10 days' jail for accepting bribes of S$6,000 from a recruitment agency director. Khoo, who worked on an incineration plant project, received the bribes in exchange for recommending the agency for the project. He also asked the director to cover his personal expenses, including a short holiday to Bangkok. Khoo pleaded guilty to two corruption charges and will begin his sentence on November 6.

site_title: Parti Liyani case: Chief Justice allows probe into prosecutors
summary: Singapore's Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon allowed an investigation into two public prosecutors amid a complaint from a former maid, Parti Liyani, who was acquitted of stealing from her ex-employer. The probe comes after the high court overturned her 2016 conviction due to an "improper motive." A disciplinary tribunal will review the case, and the deputy prosecutors welcome the inquiry. The decision highlights the challenges faced by migrant workers in accessing justice, with rights groups criticizing the handling of the case.
