site_title: Cathay Pacific's permanent pilot pay cuts 'draconian' and 'short-sighted': union
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has implemented permanent pilot pay cuts, described as "draconian" and "short-sighted" by the Hong Kong Aircrew Officers Association (HKAOA), which represents the pilots. The airline is forcing 5,900 pilots onto lower-paid contracts or risk losing their jobs as part of a restructuring plan costing HK$2.2 billion. The new contracts are open-ended and perpetual, targeting pilots based on aircraft type, and offer pay based on flying hours, leading to lower salaries in idle periods.

site_title: Two-speed recovery in services trade expected: HSBC
summary: HSBC predicts a two-speed recovery in services trade due to the pandemic, with digital services recovering more quickly than travel. International travel is expected to remain suppressed, while digitally-enabled and R&D services may see a post-COVID boost. To support the recovery, tackling barriers to digital trade and improving digital infrastructure are crucial, potentially speeding up global services trade growth.

site_title: Japan's newest low-cost carrier is hiring around 100 staff
summary: Japan's low-cost carrier, Zipair Tokyo, is hiring around 100 staff, including flight attendants and ground operations personnel, as it launches passenger flights between Tokyo and cities like Bangkok and Seoul. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic affecting the aviation industry, Japan Airlines is sticking to its philosophy of protecting jobs by swapping employees around from overstaffed units, rather than cutting positions or furloughing workers. The new employees will help support the airline's plans to add two Boeing 787 jets in fiscal 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US presidential debate
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, October 23, 2020, after a more civil US presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. The benchmark Nikkei index advanced 0.18% to 23,516.59, and the Topix index rose 0.34% to 1,625.32. Investors were relieved by the debate, leading to a positive market reaction.

site_title: HDB resale volume jumps to 10-year high in Q3 as prices rise 1.5% over quarter
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore experienced a 10-year high in Q3 2020, with 7,787 flats sold, a 127.3% increase from the previous quarter. Resale prices rose 1.5% over the quarter and 2.3% year-over-year, driven by pent-up demand and new flat launches. Analysts attribute the surge to buyers seeking affordability and living space in the current economic climate. With lower supply from Build-To-Order (BTO) flats and ongoing government support measures, resale prices may continue to climb, with predictions of up to 2.5% growth this year.

site_title: Gold up on stimulus optimism; strong USD caps gains
summary: Gold rose 0.1% to $1,906.29 per ounce, driven by optimism over a US stimulus package, despite a stronger dollar. The metal has gained 26% this year, benefiting from government stimulus. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said negotiators were making progress in talks, and market analysts expect gold to rise further, potentially reaching $1,950 an ounce, as investors seek haven positioning ahead of the US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Gold edged up on Friday on hopes that a US stimulus package would eventually be passed, boosting the metal's appeal as an inflation hedge, although a stronger dollar capped gains.

site_title: Singapore narrows inflation outlook range; core inflation at -0.1% in Sept
summary: Singapore's authorities have upgraded their inflation forecast for 2020, narrowing the lower band to -0.5% from -1%, due to core inflation remaining in negative territory for eight consecutive months. Core inflation inched up to -0.1% in September, and is expected to turn "mildly positive" in 2021. This revised forecast is a slight improvement compared to the previous estimate.

site_title: iFast Q3 net profit surges 150.6% to S$6.2m on higher revenue
summary: iFast Corporation reported a net profit of S$6.2 million for the third quarter, surging 150.6% from S$2.5 million last year. Gross revenue increased 33.3% to S$45 million, driven by a 69.5% rise in B2C segment revenue to S$9.2 million and a 26.3% increase in B2B revenue to S$35.8 million. The company attributed its growth to its integrated digital wealth management platform and expects robust growth in full-year performance.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on US stimulus uncertainty, weak manufacturing data
summary: Australian shares ended the day 0.1% lower, closing at 6,167.00, due to uncertainty over a US stimulus deal and weaker-than-expected domestic manufacturing data. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 0.8% in the week, amid market volatility. A preliminary survey showed Australian manufacturing activity in October expanded at a slower pace than last month. Investor caution was heightened ahead of the US Presidential elections, with a stimulus deal still elusive.

site_title: Tycoon who helped Evergrande has debt challenges of his own
summary: Zhang Jindong, founder of Suning Appliance Group, has provided a financial lifeline to struggling Chinese real estate developer China Evergrande Group by waiving his right to force repayment by January. This move comes as Evergrande faces a US$120 billion debt pile and has seen its shares and yuan notes plummet in recent weeks. Zhang's own company has struggled, reporting a 13% drop in revenue and a loss in the first half of 2020, with analysts citing intense competition in the retail industry and the impact of the pandemic.

site_title: PayPal in talks to buy crypto firms including BitGo
summary: PayPal is exploring acquisitions of cryptocurrency companies, including Bitcoin custodian BitGo, to expand its digital coin offerings. The talks, which could lead to a deal within weeks, would allow PayPal to store Bitcoin securely. BitGo, backed by investors such as Goldman Sachs, has raised $58.5 million in funding. The acquisition would mark a significant move for PayPal, which has already partnered with Paxos Trust Company for its new cryptocurrency service, allowing customers to buy, sell, and hold cryptocurrencies on its platform.

site_title: First Reit's Indonesian tenant asks to restructure master lease agreements
summary: First Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) has received a request from its Indonesian tenant, Metropolis Propertindo Utama (MPU), to restructure master lease agreements for three properties in Indonesia. MPU is seeking additional rental relief for the second half of the year and flexibility in payment of outstanding rents. First Reit's manager will consider the request "carefully" and ensure it is mutually beneficial for the company and its unitholders, subject to outstanding rents being fully repaid.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says Bukit Sembawang land bank undervalued, initiates with 'buy'
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on Bukit Sembawang Estates with a "buy" rating and a target price of S$5.44. The research team believes the property developer's large land bank is undervalued, with a revalued net asset value of S$12.10 per share. DBS estimates that long-term investors could receive a 70% return on their capital over the next decade, driven by dividend normalization and a pivot to a recurring income base. Shares rose 3.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Eat Just, maker of plant-based eggs, eyes US$2b valuation
summary: Eat Just Inc, a plant-based egg startup, is raising at least US$200 million in funding, valuing the company at US$2 billion or more. The company aims to achieve operating profitability and then consider an initial public offering. Eat Just has already sold over 50 million plant-based eggs and has raised over US$300 million in funding from investors. The company plans to build its first plant protein facility in Singapore and is expanding its product line, which includes eggless mayonnaise. Eat Just is part of the growing plant-based food industry, which is attracting institutional investors seeking ESG targets.

site_title: In calmer debate, Biden and Trump offer sharply divergent visions for US
summary: US President Donald Trump and Joe Biden delivered sharply divergent closing arguments in the final presidential debate, with Trump airing unsubstantiated attacks on Biden's finances and Biden outlining his policy agenda, including large-scale economic stimulus spending and a muscular expansion of healthcare and worker benefits. Trump failed to lay out a clear case for his own reelection and misrepresented facts, while Biden stuck to his core argument, denouncing Trump as a divisive and unethical leader. The debate highlighted the candidates' irreconcilable differences on issues such as the pandemic, climate change, and immigration, with Biden calling for aggressive federal action and Trump promising a vaccine and opening up the country.

site_title: Fast-fashion heiress goes green by urging shoppers to buy less
summary: Veronica Chou, heiress to the $2.7 billion textile empire, is shifting her focus from fast fashion to sustainable fashion, investing in startups that use innovative technologies to reduce waste and emissions in the industry. Chou's own brand, Everybody & Everyone, offers eco-friendly clothing made from fermented agricultural waste and wood pulp-based fibers. She aims to make a profit while promoting sustainability, saying "it's not charity." The sustainable fashion market is expected to grow to $8.25 billion by 2023, and Chou's efforts join a growing list of startups seeking to capitalize on consumers' concerns about environmental impact.

site_title: UK signs trade deal with Japan as Brexit talks heat up
summary: The UK signed a trade deal with Japan, its first major deal since Brexit, in a ceremony in Tokyo. The deal, reached in principle in September, preserves UK trade terms with Tokyo as part of the EU and is expected to boost Britain's GDP by 0.07% over 15 years. The agreement adds rules on digital trade and financial services, improving access to the UK market for Japanese train cars and car parts. The pact has strategic significance, opening a pathway to membership in the Comprehensive Trans-Pacific Partnership, and will come into effect on January 1.

images.alt_text: In a ceremony in Tokyo, UK International Trade Secretary Liz Truss and Japanese Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi put their names to the pact, which was reached in principle in September.

site_title: Gucci's appeal holds up in pandemic as Kering beats estimates
summary: Kering SA's revenue beat estimates in the third quarter, driven by strong performances from Gucci and Bottega Veneta. Gucci's organic revenue fell 8.9%, less than expected, while Bottega Veneta's revenue climbed 21%, exceeding estimates. Kering's overall revenue came in at 3.72 billion euros. The company remains confident in its strategy, aiming to reduce Gucci's wholesale presence to less than 10% of revenue by next year.

site_title: Gilead's remdesivir gets US FDA approval for hospitalised Covid-19 patients
summary: The US FDA approved Gilead Sciences' antiviral drug remdesivir for treating hospitalised Covid-19 patients, making it the first and only approved treatment in the US. Remdesivir has been available under an emergency use authorisation since May, reducing hospital stays by five days, but a global trial found no substantial effect on hospital stay or survival. The drug will be sold under the brand name Veklury at $3,120 for a five-day treatment course. Despite concerns, Gilead expects to meet demand and has regulatory approvals in 50 additional countries.

site_title: 1MDB saga: Goldman to claw back US$174m in executive pay
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay $2.9 billion to resolve its role in the 1MDB corruption scandal, including a $2.3 billion fine and $600 million in ill-gotten gains. The bank will also claw back $174 million in executive compensation and pay $122 million to Singapore authorities. Goldman's CEO, David Solomon, will see his compensation reduced for 2020, and the bank will improve its compliance controls. The settlement resolves a probe into the bank's role in helping to steal cash from the Malaysian state fund, and analysts say it will allow Solomon to accelerate his plans to turn the bank around.

images.alt_text: The bank would be clawing back compensation from the three bankers involved and its former executive team "in acknowledgement of the firm's institutional failures".

site_title: MUFG rules out more job cuts at Asia brokerage after comeback
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) has ruled out further job cuts at its Asia brokerage business after a lengthy overhaul, citing a successful transformation that has led to a 90% pretax profit from overseas operations in the quarter ended June. The move contrasts with other major banks, which are resuming job cuts amid market volatility. MUFG's brokerage arm has reduced staff by about 40% and is focusing on debt business, with plans to double managed assets to 70 trillion yen within three years.

site_title: Wells Fargo explores sale of asset management business: sources
summary: Wells Fargo is exploring the sale of its asset management business, which managed $578 billion as of June, in a move aimed at turning around the bank following a years-old scandal. The potential deal could fetch over $3 billion and would be the bank's biggest shake-up since CEO Charles Scharf joined last year. Scharf has set a goal of $10 billion in annual savings and is taking drastic measures to achieve it, following his predecessor's cost-cutting efforts. The sale would be a significant move under Scharf's leadership.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co is exploring a sale of its asset management business, in what would be the US bank's biggest shake-up since former Bank of New York Mellon chief executive officer (CEO) Charles Scharf joined as CEO last year, people familiar with the matter said on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks edge up on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.08 points or 0.1% to 1,500.88 on Friday, driven by a slight increase in trading volume. The market saw 240 gainers compared to 176 losers. The gains came despite global market trends, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, and US stocks near records despite tariff threats.

site_title: Uber, Lyft ordered by appeals court to comply with labour law
summary: A California appeals court has ruled that Uber and Lyft must comply with a state labor law that treats their drivers as employees, rather than independent contractors. The law, in effect since January, was granted as a preliminary injunction by a lower court. The appeals panel upheld the decision, citing no legal errors in the lower court's ruling. The companies have been supporting a statewide ballot measure that would partially exempt them from the law.

site_title: Airbus sets plan to gear up production in show of confidence
summary: Airbus plans to increase production of its A320neo jet by 47 units per month in the second half of 2021, up from its current target of 40, signaling growing confidence in jetliner demand recovery. The move is seen as a sign of optimism despite recent capacity cuts and order deferrals by major customers, including Delta Air Lines and Boeing. Airbus has asked suppliers to be prepared for the increased production rate, which may be adjusted based on market conditions.

site_title: Barclays Private Bank CEO tackles Brexit and pandemic challenges
summary: Barclays Private Bank CEO Jean-Christophe Gerard navigates the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit. Gerard aims to grow the UK domestic market and expand Barclays' presence in mainland Europe from its Dublin hub, where the bank will move staff and assets. Despite Brexit, Gerard believes Barclays can still serve European clients, particularly in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany. Gerard also emphasizes the importance of adapting to the pandemic and finding a balance between working from home and being in the office.

site_title: Malaysia may proclaim 'economic emergency' to avert snap polls amid pandemic: sources
summary: Malaysia's Cabinet is considering declaring an "economic emergency" to avoid snap polls amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The move would allow the government to maintain control over the budget and spending without being influenced by the unstable political atmosphere. This proposal is being discussed as the country sees a surge in new cases and the opposition has urged a delay in elections. The emergency measure would give the executive arm the power to make necessary rules for public security, suspending Parliament and potentially saving the government from collapse.

images.alt_text: Election Commission chief Abdul Ghani Salleh had also said on Oct 13 that "in light of the outbreak, we urge, if possible, that no election be held during this period".

site_title: Huawei out-hustles Trump by hoarding chips vital for China 5G
summary: Huawei successfully stockpiled critical radio chips ahead of US sanctions, ensuring it can supply Chinese carriers with 5G technology through 2021. Taiwanese contract manufacturer TSMC shipped over 2 million units of Huawei's 7-nanometre chips, exceeding initial demand. This move underscores the mixed success of the US campaign against China's largest tech company since 2018. Despite US restrictions, Huawei has secured billions of dollars in 5G orders from state-owned carriers and can continue to supply China's nationwide 5G network, driving the country's economy.

site_title: Remote work hits office toilet-paper sales - and Kimberly-Clark
summary: Remote work has negatively impacted Kimberly-Clark's business, with sales of commercial tissue-paper rolls and toilet-seat covers declining 16% last quarter. The company attributes this decline to the shift towards remote work, citing Amazon's and Synchrony Financial's permanent remote work policies. Kimberly-Clark's tissue sales to retail consumers rose 11% in North America, but the company's shares fell 6.9% due to the decline in office-focused sales. Other companies, such as ODP Corp and uniform providers, are also feeling the pinch from reduced corporate work.

site_title: Medinex buys 4.59% stake in HC Surgical for about S$2.2m
summary: Medinex, a medical support services provider, acquired a 4.59% stake in HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) for approximately S$2.2 million. The investment, made using internal resources, was completed through market transactions from Oct 9-22. Medinex aims to participate in HCSS's growth and enhance shareholder value, citing recent announcements, including a framework agreement with Prudential and the acquisition of GMH Endoscopy & Surgery.

site_title: World Bank sees slow commodities recovery after virus hit
summary: The World Bank predicts a slow commodities recovery after the coronavirus outbreak, with oil demand expected to have "lasting impacts" due to changes in consumer and employment behavior. Oil prices are forecast to average US$41 a barrel in 2020 and US$44 in 2021, below 2019 levels. Metals and agriculture prices are expected to rise modestly, with metals up 2% and agriculture up 1% this year. The pandemic's duration and vaccine development speed pose risks to price forecasts.

site_title: Singapore office rents fall 4.5% in Q3: URA
summary: Singapore office rents fell 4.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q3, moderating demand amid a bleak employment outlook. Prices in the central region rose 0.2% and rentals in the fringe eased 4.4% due to cost efficiency being the main driver for leasing enquiries. The vacancy rate of office space edged down to 12% at the end of Q3, despite a 19,000 sq m decrease in occupied space. Two record price transactions were recorded, with a unit at Suntec Tower 1 sold at S$3,443 per sq ft of strata area.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index down 0.05% to 24,773.12. The decline follows investors' focus on the US presidential election. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.13% to 3,308.16, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.05% to 2,244.26. The decline is attributed to concerns over US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore retail rents down 4.5% in Q3, vacancy flat at 9.6%: URA
summary: Singapore's retail rents declined 4.5% in Q3 2020, with a flat 9.6% vacancy rate. Despite a 2.2% price increase, the islandwide supply of retail space grew to 428,000 sq m. Occupied retail space contracted 50,000 sq m, and the stock of retail space fell 53,000 sq m. Experts predict a tough operating environment due to social distancing and crowd-management measures, leading to weaker retailers downsizing or exiting the market, with overall retail rents expected to fall 10-15% for the year.

site_title: Sunak fires third aid salvo in a month to help ailing British economy
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak has increased aid for businesses affected by the coronavirus pandemic, his third support package in a month. The new measures include increased government contributions to workers' wages, reduced working hours, and grants for businesses under tier 2 restrictions. The grants will be backdated to August for areas with longer restrictions. Sunak aims to support the economy, which is facing a recession predicted to be the sharpest and deepest in three centuries.

site_title: Tesla's release of new 'self-driving' software closely watched by US regulator
summary: US auto safety regulator the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) closely watched Tesla's release of a beta version of its "Full Self Driving" software, allowing cars to drive themselves. The upgrade, planned for wider release by the end of the year, was released to "expert, careful" drivers and prompted excitement among recipients who shared videos of their cars driving autonomously. NHTSA warned it will monitor the technology and take action to protect public safety, citing 19 crashes involving Tesla vehicles where advanced driver assistance systems were engaged.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by US gains, with the Nikkei index advancing 0.4% to 23,559.40. Investors focused on the final US presidential election debate. Meanwhile, European stocks fell, with banking and healthcare sectors weighing down, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Big-name Asia hedge funds raise billions, startups struggle
summary: Established Asian hedge funds have attracted over $3 billion in new money this year, with Tribeca Investment Partners and Dymon Asia Capital among the top recipients. In contrast, regional funds have seen a net outflow of $3.1 billion. Startups face challenges due to global travel restrictions, which limit face-to-face meetings with European and US asset allocators. Funds with proven track records or stable returns are more likely to attract new money, with some platforms offering access to star managers.

site_title: Apparel retailer Gap soars after pledging return to profitable growth in 2021
summary: Gap Inc shares surged 14% after the company pledged to return to profitable growth in 2021, driven by expansion of Old Navy and Athleta brands, reduced product assortment, and a shift away from traditional malls. The retailer aims to reach a 10% profit margin by 2023, with Athleta and Old Navy expected to make up 70% of total sales. This plan follows the company's recovery from the pandemic-induced decline in consumer spending on apparel.

images.alt_text: Gap Inc shares jumped after the retailer said it expects to return to profitable growth next year, easing investor concerns over the financial strain of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Why building an electric car is so expensive, for now
summary: Tesla aims to produce a $25,000 electric car in three years, but the technology and manufacturing are expensive, mainly due to the high cost of lithium-ion batteries. The cathode component, which stores and releases energy, is particularly pricey due to the need for expensive metals like cobalt, nickel, and lithium. While costs have decreased by 87% over the past decade, they still need to drop to match the cost of internal-combustion engine cars. Innovations such as replacing cobalt with nickel and simplifying battery designs are expected to reduce costs, with forecasts predicting a 93% per kWh price drop by 2024.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 2,532.22 on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street as investors anticipate more US fiscal stimulus. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 49, with UG Healthcare Corporation and Jiutian Chemical leading the charge. Banking stocks were mixed, while Wilmar International and Jardine Cycle & Carriage also made notable moves. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5% in the US, with stocks supported by rallies on Wall Street.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm McAfee's shares fall in return to market
summary: McAfee Corp's shares fell 6.5% in their trading debut, closing at $18.70 after a $740 million initial public offering (IPO). The cybersecurity software company cited a 70% increase in mobile malware attacks and the COVID-19 pandemic's rise in cybercrime. McAfee CEO Peter Leav stated that cybercriminals are using the pandemic as a lure. The company's shares traded below its IPO price of $20 and gave it a market value of approximately $8.1 billion.

site_title: Pelosi says 'just about there' on US stimulus; Senate hurdle awaits
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin are "just about there" on resolving a key piece of a coronavirus relief package, despite significant differences on funding for state and local governments, school funding, and a liability shield for employers. Pelosi hopes to reach an agreement by the Nov 3 election, but Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's opposition to the spending levels under discussion remains a major hurdle. The two sides are nearing agreement on how to allocate money for testing and tracing to safely reopen schools and the economy.

site_title: Intel's revenue from data-centre business misses estimates, shares slide
summary: Intel's data-centre business revenue fell 7% to $5.9 billion in the third quarter, missing estimates of $6.21 billion. The company's shares slid 8% due to the pandemic's impact on government and business customers' spending on its chips. Despite a 10-nanometre chip factory reaching full production capacity, Intel faces competition from AMD and Nvidia, which are gaining market share. The company expects fourth-quarter revenue of $17.4 billion, in line with estimates.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Commercial Trust, iFast, Straits Trading, Chip Eng Seng
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust's manager declared a 4.17 Singapore cent distribution per unit for the first half, down 9.9% from last year, due to falling gross revenue and net property income. iFast Corporation reported a 150.6% surge in net profit to S$6.2 million for the third quarter. Straits Trading Company issued S$200 million worth of 3.75% notes maturing on Oct 29, 2025. Chip Eng Seng reached a settlement over a proposed acquisition of an Australian childcare centre.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes higher, trade choppy as stimulus talks eyed
summary: US stocks closed higher on Thursday, driven by optimism over potential fiscal stimulus to support the pandemic-damaged US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5% to 28,363.66, while the S&P 500 gained 0.5% to 3,453.49. Despite White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow's caution about significant policy differences, US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi reported progress in stimulus talks, potentially paving the way for more financial aid.

site_title: Straits Trading prices S$200m five-year notes at 3.75%
summary: Straits Trading Company issued S$200 million worth of five-year notes at 3.75% interest, with net proceeds to be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing existing borrowings and financing working capital. The notes were priced at par and oversubscribed, with 99% of investor interest coming from Singapore. The deal was managed by DBS, UOB, and Standard Chartered Bank, and was oversubscribed by over S$400 million from 36 accounts, with 53% coming from fund managers and insurance firms.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on weak manufacturing survey, fading US stimulus hope
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,154 due to weak manufacturing data and fading hopes for a US coronavirus relief package. The S&P/ASX 200 index slipped despite a 0.3% drop in the previous session. A preliminary survey showed Australian manufacturing activity expanded at a weaker pace than expected, while US lawmakers struggled to reach agreement on a relief package. The metals and mining index, led by iron ore miners Rio Tinto and BHP Group, slid 1%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares fell on Friday, weighed down by miners, as weak manufacturing survey data and waning hopes for a pre-election US coronavirus relief package knocked investor sentiment.

site_title: In Time For The Holidays
summary: IWC releases the Top Gun Pilot's Watch Chronograph "SFTI" inspired by the US Naval Aviation Community, featuring a scratch-resistant ceramic case and tactical design. Panerai unveils the Luminor GMT ION Special Edition, paying tribute to Singapore with red accents and a special edition boutique release. Meanwhile, Hermes introduces the Arceau Pocket watch with a hand-crafted tyrannosaurus design, featuring leather mosaic and Grand Feu enamel.

site_title: Handbag maker Hermes echoes luxury sales rebound amid online surge
summary: Hermes, a luxury handbag maker, reported a 7% increase in comparable sales in the third quarter, driven by a rebound in Asia and other regions as COVID-19 restrictions eased. The company's online sales surged 100% in the first nine months, exceeding those of its flagship shops. Despite a cautious outlook for the full year, Hermes' positive sales trend continued into October, with comparable sales rising 8% for leather goods and 5% for fashion.

site_title: Fishing for a good catch at Catfish
summary: Catfish, a new seafood eatery in Singapore, offers a hip vibe and eclectic menu but falls short in terms of quality. The restaurant's menu features unique dishes such as avocado and wasabi cones and grilled snapper with a garish laksa sauce. However, many items are overpriced, and some dishes lack nuance. The restaurant's open kitchen and lively music create a lively atmosphere, but the overall experience is average, with a rating of 6 out of 10.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust H1 DPU down 9.9% to 4.17 cents
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 9.9% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.17 cents for the first half of 2020, down from 4.61 cents in the same period last year. The trust's distributable income rose 3.2% to S$138.42 million, while gross revenue fell 2.5% to S$218.67 million. Occupancy remained at 97.7% and the weighted average all-in cost of debt was 2.57% per annum. The manager attributed the decline to rental rebates and a revision in the net asset value per unit due to the impact of COVID-19.

site_title: Pope's support for gay civil unions seen as threat to same-sex marriage
summary: Pope Francis expressed support for gay civil unions in a documentary, stating that gay couples need legal rights and that "homosexual people have a right to be in a family." However, this stance is seen as insufficient by LGBT+ rights campaigners, who argue it does little to advance their rights or repair damage done to gay people. The comments may undermine the campaign for gay marriage in some countries by suggesting a "separate but equal" alternative, and campaigners are calling for more concrete action from the Catholic Church.

site_title: URA private home price index up 0.8% in Q3; rents fall, vacancies rise
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) reported a 0.8% increase in Singapore's private home price index in Q3, identical to the flash estimate released earlier this month. Landed homes rose 3.7% quarter-over-quarter, while non-landed homes increased 0.1%. Private home rents fell 0.5% in Q3, with landed properties dipping 0.1% and non-landed properties easing 0.6%. The vacancy rate of completed private housing units rose to 6.2% in Q3, with developers launching 3,791 uncompleted units for sale and selling 3,517 private homes.

images.alt_text: Private home rents fell 0.5 per cent quarter on quarter in Q3, a smaller decline compared with the 1.2 per cent decrease in Q2.

site_title: UK Covid-19 salary scheme fraud may hit £3.9 billion, watchdog says
summary: A UK watchdog has estimated that companies may have fraudulently claimed up to £3.9 billion in public money by having furloughed staff work during lockdown. The National Audit Office found that 9% of respondents admitted to working during lockdown at the request of their employer. The government has launched a fraud hotline and will publish the names of those making claims for the Job Support Scheme. The scale of fraud and error could be considerable, particularly for the furlough scheme, with 2.9 million people not eligible for the schemes.

images.alt_text: British companies may have fraudulently claimed up to £3.9 billion (S$6.92 billion) in public money by accepting funds from a salary support scheme while ordering furloughed staff to still work during lockdown, the spending watchdog said.

site_title: Oil struggles to recover after US petrol stocks build
summary: Oil prices rose 70 US cents to $42.42 a barrel and 59 cents to $40.62 a barrel, but struggled to recover from losses due to higher US petrol inventories and a deteriorating demand outlook amid soaring coronavirus cases. This follows a 3% drop in oil prices on Wednesday, the steepest daily fall in three weeks. The gains were attributed to the possibility of an economic stimulus package in the US.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; labour market momentum slows
summary: US jobless claims fell to 787,000, beating expectations, but remain high, indicating a slowdown in the labor market and broader economic recovery from the pandemic. The decline is attributed to the fading boost from fiscal stimulus, with businesses laying off or furloughing workers due to subdued demand. Economists predict claims will remain elevated amid a resurgence in new coronavirus cases, potentially leading to further restrictions. A new relief package is unlikely before the Nov 3 presidential election, amid opposition in the Republican-controlled Senate.

site_title: One Asia Investment Partners' former managing director charged
summary: A 41-year-old former managing director, Sun Weiyeh, of One Asia Investment Partners has been charged with two counts of defrauding investors of a fixed income fund. He allegedly sold bonds at lower prices to a securities dealer and then repurchased them at higher prices, causing investors to lose money. Sun faces up to S$250,000 in fines and seven years in jail if convicted. The charges relate to bonds managed by OAIP, which lost its licence in 2017 after being wound up by the court.

site_title: Natural gas giant EQT to pursue takeover of rival CNX Resources
summary: EQT Corp, the largest US natural gas producer, is proposing to acquire rival CNX Resources Corp, aiming to create a "gas titan" and reduce costs. The deal comes as M&A activity accelerates in the distressed shale patch, with investors seeking scale to control supplies. EQT's CEO Toby Rice, who recently took the top job, is pursuing his first deal since July 2019. CNX's shares rose 16% after trading was paused, while EQT rose 14%. The acquisition would further consolidate the US gas industry, with other deals including Pioneer Natural Resources' $4.5 billion purchase of Parsley Energy and ConocoPhillips' $9.7 billion takeover of Concho Resources.

site_title: Rise of the Rolex Oyster Perpetual
summary: The Rolex Oyster Perpetual collection has gained attention for its vibrant, colourful dials and affordable prices, making it an attractive option for first-time Rolex buyers. The collection, which includes models with sunray-finished and lacquered dials, is available in various sizes and prices range from S$6,780 to S$7,910. Despite being an entry-level model, the Oyster Perpetual collection refuses to be overshadowed by the more popular Professional models, offering a unique alternative for those looking for a stylish and affordable Rolex timepiece.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end little changed as aid hope tempers virus
summary: European stocks closed flat, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index falling 0.1% after erasing a 1.2% drop. Positive earnings reports and US stimulus optimism offset concerns about rising virus cases. Travel, auto, and banking stocks outperformed, while tech shares lagged. The Netherlands reported a record rise in coronavirus infections, joining Germany and other nations. US spy chief accused Iran of interfering in the presidential campaign. Investors await a potential US stimulus deal, with markets trading sideways due to mixed third-quarter earnings and lockdown concerns.

site_title: Cathay seen to be in tighter spot than Singapore Airlines as pandemic continues
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways, a Hong Kong-based airline, is facing a tougher financial situation than Singapore Airlines amid the ongoing pandemic. Cathay is laying off nearly 6,000 people, including 600 pilots, and eliminating 2,600 vacant positions to reduce unsustainable cash burn by HK$500 million a month. The airline's shares fell 3.1% on Thursday, erasing the previous day's gain, while Singapore Airlines' shares rose after an analyst upgraded their rating to buy. Cathay's challenges include balancing its Hong Kong roots with ties to Beijing and the rise of Chinese carriers, which could reduce the airline's relevance as a hub.

site_title: Retooling education to bridge the skills gap
summary: Singapore's workforce faces a "skills gap" due to rapidly changing job demands, with fresh graduates and older job seekers struggling to adapt. Companies are looking for candidates with practical work experience and vocational education may be the solution. Meanwhile, Mitsubishi Power Asia Pacific is shifting towards green energy, and the need for index funds in Singapore's wealth management market remains unfulfilled.

site_title: US dollar rises on stimulus setback, Covid-19 surge
summary: The US dollar rose from seven-week lows on Thursday as hopes for a US fiscal package before the November elections crumbled, and the global Covid-19 surge fueled demand for safe-haven assets. President Trump's comments on the stimulus deal also eased pressure on the currency. The dollar index rose to 92.863, while the euro fell to $1.18325. The euro, pound, and Australian dollar also declined against the US dollar, while the New Zealand dollar and yen rose.

site_title: Consulting firms facing remake as crisis hits demand for their services
summary: Consulting firms face a crisis in demand for their traditional services amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite headwinds, some firms are expected to benefit from the pandemic's acceleration of business transformation and digitalization. Others are expanding into new areas, such as work-from-home advisory services and scenario-planning. The industry's inefficiencies and slow adaptability have been highlighted by market research firm CB Insights, but firms are now focusing on pivoting their offerings to meet client demands related to digitalization and digital business strategies.

site_title: AirAsia secures loan; capital raising progressing: CEO
summary: AirAsia Group has secured a RM300 million loan from Sabah Development Bank Bhd to keep its operations afloat amid the pandemic. The loan is part of the airline's ongoing capital raising plans, which aim to raise up to RM2.5 billion by year-end. Meanwhile, Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG), parent of Malaysia Airlines, has offered early retirement to employees aged 45 and above as it continues negotiations with creditors and lessors.

site_title: Another office floor at GB Building for sale, with guide price of S$9.8m
summary: A seventh-floor office floor at GB Building in Singapore's central business district has been launched for sale with a guide price of S$9.8 million (S$1,800 psf). The renovated floor features a column-free layout and exclusive use of the lift lobby, pantry, and restrooms. Marketing agents Brilliance Capital and Savills Singapore say the price is "compelling" and "attractive" compared to recent strata office transactions in the area, with tight supply in the central business district expected to drive growth in capital and rental values.

site_title: Hungary, Singapore mark 50 years of ties
summary: Hungary and Singapore marked 50 years of diplomatic relations, with bilateral ties dominated by economic and scientific cooperation. The two countries have built strong and cordial relations, with Hungary being Singapore's largest trading and investment partner in ASEAN. Key areas of cooperation include food and agriculture, space, defense, and automotive industries. Hungary offers 30 full-fledged scholarships to Singaporean students, and cultural ties focus on music cooperation. The Hungarian ambassador highlights the investment climate in Hungary as highly attractive, with Singaporean companies like Patec Group and Thakral Corporation Ltd having operations in Hungary.

site_title: Rebirth Of An Icon
summary: Cartier is reviving its iconic Pasha de Cartier watch, first introduced in 1943, with a new unisex collection in 2020. The watch features a bold design with a square case contrasting with a round dial, signature protruding crown protector, and various modern updates. The collection includes models in steel and gold, with options for personalization, diamonds, and skeletonized versions. The Pasha's unique design has made it a timeless classic, appealing to both collectors and fashion enthusiasts.

site_title: Trailblazing Their Way To Stardom
summary: Cartier has partnered with five young celebrities - Rami Malek, Troye Sivan, Willow Smith, Maisie Williams, and Jackson Wang - to promote its new Pasha watch collection. The campaign, shot by photographer Craig McDean, showcases the watch's extroverted design and power. The collection embodies the spirit of progressiveness and open-mindedness, aligning with the values of the new generation of creators. The campaign will span across billboards and social media platforms, highlighting the watch's edgy design and relevance to today's creators.

site_title: Back To Classics
summary: Bulgari has refreshed its classic Bulgari Aluminium watch, 20 years after its initial launch, and revived the Gerald Genta Arena line. The updated Aluminium features a slim 40mm aluminium case, improved resistance, and a mechanical self-winding movement. A chronograph version is also available, priced at US$4,250. Meanwhile, the Gerald Genta Arena Bi-Retro Sport has been reintroduced, boasting a 42mm titanium case and a complex automatic movement. Bulgari has also broken a record for slimness with the Octo Finissimo Tourbillon Chronograph Skeleton Automatic, measuring just 7.44mm thick.

site_title: Global household wealth holds steady amid pandemic: report
summary: Global household wealth has remained stable amid the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a Credit Suisse report. Wealth management measures by governments worldwide have helped households recover, outperforming the 2008 global financial crisis. However, the positive impacts are expected to wear off as government assistance is curtailed and the recession takes its toll. Low-skilled individuals and small businesses have suffered disproportionately, leading to increased income inequality. Total global wealth rose to $400 trillion by end-June, with wealth per adult reaching an all-time high of $77,309.

site_title: Tesla beats on profit, reaffirms goal of 500,000 deliveries
summary: Tesla Inc reported a fifth consecutive quarter of profits, beating analysts' estimates with a profit of 76 cents a share. The company reaffirmed its goal of delivering 500,000 cars in 2020, despite weaker sales globally, and reported a 30% increase in deliveries needed in the last quarter to meet the target. Gross margins also inched up, and Tesla's revenue rose to $8.8 billion. The earnings streak could add momentum for Tesla's inclusion in the S&P 500 Index.

site_title: Little big home
summary: Interior designer Edward Seet transformed his 700 sq ft cozy apartment into a spacious living space by removing walls and reconfiguring the layout. He converted a bedroom into an open plan walk-in wardrobe and created a sunken sleeping area for a king-sized bed. Sliding doors, uniform doors, and a mechanized cooker hood were also installed to enhance the sense of space. The couple achieved a monochrome look by using black and grey, and they are planning to upgrade to a bigger apartment when they start a family.

images.alt_text: Above: The dining table, customised at bar counter height, is made of quartz and also connects to the kitchen countertop.
The dining table, customised at bar counter height, is made of quartz and also connectsto the kitchen countertop (above).

Not a conventional bedroom, for sure. Edward Seet created a sunken sleeping area to fit their mattress. The remaining space was turned into a small path to the windows, and he even managed to fit in storage space at the far end of the room.
The TV is hung from the ceiling, and tilted at a certain angle, so that it can be viewed from both the dining and living areas.
To display his collection of design magazines, Edward Seet designed an open shelf in the living room.
The monochrome look continues into their his and hers bathrooms. Mr Seet's bathroom has black tiles, while his wife's bathroom is in contrasting white.

site_title: Deutsche Bank unit may be bought by Tata Consultancy
summary: Deutsche Bank's technology services unit, Postbank Systems AG, is in advanced talks to be sold to Tata Consultancy Services Ltd, Asia's largest software exporter. The deal is expected to be finalized by the end of the year, with the Bonn-based company being sold to the Indian company. The sale is part of Deutsche Bank's efforts to focus on its core banking business.

site_title: New dining concepts
summary: New dining concepts are set to open in Singapore, including Restaurant Euphoria, a Michelin-starred chef's new elevated 'Gastro-Botanica' cuisine, Beppe De Vito's Italian steakhouse, and Adda, a new Indian restaurant by Manjunath Mural. Bootle's, an online grocer, and Chef Chan's Private Dine, a pop-up private dining experience, are also launching. These establishments aim to bring unique and sustainable dining experiences to the market, with a focus on quality ingredients, innovative flavors, and eco-friendly practices.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q3 DPU falls 21.9% to 1.848 cents
summary: Suntec Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 21.9% to 1.848 Singapore cents in Q3, due to lower distributable income from operations, which dropped 12.6% year on year. Gross revenue and net property income also declined 13.4% and 19% respectively. However, the Reit's retail business showed encouraging signs of recovery, with stronger tenant sales recovery at Suntec City Mall. The DPU will be paid out on Nov 25, despite the challenging quarter.

site_title: US official says Iran, Russia trying to interfere in election
summary: US intelligence director John Ratcliffe warned that Iran and Russia are attempting to interfere in the presidential election, with Iran spreading false information to American voters and Russia targeting Democratic candidate Joe Biden. Voter registration information has been obtained by both countries, which can be used to convey misinformation. The US has confirmed no hacking was involved, and the administration has taken steps to proactively monitor and thwart any attempts to interfere. Iran views President Trump as an archenemy due to his withdrawal from the nuclear accord and economic sanctions.

site_title: The show still goes on
summary: Patek Philippe has released new watches despite the pandemic, including a steel Calatrava model, three grand complications, and two lady's releases. The Ref 5303R-001 Minute Repeater Tourbillon features a 42mm 18K rose-gold case, adhering to Patek Philippe's principles of elegant design and simplicity. The watch is a re-release from the Watch Art Grand Exhibition in Singapore, showcasing the brand's commitment to complication watches.

site_title: Chipmaker Xilinx's profit tops estimates, sees return to growth
summary: Xilinx, a chipmaker in takeover talks with AMD, reported earnings that beat Wall Street estimates, with revenue expected to start growing again in the current period. The company's sales will be $750-$800 million in the next quarter, marking its first quarter of year-over-year growth in five periods. Xilinx is focusing on data centers, with sales up 30% in the fiscal second quarter, and is confident in sustaining double-digit growth despite "choppy" orders.

site_title: Mazda CX-8 review: A long story
summary: The Mazda CX-8 is a long-wheelbase version of the CX-5, offering room for three rows of seats, with the option for six or seven seats. The six-seater model costs $1,000 more than the seven-seater, but offers more space per seat. The CX-8 is praised for its comfortable ride, smooth transmission, and lively performance, despite its non-turbocharged engine. It is well-suited for families, with advanced safety features and ample cargo space, making it a strong proposition in the SUV market.

site_title: CMT's DPU up 1.3% to 3.1 cents as funds retained in H1 are released for distribution
summary: Capitaland Mall Trust (CMT) reported a 1.3% increase in distribution per unit to 3.1 Singapore cents for its third quarter, driven by the release of S$36.4 million in retained taxable income. Gross revenue fell 25.3% to S$150.3 million, mainly due to rental waivers and lower gross turnover. Net property income declined 27.6% to S$104.4 million. Unitholders can expect to receive the distribution on Nov 19. Despite a cautious outlook, CMT's operational performance has shown steady recovery since Singapore's Phase 2 re-opening.

site_title: Singapore maritime sector to offer 1,000 traineeships, attachments
summary: Singapore is launching 1,000 traineeships, company attachments, and training opportunities in the maritime sector, focusing on new growth areas such as automation, digitalisation, and supply chain integration. The initiatives, under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Initiative, aim to support the transformation of the industry and meet its longer-term manpower needs. Trainees will gain skills in areas like automation systems, data analytics, and maritime-specific skills, and mid-career individuals can access company attachments to explore a career in the sector.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of State for Transport and Foreign Affairs Chee Hong Tat at the National University of Singapore, prior to the SMI Forum 2020, on Thursday. Mr Chee was briefed by MPA chief technology officer Kenneth Lim (right). MPA and SSG are collaborating with institutes of higher learning.

site_title: Time To Shine
summary: Tudor has released the Black Bay Fifty-Eight Navy Blue, a compact and contemporary watch that distills seven decades of tradition into one package. The watch takes its name from 1958, the year Tudor released the Oyster Prince Submariner Ref 7924, and features a 39mm case diameter with a thinner case than its predecessors. The matte domed dial is a work of art, and the watch comes with an in-house COSC-certified Manufacture Calibre MT5402 movement. The Black Bay Fifty-Eight Navy Blue is a homage to Tudor's diving watch heritage and is available with three strap options, including a steel bracelet and a leather or fabric band.

site_title: Inward-looking policies will have great long-term harm: Iswaran
summary: Singapore Business Federation's FTA Day 2020 highlights the importance of free trade agreements (FTAs) in forging resilient supply chains and advancing the digital economy. Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran warned that inward-looking policies will have long-term harm to growth opportunities and living standards. The event featured discussions on the impact of Covid-19 on supply chains and travel, with business leaders urging Singapore to remain open and connected. Singapore has a network of 25 FTAs with economies accounting for over 85% of global GDP, and is pursuing new digital economy agreements with Chile, New Zealand, and Australia.

site_title: Rolex pips an MBA in the corporate world
summary: Eddie Sung, a former management consultant, attributes his successful corporate career to his Rolex watch collection. Introduced to Rolex watches at 15, he started collecting them, marking milestones in his career. His Rolex GMT-Master II became an ice-breaker when meeting clients, and he eventually bought his first gold Rolex at the age of 44. Sung retired at 44, citing a desire to pursue his passion for rock music and photography. He now owns multiple Rolex watches, including a gold Oyster Perpetual Datejust and a white-gold Cosmograph Daytona, with his favorite being the first Rolex watch given to him by his late father.

site_title: Throwback Timepieces
summary: Several watch brands have released retro-inspired collections to celebrate past designs. Tudor's Royal range features a notched bezel and five-link integrated bracelet, reminiscent of the 1970s. TAG Heuer's Carrera Sport Chronograph pays tribute to its 1965 Heuer Dato 45 chronograph, with a date window at the 12 o'clock position. Audemars Piguet's Master01 Selfwinding Chronograph draws inspiration from its pre-1951 vintage chronographs, with an Art Deco-inspired dial. Meanwhile, Franck Muller's Cintree Curvex Master Banker Asia Exclusive features a limited edition collection with colorful straps and a multi-timezone watch design.

site_title: Bond gets his newest watch
summary: Omega unveils its latest James Bond watch, the Seamaster Diver 300M James Bond Numbered Edition, a platinum-gold timepiece featuring a 50th-anniversary tribute to the Bond movie On Her Majesty's Secret Service. The watch boasts a Super-LumiNova display, 18K white gold accents, and a laser-engraved 007 logo. Additionally, Omega releases the Seamaster Diver 300M Chronograph and Seamaster Aqua Terra, featuring tantalum and Co-Axial Master Chronometer movements. The brand also introduces the De Ville Tourbillon Numbered Edition, a manual-winding central tourbillon certified by the Swiss Federal Institute of Metrology, priced at $168,000.

site_title: Lessons from Snoopy
summary: The luxury watch industry has recovered from the pandemic disruptions, with major watch fairs being called off due to border shutdowns. As cities reopen, revenge spending and holiday budgets are aiding retail recovery. Brands such as Omega have released new novelties, including the "Silver Snoopy Award" 50th Anniversary watch, which commemorates the first watch to be worn on the moon by astronaut Buzz Aldrin in 1969. The watch's design is inspired by Snoopy, the iconic comic strip beagle, and serves as a symbol of resilience and overcoming challenges.

site_title: German consumer morale darkens as Covid-19 cases soar
summary: German consumer morale has declined to -3.1 heading into November, according to a survey by the GfK institute, as fears of a second COVID-19 wave and potential lockdowns fueled decreased willingness to spend. The decline in sentiment is attributed to rising infection rates and economic expectations, with three-quarters of Germans viewing the pandemic as a major threat. The German government's economic forecast of a 5.8% GDP shrinkage in 2020 has been revised downward, with a slower recovery expected due to sectors heavily impacted by social distancing restrictions.

site_title: Singapore workers focus on staying relevant in tight job market: poll
summary: Singapore workers, particularly those aged 50 and above, are concerned about job security and relevance in the post-pandemic job market, with 90% believing they need to reskill or upskill to stay competitive.

site_title: End of a chapter in Singapore's art history
summary: The NTU Centre for Contemporary Art (CCA) in Singapore will close its current space after a solo exhibition of Trinh T Minh-ha's films, marking the end of a chapter in the country's art history. The centre, which has supported emerging artists and provided a platform for groundbreaking exhibitions, will shut down due to funding shortfalls caused by the pandemic. Despite the closure, CCA will continue its research efforts in a smaller building and maintain its presence in the arts community. Trinh's films, which explore memory and forgetting, serve as an apt swansong for the centre.

images.alt_text: Night Passage (2004) finds inspiration from classic Asian literature to explore similar themes of time, memory, loss, dreams and reality.

site_title: Outgoing UBS chief joins blank-cheque club
summary: UBS' outgoing CEO Sergio Ermotti has agreed to serve as chairman of Investindustrial Acquisition Corp., a blank-cheque company, after filing a revised prospectus with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The company plans to raise US$350 million in a New York Stock Exchange listing. This move follows the growing trend of prominent executives joining blank-cheque companies, also known as special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs).

site_title: Out Of This World Snoopy Tribute
summary: Omega, in collaboration with NASA, has released a commemorative moonwatch to mark 50 years since the Apollo 13 mission, where the Omega Speedmaster played a crucial role in the rescue. The watch features Snoopy, the famous Peanuts comic strip dog, on its subdials and back, where he's seen taking a trip around the moon. The Omega Speedmaster Silver Snoopy Award 50th Anniversary watch is a limited edition, powered by the manual-winding Co-Axial Master Chronometer Calibre 3861 with 50 hours of power reserve.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG CLA 45 S review: Giant-killer
summary: The Mercedes-AMG CLA 45 S is a compact saloon that surpasses its weight class with its 421 horsepower 2.0-litre turbo engine, rivaling some 4.0-litre V8s. The car delivers instant power and razor-sharp steering, making it ideal for winding roads. Its intelligent four-wheel drive system ensures stability, while its suspension is more thumpy than regular CLA models. The CLA 45 S is a more powerful option than the CLA 35, priced at S$302,888 with COE, making it suitable for those who want a petite Mercedes that can compete with larger vehicles.

site_title: Boosting auditor independence in non-assurance services
summary: The Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA) has released new guidelines to strengthen audit independence in non-assurance services, a move welcomed by observers as a step towards raising audit standards. The guidelines recommend that audit firms obtain approval from those charged with governance before providing non-assurance services, and that fees for such services do not exceed 1% of the audit firm's revenue. The aim is to maintain public confidence in audited financial information and address concerns over auditor independence.

site_title: South Korea finance minister loses home, as rental policy comes back to haunt him
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Hong Nam-ki, has lost his home due to a rental policy he implemented to protect tenants and slow deposit increases. The Housing Lease Protection Act, led by Hong, capped deposit increases at 5% and allowed tenants to extend contracts. However, landlords have responded by replacing tenants, leading to a surge in deposits. Hong's average deposit has increased by 32% in three months, making it difficult for him to find a new home. This irony has sparked online mockery, with some calling him "smart" for being a victim of his own policy.

site_title: In trying times, 20 great value wines that revive and restore
summary: During challenging times, 20 great value wines under $20 can provide a restorative escape. The wines, sourced from nine countries, offer a range of qualities, from interesting to provocative, reflecting the rising level of quality globally. Despite not being intended for drinking, these wines can fulfill a restorative role, providing a welcome distraction from daily struggles. The selection is available online, offering a risk worth taking for those seeking unique and distinctive wines.

site_title: Hong Kong's property market takes hit from Cathay job cuts
summary: Hong Kong's property market has taken a hit due to Cathay Pacific Airways' job cuts, affecting over 5,000 employees and causing some to seek cheaper housing or leave the city. Vacancies for high-end apartments have increased, with 60 renters surrendering their leases in Tung Chung over the past three months. Rental prices in the area have dropped 5% since the start of the year, and may fall another 3% in the fourth quarter. The layoffs and compensation cuts will weigh on demand in one of the world's most expensive housing markets.

site_title: Travel bubbles are a good start but they are not enough
summary: Singapore's travel bubble with Hong Kong and other countries may not be enough to revive the travel industry, according to industry estimates. Airlines' passenger numbers are expected to remain low until 2023, with a significant impact on middle- and lower-income countries. Quarantine restrictions are "killing" the demand for air travel, and governments are urged to adopt rigorous testing regimes instead. To achieve a healthy recovery, travel bubbles should be part of a larger, region-wide safe travel area that allows passengers to connect through airports, enabling the resumption of international travel and economic revival.

site_title: BOJ voices confidence in Japan's banking system
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has expressed confidence in Japan's banking system, citing sufficient buffers against risks. However, commercial banks are vulnerable to rising credit costs, particularly from loans to pandemic-hit sectors like property developers. The BOJ warns of increased riskier overseas lending and a heightened risk of defaults and credit costs due to the prolonged COVID-19 battle. A stress test shows internationally active Japanese banks' capital ratio could slump to 7.6% in the most severe-case economic downturn scenario, highlighting the need for vigilance.

site_title: Industrial property rents, prices continue slide
summary: Singapore's industrial property market continues to slide, with rents and prices easing 0.9% and 2.2% quarter-over-quarter, respectively. Occupancy improved due to increased demand for storage, but this was partly driven by landlords prioritizing occupancy over rental rates. The sector is expected to face downward pressures, with construction delays and a significant reduction in new supply completions due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Experts predict a further degree of rental moderation in the short-term, with some segments, such as data centers and high-spec warehouses, potentially more resilient.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: First Reit, a Singapore-based property manager, will extend rental relief to its Indonesian tenants for September and October, amounting to S$18.9 million, following previous relief for May and June. This comes amid Indonesia's escalating COVID-19 cases, which reached a record high last month. Meanwhile, technology solutions provider CSE Global secured S$91 million in new orders for the third quarter, down from last year, despite a 14.8% increase in its order book.

site_title: Online buys now more likely from the region than far away
summary: Online shopping is shifting towards regional purchases, driven by supply-chain disruptions and freight capacity limitations. Data from parcel-forwarding service Buyandship shows a 180% increase in parcels shipped to its warehouses in Singapore from January to September, with 47% coming from Asian retailers. This trend is also observed by local startups and e-commerce platforms, with a surge in domestic e-commerce volumes and a shift towards intra-Asian trade. As the peak e-commerce season approaches, experts warn that airfreight capacity limits may be strained, but Asia's focus on regional trade is expected to continue, creating opportunities for local businesses.

site_title: Goldman Sachs hit with record US bribery fine over 1MDB scandal
summary: Goldman Sachs agreed to a record US$2.3 billion fine for its role in the 1MDB scandal, the largest foreign bribery penalty in US history. The bank pleaded guilty to a single charge and entered a deferred-prosecution agreement, avoiding conviction that could have impacted institutional clients. Goldman's Malaysia unit knowingly agreed to bribe foreign officials to obtain and retain business from 2009 to 2014, with penalties exceeding US$5 billion globally. The deal concludes one of the biggest bank probes inherited by the Trump administration, focusing on the bank's fundraising work for 1MDB in 2012 and 2013.

site_title: In Pursuit Of Precision
summary: F P Journe's Chronometre a Resonance watch marks a milestone in horology, utilizing the "resonance" phenomenon to achieve precision. Developed by Francois-Paul Journe after 15 years of work, the watch uses two oscillators with the same frequency, allowing them to beat in sync and protect against external vibrations. This concept was first explored by Christiaan Huygens in the 17th century and later developed by Antide Janvier and Abraham-Louis Breguet. The watch's 20th anniversary model won the "Montre a Grande Complication" award, and a new version has been released with a single barrel and redesigned case.

images.alt_text: "After 15 years of work, I was able to adapt (the resonance) phenomenon to a wristwatch," recalls Mr Journe, who started the project in 1983. "I felt that this resonance system was particularly well-suited for the various wrist movements; especially the repeated shocks that can occur on the watch mechanism that are so detrimental to its smooth running."
The hand-winding Chronometre a Resonance has attracted a big following and the watch is hotly sought-after.

site_title: Coping with Covid, the virus that keeps bugging us
summary: The article discusses coping with COVID-19, a virus that continues to affect daily life. It suggests that by adopting a mindset of living with and working around the virus, people can be more successful. Improving internet communications, developing better study subjects, and reskilling individuals to cope with the new order of employment are key to moving forward. The article also highlights the importance of addressing mental health concerns, such as isolation and human disconnection, during the pandemic. Ultimately, the goal is to adapt to the new normal and prepare for a future that will likely be shaped by the virus.

site_title: Next Big Thing - Watches With Steel Bracelets
summary: Luxury watch brands are embracing stainless steel bracelets in their latest designs, following California's ban on sales of leather-strapped watches. Brands such as H Moser & Cie, A Lange & Sohne, Chopard, Bell & Ross, and Laurent Ferrier have introduced new steel watches with integrated bracelets, showcasing a new direction for the industry. The watches range in price from $7,300 to $172,000, highlighting the trend towards sustainable and high-end designs.

site_title: Lowering the barrier to a low-carbon energy future
summary: Scientists estimate that 8% of total emissions avoided in 2020 due to the pandemic were achieved at a high economic cost. To avoid the worst effects of global warming, all economic sectors must reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The UN estimates that the process must start within the next 10 years. Global consumption of renewables has grown by double digits annually for the past decade, and the capacity of renewable energy has more than doubled, leading to a virtuous cycle of investment, technology improvement, and lower prices. However, more solutions are needed to accelerate the transition to a low-carbon energy future.

site_title: Singapore property agents urged to be ethical, give accurate advice
summary: Singapore's property agents have been urged by Minister of State Tan Kiat How to be ethical, build trust with consumers, and provide accurate advice. The industry is also exploring new ways to market properties and reach out to consumers online. A best-practice guide for consumer ratings of agents has been launched, recommending attributes such as providing services above and beyond client expectations, being open, honest, and reliable, and having negotiation skills. The guide aims to ensure fair and credible comparisons of agent ratings, and agencies can sign an Estate Agents Pledge to demonstrate their commitment to professionalism and trusted service.

images.alt_text: "We must not allow the unprofessional and unethical conduct of a small handful to tarnish the overall image of the industry," Mr Tan said.

site_title: PE veteran behind LVMH arm launches own US$500m Asia fund
summary: Private equity veteran Ravi Thakran has launched a US$500 million growth fund, GCC Asia, targeting younger companies in South-east Asia, India, and the Middle East with at least US$100 million in revenue and a positive Ebitda of US$10 million. The fund will focus on companies that are digitally savvy and socially responsible, reflecting the consumption patterns of tomorrow. Thakran also plans to launch a second fund, Asia 3.0, with a targeted war chest of US$1 billion to US$1.5 billion, focusing on mature companies in Japan, China, and Australia.

site_title: A Touch Of Elegance
summary: Tissot, a Swiss watch brand, has been creating timepieces specifically for women since the launch of its family business by Charles-Félicien Tissot and his son Charles-Émile. The T-Touch Lady Solar watch, a solar-powered model with a mother-of-pearl dial, is one of the brand's offerings. Additionally, Hublot's Big Bang Millennial Pink and Zenith's Defy 21 Pink Edition, both limited edition watches, have been designed with feminine touches, while also being designed for the outdoors. These watches showcase the brands' focus on creating special timepieces for women.

site_title: Thai PM orders withdrawal of state of emergency
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha ordered the withdrawal of the state of emergency in Bangkok, allowing authorities to use existing laws to manage protests. The move follows a de-escalation in the situation, despite hundreds of protesters gathering in various locations. The state of emergency, which barred large gatherings, was imposed a week ago in response to pro-democracy protesters calling for the resignation of his government and monarchy reform. The main organisers did not stage formal rallies on Thursday, but the move is seen as a step towards pacifying the protesters.

site_title: Nvidia deal for Arm will drive computing power growth says SoftBank's Son
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son stated that Nvidia's acquisition of chip designer Arm will drive growth in computing power. He believes artificial intelligence will transform society and reiterated his support for AI at a virtual summit. Son's comments come after the US$40 billion deal, part of SoftBank's asset sales, raised concerns about Arm's neutrality in the industry. Son is expected to discuss future investment plans at SoftBank World, where he will meet with Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang.

site_title: Restaurants come back from the brink
summary: Singapore's F&B industry has seen a strong rebound from the COVID-19 pandemic, with luxury dining and eateries with a loyal following performing well. However, smaller restaurants and those that previously relied on large-scale corporate events are still struggling. Industry observers note that the recovery is uneven, with some sectors experiencing more growth than others. Restaurants are finding success with promotions, steady bookings, and adapting to social distancing measures. The government's support schemes, such as rental rebates and wage support, have been instrumental in helping the industry recover. Despite the progress, many restaurants still expect to operate at a loss or break even, with challenges ahead including manpower and no-shows.

site_title: Singapore shares flat following overnight retreat on Wall Street
summary: Singapore's stocks ended flat on Thursday, following overnight declines on Wall Street due to uncertainties surrounding the US presidential election and potential fiscal stimulus packages. The Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 2,528.41 points, with more decliners than advancers. Investors are suffering from "stimulus talk exhaustion," with some opting for the sidelines, according to AxiCorp's chief market strategist.

site_title: Navigating to a sustainable and low-carbon future
summary: Southeast Asia is urged to transition to a low-carbon future to avoid the devastation of climate change. The region has significant renewable energy potential, with countries utilizing only a quarter of their potential for cost-effective renewable power generation. By 2030, over half of Asean's electricity capacity could be renewables-based. Major banks and investors are turning away from traditional energy sources, such as coal, and investing in clean technology and renewables. The transition is capital-intensive, but could deliver significant savings and boost regional GDP by 3%. Asean countries are expected to come together to discuss the optimal path to recovery and prosperity at the Singapore International Energy Week.

site_title: Google antitrust fight pushes low-key CEO into line of fire
summary: The US Justice Department has accused Google of being a "monopoly gatekeeper of the Internet" using anticompetitive tactics to protect its dominant hold over web search and search advertising. This marks the first existential crisis in Google's 22-year history, following Sundar Pichai's succession as CEO. The company faces antitrust regulators on five continents and has generated vast profits during the recession, pandemic, and earlier investigations. Google's financial packages for executives accused of misconduct and fraying office culture also pose challenges for Pichai.

site_title: The new Kia Sorento has a tricky job to do
summary: Kia's new Sorento SUV aims to elevate its reputation from budget motoring to premium SUVs. The seven-seat model boasts a 35mm increased wheelbase, providing more interior room, and features advanced technology, including a 12.3-inch digital display and virtual blind spot monitor. Safety features such as radar cruise control, forward collision detection, and mitigation are standard in higher trims, setting the Sorento apart from mainstream competitors and luxury brands. With prices starting at S$157,999, Kia seeks to move beyond its budget image and compete with premium SUVs.

site_title: Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy to freeze development of SpaceJet regional jet
summary: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries plans to freeze development of its Spacejet regional jet due to the coronavirus pandemic's financial impact on the aerospace industry. The company had already delayed the project six times and reduced its development budget. Despite previous commitments, the decision marks a significant setback for Japan's efforts to establish itself as a commercial passenger jet maker. The pandemic's effects on Japan's largest carrier, ANA Holdings, also impacted the project's timeline. The freeze will be announced alongside a medium-term business plan on October 30.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to pay nearly US$3b to settle charges over 1MDB saga
summary: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay nearly US$3 billion to settle charges related to its role in the 1MDB corruption scandal. The bank's Malaysia unit has pleaded guilty to violating foreign bribery laws, and Goldman has been fined US$2.3 billion with US$600 million in disgorgement. The settlement follows a US$3.9 billion agreement with Malaysia in July and marks a significant step in resolving the scandal that has damaged the bank's reputation.

images.alt_text: Goldman has been investigated by regulators in at least 14 countries for what its leadership did and did not know about the transactions.

site_title: MAS bans ex-BSI banker from financial services over US$5m 'secret profits' tied to 1MDB
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has banned Kevin Michael Swampillai, a former BSI Bank Singapore executive, from any regulated activity due to his role in 1MDB's US$5 million 'secret profits'. Swampillai assisted 1MDB from 2012 to 2013, channeling funds without bank authorization and making misrepresentations to auditors. He is now permanently prohibited from performing regulated activities, managing, directing, or becoming a substantial shareholder of any capital market and financial advisory services firm. The ban was issued following an investigation by the MAS.

images.alt_text: MAS said Mr Swampillai made misrepresentations to 1MDB's auditors to try to "improperly influence" the outcome of an audit.

site_title: Singapore property agents urged to give accurate advice; new guide on ratings launched
summary: Singapore property agents are urged to provide accurate and ethical advice, build trust with consumers, and consider the overall economic outlook. A new guide on consumer ratings of property agents has been launched, recommending best practices for rating agents on online platforms. The guide aims to ensure fair and credible comparisons of agent ratings, allowing consumers to find suitable agents when searching online. The industry is also encouraged to adopt the Estate Agents Pledge to raise professionalism and deliver trusted service.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations and Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran warned that inward-looking policies will cause long-term harm to growth opportunities and living standards. A Singaporean, Sun Weiyeh, was charged with acts likely to defraud fund investors. The government announced 1,000 traineeships and attachments for the maritime sector. A poll found Singapore workers feel an urgent need to reskill and upskill due to the tight job market. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's S$759.7m preferential offering was fully subscribed, and ISCA recommended practices for auditor independence in non-assurance services.

site_title: Still Navigating To New Horizons
summary: The IWC Portugieser, first introduced in 1939, has remained largely unchanged over the years, retaining its classic design. Despite being refreshed for 2020, minimal changes have been made, with the watches maintaining their timeless appeal. The Portugieser's enduring success is attributed to its iconic status, with the brand opting not to alter a formula that isn't broken.

site_title: Hong Kong regulator fines Goldman Sachs US$350m over 1MDB scandal
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission fined Goldman Sachs' Asia unit US$350 million over its role in the 1MDB Malaysian bribery scandal.
