summary: City Developments director Kwek Leng Peck, 64, has quit the company after over 30 years, citing disagreements with the board and management over investments in a Chinese property group and the management of its British hotel arm. This marks a rare departure from the company, which has been in operation for over 50 years.

site_title: US dollar hits lowest in more than six weeks
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest in over six weeks, dropping 0.3% against a basket of currencies, as President Donald Trump's comments raised hopes for a large fiscal stimulus package. The dollar's decline boosted long-term inflation expectations for the US and led to gains in riskier currencies such as the New Zealand and Australian dollars. The Japanese yen and Canadian dollar also rose, while the euro and Chinese yuan surged to one-month highs.

site_title: Gold gains on weaker dollar, hopes of US stimulus deal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,918.56 per ounce on Wednesday, driven by optimism over a US stimulus deal and a weaker dollar. The White House and Democrats reached a closer agreement on a pre-election coronavirus relief package, lifting appetite for equities and boosting gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation. Spot gold hit a one-week high, and analysts predict prices may reach $2,000 and above by end-2020 due to a accommodative monetary and fiscal policy environment.

site_title: Strongest yuan in two years tests China's tolerance for gains
summary: China's yuan reached its strongest level in two years, climbing 0.5% to its highest since July 2018, despite the People's Bank of China setting its daily reference rate weaker than expected. The offshore yuan has been stronger than its onshore counterpart for the longest stretch in over a year, with traders predicting further gains if the US Democrats win the upcoming election. The government may need to take more drastic measures to curb the yuan's rally, with analysts warning that the market has become overly complacent and Beijing may consider relaxing capital controls to allow more outflows.

site_title: Oil prices slip as US inventory build-up stokes fears of supply glut
summary: Oil prices declined on Wednesday as a surprise US crude inventory build-up raised concerns about a global supply glut, while the resurgence of Covid-19 cases worldwide fueled fears of a stalled oil demand recovery. US crude inventories rose 584,000 barrels to 490.6 million, surpassing analysts' expectations for a draw. Oil prices slipped 1.16% and 1.34% for Brent crude and WTI futures, respectively, amid concerns about Opec+ production cuts and a potential economic stimulus from the US coronavirus aid bill.

site_title: Travel operators will face a reckoning like the banks did
summary: Regulators are considering forcing travel operators to keep customer prepayments in a ring-fenced trust account until customers return, a move similar to the UK banking system post-2008 financial crisis. This would prevent companies from spending customer money before the trip and ensure it's protected. However, the industry is concerned about the increased cash requirements and potential impact on struggling suppliers. Analysts estimate that setting up trust accounts could cost travel companies billions of euros, and some companies have already expressed concerns about the financial impact.

site_title: British banks step up calls to BOE to end dividend restrictions
summary: British banks are urging the Bank of England to lift its dividend restrictions, citing difficulties in raising capital from investors if the ban remains in place. Several major banks, including Standard Chartered, NatWest, and Barclays, have expressed concerns that the restrictions will hinder their ability to return excess capital to shareholders. The restrictions, imposed in March, have added to the pressure on bank shares, which have halved this year due to the pandemic and provisions for bad loans. The Bank of England has warned of weaknesses in British banks' ability to estimate loan losses, making a change to the guidance unlikely.

site_title: Umno's expression of support a boost for Muhyiddin's leadership
summary: Malaysia's United Malays National Organization (Umno) party expressed support for Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's leadership, announcing a "political ceasefire" and backing the government's efforts to manage the pandemic and boost economic growth. The move comes after Umno threatened to pull out unless it gets better terms, putting pressure on Muhyiddin to shore up his unstable government or call a snap election. The support is seen as a boost to Muhyiddin's leadership, but his government must continue to "tread gingerly" with Umno to preserve his premiership.

site_title: UK borrowing beats forecasts, debt highest since 1960
summary: The UK's government borrowing in the first half of the financial year exceeded forecasts, reaching £36.1 billion in September, with total public debt surpassing £2 trillion, its highest since 1960. The increased borrowing was driven by a surge in coronavirus-related spending and a fall in tax revenue. Despite this, borrowing to date is below the Office for Budget Responsibility's predicted record £372 billion by the end of the year. Economists predict further borrowing and the Bank of England may launch more bond purchases to support the economy.

site_title: BOJ urged to take swift action if recovery is delayed
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) board member Makoto Sakurai urged the central bank to take swift and appropriate action if Japan's economic recovery is delayed due to the coronavirus shock. A prolonged pandemic could push more companies under, threatening Japan's financial system and saddling commercial banks with bad loans. The BOJ is set to review its monetary settings next week, with likely cuts to growth and price forecasts, but Sakurai emphasized the need for swift action to mitigate potential risks to the banking system and economy.

site_title: Analysts divided over whether Tesla can achieve 2020 goal
summary: Tesla is set to report its third-quarter results, with analysts divided on whether the company can achieve its 2020 goal of delivering half-a-million vehicles. Despite a challenging global pandemic and economic environment, Tesla has stuck to its forecast. Analysts expect net income of $593 million and revenue of $8.4 billion, but some see a worsening macroeconomic environment ahead, making it tough for the company to hit its target. Tesla's sales in China, its largest market, remained flat, and vehicle registrations in California, its largest US market, dropped 13% compared to last year.

site_title: JC Penney rushes to finalise sale to lender, landlord group
summary: JC Penney has finalized a sale to its bankruptcy lenders and largest landlords, Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners, pending a master lease agreement between the parties by Monday. The lease agreement, considered one of the longest and most complex, must be finalized within a week. The deal could save over 60,000 jobs, according to court papers. A competing sale proposal from Aurelius Capital Management has also been made, which lenders claim is at a "much higher and better" price. The sale's future is now dependent on the completion of the lease agreement.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp's asset management arm, Keppel Capital, has launched the Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund IV with a target fund size of US$1 billion, achieving its first closing of US$295 million. ISEC Healthcare reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$2.58 million for the third quarter, driven by government grants and rental rebates. The company's revenue rose 3% to S$11.17 million, but management expects FY2020's financial performance to be lower compared to FY2019 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: STI gives up early gains to close 0.1% lower at 2,525.61
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.1% lower at 2,525.61, reversing morning gains, amid caution over US pre-election fiscal stimulus talks. Market analysts cite concerns over the US stimulus package dominating market focus, excluding other factors.

site_title: Shophouse blitz: Tiong Bahru, River Valley, Bugis assets up for grabs
summary: A slew of shophouses in Singapore's Tiong Bahru, River Valley, Bugis, and Telok Ayer areas have been put up for sale or transacted, marking a heating-up of the market after a pandemic-related lull. Freshly launched properties include these shophouses, signaling a return to activity after months of restrictions. The sales indicate a growing demand for properties in these areas, adding to the market's momentum.

images.alt_text: Three adjoining freehold shophouses (above) at 262, 264 and 266 River Valley Road carry a guide price of S$2,500 psf based on the total built-up area.
A row of four freehold conserved shophouses at 265-271 Outram Road (above) has an indicative price of at least S$50 million.
The shophouse at 96 Amoy Street has a price tag starting from S$18 million, or about S$3,871 psf based on a built-up area of 4,650 sq ft.

site_title: CDLHT sells Novotel Brisbane for A$67.9m to independent third-party buyer
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) sold its 4.5-star Novotel Brisbane hotel in Australia for A$67.9 million, a 6.9% premium to its original purchase price in 2010. The sale is seen as an opportunity to exit the market due to Brisbane's challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic and increased hotel supply. The divestment will strengthen CDLHT's balance sheet and allow for better financial flexibility. The sale price is at a 7% discount to the property's book value as of 2019.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's distributable income up 18.5% in Q3
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit reported a 18.5% increase in distributable income to US$14.7 million in Q3, driven by a 13.5% rise in gross revenue to US$34.5 million and a 10.8% increase in net property income to US$20.5 million.

site_title: GM debuts electric Hummer pickup
summary: General Motors (GM) unveiled its electric Hummer pickup truck, spearheading the automaker's push into the electric-vehicle market. The 2022 model-year truck will have a starting price of $80,000 and a range of 350 miles when fully charged. Production is set to start in the fall of 2021, with top-of-the-line models initially available, followed by a wider range of plug-in models by 2023. The GMC Hummer aims to retain GM's traditional strength in pickups and capture demand for EV pickups ahead of competitors.

site_title: Debunking a myth behind secure, affordable, sustainable energy
summary: Singapore ranks 39th globally in grid sustainability, according to the World Economic Forum's Global Energy Architecture Performance Index Report. While the country has made progress through consistent investment and innovation, it must continue to adapt and expand its power grid to meet future energy demands. Grids are not one-time infrastructure investments, but rather living networks that must evolve to accommodate changing technology and consumer needs. The goal is to create a "smarter" grid that can effectively respond to rapidly changing energy demands.

site_title: President, lawmakers and wolves: What Americans will be voting for on Nov 3
summary: US voters will choose between President Donald Trump and Democratic challenger Joe Biden on November 3, with millions also voting for congressional representatives, governors, and state-level officials. Control of Congress and the Senate could determine federal power, and voters will also decide on various initiatives, including police reform measures and local elections. If Biden wins, Democrats will control all federal levers and state-level power. The outcome will also shape the country's direction on issues like labor laws and state-level reforms.

images.alt_text: On Nov 3, American voters will choose whether US President Donald Trump will go on to a second term or if his Democratic challenger Joe Biden will take the helm at the White House for the next four years.

site_title: Home stretch - and Trump is on a wing and a prayer
summary: US President Donald Trump is facing a tough home stretch in the presidential election, with polls showing Democratic candidate Joe Biden maintaining a comfortable lead. Trump has been criticized for his handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and economic recession, and his campaign has struggled to make significant gains. Despite a tight race in Florida, Trump's chances of winning key battleground states appear slim, and his personal attacks on Biden are unlikely to change the political reality. With just days left in the campaign, Trump's options seem limited to a "political miracle."

site_title: Honda reaches US$5m defective air bag settlement with Arizona
summary: Honda Motor's US units have reached a $5 million settlement with Arizona over defective Takata air bag systems. The settlement includes $1.65 million in restitution, $2.13 million for repair incentives, $750,000 for consumer outreach, and $500,000 for the state. This follows an $85 million settlement with other US states. Faulty air bags have been linked to at least 15 US deaths in Honda vehicles.

site_title: Social media-Trump wars are really about something else
summary: Outrage over the Trump era and social media platforms is actually about government power and accountability. Despite institutions failing to check President Trump's rise to power, people are angry about the absence of consequences. Social media companies, however, are reluctant to take responsibility for enforcing accountability. The absence of government oversight has created a power vacuum, leading to demands for platforms to impose consequences.

site_title: Offices resort to sensors in futile attempts to keep workers apart
summary: Millions of workers worldwide have returned to offices with new pandemic protocols, but temperature checks and plexiglass barriers are ineffective in preventing social distancing. According to VergeSense, 60% of interactions among North American workers violate the CDC's six-foot distancing guidelines, and even higher shares in Asia. Companies are using sensors, data analytics, and AI to develop plans, but changing human behavior is difficult. Some employers are forcing workers back to the office despite rising infection rates, and many are now allowing employees to work from home until mid-2021.

site_title: Organic growth to drive UBS' goal of US$3b Asia-Pac profit
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, is on track to reach its goal of US$3 billion in full-year earnings from its Asia-Pacific operations, driven by strong organic growth. The bank's Asia-Pacific region posted a 92% jump in nine-month profit before tax to US$1.8 billion, with assets under management reaching US$500 billion. UBS Asia-Pacific president Edmund Koh attributed the growth to a rising Asia and advised clients to plan for a new normal post-Covid, with some industries expected to grow strongly while others need more time to recover.

site_title: UK's HS1 becomes the country's first renewable-powered railway
summary: The UK's HS1 railway has become the country's first train line to run entirely on renewable energy, powered by wind and solar sources. The operating company confirmed that all energy used by its trains and stations comes from renewable sources, meeting the UK's goal of a net zero carbon transport system by 2050. This milestone is part of HS1's commitment to decarbonizing its network, with UK rail minister Chris Heaton-Harris praising the move as a significant step towards a greener and cleaner railway.

site_title: CCT Q3 DPU falls 9.1% to S$0.02; expected to delist on Nov 3
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported a 9.1% fall in third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2 Singapore cents, down from 2.2 Singapore cents last year. Gross revenue declined 8.7% to S$94.7 million, primarily due to asset enhancement works and lower occupancies in Singapore. The trust expects to delist on Nov 3 and will pay a clean-up distribution by Nov 30. CCT's manager also announced the expansion of its investment mandate to include commercial properties in Singapore.

site_title: Oh, what a cool war! The soft power of the Quad
summary: The Quad, a military-economic alliance of the US, India, Japan, and Australia, aims to create a new Asian order. However, it has been criticized for overlooking cultural and economic diplomacy. Foreign ministers emphasized the importance of working with like-minded partners beyond Asean, with Japan suggesting the inclusion of European countries. South Korea has consulted with the Quad, but remains apprehensive about committing to the alliance. The alliance's potential for resolving regional conflicts and promoting stability is being questioned, prompting comparisons to the 1964 Cold War movie "Dr Strangelove".

site_title: HSBC to cut up to 300 jobs in UK commercial banking overhaul
summary: HSBC is restructuring its UK commercial banking business, resulting in around 300 job losses, according to a source. The move is part of the bank's strategy to improve profits, as economic forecasts indicate a challenging time ahead. The commercial banking unit, which provides loans and services to small and medium-sized businesses, has struggled to improve revenues due to rising competition and low interest rates. The restructuring is in line with the bank's February announcement to cut around 35,000 jobs.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant receives China approval for IPO in Shanghai
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Group has received approval from China's securities watchdog to list on Shanghai's STAR market, clearing a major hurdle for its US$35 billion initial public offering (IPO). The approval comes after Ant won earlier approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange. Ant will issue up to 1.67 billion shares in China, representing 5.5% of total outstanding shares post-IPO, and plans to gauge investor demand for its Hong Kong offering on October 29. The IPO could be the largest ever, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record US$29 billion sale last year.

site_title: I4.0 solutions key for businesses to stay ahead amid global uncertainty
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore (ESG) has facilitated over 1,300 Industry 4.0 projects for manufacturing businesses, a 65% increase from the same period last year. The top areas of focus include tech deployment, automation, and digitalization. ESG deputy chief executive Ted Tan emphasized the importance of investing in I4.0 infrastructure and expertise to future-proof businesses in the face of global uncertainty. Companies such as Lingjack, which saw efficiency gains of up to 40% through automation, are benefiting from these initiatives, with some SMEs also forming partnerships to accelerate transformation.

site_title: Venture Corp's share price hits 52-week high
summary: Venture Corp's share price hit a 52-week high of S$21.21 on Wednesday morning, up 1.6% from the previous day's close. Analysts at RHB upgraded the counter to "buy" with a higher target price of S$22.60, citing a brighter outlook and strong demand for the company's essential goods, particularly ventilators and medical equipment. Despite lower revenues, Venture is expected to maintain margins and tap into growing diversification of customers, with a higher FY21F price-to-earnings ratio of 19 times.

site_title: Australian retail sales drop in Sept as household goods give back gains
summary: Australian retail sales declined 1.5% in September, marking the first back-to-back monthly drop this year, as demand eased in industries such as food and household goods. All states and territories except the Northern Territory fell during the month. Sales of clothing, footwear, and personal accessories also decreased. The decline is attributed to easing demand, following the easing of COVID-19 restrictions.

site_title: China forecasts CNY pork supplies to be 30% higher
summary: China forecasts a 30% increase in pork supplies for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday, driven by efforts to rebuild a depleted hog herd. Pig production, large pork imports, and changes in consumer demand are expected to boost supplies. The country has built 12,500 new large-scale pig farms and restarted over 13,000 empty farms, with pig stocks reaching 84% of 2017 levels. This is expected to reduce pork prices, which have fallen for seven consecutive weeks, to 50.56 yuan (S$10.3) per kg.

site_title: GM 'going forward' with Nikola partnership talks on trucks
summary: General Motors is moving forward with its partnership talks with Nikola Corp, a startup that aims to produce electric and fuel-cell-powered trucks. GM plans to share its hydrogen-fuel-cell technology with Nikola, which will use it in both a pickup and big-rig trucks. The deal would give GM an 11% stake in Nikola and allow the startup to manufacture the Badger pickup truck, initially battery-electric and eventually fuel-cell powered. The partnership is seen as a key move by GM to expand its presence in the electric truck market.

site_title: Scientists find secret to 'uncrushable' bug's strength
summary: Scientists have discovered a secret to the "uncrushable" ironclad beetle's strength, finding a jigsaw-like mechanism in its exoskeleton that allows it to withstand forces up to 39,000 times its own body weight. The beetle's crush-resistant forewings, called elytra, are made up of interlocked joints and a laminated microstructure that provide enhanced strength and toughness. The discovery could have implications for engineering and robotics, and may even challenge cockroaches as models of insect indestructibility.

site_title: Purdue Pharma to pay US$8b to settle US opioid probe
summary: Purdue Pharma has agreed to a $8.3 billion settlement with the US Justice Department to resolve federal probes into the marketing of OxyContin, a painkiller linked to the opioid epidemic. The company's owners, the Sackler family, will pay $225 million. This settlement is part of Purdue's effort to move past claims of contributing to the public health crisis, with thousands of civil claims still pending. The company faces a separate $10 billion settlement proposal. The US Justice Department seeks reimbursement for tax dollars spent addressing the crisis, which has led to over 200,000 overdose deaths.

site_title: Time to spoil yourself
summary: Luxury watch brands continued to release novelties in the second half of 2020, despite major watch fairs being cancelled due to COVID-19. Notable releases include Rolex's Oyster Perpetual collection with funky colors, Omega's updated Seamaster watches, and Patek Philippe's limited-edition commemorative timepiece. Other brands, such as Vacheron Constantin, Franck Muller, and Jaeger-LeCoultre, also celebrated various events and milestones. These releases offer the perfect opportunity to spoil oneself or a loved one with a new timepiece, especially as the festive season approaches.

site_title: US: Wall Street muted with eyes on stimulus
summary: US stocks opened muted on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.13% to 28,270.66, and the S&P 500 opening 0.09% lower at 3,439.91. Investors await signs of a coronavirus aid package to support the economic recovery, which could impact the market. The Nasdaq Composite gained 0.12% to 11,530.39. The muted market follows recent record highs and ongoing trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Thai protesters give PM Prayuth three-day deadline to quit
summary: Thai protesters have set a three-day deadline for Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha to resign, citing demands for his removal and a new constitution. The protesters, who have been marching since July, also seek reforms to curb the powers of King Maha Vajiralongkorn. If Prayuth fails to resign within the deadline, protesters promise to take further action, indicating the ongoing tensions in Thai politics.

site_title: Japan plans hub for foreign brokers to file in English
summary: Japan is planning to create a hub where foreign brokers can file regulatory paperwork in English, aiming to attract banks and brokerages away from Hong Kong and other global financial centers. The hub, expected to start operating next spring, will offer English-language filing and simplify the regulatory process. This move is part of Japan's efforts to boost Tokyo's status as a global financial center, following concerns about Hong Kong's regulatory environment due to China's crackdown. The hub is seen as a step towards making Japan more inviting for overseas financiers.

site_title: EU reopens borders to Singapore visitors
summary: The European Union has reopened its borders to travelers from Singapore, marking the first changes to the "white list" of countries allowed to visit the bloc in over two months. The decision comes amid a resurgence in coronavirus cases in Europe, and Singapore's improved virus trends. The US and other countries remain blacklisted. The EU has also removed Canada, Tunisia, and Georgia from the list, bringing the total number of countries allowed to visit to nine: Australia, China, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Uruguay, and Singapore.

site_title: China will balance need for stabilising growth and preventing risks: central bank governor
summary: China's central bank governor Yi Gang said the country will balance economic growth and risk prevention, allowing debt to temporarily rise to support the coronavirus-hit economy. China's macro leverage ratio is expected to stabilize next year as the economy expands. Bank lending reached 16.26 trillion yuan in the first nine months, beating a previous peak. The central bank aims to smooth out fluctuations in the macro leverage ratio and keep it on a reasonable track. China's GDP is expected to grow 2% this year, making it the only major economy to report growth in 2020.

site_title: Prada appoints diversity chief in bid to become more inclusive
summary: Prada appoints Malika Savell as its chief diversity, equity and inclusion officer for North America, aiming to increase inclusivity. This move follows criticism of the company's past products and advertisements deemed racist. Savell, previously at LVMH, will develop policies for diverse representation across the group, working closely with the Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Council. The appointment marks a step towards addressing representation issues in the fashion industry, where consumers are increasingly demanding more diverse and inclusive representation.

site_title: PayPal to allow cryptocurrency buying, selling and shopping on its network
summary: PayPal is allowing customers to buy, sell, and hold cryptocurrencies like bitcoin and ethereum on its network, starting with US account holders. The service, set to expand to Venmo and international markets in 2021, aims to encourage global use of virtual coins and prepare for potential central bank and corporate digital currencies. PayPal will settle cryptocurrency transactions using fiat currencies, and initially supports four cryptocurrencies. The company has secured a conditional cryptocurrency license from the New York State Department of Financial Services and partners with Paxos Trust Company to offer the service.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare's net profit up 47%
summary: ISEC Healthcare, a medical eye-care services provider, reported a 47% increase in net profit to S$2.58 million for the third quarter, driven by the absence of impairment loss and government grants. Revenue rose 3% to S$11.17 million, with the Malaysian eye centre contributing to the growth. No dividend was declared, as in the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 18.57 points lower at 1,492.40 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 8.476 billion lots worth RM5.945 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 758 to 375.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CDL director Kwek Leng Peck quit due to disagreements with the board and management over the management of its British hotel arm and investment in a Chinese firm. JTC and SBF launched an initiative to support over 300 companies in Industry 4.0 transformation. Singapore's shophouse market is experiencing a resurgence, with properties in River Valley and Bugis being sold. HSBC ranked Singapore as a frontrunner for sustainable infrastructure investment. Keppel Capital achieved its first closing of US$295m for the Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund IV. Mastercard, MatchMove, and Idemia will pilot a fingerprint biometric card in Asia.

site_title: STI gives up early gains to close 0.1% lower at 2,525.61
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.1% lower at 2,525.61, reversing morning gains, amid cautious market sentiment due to US pre-election fiscal stimulus talks. The market remained focused on US fiscal stimulus packages, with some analysts warning of potential corrections if negotiations or the US Senate disappoint. Local decliners outnumbered advancers 243 to 182, with glove makers and City Developments Limited among the biggest losers.

site_title: Mindset puts spotlight on mental health
summary: Jardines Mindset, a registered charity in Singapore, is working to raise awareness of mental health issues and provide support to those affected. The organization, backed by the Jardine Matheson Group, has run training centres and public education campaigns to help individuals with mental health issues find jobs and reintegrate into the community. The Company of Good Fellowship, a talent development programme, has also provided Ms. Colyn Chua, programme head at Jardines Mindset, with the tools and partnerships to strengthen the mental health sector in Singapore.

site_title: IMF cuts Asia's growth forecast, warns of pandemic-driven risks
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its growth forecast for Asia, citing a sharper-than-expected contraction in countries like India due to the coronavirus pandemic. The IMF expects Asia's economy to contract 2.2% this year, with India's economy shrinking 10.3% and China's economy growing 1.9%. While the IMF upgraded next year's growth forecast to 6.9%, it warns of sluggish and patchy recovery, with countries dependent on tourism taking a hard hit. The IMF also highlights risks such as a second wave of infections and escalating US tensions.

site_title: Mastercard, MatchMove, Idemia to pilot fingerprint biometric card in Asia
summary: Mastercard, MatchMove, and Idemia are collaborating to develop a fingerprint biometric card, F.CODE Easy, for in-store payments in Asia. The card, set to launch in Q4 this year, eliminates the need for PIN numbers or signatures, reducing public touch points. The biometric card, certified to International Organization for Standardization standards, stores biometric credentials on the card chip and harvests energy from payment terminals. This move aims to enhance the safety and security of contactless transactions, offering consumers more choice and greater security.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's distributable cash flow down 18.8% in Q3
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 18.8% drop in distributable cash flow (DCF) to S$45.2 million in Q3, mainly attributed to a 32.9% decline in its distribution and network sector. However, the energy sector saw a 15.7% increase to S$12.5 million. Ebitda rose 7% to S$83 million. The trust plans to focus on organic growth, acquisitions, and partnerships to drive defensive cash flows and revenues linked to inflation or GDP. Its net gearing stood at 33.7% as of Sept 30.

site_title: Snapchat co-founders share US$2.7b windfall
summary: Snapchat co-founders Evan Spiegel and Bobby Murphy saw their fortunes increase by $1.3 billion and $1.4 billion, respectively, after the company reported a 52% sales jump to $678.7 million in the third quarter. The surge in sales, driven by the coronavirus pandemic, led to a 25% stock price increase, taking Spiegel's net worth to $6.9 billion and Murphy's to $7.2 billion. This marks a significant windfall for the co-founders, who have already pocketed over $200 million from Snap stock sales this year.

site_title: MLT to acquire Brisbane warehouse for A$114m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) plans to acquire a Brisbane warehouse in Australia for A$114 million. The acquisition will expand MLT's portfolio to three properties in Brisbane and 13 in Australia, offering 347,287 sqm of leasable space. The property, Acacia Ridge Distribution Centre, is fully leased to established industry players with a weighted average lease expiry of 5.3 years, providing a stable income stream. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter of 2020/21 and will be funded by debt, generating an initial net property income yield of 4.9%.

site_title: EU says Britain has choices to make on Brexit
summary: The European Union's President Charles Michel stated that Britain has sovereign choices to make on Brexit, which will determine its future access to the EU's internal market. The EU and Britain are at an impasse in trade negotiations, with the bloc seeking continued access to UK fishing waters and the UK wanting access to the EU's market. Michel warned that a deal is possible before the end of the year, but emphasized that the EU is ready to negotiate and that the UK's decision will determine its future relationship with the EU.

images.alt_text: Britain has sovereign choices to make on Brexit and they will determine its future access to the European Union's (EU) internal market, the chairman of the bloc's leaders said on Wednesday, stressing it was now up to London to break an impasse in trade negotiations.

site_title: CDL director Kwek Leng Peck quits due to disagreements with board, management
summary: CDL director Kwek Leng Peck, a veteran of over three decades, has resigned citing disagreements with the board and management over investments in Chinese real estate firm Sincere Property Group and the management of London-based Millennium & Copthorne Hotels. He also had reservations about the group's approach in managing M&C. CDL has confirmed its investments into Sincere total around S$1.9 billion, and is now expected to divest assets to lighten the debt load.

site_title: UBS expects further growth from a rising Asia
summary: UBS, the world's largest wealth manager, expects further growth from its Asia-Pacific operations, with full-year earnings projected to hit US$2 billion by the end of 2020. The bank's Asia-Pacific region posted a 92% jump in nine-month profit before tax to US$1.8 billion, driven by strong organic growth from a rising Asia. Assets under management in the global wealth-management segment reached US$500 billion, with the Asia wealth franchise aiming for an all-time record. UBS president Edmund Koh notes that industries like healthcare and tech will grow strongly, while hospitality and others may need more time to recover.

site_title: Key party in Malaysia's ruling alliance urges 'ceasefire' amid political turmoil
summary: Malaysia's ruling alliance party, led by Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, has urged a "political ceasefire" amid a surge in coronavirus infections and a challenge from opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. The party, United Malays National Organisation (Umno), agreed to support Muhyiddin's government by focusing on fighting the virus and addressing economic uncertainty. This comes after Umno threatened to withdraw support, and amid public anger over graft, which led to its defeat in the 2018 general election. A possible Cabinet reshuffle is being considered to add more Umno members to the government.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faces a challenge from opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, who met Malaysia's king last week in a bid to prove he has majority support from lawmakers, including administration defectors, to form a new government.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.75% on Wednesday, driven by hopes of a US stimulus agreement. The Hang Seng Index reached 24,754.42, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.09%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 1.10%. The gains come as investors await a potential US-EU trade deal, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip as healthcare, real estate sectors weigh
summary: European stocks slipped 0.3% as the healthcare and real estate sectors fell, outweighing gains from consumer giant Nestle and telecoms equipment maker Ericsson. Nestle rose 0.6% on positive quarterly results, while Ericsson jumped 7.2% after beating earnings estimates. Economically sensitive sectors like banks and automakers rose as US lawmakers moved closer to a new coronavirus relief package. Despite this, the pan-European Stoxx 600 remained in the red, weighed down by losses in the healthcare and real estate sectors.

site_title: Nasdaq profit surges 76% on non-trading business strength
summary: Nasdaq reported a 76% surge in third-quarter profit, driven by strength in non-trading businesses and increased trading volumes. Net income rose to $264 million, or $1.58 per share, from $150 million, or 90 cents per share, last year. Revenue from information services increased 20% to $238 million, while market services revenue jumped 39% to $958 million. Excluding transaction-based expenses, revenue rose 13% to $715 million.

site_title: Japan's ANA likely to suffer 530b yen net loss this year: Kyodo
summary: ANA Holdings, Japan's largest airline, is expected to suffer a net loss of approximately 530 billion yen (S$6.81 billion) for the fiscal year ending in March due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on air travel demand. ANA plans to cut its wide-body aircraft fleet by half as part of its restructuring plans. The airline has turned to loans and a government tourism campaign to weather the slump, and may use accounting rules to avoid aircraft writedowns. ANA's earnings forecast remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Japanese airline operator ANA Holdings is expected to suffer a net loss of around 530 billion yen (S$6.81 billion) for the fiscal year ending in March after the Covid-19 pandemic battered demand for travel, Kyodo News reported on Wednesday.

site_title: Tiong Bahru row of freehold shophouses goes on the market for at least S$50m
summary: A row of four freehold conserved shophouses near the Tiong Bahru Market in Singapore will be launched for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise, with an indicative price of at least S$50 million. The properties, located on Outram Road, follow recent shophouse sales in the market, which have seen prices rise as demand continues to grow. The sale is expected to attract significant interest, given the area's popularity and limited supply of freehold properties.

site_title: COEs end mostly higher on eve of new quota
summary: COE certificates ended mostly higher in the latest tender, with prices rising due to a smaller supply of certificates in the new quota starting next month. COE prices for cars up to 1,600cc increased to S$37,334, while commercial vehicle COE rose to S$33,778. The motorcycle premium dropped to S$7,300. Industry watchers attribute the rise in COE prices to the smaller supply, while a larger supply in other categories may explain the dip in the premium for the Open category. The new quota starts in November.

site_title: Nestle raises full-year guidance after Q3 sales beats poll
summary: Nestle raised its full-year guidance for organic sales growth to around 3% after beating analysts' expectations with a 4.9% growth in the third quarter. The company's pet food and health businesses drove growth, while food sales to restaurants and cafes slumped. For the first nine months, Nestle's organic sales grew 3.5%, exceeding the 2.8% average estimate. The company had previously expected 2-3% growth. Sales in the Americas were the strongest, while Asia was only slightly positive.

site_title: Landlords in SEA rethinking operations and strategies
summary: Landlords in Southeast Asia are rethinking their operations and strategies due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has accelerated trends in consumer behavior. Retail sales declined double digits initially, but online shopping has seen explosive growth, with platforms like Shopee Thailand and e-commerce platforms from landlords like CapitaLand offering convenient access to daily necessities. Landlords are now focusing on technology to complement sales at their malls, with some partnering with online retailers or launching their own e-commerce platforms. This shift is expected to continue, with Vietnam aiming for double-digit annual growth in e-commerce and the government targeting 10% of total retail sales to be online by 2025.

site_title: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's distributable income up 18.5% in Q3
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit posted distributable income of US$14.7 million in Q3, a 18.5% increase from the same period last year. Gross revenue rose 13.5% to US$34.5 million, while net property income increased 10.8% to US$20.5 million. The Reit's growth was attributed to new and expansion leases in tech hubs. The portfolio's committed occupancy stood at 92.8% and weighted lease average expiry was 3.9 years.

site_title: Council for Estate Agencies to have three new members from Oct 22
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) will have three new members effective October 22, including Lok Vi Ming, Ong Choon Fah, and Thomas Tan. Michael Tan, current executive director, will step down at the end of his term on October 21.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for third straight day on US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose for the third consecutive day, driven by renewed hopes for US stimulus. The benchmark Kospi closed up 0.53% at 2,370.86, following a two-day winning streak. Despite sluggish preliminary trade data and a rise in coronavirus infections, investors remained optimistic due to the White House and Democrats' closer agreement on a new coronavirus relief package. The won and bond yields also rose, with foreign investors net buyers of 6.4 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: UK budget deficit hits £208.5b amid calls for more aid
summary: The UK budget deficit reached £208.5 billion in the first six months of the fiscal year, driven by pandemic-related costs. Chancellor Rishi Sunak's job support plan has been scaled back, with local leaders calling for more aid amid a resurgence in the virus. The government's debt has risen to 103.5% of GDP, the highest since 1960, but borrowing costs remain low due to Bank of England bond-buying. The government is cutting its spending review period to one year, sparking uncertainty about future economic support.

site_title: JTC, SBF launch initiative to help firms embark on Industry 4.0 transformation
summary: JTC and the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) launched the JTC-SBF Industry Transformation Initiative to support over 300 SMEs in Industry 4.0 transformation over the next two years. The initiative aims to provide workshops, capability-building initiatives, and technology partnerships to help manufacturers, particularly SMEs, remain globally competitive and create quality jobs. The collaboration will leverage the combined network of companies from both organizations to access Industry 4.0 resources and support Singapore's manufacturing sector, which contributes over 22% to the country's nominal GDP.

site_title: Thailand welcomes tourists back as Bangkok protests heat up
summary: Thailand welcomed its first group of tourists from China since April 2020, as commercial flights resumed. Thirty-nine tourists from Shanghai arrived at Suvarnabhumi Airport, wearing protective gear and undergoing disinfection. The arrivals come amid escalating street demonstrations in Bangkok, but the tourists seemed undeterred. This marks a significant step in Thailand's efforts to revive its tourism industry.

site_title: Ericsson profit surged as Huawei ban offsets hit from pandemic
summary: Ericsson reported a 38% surge in third-quarter adjusted operating profit to 9 billion kronor (S$1.39 billion), beating analyst estimates. The company gained market share in China and Europe amid government restrictions on Huawei gear for 5G technology. Adjusted gross margin rose to 43.2%, its highest since 2006. Ericsson reiterated its sales targets and adjusted operating margin goals for 2020 and 2022, and expects to close its US wireless solutions provider CradlePoint purchase in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise on US stimulus optimism
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.31% to 23,639.46, driven by optimism over a potential US stimulus package ahead of the presidential election. The benchmark Nikkei and broader Topix indices also gained, with all but two sector sub-indices finishing higher. Analysts attributed the boost to rising US stock futures, which created a tailwind for the market. The news lifted sentiment in Asia and helped Wall Street finish higher overnight.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar rates rise as Ant IPO anticipation tightens liquidity
summary: Hong Kong dollar rates rose on Wednesday, with the two-week Interbank Offered Rate reaching a three-week high of 0.36387% due to anticipation of a record-breaking $35 billion initial public offering (IPO) by Ant Group. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority flooded the market with Hong Kong dollars to keep the currency from strengthening, but traders expect liquidity to tighten in the coming weeks. This has prompted the HKMA to sell HK$98 billion into the market in October to keep the currency below its upper limit of 7.75 per US dollar.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on lift from financial, energy stocks
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by gains in financial and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,191.80, following a 0.7% drop on Tuesday. Gains were attributed to hopes of a US stimulus package and the potential resumption of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine trial. Financial sub-index rose 1% due to gains in the "Big Four" banks, while the energy sector rose 1.3% on the back of Woodside Petroleum and Santos' gains.

site_title: Britain says London mayor 'bankrupted' the capital, demands cost cuts
summary: Britain is demanding cost cuts from London Mayor Sadiq Khan, who has requested a £5.7 billion bailout to keep the city's transport system running. The government is insisting on higher fares and revenue-raising mechanisms, such as increasing the congestion zone fee, in response. Khan has criticized the proposal, calling it "bankrupting" for the capital. The dispute highlights the financial challenges facing London during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Huawei, China firms are said to seek curbs on Nvidia's Arm deal
summary: China's top tech firms, including Huawei, have expressed concerns to regulators about Nvidia's proposed $40 billion acquisition of Arm Ltd, potentially jeopardizing the deal. The companies fear Nvidia may force Arm to cut ties with Chinese clients, threatening China's growing tech supremacy. China's State Administration for Market Regulation is likely to review the deal, potentially imposing conditions to preserve Arm's neutrality and separate its business from Nvidia. The review process may take up to 18 months to secure necessary approvals.

site_title: Asia: Markets lifted by stimulus optimism, vaccine hopes
summary: Asian markets rose on October 21, 2020, as optimism grew over US stimulus talks and vaccine hopes. US lawmakers are closing the gap on proposals, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi saying legislation could be passed before the November 3 election. Despite concerns over surging virus infections, markets lifted, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, and other Asian markets up, while Shanghai fell. Vaccine developments, including Moderna's potential emergency use approval, also boosted sentiment.

site_title: Credit Suisse teams up with AXA for digital app
summary: Credit Suisse has partnered with AXA to offer financial products through its new digital banking app, CSX, set to launch next week. The app aims to challenge fintechs like Revolut with free foreign transactions and digital wealth management. Insurance products will be available for some client groups in the first quarter of 2021. This partnership seeks to expand Credit Suisse's digital offerings and provide clients with more convenient access to financial products.

site_title: Who said Jack Ma's Ant IPO is a money maker?
summary: Savvy retail investors in Hong Kong are lining up for Ant Group's potential IPO, borrowing as much as they can from brokers to apply for shares. The process can be a "convoluted lottery," with 90% of investments covered by margin loans. Despite Ant Group's enviable sales growth and profitability, making money from a hot IPO is a delicate balance.

site_title: Singapore is frontrunner on sustainable infrastructure investment: HSBC survey
summary: Singapore is a frontrunner in sustainable infrastructure investment, according to a recent HSBC survey. Issuers and investors in the country see strong potential in sustainable areas such as smart cities, water and waste management, and electrifying transport. Nearly a quarter of Singaporean issuers expect to increase disclosures of environmental and social impacts, ahead of regional counterparts. The survey's findings come amid increasing evidence of the need to address climate change in South-east Asia, with Singapore poised to see increased international investment in its sustainable finance market.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB upgrades Venture to 'buy'; share price hits 52-week high
summary: Venture Corp's share price reached a 52-week high of S$21.21 after RHB upgraded the counter to "buy" with a higher target price of S$22.60. Analyst Jarick Seet expects the company to chart a steady recovery in the second half of the year, driven by fulfilling backlog orders and new product releases. Venture is diversifying its customers and has gained traction with new customers in industries such as life sciences and semiconductors, leading to more resilient margins and a higher FY21F price-to-earnings ratio.

site_title: Broker's take: Jefferies says Cathay Pacific restructuring removes key overhang
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways' restructuring plan removes a key overhang, allowing the airline to lower its cash burn by HK$500 million a month. The plan includes cutting 17% of existing jobs and ceasing operations of regional arm Cathay Dragon. Jefferies analysts say the airline's earnings recovery will depend on the opening of the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble, with passenger recovery dependent on this development. The restructuring was broadly in line with expectations, and Cathay Pacific shares rose 4% following the announcement.

site_title: Wizz Air CEO expects smaller airline industry after pandemic
summary: Wizz Air CEO Jozsef Varadi expects a smaller airline industry due to the pandemic, with many privately funded carriers likely to go under. Governments are throwing money at national carriers, but inconsistent travel restrictions have reduced demand. Wizz Air, however, aims to capitalize on cheap fares and direct routes, with a focus on central and eastern Europe. Varadi expects demand to snap back once the pandemic fades, and the airline is adding new Airbus aircraft to widen the gap in unit costs with the rest of the industry.

site_title: Japan's Suga opposes actions that boost tension in South China Sea
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has stated that Tokyo opposes actions that escalate tension in the South China Sea, emphasizing the importance of peaceful resolutions based on international law. Suga's visit to Vietnam and Indonesia aimed to bolster regional ties amid concerns about China's growing assertiveness. Japan is not seeking to create an Asian version of NATO to contain any specific country, but rather to defend its territory and interests. Suga also agreed to speed up talks on defense gear exports to Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: GIC-backed Aegea wins 580m reais sanitation auction in Brazil
summary: Aegea, a Brazilian sanitation company backed by Singapore's GIC, won a 580 million reais (S$140.3 million) auction to operate water and sewage services in Cariacica, Espirito Santo, for 423,000 people. Aegea offered the lowest fee among six competitors, securing the concession for 30 years. The company must invest in the project over the next 30 years, according to concession rules.

site_title: Singapore's shophouse comeback continues; River Valley, Bugis properties for sale
summary: Singapore's shophouse market continues to heat up, with several properties launched for sale or transacted this week. A four-storey conservation shophouse in River Valley was sold at S$12.2 million, while three adjoining freehold shophouses in the same area are offered for sale via an EOI exercise with a guide price of S$21.9 million. In Telok Ayer, a shophouse available for purchase by tender has a price tag starting from S$18 million. Meanwhile, shophouses in Bugis are up for grabs, with one at 5 Tan Quee Lan Street open for offers at an indicative price starting from S$15 million.

site_title: Gold gains on US stimulus deal optimism, weaker dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,917.76 per ounce as optimism over a US stimulus package deal pressured the US dollar and boosted the metal's appeal as an inflation hedge. The White House and Democrats moved closer to agreement on a fresh stimulus package, lifting risk appetite and sending the dollar index to a one-month low. The news also boosted silver, platinum, and palladium prices. Investors await more certainty on the US stimulus front before taking a position, but the pandemic has prompted unprecedented money printing and low-interest rates globally, putting gold on track for its best year in a decade.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were 12 new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 57,933, all of whom were imported and asymptomatic upon arrival. No community cases were reported. The cases included six new cases from worker's dormitories and six imported cases, with one each from Indonesia, India, the UAE, Germany, and two work pass holders. The number of unlinked community cases increased to two, with 57,804 patients having fully recovered from the disease.

site_title: United Airlines testing global health app on UK-US flight in effort to reopen borders
summary: United Airlines is testing a digital health pass on a UK-US flight as part of a global pilot program to establish a common standard for Covid-19 test results and vaccine records. The program, called CommonPass, aims to help reopen borders by allowing passengers to present verified QR codes instead of paper-based test results. If successful, the program could persuade governments to ease travel restrictions. The trial, which began on a United flight from London to Newark, will be observed by the US CDC and is part of a broader rollout targeted for January.

images.alt_text: United Airlines is set on Wednesday to test a digital health pass under a global pilot programme seeking to establish a common international standard for Covid-19 test results and eventually vaccine records that could help reopen borders.

site_title: Amazon extends work from home option till June
summary: Amazon has extended its work-from-home option for employees until June 30, 2021, citing the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. This move comes after the company reported that over 19,000 US frontline workers contracted the virus this year. Amazon had previously allowed remote work until January, and this extension is in line with other tech giants such as Google and Facebook, which have also extended their remote work policies. The company emphasizes its efforts to keep employees safe, including physical distancing, deep cleaning, and providing face coverings and hand sanitizers.

site_title: Macau casinos seen posting combined US$823m quarterly loss
summary: Macau casino operators are projected to post a combined quarterly loss of over US$823 million in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) for the quarter ended Sept 30, according to a Bloomberg survey. The gaming revenue has plummeted by at least 90% for six consecutive months due to the pandemic, but a slow recovery is underway as China lifted travel restrictions and formed a travel bubble with Macau. Mainland Chinese visitor arrivals during the Golden Week holiday were 84% lower compared to the previous year.

site_title: I4.0 solutions key to stay ahead
summary: Companies in Southeast Asia can stay ahead by adopting Industry 4.0 solutions, which can enhance workplace safety and resilience. Enterprise Singapore has worked with over 1,300 enterprises to upgrade and transform their businesses, with a focus on tech deployment and automation. The region's growing consumer market, productive labor force, and adequate infrastructure make it an ideal location for capturing diversification of supply chains. By partnering with experts and building an ecosystem, companies can future-proof their businesses and accelerate growth.

site_title: Malaysia allows 10% of workers under lockdown to work in office
summary: Malaysia has exempted up to 10% of workers in specific job categories, including accounting and finance, from its work-from-home order. These workers can work in office from 10am to 2pm, three days a week, without requiring travel exemption letters from employers. The exemption applies to Kuala Lumpur, Selangor, Sabah, Labuan, and Putrajaya, and is intended to support businesses in these areas.

site_title: As oil prices dive, Iraqi Kurds seek to diversify economy
summary: Iraq's Kurdish region, reliant on oil wealth, is diversifying its economy due to plummeting energy prices. Locals are returning to agriculture and other businesses to make ends meet, with vineyards and other crops becoming a new source of income. The region's bloated public sector has also been affected, with civil servants going without pay. This shift is seen as a necessary move to reduce dependence on oil and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Cathay Pacific shares rises over 3% after announcing restructuring plan
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways shares rose over 3% after announcing a restructuring plan, including 5,900 job cuts and the end of its regional Cathay Dragon brand, in response to the coronavirus pandemic's decline in demand. The airline's stock climbed to HK$5.92, surpassing the previous close, and compared to a 0.5% gain in the Hong Kong benchmark Hang Seng Index.

images.alt_text: Shares of Cathay Pacific Airways jumped more than 3 per cent after the Hong Kong flagship carrier announced a restructuring plan involving jobs cuts and a decision to end its regional Cathay Dragon brand.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at open, tracking modest gains on Wall Street; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at the open, tracking modest gains on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,535.16. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 41, driven by gains in banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Other active index counters, such as Frasers Centrepoint Trust and SATS, also rose. The US market saw gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq rising 0.4%, 0.5%, and 0.3% respectively, amid renewed hopes for a stimulus package.

site_title: Qualcomm, Mukesh Ambani's Jio team up to ready 5G for India
summary: Indian billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Jio Platforms is partnering with Qualcomm to develop 5G solutions in India, aiming to bring the high-speed network to the world's No 2 mobile market by users. Jio, which has over 400 million users, is working with Qualcomm to "fast track the development and roll out of indigenous 5G network infrastructure and services." The partnership allows Jio to develop its own 5G technology, potentially giving it an advantage over rivals and leaving it immune to political disputes over Chinese equipment vendors.

site_title: Protesters ready in case Trump refuses to accept election result
summary: Protesters are preparing for potential unrest if President Donald Trump refuses to accept the results of the November 3 presidential election. Organizer Sean Eldridge is "preparing for the worst" in case Trump tries to undermine the election or refuses to concede. Trump has repeatedly refused to say whether he would cede power peacefully in the event of defeat. A coalition of protesters is planning demonstrations across the US if Trump loses to Joe Biden.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, increasing 1.12 points or 0.07% to 1,512.09. The index saw 250.99 million lots traded worth RM84.83 million, with 265 gainers outpacing 76 losers.

site_title: JC Penney rushes to finalise sale to lender, landlord group
summary: JC Penney has finalized a planned sale to its bankruptcy lenders and biggest landlords, Simon Property Group and Brookfield Property Partners. The retailer must first finalize a lease agreement with the mall owners, which has a deadline of Monday. The sale is expected to save over 60,000 jobs. However, a competing sale proposal from a smaller group of lenders has been made at a "much higher and much better" price, adding complexity to the deal. The parties involved are working to finalize the agreement, with a court hearing describing it as "one of the longest and most complex lease agreements known to mankind".

images.alt_text: JC Penney has formalised a planned sale to its bankruptcy lenders and biggest landlords, but must first finalise a staggering lease agreement in less than a week to close the deal.

site_title: Here's a playbook for handling corporate fraud
summary: A series of high-profile investigations in Singapore has uncovered suspected corporate fraud at companies such as New Silkroutes, Agritrade International, and Hin Leong. The investigations were sparked by financial difficulties and allegations of hidden financial troubles. As the economic uncertainty caused by the Covid-19 pandemic continues, corporate fraud scandals are likely to increase, with significant reputational, financial, and legal ramifications for companies and their directors. Companies must demonstrate a commitment to good corporate governance and ethical business practices to prevent escalation into major public crises.

site_title: Asia's biggest film fest opens as a shadow of its usual self
summary: Asia's Busan International Film Festival (BIFF) opened with a reduced scale due to the COVID-19 pandemic, featuring around 190 movies shown only once, a 80% cut from its usual screenings. The festival, now in its 25th year, lacks its usual scale, with no opening ceremony, red-carpet events, or outdoor fan activities. Despite this, some international stars will participate online, and the festival will still hold its core components, including judging and press conferences, online.

site_title: Keppel Capital gets first closing of US$295m for Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund IV
summary: Keppel Capital's Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund IV has raised US$295 million in its first closing, exceeding its initial target of US$200 million. The fund, which aims to invest in Asian real estate, has attracted support from investors in the insurance, endowment, and pension sectors. With a target fund size of US$1 billion, the fund is expected to manage up to US$2.5 billion when fully leveraged. This marks the fourth value-add pan-Asian fund in Keppel Capital's flagship series, focusing on mega trends in urbanization and growth.

site_title: DBS launches solution for businesses to track cross-border collections in real time
summary: DBS has launched a real-time cross-border collection tracking solution for corporate clients in Singapore and Hong Kong, utilizing Swift Global Payments Innovation (gpi). Over 240,000 users will benefit from the solution, which aims to improve working capital management and foster trust with overseas counterparties. The solution provides instant updates on incoming funds, reducing manual tracking and costs. DBS plans to expand the offering to its other core markets in the coming months, building on its existing real-time digital cross-border payment tracking solution launched in 2018.

site_title: South Korea's Oct 1-20 exports drop 5.8% on year
summary: South Korea's exports dropped 5.8% from last year during the first 20 days of October, reversing the 3.4% growth in September. Shipments of chips surged 12.1%, but exports to China and the US declined 4.6% and 2.3%, respectively. Imports fell 2.8% in the same period. Full month trade data will be released on November 1.

site_title: Malaysia's September CPI drops 1.4% y-o-y, more than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) fell 1.4% in September, exceeding the forecasted 1.3% decline. This marks the seventh consecutive month of decline. The drop was primarily driven by a 9.9% decrease in the transport sector index and lower housing, water, electricity, gas, and fuel prices.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) fell for the seventh straight month in September, declining 1.4 per cent from a year earlier, government data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Wednesday, following a rally on Wall Street, as investors gained fresh hopes of a US stimulus breakthrough. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.51% to 24,695.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains came as traders brushed off new US President Trump's threats to extend a stocks rally.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks kicked off Wednesday on a positive note, tracking a rally on Wall Street and fuelled by fresh hopes of a US stimulus breakthrough.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on renewed US stimulus hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,203.50, driven by hopes of a US fiscal stimulus package and positive news on AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine trial. Banking and mining stocks led the gain, with the "Big Four" banks and top iron ore producers BHP Group and Rio Tinto advancing. An overnight rebound in oil prices also boosted energy stocks.

site_title: Bank of Japan must act swiftly if pandemic delays Japan's recovery: Sakurai
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Makoto Sakurai urged swift action to address potential economic and financial system risks from the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic. If the pandemic prolongs, it could lead to more companies failing, commercial banks carrying bad loans, and threaten Japan's financial stability. Sakurai emphasized the need for preparedness and swift action to mitigate these risks, citing sufficient capital reserves in financial institutions.

site_title: US trial of AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine may resume this week: sources
summary: AstraZeneca's US Covid-19 vaccine trial may resume as early as this week after the FDA completed its review of a serious illness in a study participant. The trial was put on hold in September after a participant in the UK trial fell ill with a rare spinal inflammatory disorder. Regulators in the US, UK, Brazil, India, and South Africa have previously allowed AstraZeneca to resume its vaccine trials. The FDA is requiring researchers to add information about the incident to consent forms signed by study participants.

site_title: US seeks to sway Brazil on Chinese 5G with US$1b deal
summary: The US has offered Brazil a $1 billion deal to finance US imports, including telecommunications, in an effort to persuade the country not to use China's Huawei for its 5G network. The deal includes loans, guarantees, and insurance. US National Security Advisor Robert O'Brien and President Jair Bolsonaro signed the agreement during O'Brien's visit to Brazil. The move comes as Brazil plans to upgrade its mobile network and follows other US allies in banning Huawei from their 5G networks due to security concerns.

site_title: Dalio Philanthropies makes US$25m grant to WMI for new programme
summary: Wealth management billionaire Ray Dalio is donating $25 million to Singapore's Wealth Management Institute (WMI) to launch the Dalio Sustainable Market Principles Program. The program aims to train investment professionals and policymakers on universal market principles, with a focus on sustainable investing and post-Covid market behavior. The grant will support research, conferences, and a curriculum that spans economic fundamentals, market principles, and risk management. The program is expected to be launched in January and is seen as a significant partnership between Dalio Philanthropies and WMI, with potential expansion into a graduate qualification or master's degree.

site_title: US: Stocks end with modest gains on renewed stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks ended with modest gains on Tuesday, recouping some of Monday's losses, amid renewed signs that policymakers can agree on a spending package to aid the US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.4%, the S&P 500 rose 0.5%, and the Nasdaq increased 0.3%. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said lawmakers were starting to write stimulus spending legislation, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell agreed to bring the package to a vote if President Trump supports it.

site_title: Euro rebounds to one-week high as stocks gain
summary: The euro rebounded 0.3% to a one-week high at $1.18065 due to a broader recovery in European stock markets and fading hopes for a US Covid-19 aid package. Investors remain cautious ahead of the Nov 3 US presidential election, with some wary of a contested result boosting the safe-haven appeal of the US dollar. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar dropped 0.4% to a three-week low, and sterling held onto small gains, while the US dollar index fell 0.2% to 93.227.

site_title: In US election with record spending, Biden is out-advertising Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump is projected to spend less on television advertisements than rival Joe Biden in the presidential election, with Biden expected to spend twice as much. Trump's campaign has reduced broadcast ad funding in key battleground states, including Ohio and Pennsylvania, while Biden has expanded ad spending to traditionally non-play states like Georgia. The Trump campaign claims its "strategic, surgical" ad spots are effective, but critics argue it's a risky strategy due to the unprecedented ad spending record. Biden's deep pockets, with $432 million in the bank, will fuel his advertising efforts, which could potentially turn the tide in his favor.

site_title: MLT preferential offering's issue price set at S$1.99; placement oversubscribed
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust's (MLT) private placement, including a new unit placement and a unit offering, has been priced at S$2.027 per unit, exceeding the indicative range. The placement was 5.5 times covered, with the issue price fixed and the upsize option exercised in full. The funds will be used to finance its Asia acquisition spree. The placement saw strong participation from new and existing investors, with the issue price fixed at the top end of the range.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on US stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Wednesday, driven by renewed hopes for a US stimulus package. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.27% to 23,630.88, and the Topix index climbed 0.53% to 1,634.42. The positive move followed overnight gains on Wall Street.

site_title: CDLHT sells Brisbane hotel at slight premium, exiting market as challenges loom
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) is selling its 4.5-star Novotel Brisbane hotel for A$67.9 million, a 6.9% premium to its original purchase price. The sale represents a 0.6% premium to an independent valuation and a 7% discount to its book value as of 2019. The sale comes as the company exits the market amid challenges, with the coronavirus outbreak and its impact on hotel trading performance and outlook.

site_title: Top Morgan Stanley commodities executives leave after rules breach: source
summary: Two top Morgan Stanley commodities executives, Nancy King and Jay Rubenstein, are leaving the bank after breaching company policy related to communication tools. The departures follow years of service, with King joining in 1986 and Rubenstein in 2007. The move has raised concerns about the use of messaging services in trade, with banks and oil majors having strict compliance rules due to monitoring concerns. Despite Morgan Stanley not finding any wrongdoing, the use of unauthorized communication channels went against policy.

site_title: Barnier warns 'little time left' as Brexit stalemate drags on
summary: EU Chief Negotiator Michel Barnier warned Britain that little time remains to clinch a post-Brexit deal, urging London to make concessions. The stalemate continues after the UK refused to restart talks, with Brussels offering to move on to "legal texts" and discuss the "structure" of the dialogue. The British government demands that the EU confirms both sides will have to make compromises, while the EU insists it will not change its approach. The UK's transition period ends on December 31, and a no-deal scenario would disrupt cross-Channel business.

images.alt_text: The EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier urged Britain on Tuesday to use the little time that remains to clinch a post-Brexit deal, with London refusing to restart talks until Brussels signals willingness to make concessions.

site_title: Why Biden will need to spend big
summary: US presidential candidate Joe Biden may need to implement large-scale deficit spending due to the current and likely future state of the US economy. His economists suggest spending a lot on the future, regardless of the source of funding. This approach is considered responsible, especially for the next few years, as deficit spending is not just acceptable but necessary. Biden's economic policy will likely involve significant spending, which may cause sticker shock for the news media and the public.

site_title: Oil up on US stimulus hopes, rising virus cases keep prices in check
summary: Oil prices rose 1.54% on Tuesday as investors awaited a potential US coronavirus aid package, but rising virus cases worldwide and increased Libyan output kept prices in check. November US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at $41.46 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose 1.27% to $43.16 a barrel. Despite optimism from US Speaker Nancy Pelosi, skepticism over the impact of a deal on oil markets lingered, with some analysts predicting prices could fall if a deal is not reached.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Mapletree Logistics Trust, SIA, Keppel DC Reit, CDLHT
summary: Keppel Corp launched the Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund IV with a target fund size of US$1 billion, achieving its first closing of US$295 million. Mapletree Logistics Trust's private placement was 5.5 times covered, with issue prices fixed at S$2.027 and S$1.99 per new unit. Singapore Airlines will return to New York with non-stop flights to the John F. Kennedy International Airport on November 9. Keppel DC Reit reported a 22.1% increase in distribution per unit to 2.357 Singapore cents for the third quarter. CDL Hospitality Trusts sold its 4.5-star hotel in Australia for A$67.9 million.

site_title: Australian retail sales fall again in Sept: preliminary data
summary: Australian retail sales declined 1.5% in September from the previous month, according to preliminary data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Despite this, sales in the September quarter rose 6.8%, following a 2.3% fall in the June quarter. The declines were mainly attributed to food retailing and household goods sectors, which still trade above September 2019 levels. The ABS will release the final estimate on November 4.

site_title: Snap shares jump as user growth, revenue beat estimates
summary: Snapchat's shares surged 23% after beating user growth and revenue forecasts, driven by a 18% year-over-year increase in daily active users to 249 million and a 52% jump in revenue to $679 million. The company exceeded analyst estimates and predicted continued user growth, with forecasted daily active users reaching 257 million in the fourth quarter. This performance helped Snap maintain its reputation as a safe platform for advertising, with over 1,000 advertisers boycotting Facebook in July due to hate speech concerns.

site_title: CapitaLand Commercial Trust Q3 DPU falls 9.1% to S$0.02
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust's (CCT) third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 9.1% to S$0.02, down from S$2.20 in the same period last year. Gross revenue declined 8.7% to S$94.7 million, and net property income fell 9.9% to S$73.1 million. The company has suspended trading and will be delisted from the Singapore bourse on Nov 3. A clean-up distribution for the period from July 1 to Oct 20 is expected to be paid by Nov 30.

site_title: CMT to be renamed CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust on Nov 3
summary: CMT, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, will be renamed CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust on November 3. The trust scheme for the merger of CMT and CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) became effective, with CCT unitholders receiving payment of 25.9 cents in cash and 0.72 new CMT units for each CCT unit held. The payment is expected to be made on October 28, and CCT is expected to delist on November 3.

site_title: Netflix reports slowing subscriber growth; shares slide
summary: Netflix reported slower subscriber growth in the third quarter, adding 2.2 million new subscribers, with a total of 195 million subscribers worldwide. Despite this, the company still expects to add 6 million new subscribers in the current quarter, bringing the year's total to 34 million. Netflix shares fell 4.8% after the earnings release, citing competition from other streaming services. The company remains confident in its ability to produce original content and expects to complete over 150 productions by year-end.

images.alt_text: Netflix shares slid on Tuesday after the US streaming television titan reported that subscriber growth slowed in the recently ended quarter after booming in the early days of the pandemic.

site_title: Peru unveils giant cat etching at famous Nazca site
summary: Peru has unveiled a 2,000-year-old giant cat etching at the Nazca Lines attraction, which was on the brink of disappearing due to natural erosion. The geoglyph, 37m long, was discovered by a drone and cleaned and preserved by a team of archeologists. Experts believe the cat dates back to 200-100 BC, during the Paracas culture period, and is one of the oldest known feline representations in the Nazca civilization's iconography. The Nazca Lines, a UNESCO World Heritage site, are expected to reopen to tourists in November.

site_title: Lynas posts 8% jump in rare earth output as Covid-19 curbs ease
summary: Lynas Corp, an Australian rare earth producer, reported an 8.1% increase in first-quarter neodymium and praseodymium output to 1,342 tonnes, exceeding a UBS estimate of 1,350 tonnes. Production normalized following the easing of coronavirus restrictions in Malaysia and Western Australia. The company stated that a 75% production rate is sufficient to meet demand, despite ongoing coronavirus-related demand pressures.

site_title: US officials more optimistic on stimulus, timing unclear
