summary: US officials have expressed optimism about a new stimulus package to support the US economy, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi stating that legislators are starting to write the bill and she is optimistic it can win bipartisan support. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has agreed to bring the measure to the Senate floor for a vote. Economists say the US economy needs more support to avert another downturn, and a new package could boost growth by two percentage points next year. However, talks between the White House and congressional Democrats have dragged on for months, and the timing of the package's approval remains unclear.

site_title: Amcorp Global gets green light to resume trading
summary: Amcorp Global, a Malaysian real estate developer, has received approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to resume trading. The shares will resume trading on October 21 after the restoration of the free float, following the completion of two sale and purchase agreements to sell approximately 7.4% of the company's share capital. The company had been suspended from trading since March 23 due to the loss of its free float after a mandatory cash offer.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as Brexit, lockdown worries outweigh upbeat earnings
summary: European stocks fell on Tuesday as concerns over COVID-19 curbs and Brexit weighed on the market, despite strong earnings from UBS and Reckitt Benckiser. Italy, Spain, and Britain imposed new restrictions, with Ireland's Finance Minister predicting a 3.5% GDP decline this year. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.35% lower, plateauing near pre-crisis levels as the pandemic grips the region.

site_title: Republicans running short on time and money to defend Senate majority
summary: US Senate Republicans are facing a tight deadline to defend their majority as the election is just two weeks away. With President Trump's declining opinion polls, Republicans are struggling in 10 competitive races, while Democrats are playing defense in two seats, increasing the likelihood of Republicans losing their 53-47 majority on November 3. The outcome would give Democrats full control of Congress.

site_title: Retailers revel as stuff, not experiences, makes a comeback
summary: US households are expected to decrease 7% in holiday spending this year, with a 34% drop in travel spending, according to Deloitte's holiday survey. This shift towards non-experience purchases like home furnishings and seasonal decor is good news for retailers like Bed Bath & Beyond and Gap Inc. Consumers are instead focusing on home-based purchases, with some considering gift cards or subscription boxes as alternatives to experiences.

site_title: Singapore's city-fringe business park rents to rise as firms cut costs
summary: Rentals for business parks in Singapore's city fringe are projected to rise due to companies cutting real-estate costs by moving to Grade-A office specifications in business parks. Rents in the city fringe increased 0.2% quarter-on-quarter and 2.4% year-on-year to S$5.91 per square foot per month. In contrast, rents in outlying areas will decline due to the older stock. The prime logistics segment is expected to see increased rents, while science park facilities and high-tech rents may also rise.

site_title: Ant Group receives HK exchange approval for IPO
summary: Ant Group Co, a fintech giant led by Jack Ma's Alibaba Group, has received approval from the Hong Kong stock exchange to proceed with its initial public offering (IPO), clearing a key hurdle. The company is seeking to raise $35 billion in a dual listing, with half in Hong Kong and half in Shanghai, and may complete the sale ahead of the US election. The approval paves the way for what could be the world's largest IPO, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record sale last year.

site_title: New Silkroutes appoints Darrell Lim as acting independent non-executive chairman
summary: New Silkroutes Group appointed Darrell Lim as acting independent non-executive chairman, replacing former chairman Goh Jin Hian, who resigned amid investigations by the Commercial Affairs Department. Lim, a former head of investor relations at the Singapore Exchange, was appointed to the board in August 2020. The move comes after Dr. Goh and former finance director William Teo Thiam Chuan were being investigated for possible false trading and market rigging. The company's shares closed flat at 8.2 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: Cathay to cut 6,000 jobs and close Dragon brand: SCMP
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways plans to cut 6,000 jobs and close its Dragon brand as part of a strategic review to combat the pandemic's impact. The Hong Kong-based airline initially planned 8,000 layoffs but reduced it to 18% of its workforce after government intervention. The move comes as Cathay faces significant losses, with a HK$9.9 billion loss in the first half, and is expected to operate at 10% of pre-pandemic capacity for the rest of the year.

site_title: Foreign investors flocking to Japan with Warren Buffett's seal of approval
summary: Foreign investors are flocking to Japan's stock market, with a record $18.2 billion in purchases in the week ended October 9. The renewed interest is attributed to Japan's relative success in coping with the pandemic and the endorsement of Warren Buffett, who invested $6 billion in Japanese trading houses in August. Newly elected Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's focus on digital transformation and economic growth is also seen as a positive factor. Despite lingering hurdles, experts believe that Japan's stable economy and low valuations make it an attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: IReit Global raises S$142.8m in rights issue
summary: IReit Global has successfully raised S$142.8 million in a rights issue to finance the acquisition of a 60% interest in properties in Spain and to repay a loan from City Developments (CDL). The renounceable, non-underwritten rights issue was priced at S$0.49 apiece, with 454 units available for every 1,000 units held. The move aims to strengthen IReit Global's financial position and support its expansion plans.

site_title: Fishing rights breakthrough could net EU-UK trade deal
summary: A breakthrough agreement on fishing rights between the UK and EU is expected to lead to a trade accord in the coming weeks. French President Emmanuel Macron has acknowledged the EU's need for long-term visibility in post-Brexit fishing arrangements, while the UK insists on annual fishing quotas. A deal is seen as crucial for the EU fishing industry, which has traditionally enjoyed preferential access to UK waters. The UK government has used fishing rights as leverage in negotiations, with the industry representing only 0.1% of the UK's GDP.

site_title: The Pines members unswayed by offer for Laguna club membership
summary: The Pines members reject an offer from the club's management to resume operations at the Laguna National Golf Resort Club in two months, calling it "not genuine" and "too little, too late". The 162 disgruntled members, led by Lim Seng Hoo, intend to continue the court case against Exklusiv Resorts and Peter Kwee. The offer included discounts on hotel and golf course rates, but members feel it doesn't address their concerns about the location and lack of consultation.

site_title: Air pollution costs Europe cities 160b euros a year: analysis
summary: A study by the CE Delft alliance found that air pollution in European cities costs inhabitants over 160 billion euros annually due to long- and short-term health impacts. The average citizen pays about 4% of their annual income in costs, with London having the highest social cost at 11.38 billion euros. The study links increased car use to heightened social costs, suggesting reduced commuting and car ownership can improve air quality and reduce costs. Air pollution is also linked to a higher risk of premature death, similar to the impact of Covid-19.

images.alt_text: Air pollution costs inhabitants of European cities more than 160 billion euros (S$258 billion) each year due to long- and short-term health impacts, a group of environmental and social watchdogs said in research published Wednesday.

site_title: Family jewels
summary: Maiko Makito, co-owner of Pearl Falco Corp, a Japanese pearl jewelry company, aims to expand its business beyond Japan to tap into the Asian market, where pearl appreciation is less common. The company's Ise Shima location in Japan is renowned for its 2,000-year-old tradition of women oyster divers and its birthplace of cultured pearls. Despite challenges such as aging oyster farmers and environmental threats, Makito believes diversification is key to survival. Pearl Falco has established a Singapore gallery and conducts workshops to educate consumers about pearls, with plans to target the global market.

site_title: Becoming an entrepreneur in investment management
summary: Starting an investment management firm can be an overwhelming decision due to the competitive industry. However, recognizing the limitations of perfection is key. Experienced firms can learn from others' mistakes, providing a framework for success. Six reasons to start your own firm include expanding services, increasing client base, and diversifying investment products. Key factors to consider include market research, financial planning, and regulatory compliance. Embracing a growth mindset and being adaptable can help entrepreneurs navigate the challenges of the investment management industry.

site_title: UBS posts US$2.1b net profit in third quarter amid heavy turnover in global markets
summary: UBS reported a 99% jump in third-quarter profit to US$2.1 billion, beating expectations, driven by heavy turnover in global markets. Investment banking earnings more than tripled, while wealth management pre-tax profit rose 18%. The strong performance came under CEO Sergio Ermotti's last month at the helm.

site_title: UOB's Sydney branch to issue A$750m in floating rate notes due October 2025
summary: UOB's Sydney branch plans to issue A$750 million in floating rate notes due October 2025, with a coupon rate of 0.59% per annum. This is the largest benchmark issuance in Australian dollars issued by UOB and the largest single tranche senior unsecured transaction from a Singapore bank. The notes have attracted significant investor interest, with a final order book exceeding A$1 billion and allocations to Australian and Asian investors. The issuance comes amid improved investor sentiment and UOB's two-pronged approach to the Australian dollar market.

site_title: Goldman to pay more than US$2b in 1MDB probe: Sources
summary: Goldman Sachs has reached a deal with the US Department of Justice to pay more than $2 billion in connection with the 1MDB scandal. The payment, part of an international action, will let the bank avoid a US criminal conviction. This follows an agreement in July to settle a related probe with Malaysia, in which Goldman promised to pay $2.5 billion. The total payment, including accords with Malaysia and other agencies, could reach $5 billion. The deal removes uncertainty for the bank, which has faced years of investigations and negotiations over its fundraising for the 1MDB investment fund.

site_title: Bolstering cyber security capabilities during Covid-19 and beyond
summary: During the Covid-19 pandemic, companies worldwide accelerated their shift to digital technologies, resulting in a significant rise in cybercrime. Research by Bain & Company found that 70% of companies implemented work-from-home policies, increasing network connectivity and cloud adoption, but many lacked robust cyber security capabilities. As a result, over 40% of large enterprises reduced their IT budgets and 20% cut security spending, exacerbating the vulnerability to cyber threats. This lack of investment in cyber security has long-term implications for businesses and their ability to protect sensitive information.

site_title: Afterpay, Westpac link up for Australia savings accounts
summary: Afterpay Ltd has partnered with Westpac Banking Corp to offer savings accounts to its 3 million Australian customers through Westpac's digital platform. The accounts will be available in the second quarter of 2021 and will help Afterpay gain insight into its customers' financial habits. The partnership marks a shift for Afterpay into mainstream banking and will also offer budgeting tools and other services. The announcement sent Afterpay's shares up 6%, marking a significant rise for the company.

site_title: China's new home prices grow at slowest rate since 2016 on tighter rules
summary: China's new home prices grew at their slowest pace in over 4½ years, with a 0.4% monthly increase in September, according to official data. This is the slowest pace since February 2016, as policy-makers tightened rules to prevent a potential market bubble. The number of cities reporting monthly price increases fell to 55 out of 70, and developers cut prices to attract buyers ahead of the National Day holiday. Economists expect home prices to rise 4.8% this year, a slower pace than last year.

site_title: Key investment ideas for 4Q 2020
summary:
Key investment ideas for Q4 2020 include:

- US equities, particularly cyclicals and small caps, as a fiscal stimulus is expected post-election, driving an outperformance for these sectors.
- Asia, with a focus on China, South Korea, and Taiwan equities, as the economic recovery is picking up steam and domestic demand is reviving.
- Emerging Markets (EMs), as risk sentiment is expected to rise post-election, driven by a likelihood of a larger fiscal stimulus and a weakening US dollar.
- Investors should be selective within EMs due to event risks and rising Covid-19 case counts.
- The overall outlook remains an overweight on equities over fixed income, with a focus on Asia and EMs.

site_title: Singapore shares track Wall Street losses, with STI sliding 0.59%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.59% to 2,528.64 points, mirroring overnight Wall Street losses due to dwindling US stimulus hopes. Sats was the top performer, gaining 1.96%, while ComfortDelGro declined 3.38%. Regional bourses were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 down, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.47%.

site_title: SK Hynix to buy Intel NAND business for US$9b
summary: SK Hynix Inc has agreed to purchase Intel's NAND memory chip business for US$9 billion in an all-cash deal. This move will propel SK Hynix to second place globally in the NAND chip industry. Intel is divesting its non-core business to focus on its remaining Optane memory business, which utilizes advanced technology. The sale marks the latest effort by Intel to shed volatile commodity NAND chip operations.

site_title: Singapore as 'resilient' hub for advanced global manufacturing
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized Singapore's potential as a resilient hub for advanced global manufacturing, citing the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on production and supply chains. He noted the region's and Singapore's opportunities for reshoring, regionalization, and diversification. The government is supporting this shift with initiatives such as the Advanced Manufacturing Training Academy and a partnership with the World Economic Forum to standardize Singapore's Smart Industry Readiness Index. The goal is to create jobs, training opportunities, and strengthen business linkages across borders.

site_title: JLC Advisors' Jeffrey Ong charged with misappropriating S$17.5m from CW Group
summary: Singaporean lawyer and JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong has been charged with misappropriating S$17.5 million from CW Group Holdings, a precision machine tool maker. The charges, announced on Tuesday, include 14 counts of misappropriation of funds from 2015 to 2016 and four counts of cheating the auditor. Ong's alleged modus operandi involved tricking the auditor into believing that funds were still in escrow, leading to a clean audit opinion. He faces 76 total charges and is scheduled to appear in court on November 25.

site_title: Rotimatic gets new breadwinner
summary: Zimplistic, the Singapore-based company behind the Indian flatbread-making machine Rotimatic, has been fully sold to Light Ray Holdings, a special-purpose vehicle incorporated in the British Virgin Islands. Founded in 2008, Zimplistic had previously raised US$30 million in funding but was burning cash at a rapid pace, reporting losses of US$23.6 million in 2018. The company had also implemented pay cuts during the Covid-19 lockdowns in China.

site_title: Lion Global Investors builds 'curated portfolios' capability
summary: Lion Global Investors (LGI) has established a "Curated Portfolios Team" to provide retail investors with access to private banking solutions. The team, in partnership with digital partners, will create risk-based portfolios using a mix of exchange-traded funds and best-in-class funds. LGI's investment process involves idea generation, fund manager due diligence, and portfolio monitoring. The firm uses Inalytics' research tool to analyze fund managers' decisions and identify skill or luck behind performance. LGI aims to differentiate itself with a rigorous approach to understanding portfolio construction and manager decisions.

site_title: Adobe unveils authentication tool in battle against deepfakes
summary: Adobe has unveiled an authentication tool to combat deepfakes, a software feature that will let creators tag pictures with their names, edit history, and location to provide transparency. The tool, part of the Content Authenticity Initiative, aims to build trust in images and distinguish between genuine and manipulated content. Released in 2021, the feature will be available for testing and is part of a coalition with Microsoft, Twitter, and others to combat online misinformation and disinformation.

site_title: SIA returns to New York with non-stop service from Nov 9
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will resume non-stop flights to New York's John F Kennedy International Airport (JFK) on November 9, operating three times a week. The 18-hour flight will be operated using Airbus A350-900 aircraft, with a three-class configuration. SIA sees an opportunity to grow both passenger and cargo operations out of JFK, with significant cargo demand expected in the New York metro area. Analysts predict a low passenger load factor due to restrictions on payload, but SIA aims to restore connectivity in key markets and protect its long-term position.

site_title: Building organisational resilience
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need for businesses to build organisational resilience. Companies like Starbucks have adapted to the crisis by implementing digitalization, menu changes, and safety measures, showcasing the importance of flexibility and proactive planning. Experts emphasize the need for organisations to focus on employee health and wellbeing, talent and workforce, supply chain and global trade, and risk management to ensure sustainability and growth. The pandemic has highlighted the need for new ways of working, business models, and risk management practices, with companies required to develop contingency plans and scenario planning to respond to disruptions.

site_title: Pilots being rolled out on road to Phase 3
summary: Singapore is piloting pre-event testing as part of efforts to move towards Phase 3, which could occur by the end of the year. The pilot will use antigen rapid test kits (ARTs) and confirmatory PCR tests, which will be offered free of charge. The government is also considering limited pilots for higher-risk settings, such as bars and nightclubs, and will implement stricter measures, including testing customers before entry and using CCTV monitors. Phase 3, if implemented, will allow for increased gatherings, public venue capacity, and wedding receptions, but with additional safety measures.

images.alt_text: The Multi-Ministry Taskforce added that it is also prepared to consider limited pilots for higher-risk settings such as bars, pubs, karaoke lounges and nightclubs.

site_title: Mid-career talents can avail of 500 new training opportunities
summary: SKILLSFUTURE Singapore (SSG) will add 500 training opportunities in leading Industry 4.0 tech firms for mid-career talents through the SGUnited Jobs and Skills for Advanced Manufacturing programme, bringing the total to 2,300.

site_title: Thai court orders shutdown of news site linked to Thaksin
summary: A Thai court ordered the shutdown of Voice TV, a news site linked to exiled former premier Thaksin Shinawatra, over its coverage of anti-government protests in Bangkok. The outlet was critical of the government and accused of disseminating "distorted information" that incited unrest. The ruling comes as thousands of protesters demand the resignation of Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha and face a ban on gatherings of more than four people. The Foreign Correspondents Club of Thailand expressed deep concern over the investigation and the potential impact on media freedom.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to pay US$2.8b over 1MDB scandal, says report
summary: Goldman Sachs is expected to admit wrongdoing in the 1MDB scandal and pay the US government $2.8 billion, ending a criminal probe. The deal follows an Asian subsidiary's expected guilty plea this week, avoiding a damaging plea from Goldman. The Justice Department had alleged more than $4.5 billion was stolen from 1MDB between 2009 and 2015. Goldman helped raise $6.5 billion for the fund and two ex-bankers are accused of misappropriating billions. The Malaysian government previously dropped charges against Goldman after a $3.9 billion settlement.

site_title: Google eyes £800m London office hub
summary: Google is in talks to buy the Central Saint Giles office complex in London for up to £800 million, with the search giant already occupying 40% of the space. The complex, jointly owned by Legal & General Group and Mitsubishi Estate, would be one of the largest office deals in London this year. Negotiations are ongoing, with no official completion date announced.

site_title: Indonesia street protests reignite over controversial labour law
summary: Indonesia's student groups and labour unions have resumed protests against a new labour law, citing concerns it will erode workers' rights and dismantle environmental protections. The law, passed on October 5, aims to simplify regulations and boost local businesses, but unions argue it was rushed through Parliament without their input. The protests, which have turned violent in Jakarta, come after thousands were detained last week. The government claims the law reflects input from experts and stakeholders, but labour unions plan to challenge its constitutionality.

site_title: Lustre legacy
summary: Singaporean jeweller Pearl Falco showcases a 14cm Akoya pearl necklace, crafted over 5-6 years from forming in baby oysters to completion. The labour-intensive process involves carefully nurturing the pearls to achieve the desired quality. The necklace's intricate design and rarity make it a testament to the craftsmanship and dedication of the artist behind it.

site_title: Make the circular economy a reality and keep it rolling
summary: The article emphasizes the need for a circular economy to replace linear growth, mitigating environmental degradation and resource depletion. It cites the fourth Industrial Revolution as a catalyst for innovation, leveraging technologies like big data and AI. Disruptive innovation can shift reliance from finite to renewable resources, and entrepreneurs are encouraged to study circular economy nuances, identify sectors ripe for disruption, and align with business environments. Collaborative approaches, such as initiatives like ideasinc, are also crucial, and social entrepreneurship must be incentivized to drive sustainable prosperity.

site_title: Local construction firms 'still playing second fiddle to foreign ones'
summary: Singapore's local construction firms face stiff competition from foreign companies, with 50% of public sector contracts worth over S$85 million awarded to foreign firms from 2017 to 2019. Despite winning 90% of smaller contracts, local companies are struggling to gain a foothold in larger projects. The government has acknowledged the issue, with Second Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng suggesting tweaks to procurement policies to help smaller local companies secure government contracts. Local firms are calling for more opportunities and support to build their capabilities and compete with foreign players.

site_title: Are banks currently value traps?
summary: Banks are not currently value traps, despite trading at low valuations, according to the article. A value trap implies a share price that is undervalued and will eventually rise, but this does not necessarily apply to banks. Instead, the instability in the market will eventually react, but the time scale for this to happen is impossible to define. Banks are trading at a median price-to-book ratio of 0.5, a level last seen during the Great Financial Crisis, and are facing challenges such as low interest rates and uncertainty due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Interest rates are at historic lows, which make it harder for banks to earn profits from lending.

site_title: MLT to raise S$650m to partially fund Asia property acquisitions
summary: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) plans to raise up to S$650 million through a private placement and preferential offering to partially fund its S$1.09 billion acquisition of logistics properties in China, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The move is expected to strengthen MLT's connectivity across key logistics nodes and improve supply chain resiliency, with analysts predicting medium-term rental growth and increased multi-location tenants. The fundraising exercise will allow MLT to reduce debt and potentially fund further acquisitions.

site_title: Rapid Covid tests give hope to organisers of larger events
summary: Singapore's events industry is cautiously optimistic about the use of Covid-19 rapid tests, which could enable larger gatherings. However, the road to recovery is expected to be long, with many uncertainties remaining, including logistics, costs, and buy-in. Industry players anticipate that rapid testing will not replace existing safety measures, and that costs could add up. The government's condition for moving to Phase 3 of its business reopening is a higher participation rate in the TraceTogether contact-tracing technology, which could further delay the industry's recovery.

site_title: Is herd immunity mass murder?
summary: A proposal by a group of scientists, known as the Great Barrington Declaration, suggests lifting restrictions to achieve herd immunity by allowing those with low risk of infection to live normally. However, critics argue that this approach could lead to one million or more preventable deaths, as it fails to account for harm to infected people, protection of vulnerable populations, and the number of deaths it would cause. The plan is also based on flawed assumptions, as herd immunity may not be achieved until 60-70% of the population is infected, and the cost could be much worse due to lingering health effects.

site_title: Fintech sector overlooks lucrative women's market amid data gaps and bias
summary: Fintech companies are overlooking a lucrative women's market, despite the fact that women control over 40% of global wealth and earn $24 trillion annually. A report by the Financial Alliance for Women found that only 65% of women benefit from financial services, with most being dissatisfied with existing solutions. To capitalize on this market, fintechs must prioritize collecting "sex-disaggregated" data, move beyond gender-neutral products, and track metrics such as customer acquisition cost and usage rates. Investors and regulators also play a crucial role in supporting women-focused fintechs and creating an enabling ecosystem.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q3 DPU up 22.1%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 22.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.357 Singapore cents for Q3 2020, driven by new acquisitions and strong leasing momentum. Net property income and gross revenue also rose 47.6% and 46% respectively. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 96.7% and weighted average lease expiry was 7.2 years. Units fell 7 cents to close at S$2.97, but the Reit's net asset value per unit increased to S$1.16.

site_title: Didi Chuxing mulls HK initial public offering
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's top ride-hailing firm, is considering a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) in 2021, shifting from its previous plan for a New York listing due to rising Sino-US tensions. The company, backed by SoftBank, Alibaba, and Tencent, aims for a valuation of over $60 billion. Didi has started talks with investment banks and may also consider a new fundraising round to boost its valuation, as some investors seek to cash in. The IPO plan is still in its early stages and may change due to market conditions.

site_title: Malaysia orders nearly 1m people to work from home
summary: Malaysia has ordered nearly 1 million workers in management and supervision categories to work from home due to a conditional movement control order (MCO) effective October 22. The order aims to limit movement and prevent new Covid-19 infections, with around 800,000 from the private sector and 200,000 civil servants affected. Those in the financial sector, enforcement, and welfare officers will continue to work from the office, with mandatory swab tests and subsidized tests for Socso contributors. The directive may be extended if the MCO is prolonged.

site_title: Brookfield's US$2b property deal will be India's biggest
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has agreed to purchase 12.5 million square feet of commercial properties in India from RMZ Corp for US$2 billion, the largest real estate deal in the country. The deal will give Brookfield zero debt and allow it to expand its portfolio. The transaction follows a surge in foreign investment in India's office market, with US$15.4 billion in equity investments since 2011. The sale includes properties occupied by major clients such as Accenture and Google.

site_title: Singaporeans who travelled overseas on or after March 27 can now tap government subsidies, insurance in case of infection
summary: Singapore citizens, permanent residents, and long-term pass holders who traveled overseas on or after March 27 can now access government subsidies and insurance coverage for Covid-19 treatment upon return. This move aims to progressively reopen the country's borders, with exceptions made for those on permitted travel arrangements and students traveling for studies. The government will also continue to pay Covid-19 medical bills for those who left before March 27, as it cannot keep its borders closed indefinitely to maintain its economic survival.

site_title: Consortium to build plant-based protein facility in Singapore
summary: A consortium led by Proterra Investment Partners Asia has partnered with Eat Just to build a plant-based protein facility in Singapore, generating thousands of tonnes of protein, including an egg substitute. The facility, valued at up to US$120 million, will create jobs and support the company's expansion in Asia. Eat Just, which already has facilities in North America and Germany, aims to meet the region's growing demand for protein and sustainable food systems. The project is seen as an important addition to Singapore's agri-food ecosystem, enabling the country to cater to Asian markets and create innovative production capabilities.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Eat Just's plant-protein factory in Singapore, which is expected to break ground before Q1 2021.

site_title: CRCT, Suntec Reit go to market with perps offering
summary: Real estate investment trusts (Reits) CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) and Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Suntec Reit) have launched perpetual securities, or perps, with annual distributions of 3.375% and 3.8%, respectively. The perps have no fixed redemption date, and distributions will be based on a swap offer rate or its successor rate. Net proceeds from the issues will be used for refinancing, financing, and general corporate purposes. The perps are expected to be issued on October 27, 2020, and will be paid semi-annually starting April 27, 2021.

site_title: Jurong Innovation District has S$420m new investments
summary: Singapore's Jurong Innovation District (JID) has secured S$420 million in new investments over the past year, despite the Covid-19 pandemic. The investments, valued at S$2 billion, are for facilities set to open by 2023, including a Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Centre and Additive Manufacturing Centres from DMG MORI, Makino, and Konica Minolta. These new entrants aim to develop future mobility technologies and support the adoption of additive manufacturing. The investments further solidify JID's position as a key manufacturing hub in Singapore.

site_title: Procter & Gamble reports broad growth, raises full-year forecast
summary: Procter & Gamble reported its best organic sales growth since 2005, with a 9% increase in the quarter ended Sept 30. The company raised its full-year forecast, expecting organic revenue to grow 4-5% and earnings per share to rise 4-9%. The growth is attributed to increased at-home consumption of toilet paper and cleaning supplies, as well as higher demand for health and wellness products. CEO Jon Moeller expects sustained results as long as consumers remain homebound, and a slowdown appears unlikely.

site_title: UK government suffers defeat by House of Lords over Brexit law
summary: The UK House of Lords voted 226-53 to express "regret" over the government's Brexit legislation, which critics claim undermines the UK's reputation as a defender of the rule of law. The bill, which regulates trade among the country's four constituent nations after Brexit, has already passed the House of Commons but faces detailed scrutiny by the lords. The EU has initiated legal action against the UK over the bill's treaty-breaching provisions, amid a standoff over future trading relationship talks.

site_title: US insurer Travelers profit beats on higher premiums, lower costs
summary: Travelers Companies, a US insurer, reported a 3% increase in net written premiums to $7.77 billion in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company's core income rose to $3.12 per share, more than doubling overall profit to $827 million, driven by a one-time gain from Pacific Gas & Electric's emergence from bankruptcy. Despite catastrophe losses, Travelers' combined ratio of 94.9% indicated the insurer earns more in premiums than it pays out in claims.

site_title: Daimler chief eyes China growth as trade tensions rise
summary: Daimler's CEO, Ola Kaellenius, emphasizes China as Mercedes-Benz's biggest growth market over the next decade, despite rising global trade tensions. The company will adjust production locations to capitalize on shifting demand. China accounted for 700,000 passenger car sales last year, while the US was the next largest market with 320,000-330,000 cars. Kaellenius warns that uncertain international trade conditions, such as a potential hard Brexit, may impact global sales and production decisions.

site_title: 5G jobs drive is wind beneath telcos' wings
summary: Singapore's telcos are receiving support from the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) to hire or reskill 1,000 5G professionals. The initiative, announced in September, aims to help telcos meet the growing demand for 5G skills. Despite the telcos' trend of headcount reduction, the IMDA's plan is seen as a triple win for telcos, Singapore residents, and the national 5G network rollout. The government's efforts to spur consumer and enterprise interest in 5G have already shown promising results, with Citi upgrading its consumer mobile revenue outlook for Singapore.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves parliament session to discuss protests
summary: Thailand's parliament is set to hold a special session on October 26 to discuss demands of pro-democracy protesters, following failed emergency rules and police crackdowns on activists. The Cabinet, chaired by Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha, agreed to support the two-day parliamentary debate, which may move forward constitutional amendment to placate protesters. The protesters, who have been calling for the prime minister's resignation and reform of the monarchy, vow to continue demonstrations until all demands are met.

site_title: Indonesia street protests reignite over controversial labour law
summary: Indonesia's student groups resumed protests against a newly passed labour law, citing its erosion of workers' rights and environmental protections. The law, passed on October 5, aims to simplify regulations and boost local businesses, but labour unions plan to challenge its constitutionality. The law's passage has sparked widespread discontent, with thousands detained last week in Jakarta clashes. Critics argue the law's provisions will weaken protections for workers, indigenous groups, and the environment, raising concerns about land grabbing.

site_title: US suing Google in biggest antitrust case in decades
summary: The US government is suing Google in the largest antitrust case in decades, accusing the company of illegal monopoly behavior to preserve its dominance in internet search and advertising. The Justice Department filed the suit after months of investigations into Google's power and parallel probes into Amazon, Facebook, and Apple. This move marks a major test for the technology sector and follows months of antitrust enforcers seeking to check Google's influence.

site_title: Foreign investors flock to Japan with Buffett's seal of approval
summary: Foreign investors are flocking to Japan's stock market, with a record $18.3 billion in purchases in the latest week. Warren Buffett's $6 billion investment in Japan's trading houses is seen as a strong signal to value investors that the country's market is undervalued. Newly elected Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's focus on digital transformation and economic reforms is also attracting investors. Despite some hurdles, Japan's relatively stable economy and low valuations are making it an attractive destination for foreign investors, with the Nikkei 225 index erasing its year-to-date losses.

site_title: Doctors may have found secretive new organs in the centre of your head
summary: Researchers in the Netherlands have discovered a possible set of previously unidentified organs in the human head, specifically a pair of large salivary glands near the nasal cavity and throat. The glands, which were found in a small patient population, could potentially explain chronic dry mouth and swallowing problems in cancer patients undergoing radiation therapy. If confirmed, this discovery could mark the first identification of a new salivary gland type in about three centuries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 7.14 points lower on Tuesday at 1,510.97. The market saw 660 losers outweighing 393 gainers in volume worth RM5.825 billion.

site_title: UOB's Sydney branch prices A$750m floating rate notes due October 2025
summary: UOB announced plans to issue A$750 million in floating rate notes due October 2025 with a coupon rate of 3-month bank bill swap reference rate plus 0.59% per annum. This is the largest benchmark issuance in Australian dollars issued by UOB, with a final order book exceeding A$1 billion. The notes were allocated to 70% Australian investors and 30% Asian investors, with a fifth allocated to middle-market investors. ANZ was appointed as the sole lead manager and book runner for the notes.

site_title: Sterling neutral as traders hope for Brexit trade deal
summary: Sterling remains neutral as traders await a potential Brexit trade deal by the end of the year. Despite Brexit-induced volatility, the pound's price has remained little changed on a month-to-date basis. Investors are leaning towards a scenario where both the UK and EU reach a deal, similar to last year's divorce agreement, suggesting a positive outcome for sterling.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore received S$420 million in new investments for the Jurong Innovation District, with facilities set to be completed by 2023. SIA launched non-stop flights to New York's JFK airport, while Sembcorp Industries secured a S$100m SORA-based loan. The Straits Times Index (STI) slid 0.59% due to Wall Street losses. Additionally, SIA is launching 500 new training opportunities and an Industry 4.0 expertise-sharing platform, bringing the total to 2,300.

site_title: EU may shut door to travel from Canada, allow Singapore visitors
summary: The European Union is set to remove Canada, Tunisia, and Georgia from its list of countries allowing travel, while reopening its doors to Singapore visitors due to improved virus trends. The changes, planned for Wednesday, will reduce the list to nine countries, including Australia, China, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, and Uruguay. The US will remain blacklisted, and the EU aims to identify Hong Kong and Macau as separate entities in its visa rules.

site_title: Euronext resumes trading as outage raises concentration concerns
summary: Euronext resumed trading on Tuesday after a technical failure impacted one of its data management systems, disrupting trading for over three hours on Monday. The outage raised concerns about the concentration risk of one operator hosting multiple bourses across Europe. Despite a resolution, the incident highlighted the need for improved corrective and preventive measures. Euronext attributed the issue to a bug in a third-party component, with no evidence of a cyber attack. The outage followed a string of breakdowns on international exchanges this year, including hardware failures and software glitches.

site_title: US single-family homebuilding accelerates in September
summary: US single-family homebuilding surged 8.5% in September, reaching a rate of 1.108 million units, as Americans seek more room for home offices and schooling. Housing starts increased 1.9% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.415 million units. However, multi-family housing starts fell 16.3% to 307,000 units. The rebound in the housing market is seen as a bright spot in the economy, which has been recovering from the Covid-19 recession.

site_title: Cathay to cut 6,000 jobs and close dragon brand
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways will cut 6,000 jobs and close its Cathay Dragon brand as part of a strategic review to combat the pandemic's damage. The Hong Kong-based airline initially planned 8,000 layoffs but reduced it to 18% of its workforce due to government intervention. The move comes as the airline posts a $1.3 billion loss and expects to operate at 10% of pre-pandemic capacity for the rest of the year. The company has already introduced cost-cutting measures, including unpaid leave and salary reductions.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways will cut 6,000 jobs and close its Cathay Dragon brand, the South China Morning Post reported, as part of a strategic review to combat the deep damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: New WTO chief faces tough job to restore order to global trade
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is nearing a new director-general, with Nigeria's Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala and South Korea's Yoo Myung-hee as the final candidates. The selection process began with eight hopefuls and will conclude on October 27, with a consensus decision expected in early November. This comes after the previous director-general, Roberto Azevedo, stepped down in August amidst the US-China trade war. Okonjo-Iweala and Yoo will take over the role, aiming to restore order to global trade after the WTO's troubled period.

site_title: Lufthansa loses 1.26b euros in Q3
summary: Lufthansa reported a loss of 1.26 billion euros in the third quarter of 2020, slightly improving from a 1.5 billion euro loss in the previous quarter. The airline attributed the improvement to expanded flight schedules and cost reductions in the summer months. However, demand for air travel is expected to remain low due to the ongoing pandemic and travel restrictions, according to Lufthansa.

site_title: Microsoft cloud computing looks to the stars
summary: Microsoft's Azure cloud computing service is launching "Azure Space" to provide datacenter power to remote spots on Earth via partnerships with satellite operators like SpaceX. The service aims to handle vast data from satellites and deliver high-speed internet to distant areas. New partnerships will enable Azure Modular Datacenters to provide secure computing power for various industries, including space missions, humanitarian assistance, and military operations. Microsoft's approach is designed to address technology challenges in space and facilitate faster data analysis and insights.

site_title: SIA to launch non-stop flights to New York's JFK airport from next month
summary: Singapore Airlines will launch non-stop flights from Changi Airport to New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport starting November 9, with the world's longest flight at over 18 hours. The airline suspended its non-stop service to Newark Liberty International Airport in March due to the pandemic and expects significant cargo demand from industries in the New York metro area. The new direct flight will be operated using an Airbus A350-900 aircraft and will be supported by transfer passengers.

site_title: Thailand suspends TV station over protests coverage
summary: A Thai court ordered the suspension of online TV station Voice TV, critical of the government, for violating emergency measures and breaching the Computer Crime Act by uploading "false information". The station's owner, part-owned by former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's family, will continue broadcasting until the court order arrives. The suspension comes amid three months of protests against Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha and the monarchy, with the government cracking down on demonstrations and news deemed damaging.

site_title: Amcorp Global to resume trading on Oct 21
summary: Amcorp Global's shares will resume trading on Oct 21 after the Singapore Exchange regulators lifted the suspension due to the restoration of the free float. As of Oct 20, 1,091 public shareholders held 55.3 million shares, representing 12.37% of the total issued share capital, meeting the requirement of at least 10% held by 500 public shareholders. The suspension was imposed following the sale of Tee International's 63.3% stake in Tee Land to Amcorp Group in February for S$50.6 million.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher with focus on stimulus
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday as investors awaited potential stimulus from Washington. The Dow Jones rose 50.43 points, the S&P 500 gained 12.46 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 52.95 points. The positive start comes as Senate Republicans prepare to vote on a bill to help small businesses affected by the Covid-19 pandemic. The gains were despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: German, Danish power grid firms launch Baltic Sea wind link
summary: Germany and Denmark launched a Baltic Sea wind link, connecting offshore wind turbines to both countries' power markets. The Combined Grid Solution (CGS) costs 300 million euros and enables electricity production from wind parks to flow to both markets, boosting supply security and enabling more wholesale trading. The project aims to integrate Baltic wind capacity into the Nordic and continental European regions, offering arbitrage possibilities. The initiative is part of the European Commission's efforts to make volatile renewables a more reliable source of energy.

site_title: MTF outlines roadmap to Phase Three of Singapore's re-opening
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has outlined a roadmap for Phase Three of the country's re-opening, with a possible start by the end of this year. To achieve this, two prerequisites must be met: a higher take-up rate for the TraceTogether app and expanded deployment of SafeEntry for events. Pre-event testing will be piloted using antigen rapid tests (ARTs), which can provide results within half an hour, and will be offered free of charge to participants. Increased gathering sizes, public venue capacities, and event capacities may also be allowed in Phase Three.

site_title: Good Class Bungalow at King Albert Park put on market for S$45.5m
summary: A Good Class Bungalow at 22A King Albert Park in Singapore's District 21 is available for sale via private treaty at a guide price of S$45.5 million, working out to S$1,248 per square foot. The freehold property features five bedrooms, a basement, and a swimming pool, and sits atop a hill with a bird's eye view of the surrounding lush vegetation. The land could be subdivided into two plots, subject to Urban Redevelopment Authority approval, and is situated in a private cul-de-sac ideal for redevelopment.

site_title: Race to become Russia's Amazon is heating up
summary: Russia's e-commerce market is experiencing a surge in growth due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with internet sales projected to reach 2.5 trillion rubles ($43 billion) in 2020. Despite Wildberries, the largest online retailer, controlling only 13% of the market, competition is heating up, and two or three platforms are expected to dominate. Entrants like AliExpress, Ozon, and Yandex NV are gaining traction, with Ozon announcing plans to sell shares in the US to fund growth. The market remains fragmented, with logistical challenges and entrenched consumer habits hindering widespread adoption of e-commerce.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q3 DPU up 22.1%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 22.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.357 Singapore cents for Q3, driven by new acquisitions and strong leasing momentum. The Reit's distributable income jumped 47.6% to S$40.48 million, with net property income and gross revenue also rising. The company secured new leases and lease renewals, maintaining a portfolio occupancy of 96.7%. Net asset value per unit increased to S$1.16, and the Reit's interest coverage ratio was at 12.7 times.

site_title: Opec+ vows 'proactive' response to precarious oil market
summary: The Opec+ alliance has warned of a "precarious" oil market outlook due to a resurgent coronavirus pandemic, which is hurting oil demand. Saudi Arabia and Russia, key Opec+ members, have expressed bearish views, with Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman and Alexander Novak calling for a "proactive" response to head off negative trends. The group is expected to postpone its planned production increase in early 2021, possibly by several months, to address the market concerns.

site_title: Eat Just, Proterra Asia to invest up to US$120m on plant-based protein facility in Singapore
summary: Eat Just, a US-based plant-based food company, has partnered with Proterra Asia to build a plant protein production facility in Singapore. The consortium will invest up to $120 million, with Eat Just investing $20 million. The facility will produce thousands of tonnes of protein, complementing Eat Just's existing facilities in North America and Germany. The partnership aims to accelerate Eat Just's growth, with plans to expand to cultured meat production in the future. The Singapore government's support and favorable business environment have made the country an attractive location for the project.

site_title: Reckitt sees fastest sales growth in decade on disinfectants
summary: Reckitt Benckiser Group forecasts its fastest revenue growth in a decade, driven by increased demand for disinfectants amid the pandemic. Sales are expected to rise at a low double-digit rate this year, with a 20% increase in hygiene products sales for the third quarter. The company's expansion into 19 new markets also contributed to its growth.

site_title: Singapore city-fringe business park rents to rise as firms cut costs: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: Rents for business parks in Singapore's city fringe are projected to rise as firms seek Grade A office specifications to cut costs. In the third quarter, rents increased 0.2% quarter-over-quarter and 2.4% year-over-year to S$5.91 per square foot per month. This trend is expected to continue until 2021, when Grade A CBD rents are projected to decline by 20%. In contrast, outlying area business park rents are expected to decline due to older stock. The logistics sector is also expected to see rent increases, while high-tech rents may remain stable.

site_title: Number of women in tech in South-east Asia beats global average
summary: A study by the Boston Consulting Group and Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority found that women in South-east Asia are participating more in technology than the global average, with 32% of the region's tech sector consisting of women, surpassing the global average of 28%. The region's higher education and workforce participation rates also exceed the global average.

site_title: Seoul: Shares up on foreign buying as won hits 18-month high
summary: South Korean shares rose 11.67 points, or 0.50%, to 2,358.41, driven by strong foreign buying interest as the won hit an 18-month high. Foreign investors net bought 41.6 billion won worth of shares, boosting the Kospi's gains. The currency's strength is seen as a positive sign for the economy, despite a 7.31% year-to-date gain.

site_title: STI tracks Wall Street losses, down 0.59% at 2,528.64
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.59% to 2,528.64 points, following overnight Wall Street losses due to dwindling hopes for a stimulus deal. Sats was the top performer, gaining 1.96%, while ComfortDelGro was the worst, losing 3.38%. Despite RHB Securities' "buy" recommendation for ComfortDelGro, the stock's decline was attributed to concerns over public transport ridership. The decline marks a reversal of the STI's 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China's super rich got US$1.5t richer during pandemic: report
summary: China's super wealthy earned a record $1.5 trillion in 2020, surpassing the past five years combined, as e-commerce and gaming boomed during pandemic lockdowns. 878 billionaires now exist in the country, with Jack Ma topping the list at $58.8 billion, followed by Pony Ma and Zhong Shanshan. The report highlights China's shift towards the new economy, with healthcare entrepreneurs also experiencing significant growth, and notes that the country is on track to become the only major economy to expand this year.

images.alt_text: China's super wealthy have earned a record US$1.5 trillion in 2020, more than the past five years combined, as e-commerce and gaming boomed during pandemic lockdowns, an annual rich list said Tuesday.

site_title: Sweden bans Huawei, ZTE from upcoming 5G networks
summary: Sweden's Swedish Post and Telecom Authority (PTS) has banned the use of telecom equipment from China's Huawei and ZTE in its 5G network ahead of the spectrum auction scheduled for next month. The decision follows assessments by the Swedish Armed Forces and the Swedish Security Service, citing concerns over security threats. The ban applies to central functions, requiring companies to remove Huawei and ZTE gear by January 1, 2025. This move follows similar actions by the UK, which ordered Huawei equipment to be purged from Britain's 5G network by 2027.

images.alt_text: Swedish regulators on Tuesday banned the use of telecom equipment from China's Huawei and ZTE in its 5G network ahead of the spectrum auction scheduled for next month.

site_title: Retailers revel as stuff, not experiences, makes a comeback
summary: US households are expected to spend 7% less this holiday season compared to 2019, with a 34% drop in travel spending. The shift towards home-focused purchases, such as home furnishings and seasonal decor, is benefiting retailers like Bed Bath & Beyond and TJX Cos. Consumers are opting for material gifts instead of experiences, citing the ability to create lasting memories. This trend is attributed to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and temporary extra jobless benefits.

site_title: Bank of Japan to downgrade growth, inflation forecasts: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to downgrade its economic and inflation forecasts for the current fiscal year when it releases fresh quarterly projections next week. The central bank is expected to maintain its scenario of a moderate economic recovery, despite a bigger-than-expected economic slump in April-June and soft consumption during the summer. The BOJ's growth forecast is likely to be cut to around 4.7% from 5.0%, and its inflation forecast for core consumer prices is expected to be trimmed to 0.5% from 0.7%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge lower as virus worries dampen earnings boost
summary: European stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, weighed down by concerns over tighter coronavirus curbs and doubts on US stimulus ahead of the presidential election. Earnings reports from Swiss bank UBS and Swedish bank Swedbank boosted the market, with UBS rising 2.1% and Swedbank gaining 0.9%. Despite this, the impact of the curbs and potential economic impact from the US-EU trade tensions remained a concern.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip on fears of lockdowns in Europe
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to close at 6,184.60, marking its worst session since Oct 2, amid fears of lockdowns in Europe due to surging coronavirus cases. Italy and Spain tightened curbs, while the UK government adviser suggested a national lockdown. US House Speaker expressed uncertainty over a coronavirus stimulus bill before the Nov 3 presidential election. Technology stocks gained 1.7%, with Afterpay reaching a record high, while miners and bank stocks declined.

site_title: Philippines' PNOC aims to start South China Sea venture with CNOOC by 2021
summary: The Philippines' PNOC aims to start an energy exploration venture with CNOOC in the South China Sea by 2021. PNOC was awarded Service Contract 57 in 2005 for the Calamian oil and gas prospect, which may have natural gas reserves equivalent to two-thirds of Malampaya's reserves. Following President Duterte's decision to lift a moratorium, the project can proceed. Initial studies suggest drilling may begin in the fourth quarter of 2020, with production starting by 2026 or 2027.

site_title: Swiss watch exports decline, leaving industry more China-reliant
summary: Swiss watch exports declined 12% to 1.6 billion francs in September, marking the eighth consecutive month of decline. The industry has become increasingly reliant on China, with exports to the country surging 79% in the same period. China is replacing Hong Kong as the top destination for Swiss luxury timepieces, with the southern province of Hainan emerging as a promising market. Overall, Swiss watch exports have dropped 28% in the first nine months of the year, highlighting the industry's dependence on China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks drop on caution over US stimulus package
summary: Japanese stocks dropped 0.44% to close at 23,567.04, tracking overnight US Wall Street losses, amid caution over a potential US stimulus package deadline. Investors refrained from taking big positions ahead of key events, including the US election and earnings results. The broader Topix lost 0.75% to 1,625.74, with profit-taking and uncertainty over US-EU trade talks contributing to the decline.

site_title: Espionage in Australia at higher levels than Cold War, spy chief warns
summary: Australia's spy chief warns that espionage in the country has surpassed Cold War levels, with foreign powers monitoring and harassing citizens, particularly diaspora groups from China and Hong Kong. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) chief, Michael Burgess, stated that this is an attack on Australia's sovereignty. Several politicians have been embroiled in investigations into suspected overseas influence operations, and the US has warned its ally against complacency. China's growing efforts to influence politics overseas have long concerned the US and other allies, including Australia and the Five Eyes intelligence-sharing alliance.

site_title: Foxconn says it will continue to work with Wisconsin to create jobs, woo investors
summary: Foxconn Technology Group, a Taiwan-based manufacturing company, reaffirmed its commitment to Wisconsin, stating it will continue to work with US President Donald Trump and the local government to create jobs and attract investment. Despite missing tax credit targets for the second year, Foxconn founder Terry Gou expressed his commitment to creating more jobs and attracting new investment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with small gains on Tuesday, driven by traders' optimism over US stimulus talks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.11% to 24,569.54, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains. The slight gains come ahead of a US deadline for an agreement on stimulus talks.

site_title: Japan regulators plan on-site probe of Tokyo exchange
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) plans an on-site investigation of the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) after a full-day trade suspension on October 1 due to a system failure. The TSE will draw up new rules on restarting trading by March next year. The FSA may issue a business improvement order based on the outcome of the investigation, following a report submitted by the TSE detailing the incident.

site_title: A centuries-old Korean style gets an update
summary: K-pop groups like BTS and Blackpink have popularized a modern take on traditional Korean hanbok clothing, boosting sales for designers who create updated versions of the centuries-old garment. Hanbok, which typically consists of a jacket, pants or skirt, has been reimagined for everyday wear, with designers incorporating traditional elements into contemporary designs. The trend is attributed to K-pop's "soft power," which has increased interest in Korean culture worldwide. Designers like Leesle and Danha have seen significant increases in visitors and sales after their pieces were featured on K-pop stars, and the hanbok has become a staple in modern fashion.

site_title: Japan's oldest mill turns to cleaner steel to take on China
summary: Japan's oldest steel mill, Nippon Steel, plans to transition to cleaner steel production by recycling steel from scrap in electric-arc furnaces to reduce costs and compete with Chinese mills. The move aims to cut carbon emissions and help the company expand in emerging Asian economies. With the cost of building an electric-arc furnace estimated at 20th of a blast furnace, Nippon Steel plans to utilize the resource while curtailing initial investment in facilities. The company aims to achieve zero carbon emissions by 2030 and 2050.

site_title: Six new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, with two from dorms and four imported
summary: Six new COVID-19 cases were confirmed in Singapore as of October 20, 2020, bringing the total to 57,921. The cases included two from workers' dormitories and four imported cases who had been placed on stay-home notices.

site_title: Stock market boom, new listings mint China billionaires at record pace
summary: China is creating new billionaires at a record pace due to booming share prices and new stock listings, despite the coronavirus pandemic. The Hurun China Rich List 2020 shows China's accelerated shift towards e-commerce, fintech, and new economy industries. Jack Ma retained the top spot, and the combined wealth of those on the list totals US$4 trillion, more than Germany's GDP. Five new dollar billionaires were created in China each week for the past year, with total wealth creation surpassing half of Britain's GDP.

site_title: Remy Cointreau raises H1 profit outlook as Q2 sales beat estimate
summary: Remy Cointreau raised its first-half core profit outlook after posting broader-than-expected second-quarter sales growth. The company's sales rose 4% in Q2, beating estimates, driven by robust demand for premium cognac in the US and China. Cognac sales fell 2.5%, slower than the 4.9% decline forecast, and the company now expects a 25-30% drop in six-month operating profit. Despite an uncertain economic environment, Remy Cointreau expects a strong recovery in the second half, driven by its two key markets.

site_title: Brookfield invests US$2b in biggest India property deal
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has invested US$2 billion in its largest Indian property deal, acquiring 12.5 million square feet of rent-yielding offices and co-working spaces from RMZ Corp. This is the biggest real estate deal in India and marks a significant expansion of Brookfield's portfolio in the country. The transaction is expected to reduce RMZ's debt to zero and enable the firm to expand its portfolio to 85 million square feet over the next six years. The deal highlights growing interest from foreign investors in India's office market, which has seen US$15.4 billion of equity investments since 2011.

site_title: Didi mulling 2021 Hong Kong IPO, targets valuation of more than US$60b: sources
summary: China's ride-hailing firm Didi Chuxing is considering a Hong Kong IPO in 2021 with a target valuation of over $60 billion, according to sources. The company, backed by SoftBank, Alibaba, and Tencent, has started talks with investment banks for the long-awaited IPO amid rising Sino-US tension, rethinking its previous aim to list in New York. Didi has been generating healthy profits since the second quarter of 2020 and some investors are keen to cash in, making the IPO a potential opportunity for them.

site_title: Thai economy faces severe shocks, slow recovery: central bank chief
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to face severe shocks from the coronavirus pandemic, with a predicted 7.8% contraction this year. The country's central bank governor, Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, stated that a recovery to pre-pandemic levels is expected to take at least two years. The tourism sector is expected to be particularly hard hit, with potential losses of 1.6 trillion baht (S$69.2 billion). The Bank of Thailand has predicted some growth in the second quarter of next year and will ensure monetary policy and liquidity support the recovery.

site_title: Impossible Foods launches for retail in Singapore, Hong Kong supermarkets
summary: Impossible Foods has launched its plant-based Impossible Beef in retail stores in Singapore and Hong Kong, marking its entry into the Asian market. The product is available at over 100 stores in Singapore, including NTUC FairPrice and online grocery delivery through RedMart, and at around 100 ParknShop outlets in Hong Kong. The launch comes as the company awaits approval from Chinese regulators for its key ingredient, heme, made from genetically modified yeast. The product is available in packages of 340 grammes, with a recommended retail price of S$16.90.

site_title: Malaysia Sime Darby said to mull health care unit spinoff in Malaysia
summary: Sime Darby Bhd, a Malaysian conglomerate, is considering spinning off its healthcare unit, Ramsay Sime Darby Health Care Sdn, into a separate listing on Malaysia's stock exchange. The move, which could raise at least 500 million ringgit (S$164 million), is at an early stage and details are still being discussed. This would be Sime Darby's second spinoff, following the listing of its plantation and property arms in 2017. The healthcare business has seen a 20% drop in net income due to the pandemic and one-off impairments.

site_title: Lowe's aims to be holiday destination with scooters, trampolines
summary: Lowe's plans to transform itself into a holiday destination by offering a range of products, including electric scooters, trampolines, and Ninja air fryers, both online and in select stores. This move comes as sales at the home-improvement chain have surged during the COVID-19 pandemic, with analysts predicting a 8.9% growth in November and December sales. By expanding its product offerings, Lowe's aims to capitalize on the trend of Americans spending more on home improvements during the holiday season.

site_title: Chinese firm BAIC's electric-vehicle unit bets on luxury model for comeback
summary: China's electric-vehicle unit BAIC BluePark New Energy Technology Co is launching a new high-end luxury model, the Arcfox, to revive its sales, which plummeted 80% in the first nine months of 2020. The company aims to resume year-on-year growth in 2021 with the new lineup, working with partners like Magna International and Huawei. The Arcfox aT will retail between $37,360 and $37,900 and is expected to put the company ahead of the competition. Total sales of new energy vehicles in China are predicted to rise by up to 30% next year.

site_title: S$420m in new investments in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Singapore's Jurong Innovation District has attracted S$420 million in new investments, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat highlighted the district's potential as a resilient base for advanced manufacturing. The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) is partnering the World Economic Forum (WEF) to establish Singapore's Smart Industry Readiness Index (SIRI) as an international standard for Industry 4.0 transformation. This move aims to further establish Singapore's leadership in advanced manufacturing and Industry 4.0 transformation.

site_title: Asia: Markets dip as US stimulus hopes fade ahead of deadline
summary: Asian markets declined as US stimulus hopes faded ahead of a deadline, tracking a Wall Street sell-off. Fading hopes for a US rescue package and concerns over virus infections weighed on markets. Analysts say lawmakers' haggling is unlikely to bear fruit until after the November 3 US election. With a House Speaker Nancy Pelosi deadline set for later in the day, US lawmakers' differences continue to narrow.

site_title: Pitt's 'Fight Club' jacket, 'Pretty Woman' boots up for sale in memorabilia auction
summary: Film fans can bid on nearly 1,000 movie memorabilia items, including Julia Roberts' "Pretty Woman" boots and Tom Cruise's "Top Gun" bomber jacket, in a December auction. The items, sourced by Prop Store boss Stephen Lane, include props from over 350 films and TV shows, with estimated values ranging from £400 to £120,000. The auction, due to the pandemic, will take place online or in Prop Store warehouses, with increased interest in movie memorabilia.

site_title: Restaurants and catering sector preparing for 'new normal': DBS Research
summary: DBS Research predicts 17-23% year-on-year sales declines for Singapore, Indonesia, and Hong Kong in the second half of 2020, while China and Thailand could experience milder declines of -1% and -8% respectively. Despite this, the report forecasts a 10%+ sales recovery in 2021, with China leading the way at 21% growth. Restaurant operators are adopting cost-cutting measures and refining business models to mitigate losses and capitalize on the rebound.

site_title: Got crystals? Gem mining could be your full-time job
summary: Gemstone prospecting is gaining popularity as a full-time career, with entrepreneurs and rockhounds finding success selling crystals and gemstones online. Pay-to-dig mines across the US offer visitors the chance to prospect for crystals and gemstones for as little as $10 a day. Some entrepreneurs, like Frank and Kyndall Stallings, have turned their passion into a business, selling crystals and gemstones on eBay and at local markets. Others, like Patrick and Samantha Krug, find crystals in their own backyard and sell them online, emphasizing the unique stories behind each find.

site_title: Britain's Asda targets 2040 for net zero carbon emissions
summary: Britain's supermarket group Asda has committed to generating zero carbon emissions by 2040, reducing waste by 50% by 2050, and achieving a net "regenerative impact on nature" by 2050. The pledge, made in response to growing consumer demands, aims to make greener options available to customers without increasing prices. Asda's move follows rival Sainsbury's commitment to net zero emissions by 2040, and is seen as a step towards addressing climate change, with over 80% of Asda's customers believing supermarkets have a responsibility to reduce single-use plastics.

site_title: UK to start one-hour Covid-19 tests at Heathrow from Tuesday: The Times
summary: The UK will introduce one-hour Covid-19 tests at Heathrow Airport starting Tuesday, allowing passengers to travel to countries requiring a negative test result to skip quarantine. Passengers can book a test in advance for £80 (S$140). The testing facilities, set up by Collinson and Swissport, will initially be open for four weeks and may be extended based on demand. Airlines such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic are among the first to offer the facility in Terminals 2 and 5.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.80 points, or 0.12%, to 1,519.90 on Tuesday, with a trading volume of 1.08 billion lots worth RM481.10 million.

site_title: SMEs tap Visa's support to bounce back from Covid-19
summary: Visa's "Where You Shop Matters" campaign aims to help Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) recover from the COVID-19 pandemic by encouraging local shopping. The campaign provides an e-commerce starter kit and partners with Shopee to promote local merchants. SMEs have seen increased online sales and exposure through the campaign, with some retailers experiencing a 250% surge in website traffic. Visa's initiative is part of its effort to support 10 million small and micro businesses in Asia Pacific and aims to create a "virtuous cycle" that benefits the wider community.

site_title: UBS posts doubling of Q3 profit in Ermotti's swan song
summary: UBS has reported a 99% jump in Q3 profit to $2.1 billion, exceeding analyst expectations. The bank's investment banking division saw strong performance, while wealth management earnings rose unexpectedly. This marks a notable sendoff for CEO Sergio Ermotti, who is stepping down in November, with former ING head Ralph Hamers taking over. The result contrasts with a mixed performance from US banks and highlights UBS's adaptability under Ermotti's leadership, which has focused on serving the world's rich.

site_title: JLC Advisors' Jeffrey Ong faces 19 more charges involving S$17.5m linked to HK-listed firm
summary: Singapore's JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong faces 19 additional charges related to misappropriating S$17.5 million from CW Group Holdings, a Singapore company. Ong allegedly removed funds from escrow accounts between 2015 and 2016 and deceived auditors, Ernst & Young, into believing the funds were still present. Ong now faces a total of 76 charges, having been in remand since last year.

images.alt_text: JLC Advisors' managing partner Jeffrey Ong Su Aun has allegedly misappropriated funds belonging to Hong Kong-listed company CW Group Holdings.

site_title: Suntec Reit prices S$200m perps at 3.8%
summary: Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Suntec Reit) priced S$200 million in subordinated perpetual securities at 3.8% per annum. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing, financing, or investments, as well as corporate purposes. The new perps are expected to be issued on October 27, subject to closing conditions. Distributions will be payable semi-annually starting April 27, 2021, with a reset rate to be determined based on the swap offer rate or alternative reference rate. OCBC is the sole lead manager for the issue.

site_title: Gold inches lower on caution over US coronavirus aid
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,901.16 per ounce due to caution ahead of the US coronavirus stimulus package deadline and the upcoming presidential election. Investors are on the sidelines, with a stimulus potentially pushing prices to the $1,882-$1,932 range. The US dollar index remained flat, while Asian stocks slipped as investors adjusted risk exposure. Silver fell 0.1%, platinum was steady, and palladium rose 0.1% amid uncertainty surrounding the election outcome.

site_title: Microphones to be muted in US presidential debate to stop interruptions
summary: The US Commission on Presidential Debates has announced that microphones of President Donald Trump and Democratic rival Joe Biden will be muted during their final debate, except when they are answering questions, to prevent interruptions. The candidates will have two minutes each to respond to moderator questions, with open discussion afterwards. Trump's campaign manager Bill Stepien reacted angrily to the announcement, stating that Trump would continue to raise unsubstantiated claims about Biden's son Hunter, despite the commission's efforts to promote civil discourse. The debate is scheduled for Thursday, the last time the two candidates face off before the November 3 election.

site_title: Singtel's Arthur Lang named chairman of National Kidney Foundation
summary: Singtel's CEO Arthur Lang will become the chairman of the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) on October 31, replacing Koh Poh Tiong. Lang brings commercial experience in corporate governance and risk management to the role. NKF oversees 4,800 needy patients with an annual operating expense of S$133 million. Lang is committed to corporate philanthropy, supporting vulnerable groups and online charitable engagements. His appointment reflects NKF's focus on sustaining its services and expanding support for the community.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday due to dwindling US stimulus package hopes and surging coronavirus cases in Europe. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.23% and the Topix index 0.25%, with the benchmark indices at 23,615.83 and 1,633.83 respectively.

site_title: US CDC issues 'strong recommendation' for mask mandate on airplanes, trains
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has issued a "strong recommendation" for mask mandates on airplanes, trains, subways, buses, taxis, and ride-share vehicles to prevent Covid-19 spread. The guidance also applies to transportation hubs like airports and train stations. The CDC aims to protect Americans and boost confidence in safe travel during the pandemic. This move follows recent updates in mask mandates, with the goal of reducing the transmission of the virus.

site_title: 500 new training opportunities and Industry 4.0 expertise-sharing platform launched
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) has launched 500 new training opportunities and an Industry 4.0 expertise-sharing platform, SGUnited Jobs and Skills for Advanced Manufacturing, in partnership with leading tech firms like Bosch and NVIDIA. The programme aims to upskill mid-career job-seekers in emerging technologies like collaborative robotics, additive manufacturing, and artificial intelligence. The initiatives also include a collaboration with the Asian Development Bank to form the Global Technology Innovation Village, sharing Singapore's Industry 4.0 knowledge and technology with regional governments and businesses.
