However, the US, Europe, and Japan's recoveries are proceeding cautiously, and China's authoritarian system played a role in its initial lockdown.

site_title: Seoul: Shares climb on US stimulus talks, drop in local virus cases
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.22% on Monday as optimism over US stimulus talks and declining local coronavirus cases lifted sentiment. The Kospi index gained 5.21 points to 2,346.74. Despite hopes of a US fiscal package, weaker-than-expected Chinese economic growth data capped gains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Monday due to hopes for a new US stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.64% to 24,542.26. In contrast, mainland Chinese markets fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.71% and the Shenzhen Composite Index down 0.70%. The slowest third-quarter growth rate for China since 2020 contributed to the decline.

site_title: The power picnic is spreading.
summary: The "power picnic" trend is gaining popularity, with companies offering high-end outdoor dining experiences. Inspired by luxury settings like Monet's "Luncheon on the Grass," these picnics often feature elaborate table settings, vintage items, and personalized touches. Companies like Gather Picnic Co and Perfect Picnic offer bespoke experiences, including food, decorations, and even photographers. The trend is driven by people seeking unique ways to celebrate milestones and milestones during the pandemic, with many opting for outdoor gatherings over traditional restaurants.

site_title: EU needs long-term plan to tackle 5G fake news, 15 EU countries say in joint call
summary: The European Union needs a long-term plan to counter disinformation about 5G technology, following a joint letter from 15 EU countries, including Poland and Sweden. Conspiracy theories linking 5G to the novel coronavirus have led to mobile phone mast torchings and assaults on maintenance workers in 10 European countries. The EU sees 5G as crucial to its economic recovery and digital goals, and the countries urge more scientific research, an awareness-raising campaign, and a broad debate to tackle the issue.

site_title: UK lockdowns: Wales and Manchester head towards tougher lockdowns
summary: The UK is poised to impose tougher lockdowns in Wales and Manchester, with 6 million people potentially affected, amid a surge in Covid-19 cases. The UK recorded 16,982 new daily cases, a 16% increase from the previous day. The lockdown threat comes after a public dispute between the UK government and Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham. Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick warned a lockdown could be imposed within days, citing concerns over the spread of the virus.

site_title: WWF Australia drones to drop seeds for koala gum trees
summary: WWF Australia is testing drones to drop seeds for gum trees, aiming to boost koala numbers on the east coast of Australia. The program, part of a $300 million initiative, seeks to restore bushland and forest habitat destroyed in the 2019-2020 bushfires, which killed or displaced three billion animals and destroyed up to seven billion trees. The drones can plant 40,000 seeds a day, creating corridors for wildlife to move across fragmented landscapes. The goal is to double koala numbers by 2025, as a parliamentary inquiry warned the species could become extinct by 2050.

images.alt_text: Gum tree leaves are koala's main food source, and restoring bushland and forest habitat razed in the 2019-2020 fires is key to their long-term survival in New South Wales state.

site_title: Irish regulator probes Facebook's handling of children's data on Instagram
summary: Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC) has launched two inquiries into Facebook's handling of children's data on Instagram, following complaints and concerns about the social network's processing of minors' personal data. The inquiries focus on whether Facebook has adequate protections in place and whether Instagram's profile settings comply with data protection requirements. The DPC's power to impose fines under the EU's General Data Protection Regulation's "One Stop Shop" regime could be up to 4% of Facebook's global revenue or 20 million euros.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical proposes up to S$10.3m share placement
summary: Jiutian Chemical proposes a non-underwritten share placement of up to 170 million new shares at 6.03 Singapore cents apiece, raising up to S$10.3 million for general working capital. The placement is expected to strengthen the firm's financial position and improve its shareholder profile. The shares will represent about 8.55% of the enlarged issued share capital, and the company will pay a placement commission of 2.25% to the placement agent.

site_title: Japan to join forces with US, Europe in regulating Big Tech firms
summary: Japan's Fair Trade Commission chairman Kazuyuki Furuya announced plans to join forces with the US and Europe to regulate Big Tech firms. The move aims to combat market abuses by companies like Google, Apple, Amazon, and Facebook. Furuya stated that Japan could open a probe into any merger or business tie-up involving Fitbit if the size of such deals is big enough. The FTC will work closely with its US and European counterparts to respond to any moves that harm competition, and conduct research into Japan's mobile phone market to spur competition and help reduce mobile phone charges.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to operate less than 50% of pre-pandemic capacity in 2021
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects to operate less than 50% of its pre-pandemic passenger flight capacity in 2021 due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The airline plans to operate around 10% for the remainder of 2020 and assumes a recovery in the second half of 2021 if vaccines prove effective. The airline has not yet announced major job losses despite a strategic review, but is expected to implement staff redundancies and pay cuts. Cathay's passenger numbers fell by 98.1% in September compared to the previous year.

site_title: Philips Q3 results top estimates on strong Covid-19 demand
summary: Philips reported strong Q3 results, beating analyst estimates with 10% growth in comparable sales to 4.98 billion euros, driven by a 42% increase in connected care division sales. Adjusted EBITA rose to 769 million euros, surpassing expectations. The company attributed the growth to increased demand for hospital equipment to treat Covid-19 patients and consumer products during the pandemic. Philips now expects 5-6% average annual sales growth from 2021 to 2025, with a 60-80 basis point improvement in adjusted EBITA margin.

site_title: Julius Baer sees profitability rise on client trading, cost cuts
summary: Swiss wealth manager Julius Baer reported an improvement in profitability for the first nine months of 2020, driven by increased client trading and cost cuts. Client activity and stock market recovery helped stem a fall in managed assets, with assets under management rising 3% to 413 billion Swiss francs. The bank's adjusted cost-income ratio improved to 66.1% and gross margins remained consistent with levels seen in May and June. Shares were up 2.1% in pre-market trading.

site_title: China's Jan-Sept property investment rises 5.6% y-o-y
summary: China's real estate investment in January to September rose 5.6% year-over-year, accelerating from the 4.6% growth seen in the first eight months. Property sales by floor area dropped 1.8% in the first nine months, while new construction starts fell 3.4%. Funds raised by property developers grew 4.4%, contrasting with a 3.0% growth in the first eight months. Analysts expect a sustainable rebound to be less likely due to soft consumer confidence and policy curbs in place.

site_title: Renault aims to turn US$80,000 sports-car line into a mini Ferrari
summary: Renault's Italian-born CEO, Luca de Meo, aims to turn the struggling sports-car brand Alpine into a Ferrari rival, with plans to expand the brand and increase production. Despite selling only 1,000 A110 sports cars this year, de Meo sees potential for growth, particularly after re-branding Renault's Formula One team as Alpine for the 2021 season. The goal is to increase Alpine's presence in the market and potentially challenge Ferrari's dominance.

images.alt_text: Renault SA's Italian-born chief executive has an impossible-sounding ambition: to build a sports-car brand barely brought back to life into a Ferrari fighter.

site_title: South Korea's 40 trillion won rescue fund sells debt as airlines seek help
summary: South Korea's 40 trillion won Key Industry Stabilization Fund is selling its first bonds, worth 200 billion won, to support struggling airlines. The bonds, guaranteed by the government, are part of a fund established to prevent major companies from going bankrupt during the Covid-19 pandemic. Asiana Airlines received 2.4 trillion won from the fund after its stake sale collapsed, and Korean Air Lines is also seeking financial support. The sale of bonds could strain the government bond market, which is already planning record issuance this year.

site_title: Lufax may find three's a China fintech IPO crowd
summary: Lufax, a Chinese fintech company, may face challenges in its initial public offering (IPO) due to competition from other fintech companies, including Ant and JD.com's fintech arm. Despite successfully pivoting to a more stable business model, Lufax's valuation and growth rate are lower compared to its peers. Lufax has chosen to list its shares in New York, where valuations are lower, and its business is more focused on facilitating loans, which concentrates regulatory risk. The company aims to raise about $3 billion in its IPO.

site_title: Japan, Vietnam reach broad agreement on transfer of defence gear
summary: Japan and Vietnam agreed on a broad agreement to strengthen security and economic ties, including a deal in principle for Japan to export military gear and technology to Vietnam. The agreement aims to counter China's regional assertiveness and promote a free and open Indo-Pacific. Both countries also agreed on maintaining peace and freedom of navigation in the South China Sea. The deal is seen as a key step in Japan's efforts to diversify its supply chains and reduce reliance on China.

site_title: Can foreign investment in Indonesia's upstream oil and gas sector live up to expectations?
summary: Foreign investment in Indonesia's upstream oil and gas sector has failed to meet expectations, with declining investments and decaying facilities. The country's regulatory environment is challenging, ranking 73rd in the World Bank's Ease of Doing Business Rankings and 85th in Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index. Despite ambitious targets and government efforts to simplify the licensing regime, the sector remains plagued by bureaucracy and uncertainty. However, the government's willingness to adapt and meet investor concerns, such as the creation of a new oil and gas agency and revisions to the production sharing contract regulation, suggests a potential for growth and investment in the sector.

images.alt_text: Commuters making their way to downtown Jakarta, Indonesia.

site_title: Brokers' take: Singtel dividends to get boost from associate's 10.3t rupiah tower sale, says DBS
summary: Singtel is expected to receive approximately S$333 million in pre-tax contributions from its Indonesian associate after selling 6,050 telecommunication towers to Dayamitra Telekomunikasi for S$950 million. This sale is part of a 10-year leaseback arrangement, with Telkomsel, Singtel's 35% stakeholder, renting tower space from Mitratel, the new tower owner. The sale is expected to support Singtel's dividend payments, with DBS Group Research projecting S$2 billion in dividends for FY21.

site_title: Sustainable winemaking is a zoo with armadillos, falcons and pigs
summary: Tablas Creek winery in Paso Robles, California, is pioneering sustainable winemaking by employing a menagerie of animals to replace toxic pesticides and herbicides. The winery, certified regenerative organic, uses sheep, donkeys, Spanish mastiffs, owls, chickens, and pigs to maintain vineyard health. Other wineries worldwide, such as Yealands in New Zealand and Vergenoegd Low in South Africa, also utilize unique animals like armadillos, Norwegian Fjord Horses, and Indian Runner ducks to control pests and promote biodiversity. These eco-friendly approaches aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change.

site_title: Singapura Finance to invest US$3m in MatchMove PowerBank
summary: Singapura Finance is investing US$3 million in MatchMove PowerBank, a subsidiary of digital payments startup MatchMove Pay, in support of establishing and growth. The investment includes US$1 million in equity financing and US$2 million in convertible debt financing. Following completion, Singapura Finance will hold approximately 10% of PowerBank's share capital. The deal aligns with Singapura Finance's strategic goal to invest in the fintech sector, which it believes offers growth opportunities in the financial services sector.

site_title: Gold steadies at US$1,900 as US stimulus hopes support
summary: Gold steadied at US$1,900 per ounce, supported by hopes for US stimulus ahead of the presidential election, despite a firmer US dollar. US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi expressed optimism about a coronavirus relief package, which could boost gold prices. Economists expect gold to trade cautiously around the US$1,900 level, citing stimulus measures as a factor in its 25% year-to-date rise.

images.alt_text: A firmer US dollar held back gold near the US$1,900 per ounce psychological level on Monday even as US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi raised hopes for a coronavirus relief package before the presidential election.

site_title: Jurong Point, FairPrice's Aljunied outlet added to list of places visited by infectious Covid-19 patients
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore has released a list of locations visited by infectious Covid-19 patients, including Jurong Point and a FairPrice outlet in Aljunied. These locations were visited for at least 30 minutes, and individuals who were present during the same time period are being monitored for two weeks. The full list of locations and times is available on the gov.sg website. This move aims to help track the spread of the virus and ensure public safety.

images.alt_text: MOH confirmed four new imported cases of Covid-19 on Oct 19, 2020.

site_title: Indonesia's Jan-Sept fiscal deficit at 4.16% of GDP on higher spending
summary: Indonesia's budget deficit for the first nine months of 2020 reached 4.16% of GDP, totaling 682.1 trillion rupiah (S$63.22 billion). The government has forecast a wider fiscal deficit of 6.34% of GDP for 2020 due to increased spending on the Covid-19 pandemic response. Total spending increased 15.5% from the same period in 2019, while revenue declined 13.7%. The government aims to utilize its bond sale agreement to finance vaccine procurement, with the central bank meeting 58% of its targeted bond purchases.

site_title: French food group Danone launches portfolio review to cope with Covid-19 world
summary: Danone, the world's largest yoghurt maker, is launching a portfolio review to cope with the challenges of the coronavirus pandemic. The company aims to rapidly reconnect with its mid-term sales growth goal of 3-5%. It also reinstated its 2020 forecasts, targeting a 14% recurring operating margin and 1.8 billion euros of free cash flow. Following a 2.5% drop in like-for-like third quarter sales, Danone is reshaping its management and exploring strategic options for assets, including a North American plant-based brand.

site_title: Thai Sept domestic car sales fall 4.1% y-o-y: industry federation
summary: Thailand's domestic car sales declined 4.1% year-over-year in September, reaching 77,433 vehicles, for the 16th consecutive month due to the coronavirus outbreak. However, sales rose 12.4% from August, driven by easing virus restrictions, government relief measures, and new car model launches. Thailand remains a significant vehicle production and export hub for major automobile manufacturers.

site_title: Panama offers Covid-19 tests to international travellers
summary: Panama has begun offering Covid-19 tests to international travelers arriving at its main airport. The tests, a Sofia SARS Antigen Fluorescent Immunoassay, aim to prevent new cases as Europe and the US experience a resurgence. Following a seven-month suspension, international flights resumed on October 12. This measure is part of efforts to control the spread of the virus, particularly in a region considered a transportation hub.

site_title: E-motorbike startup ION Mobility raises US$3.3m in seed funds
summary: ION Mobility, a Singapore-based startup, has secured US$3.3 million in seed funding to launch its electric motorbike in Indonesia in 2021 and expand regionally. The funding was led by venture firms Monk's Hill Ventures, TNB Aura, and 500 Startups' South-east Asia-focused fund. ION Mobility aims to develop in-house capabilities, build supply chain partnerships, and launch its first motorbike in Indonesia, with plans to expand to Singapore, Jakarta, and Shenzhen. The startup's founders, James Chan and Joel Chang, bring technical, domain, and market expertise to the table.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Monday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.73% to 24,565.43, driven by investors monitoring US stimulus talks. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with gains of 0.44% and 0.67%, respectively. The positive start follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Alibaba shops for hypermarket chain Sun Art in US$3.6b deal
summary: Alibaba Group Holdings has agreed to invest US$3.6 billion in hypermarket operator Sun Art Retail Group, increasing its stake to around 72% and solidifying its presence in China's offline retail market. The move aims to leverage Alibaba's digital presence to support Sun Art's 481 hypermarkets and three mid-size supermarkets. Alibaba chairman Daniel Zhang stated that the investment aligns with the company's "New Retail vision" to serve consumers with a fully integrated experience. Shares of Sun Art soared over 20% following the announcement.

site_title: A kimchi disaster is brewing after cabbage fields crippled
summary: A series of typhoons in South Korea this summer has devastated cabbage fields, leading to a kimchi shortage and price surge of over 60%. The extreme weather has crippled the country's kimchi production, forcing households to pay exorbitant prices for the essential ingredient. This is a significant blow to South Korea's kimchi-making tradition, which relies on cabbages for months to ferment into the country's favorite dish. The shortage is expected to have a lasting impact on the kimchi industry, with prices likely to remain high for the foreseeable future.

site_title: China's Q3 GDP grows 4.9% y-o-y, misses expectations
summary: China's Q3 GDP grew 4.9% year-over-year, missing analyst expectations of 5.2%, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics. This follows 3.2% growth in the second quarter and 0.7% growth for the first nine months. The slower-than-expected growth is part of China's steady recovery from the coronavirus shock, driven by government measures such as fiscal spending, tax relief, and lending rate cuts.

site_title: Iata working with WHO and civil aviation body on testing regime
summary: IATA is collaborating with the WHO and International Civil Aviation Organization to establish a testing system, aiming to replace compulsory quarantine and revive the airline industry. The testing regime, designed to be scalable, affordable, and fast, will be implemented before departure. IATA's goal is to reduce quarantine requirements, particularly for countries with similar COVID-19 risk levels, such as Singapore and Hong Kong, thereby lifting further testing requirements.

site_title: Opec+ faces growing pressure to change course as ministers meet grant
summary: OPEC+ ministers are meeting to assess the global oil market amid growing pressure to revise their plan to ease output cuts. The cartel has already relaxed its cuts by 2 million barrels a day and is set to add another 1.9 million in January, but influential voices are warning against the planned increase due to fragile market conditions. With global demand recovering to 94% of pre-pandemic levels and Libya's production surging, OPEC+ is under pressure to prevent a market "relapse" and maintain prices above current levels. A decision on the planned increase will be made in six weeks.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on US stimulus hope, China growth falls short
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, driven by hopes for a new US stimulus package, despite China's slower-than-forecast economic growth. US lawmakers face a Tuesday deadline to reach a coronavirus support agreement, with talks stalled. US President Donald Trump urged his party to offer more than their proposed $1.8 trillion, while Democrats proposed $2.2 trillion. The rally was short-lived in Shanghai and Hong Kong, which pared their gains after the China data.

site_title: Teho director resigns amid CAD probe involving New Silkroutes
summary: Independent director Kelvyn Oo of Teho Intl resigned amid a Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) probe involving New Silkroutes, a healthcare provider. Oo, 49, cited a change in personal focus to quit, despite assisting with the investigation into possible false trading and market rigging. The probe is not related to Teho and will not affect its business operations. A suitable candidate will replace Oo on the audit committee by January 16, 2021.

site_title: China's Sept industrial output rises 6.9% y-o-y; retail sales up 3.3%
summary: China's industrial output rose 6.9% in September from a year earlier, marking the sixth consecutive month of expansion. Retail sales also increased 3.3% year-over-year, beating forecasts. Fixed asset investment grew 0.8% in the first nine months of the year, exceeding expectations. These positive economic indicators suggest China's economy is continuing to recover from the coronavirus shock.

site_title: EU-US alliance 'on life support' after four years of Trump
summary: The US-EU alliance is severely strained after four years of Donald Trump's presidency, with many Europeans viewing the US as a foe due to its withdrawal from international agreements and protectionist policies. Recent surveys show a record low of 26% of Germans holding a favorable view of the US, and experts predict that the relationship will not improve even if Joe Biden wins the November election. Trump's abrasive foreign policy and domestic issues have damaged the transatlantic relationship, with some experts suggesting that the EU may become more united in the face of a rising China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.91 points, or 0.26%, to 1,507.75 on Monday, driven by gains. The index saw a volume of 313.03 million lots worth RM115.72 million. Gainers outpaced losers 298 to 79.

site_title: China regulator approves Ant Group's Hong Kong IPO: IFR
summary: China's securities regulator has approved Ant Group's Hong Kong leg of a planned dual-listing worth up to US$30 billion. Ant Group, backed by Alibaba Group, plans to seek listing approval from Hong Kong's stock exchange and has also received approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission for its Shanghai leg. This move is part of Ant's plan to become the world's largest initial public offering (IPO).

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as coronavirus curbs ease in Victoria; New Zealand flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Monday, led by miners and financials, after Victoria state eased its coronavirus lockdown and the US House Speaker expressed optimism about a coronavirus relief package. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,223.20, with BHP Group and Rio Tinto gaining 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat, while Crown Resorts fell 9% after a financial crime watchdog launched a probe into its Melbourne business.

site_title: SK Jewellery suspends trading after close of privatisation offer
summary: SK Jewellery Group suspended trading of its shares on October 19, 2020, after the close of a voluntary cash offer that received valid acceptances representing 97.8% of issued shares. The offeror, OroGreen Investment, had launched an offer to take the jeweller private at S$0.15 per share, and the company will compulsorily acquire remaining shares at the same price. The offer closed on October 16, after which the founders requested a trading suspension.

site_title: Mining billionaire Forrest buys famed Australian bootmaker RM Williams
summary: Australian mining billionaire Andrew Forrest's private company, Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, has acquired RM Williams, a famed Australian bootmaker, from a French fashion giant's fund, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE, after six years of foreign ownership. The deal, valued at approximately A$190 million, brings back the manufacturing icon to its home country. Forrest praised RM Williams' long history of high-quality Australian craftsmanship and plans to keep the manufacturing operations intact.

images.alt_text: Australian mining billionaire Andrew Forrest said his private company bought bootmaker RM Williams from a fund backed by French fashion giant LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE, returning ownership of the famed fashion label to its home country after six years.

site_title: Singapore 'firing on all cylinders' to attract MNCs; capabilities can be acquired over time: Chan
summary: Singapore is actively attracting multinational companies (MNCs) to create jobs and strengthen its labor market. Recent investments by Thermo Fisher Scientific and Hyundai Motor Group demonstrate the country's capabilities in various industries. The electronics industry, in particular, is a bright spot, with S$5.7 billion of fixed assets investment and S$376 million of total business expenditure expected to create 1,100 jobs over the next three to five years. Despite this, there is a low take-up rate of job opportunities, with only 220 individuals being placed out of 2,800 identified. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized that Singapore's capabilities can be acquired over time, and the country should not be deterred from bringing in new investments.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing and Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo at GlobalFoundries Singapore Pte Ltd on Monday, Oct 19, 2020.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit to buy 58 UK properties for £212.5m from sponsor
summary: Elite Commercial Reit plans to acquire 58 UK properties for £212.5m from its sponsor, Elite UK Commercial Fund II. The assets are leased to the UK government via various agencies and have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet. The acquisition is expected to increase the Reit's size, market capitalization, and free float, with a distribution per unit accretion of 3.2%. The properties provide stable cash flows and attractive recession-proof yields, and will maintain the Reit's exposure to UK sovereign tenants.

images.alt_text: ELITE Commercial Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) rose by 20.3 per cent to 1.48 pence for its third quarter ended Sep 30, from 1.23 pence a year ago.
29 Newport Road in Cardiff, Wales, one of the freehold assets the Reit is looking to acquire. About 99 per cent of the properties' leases are signed with the UK government.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.84% and the Topix index up 0.75%. Investors were influenced by bargain-hunting purchases amid a close watch on a fresh US stimulus package and the global coronavirus situation. The gains came despite US-EU trade tensions and ongoing tariff threats.

site_title: Key battlegrounds to decide US election
summary: The US presidential election is narrowing down to six key battleground states: Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, Florida, North Carolina, and Arizona. According to state polls, Democratic candidate Joe Biden leads President Donald Trump by narrow margins in these states, with Biden's average lead across the six states at 5.3 percentage points. The Rust Belt state of Pennsylvania, Biden's birth state, is a crucial battleground, while Michigan, Wisconsin, and Arizona are also considered key. Trump trails Biden in three other states he won in 2016, including Georgia, Iowa, and Ohio.

site_title: Australia's CIMIC to sell 50% of Thiess to Elliott
summary: CIMIC Group has agreed to sell 50% of its Thiess mining services business to Elliott Management, valuing the unit at A$4.3 billion. CIMIC expects a pre-tax gain of around A$2.2 billion and a post-tax gain of around A$1.4 billion from the stake sale.

site_title: Japan's Sept exports fall 4.9% y-o-y
summary: Japan's exports fell 4.9% in September from the previous year, a slower decline than in August, as the coronavirus pandemic's pressure eased. This followed a 14.8% drop in August. Imports dropped 17.2% in the year to September, exceeding the median estimate of a 21.4% decline. The trade balance turned into a surplus of 675 billion yen, higher than the median estimate of 989.8 billion yen.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 9.97 points or 0.4% to 2,542.99. Investors pushed stocks higher after Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 5.9% in September. Local banks gained ground, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC advancing 0.7-0.3%. US stocks ended the week mixed, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 closing at 0.4% and 0.1% gains, respectively.

site_title: Biolidics issues letter of demand to biochip partner Sysmex over IP matters
summary: Biolidics, a medtech firm, has issued a letter of demand to Japanese company Sysmex Corporation, alleging that Sysmex breached intellectual property (IP) agreements. The 2016 collaboration agreement involved joint development of biochips, but Sysmex has filed patent applications in the US, China, Japan, and Europe containing Biolidics' IP. Biolidics claims Sysmex has used technical information and know-how without permission, damaging their joint development. The exact nature of the breaches is unclear, but Biolidics is seeking compensation for the IP infringement.

site_title: Bank of Japan to stand pat, extend Covid-19 programme in coming months: survey
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to keep its policy steady and extend its Covid-19 response measures by January at the latest, according to a survey of 43 economists. The central bank will likely maintain its existing economic forecasts and only slightly tweak its growth outlook. Only 5% of respondents expect the bank to extend the deadline for two virus-linked funding programs, while 95% expect a decision by January. The move aims to support the economy, with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga planning to compile an extra budget by the end of the year.

site_title: Oil prices little changed ahead of China GDP data
summary: Oil prices remained little changed ahead of China's GDP data release, with Brent crude rising 4 cents to $42.97 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $40.90 a barrel. China's economy is expected to show a 5.2% growth in the third quarter, offsetting concerns of a virus resurgence on consumption. However, oil-buying frenzy is expected to slow in the fourth quarter due to high inventories and limited import quotas. The Joint Technical Committee warned of a potential oil surplus in 2021, threatening Opec's plans to taper record output cuts.

site_title: Federal Reserve, central banks will find exit from massive stimulus impeded
summary: The Federal Reserve and other central banks face challenges in scaling back stimulus measures due to investor and lawmakers' expectations of cheap money. The "no-exit paradigm" may hinder monetary authorities' efforts to throttle back quantitative easing and other stimulus measures, potentially leading to asset bubbles and inflation. Central banks and governments' close coordination during the pandemic has created a delicate situation, with the risk of diverging interests and the potential for the Fed to struggle with trimming its balance sheet.

site_title: China's next problem: recycling 26 million tons of discarded clothes
summary: China faces a significant problem with its discarded clothes, with 26 million tons of garments thrown away annually, less than 1% of which are reused or recycled. The stigma of wearing old or second-hand clothes, combined with a boom in e-commerce, has turned China into the world's biggest fashion market, prioritizing fast fashion over sustainability. Recycling clothing is unprofitable by law, and most garments are sold overseas, with China's exports rising to 6.4% of the world total in 2015. Only 15% of donations are given to poor regions in China, and the environmental cost of this waste is huge, with the fashion industry accounting for around 10% of global carbon emissions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Biolidics, Keppel DC Reit, DBS, SATS, Metech
summary: Singapore Post (SingPost) plans to buy a 38% stake in Freight Management Holdings for A$85 million (S$84.1 million) in cash. Biolidics issued a letter of demand to Japan-based Sysmex Corporation over breached intellectual property obligations under a collaboration agreement. No other developments were reported for the listed companies mentioned.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines restructuring talks prolonged, CEO tells staff
summary: Malaysia Airlines' parent company, Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG), is prolonging restructuring talks with lessors and creditors to keep the airline afloat. The talks, which were initially planned to be completed sooner, are now taking longer than expected. Despite this, MAG's CEO, Izham Ismail, stated that the airline is gaining "encouraging traction" from the lessors and creditors. The airline is seeking to restructure after the COVID-19 pandemic forced it to slash operations, and a recent plan was rejected by a group of lessors. MAG's subsidiary, Firefly Airlines, will start flying in early 2021 as part of a realigned business strategy.

site_title: Anti-Amazon Shopify takes flight amid e-commerce boom
summary: Shopify, a Canadian e-commerce platform, has seen significant growth amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with a 71% increase in new stores created in the second quarter of 2020. Founded in 2006, Shopify has become a thriving alternative to Amazon, allowing businesses to create an online presence in just a few clicks. The platform now boasts over 1 million e-stores in 175 countries, and has attracted established brands such as Pepsi, Unilever, and Lindt chocolates. Shopify's share price has tripled since March, making it Canada's most valuable company.

site_title: British woman accuses UAE minister of sexual assault: report
summary: A British woman, Caitlin McNamara, 32, has accused UAE Minister Sheikh Nahyan bin Mubarak Al Nahyan of sexual assault in February. The alleged incident occurred when she visited the minister at a private island villa on Valentine's Day. McNamara has waived her anonymity and made a formal complaint to Scotland Yard, who are investigating as an allegation of rape. Sheikh Nahyan has denied any wrongdoing, and his lawyers claim the account is false and arrived eight months after the incident via a national newspaper.

site_title: Mourinho questions Tottenham's mental strength after West Ham collapse
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Jose Mourinho expressed concern over his team's mental strength after a 3-3 draw with West Ham United, in which Spurs collapsed from a 3-0 lead with eight minutes remaining. The team's defensive shortcomings allowed West Ham to stage a remarkable comeback, with Manuel Lanzini scoring the equalizer in the 94th minute. Mourinho attributed the loss to his team's inability to cope with the psychological pressure of the situation, saying "my guys were not strong enough" to maintain their lead.

site_title: EU's first social debt set for surefire success in hungry market
summary: The European Commission is set to sell its first social bonds, tied to a regional job support programme called SURE, as early as this week. The move aims to counter the devastating impact of the coronavirus. Sales of social bonds have recently enabled borrowers to lower costs, driven by investor demand for sustainable finance offerings. The European Commission is expected to sell 10 billion euros of debt per month, making social debt the fastest-growing sustainable finance market.

site_title: Europe surges past 250,000 virus deaths as Israel lifts lockdown
summary: Europe has surpassed 250,000 deaths from coronavirus, with a 44% increase in cases this week. In response, several countries have implemented strict measures, including night-time curfews in France and mask-wearing in Switzerland. Israel has lifted its lockdown, reopening kindergartens and national parks, while Melbourne, Australia, has allowed its residents to leave their homes for more than two hours a day. The European region is now the second hardest hit, with Latin America and the Caribbean having surpassed 350,000 fatalities.

site_title: Trump and Biden hit the trail in a charged election week
summary: US President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden intensified their campaigns, with Trump embarking on a multi-state tour to regain lost ground and Biden focusing on key battleground states. Trump raised unsubstantiated allegations against Biden, while Biden emphasized unity and truth. The two men will face off in a final televised debate on Thursday, which could be decisive in the election. With Trump trailing in polls, analysts suggest he should focus on the economy, but he instead continues to stoke controversy, including attacks on his handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Why people shell out big bucks to eat on grounded planes
summary: Singapore Airlines is offering a unique dining experience on two of its Airbus 380s at Changi Airport, charging $642 per person for a suite, $321 for business class, $96.30 for premium economy, and $53.50 for economy. The experience includes meals, drinks, and in-flight entertainment, with business class and suites proving the most popular among those who could afford it. The airline aims to generate publicity and capture new revenue streams, with food and beverage costs factored into the costs.

site_title: Emerging-market bond fund screening for ESG factors
summary: A US$1.5 billion emerging-market bond fund, Candriam SRI Bond Emerging Markets Fund, is avoiding investments in Russia, China, and Saudi Arabia due to low ESG ratings. The fund screens for environmental, social, and governance risks and excludes countries with low scores, currently excluding 33 emerging markets. This approach may become more common as investors increasingly demand higher risk premia for ESG-related risks, and sovereign borrowing costs may start to take into account factors such as carbon emissions and corruption.

site_title: Viking Offshore plans S$4m share placement as part of proposed creditors scheme.
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine plans to raise S$4 million through a share placement as part of its proposed creditors scheme to restructure debts and liabilities. The company has entered into a binding conditional term sheet with three investors, including businessman Li Suet Man, Blue Ocean Capital Partners, and Viking's CEO Ng Yeau Chong, who will subscribe for new shares equivalent to 65.25%, 15.225%, and 6.525% of the enlarged issued shares. The proceeds will be used to repay debt, professional fees, and working capital needs.

site_title: SingPost to buy stake in Australia fourth-party logistics service firm for A$85m
summary: SingPost is acquiring a 38% stake in Australian fourth-party logistics firm Freight Management Holdings (FMH) for A$85 million (S$84.1 million). The acquisition, through SingPost Logistics Holdings, will set up a new Australian holding company to hold FMH shares. The deal includes a call option for SingPost to buy additional shares, potentially giving it a majority stake.

site_title: Economists lower growth forecasts despite Jakarta reopening
summary: Economists have lowered growth forecasts for Indonesia despite Jakarta's reopening from Covid-19 restrictions. Citi economist Helmi Arman reduced its GDP expectation for 2021 to 4% from 5.6%, citing oscillations in economic activity due to rising infections. DBS economist Radhika Rao expects fiscal policy to take over from monetary policy, with a contraction in the third quarter followed by a smaller fall in the fourth quarter. Indonesia's finance ministry has also lowered its official projection to between -1.7% and -0.6% for 2020.

site_title: China gives Shenzhen greater autonomy to attract investment
summary: China has granted Shenzhen greater autonomy to attract investment, with reforms including financial markets, intellectual property protection, and talent attraction. The move aims to elevate Shenzhen as a tech and financial hub, rivaling Tokyo Bay or Silicon Valley. The city is home to leading technology giants like Huawei and Tencent, and is part of Beijing's plan to integrate with Hong Kong and Macau. Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized the need for autonomy and protection of foreign investors' interests in a speech commemorating Shenzhen's 40th anniversary as a special economic zone.

site_title: Gulf currency pegs offer silver lining in era of weaker US$
summary: Gulf Arab nations' currency pegs may benefit from a declining US dollar, which could boost non-oil industries like tourism once the pandemic eases. Unlike previous periods of weak US dollar, current sluggish domestic demand has limited price growth. The pegs, established in the early 1970s, have helped shield economies from energy market volatility and allowed central banks to accumulate foreign-currency reserves. Experts say the decline in the dollar will be positive for the Gulf Cooperation Council once the pandemic impact softens, and the pegs remain an important anchor to the economy and capital inflows.

site_title: Hello You - Israeli-UAE joint song a YouTube hit
summary: Israeli singer Elkana Marziano and Emirati artist Walid Aljasim have collaborated on a joint song, "Ahlan Bik" or "Hello You," marking the first musical collaboration between Israel and the UAE. The song, which combines Arabic, Hebrew, and English, has gained over 1.1 million YouTube views. The collaboration reflects the normalization of ties between the two countries, announced in August and approved by Israel's parliament last week. The song's release has sparked both celebration and criticism, with some praising the new era of cooperation and others condemning the deal and calling for a Palestinian state.

site_title: Remote work forces rethink on flexi-work penalty
summary: A recent Law Society study on gender diversity in the legal profession found that flexible work arrangements traditionally hurt female lawyers, but the COVID-19 pandemic has changed this dynamic, allowing women in the industry to be acknowledged for their work from home. This shift could bring about positive changes in the industry's perception of flexible work arrangements, potentially benefiting women lawyers.

site_title: Crown Resorts says financial crime agency to probe Melbourne unit
summary: Crown Resorts announced that the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre (AUSTRAC) has initiated a formal investigation into the compliance of its Melbourne business with anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing rules. The investigation follows AUSTRAC's regulatory operations branch identifying potential non-compliance. The company did not provide further details on the nature of the issue.

images.alt_text: Australia's Crown Resorts said on Monday the financial crime watchdog had started a formal investigation into compliance of the casino operator's Melbourne business.

site_title: Law Society study flags gender bias in legal profession
summary: A study by the Law Society in Singapore found pervasive unconscious bias may be preventing women from attaining senior positions in the legal profession. The study suggests that even when two candidates have identical qualifications, experience, and demeanour, a woman is less likely to be hired than a man. This bias may be linked to a culture of bullying in the industry, which has yet to be addressed. The study highlights the need for the legal profession to address these issues to promote greater representation of women.

site_title: More uncertainty amid US polls, Brexit, vaccine issues
summary: The world is experiencing uncertainty as the US presidential election, Brexit negotiations, and COVID-19 vaccine development continue to unfold. US stocks remain near record levels despite volatile weeks, with the US Federal Reserve and vaccine developers offering some relief. Polls show a wide lead for Joe Biden, but a "contested election" could lead to renewed civil unrest and market volatility. Meanwhile, the COVID-19 crisis is worsening, with cases surging in the US and Europe, and economic growth is slowing due to pandemic-related restrictions.

site_title: Dysons sell Wallich Residence penthouse to tycoon Leo Koguan for S$62m
summary: The Dyson family, owners of the British consumer electronics company, is selling their triplex penthouse at Wallich Residence in Singapore for S$62 million, approximately S$3,000 per square foot. The buyer is Leo Koguan, a US-born Indonesian tycoon and chairman of IT provider SHI International. Industry observers consider the sale price reasonable due to the cautious business sentiment amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The Dysons' decision may also be attributed to the convenience and amenities of living in a mixed-use development versus the exclusivity of a freehold penthouse.

site_title: Turkey says Black Sea gas find bigger than first thought
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan announced that a Black Sea gas field discovered in August is now estimated to be 405 billion cubic meters, significantly larger than the initial estimate of 320 billion cubic meters. The discovery could help Turkey reduce its dependence on imported energy, particularly from Russia, and could start being pumped into homes in 2023. Analysts have urged caution due to the high cost of deep-sea drilling, but Turkey plans to proceed with exploration in the eastern Mediterranean, defying calls from NATO members.

site_title: ARA unit awarded £3b affordable housing guarantee scheme in UK
summary: ARA Asset Management's subsidiary, ARA Venn, has been appointed to manage a £3 billion Affordable Housing Guarantee Scheme by the UK Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government. The scheme aims to deliver 17,000 critical homes for lower-income families, alleviating the housing affordability issue. ARA Venn will provide £3 billion of cost-effective long-term loans to registered providers, with an option to increase to £6 billion. This deepens ARA's collaborative relationship with the UK government, supporting the sustainable development of its housing sector.

site_title: Coffee retailers may brew better margins on beans surplus
summary: Coffee retailers and processors may benefit from the current surplus of coffee beans, with prices expected to remain low and potentially weaken from previous annual averages. The surplus is expected to double to 12 million bags in 2020/21, and may remain high beyond 2021. This could lead to higher margins for companies like Food Empire Holdings, which has seen revenue dip only 4% in the first half of the year. Analysts also expect demand for home consumption segments to grow, benefiting Robusta-heavy blends.

site_title: SunMoon Food in talks with potential investor for fundraising
summary: SunMoon Food, a Singapore-based fruit and seafood distributor, is in talks with a potential investor for fundraising amid its parent company's involuntary bankruptcy reorganisation in China. The company's board is reviewing its ability to continue operating as a going concern. This comes as the company faces uncertainty due to the bankruptcy reorganisation, which may impact its ability to continue operating.

site_title: Diversification is a full meal at Sats
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground handling and in-flight catering firm, is diversifying its revenue streams amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The company has seen a 55% year-on-year decline in revenue, with non-aviation revenue increasing 73.3% to S$96.9 million. SATS is expanding into food production, e-commerce, and logistics, with a focus on supplying ready-to-cook ingredients and prepared food products to supermarkets and restaurants. The company plans to build more central kitchens and e-commerce hubs, with a goal of increasing revenue from overseas markets. SATS is also looking to acquire assets from airlines and expand its stakes in overseas associates.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Oct 12)
summary: Money FM highlights its top podcasts for the week of October 12, 2020, including BT Podcasts on transforming businesses and building youths, and discussions on yield-generating asset classes and market trends. Additionally, it features articles on wealth management strategies, private equity, and the impact of US dollar fluctuations on the market. The articles also touch on the appeal of gold in uncertain economic times, providing insights for investors and business owners.

site_title: Several real estate directors raise their company stakes
summary: Several Singaporean real estate directors have increased their company stakes through share buybacks. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (Holdings) led the consideration tally, buying back 7 million shares. Hong Fok Corporation executive director Cheong Pin Chuan acquired 1.1 million shares, increasing his total interest in the company to 20.24%. Ho Bee Holdings' Chua Thian Poh acquired 97,800 shares, further increasing his stake to 75.40%. Other directors, including Kelvin Fong Keng Seong of PropNex and Wong Teek Son of Riverstone Holdings, also increased their holdings. These transactions are part of the companies' efforts to boost their share prices and stabilize their financial performance.

site_title: HSBC criticised despite net zero emissions pledge
summary: HSBC has faced criticism for its recent announcement of aligning CO2 emissions with the Paris Agreement goal of net zero emissions by 2050 or sooner. Despite the pledge, the bank financed over $1.8 billion in fossil fuel projects in the months leading up to the announcement, including coal, tar sands, and oil and gas infrastructure. Critics argue that the lack of interim targets and detail on portfolio alignment raises doubts about the bank's credibility.

images.alt_text: Like other banks that have made long-dated 2050 commitments, HSBC is being criticised for a lack of clearly defined interim targets within its pledge.

site_title: Deloitte to shut four UK offices as Covid-19 entrenches remote working
summary: Deloitte is closing four UK offices due to reduced demand for office space amid the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to a shift towards remote working. The closures will affect approximately 500 staff members, but they will continue to work from home under permanent contracts. The decision is part of Deloitte's review of its real estate portfolio, with the goal of adapting to the "new normal" of working life.

site_title: BOJ has plenty of tools to cushion Covid-19 blow, says deputy governor Wakatabe
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masazumi Wakatabe stated that the central bank has tools to expand stimulus if needed to counter a strong yen's impact on inflation. The BOJ has already set up yield curve control and a lending facility to support firms affected by Covid-19. Wakatabe said the bank would not rule out deeper negative rates if necessary, but would judge any move against the entire yield curve. He emphasized the benefits of the BOJ's stimulus outweighing its costs, citing Japan's experience with sustained ultra-loose policy.

site_title: Dollar edges lower against basket of currencies, paring week's gains
summary: The US dollar edged lower against a basket of currencies on Friday, paring some of its week's gains due to concerns over a global surge in Covid-19 cases and a fading US stimulus package before the Nov 3 election. However, strong US retail sales data helped alleviate concerns about the US consumer. This move follows a week of increased caution, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: Renting a luxury room brings respite for home workers (and hotels)
summary: Hotels are adapting to the shift to flexible working by offering luxury rooms for rent, catering to home workers. MGM Resorts International and Accor SA are launching "Viva Las Office" and "Hotel Office" programs, respectively, with flexible workspaces, Wi-Fi, and amenities. This trend is expected to benefit the hotel industry, which has been hit hard by the pandemic. With occupancy rates at less than 50% globally, hotels are seeking alternative revenue streams, and flexible working may become a long-term winner for the industry.

site_title: What's up doc? Donkey therapy eases Spain medics' stress
summary: Donkey therapy is being offered to Spanish healthcare workers as a way to ease stress and anxiety during the COVID-19 pandemic. The program, called El Burrito Feliz, provides free sessions where participants can interact with 23 donkeys in a forest setting. Experts say donkeys are well-suited for animal-assisted therapy due to their gentle nature and respect for personal space. Studies show that the therapy can trigger changes in oxytocin, endorphins, and cortisol levels, reducing stress and increasing emotional well-being. So far, 25 doctors and nurses have visited the project, which is being extended and may potentially become a long-term solution for Spain's healthcare workers.

images.alt_text: Studies show that animal-assisted therapy triggers changes at a physiological level.

site_title: Thermo Fisher partners EDB for US$130m sterile fill-and-finish facility
summary: Thermo Fisher Scientific has partnered with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to build a US$130 million sterile fill-and-finish facility in Singapore, creating 300 jobs. The facility, expected to be operational in 2022, will support the development and manufacture of therapies and vaccines for the Asia-Pacific region. The investment aims to strengthen Singapore's ability to respond to future health crises, particularly in the fight against Covid-19.

site_title: No quick fix in sight for anaemic Thai economy
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to contract by 8-10% this year due to mounting political unrest, dim export prospects, and a reluctance to reopen borders. The country's tourism sector, which accounted for 18% of GDP in 2019, is severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with foreign tourist arrivals expected to be less than 7 million this year. The government has implemented various stimulus packages and measures to mitigate the economic impact, but analysts predict a slow recovery in 2021.

images.alt_text: If the ongoing anti-government protests in Thailand do eventually result in the dissolution of parliament and fresh elections, analysts expect further delays to public investment and further uncertainty.

site_title: Asia-Pacific's office market on the mend
summary: Asia-Pacific's office market is expected to be more resilient than other global regions due to demographic growth in emerging markets, which will help mitigate office job losses. Emerging markets like South-east Asia and India will add 683,000 office jobs in 2020, while advanced economies like Singapore will lose 340,000 jobs. Despite a significant decline in demand, the region's office fundamentals are forecast to remain positive, with demand expected to remain positive through 2030. Vacancy rates are expected to peak at 16.7% in late 2021, but will decrease rapidly, and the region's occupied inventory is forecast to increase by 84% by the end of the decade.

site_title: FTAs can open doors as firms seek global opportunities
summary: Singapore has been promoting free trade agreements (FTAs) as a strategic tool for businesses to internationalize and access new markets. With over 25 FTAs, the city-state aims to help companies diversify and reduce costs. However, many businesses struggle with the legal intricacies of FTAs, resulting in missed opportunities. To address this, the Singapore government has invested in online tools and public outreach sessions to raise awareness of how FTAs work. Businesses must take the initiative to learn about FTAs, develop due processes, and proactively apply for preferential duty claims to unlock the benefits of these agreements.

site_title: Potential woes for GBP/USD
summary: GBP/USD is at risk of a downtrend due to the ongoing Brexit process and US presidential elections. The European Central Bank's expansion of its purchase programs has led to fluctuations in the foreign exchange market. The UK's additional restrictions to combat the Covid-19 pandemic and banks' plans to shift assets from the UK to Frankfurt further contribute to a bearish view. The currency has traded lower from its peak near US$1.3500 in September 2020, breaking below key support levels, and is currently trading at US$1.2680.

site_title: The big breakup conversation
summary: The debate over whether to split up or regulate Big Tech companies continues, with proponents arguing that it can help maintain a level playing field and protect consumer welfare. Experts suggest that regulation, rather than breakups, could be a more effective solution, as it can curb anti-competitive practices and promote innovation. Some argue that breaking up Big Tech could lead to unintended consequences, such as technology fragmentation and stifling innovation. Instead, they advocate for nuanced regulation that takes into account the unique nature of the tech industry.

site_title: Fraud, rules and thin margins putting global banks off commodity financing
summary: Global banks are reevaluating their involvement in commodity financing due to recent high-profile fraud scandals, such as Hin Leong and Zenrock, which may have led to a pullback from European banks. Basel IV regulations, which took effect, have heightened concerns about risk management. Singapore's reputation as a trusted commodity trade financing hub has taken a hit, with European banks likely to be the most affected. Industry watchers believe the revelations of fraud were the last straw for these banks.

site_title: Brexit sidelined as second wave of Covid-19 grips European markets
summary: European investors shifted focus from Brexit to the second wave of COVID-19, with the Stoxx 600 experiencing its first weekly loss in three weeks. Virus restrictions in Paris and London drove the decline, while the euro fell to its lowest level this month. Investors are prioritizing pandemic concerns over Brexit, with the eurozone's consumption and investment remaining the main drivers of risk. The UK's FTSE 100 underperformed the Euro Stoxx 50, and sterling's weakness failed to support UK-listed multinational companies.

site_title: DBS' new ESG outperformance trade banks on a 'quality tilt'
summary: DBS Bank is launching a new structured product with an ESG (environmental, social, and governance) theme, targeting investors who expect companies with strong ESG ratings to outperform the market. The product, "MSCI EM Asia Leaders Outperformance Trade," has a 15% cap on maturity pay-off and is available to accredited investors from DBS Private Bank and DBS Treasures Private Client. This follows a successful run of an earlier "ESG Outperformance Trade" series, which raised S$95 million. The product aims to capitalize on the "quality tilt" of the MSCI EM Asia ESG Leaders Index, which has consistently outperformed the broader MSCI EM Asia Index over the past decade.

site_title: Ardern to form New Zealand government in 2-3 weeks after historic election win
summary: New Zealand's Labour party leader Jacinda Ardern is set to form a government within 2-3 weeks after winning a historic election with a majority of 49.1%. Ardern's victory means she can implement policies without coalition support, and opposition leader Judith Collins criticized her for failing to deliver on key promises. Ardern has pledged to accelerate policies on state housing, renewable energy, and job creation, while Collins questioned the government's fiscal policies and expressed concerns about the country's economic future.

site_title: American Air sets new daily Miami-NY flight for 737 MAX debut
summary: American Airlines plans to resume Boeing 737 MAX passenger flights on December 29, operating one daily flight on the Miami-New York corridor. The airline will take a phased approach to returning the MAX to service, contingent on Federal Aviation Administration approval. The 737 MAX was grounded in 2019 after two crashes killed 346 people. American will initially operate the MAX on one Miami-LaGuardia-Miami route, with flights bookable starting October 24. The airline has 24 737 MAX planes, with orders for another 76.

site_title: DBS launches new tranche of structured product with ESG theme
summary: DBS is launching a new tranche of a structured product with an ESG (environmental, social, and governance) theme, designed to profit from companies that are best-in-class in terms of ESG. The product, called the MSCI EM Asia Outperformance Trade, has a 36-month tenor and caps maturity pay-off at 15% on a cumulative basis. It is available to accredited investors with a minimum investment of US$500,000. DBS Private Bank believes the ESG proposition can ride out market uncertainties and outperform in the long term, with a recent survey showing 98% of clients have a positive view on ESG investing.

site_title: SunMoon says in talks with a potential investor for fund raising
summary: SunMoon Food, a Singapore-based fruit and seafood distributor, is in talks with a potential investor for a fundraising option amid its parent's involuntary bankruptcy reorganisation in China. The company's board has suspended trading of its shares voluntarily and set up an executive committee to review its financial position and operations. SunMoon aims to resume trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) within 12 months, with a proposal to be submitted to the exchange.

site_title: 2.2m Facebook and Instagram ads rejected ahead of US vote
summary: Facebook and Instagram have rejected 2.2 million ads and 120,000 posts ahead of the US presidential election, aiming to "obstruct voting". Facebook's vice-president Nick Clegg warned of 150 million examples of false information online. The company has increased security efforts, including partnerships with media organizations and AI-powered post deletion. Facebook also stores ads and funding information for seven years for transparency.

site_title: Cold Hawaii: Danish coast surfs on virus wave
summary: Surfers flock to Denmark's western coast, known as "Cold Hawaii," as a result of travel restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic. The rugged coastline, characterized by chilly waters and grey skies, has become a popular destination for surfers, with a growing number of board enthusiasts drawn to the area. Mor Meluka, a 34-year-old Israeli resident, attributes the surge in popularity to the pandemic, stating that it has "really created a big boom" for the region. The area's unique combination of harsh weather conditions and world-class surfing spots has made it an attractive alternative for surfers.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for October 16, 2020, reveals a decline in tanker and dry bulk market values. The Capesize market experienced a 30% drop, with rates decreasing from $29,479 to $19,952. The Atlantic basin was the most affected, while the Pacific Basin saw a 7.668 decline. The Panamax market also faced pressure, with rates decreasing in the Atlantic basin. The Supramax/Ultramax market remained flat, with low activity reported. The Handysize market saw some firmness in the Continent market, while the Clean market declined in several trades. The VLCC market saw slight improvements, with rates increasing for certain routes.

site_title: Gove says UK 'well prepared' for no-deal Brexit, even as businesses sound alarm
summary: UK Minister Michael Gove says the country is "increasingly well-prepared" for a no-deal Brexit, despite businesses urging a compromise over trade terms. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has suggested a deal similar to Australia's, which would lead to tariffs and significant price rises. More than 70 British business groups have called on politicians to negotiate a deal, warning of chaos and economic hit from a no-deal Brexit. The EU has delivered an ultimatum, warning of a rupture of ties if no progress is made by January 1.

site_title: Nextdoor is said to eye public listing, US$5b valuation
summary: Nextdoor, a social network for neighbors, is considering an initial public offering or merger with a blank-check firm, valuing the company between $4 billion and $5 billion. The company has raised $470 million and was last valued at $2.2 billion after a 2019 funding round. Nextdoor's platform allows users to provide feedback on local businesses and has 268,000 neighborhoods globally, including one in every four in the US. A potential IPO or merger could happen before the end of next year.

site_title: HSBC draws criticism despite net zero pledge
summary: HSBC drew criticism for its recent net zero pledge, despite financing companies involved in coal, tar sands, and oil and gas infrastructure. The bank provided up to $1.8 billion in deals for these companies in the months leading up to its announcement, casting doubt on its credibility. Critics say HSBC lacks clear interim targets and detail on how it will align its portfolio with Paris Agreement targets. The bank aims to provide $750 billion to $1 trillion for low-carbon investments over the next decade.

site_title: VW says has reached agreement in principle to buy Navistar for US$44.50 per share
summary: Volkswagen's truck unit Traton has agreed to buy Navistar International Corp for US$44.50 per share, a 1.16% increase from its initial offer of US$43 per share. The deal, which includes Traton's existing 16.8% stake in Navistar, aims to acquire all remaining Navistar shares by merger. The agreement is considered a significant move to strengthen Traton's position in the US truck market.

site_title: Japan's WealthNavi applies to list on TSE, IPO likely later this year: Nikkei
summary: WealthNavi, a Japanese fintech firm, has applied to list its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, with an initial public offering (IPO) expected later this year. The corporate value is estimated at 50-60 billion yen, and SBI Securities and Daiwa Securities will be lead managers. This would mark Japan's first IPO of a fintech firm in asset management and one of the biggest IPOs in the country this year, following Kioxia Holdings' cancellation of plans due to US-China tensions.

site_title: Australia-New Zealand travel bubble hits a snag
summary: Australia's travel bubble with New Zealand hit a snag when 17 passengers who flew into Sydney broke quarantine rules by catching a connecting flight to Melbourne. The passengers, who were allowed to enter the country without hotel quarantine, flew on within minutes of arriving in Sydney. Victoria state Premier Daniel Andrews expressed disappointment and frustration, stating that Melbourne is not part of the bubble. The incident highlights the limitations of the travel corridor, which only covers New South Wales state and the Northern Territory.

site_title: Seven new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one community case
summary: Seven new Covid-19 cases were reported in Singapore, bringing the total to 57,911. The cases include one community case and one in a worker's dormitory, with five imported cases also confirmed. This marks a decrease from the peak of 100 active cases in March and a stable community transmission rate. The number of unlinked cases in the community has decreased to zero. Globally, over 39.6 million people have been infected and over 1.11 million have died from the virus.

site_title: Amid e-commerce boom, anti-Amazon Shopify takes flight
summary: Shopify, a Canadian e-commerce platform, has seen significant growth amid the pandemic, with over one million e-stores at the end of 2019. The company's user base has exploded, and its president, Harley Finkelstein, notes that the retail world has been "pulled back into 2020." This shift has led to Shopify emerging as a thriving alternative to Amazon, as businesses worldwide pivot online to survive.

site_title: Trump has been good for stocks, but investors should still root for a Biden win
summary: US stocks have risen 53.9% since Donald Trump's inauguration, outperforming other Republican presidents, including Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush. The S&P500's gains were largely driven by corporate-friendly policies, including tax cuts and deregulation, which led to significant share buybacks. However, the pace of buybacks slowed in Q2 2020 due to the COVID-19 crisis. Despite this, the S&P500 has rebounded, driven by monetary loosening and strong performance of tech-oriented stocks. As the US presidential election approaches, investors are weighing the potential impact of a Biden presidency, which could bring a shift towards more sustainable economic growth and social stability.

site_title: Singapore takes lead to boost transparency in trade finance
summary: Singapore is leading efforts to boost transparency in trade finance, a commodity-trade finance business plagued by scandals and structural issues. The country's TradeTrust platform connects platforms to exchange digital trade documentation, and has partnered with Swift and the Infocomm Media Development Authority to improve cross-border trade. DBS and Standard Chartered have also formed a work group to create a digital trade finance registry, a secure central database for banks to access records of trade transactions. This initiative aims to prevent duplicate financing and promote greater transparency in the industry.

images.alt_text: WIith the commodity-trade finance business rocked by scandals and structural issues such as falling prices and regulatory pressures on profits, industry watchers are certain that this age-old business is due for reckoning.

site_title: Blackstone signs non-binding agreement to buy prestige's assets
summary: Blackstone Group has signed a non-binding agreement to acquire some assets of Indian developer Prestige Estates Projects, including commercial offices, retail properties, and mall management businesses, for US$2 billion. The deal, subject to due diligence and approvals, will be exclusive to Blackstone, and Prestige Estates is one of the largest developers in southern India with 45 existing projects spanning 52 million square feet.

images.alt_text: Indian developer Prestige Estates Projects said Blackstone Group signed a non-binding agreement to buy some of its assets.

site_title: China's millennials stimulate 100b yuan sex toy market
summary: China's sex toy market, valued at over 100 billion yuan, is driven by millennials who are increasingly open to using sex toys due to the pandemic and changing societal attitudes. The market, mainly fueled by female consumers, is expected to continue growing despite a potential decline in demand after the pandemic. China now produces 70% of global exports of sex toys, with overseas demand remaining high. As societal values shift, women in their 30s and younger are becoming more comfortable with using sex toys to enhance their pleasure and satisfaction.

site_title: Hong Kong could halt plan for vacancy tax on apartments
summary: The Hong Kong government is reconsidering a plan to introduce a vacancy tax on new housing stock, citing community feedback and the economic state of the city. The proposal, which would have imposed a hefty tax and jail time on property developers who fail to sell new apartments, was met with resistance. The decision to suspend the plan comes as the city continues to recover from last year's protests and the coronavirus pandemic. The move is seen as a relief for property developers and may help boost housing sales in the city.

site_title: An eye test can save your life
summary: An eye test can potentially save lives by identifying underlying health issues. The eye is connected to the rest of the body, allowing for a direct visualization of nerve and blood vessels, making it a "crystal ball" for health. Recent cases have shown that eye problems can be linked to cardiovascular health, stroke, and brain diseases. Regular eye exams can prompt health-seeking behavior, leading to timely interventions and prevention of life-threatening conditions, such as stroke and brain tumors.

site_title: Arbitration proceedings against Ezion unit Teras Conquest 2 have re-commenced
summary: Arbitration proceedings against Ezion unit Teras Conquest 2 (TC2PL) have re-commenced. Whitesea Shipping & Supply, an offshore support vessel operator, initiated the arbitration against TC2PL over an unpaid deposit of US$37 million. However, Whitesea has discontinued its claim, leaving the proceedings to focus on TC2PL's counterclaim. Ezion's shares remain suspended due to the ongoing arbitration.

site_title: Airlines face tough winter as hoped-for pick-up fails to materialise
summary: Airlines face a challenging winter season as a hoped-for rebound from the coronavirus crisis failed to materialize, with revenues plummeting 80% in the first six months of the year. Despite a slight recovery in July, traffic fell again in September, and bookings for the winter season are down 78% compared to last year. Airlines are implementing cost-cutting measures and seeking government support to stay afloat, with some offering "flights to nowhere" and selling in-flight food to desperate passengers.

site_title: Russia, Saudi Arabia prepared to keep energy market stable
summary: Russia and Saudi Arabia held a phone call to discuss the OPEC+ agreement, aiming to maintain stability in the global energy market. The two officials reiterated their readiness for further coordination, following warnings of a weaker oil market in 2021. This is the second unusual call between the two nations, with the previous one taking place on October 13. The goal is to ensure a stable energy market, despite potential market fluctuations.

site_title: WHO trial to assess other antibody, antiviral drugs after remdesivir doubt
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) announced it will continue its Solidarity Trial, launched in March, to assess other treatments for COVID-19 after remdesivir showed no impact on survival rates. The trial, which is recruiting 2,000 patients per month in 30 countries, will also evaluate monoclonal antibodies and new antivirals. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated that the trial will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of various treatments, helping to inform COVID-19 treatment strategies.

site_title: Japanese ad firm Dentsu eyes NYC sublease in sign of mounting office woes
summary: Japanese advertising firm Dentsu is considering subleasing space in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood, a sign of mounting office woes in the city. Dentsu had signed a lease for a 630,000-square-foot office redevelopment, but with quarterly profits down 60% due to the pandemic, the company is reassessing its real estate footprint. This move comes as Manhattan landlords face pressure, with 2.5 million square feet of office space put on the market in the third quarter, more than double the amount from a year earlier.

site_title: Nikola shares plunge after CEO says startup can go it alone
summary: Nikola Corp shares plummeted 16% in Friday trading after CEO Mark Russell stated that the electric-truck startup can proceed with its plans without a strategic partnership with General Motors (GM). Russell said the company has a "base plan" to develop its products on its own, reducing reliance on a partner. The planned electric pickup, Badger, may be dropped if an agreement with GM cannot be reached by December 3, as the two companies continue to negotiate a deal.

images.alt_text: Nikola Corp shares sank as much as 16 per cent in Friday trading after the electric-truck startup's chief executive officer said he sees a path for his company even if it can't come to terms with General Motors (GM) on a proposed strategic partnership.

site_title: Teenager asked pupils to identify French teacher before beheading him
summary: A 18-year-old Russian-born teenager beheaded 47-year-old French history teacher Samuel Paty in broad daylight outside a Paris suburb school on Friday. The attacker, who was shot dead by police, asked pupils to identify Paty's body before committing the crime. A photograph of Paty's body with a message claiming responsibility was found on the attacker's phone, which was linked to his Twitter account. The incident has sparked widespread outrage and is being investigated by France's anti-terrorism prosecutor.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends mixed, tech shares see late selloff
summary: US stocks ended the week mixed on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.4% and the S&P 500 rising 0.1%, despite a soaring US deficit and a lack of a new stimulus package. Retail sales data showed a 1.9% increase in September, boosting shares of Boeing and Pfizer. However, the tech-rich Nasdaq lost 0.4% due to declines by Amazon, Apple, and Netflix. Economists say the recovery is losing steam, and a stimulus package is unlikely before the November presidential election.

site_title: New Zealand's Ardern seeks second term as pandemic-focused polls open
summary: New Zealand held a general election on October 17, 2020, with Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern seeking a second term. Labour Party leader Ardern, 40, and National Party leader Judith Collins, 61, are the main contenders. The election, focused on the pandemic, saw a record number of advance votes, with polling booths opening at 9 am. The outcome could determine Ardern's hold on government, with Collins leading the conservative challenge.

site_title: Boeing Max judged safe to fly by Europe's aviation regulator
summary: Europe's aviation regulator, EASA, has deemed Boeing's 737 Max plane safe to fly, with the agency's executive director, Patrick Ky, stating that the changes made to the plane have reached a "high level of safety." EASA's review is expected to be completed next month, with a draft airworthiness directive expected to be issued, followed by a four-week public comment period. The regulator has also demanded a synthetic sensor to add redundancy, which will be required on the Max 10 variant and retrofitted onto other versions.
