site_title: Air Canada CEO to retire in February as pandemic roils industry
summary: Air Canada's CEO, Calin Rovinescu, will retire in February after 11 years as president and CEO. Deputy CEO Michael Rousseau will succeed him, following a 2018 appointment as deputy CEO. Rovinescu led the airline through the COVID-19 pandemic, raising C$6 billion in liquidity and pushing for government aid. Despite turmoil in the airline industry, investors credit Rovinescu with strengthening the airline's balance sheet, turning it into a "winner."

site_title: Firms in London CBD quietly starting to rent large offices again
summary: Companies like Netflix and Morgan Stanley are moving into large offices in London's CBD, indicating a recovery in the pandemic-struck office market. Law firms Travers Smith and Latham & Watkins are close to leasing new headquarters in the City of London. Despite concerns about home-working, the scarcity of large modern office space may be driving companies to secure space now. New developments are being built, and investors are taking notice, with KKR & Co and Brookfield Asset Management increasing their stakes in London office developers.

site_title: US Senate to vote this week on 'skinny' pandemic relief bill
summary: The US Senate is set to vote on a $300 billion "skinny" pandemic relief bill, a pared-down version of the estimated $2 trillion Democrats have demanded. The bill was previously rejected by Democrats in September and is expected to fail. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have agreed to continue discussions, but significant differences remain, including funding for coronavirus testing and liability protection for companies. Time is running out before the Nov 3 presidential election to reach a bipartisan agreement on a new relief package.

images.alt_text: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said in a statement Saturday that the vote would follow a standalone vote on additional Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) funds on Tuesday.

site_title: PVPA honours everyday heroes
summary: Q&M Dental Group's staff, comprising 75 dentists and 45 nurses, volunteered to swab over 13,000 foreign workers in 160 dormitories during the Covid-19 outbreak. They were recognized as one of the five winners of the President's Volunteerism & Philanthropy Awards Special Edition 2020 under the Organisations of Good Award Category. The awards celebrate unsung heroes who have given selflessly during the pandemic, with a record 236 nominations received this year. The recognition highlights the spirit of selflessness and teamwork among the winners, who came together to help others despite personal risks.

site_title: Evergrande says it may buy back dollar bonds to boost confidence
summary: Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, is considering buying back some of its dollar bonds to boost market confidence. The company is also exploring ways to repay a HK$18 billion convertible bond due in February. Evergrande will consult investors on a solution, following a meeting with Bank of America. This move aims to stabilize the company's financial situation and alleviate concerns among investors.

site_title: ARA unit awarded £3b affordable housing guarantee scheme in UK
summary: ARA Venn, a subsidiary of ARA Asset Management, has been appointed as the exclusive manager of a £3 billion Affordable Housing Guarantee Scheme by the UK Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government. The scheme aims to deliver around 17,000 affordable homes for lower-income families, addressing housing affordability in the UK. ARA Venn will provide £3 billion of cost-effective long-term loans, with an option to increase to £6 billion, and will manage the scheme for up to 30 years. This deepens ARA's collaboration with the UK government to support the sustainable development of its housing sector.

site_title: Oil dips on Covid-19 resurgence, fears of more supply
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, with Brent crude futures dropping 23 cents to US$42.93 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling eight cents to US$40.88 a barrel. Concerns over a prolonged Covid-19 pandemic and increased Libyan output may lead to a surplus in the oil market next year, according to a confidential Opec+ document. This gloomy outlook has led to a decrease in oil demand recovery, with European countries imposing curfews and lockdowns to combat the spread of the virus.

site_title: Markets without havens are becoming all too real
summary: Financial markets have become increasingly interconnected, making traditional portfolio diversification challenging. Central bank quantitative easing has artificially boosted asset prices, but failed to achieve its primary goal of sparking inflation. As a result, haven-like assets, such as government bonds and stocks, have lost their safe-haven status. Investors can navigate turbulent markets by adopting a "barbell" approach, holding a mix of low-risk and high-risk assets, and maintaining a significant cash reserve. Active management can also provide benefits, particularly in understanding which sectors and firms will thrive in the post-pandemic economy.

site_title: Madison Avenue rent plunges as Manhattan retail takes a hit
summary: Madison Avenue retail rents in Manhattan plummeted 17% in the third quarter, reaching an average of $779 per square foot, a 52% decline from the peak over the past five years. The decline is attributed to the pandemic driving store closures, pushing shoppers to e-commerce, and reduced foot traffic. Other popular retail districts, such as Herald Square and Times Square, also experienced significant rent drops. The increased availability of space, with 35% of Madison Avenue's space available, contributes to the downward trend.

site_title: Is Big Tech a bubble?
summary: A long-standing value investing strategy has underperformed since the 2007 bull market peak, with growth investing dominating the market. Historically, value investing outperforms growth, but the current 13-year outperformance is the longest and biggest in history. The COVID-19 pandemic has fueled growth, and companies like Tesla have exhibited exponential upside movements, raising concerns about a bubble. A shift in portfolio allocations between value and growth investing may be necessary, as the current growth outperformance has led the value-growth ratio back to 1975 levels, potentially marking a cyclical shift.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Group raises IPO valuation target to US$280b
summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, plans to increase its initial public offering (IPO) valuation target to at least US$280 billion, citing strong demand. The company aims to raise about US$35 billion in the sale, with same-day listings in Hong Kong and Shanghai. Despite US headwinds, Ant is moving forward with the IPO, which would be the world's largest, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record US$29 billion raise. The Hong Kong stock exchange has scheduled an Ant hearing for next week, pending approval from the Chinese securities watchdog.

site_title: Goodbye open office, and hello hybrids
summary: US tech giants are shifting towards hybrid office models, allowing employees to work from home permanently, citing flexibility and work-life balance as key benefits. A recent survey by Slack found that 72% of global knowledge workers prefer a hybrid arrangement, citing improved work-life balance and cost savings. However, cultural norms, such as Japan's overworking culture, hinder some benefits of remote working. Managers must adapt to a new role, shifting from gatekeepers to coaches and social connectors, to ensure remote work's success.

site_title: Fujifilm seeks approval for Avigan as Covid-19 treatment in Japan
summary: Fujifilm Holdings Corp is seeking approval for its flu drug Avigan as a Covid-19 treatment in Japan, following a late-stage study showing reduced recovery time for patients with non-severe symptoms. The study, involving 156 patients, found symptoms improved after 11.9 days for those treated with Avigan, compared to 14.7 days for a placebo group. The Japanese government has called on Fujifilm to triple national stockpiles of the drug, which has been approved for emergency use as a flu medicine and for treating Covid-19 in India and Russia.

images.alt_text: Fujifilm Holdings Corp said on Friday it was seeking approval for its flu drug Avigan as a treatment for Covid-19 in Japan, a move that comes after a late-stage study showed reduced recovery time for patients with non-severe symptoms.

site_title: UK data privacy watchdog slashes British Airways fine as virus bites
summary: The UK Information Commissioner's Office reduced a fine of £183 million on British Airways to £20 million due to the financial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. The airline had faced a record fine over a 2018 cyber attack, but the watchdog considered representations from BA and the economic fallout of the pandemic before setting the final penalty.

site_title: Audi A5 Sportback: Midlife reboot
summary: The Audi A5 Sportback is a midlife update of the 2016 design, offering a sleek fastback with more boot space than similar cars. The updated model features a flatter front grille, wider bumper lines, and a low, sloping roofline, while maintaining a quiet interior with Audi's latest Multi Media Interface. The car offers ample space for five occupants, with a 465-liter boot space and 1,280-liter capacity with rear seats folded. The 2.0-liter turbocharged engine provides smooth but not rapid progress, and the car is a mild hybrid, allowing for seamless coasting at highway speeds. Priced at S$199,900, the A5 Sportback offers a premium but practical package.

site_title: Singapore retail rents stabilising at suburban malls; may bottom out by early 2021
summary: Singapore's retail rents are expected to stabilize by the end of 2020 or early 2021, with overall retail rents predicted to fall by 10-15% due to recessionary pressures. Suburban mall rents, however, are expected to decline by 7.5% or less, as shopper traffic returned to a greater extent in suburban malls compared to centrally located ones. Prime retail rents islandwide decreased by 10.3% in Q3 to S$27.40 per square foot, with Orchard Road and Marina Centre seeing significant declines, while suburban areas recorded the smallest drop.

site_title: Rethinking retirement
summary: Ken Dychtwald, psychologist and gerontologist, argues that the traditional retirement model is outdated and instead advocates for a "Third Age" where individuals reinvent themselves, focusing on relationships, wellness, and purpose. A survey of over 100,000 boomers found that retirees value interdependence, health span, and financial security. Dychtwald challenges retirees to be empathetic to younger generations and to continually learn and grow, rather than simply "hoarding" their life and memories. He emphasizes the importance of purpose, volunteering, and continued learning, and warns that a lack of usefulness among seniors can lead to isolation and boredom.

site_title: Moody's cuts UK's debt rating on weak economic growth
summary: Moody's downgraded the UK's debt rating to Aa3 from Aa2, citing weak economic growth due to the coronavirus crisis, Brexit, and lack of clear budget plans. The UK's public debt surpassed 100% of GDP, and its economy shrank by the most among Group of Seven nations in the second quarter. Moody's warned that Britain's high debt levels and failure to reach a trade deal with the EU would compound the damage, making it difficult to achieve budgetary discipline and reduce debt levels.

site_title: Singapore key exports tipped to cool towards year-end
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 5.9% year-on-year in September, lower than expected, due to a decline in pharmaceutical exports. The electronics sector, however, showed resilience with an increase in shipments of integrated circuits, disk media products, and personal computer parts. Economists predict a cyclical recovery in the electronics sector will continue, with chip exports expected to remain strong. However, the volatile pharmaceutical cluster's decline and potential impact of the US presidential election on consumer demand pose uncertainty for the overall export picture.

site_title: More glove-maker stocks may join Malaysia's benchmark index amid Covid-19 rally
summary: Malaysia's benchmark index may see glove-makers Supermax and Kossan Rubber Industries join the 30-stock FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index, potentially replacing gaming companies like Genting, in a review scheduled for November or December. This follows the impressive rally in glove-maker shares, with Top Glove and Hartalega Holdings already listed on the index. Analysts at Maybank Investment Bank and Smartkarma predict the changes, citing the sector's growth and strong investor interest.

images.alt_text: Top Glove is close to overtaking Malayan Banking as the biggest stock on the KLCI Index, and Hartalega is in third position. Analysts say that with the new additions, glove-makers' weighting in the gauge will jump to about 20 per cent from around 15 per cent now.

site_title: Lone money-making S-E Asia stock fund is changing tack
summary: Hong Kong-based fund manager Alan Richardson's Samsung Asean Securities Master Investment Trust (Equity) has gained 13% this year, outperforming the MSCI Asean Index, which has lost over 22%. Richardson is shifting his portfolio to cyclical and value shares, expecting a potential COVID-19 vaccine rollout to accelerate the global economic recovery. He expects old-economy stocks in South-east Asia to benefit, and has started to buy consumer discretionary, industrials, materials, and energy sectors. This shift comes after some of his initial bets on COVID-19 beneficiaries paid off.

site_title: Europe: Vaccine hopes, upbeat earnings power shares
summary: European shares rose 1.3% on Friday, their best session in nearly three weeks, as hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine's availability in the US before the end of the year lifted sentiment. Pfizer Inc said it could file for US authorization of its vaccine as early as November, boosting the pan-European Stoxx 600. Upbeat quarterly earnings also contributed to the gains, following a torrid week.

site_title: Swab tests for that overseas trip could cost more than the return plane ticket
summary: Swab tests for overseas trips may cost more than the return plane ticket, with costs ranging from S$300 to over S$1,000. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) supports testing as an alternative to quarantine, but notes that the cost should not hinder travel. New-generation rapid tests cost under US$10 each, and Iata advocates for systematic testing under government authority. Travelers may need to take multiple tests, adding to the overall cost, with some airlines and destinations charging up to S$300 for pre-departure testing.

images.alt_text: Travelling costs will go up by at least S$300 to over a thousand dollars - if more than one test is required.

site_title: Air travel bubble may lift aviation, hospitality, property stocks
summary: Analysts predict a boost in aviation, hospitality, and property stocks in Singapore and Hong Kong as a two-way air travel bubble resumes between the two cities. Cathay Pacific may see increased cash burn due to route startup costs, but Jefferies maintains a "hold" call on the airline. Singapore Airlines, Sats, and Far East Hospitality Trust are also expected to benefit, with analysts suggesting a "buy" call on SIA, Sats, and FEHT. Meanwhile, analysts Krishna Guha and Yeo Kee Yan recommend "buy" calls on Mapletree Commercial Trust and Suntec Reit, respectively, citing undervalued valuations.

site_title: NTU's nanofilm spin-off may raise up to S$510m in IPO
summary: Nanyang Technological University's (NTU) spin-off company Nanofilm Technologies is set to list on the Singapore Exchange with a potential initial public offering (IPO) of up to S$510 million, making it one of the largest non-Reit mainboard listings in recent years. Temasek Holdings will be a substantial shareholder in the listing, which would be the first mainboard listing since March. The IPO is expected to raise significant funds for Nanofilm Technologies.

site_title: Offer to delist SK Jewellery closes with 97.8% valid acceptances
summary: SK Jewellery Group's voluntary cash offer closed on October 16 with 97.8% valid acceptances, representing a S$0.15 per share offer. The offeror, OroGreen Investment, will compulsorily acquire remaining shares at the same price. The founders believe privatization will provide greater control and management flexibility, allowing the company to respond to changing market conditions and optimize management resources.

site_title: China drug stock surges after doctor endorses its treatment for Covid
summary: China's Guangzhou Baiyunshan Pharmaceutical Holdings saw its stock surge 13% in Hong Kong after its treatment, banlangen, was reportedly endorsed by top medical adviser Zhong Nanshan for potentially inhibiting Covid-19. The endorsement came during a ceremony in Guangzhou to launch the project. However, it's unclear if the medicine is effective as tests are still in the early stage. The company's Hong Kong shares have dropped 18% this year, and its Western pharmaceutical products division has also been affected.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ayondo's independent director Lam Shiao Ning is under investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for a possible offence under the Securities and Futures Act. Ayondo's nominating committee has deemed her suitable to continue as a director despite the investigation. Meanwhile, Metech International's executive director and CEO Clement Tay Ming Liang has resigned, and Acesian Star (S), a subsidiary of Acesian Partners, has been wound up by the High Court. The winding-up is expected to have no material impact on Acesian Partners' financials.

site_title: Malaysia tycoon Syed Mokhtar seeks stake in major palm oil producer
summary: Malaysian tycoon Syed Mokhtar Albukhary is seeking a merger with palm oil producer FGV Holdings, which could give him a stake in one of Malaysia's largest palm oil producers. FGV shares rose 7.5% after the proposal, and a merger could bolster the company's fortunes and challenge rival Sime Darby Plantations' position as the world's top palm oil producer. The merger, if successful, would see FGV owning about 473,000 acres of plantation assets, with Syed Mokhtar's company, Persatuan Land, intending to "inject" its assets into FGV.

site_title: Global IPO value at 20-year high in Q3; Asean shows quarter-on-quarter rebound: EY
summary: Global Initial Public Offerings (IPOs) reached a 20-year high in Q3, with 872 deals raising $165.3 billion in proceeds. Asia-Pacific, particularly Asean markets, showed quarter-on-quarter rebound, with 77 IPOs in the region raising $4.3 billion. However, the US presidential election could negatively impact regional and global equity markets, affecting IPO activity levels. Key sectors dominating global IPO activity include technology, industrials, and healthcare.

site_title: REC marketplaces good for local firms, but face regional competition
summary: Singapore's renewable energy certificate (REC) marketplaces have recently launched, providing tradable certificates to benefit companies meeting sustainability goals. Four platforms have emerged in the last two years, including Singapore's Energy Market Company (EMC) and SP Group, which aim to make it easy for households to contribute to a low-carbon future. However, the long-term success of these marketplaces is uncertain due to regional competition, with similar platforms emerging in Thailand and Australia. Experts warn that the high prices of local RECs and limited renewable energy capabilities in Singapore may make it difficult for local platforms to sustain themselves in the long run.

site_title: Twitter CEO says blocking New York Post article without context was wrong
summary: Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey stated that blocking a New York Post article without context was wrong. He announced Twitter's new goal of adding context to such incidents. The company had previously blocked links to the article, which claimed to have information about Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden's son. Twitter's Hacked Materials Policy, introduced in 2018, will be revised following feedback. Despite this, the New York Post story will still be blocked for violating Twitter's rules on private personal information. The US Senate Judiciary Committee is set to vote on a subpoena to send to Twitter on Tuesday.

site_title: New IBF-MAS survey to project job losses, placements in financial sector
summary: The Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have launched a new six-monthly survey to project job losses and placements in the financial sector. The survey aims to better match job seekers to roles available in financial services and support staff through pre-emptive reskilling and redeployment. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized the need for a proactive approach, focusing on creating new roles and customizing training for individuals, rather than waiting for people to become redundant.

site_title: KrisEnergy seeks approval to convene scheme meeting and moratorium extension
summary: KrisEnergy, a debt-laden upstream oil and gas company, has applied to the High Court to convene a scheme creditors meeting and extend its debt moratorium for two months. The company seeks to restructure its US$476.8 million debts and proposes a debt-to-equity swap, with unsecured creditors owning 46.2% and zero coupon note holders holding 43.8%. The meeting will only allow contractual creditors to vote, and the company has sought a fifth extension to its debt moratorium, which was first granted in September last year.

site_title: Even without a live audience, the show must still go on
summary: One Championship, a Singapore-based mixed martial arts organization, has successfully held its first international show in the city-state since March, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. The event, "Reign of Dynasties," took place in an empty stadium with no fans in attendance, but was well-received by the audience at home. CEO Chatri Sityodtong expects stadiums to remain empty for at least another year, but sees the pandemic as an opportunity for the organization to adapt and thrive. One Championship has multiple events planned for the rest of the year, including a live show on October 30 and a reality TV show production in Singapore.

site_title: Where to find investment income now that bank dividends are drying up
summary: Asia's worst year for stock dividends in over a decade has left retirees scrambling for better returns, with nearly a third of companies in the region slashing or cutting payouts due to the pandemic. Key findings include: Australia and Hong Kong have the highest number of dividend cuts, with nearly 50% of companies in Europe outpacing them. Investors are taking bigger risks, shifting to tech stocks and alternative sectors, and exploring income-generating options like Reits and physical infrastructure. Experts advise considering emerging cash-flow-rich sectors, China's energy and real estate sectors, and sectors with high dividend yields, such as gloves and materials.

site_title: US retail sales beat expectations; outlook murky
summary: US retail sales rose 1.9% in September, beating expectations, with core sales increasing 1.4% and excluding automobiles, petrol, building materials, and food services. The strong quarter of economic activity is tempered by uncertainty over government funding and rising coronavirus infections, which could lead to business restrictions and undercut spending on services. The economy is at a crossroads, with growth estimates for the third quarter as high as 35.2% and the fourth quarter revised downward to 2.5%.

site_title: Tennis: Wimbledon set to return even without fans
summary: Wimbledon, the prestigious tennis tournament, is set to proceed in 2021 despite the ongoing pandemic, with plans for various scenarios including a full-capacity event, reduced capacity, or holding it behind closed doors. The 134th championships will take place from June 28 to July 11, 2021, with the All England Club prioritizing the event's staging. Chief executive Sally Bolton emphasized the club's focus on delivering the championships, while considering safety measures and fan attendance.

images.alt_text: Wimbledon is set to go ahead next year even if the Grand Slam tournament has to be staged behind closed doors, organisers announced on Friday.

site_title: Food security in the spotlight
summary: The state of global food security is a growing concern, particularly in Africa and Asia, with 381 million undernourished people in Asia and 250 million in Africa, with the youth of these regions suffering from malnutrition. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated the issue, with an estimated 3 billion people unable to afford a healthy diet. Locust swarms and invasive pests, such as the Fall Armyworm, have devastated crops, while climate change is further threatening food production. A collaborative effort among stakeholders is needed to address the "tipping point" in food security, with a recent partnership between the UN's Food and Agriculture Organization and CropLife International being a step forward in promoting rural development and transforming agri-food systems.

site_title: KrisEnergy seeks permission to convene scheme meeting and moratorium extension
summary: KrisEnergy, a debt-laden upstream oil and gas company, has applied to the High Court to convene a scheme creditors meeting and extend its debt moratorium by two months. The court will hear these applications on October 30. Scheme creditors in a contractual relationship with the company will be allowed to vote to appoint the meeting chairman. Those objecting to the requests must file an affidavit by October 22.

site_title: US: Wall Street climbs on vaccine hopes, upbeat retail sales data
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, driven by hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine and strong retail sales data. Pfizer announced it could apply for emergency use of its vaccine candidate as early as November, boosting market sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also opened higher, with the Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.41%. The positive start to the week comes despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and tariff threats.

site_title: Gilead questions WHO study that cast doubts on drug's Covid-19 benefits
summary: Gilead Sciences has questioned the findings of a World Health Organization (WHO) study that found its Covid-19 drug remdesivir had little to no effect on patients hospitalized with the disease. The company cited inconsistent data and premature conclusions, despite previous studies validating the drug's benefits. The WHO trial involved 11,266 patients and found that remdesivir did not reduce 28-day mortality or hospital stays, contradicting previous findings.

images.alt_text: Gilead Sciences has questioned the findings of a World Health Organization (WHO) study that concluded its Covid-19 drug remdesivir does not help patients who have been admitted to hospital.

site_title: Iras collects S$53.5b in tax revenues for FY2019/20
summary: Singapore's tax authority, Iras, collected S$53.5 billion in tax revenue for FY2019/2020, a 2.1% increase. Personal income tax rose 5.7% to S$12.4 billion, while corporate tax grew 4.3% to S$16.7 billion. However, analysts predict tax collection will decline in FY2021 due to the economic crisis, with GST collections projected to fall by 14% and stamp duty expected to decline further. Iras is continuing to support the government with assistance schemes and digital initiatives to ease taxpaying.

site_title: Gold awaits US fiscal stimulus package
summary: US fiscal stimulus package negotiations have been stagnant, with gold prices influenced by sentiment and expectations of a larger stimulus after the Nov 3 election. Despite fading prospects for a new pandemic relief package, gold remains bullish due to ultra-low yields, negative real interest rates, and ongoing quantitative easing. The outcome of the US presidential elections and Senate elections will also impact gold prices, with a potential Democratic sweep leading to a larger stimulus package. Central banks' concerns about economic growth and safe-haven demand will continue to support gold prices.

site_title: Lockdowns in Malaysia 'will affect sentiment more than business'
summary: Malaysia has implemented a two-week partial lockdown, known as the Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO), in Kuala Lumpur, Putrajaya, Sabah, and Selangor. Analysts at MIDF Research predict minimal economic impact, with businesses allowed to operate according to standard procedures. However, markets are expected to be volatile, and consumer spending may weaken due to the lockdown, with spillover effects on service industries. The government has approved 98% of loan extension applications, and 60% of companies will receive reduced monthly loan instalments.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while in Europe, stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: From peak city to ghost town: the urban centres hit hardest by Covid-19
summary: London and New York are experiencing significant declines in city centre visits, with London's cafés, restaurants, and retailers seeing less than one-third of pre-pandemic levels, and Manhattan's amenities less than half that of pre-pandemic levels. The shift towards remote work, driven by Covid-19, is accelerating the pull of suburbs for families and shifting jobs out of city centres. Experts predict that cities will become less dense and more dispersed, with a focus on innovation, face-to-face interaction, and meeting space, and that the role of cities may be diminished, with suburbs becoming more interesting over time.

site_title: Klopp happy 'Project Big Picture' kickstarted debate on English football
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp expressed support for the English football debate sparked by "Project Big Picture," which proposed increasing funds for clubs and introducing special voting rights for top-flight teams. Premier League clubs rejected the plans, but Klopp welcomed the discussion to improve the sport. He believes that a crisis is necessary to initiate change and improve the sport before potential problems arise. Klopp also expressed admiration for Everton's current form under Carlo Ancelotti, who has led the team to a 100% record in the league.

images.alt_text: Liverpool boss Juergen Klopp said on Friday that it was crucial that Premier League clubs and stakeholders continue to discuss how to improve English football after the controversial proposals in "Project Big Picture" came to light.

site_title: China-owned gaming firm Playtika files confidentially for US IPO
summary: Playtika Holding, a mobile gaming company owned by a Chinese investor group, has confidentially submitted paperwork with the US Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering (IPO). The company, known for its casino-themed games, aims to go public later this year or early in 2021, potentially valuing it at around $10 billion. This move comes as several China-owned companies are reconsidering their listings on US exchanges amid rising tensions between Washington and Beijing.

site_title: Reits (October 17-18, 2020)
summary: Realtors and investors are bracing for a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore's prime projects, with prices expected to surpass the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed for the first time in five weeks, while Manhattan rents have reached a new record. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at a Singapore property post-bankruptcy, and New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. These developments signal a potentially volatile real estate market.

site_title: Opec+ fears second virus wave could lead to oil surplus in 2021
summary: OPEC+ officials fear a prolonged second wave of the Covid-19 pandemic and increased Libyan oil output could lead to an oil surplus in 2021, contrary to a gloomier outlook just a month ago. The Joint Technical Committee considered a worst-case scenario where the market could flip into a surplus of 200,000 barrels per day, threatening plans to add 2 million barrels per day to the market. Despite this, OPEC has not indicated plans to scrap its supply boost, and a ministerial OPEC+ panel will consider the outlook on Monday.

site_title: Pet relocation and prices surge with easing of cross-border curbs for owners
summary: Pet relocation companies in Singapore have seen a surge in demand, with some reporting up to three times more queries during the past six months compared to the same period last year. The easing of cross-border curbs for owners has led to a significant increase in pet relocations, with industry players noting that they are moving 15-100% more animals. However, transport issues remain a problem, with unpredictable flight schedules and higher freight costs affecting the industry.

images.alt_text: At the peak of the relocation crunch in August, it could cost around three times more per pet, observers told BT.

site_title: STI up on the week amid NODX gains, HK travel bubble
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week in the black, climbing 0.37% or 9.4 points to close at 2,533.02. The NODX figures for September rose 5.9% year on year, mainly due to an increase in electronics shipments. Wilmar International was the top performer among STI constituents, gaining 2.98%. The week's gains were a rebound after a previous decline, as investors reacted positively to the NODX figures and the potential for travel to resume, sparked by the Hong Kong travel bubble.

site_title: EU says still seeking Brexit accord despite Johnson's 'no-deal' rhetoric
summary: The European Union (EU) continues to pursue a Brexit accord despite British Prime Minister Boris Johnson's comments on preparing for a no-trade deal split. EU President Ursula von der Leyen stated that the EU will intensify negotiations with the UK next week. Johnson claimed the EU refused to negotiate seriously, but an EU diplomat said his statement was "just rhetoric" and that talks would continue. The EU's Brexit negotiating team is packing for an intense week in London, with a focus on a zero-tariff and zero-quota deal.

site_title: UnUsUaL expects net loss for H1 FY2021
summary: UnUsUal Limited, a Catalist-listed entertainment company, expects to report a net loss for the first half of its financial year to September 2021 due to the impact of the pandemic on its projects. The company was profitable for the corresponding period last year, but its projects were postponed during the "circuit breaker" period in Singapore. UnUsUal is currently working on new projects and will make announcements at an appropriate time. The company is also finalizing its unaudited financial results for H1 FY2021.

site_title: Philippines' Parliament approves 4.5t peso budget for 2021 coronavirus recovery
summary: The Philippines' lower parliamentary house approved a 4.5 trillion pesos (S$125.59 billion) budget bill aimed at recovering from the coronavirus pandemic. The bill, approved by 257 lawmakers, now passes to the senate for further hearings. The budget plan is part of President Rodrigo Duterte's efforts to help the economy recover from the pandemic, following a special session of Parliament last week. The bill will be finalized in a joint congressional session before being signed by the President.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post third week of gains on upbeat China data, policy support
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for the third consecutive week, driven by upbeat China data and policy support. The Hang Seng index gained 0.9% to 24,386.79, while the China Enterprises Index rose 1.6% to 9,914.90. Investors cheered China's fastest-growing imports in September, new bank loans, and policy reforms. Beijing's continued support for its capital markets boosted risk appetite. The economic recovery in China is likely to step up in the third quarter, with consumers returning to shopping malls and major trading partners reopening.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar says facing 'malicious' probe on list of backers for PM bid
summary: Malaysia's opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim claims a police investigation into a viral list of lawmakers backing his bid for prime minister is "malicious" and a "political harassment." The probe, sparked by a list of 121 lawmakers, is seen as an attempt to pressure Anwar into revealing his supporters. Anwar, who met with King Al-Sultan Abdullah to present documentation, says only the king has the right to know the identities of lawmakers backing him. The investigation is seen as a bid to undermine Anwar's chances of becoming prime minister.

site_title: Cut pay only if needed to minimise retrenchments: NWC
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore has given the green light for temporary wage cuts to minimize retrenchments. The wage guidelines, applicable from Nov 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021, aim to help businesses emerge stronger from the crisis. The cuts are only to be made after exhausting non-wage saving measures and government support. The six principles set by the NWC include making pay cuts only when necessary, retaining jobs, and prioritizing workers who are most vulnerable to retrenchment. The goal is to save jobs and support businesses during the crisis.

site_title: US-based hedge fund D E Shaw to open Singapore office
summary: US-based hedge fund D E Shaw is set to open an office in Singapore next year, expanding its reach in Asia. The firm, with over $50 billion in investment capital, has applied for a fund management licence from the Singapore central bank. This move follows other hedge funds, including Citadel and Marshall Wace, which have also opened offices in Singapore amid rising uncertainty in Hong Kong. D E Shaw plans to tap into the region's talent, capital, and investment opportunities, further growing its geographic footprint.

site_title: Digital payments in Asean to triple to US$1.5t by 2030: report
summary: Digital payments in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) are expected to triple to US$1.5 trillion by 2030, driven by underbanked consumers, high smartphone and internet penetration, and merchant acceptance of QR code payment methods. Ride-hailing and e-commerce apps, such as Sea's SeaMoney e-wallet and Shopee, are well-positioned to gain share due to their large consumer bases and engagement with users and merchants. Telecom-driven platforms and fintech companies are also expected to play a significant role in the region's growing digital payments market.

site_title: Nine new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including eight imported
summary: Nine new Covid-19 cases were reported in Singapore, bringing the total to 57,901. The cases include one in a worker's dormitory and eight imported cases who were placed on stay-home notices. The average number of new daily cases in the community has decreased, with no new unlinked cases reported in a week. 57,749 patients have fully recovered from the disease, and 36 remain in hospital.

images.alt_text: There were nine new coronavirus cases confirmed as of Friday noon, taking Singapore's total to 57,901.

site_title: Indonesia sees China firms lead 'commitment' for US$35b in nickel investments
summary: Indonesia expects a significant increase in nickel investments, reaching US$35 billion by 2033, led by Chinese companies. During a visit to Yunnan province, Indonesian Coordinating Minister for Maritime and Investment Affairs Luhut Pandjaitan met with representatives from China's Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Ltd and Ningbo Lygend Mining Co, among others, to discuss expansion plans for nickel processing and petrochemicals. The companies aim to double their current investment of around US$16 billion and collaborate with investors from other countries to achieve this goal.

site_title: India's car, motorbike sales surge as dealerships stock up ahead of festive season
summary: India's passenger vehicle and motorbike sales surged in September, driven by dealerships stocking up ahead of the festive season. Passenger vehicle wholesale sales rose 26% from last year, while motorbike sales to dealers increased 12%. However, retail sales growth was slower, with a 10% increase in passenger vehicles and a 12% decline in motorbike sales. This marks a rebound from months of decline due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: STI ends the week in the black, following gains in NODX figures and air travel bubble plans
summary: Singapore shares ended the week in the black, driven by gains in non-oil domestic exports (NODX) figures and air travel bubble plans. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.37% to close at 2,533.02, with Wilmar International and Singapore Airlines top performers. Despite concerns about the path of recovery in the services-producing sector, the STI rebounded as investors reacted positively to the news of the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble.

site_title: Hulu gets sidelined in Disney's global streaming ambitions
summary: Walt Disney Co. has decided to limit Hulu's global streaming ambitions, opting instead to create a new general entertainment service under the Star umbrella. The decision, made after considering a proposed expansion plan, was influenced by Hulu's limited name recognition outside the US and the cost of investing at least $4 billion in international expansion. The move comes as Disney faces financial pressures, including the looming cost of buying out Comcast's ownership stake in Hulu. The decision underscores the challenges of adapting entertainment companies built on traditional TV and movie studios to the world of streaming.

site_title: Tokyo opens Hong Kong office to attract firms to financial hub
summary: Tokyo has opened an office in Hong Kong to attract foreign firms and make the city a global financial hub. The move aims to counter Hong Kong's recent turmoil and high taxes. Governor Yuriko Koike said her goal is to make Tokyo the No 1 financial city in Asia. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government is offering to cover three months' rent for foreign companies considering setting up offices in the city, with the goal of finding space for overseas firms by November.

site_title: Singapore's Nanofilm to raise up to S$510m, largest local IPO in year
summary: Singapore's Nanofilm Technologies International launched an initial public offering (IPO) on Friday, aiming to raise up to S$510 million, the largest local IPO in a year. The company, which makes coating materials for electronics, would be the first local tech unicorn to list in Singapore, if successful. Nanofilm has secured 13 cornerstone investors, including subsidiaries of Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings, and is led by executive chairman Shi Xu, a professor at Nanyang Technological University. The IPO is seen as a step to attract companies to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after Hong Kong became Asia's dominant IPO market.

site_title: Medical product sector to cushion Asean's growth amid pandemic
summary: ASEAN's medical product sector is expected to cushion the region's growth during the Covid-19 pandemic, with a 14.6% market share in emerging Asia. Asean countries like Singapore and Thailand have benefited from strong pharmaceutical production, while Malaysia and Vietnam have seen growth from rubber glove production. However, protectionism in the medical trade poses risks, particularly for Singapore and Vietnam, and export controls may disrupt supply chains. Despite this, capacity-building efforts in Indonesia may help mitigate the risks, and Asean's GDP cushion is expected to be larger than other emerging Asia economies.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX judged safe to fly by Europe's aviation regulator
summary: Europe's aviation regulator, EASA, has deemed Boeing's 737 MAX safe to fly, with the agency's executive director Patrick Ky stating that the plane's analysis shows a high level of safety. The decision comes after test flights in September and is expected to be finalized next month, pending public comment. A synthetic sensor, which will be required on the larger Max 10 variant, is expected to take 20-24 months to develop. The FAA has also expressed comfort with the plane's safety, but has not predicted a specific timeline for its return to service.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore non-oil exports rose 5.9% in September, driven by the electronics sector's recovery. The National Wages Council set temporary wage-cutting guidelines to save jobs. Big Tech firms are snapping up office space in Singapore, while airfares between Singapore and Hong Kong are expected to increase 40% due to a travel bubble plan. Despite gloomy conditions, Asean IPO volume rebounded in Q3. Retail rents may bottom out by early 2021, with Orchard malls leading the decline. The STI ended the week in the black, following positive reactions to non-oil exports and air travel bubble plans.

site_title: New Jobs Development Partners to proactively work with firms to create new roles
summary: The National Jobs Council has appointed the Singapore Business Federation, Institute of Banking & Finance, and NTUC's Employment and Employability Institute as Jobs Development Partners to create new job opportunities and traineeships. The partners will identify companies with hiring potential, help create or redesign jobs, and provide training programs to bridge skill gaps between job seekers and companies. The Institute of Banking & Finance will launch a survey on hiring opportunities in the financial services sector, while the Singapore Business Federation and NTUC's e2i will work with companies to internationalize and upskill employees.

site_title: Malaysia tycoon seeks stake in major palm oil producer
summary: Malaysian tycoon Syed Mokhtar Albukhary is seeking to merge his plantation assets with FGV Holdings, aiming to secure a stake in the country's largest palm oil producer. The proposed merger, if successful, could bolster FGV's fortunes and challenge rival Sime Darby Plantations as the world's top palm oil producer. FGV shares rose 7.5% following the announcement, with analysts expressing concerns over the lack of details on how the merger would create value for shareholders.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest weekly fall in three as global virus woes weigh
summary: South Korean shares posted their largest weekly fall in three as global COVID-19 concerns weighed on sentiment, with the benchmark Kospi falling 2.1% and shares of Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix declining 0.83% and 2.07% respectively. The won weakened, while the 10-year bond yield rose, amid fading hopes for a US stimulus package and a resurgence in cases across Europe and the US, with 47 new cases reported in South Korea.

site_title: British Airways slapped with UK data watchdog's biggest-ever fine
summary: The UK's Information Commissioner's Office has fined British Airways £20 million for failing to protect the personal and financial details of over 400,000 customers following a 2018 cyber attack. The regulator considered BA's representations and economic impact before setting a final penalty, which was less than the £183.4 million proposed last year. The ICO found that BA should have identified and resolved security weaknesses to prevent the attack, which may have caused anxiety and distress for affected customers. IAG shares fell 3% following the announcement.

site_title: Hertz gets US$1.65b bankruptcy financing package
summary: Hertz Global Holdings has secured a $1.65 billion debt financing package to support its bankruptcy case. The deal, structured as a delayed-draw term loan, will be used for vehicle acquisition in the US and Canada and working capital. The company had previously attempted to sell new shares to fund its bankruptcy, but the new deal is seen as a positive development, with the stock rising 40% premarket. Certain first-lien lenders will provide the financing, which is expected to help Hertz recover from its financial struggles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 10.11 points to 1,503.84. The index saw a trading volume of 8.705 billion lots worth RM4.768 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 583 to 488.

site_title: Instagram commits to fighting hidden ads amid UK probe
summary: Facebook's Instagram has committed to making it "much harder" for users to post ads without labeling them as such, following a UK probe by the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) into combatting misleading online ads. Users will be prompted to confirm if they have been incentivized to promote a product or service and, if so, require them to disclose this fact clearly. The changes will affect users in the UK and those directing posts to Instagram users in the country.

site_title: Tencent chooses co-working space for first Singapore office
summary: Tencent Holdings has chosen a co-working space in Singapore for its first office in the city-state, with a 10,000 square foot lease at JustCo's OCBC Centre East at Raffles Place. The lease runs for one year, allowing the company flexibility to expand as needed. This move follows similar expansions by Bytedance and Alibaba Group, and is seen as a strategic push into South-east Asia, where Singapore's office market could benefit from increased demand from Chinese tech firms.

site_title: Europe car sales rise 1.1% in surprise first gain of the year
summary: Europe's new-car registrations rose 1.1% in September, the first sales increase this year, driven by gains in Italy and Germany, where government incentives for electric vehicles supported sales. However, the momentum is expected to be short-lived due to ongoing COVID-19 cases and targeted strategies to slow the spread of the disease. Europe's car sales are still down 29% for the year through September, with analysts predicting annual deliveries to decline at least 20%.

site_title: Japan to release Fukushima's contaminated water into sea: reports
summary: Japan plans to release nearly 1.2 million tonnes of contaminated water from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant into the sea, a decision expected to be made later this month. The water, stored in tanks since 2011, contains radioactive materials except for tritium, which is considered harmless. The move is expected to devastate the fishing industry and rankle neighboring countries, including South Korea. The process is expected to take around two years to prepare and dilute the water with seawater before release.

site_title: Firm US dollar, fading stimulus hopes put gold on course for weekly loss
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,903.24 per ounce, set for its first weekly loss in three, due to a firm US dollar and fading hopes for additional US fiscal stimulus before the presidential election. The US dollar, considered a safe haven, is headed for its first weekly gain in three, supported by surging coronavirus cases globally. Gold may retest support at $1,896 per ounce, a break below which could cause a fall to $1,877.

site_title: Schroders to accelerate regional sustainability efforts from Singapore
summary: Schroders, a leading asset manager, announced plans to accelerate its regional sustainability efforts from Singapore, establishing a Centre of Excellence for Sustainability (CoES) to drive ESG research and innovation across the Asia-Pacific. The move comes as institutional asset owners and intermediary partners accelerate their ESG adoption, catalyzed by the Covid-19 pandemic. Schroders will anchor the CoES in Singapore with senior ESG specialists, aiming to provide thought leadership in sustainability and drive impact across the region.

site_title: Singapore's tax revenue up 2.1%, but analysts say collections may fall next year
summary: Singapore's tax revenue rose 2.1% to S$53.5 billion in the fiscal year 2019/20, accounting for 72% of government operating revenue. The collection represented 10.5% of the country's gross domestic product. Analysts warn that this growth may slow due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Brokers' take: SIA, Cathay Pacific, Far East Hospitality to get fillip from planned travel bubble
summary: Singapore Airlines, Cathay Pacific Airways, and Far East Hospitality Trust are expected to benefit from the planned two-way air travel bubble between Singapore and Hong Kong. The bubble, which may launch in weeks, will allow for quarantine-free travel between the two cities, sparking interest from both leisure and business travelers. This could boost SIA's passenger capacity, SATS' air traffic, and FEHT's hospitality sector, with DBS analysts predicting improved occupancies and a "buy" rating for these companies.

site_title: Big Tech is here, and it's snapping up real estate in Singapore
summary: Tech giants, including Tencent, ByteDance, and Amazon, are snapping up office space in Singapore, taking advantage of crimped rents amid the pandemic. These firms are expanding into the Asean region and plan to hire hundreds of staff in Singapore. Central business district office rents have fallen 3.4% year-to-date, with further compression expected. Landlords are offering higher incentives, including rent-free periods, to attract tenants. The take-up of office space by tech firms is expected to increase to 400,000-500,000 sq ft in 2021.

images.alt_text: The relatively stronger take-up of real estate by Big Tech in Singapore reflects a global trend of tech giants taking up more real estate.

site_title: Singapore-Hong Kong airfares jump 40% on travel bubble plan
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong unveiled plans for a travel bubble, which would allow passengers to travel between the two cities without quarantine upon arrival. The move is expected to boost air travel between the two financial hubs, with airfares rising 40% on the cheapest return economy seat from S$400 to S$558. Cathay Pacific Airways rose 6.4% on the news, while Singapore Airlines added 0.9%. The travel bubble is set to start in "weeks," with compulsory quarantine replaced by coronavirus testing.

site_title: Europe: Shares set for weekly losses as virus cases surge
summary: European shares are expected to end the week with losses despite a 0.7% gain on Friday, driven by concerns over a second wave of Covid-19 infections, Brexit uncertainty, and US fiscal stimulus doubts. Banks, insurers, and energy stocks bounced, but the Stoxx 600 index is still on track for a weekly decline. A resurgence in coronavirus cases and lockdown fears in London and Paris have contributed to the sell-off, while Brexit negotiations will be closely watched on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls as coronavirus resurgence in Europe hits sentiment
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.41% to 23,410.63 on Friday, weighed down by a resurgence of coronavirus cases in Europe, which dimmed hopes for a swift global economic recovery. The broader Topix lost 0.86%, with all but two sector sub-indexes trading lower. Despite this, gains from Fast Retailing and Fujifilm Holdings helped limit losses. The Nikkei dropped 0.89% for the week, its largest decline in over two months.

site_title: Singapore firms may cut wages temporarily to protect jobs: NWC
summary: Singapore's National Wages Council has set six principles for temporary wage cuts to protect jobs, applicable from Nov 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021. The guidelines require businesses to exhaust non-wage saving measures and government support before implementing cuts. The council also emphasizes the urgent need for businesses to implement the flexible wage system. Despite rejecting wage cuts for employers' CPF contributions, the guidelines aim to help businesses emerge stronger from the crisis.

site_title: EVOS Esports parent snags US$12m in Series B round led by Korea Investment Partners
summary: ATTN Holdings, the parent company of EVOS Esports, has raised US$12 million in a Series B investment round led by Korea Investment Partners, with other investors including Mirae Asset Ventures and Indogen Capital. The funding will help the company expand its e-sports ecosystem in Asia, where revenue has doubled since the start of the year and surpassed last year's numbers despite the pandemic. With a compound annual growth rate of 15% projected for global e-sports revenue, EVOS aims to launch the region's first-ever e-sports platform.

site_title: Thai central bank will not extend debt moratorium, but plans targeted measure
summary: Thailand's central bank will not extend its six-month debt moratorium, but will introduce targeted measures to assist debtors affected by the pandemic. The bank will focus on small and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) with significant debt, offering debt relief and restructuring talks. SMEs with 400 billion baht owed to specialized state banks will receive an additional three-six month debt moratorium, while those owing 950 billion baht to commercial banks and non-banks will be mostly able to service their debt. The bank aims to prevent non-performing loans and encourage debt repayment.

site_title: Australia: Shares finish lower as mining, energy stocks fall
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Friday, led by mining stocks after Rio Tinto raised concerns about steel production outside China. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,176.80. The broader mining sector lost 0.6%, while BHP Group fell 1.4%. The energy sector declined 1%, and healthcare stocks dropped 0.7%. The decline was attributed to concerns over global economic growth due to rising coronavirus cases in Europe and stalled US stimulus talks.

site_title: China warns Canada against granting Hong Kongers sanctuary
summary: China's top diplomat in Ottawa, Cong Peiwu, warned Canada against granting asylum to Hong Kong democracy protesters, stating it could jeopardize the "health and safety" of Canadians in Hong Kong. The warning came after a Hong Kong couple who participated in last year's protests was granted refugee status, potentially leading to more Hong Kongers seeking sanctuary in Canada. Canada's Foreign Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne responded, calling Cong's comments "totally unacceptable" and vowing to stand up for human rights. Tensions between the two countries have been escalating since Canada's arrest of Huawei executive Meng Wanzhou in 2018.

site_title: NEA, Shell to explore feasibility of chemically recycling Singapore's plastic waste
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) and Shell are collaborating on a study to explore the feasibility of chemically recycling plastic waste in Singapore. The joint study will examine various methods, including waste segregation facilities and plastic pyrolysis plants, to convert plastic waste into higher-value products. The goal is to improve plastic recycling rates, reduce carbon emissions, and create new jobs. This initiative complements NEA's consultancy study on a pilot Plastic Recovery Facility and aligns with Shell's ambition to use one million tonnes of plastic waste as feedstock by 2025.

site_title: Taiwan's Foxconn says eying electric vehicle market
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, a major supplier to Apple, aims to capture 10% of the global electric vehicle market by 2027. Chairman Liu Young-way stated the company's goal is to push Taiwan's EV industry to the world through future cooperation with multiple carmakers. Foxconn is diversifying its investments into sectors like electric vehicles, digital health, and robots to drive growth. The company's move follows a broader trend of automotive companies shifting focus to electric vehicles as governments implement emission-reducing policies.

site_title: Asean IPO volume, proceeds rebound in Q3 from previous quarter: EY
summary: Asean IPO volume and proceeds rebounded in Q3 2020, with 33 IPOs raising $1.10 billion, a 175% and 491% increase from the previous quarter. The region has seen 77 IPOs this year, totaling $4.30 billion, a 12% increase from last year. Key sectors such as technology, industrials, and healthcare have dominated global IPO activity, with 62% of deals and 67% of proceeds. Despite uncertainty over US-China trade tensions and the US presidential election, EY expects deals to continue as long as a "window of opportunity remains open".

site_title: Lone money-making South-east Asia stock fund is changing tack
summary: Singapore-based fund manager Alan Richardson is shifting his portfolio to focus on cyclical and value shares in South-east Asia, expecting a global economic recovery driven by the potential rollout of a successful Covid-19 vaccine. With a 13% return this year, Richardson's fund is the only Asean mandate to gain, despite the region's worst-performing national benchmarks. He expects emerging markets and cyclical sectors to outperform developed markets, with a potential US victory for Joe Biden adding impetus to this shift.

site_title: Australia: Miners drag shares lower; New Zealand falls before election results
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,193.40, pressured by weak iron ore prices and waning hopes for US fiscal stimulus. New Zealand's benchmark slipped 0.5% ahead of election results. Global market sentiment was also affected by US presidential election uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore retail rents may bottom out by early 2021; Orchard malls still leading decline
summary: Singapore retail rents are expected to bottom out by early 2021, with overall rents predicted to fall 10-15% for the year due to recessionary pressures and safe-distancing restrictions. Suburban malls, however, are expected to recover sooner due to domestic demand. Prime retail rents in Orchard fell 11% year-on-year, while those in suburban areas declined by 6.9%. Despite store closures, new retail openings, such as Hang Heung and Decathlon, indicate a stabilizing market.

site_title: Malaysia's king urges politicians to end uncertainty amid power struggle
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah has urged politicians to resolve the country's power struggle through negotiations and legal processes, calling an end to the uncertainty amid a dispute between Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. The king's comments come as the country faces various problems, including the COVID-19 epidemic. He advised politicians to put the country's interests above personal interests, emphasizing the need for unity and cooperation to overcome the challenges facing the nation.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh lockdowns, stimulus
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday, with gains driven by bargain-buying after a sell-off, amid concerns over new lockdowns in Europe and the US economy's need for stimulus. Traders also monitored developments in Washington as lawmakers struggle to agree on a new stimulus package. Analysts believe Democrats' strong opinion poll leads may lead to a bigger rescue package, boosting equities.

site_title: Chinese cotton mills told to stop buying Australian cotton: source
summary: Australia's government has ordered Chinese cotton mills to stop buying Australian cotton, a move amid worsening trade relations between the two countries. China was the largest buyer of Australian cotton, worth around A$900 million in the 2018/19 crop year. The decision follows Canberra's allegations that China was meddling in its domestic affairs. This marks the latest sign of strained relations between the two nations.

images.alt_text: Chinese cotton mills have been ordered to stop buying Australian cotton, an Australian government source briefed on the matter said on Friday, the latest sign of worsening trade relations between the two countries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.15% to 24,194.41, following a sharp sell-off the previous day. China stocks also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.39% to 3,345.06 and the Shenzhen Composite Index adding 0.09% to 2,276.54. The gains were despite a worse-than-forecast US jobs reading, leaving traders cautious about market movements.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, up 4.13 points, or 0.27%, to 1,518.08. The market saw a 195-64 gain-to-lose ratio. No specific reasons for the increase were mentioned in the article.

site_title: Tokyo Stock Exchange to submit report on trade outage to regulator: Nikkei
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) will submit a report to its regulator on a trading outage that occurred on October 1, 2020, halting trading due to a hardware problem and system failure. The TSE will develop procedures to resume trading following system trouble and establish a consultation body with brokerages to discuss necessary measures. This move aims to prevent future trading halts and ensure the stability of the bourse.

site_title: China set to pass law protecting vital tech from US
summary: China is set to pass a new Export Control Law, which would restrict sensitive exports vital to national security, expanding its toolkit as competition with the US grows. The law would apply to all companies in China, including foreign-invested ones, and would add to Beijing's regulatory arsenal. It would help put China on a similar footing to the US, which regularly uses export controls and licenses strategically against its adversaries. The law would allow China to take reciprocal measures against countries that have "abused export control measures and damaged national security."

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on positive NODX figures; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% or 11.20 points to 2,534.82 on Friday, driven by positive non-oil domestic exports (NODX) figures that rose 5.9% year-over-year. This beat analysts' expectations and follows gains in July and August. Shares of glove manufacturers and local lenders also advanced, while Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Cycle and Carriage declined. US stocks fell for the third day in a row amid rising doubts over a potential stimulus package and the reinstatement of Covid-19 restrictions in Europe.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following Wall Street's falls, as investors watched corporate earnings reports. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.13% to 23,477.20, while the Topix index slipped 0.27% to 1,627.36. This is the second day of losses, with investors closely monitoring US-EU trade talks and the ongoing corporate earnings season.

site_title: Japan to release treated Fukushima water into sea: reports
summary: Japan plans to release over 1.23 million tonnes of treated Fukushima water into the sea, starting in 2022, despite opposition from local fishermen and environmental activists. The water, filtered to reduce radioactivity, will be diluted 40 times before release. The decision comes after a government panel deemed releasing the water or evaporating it as "realistic options." Tritium, a remaining radioactive isotope, poses a risk but can be diluted to a safe level. The process will take 30 years.

site_title: Australia's New Hope to lay off up to 75% of HQ staff amid sour market
summary: Australian coal miner New Hope Corp plans to lay off up to 75% of its headquarters staff due to uncertainty over approvals for its New Acland mine. The layoffs, affecting around 90 workers, are largely due to a decline in coal prices and China's halt on imports. The company, which has already cut 175 jobs, cited a tough market outlook, with thermal coal prices hitting decade lows. CEO Reinhold Schmidt stated that even with approvals, the company faces a challenging period ahead.

site_title: Fashion brands accused of exploiting workers at risk of layoffs
summary: Fashion brands are demanding price cuts and delaying payments to suppliers, putting millions of garment workers at risk of layoffs. Global brands are asking suppliers to reduce prices by an average of 12% and are paying suppliers an average of 77 days after orders, up from 43 days before the pandemic. Suppliers have already laid off 10% of their workers and may have to cut another 35% if orders continue to decline. This could lead to millions of garment workers losing their jobs, with over half of manufacturers saying they would have to close if the "sourcing squeeze" continues.

site_title: Twitter says investigating global platform outage
summary: Twitter is investigating a global platform outage affecting hundreds of millions of users. The company stated they are working to resolve the issue as quickly as possible. The cause of the outage is not specified.

images.alt_text: Twitter was working on Thursday evening to resolve a global outage of the social media platform used by hundreds of millions worldwide.

site_title: Uber to invest over US$150m in partnership with SK Telecom's mobility business
summary: Uber is investing over US$150 million in a partnership with SK Telecom's mobility business, T Map Mobility. SK Telecom plans to split off its mobility business unit, with Uber committing US$100 million in a joint venture and US$50 million in T Map Mobility. The partnership aims to enhance mobility services in South Korea.

site_title: Biden, Trump squabble over coronavirus response in dueling town halls
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden attacked President Donald Trump's handling of the coronavirus pandemic during dueling televised town halls, blaming Trump for downplaying the virus that has killed over 216,000 Americans. Trump defended his response and criticized Biden for spending months off the campaign trail, while also showing little interest in altering his belligerent tone. The town halls came after a second presidential debate was canceled, with millions already voting early ahead of Election Day on November 3. Biden's campaign collected $1.5 billion in online donations, setting a new record for a US campaign.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Singapore's first food truck, The Travelling C.O.W, has launched a curated beef tray of five different cuts of meat that can be delivered to homes. The C.O.Wabunga tray includes assorted meat rubs, recipes, and a beef journal, priced at S$168. Meanwhile, a recent push by Korea's agriculture ministry aims to promote high-quality ingredients, with top Michelin chefs creating dishes using Korean produce available at Culina Market in Dempsey.

site_title: Half of England now under tougher virus restrictions
summary: The UK government has imposed tougher coronavirus restrictions on roughly half of England, including London and seven other areas, to combat surging case numbers. The measures, which come into effect on Saturday, ban households mixing indoors and limit groups meeting outside to six. The restrictions will affect nearly 28 million people, with the UK recording nearly 19,000 new positive cases. The government has refused to impose a national lockdown, instead favoring a targeted, local approach, which has sparked criticism from leaders in northwest England.

site_title: HC Surgical's Julian Ong awarded costs after Serene Tiong's appeal bid falls through
summary: HC Surgical Specialist Julian Ong has been awarded costs of S$3,000 after Serene Tiong's appeal bid to the Court of Appeal was dismissed. Tiong, a minority shareholder of HC Surgical, had claimed that Ong and psychiatrist Chan Herng Nieng colluded to take advantage of vulnerable patients, but the High Court ruled in Ong's favor on Oct 2, finding her defamatory. The court also ordered her to pay S$40,000 in costs to Ong.

site_title: Twitter service restored following global platform outage
summary: Twitter service was restored on Thursday evening after a nearly two-hour global outage caused by a technical problem. The outage occurred around 2130 GMT and affected users worldwide, with concentrated issues on the east and west coasts of the US and Japan. Twitter attributed the issue to internal systems trouble and denied evidence of a security breach or hack. The platform had previously experienced outages in July 2019 and February 2020, and had also been targeted by hacking attacks in July 2020.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to invest in electric car producton in Canada
summary: Fiat Chrysler has committed to investing up to C$1.5 billion in its Windsor plant in southern Ontario, Canada, as part of a three-year deal with union Unifor. The investment will outfit the factory to assemble plug-in hybrids and battery-powered vehicles, with at least one new model expected in 2025. The move is expected to create up to 2,000 new jobs, with the company aiming to expand its electric vehicle production in Canada.

site_title: US recovery will be grinding and slow without more stimulus: Federal Reserve's Kashkari
summary: US economic recovery is expected to slow down without additional stimulus, according to Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari. If unemployed Americans and struggling businesses don't receive more assistance, the recovery will be "grinding" and slower. Lawmakers are still in negotiations for further fiscal stimulus, with President Trump calling for larger benefits. The Fed is limited in its ability to help, and Kashkari emphasized the need for direct fiscal aid to small businesses and jobless Americans to prevent financial pain from spilling over to the economy.

site_title: EU leaders to decide tougher climate goal in December
summary: EU leaders agreed to decide on a more stringent climate goal for 2030 at a summit in December, aiming to surpass the current 40% reduction in CO2 emissions. The European Commission proposes a 55% target, while the European Parliament suggests 60%. The decision comes as the EU seeks to meet its Paris Climate Agreement commitment of being climate-neutral by 2050. Eastern member states, reliant on coal, face resistance to the new target, but big EU powers like France and Germany support the move to forge a united response to climate change.

site_title: Goh Jin Hian resigns from New Silkroutes Group as chairman; finance director also quits
summary: New Silkroutes Group chairman Goh Jin Hian and finance director William Teo Thiam Chuan have resigned, with Dr. Goh also stepping down as Cordlife Group's independent director. The resignations come after the firm's auditor gave a disclaimer of opinion on its financial statements and amid investigations into alleged false trading and market rigging. Dr. Goh had previously quit as Cordlife's chairman after a judicial manager sued him over alleged breach of director's duties.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, New Silkroutes, Wilmar, SIA, Keppel DC Reit, Straits Trading
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies saw developments on Friday, including ThaiBev, New Silkroutes, and Wilmar International. ThaiBev lost 1.7% to S$0.57 after a tightening of emergency regulations in Thailand, while New Silkroutes shares fell 2% to 11.4 cents after the resignation of its chairman and finance director. Wilmar International's stock price dropped 6.4% to S$4.36 after a high-volume trading day. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines reported a 29.5% year-on-year increase in cargo load factor, and Keppel DC Reit will join the Straits Times Index on October 19.

site_title: SIA's September cargo load factor improves on reduced capacity
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 29.5 percentage point improvement in September's cargo load factor to 89% due to a 59.4% contraction in capacity, outpacing the 39.3% decline in cargo traffic. Total freight carried increased to 59.6 million kg, while group passenger capacity remained weak, with a 98.1% decline in revenue passenger-kilometres. The airline's recovery is attributed to government efforts to reopen borders, with the carrier rebuilding its network and increasing passenger flights.

site_title: Daimler announces better than expected third-quarter results
summary: Daimler announced better-than-expected third-quarter results, citing a faster-than-expected market recovery, especially in September. The German carmaker's third-quarter earnings before interest and tax reached 3.07 billion euros, thanks to the strong market recovery. The car industry was severely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic earlier in the year, with lockdowns and shutdowns affecting sales. Daimler's results were a positive sign for the industry, indicating a potential recovery.

site_title: US trade imbalance hits crop exports with lack of containers
summary: US trade imbalance affects crop exports due to limited shipping containers. The country's imports exceed exports, causing a squeeze on containers carrying American cotton, grain, and hay. Shippers in Asia prefer empty containers over delayed shipments, and US customers may avoid supplies if competitors in Australia or South America offer cheaper options. The US Department of Agriculture reports that only 9% of waterborne grain shipments were in containers last year. The Port of Los Angeles sees a decline in exports and a record number of inbound shipments, highlighting the need for a cohesive export plan and national infrastructure.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports rise 5.9% in September amid recovery in electronics
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 5.9% in September, driven by a recovery in the electronics sector, which grew 21.4% year-over-year. This was short of analyst expectations of an 11.5% increase. Non-electronics exports grew 1.8%, supported by safe-haven gold and machinery shipments. However, the chemicals cluster declined 23.8%, and pharmaceuticals contracted 27.3% due to a high-base effect and the pandemic's volatility. Total trade dipped 1.9% year-over-year, with oil trade and prices continuing to decline.

site_title: Trump ex-fundraiser to plead guilty in 1MDB foreign lobbying case
summary: Former Trump fundraiser Elliot Broidy is expected to plead guilty to charges of illegally lobbying US President Donald Trump to drop an investigation into Malaysia's 1MDB scandal. Broidy, a businessman with ties to Trump, agreed to take millions in exchange for lobbying Trump and the Department of Justice to end the investigation. The charges, filed under the US Foreign Registration Act, mark the latest person with ties to Trump to be charged with a crime. Broidy is due in court next week to hear a plea deal.

images.alt_text: A former fundraiser for US President Donald Trump is expected to plead guilty next week to charges of illegally lobbying Mr Trump to drop an investigation into a massive Malaysian embezzlement scandal, according to court documents filed Thursday.

site_title: Zoom wants to partner with Slack and Microsoft
