ST Engineering leveraged its existing technologies, such as robots used in hospitals and hotels, to provide solutions for the pandemic. The company's agility and speed in responding to the crisis demonstrated its ability to adapt and provide solutions to emerging problems.

site_title: K-pop group BTS' label Big Hit debuts at double its IPO price
summary: Big Hit Entertainment, the management label of K-pop group BTS, debuted at double its initial public offering (IPO) price, opening at 270,000 won. The company is valued at approximately 9.6 trillion won (S$11.4 billion). This marks the largest IPO in South Korea in three years and puts Big Hit on track to join the all-time top 10 debuts on the South Korean stock market.

site_title: CapitaLand's Ascott signs 12 more properties in China; enters Austria
summary: CapitaLand's Ascott Limited has secured over 2,100 new units in 12 properties in China, with revenue from its Chinese properties almost fully recovering to pre-Covid-19 levels. The company has also signed contracts for 10 more properties and over 1,600 new units in Austria and Indonesia, set to open between 2021 and 2024.

site_title: Virgin Australia CEO negotiating terms of exit with new owner Bain: sources
summary: Virgin Australia CEO Paul Scurrah is negotiating the terms of his exit with new owner Bain Capital, reportedly due to disagreements over the airline's strategy and premium offerings. Scurrah wants to maintain a full-service model, while Bain plans to keep lounges and business-class services but at a lower premium level. The exit is expected to be announced within days, sparking concerns from unions and employees who fear the airline may become a budget carrier.

site_title: Australia's unemployment rate edges up to 6.9% in Sept
summary: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 6.9% in September, holding below a 22-year high of 7.5%. Employment declined by 29,500 after a 111,000 increase in August, contrary to economists' predictions of a 35,000 drop. The data suggests the labor market remains resilient despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong discontinues legal action against Raffles Education
summary: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong has discontinued his legal action against Raffles Education Corp, a Singapore-listed education firm. He had filed a notice of discontinuance after failing to obtain two interim injunctions against the company, which had proceeded with a shareholders meeting to vote on a proposed acquisition. The High Court has approved the discontinuance of the legal action. Following the failure to obtain injunctions, REC's shares closed up 0.5 cents at S$0.138 on Wednesday.

site_title: Thailand declares emergency, bans rallies as protests swell
summary: Thailand's government declared a state of emergency and banned gatherings of more than four people to quell pro-democracy protests. The move came after student activists, demanding Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha's resignation, scuffled with royalists and held up three-fingered salutes during a drive-by of the royal motorcade. The state of emergency allows for seizure of electronic communications equipment and data, and protesters are warned that gathering will lead to arrest. The protests, which began in July, call for reforms to the monarchy and an end to the military's influence in Thai politics.

site_title: US destroyer crosses Taiwan Strait, risking Chinese anger
summary: A US destroyer, USS Barry, crossed the Taiwan Strait on October 14, 2020, in a routine transit, risking anger from China, which claims sovereignty over the maritime thoroughfare. The operation, part of the US Navy's "freedom of navigation" exercises, aims to demonstrate the US commitment to a free and open Indo-Pacific. China views the passage as a violation of its sovereignty, while the US sees the waterway as part of international waters. The move has sparked strong responses from Beijing, which has threatened to use force if Taipei proclaims independence.

site_title: US business creation soars to record in Q3
summary: US business formation surged 77% in Q3, reaching a record high of 1.6 million applications for tax identification numbers, according to the Commerce Department. The increase was seen in all regions, with the Northeast and Midwest experiencing the largest gains. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the surge was not a rebound from a bad period, as applications also increased in the second quarter. Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Randal Quarles attributed the growth to the American economy's inherent dynamism and flexibility, while noting a "deeply depressed" labor market.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kaplan says disadvantaged Americans need help getting back to work
summary: US Federal Reserve President Robert Kaplan stated that disadvantaged Americans, particularly women and minorities, will need help getting back to work as the economy shifts to sectors less dependent on face-to-face interaction. To aid these groups, Kaplan emphasized the need for training, greater access to childcare, and other resources. The US labor market is recovering slowly, and businesses and policymakers may need to invest in education and training to help displaced workers pivot to in-demand jobs. Kaplan forecasts a 2.5% economic contraction in 2020 and a 3.5% growth in 2021, with an unemployment rate between 7% and 7.5%.

images.alt_text: Women and minorities, who have been affected by pandemic-related job losses, will need help getting back to work as more economic activity shifts to sectors less dependant on face-to-face interaction, Dallas Federal Reserve President Robert Kaplan said on Wednesday.

site_title: Germany tightens restrictions to fight virus surge
summary: Germany has introduced tougher measures to combat a surge in coronavirus infections, including limits on gatherings and mandatory mask-wearing in crowded areas. The new restrictions, set by Chancellor Angela Merkel, will be imposed when new infections reach 35 per 100,000 in seven days, earlier than previously. The measures include limiting gatherings to 25 in public and 15 in private spaces, and stricter restrictions will apply if the threshold of 50 new infections per 100,000 is exceeded.

site_title: Fresh 'emails' challenge Biden over son's Ukraine business
summary: Facebook and Twitter restricted links to a New York Post article claiming to have obtained emails from a computer abandoned by Hunter Biden, implicating Joe Biden in his son's Ukraine business dealings. The emails, obtained by Rudy Giuliani, show a Burisma board advisor thanking Hunter Biden for inviting him to a meeting with his father. Facebook and Twitter cited concerns about the article's validity, but critics accused them of partisan censorship, with some arguing that the restrictions were aimed at protecting Joe Biden's campaign.

site_title: Wilmar's chief rides on cooking oil dominance
summary: Wilmar International's CEO Kuok Khoon Hong is set to debut his Chinese edible oil unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings, on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange with a 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.81 billion) IPO. The IPO comes after the country opened doors for foreign firms to invest in the oilseeds crushing sector. Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings now holds 40% of China's edible oil market, consuming nearly 40 million tonnes annually. The IPO marks a significant milestone for Wilmar International, fuelled by its popular cooking oil brand, which has been a staple in Chinese kitchens for decades.

site_title: Oil rises 2% as Opec complies with production cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday as Opec and its allies were seen complying with a pact to cut oil supply in September, despite concerns over the impact of soaring global coronavirus cases. Crude oil futures for December delivery settled up 87 cents, or 2.05%, at $43.32 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures rose 84 cents, or 2.09%, to $41.04 a barrel. Opec+ had 100% compliance with the pact, with 105% conformity reported by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

site_title: Bidenomics vs Trumponomics: Similar spending, very different outcomes
summary: US presidential candidates Joe Biden and Donald Trump have differing economic plans, with Biden's "Bidenomics" expected to result in a stronger US economy. Moody's Analytics analysis suggests Biden's plan would lead to a quicker return to full employment, with a potential 18.6 million jobs created and a $4,800 per average household income boost. In contrast, Trump's "Trumponomics" would continue his first-term policies, prioritizing the private sector, but may lead to a slower economic recovery.

site_title: United Airlines posts steep loss; prepares for travel rebound
summary: United Airlines reported a third-quarter loss of $1.8 billion, with revenues plummeting 78% due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the airline is preparing for a potential rebound, having cut costs and built up cash reserves. United has available liquidity of $19.4 billion and plans to bring back furloughed employees. The airline is also seeing some improvement in travel, with resumed nonstop service on 146 domestic routes and restarted international routes. United is optimistic about a strong recovery, but acknowledges the pandemic's ongoing impact.

site_title: Gal Gadot 'whitewashing' row sparks Cleopatra history debate
summary: Israeli actress Gal Gadot will play Cleopatra in a new Paramount biopic, sparking controversy over "whitewashing" after the role was previously held by Elizabeth Taylor. Gadot, known for her role in Wonder Woman, has been criticized for her casting as an African queen, but some argue that Cleopatra was of Greek heritage. Director Patty Jenkins and writer Laeta Kalogridis are on board, with Kalogridis stating she's "incredibly excited" to tell the story of a Macedonian Greek woman.

site_title: EU chiefs want Brexit deal 'but not at any price'
summary: EU chiefs told UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson they will pursue post-Brexit trade talks but won't make a deal at any price. EU officials, including President Charles Michel and Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, pressed for progress on fisheries, level-playing field, and governance. The EU is working on a deal, but conditions must be right, von der Leyen tweeted. This stance suggests the EU is willing to negotiate but won't compromise on key issues.

site_title: Citigroup's Corbat asked to prove bank isn't next Wells Fargo
summary: Regulators have placed pressure on Citigroup's CEO, Mike Corbat, to prove the bank isn't headed for a Wells Fargo-like regulatory overhaul. The bank has entered consent orders with the Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and faces a US$400 million fine for failing to address long-time infrastructure and control issues. Despite affirming a US$1 billion investment in improving these efforts, analysts expressed concerns about the bank's path forward, with some calling for a new CEO to demonstrate urgency and others questioning the timeline for CEO-elect Jane Fraser's transition.

site_title: Ardern on course for victory in New Zealand's 'Covid election'
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern is on track to win the country's general election with an outright majority, according to recent polls. Ardern, who attended a campaign rally without a mask, was seen rubbing shoulders with supporters and posing for selfies, sparking a rock-star reception from university students. The election is expected to take place in the coming weeks, with Ardern's Labour party looking to maintain power under her leadership.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip on second wave fears, Brexit uncertainty
summary: European shares declined slightly, extending a drop from the previous day, due to fears of more lockdowns and uncertainty over a Brexit trade deal. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 0.1% as food and healthcare stocks led declines. Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte imposed new restrictions, and Brexit talks are set to prolong past a mid-October deadline. Euro zone industrial production slowed in August, and third-quarter earnings at Stoxx 600 firms are expected to decline 36.7% year-on-year.

site_title: PPE supplier Medtecs' share price swings to end lower
summary: Medtecs International, a Singapore-based PPE supplier, reported stellar third-quarter results with revenue surging 636% to US$124.6 million and net profit increasing 1,115 times to US$45.7 million. Despite a share price drop of 8.1% to S$1.36, Medtecs' shares are still up 3,570% this year. The company expects strong demand for PPE to remain, given the uncertainty of a Covid-19 vaccine, and anticipates record revenue and profit in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Trump's son Barron contracted Covid-19, now negative: first lady Melania
summary: President Donald Trump's 14-year-old son Barron contracted Covid-19 after his parents tested positive, but is now negative, according to First Lady Melania. Barron initially tested negative but later tested positive after his parents' diagnosis two weeks prior. Melania reflected on the experience, stating that being tested together allowed the family to care for each other and spend quality time together.

site_title: Goldman Sachs posts best results in a decade
summary: Goldman Sachs reported its best quarterly performance in a decade, with a 29% jump in trading revenue and a 49% surge in bond trading revenue to $2.5 billion. The bank's lack of a large consumer business protected it from loan defaults during the pandemic, and its return on equity climbed to 17.5%, its best since 2010. Net earnings applicable to common shareholders surged to $3.5 billion, and earnings per share doubled to a record $9.68.

site_title: Thai protesters and police face off as tensions rise in Bangkok
summary: Protesters in Bangkok, Thailand clashed with police and pro-establishment groups, with thousands demanding democratic reforms and curbs on the monarchy. The protesters, calling for Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha's resignation and a rewritten constitution, faced off at Government House, with minor scuffles breaking out. The protests have weighed on the Thai economy, with the currency and stocks tumbling, and economists warn of a cautious outlook for the rest of 2020 and into 2021.

site_title: US: Stimulus doubts send stocks to gloomy finish
summary: US stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% and the S&P 500 losing 0.7%, following downbeat comments from Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin on potential new stimulus for the struggling US economy. The Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 0.8%. The decline was fueled by ongoing fears of the coronavirus and announcements from Johnson & Johnson and Eli Lilly halting their vaccine trials. Market losses were exacerbated by a cautious start to the day, with Amazon and other tech stocks also sliding.

site_title: JPMorgan sticks with plan to build giant New York headquarters
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co plans to build a new headquarters in New York, despite the Covid-19 pandemic casting doubt on office buildings. The 1,425-foot skyscraper, set to open in 2024, will house 14,000 employees at a cost of up to $3 billion. CEO Jamie Dimon says the decision is long-term, and the bank will likely adopt new floor plans with more private offices and less dense layouts. However, with fewer workers returning to offices, the necessity of such a large skyscraper is unclear, and companies may need 10-20% less office space in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: Liquidity drying up for VC firms as investments age
summary: Venture capital (VC) funds in Singapore are facing pressure to show real cash returns to investors as exits are delayed and market conditions remain rocky. Fund managers are struggling to decide between offloading shares at a discount in the secondary market or asking investors for more time, which could impact their ability to fund future bets. Investors are looking for DPI, which measures how much of a fund's returns have been paid out, as a more accurate benchmark of a mature fund's performance. Some top-performing funds have been able to maintain holding power due to consistent performance, but others may need to convince investors for more time to capture upside.

images.alt_text: The pressure for liquidity on early-stage investors rises each year as funds mature, said Harold Ong, managing director of Indies Capital Partners.

site_title: Mediacorp puts former Caldecott Hill site for sale
summary: Mediacorp has put its 7-hectare Caldecott Hill site up for sale via a public tender, with a gross land value expected to exceed S$400 million. The site, currently zoned for civic use, will be redeveloped into 67 bungalows, dubbed "junior GCBs", with prices potentially ranging from S$11-14 million per unit. The project will cater to the underserved mid-tier segment of detached houses, offering a more affordable alternative to conventional GCBs. The public tender will close on Dec 9.

site_title: Shipping needs tighter limits on greenhouse-gas emissions
summary: Shipping emits nearly 3% of global greenhouse gas emissions, with over 1 million tons annually, and is expected to increase. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has set a target to reduce emissions by 50% by 2050, but this goal is deemed too timid. To avoid warming beyond 1.5 degrees Celsius, shipping needs to accelerate its transition to cleaner technologies, such as advanced biofuels, zero-carbon fuels, and more efficient operations. Governments, ports, businesses, and the shipping industry must work together to implement stricter regulations and invest in low-carbon technologies, with the goal of almost eliminating shipping emissions by 2035.

site_title: Time to start thinking about debt repayment, restructuring
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to suffer a 5-7% contraction this year due to the pandemic, with aviation and tourism still heavily impacted. The government has allocated S$100 billion in relief measures, but experts warn that prolonged support could threaten the broader economic recovery. Companies must start making provisions for future debt repayment and restructuring to mitigate looming debt strain. With the global aviation industry unlikely to recover until 2022, Singapore's role as an aviation hub is at risk, particularly for national carrier Singapore Airlines.

site_title: Supply chain tech startup Tramés raises seed funding led by Kamet Capital Partners
summary: Singapore-based supply chain tech startup Tramés has raised seed funding led by Kamet Capital Partners. Founded in 2019, Tramés aims to unify and digitize workflows for shippers and logistics partners. The platform features a blockchain-enabled document repository and analytics module. The fresh funding will be used to hire talent and enhance blockchain capabilities, aiming to add value to the digitization of the supply chain industry. Tramés plans to empower multinational clients and small and medium-sized enterprises to digitize their operations, aligning with Gartner's estimate that 50% of large companies will implement AI and analytics in their supply chain operations by 2023.

site_title: BTS' US$800m IPO backed by army of fans
summary: South Korean entertainment company Big Hit Entertainment, which manages K-pop group BTS, has raised over $800 million through its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at $4 billion. The IPO is backed by an army of dedicated fans, known as the BTS Army, who have created a highly connected ecosystem of services and promotions for the band. These fans, who span diverse demographics, have driven the company's success through their enthusiasm, strategic marketing, and metrics-driven approach, transforming Big Hit into a lifestyle product beyond just a music group.

site_title: India's prolific film industry hinges on cinemas reopening
summary: India's film industry is poised for a significant revival as cinemas reopen after a seven-month hiatus due to the pandemic. The resumption of screenings will benefit film buffs, big-budget Bollywood movies, and Hollywood films, including Christopher Nolan's Tenet. However, concerns remain over audience turnout and the impact of growing online audiences, with many titles being acquired by streaming services like Netflix and Amazon. The reopening is crucial for the industry's survival, with 2,000 films produced annually and over 2 billion cinema tickets sold annually.

site_title: SPH down almost 5% on first ever loss
summary: SPH shares dropped 4.8% to 99.5 cents on Wednesday after the media and property group reported its first-ever loss of S$83.7 million for the full year ended August 31. The loss was attributed to non-cash fair-value losses of S$232 million. Despite operating profitability, the group's media business continued to be hurt by weak advertisement revenue, while its property business was boosted by the acquisition of Westfield Marion mall and Student Castle PBSA portfolio. Analysts maintained a "hold" rating on SPH, with lowered target prices, citing continued weakness in the media segment.

site_title: When a burger patty isn't from a cow ...
summary: Singapore is investing in the growing food tech industry, including alternative meat options. Companies like those producing plant-based beef patties and lab-grown meat are gaining popularity. The alternative meat scene is being showcased, highlighting local startups and their efforts to change the way people eat.

site_title: Growth, jobs, and fiscal matters main themes of debate as MPs highlight areas of concern
summary: Singapore Parliament debated the economic reopening amidst the Covid-19 pandemic, with key themes including growth, jobs, and fiscal matters. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan emphasized the need for careful and calibrated reopening, with pilot schemes such as safe cruises and MICE events to set global standards. The government has supported over 28,000 projects, including the Jobs Support Scheme wage subsidy, with MPs proposing tweaks to the scheme and calling for extensions beyond March 2021. Fiscal matters, including balancing the budget and tax hikes, were also raised, with some MPs questioning the timing of these measures.

site_title: Teething problems in job-matching sorted: minister
summary: Singapore's job-matching program has largely overcome initial teething problems, according to Manpower Minister Josephine Teo. Over 20,500 traineeship and company attachment opportunities have been made available, with 2,800 local job-seekers helped under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package. The program has expanded its team and will reach full strength by end-October, and the focus is now on companies making opportunities available to job-seekers. The government is also introducing measures to encourage permanent hiring, such as the Jobs Growth Incentive.

site_title: Microsoft in deal with Equinor for Norway CO2 storage project
summary: Microsoft has signed a memorandum of understanding with Equinor to explore a carbon dioxide storage facility in Norway as part of the tech firm's efforts to cut its carbon footprint. Microsoft aims to remove enough CO2 by 2050 to account for all its emissions since 1975 and invest US$1 billion in a carbon removal technology. This deal follows Microsoft's pledge in January to remove all its CO2 emissions since its founding.

site_title: Singapore shares fall despite economic contraction easing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.47% to 2,555.59 due to uncertainties over the coronavirus vaccine and US stimulus talks. Despite a third-quarter easing of economic contraction, regional markets were weighed down. Medical suppliers like Medtecs and QT Vascular rose, while real estate investment trust Mapletree Industrial Trust fell. The decline was part of a broader regional market downturn, with other indices including the Kospi, S&P/ASX 200, and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index also falling.

site_title: Prices of metals key gauge of global recovery
summary: The performance of industrial metals will be a key indicator of the global economy's recovery, with prices of copper, base metals, and iron ore surging due to China's increased imports since June. However, new COVID-19 outbreaks in the US and Europe may dent hopes of a rebound. China's revival and continued commodity imports will be crucial in determining the global recovery trajectory.

site_title: US dollar holds on to gains; euro hits nine-day low
summary: The US dollar index held steady, while the euro reached a nine-day low, as investors remained cautious due to diminished hopes for a COVID-19 vaccine or US fiscal stimulus. The dollar index rose 0.4% on Tuesday, its largest daily jump in three weeks, before holding flat on Wednesday. The euro was down 0.1% against the US dollar, while the British pound fell to a low of $1.2865 due to dimmed hopes for a Brexit agreement. Despite this, markets still expect a victory for Joe Biden in the US presidential elections to result in more fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Apple enters 5G race with new iPhone 12 range
summary: Apple has launched its new iPhone 12 range, featuring faster 5G connectivity, with the goal of boosting sales through the end of the year. The iPhone 12, 12 mini, Pro, and Pro Max models will be available in Singapore starting October 23, with prices ranging from S$1,149 to S$1,799. However, the availability of 5G speeds may vary depending on the carrier and location, with some models lacking millimeter wave compatibility in certain countries. The launch comes as Apple faces a potentially challenging holiday season due to the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Court grants 'last' adjournment for JM application for Hyflux
summary: The Singapore court granted Hyflux a last-minute adjournment for its judicial management (JM) application, which will be heard "no earlier than three weeks" from now. This move came after the judge chastised Hyflux's lawyer for making a last-minute request. The adjournment gives Hyflux one final chance to conclude a deal.

site_title: Tweaks to the scoring for governance index prepare trusts for more volatile weather
summary: The Governance Index For Trusts (GIFT) 2020, published by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Singapore Exchange (SGX), assesses 45 real estate investment trusts (Reits) and business trusts listed on SGX. The index now carries 75 points for governance and 25 points for business risk, with a mean combined score of 64.3, down from 68 last year. The top-ranked trusts include Netlink NBN Trust and Keppel DC Reit, while the lowest-ranked trusts are Asian Pay Television Trust and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust. The report highlights areas of stagnation, regression, and under-performance, including low unitholder endorsement of directors, inadequate disclosure of executive director remuneration, and poor business risks, such as high leverage and currency risks.

site_title: Majority of Indian Americans to vote for Biden, survey says
summary: A survey by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace found that over two-thirds of Indian American voters are expected to support Joe Biden and the Democratic Party in the US presidential elections. Only 22% are expected to support President Donald Trump, with 55% strongly disapproving of Trump's performance and 68% believing America is headed in the wrong direction. Despite Trump's perceived closeness to Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Indian American voters remain strongly attached to the Democratic Party. The survey polled 936 Americans of Indian origin and found that Indian Americans are an affluent and influential voting bloc.

site_title: Slow recovery a setback for hotels, but there're encouraging signs
summary: Singapore's hotel sector continues to recover slowly from the pandemic, with occupancy rates surpassing 90% in Q3, according to hospitality Reits. Despite encouraging signs, the industry still lags behind 2019 levels, with room rates and RevPAR at low levels. Analysts expect a rebound in the second half of 2021, driven by vaccine availability and travel bubbles. In the meantime, staycations and travel-starved residents may fill hotel rooms, particularly during the festive season. Hospitality Reits such as CDL Hospitality Trusts and Ascott Residence Trust are seen as potential winners, but face risks from master lease renewals and exposure to markets with ongoing pandemic challenges.

site_title: Digital economy holds a large chunk of new opportunities: Chan
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasizes the global economy's need for integration or fragmentation, but notes that nations' ability to reap globalization benefits depends on inclusive growth and adapting to change. He urges the US and China to work together to uphold the global trading system, and highlights the digital economy as a key driver of global growth. Chan also stresses the need for international rules and frameworks to support digital trade and e-commerce, and Singapore is actively working on these agreements with other countries.

site_title: Johnson resists national lockdown but rules nothing out
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson resisted a national lockdown for England, instead opting for a three-tier system of local measures to combat rising Covid-19 cases. The Liverpool area is in the highest category, requiring businesses to shut. Johnson said he rules nothing out in combating the virus but prefers a localized approach. The Welsh government plans to ban people from high-infection areas from entering the country, while Northern Ireland introduced tougher measures. Critics argue a short lockdown could be more effective, but a snap poll shows 68% support for a "circuit breaker" lockdown.

site_title: KidZania Singapore owes S$53m to over 1,000 creditors
summary: KidZania Singapore, a family attraction backed by Malaysian sovereign fund Khazanah Nasional, owes over S$53 million to more than 1,000 creditors, including businesses and government agencies in Singapore. The company's assets have diminished to S$5.9 million, and creditors are frustrated by the lack of clarity in the recouping process, which is expected to take 1.5 to 2 years. Khazanah-backed Themed Attractions Resorts & Hotels (TARH) holds an 80% stake in Rakan Riang, the joint venture company behind KidZania Singapore.

images.alt_text: The family attraction owes money to customers, businesses and government agencies, including STB, SDC and MOE, according to a list of creditors seen by BT.

site_title: MOM actively monitoring shifts in remote working
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore is monitoring shifts in workplace practices due to remote working, with Senior Minister of State Zaqy Mohamad highlighting the need for policy intervention. The government aims to retain a competitive edge by strengthening the business environment and helping Singaporeans build skills relevant to the global marketplace. In response to concerns about the Jobs Growth Incentive, Manpower Minister Josephine Teo explained that the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore has a robust anti-gaming framework to prevent abuse, and the JGI payout is reduced in proportion to the number of existing employees that left the firm.

site_title: Omnibus law charts new direction for Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's new omnibus law aims to drive job creation and economic growth by deregulating the economy, reducing barriers to entry, and amending restrictive labor laws. The law, which has been welcomed by the business community, cuts red tape, increases foreign investment, and provides incentives for companies to set up shop in the country. However, labor unions argue that the changes will erode worker protections and lead to exploitation. With nearly 7 million workers currently unemployed, the government faces a critical challenge in balancing economic growth with social welfare, and the law's success will depend on its ability to address these concerns.

site_title: HDB rental volume jumps in September as Malaysian workers return to Singapore
summary: Singapore's HDB rental volume surged 49.7% in September, with 1,611 units rented, amid the phased reopening of the border with Malaysia. Condominium rental volumes also jumped 49.1% to 4,252 units. Overall HDB rents edged up 0.4% from August, while condo rents rose 0.2%. The increase in demand is attributed to Malaysian workers returning to work in Singapore. However, the neutral overall effect on the rental market is expected due to a drop in demand in other sectors.

site_title: Carro confirms new funding; claims to be on track for S$1b run rate by 2022
summary: Carro, a used car marketplace, has raised nearly US$150 million in debt financing facilities and fresh equity from investors Mitsubishi Corp and MS&AD Ventures. The startup aims to reach a S$1 billion annualized revenue run rate by 2022, exceeding 15 times its revenue in FY2019. With a nearly S$1 billion annualized Gross Merchandise Value (GMV) run rate and over 2 million monthly active users, Carro expects to grow its ecosystem services, including financing and insurance.

site_title: Trusts' corporate governance scores 'have stagnated or regressed'
summary: Singapore-listed trusts' corporate governance scores have stagnated or regressed, with the overall average score dropping to 64.3 from 68 in 2019. The Governance Index for Trusts (GIFT) 2020, produced by Mak Yuen Teen and Chew Yi Hong, found that only six trusts allow unitholders to endorse directors at the annual general meeting, and a third of managers collect higher fees while delivering lower distribution per unit. The top-ranked trusts, including Netlink NBN Trust, retained their positions, while the six lowest-ranked trusts were Asian Pay Television Trust, First Reit, and others.

site_title: UK's new travel testing plan will boost flying, minister says
summary: The UK's transport minister, Grant Shapps, announced plans to replace a 14-day quarantine with a shorter isolation period followed by a negative test result for arrivals from most countries. This change aims to boost flying in the months ahead, as airlines have cut back schedules due to travel restrictions. Shapps stated that the new arrivals regime will enable more people to fly, while a recovery plan for the aviation industry will be set out later this autumn. The International Air Transport Association has expressed concerns that the plan does not go far enough to address travel restrictions.

site_title: Seven linked to Keppel FELS charged with bribery-related offences
summary: Seven individuals, including a former Keppel FELS employee and three subcontractors, were charged in court with bribery-related offences in Singapore. The alleged misdeeds occurred between 2014 and 2017 and involved bribes totaling S$1.3 million. The individuals, including Alvin Lim and three subcontractors, were accused of conspiring to obtain bribes from three companies in exchange for business interests with Keppel FELS. The charges carry penalties of up to S$100,000 or five years in prison.

site_title: Investors not pricing in broader climate risks
summary: Investors are not pricing in broader climate risks, and a strong, global carbon pricing is needed to drive a rapid transition to a net-zero economy. The author believes that an immediate, high price today is necessary to address uncertainty about the future and slow the rate of carbon emissions. A globally harmonized pricing of carbon is expected to accelerate, with incentives already in place in many countries. Investors should be concerned about underlying policy uncertainty and seek compensation, but also recognize opportunities to generate returns in a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Singapore poised for K-shaped recovery following Q3 rebound
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a K-shaped recovery, with IT, advanced manufacturing, and financial services leading the way, while other sectors, such as construction and services, may take longer to recover. The country's third-quarter GDP contracted 7% year-over-year, but rebounded 7.9% on a quarter-on-quarter basis, driven by a 2% growth in manufacturing. Economists predict an uneven recovery, with a widening income gap between high- and low-income households. A possible Phase 3 reopening in the fourth quarter may support economic recovery, but job losses and business closures are still expected, particularly in industries such as tourism and retail.

site_title: MAS Singdollar policy tipped to be in neutral gear for a while
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has signaled that its neutral stance on monetary policy may persist for the foreseeable future, despite hopes of a return to mild positivity for core inflation. Analysts predict the Singapore dollar (SGD) could end the year at 1.35 or 1.36 against the US dollar, strengthening to 1.31 or 1.32 by end-2021. The MAS has projected core inflation to come in at between zero and 1% next year, with a neutral policy stance expected to remain appropriate for some time.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group's lead independent director, Ling Chung Yee, has quit due to a disagreement over the audit process. The company plans to appoint a local replacement as soon as possible. This departure follows a period of market volatility, with oil prices rising over 2% and stocks down in Europe due to bank and healthcare concerns, as well as US-EU tariff tensions.

site_title: Copy of Shakespeare's collected plays sells for record US$9.9m
summary: A rare 1623 book containing 36 of William Shakespeare's plays, known as the First Folio, sold for a record US$9.97 million at an auction in New York. This sale broke the previous record of nearly US$6.2 million paid in 2001. The book, compiled by friends of Shakespeare seven years after his death, is one of only six known complete copies in private hands. The sale marked the first time in nearly 20 years that a complete copy of the First Folio had come to auction, with the buyer's identity remaining unknown.

site_title: China's President Xi backs stronger property rights, protection for Shenzhen entrepreneurs
summary: China's President Xi Jinping announced plans to strengthen property rights and protection for entrepreneurs in Shenzhen, a southern city that has been a key economic hub. Xi praised Shenzhen for achieving "miracles" and urged it to continue developing with courage. This move aims to support the city's growth and entrepreneurship, marking a shift in the government's stance on property rights and business protection.

site_title: Fabchem China's acquisition target was loss-making, says company in response to SGX queries
summary: Fabchem China, a mainboard-listed company, revealed that its acquisition target, Renewable Power Management, had declining financials over the past three years. The company reported an audited net profit of A$1.67 million for FY2018 but a loss of A$1.4 million for the year to June 2020. This indicates that the target company was loss-making.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as tech gains overshadow mixed banks results
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by gains in technology stocks, despite mixed quarterly earnings reports from major US lenders. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.18%, the S&P 500 increased 0.10%, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.21%. The mixed results from banks overshadowed investor concerns over US-EU trade tensions, with stocks continuing their upward trend.

site_title: Israeli private tech firms raised record US$2.74b in third quarter
summary: Israeli private tech firms raised a record $2.74 billion in the third quarter, a 24% increase from last year, despite the coronavirus pandemic. This brings the total fundraising to $7.5 billion for the year, exceeding 2019's total. Foreign investors allocated the highest amounts ever, while life science firms dominated the third quarter with one in four deals. Early-stage companies have been affected, with fewer than $100 million raised in 95 seed deals this year.

site_title: Falcon sells for record-breaking US$170,000 in Saudi Arabia
summary: A young Shaheen peregrine falcon sold for a record-breaking US$170,000 in Saudi Arabia, the most expensive sale of its kind globally. Captured from the wild, the 1.1kg falcon was sold through an annual 45-day auction, highlighting the cultural significance of falconry in the region. The sale, supported by the government, aims to preserve this ancient heritage activity, which has been practiced for thousands of years in Gulf countries.

site_title: Wells Fargo profit slumps on severance, remediation charges
summary: Wells Fargo's profit slumped 56% in the third quarter due to $1 billion in customer remediation and $718 million in restructuring charges. The bank set aside $769 million in loan-loss provisions, less than expected. CEO Charlie Scharf is working to address old scandals and reduce annual expenses, aiming to cut $10 billion. Despite this, the firm's nonaccrual loans rose 5.5% and the bank has $20.5 billion set aside for credit losses. Scharf attributed the challenges to the unclear economic recovery due to COVID-19.

site_title: US producer prices accelerate in September
summary: US producer prices increased 0.4% in September, the first year-on-year gain since March, according to the Labor Department. This surpasses economists' expectations of a 0.2% gain. The producer price index for final demand rose from 0.3% in August. The 12-month increase was also 0.4%, rebounding from a 0.2% decline in August, marking the first year-on-year gain since March.

site_title: China's credit growth remained robust in September amid recovery
summary: China's credit growth remained robust in September, reaching 3.48 trillion yuan, exceeding median estimates. New loans offered by financial institutions totaled 1.9 trillion yuan, higher than expected. The economic recovery momentum continued to strengthen, with activity in both manufacturing and services sectors. Policy makers are seeking to normalize monetary policy and fine-tune it to be more precise and targeted. Overall liquidity remains reasonable, and credit and social financing growth are at a reasonable pace.

site_title: KS Energy CEO, independent directors quit as company goes under judicial management
summary: KS Energy's CEO and independent directors Richard Wiluan, Lawrence Basapa, Chew Choon Soo, and Soh Gim Teik have resigned following the company's judicial management order by the High Court on October 13. The decision comes after the company was put under judicial management, with the mainboard-listed oil services firm citing the court order as the reason for the cessations. The changes come just a day after Wiluan's appointment as CEO and chairman in August, following his father Kris Wiluan's resignation amid false trading and market-rigging charges.

site_title: WHO fears spike in global covid-19 cases will be followed by increased deaths
summary: The World Health Organization's chief scientist warns that the recent surge in global Covid-19 cases will likely be followed by rising deaths, with nearly 5,000 fatalities reported daily. Despite the number of infections reaching 38 million and 1.1 million deaths, Dr. Soumya Swaminathan notes that mortality rates are not decreasing, and cases are expected to lag behind deaths by a couple of weeks. This raises concerns about the potential for increased mortality rates.

site_title: Evergrande deal misses target after it cuts out founder's rich friends
summary: Evergrande Group's share sale fell short of its target, raising about half the intended US$1.09 billion and priced at a steep discount to its previous close. The company excluded billionaire founder Hui Ka Yan's friends from the deal, aiming to bolster investor confidence, but the move may have weakened investor demand instead. Evergrande's stock slumped 17% and its offshore bonds fell by 5 cents on the dollar, adding pressure to raise more money through other means, including business unit spin-offs and condominium sales. The company's US$120 billion debt remains a concern for investors and Chinese regulators.

site_title: MPs voice concerns over balancing the books given heavy spending on Covid-19 measures
summary: Singapore's government has committed nearly S$100 billion in Covid-19 support measures this year, drawing S$52 billion from reserves. MPs have expressed concerns over balancing the books, citing a potential deficit of S$2.9 billion and a 16.1% drop in government revenue. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has announced S$8 billion in additional support, funded by reallocation from other areas. The government is considering further draws on reserves to balance the budget in the next two to three years, but MPs have questioned the feasibility and impact on reserves' returns.

site_title: Trump, Biden to hold rival TV town halls instead of debate
summary: US President Donald Trump and Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden will hold rival TV town halls instead of a second presidential debate, set to air on NBC and ABC respectively on Thursday. Trump will appear in Miami, while Biden will appear in Philadelphia. The decision comes after the two campaigns failed to agree on a debate format. The town halls will allow voters to ask questions and engage with the candidates separately, bypassing the scheduled debate.

site_title: Nokia moves to Google Cloud
summary: Nokia has signed a 5-year deal with Google to replace its IT infrastructure, including data centres, with Google's Cloud offering, aiming to cut costs and drive operational efficiencies. The agreement is expected to reduce real estate footprint, hardware energy consumption, and hardware capacity purchasing needs. The full migration is expected to take 18-24 months, but financial details of the contract were not disclosed.

site_title: IMF urges governments to keep spending
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is urging governments to continue spending to support the economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, citing the need for a swift and targeted boost. Central bankers, including the European Central Bank's Christine Lagarde and the US Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell, are also pushing for fiscal aid to workers and businesses to avoid premature withdrawal of support. The IMF estimates global government debt will surge this year, but it's seen as a short-term risk, with the near-term priority being to avoid cutting support too abruptly.

site_title: No train service on parts of North-South, East-West, Circle lines after power fault
summary: A power fault caused train disruptions on parts of the North-South, East-West, and Circle MRT Lines in Singapore, affecting thousands of commuters. The fault occurred at around 7pm, with service restored by 10:35pm. Preliminary investigations indicate a faulty power cable was the cause, the most serious power-related incident since 2017. Free bus bridging services were activated, and bus operators increased frequency to affected areas. Commuters were advised to add 25 minutes to their travel time.

images.alt_text: A power fault on the North South and East West Lines during the evening rush hour on Wednesday (Oct 14) has resulted in delays for commuters.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust receives HK$263 million in interim insurance payout for Festival Walk damages
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) has received HK$263 million (S$46 million) in interim insurance payouts for damages to its Festival Walk mall in Hong Kong, which was closed for months due to civil unrest. The insurers have also paid out HK$118 million as partial payments. The full quantum of revenue loss and property damage recoverable from insurance claims remains in progress, with MNACT continuing to pursue the claims. The counter closed down one Singapore cent to S$0.92 on Wednesday.

site_title: Khazanah says Firefly could become Malaysia's new national airline
summary: Khazanah Nasional, Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund, has the option to invest in Firefly, a low-cost carrier, which could become the country's national airline if Malaysia Airlines is shut down. Firefly, currently a fully owned subsidiary of Malaysia Aviation Group, would obtain narrow-body and wide-body aircraft if restructuring talks fail. Khazanah's head, Shahril Ridza Ridzuan, stated that continued financing of Malaysia Airlines would require disposal of other strategic assets or increased debt. The government has also stated that it will not provide financial support to Malaysia Airlines.

site_title: Goldman Sachs profit nearly doubles on trading surge
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a 94% rise in quarterly profit to US$3.5 billion, driven by a surge in deal-making and trading. Earnings per share doubled to US$9.68, exceeding expectations. The bank's strong performance is attributed to its trading and underwriting businesses.

site_title: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong discontinues legal action against Raffles Education
summary: Tycoon Oei Hong Leong has discontinued his legal action against Raffles Education Corp (REC) after being unsuccessful in obtaining two interim injunctions against the company. The injunctions were sought to stop REC from proceeding with a proposed acquisition of an interest in a Chinese property firm. Following the failure to obtain the injunctions, REC went ahead with an extraordinary general meeting and approved the proposed acquisition. The High Court has approved the discontinuance of the legal action.

site_title: BM Mobility to be delisted on Nov 12
summary: BM Mobility, an electric transport company, will be delisted from the main board of the Singapore Exchange on November 12. The company, which had suspended trading in its shares since last year, was placed under judicial management on July 20. Shareholders can contact Kim Lim or Randy Pay at Deloitte &Touche for information on the delisting. This move follows the company's financial struggles, with its affairs, business, and property being managed by judicial managers since July.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.95 points to 1,523.25. Volume reached 6.991 billion lots worth RM6.991 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 571 to 495.

site_title: Bank of America misses revenue estimates on lower interest rates
summary: Bank of America reported third-quarter revenue that fell short of estimates due to lower interest rates, which reduced net interest income by 17%. The bank set aside $1.4 billion to cover potential losses in its commercial loan portfolio. Despite this, the bank beat profit expectations due to cost control measures. Net income applicable to common shareholders declined 15.8% to $4.44 billion, or 51 cents per share. The bank's adjusted revenue of $20.45 billion was below analysts' average estimate of $20.81 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as vaccine trials halt, stimulus hopes fade
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,179.20, driven by halted Covid-19 vaccine trials and dwindling hopes for a US coronavirus relief package. Global markets followed, with major indexes on Wall Street closing in the red. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1% higher the previous day. The decline was attributed to heavy selling in financial and energy stocks, with the "Big Four" banks closing in the red.

site_title: Battered UK travel industry calls for testing, more support
summary: The UK travel industry is calling for testing and more support as demand for overseas trips plummets due to the pandemic. Figures show that only 15% of Britons took a foreign holiday between February and July 2020, down from 64% the previous year. The industry body ABTA blames the government's approach for exacerbating consumer reticence to travel. The industry is facing tens of thousands of job losses and the government's furlough scheme is set to end, with a testing regime being considered by the newly launched Global Travel Taskforce.

site_title: Sino Grandness director quits over difference in opinion on audit process
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group has announced the resignation of its lead independent director, Tay Peck Gek, due to a disagreement over the audit process. This is the fourth executive or director to leave the company in the past year. Sino Grandness has appointed a local replacement and will seek to fill the position as soon as possible. The company's stock closed flat at two Singapore cents on Wednesday.

site_title: Trusts' corporate governance score have 'stagnated, regressed'
summary: The Governance Index for Trusts (Gift) 2020 has shown that trusts' corporate governance scores have stagnated and regressed. NETLINK NBN Trust retained its top spot, but the overall average score for the sector dropped due to higher standards. The index assesses 45 out of 50 Singapore-listed trusts and evaluates governance and business risks. The drop in scores is attributed to the rising standards, with the index excluding suspended Eagle Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher as Xi's speech lifts tech stocks
summary: Hong Kong shares ended higher on Wednesday, driven by tech stocks following Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech in Shenzhen, which emphasized property rights and protection for entrepreneurs. The Hang Seng index rose 0.07% to 24,667.09, while the Shanghai Composite index fell 0.56%. The gains were largely offset by a decline in the CSI300 index, which fell 0.66%. The positive sentiment was attributed to Xi's speech, which boosted risk appetite and lifted tech stocks.

site_title: ANA Airline secures US$3.8b loans to tackle virus impact
summary: ANA Holdings, Japan's largest airline, has secured a US$3.8 billion subordinated loan package to bolster its funds amid a slump in air travel caused by Covid-19 restrictions. The loans, totaling 130 billion yen each from Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group and the Development Bank of Japan, will help the airline maintain its operations and jets, which are burning through cash. ANA reported an operating loss of 159 billion yen in the three months to June 30, and the airline plans to offer voluntary redundancies and cut bonuses to reduce costs.

site_title: Two schoolchildren among five new confirmed coronavirus cases
summary: Two new confirmed coronavirus cases were reported in Singapore, with two schoolchildren, a 13-year-old boy and a 10-year-old girl, among them. The cases were imported, with three cases linked to travelers returning from the UK, Russia, and India. The community cases, however, have decreased significantly, with only one case reported per day in the past week. The average number of community cases has decreased from one case per day two weeks ago to fewer than one per day in the past week.

images.alt_text: There were five new coronavirus cases confirmed as of Wednesday noon, taking Singapore's total to 57,889.

site_title: German yields fall to lowest since May, Italy's at new record low
summary: Germany's 10-year bond yield fell to its lowest since May, while Italy's equivalent hit a new record low. The move is attributed to investors' expectations of further European Central Bank stimulus to support Europe's coronavirus-hit economy, particularly benefiting debt from lower-rated, Southern European countries. This trend is expected to continue as investors await key speakers from the European Central Bank and bond sales from Germany and Portugal.

site_title: EU summit to say Brexit progress 'still not sufficient'
summary: European Union leaders meeting in Brussels will say that progress in Brexit talks with Britain is "still not sufficient" to seal a new trade deal by the year-end deadline. The 27 EU heads will step up contingency preparations for an abrupt split and intensify talks to get an agreement by December 31. Key issues include the level playing field, fisheries, and governance, with the EU also telling Britain to implement its earlier Brexit divorce treaty in full. The EU is gearing up to negotiate until mid-November to avoid being blamed if talks fail, with a deal still considered possible.

site_title: Million-dollar HDB flats make up 0.3% of total resale flats sold
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee stated that million-dollar HDB flats (0.3% of total resale transactions) were sold 38 times as of August 2020, with the highest price reaching S$1.26 million. This year's sales are lower than 2019's 64 and 2018's 71 million-dollar flats. The government continues to monitor affordability, with a focus on pricing BTO flats under five times median household income.

site_title: Court grants 'last' adjournment for Hyflux's judicial management application
summary: Singapore's High Court granted Hyflux a last adjournment for its judicial management application, allowing for a hearing no earlier than three weeks from now. The decision came after the court chastised Hyflux's lawyer for making a last-minute request, citing "hairdressers and dentists" getting more notice than the judge. The adjournment was requested due to new developments, including a new expression of interest from American fund manager Strategic Growth Investments. The court expressed skepticism about the company's restructuring efforts, with the unsecured creditors' lawyer arguing that the delay would only diminish their chances of a successful judicial management.

site_title: More than 20,500 traineeship, attachment opportunities available: Josephine Teo
summary: More than 20,500 traineeship and company attachment opportunities have been made available in Singapore, with over 2,800 local jobseekers placed under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package. The top five sectors include financial services, infocomm technology, and media, and most applications are approved within four weeks. The SGUnited Traineeships Programme and SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme were launched to provide opportunities for recent graduates and mid-career jobseekers, with existing openings available to jobseekers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Q3 GDP contracted 7% due to its "circuit-breaker" period, but rebounded in the third quarter. The top sectors for traineeships are financial services, infocomm technology, and media. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintained its neutral stance on the Singdollar policy. Hyflux received a last adjournment for its judicial management application. Seven individuals, including Keppel FELS staff, were charged with corruption between 2014 and 2017. The STI closed 0.47% lower to 2,555.59 due to uncertainties over US coronavirus vaccine and stimulus talks.

images.alt_text: Q3's better performance came largely from the manufacturing sector, which expanded by 2 per cent year on year, undoing the 0.8 per cent contraction seen in Q2.

site_title: Mediacorp's former Caldecott Hill site up for sale; gross land value exceeds S$400m
summary: Mediacorp's former Caldecott Hill site, a 7-hectare leasehold plot, is up for sale with a gross land value exceeding S$400 million. The proposed 67 bungalows, dubbed "junior GCBs," will be developed on the site, priced at S$11-14 million each. The land rate is around S$540 per square foot, making it comparable to detached houses in Sentosa Cove and GCBs in the central region. The public tender for the property will close on Dec 9, with the site having a 99-year lease term and a balance lease term of 73 years.

site_title: Japan supercomputer shows humidity affects aerosol spread of coronavirus
summary: A Japanese supercomputer, Fugaku, has shown that low humidity levels can significantly increase the spread of coronavirus particles in indoor environments. Research found that air humidity below 30% results in more than double the amount of aerosolized particles compared to levels above 60%. The study suggests using humidifiers to limit infections in dry, indoor conditions during winter months. Clear face shields are also less effective than masks in preventing aerosol spread, and diners are more at risk from people to their side than across the table.

site_title: GIC looks to integrate climate change into all investment processes
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC plans to integrate climate change into its investment processes, taking a holistic and long-term approach. The fund will evaluate the impact of climate change on long-term capital market assumptions under different scenarios. This move aims to manage potential risks associated with abrupt policy changes that may affect portfolio returns. GIC will assess whether global warming is contained below two degrees Celsius by the end of the century, a goal set by the Paris Agreement. The integration of climate change into investment processes reflects the growing recognition of climate change's impact on investors.

site_title: STI down 0.47 per cent to 2,555.59 despite ease in economic contraction
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.47% to 2,555.59 on Wednesday, despite the third-quarter easing of economic contraction. Uncertainties surrounding the coronavirus vaccine and US stimulus talks weighed on regional markets. Medical suppliers like Medtecs, Top Glove, and QT Vascular saw gains, while real estate investment trust Mapletree Industrial Trust lost 2.7%. Asia markets were down, with the Kospi closing 0.94% lower, while Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.11%.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on caution around vaccine trials, US stimulus
summary: European shares declined 0.2% on Wednesday, driven by caution over vaccine trials and uncertainty over US stimulus, with investors avoiding big bets ahead of Brexit talks. The UK-imposed deadline on Brexit negotiations boosted London's FTSE 100 by 0.2%, while Italy's bourse remained flat due to new COVID-19 restrictions. The European Union is prepared for a no-deal Brexit, with the EU's single market Commissioner stating they would prefer a deal.

site_title: Singapore SMEs digitalised, leveraged data at higher rates than global peers amid pandemic
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) significantly digitalized and leveraged data during the COVID-19 pandemic, outpacing their global peers. About 62% of Singaporean SMEs used online business solutions, resulting in a 30% increase in cloud adoption. They relied more on customer data analytics than instinct to inform their strategy, and used data-driven insights to tackle key challenges such as retaining existing customers and attracting new ones. The majority of SMEs (92%) also leveraged government support, with 43% making decisions based on customer feedback.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall most in three weeks on vaccine, US stimulus uncertainties
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.94% to 2,380.48, marking their largest drop in nearly three weeks, due to halted Covid-19 vaccine trials and fading hopes for a US pandemic relief package. The Kospi closed down 22.67 points, with Hyundai Motor's shares down 0.6% and LG Chem's shares down 2.5%. Foreigners were net sellers of 37.4 billion won, and the won remained nearly unchanged against the US dollar. The central bank kept its policy rate steady, citing a downbeat outlook for the coronavirus-hit economy.

site_title: Virgin Australia union suspends talks, seeking clarity over CEO's future
summary: Virgin Australia's Transport Workers' Union suspended bargaining talks with new owner Bain Capital over the status of CEO Paul Scurrah, citing a lack of clarity. Scurrah clashed with Bain over Virgin's strategy, which may shift away from becoming a budget carrier. The airline plans to cut a third of its workforce as part of an overhaul, while Bain aims to exit the business as a domestic and short-haul international Boeing 737 operator. The union described the lack of clarity as a "serious and worrying development" amid the airline's transition under Bain's business plan.

site_title: Pearson's strategy pays off as Covid-19 accelerates online learning
summary: Pearson's CEO John Fallon credits the company's previous strategy of shifting to digital learning for its success in navigating the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite a 9-month sales decline, the company's global online learning jumped 32% in the third quarter. Fallon notes that the company's preparation paid off, allowing it to adapt quickly to the shift online. This comes as the pandemic accelerated the adoption of online learning, with students moving away from expensive textbooks. Pearson's preparedness has enabled it to capitalize on this trend, demonstrating the effectiveness of its digital transformation strategy.

site_title: Tata drops ad featuring Hindu-Muslim family after fury in India
summary: Tanishq, a jewellery firm under Tata Group, removed an advertisement featuring a Hindu-Muslim family celebrating a baby shower after social media backlash. The ad, part of the "Ektavan" campaign, showed a Hindu bride and Muslim in-laws in a Hindu tradition. Critics accused Tanishq of promoting "Love Jihad", a conspiracy by Muslims to forcibly convert Hindu women. The move came after calls to boycott the company trended on social media. The ad's removal was seen as a response to the criticism and social media outrage.

site_title: Green hydrogen, electric trucks 'ripe for investment' by EU recovery fund
summary: The European Union's research by Capgemini Invent identified 55 clean technologies, including green hydrogen, low-carbon aviation fuel, and electric trucks, as "ripe for investment" to achieve climate neutrality by mid-century. These technologies aim to deliver results quickly and at scale by 2030 and 2050. The EU can use its budget and recovery fund to invest in these projects, supporting the region's economies as they recover from the coronavirus crisis. The research provides a guide for policymakers and investors to drive sustainable growth and reduce the EU's carbon footprint.

site_title: China's US$1 trillion wealth fund to step up soured asset sales
summary: China's US$1 trillion sovereign wealth fund, China Investment Corp (CIC), is stepping up sales of soured assets, including its stake in embattled commodity trader Noble Group Holdings, amid the coronavirus pandemic. CIC's direct investment unit has set up a special team to recoup value and potentially exit billions of dollars in troubled investments. The fund has a history of disposing of distressed assets, with previous examples including the sale of a stake in Canadian mining company Teck Resources and Brazilian oil company OGX.

site_title: Britain's ASOS sees quadrupling of profit on strong pandemic demand
summary: British online fashion retailer ASOS reported a quadrupling of its full-year profit to £142.1 million, driven by strong demand during the Covid-19 pandemic. Sales rose 19% to £3.26 billion, serving 23.4 million customers. Despite cautious outlook, ASOS is well-positioned for the peak Christmas trading period. Shares have doubled over the last year, valuing the business at £5.4 billion.

site_title: Nomura Asia M&A co-head leaves in leadership rejig: sources
summary: Apoorva Shah, co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Nomura Asia, has left the Japanese investment bank following a recent leadership rejig. Shah, who had been with the bank for over six years, departed last week after Nomura reshuffled its Asia M&A leadership. Chou Pei Shen, who joined Nomura from UBS in January, has taken on the role of sole head of the Asia M&A team, while Hajime Higuchi relocated to Singapore as joint head of international M&A.

site_title: Malaysia's king postpones meetings due to coronavirus curbs
summary: Malaysia's King Al-Sultan Abdullah has postponed all meetings scheduled for the next two weeks due to coronavirus curbs in Kuala Lumpur and Selangor. The decision comes as opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim meets the king to prove his parliamentary majority. New meeting dates will be decided after the curbs are lifted, according to palace comptroller Ahmad Fadil Shamsuddin.

site_title: TikTok video propels Fleetwood Mac classic into top 100
summary: A viral TikTok video featuring a skateboarder lip-syncing to Fleetwood Mac's "Dreams" has propelled the 1977 hit back into the Billboard Hot 100, reaching number 21 after an absence of over three decades. The video, which garnered 8.6 million likes, reignited interest in the classic rock band and sparked a surge in streams of their other work. This is the second time a classic song has benefited from a TikTok "bounce," following Phil Collins' "In the Air Tonight." The song's universal appeal is attributed to its wholesome and relatable vibe.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei recoups losses but stalled vaccine trials, stimulus talks weigh
summary: Japan's stock benchmark Nikkei recouped early losses to close marginally higher, but sentiment remained subdued due to stalled Covid-19 vaccine trials and lack of US fiscal stimulus agreement. The Nikkei rose 0.11% to 23,626.73, while the Topix lost 0.32% to 1,643.90. Semiconductor stocks performed strongly, with Tokyo Electron rising 2.6% and Lasertec up 0.1%. Financial shares were hit by weak US peers, while ANA Holdings and Nippon Steel fell due to wage cuts and plant sales.

site_title: In China, Apple's 5G iPhone 12 sparks fever-pitch, but divided reaction
summary: Apple's 5G iPhone 12 launch in China drew mixed reactions, with fans cheering the device and others planning to wait for local rivals like Huawei. The launch sparked heated discussions on social media, with over 6 billion views on Weibo. Analysts expect the iPhone 12 to benefit from Huawei's potential decline due to US trade restrictions, but are also concerned about growing geopolitical tensions between the US and China. The device's price, ranging from $1,108 to $11,899, was also a topic of discussion, with many complaining it's too expensive.

site_title: Huawei in talks to sell parts of its Honor smartphone business: sources
summary: Huawei is in talks to sell parts of its Honor smartphone business, potentially worth up to $5.04 billion, to suitors such as Digital China Group, TCL, and Xiaomi. The sale would focus on Honor's brand, research and development capabilities, and supply chain management, as Huawei prioritizes its higher-end Huawei phones amid US sanctions. The deal may be all-cash and could be finalized in the coming weeks, with Digital China emerging as the frontrunner.

site_title: ConocoPhillips in talks to buy Concho Resources in big shale bet
summary: ConocoPhillips is in talks to acquire Concho Resources, a rival independent oil explorer, as part of a bold bet on shale during an industry downturn. The potential deal, which could be announced in the coming weeks, would see ConocoPhillips acquire Concho Resources for approximately $8.7 billion. The move would mark a significant move into the shale market for ConocoPhillips, which has a market value of around $37 billion. No final decision has been made, and talks could fall through.

site_title: London's wealthy are paying top dollar for city's mega mansions
summary: London's luxury property market has seen a surge in sales, with buyers paying 95% of asking prices for homes over £10 million in the second quarter, according to Knight Frank. Despite a slowdown in other UK house sales, the luxury market has recovered, with £1.1 billion spent on high-end homes in the first eight months of 2020, a 16% increase from the previous year. The market is expected to continue, with UK buyers accounting for 40% of deals, driven by restrictions on international travel easing in the fourth quarter.

site_title: South Korea food delivery giants rev up rider race amid coronavirus boom
summary: South Korea's food delivery market is experiencing a surge, with the market expected to jump 40% this year to $15.4 billion, driven by the coronavirus pandemic. Food delivery giants are contracting thousands of new riders, offering competitive pay and low entry barriers, making it an attractive option for many. However, concerns are raised about the lack of labor rights and safety for these self-employed riders, who face minimal access to insurance and employment safety nets, according to professor Kim Sung-hee.

site_title: The world needs integration, inclusive growth, and to seize the digital economy: Chan
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasized the need for global integration, inclusive growth, and seizing the digital economy to drive the global economy's trajectory. He noted that countries must adapt to the forces of change and help businesses and workers adjust to thrive. Chan also highlighted the importance of updating the global trading system, particularly between major powers like the US and China, and encouraged international cooperation to drive growth.

site_title: Economists lower growth forecasts despite Jakarta reopening
summary: Indonesia's economic growth forecasts have been lowered due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. Citi economist Helmi Arman reduced the country's GDP expectation for 2021 to 4% from 5.6%, citing the psychological impact of rising infections on consumer behavior. DBS economist Radhika Rao expects the fiscal deficit to nearly reach the halfway mark by August, with total expenditure jumping 86% year-over-year. The government has also lowered its official projection to -1.7% to -0.6% for 2020. Economists attribute these changes to the uneven response to social restrictions and below-budgeted fiscal disbursements.

site_title: Just Eat Takeaway's order growth jumps as online delivery surge continues
summary: Just Eat Takeaway.com reported a 46% increase in orders in the third quarter compared to the same period last year, driven by a surge in online delivery due to coronavirus social distancing measures. The company saw significant growth in Germany (47%) and the UK (43%), with restaurants in the Netherlands delivering 33% more meals through the platform. CEO Jitse Groen stated the company is well-positioned for its traditional growth season, despite not providing further financial details.

site_title: MOM monitoring shifts in workplace practices due to remote working
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore is monitoring shifts in workplace practices due to remote working and discussing policy interventions with international counterparts. Senior Minister Zaqy Mohamad emphasized that remote workers may move to lower-cost locations, but Singapore can retain its competitive edge by strengthening its business environment and helping Singaporeans build skills relevant to the global marketplace. The Manpower Minister, Josephine Teo, also assured that the Jobs Growth Incentive scheme will not be used to reduce headcounts of existing employees, and instead, the scheme's payout will be reduced in proportion to the number of existing employees that left the firm.

site_title: JPMorgan, Citi wary of economic grind, but ease from gloomiest outlook
summary: Two major US banks, JPMorgan Chase & Co and Citigroup Inc, have set aside less than expected for loan losses, indicating a decrease in economic concerns. Despite cautioning that the economy will continue to face challenges, the banks' actions suggest some worst-case scenarios are less likely in the near term. The US economy is expected to experience a moderate pace of improvement, with a lower unemployment rate at the end of 2020 than initially forecast. The banks' confidence is tempered by uncertainty and the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Mega-refiner buying oil a bright spot for constrained market
summary: A Chinese mega-refiner, Rongsheng Petrochemical's Singapore unit, is buying up to 7 million barrels of Middle Eastern crude in the spot market for its expanded refinery in Zhejiang province. This purchase is a rare bright spot for the constrained oil market, which is facing dwindling import quotas. The company is buying crude to feed its trial run operation, which is expected to double processing capacity to 800,000 barrels a day. This purchase is part of a trend of independent refiners, known as "teapots," ramping up crude purchases in anticipation of increased demand.

site_title: Latest Covid-19 wave threatens Malaysia's Q4 recovery: economists
summary: Malaysia's Q4 recovery is threatened by the latest Covid-19 wave, with reintroduced restrictions hindering economic growth in key regions. Economists warn that the conditional Movement Control Order will add pressure on households to resume loan repayments, potentially slowing growth momentum. The recovery is expected to slow, with downside risks to GDP and labor market recovery, and economists are looking to the upcoming Budget 2021 for support measures to stimulate consumption and investments.

site_title: Australia's watchdog says banks' impaired assets likely understated
summary: Australia's banking regulator, APRA, says banks' impaired assets are likely understated due to lingering economic uncertainty from the coronavirus slump. APRA chairman Wayne Byres stated that banks' loan books are slightly overvalued, and capital levels remain strong despite provisions for defaulted debts. The regulator has given banks leeway to lend during the crisis, and they have improved capital levels by asset sales and dividend halts. APRA has also set a dividend payout limit of 50% of statutory earnings for Australian banks this year.

site_title: Top battery makers in talks over US$20b Indonesia EV plans
summary: Indonesia is set to receive US$20 billion in investments from top battery makers LG Chem and Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) to develop its electric vehicle industry. The firms have signed heads of agreement with Aneka Tambang to manufacture higher-value battery products from the state-owned miner's nickel output. This move aims to establish Indonesia as a key regional center in the industry, with existing projects worth over US$30 billion already announced. The country aims to use its nickel reserves, low-cost manufacturing, and cheap power prices to build a domestic battery industry.

site_title: Australia's Great Barrier Reef might lose ability to recover from warming
summary: Australia's Great Barrier Reef has lost over half its coral in the last three decades, with frequent bleaching events compromising its ability to recover. Record-breaking temperatures have reduced the number of small, baby corals and breeding adults, making the reef more vulnerable to mass bleaching events. Scientists warn that even the world's largest reef system, the Great Barrier Reef, is increasingly compromised and in decline. Bleaching events, including the 2016 and 2017 events, have had a lasting impact on the reef's resilience.

site_title: Chip-tech maker ASML posts growth despite Covid-19
summary: Dutch microchip machine maker ASML reported greater-than-expected sales during the third quarter, with sales rising 33% to €4 billion. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the company sees the tech sector fueling demand, with 10 Extreme Ultraviolet machines shipped. Net profits rose 69% to €1.1 billion, and the company forecasts slightly lower sales in the fourth quarter but expects "low double-digit growth" in 2021. ASML's performance is seen as a bellwether for the IT industry.

site_title: Hot stock: Medtecs gains 7.4% on active trading after earnings boom
