summary: Medtecs International, a medical products supplier, saw its shares surge 7.4% to S$1.59 following its third-quarter financial results, which reported a 636% increase in revenue to US$124.6 million and a 1,115% surge in net profit to US$45.7 million. The company attributed the growth to explosive demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) during the Covid-19 pandemic, with sales of products carrying its own label making up over 68% of total sales.

site_title: Negative rates 'not a game of bluff': RBNZ official
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) is considering negative interest rates as a policy option to support the virus-ravaged economy. Assistant Governor Christian Hawkesby stated that negative rates are a real possibility and not a "game of bluff," despite concerns from Australia. Hawkesby emphasized the need for continued policy support due to the economy's "weak" labor market and uncertain outlook, indicating that monetary policy will remain stimulatory for a long time. The RBNZ has held its official cash rate at a record low 0.25% since a larger-than-expected cut in March.

site_title: Thai protest brought forward over disruption fears
summary: Thai anti-government protesters brought forward a demonstration in Bangkok, fearing confrontation with royalist groups supporting King Maha Vajiralongkorn. The protesters, demanding a new constitution and Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's departure, have been peaceful despite scuffles with police and arrests. The early protest was called to prevent royalist supporters from starting a conflict. Protest leaders say they will hold the protest peacefully, while the government has stated that people have the right to protest, but made no immediate comment on the matter.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop on virus, vaccine worries
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday, following a global sell-off, due to concerns over the COVID-19 resurgence and vaccine developments. The Netherlands and France announced partial lockdowns, while Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson introduced new containment measures. The halt of vaccine trials and economic uncertainty have heightened anxiety, with investors pricing in expectations of a Democratic sweep in US elections and a potential new stimulus package. Markets in Asia fell, with Shanghai and Hong Kong dropping 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively, while Wellington and Jakarta edged up.

site_title: Gold struggles for traction as US dollar holds firm
summary: Gold struggled to gain traction on Wednesday, stuck below the US$1,900/ounce psychological level, as the US dollar remained firm. The lack of a US fiscal stimulus agreement and fading optimism over a new package contributed to the decline. The dollar index held gains, and Asian equities fell, while hopes for a coronavirus relief package faded after US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi rejected a US$1.8 trillion proposal. The IMF's statement on global economy forecasts also weighed on gold's appeal, leading analysts to expect less stimulus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks reopen with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks reopened with gains on Wednesday, driven by investor confidence after Chinese trade data beat forecasts. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.65% to 24,808.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.18%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.13%. The gains followed a typhoon-induced break and came as investors reacted to US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: HDB rental volume jumps in Sept as Malaysian workers return to Singapore
summary: Singapore's HDB rental volume surged 49.7% in September, with 1,611 units rented, while condominium rentals also increased 49.1% to 4,252 units. The boost in demand is attributed to Malaysian workers returning to Singapore after the border reopened in August, with many opting for shorter leases as they intend to move elsewhere. Rents for HDB flats edged up 0.4% year-over-year, while condominium rents inched up 0.2%. The increase in demand is expected to be balanced by a drop in demand in other sectors, with some landlords commanding higher rents due to high demand in certain areas.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Medtecs, SPH, Frasers Property, Wilmar, Top Glove, iFast
summary: Medtecs International saw a surge in revenue and net profit due to explosive demand for personal protective equipment, with shares rising 4.2% to S$1.48. Singapore Press Holdings reported its first net loss of S$83.7 million, while Frasers Property expects a 70% decline in attributable profit for FY2020. Wilmar International allotted 542.2 million new shares to investors, and Top Glove is set to list in Hong Kong with a potential raise of at least US$1 billion. iFast Corp clarified its recent response to queries, with shares rising 2.1% to S$2.88.

site_title: Australia's Westpac to exit operations in China
summary: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp announced plans to exit operations in China, along with other Asian markets, to focus on domestic and New Zealand customers. The bank will consolidate its operations into branches in Singapore, London, and New York, reducing risk-weighted assets by over A$5 billion. The move aims to improve capital efficiency and is part of a review of its international businesses.

images.alt_text: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp on Wednesday said it will exit operations in China along with other markets in Asia after a review of its international businesses, as it seeks to focus on its core domestic and New Zealand customers.

site_title: Record early US turnout with three weeks to go: Georgians, Texans line up to vote
summary: US early voting has reached a record-breaking pace, with over 10 million Americans casting ballots in person and by mail across the country. In Texas, long lines of voters snaked out of polling places, while in Georgia, people waited five hours or more to cast ballots, with record-breaking early turnout. The surge in early voting is attributed to concerns about the pandemic and the logistics of voting, with many Americans seeking to avoid Election Day crowds. With three weeks left until the election, the high turnout is seen as a sign of enthusiasm for the presidential contest between Donald Trump and Joe Biden.

site_title: Citigroup's Corbat faces tense analyst questions as he approaches exit
summary: Citigroup CEO Mike Corbat faced intense questioning from analysts about his exit strategy and pay during a conference call, amid mistakes that led to a $400-million penalty and regulatory consent orders. The bank's technical and operational problems have plagued it for years, and analysts pressed Corbat to explain how management plans to fix these issues. Corbat will retire earlier than expected in February, to be replaced by Jane Fraser, and will not leave immediately.

site_title: Ex-Airbnb, Blackstone CFO nears US$750m for fund
summary: Laurence Tosi, former CFO of Airbnb and Blackstone Group, is raising a US$750 million fund for his investment firm WestCap Investment Partners. The fund has received US$1.2 billion in investor interest, with sovereign wealth funds, pension funds, and ultra high net worth individuals backing it. WestCap has backed companies like Sonder, Addepar, and Cerebral, and typically acquires 10-15% of its portfolio companies. The firm is set to close the fund in mid-November, following a similar US$750 million fund that closed in 2018.

site_title: Uber and Lyft argue in California court over status of drivers
summary: Uber and Lyft defended their business model in a California appeals court, arguing against a law requiring them to reclassify drivers as employees. The law, AB5, was enacted in January to regulate the status of independent workers. The court had previously ordered the companies to comply, but granted them a temporary reprieve. Uber and Lyft are seeking to have their case heard separately, citing differences in their business models. The outcome of a ballot measure supporting Proposition 22, which would guarantee flexibility for independent drivers, may influence the court's decision.

site_title: Hong Kong's FX intervention highest since 2009 crisis
summary: Hong Kong's central bank, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), has sold a record HK$230.6 billion of its local currency this year to maintain the currency's peg with the US dollar. The sales, which began in January, are the highest since the 2009 global financial crisis. The move is aimed at preventing the Hong Kong dollar from strengthening and breaking its peg. The sales are attributed to increased capital inflows, driven by high interest rates and a series of large initial public offerings, including the looming Ant Group joint listing.

site_title: Seven individuals, including staff and subcontractors of Keppel FELS, charged with corruption
summary: Seven individuals, including an employee and three subcontractors of Keppel FELS, were charged with corruption in Singapore. The charges, filed by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau, relate to gratification between 2014 and 2017, with total amounts of $879,900 and $196,700. The individuals, including Alvin Lim, a yard manager at Keppel FELS, and three subcontractors, are accused of corruptly obtaining and giving gratification to further business interests. If convicted, they may face fines of up to $100,000 or imprisonment of up to five years.

site_title: Monetary Authority of Singapore stands pat on Singdollar policy at October meeting
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its neutral stance on monetary policy, keeping interest rates unchanged at its October meeting. The MAS cited weak underlying momentum in the economy and expected core inflation to stay low, supporting a accommodative policy stance. The forecast for headline inflation was narrowed to between -0.5% and 0.5% for the full year, and core inflation is expected to return to mildly positive levels in 2021, but remain below its long-term average.

site_title: Qantas launches athleisure clothing line in latest revenue-raising initiative
summary: Qantas launches an athleisure clothing line, priced between A$146 and A$425, as its latest revenue-raising initiative amid the coronavirus pandemic. The airline, grounded and raising equity and debt, is bracing for a A$10 billion revenue hit. This follows sold-out sales of retired Boeing planes' bar carts and business class pajamas. Qantas aims to weather the pandemic with this new revenue stream, as it cuts nearly 30% of its workforce and grounds its fleet.

site_title: Tencent plans to raise stake in Universal Music
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to increase its stake in Universal Music Group by 10% to 20% before the option expires in January 2021, valued at $48 billion. This move comes after Tencent led a consortium that purchased 10% of the world's largest music company from Vivendi last year. Three people familiar with the matter expect Tencent to exercise the option, which could be done before the year-end.

site_title: China Evergrande raises HK$4.3b in slimmed-down share sale
summary: China Evergrande Group raised HK$4.3 billion in a slimmed-down share sale after initially targeting up to double that amount. The company sold 260.65 million shares at HK$16.50 each, the low end of the price range. Evergrande has been scrambling to raise cash amid government efforts to tackle excessive borrowing in the real estate sector. The sale will help the company pay debt and enhance its financial position. Chairman Hui Ka Yan's stake in the company will fall to 70.32% after completion of the subscription.

site_title: Hot stock: SPH shares dip below S$1 after posting first net loss
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) shares fell 5.2% to 99.5 cents on Wednesday after posting its first net loss of S$83.7 million for the full year ended August 31, due to non-cash fair-value losses of S$232 million. The group's operating profit fell 41% to S$110.2 million, while media advertising revenue declined 31.4%. SPH remains operationally profitable, but analysts expect weakness to persist in the media segment, dragging overall earnings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking falls on Wall Street after two coronavirus medical trials were paused due to potential safety concerns. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.27% to 23,538.79, while the Topix index fell 0.42% to 1,642.20. The decline follows a global market trend, with US stocks also falling despite reaching new records earlier in the week amid ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: World Bank approves US$12b for Covid-19 vaccines
summary: The World Bank approved US$12 billion to support the purchase and distribution of Covid-19 vaccines, tests, and treatments in developing countries. The funding aims to vaccinate up to a billion people, complementing a US$160 billion package through June 2021. The financing will also support countries to access Covid-19 tests and treatments, expand immunisation capacity, and prepare for vaccine deployment. The World Bank's approach draws on its expertise in large-scale immunization programs and public health initiatives.

site_title: Michigan militia also targeted Virginia governor: FBI
summary: The FBI testified that a Michigan militia group that plotted to kidnap Governor Gretchen Whitmer also discussed targeting Virginia Governor Ralph Northam. The group, motivated by anger over COVID-19 lockdown measures and other issues, ultimately decided to focus on kidnapping Whitmer. The plot, foiled by FBI and Michigan police, highlighted the growing threat of white supremacist and anti-government militia groups as the country's top domestic terror threat. The FBI warned of similar plots against other government officials, with Northam blaming President Trump for instigating such sentiments.

site_title: Britain's biggest fund manager expands engagement on climate
summary: Britain's largest fund manager, Legal & General Investment Management (LGIM), plans to increase its engagement on climate change, assessing and engaging with 1,000 companies by 2022, up from 100. The move aims to accelerate the global transition to a low-carbon economy. LGIM will publish its climate ratings on its website and engage with companies in various sectors, including oil and gas, mining, and technology, to promote decarbonization. The asset manager will also publish the names of laggard companies and vote against their boards if no action is taken.

site_title: Singapore shares dip at open despite easing of GDP contraction; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.3% at open on Wednesday, despite a slowdown in the country's GDP contraction to 7% in Q3. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,560.96. The Monetary Authority of Singapore kept monetary policy settings unchanged, following two rounds of easing. The benchmark index fell as healthcare and lender stocks traded actively, while gains were seen in healthcare plays and some media counters. US stocks tumbled on Tuesday amid mixed earnings results and concerns over a second COVID-19 wave.

site_title: ESports fights cheating bugs, bots and hacks
summary: A scandal in the gaming world has led to the ESports Integrity Commission sanctioning 37 team coaches for exploiting a bug in the game Counter Strike to spy on rival teams' strategy. The coaches were barred for periods ranging from a few months to several years, with one coach, Allan "Rejin" Petersen, banned for 20 months. The incident highlights the growing issue of cheating in eSports, with high stakes and the temptation of easy victories contributing to the problem.

site_title: Japan firms fall woefully short of meeting government goals on women in management: poll
summary: Japan's companies have failed to meet government goals on increasing women in management, with 71% of firms saying women account for less than 10% of management and 17% having no female managers. The Reuters Corporate Survey found most firms see limited scope to increase female managers, with 55% estimating a 10% increase. Japan's global ranking on gender parity fell to 121st out of 153 countries, and women account for just 10% of lawmakers in parliament's lower house.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.96 points, or 0.19%, to 1,522.24. Volume was 138.31 million lots worth RM81.83 million. The decline was largely due to a global trend, with stocks in Europe and the US also experiencing losses. The US-EU trade talks and tariff threats were also a concern.

site_title: Facebook bans ads discouraging vaccines
summary: Facebook has banned ads discouraging people from getting vaccinated against COVID-19, following the importance of preventive health behaviors highlighted by the pandemic. The platform had previously banned disinformation and scams related to vaccines, but this new ban specifically targets ads discouraging vaccination. Facebook will continue to allow ads for or against government regulations linked to vaccinations. The company also plans to launch a public information campaign in the US to promote seasonal flu vaccination.

site_title: Is Trump politically a dead man walking?
summary: US President Donald Trump's health and presidency are in turmoil. After a COVID-19 hospitalization, Trump declared himself "cured" and plans to hold election campaign rallies despite healthcare guidelines requiring quarantine. This move has raised concerns about his ability to effectively lead the country. Trump's administration is also plagued by scandals and bureaucratic intrigues, leading some to question whether he is "a dead man walking" in the presidential election. Despite low opinion poll numbers, Trump's supporters claim the race is not over.

site_title: Spanish firms must publish details of gender pay gap
summary: Spanish companies with over 50 employees must publish details of average wages by sex within each professional category or position, aiming to ensure equal pay for equal work. The new decree, agreed upon by unions and the Socialist government, follows data showing Spanish women earn 14% less than men on average. Firms have six months to adapt to the new norm, which is part of a broader effort to promote gender equality in the workplace.

site_title: US$5t investor group sets tougher portfolio carbon targets
summary: Thirty US$5 trillion investors, including CalPERs and Allianz, have set tougher portfolio carbon targets, aiming to lower emissions by 16-29% over the next five years. The move aligns with the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change and challenges other investors to step up efforts. The group's 2025 Target Setting Protocol will influence markets and government policies, promoting investment in low-carbon companies and deep emissions cuts.

site_title: The Pines members sue Peter Kwee; hearing dates in Nov and Dec
summary: About 145 members of The Pines club in Singapore are suing Peter Kwee and his company Exklusiv Resorts for tens of thousands of dollars in damages, claiming the loss of club facilities and membership. The lawsuit, filed in 2019, alleges breach of contract, deceit, and negligence. The plaintiffs had expected a new clubhouse to be built on the site where their club was closed for renovation in 2013, but Exklusiv Resorts sold the land to a property developer. The case will be heard in November and December 2020.

images.alt_text: Members had demanded Exklusiv Resorts procure back one of the two hotels. In return, Mr Kwee said he had offered members the use of a newly built clubhouse.

site_title: Investor Ubben warns more stocks vulnerable to social, environmental selling
summary: Former activist investor Jeffrey Ubben warned that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns will increasingly impact company stock prices, reflecting the global problems companies contribute to, such as climate change. Ubben stated that many large companies' stock prices have yet to fully reflect these concerns, but are starting to change. He also criticized the "productizing" of ESG investing through exchange-traded funds (ETFs), which he believes allows investors to feel good but doesn't lead to major change. Ubben's firm, Inclusive Capital Partners, will focus on investments in growth companies with strong ESG potential or those that have already accounted for external ESG impact and are committed to change.

site_title: Lilly pauses Covid-19 antibody treatment trial over safety concern
summary: US pharmaceutical firm Eli Lilly paused a late-stage trial of its experimental Covid-19 antibody treatment due to an unspecified safety concern. The Phase 3 trial, which began in August, aimed to recruit 10,000 hospitalised Covid-19 patients. The decision was made by an independent data safety monitoring board, and Lilly is supportive of the decision. The pause may affect other clinical trials, but details on the safety concern and affected individuals are not disclosed.

site_title: Maersk to lay off 2,000 in major revamp
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, announced plans to cut 2,000 jobs as part of a major cost-cutting effort. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, the company forecasts stronger earnings growth due to cargo volumes recovering faster than expected. Cargo volumes have picked up more than forecast, with demand recovering from a sharp decline earlier in the pandemic. The company's earnings outlook has been lifted as a result.

site_title: Retailer French Connection loss triples on virus hit; shares slump
summary: British clothing retailer French Connection Group Plc reported a tripled underlying loss of £12.2 million in the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis, with sales halved and shares plummeting 16% to 7.55pence. The company attributed revenue and profit losses of £22.2 million and £9 million, respectively, to virus restrictions. The UK government's tightening of curbs has reversed the sales recovery since store reopenings. French Connection had warned it could run out of cash before securing a £15 million funding for two years.

site_title: Wilmar unit YKA's IPO shares to start trading on Shenzhen bourse on Oct 15
summary: Wilmar International announced that 542.2 million new shares of Yihai Kerry Arawana Holdings (YKA) will start trading on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext board on October 15. These shares account for 10% of YKA's enlarged issued share capital. The IPO marks a significant milestone for the Chinese company, allowing it to raise capital and expand its operations. The shares will be listed on the Shenzhen bourse, marking the company's entry into the public market.

site_title: A look at Apple's 5G iPhone lineup
summary: Apple has released its four new 5G iPhone models, including the iPhone 12, iPhone 12 mini, iPhone 12 Pro, and iPhone 12 Pro Max. The devices will be available in more than 30 countries starting October 23, with prices ranging from $699 to $1,099. The new iPhones will feature Apple's A14 Bionic processor, dual-camera systems, and advanced display technologies. The iPhone 12 Pro and Pro Max models will also include features such as LiDAR scanning technology and improved camera capabilities.

site_title: Cristiano Ronaldo tests positive for Covid-19
summary: Portuguese football star Cristiano Ronaldo has tested positive for Covid-19, ruling him out of Wednesday's Nations League match against Sweden. Despite being asymptomatic, Ronaldo will not participate in the game. He played in Portugal's goalless draw against France on Sunday. The Portuguese federation confirmed the news, stating Ronaldo is "fine and sunbathing" after the positive test.

site_title: Europe: Shares tumble on J&J vaccine worries, banks slide
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, as Johnson & Johnson paused its Covid-19 clinical trials due to an unexplained illness in a study participant. Bank stocks declined 2.7% amid bets of more European Central Bank stimulus. The US S&P 500 and Dow indexes lost 0.3% as investors digested mixed signals on US fiscal aid. Despite this, analysts say the setback may not be viewed negatively due to numerous vaccine candidates in the pipeline.

site_title: Bukit Timah Plaza ground-floor unit up for sale with S$30m guide price
summary: A prime ground-floor commercial unit at Bukit Timah Plaza in Singapore, spanning 17,351 sq ft, has been launched for sale via an EOI exercise with a guide price of S$30m. The unit includes 12 accessory car-park lots leased to a parking management company. The sale marks a significant commercial opportunity in the area.

site_title: Shanghai-listed firm to take stake in Zheneng Jinjiang, plans cash offer
summary: Shanghai-listed thermal power generation firm Zhejiang Zheneng Electric Power (ZZEP) plans to buy a stake in Singapore-listed waste-to-energy plant operator Zheneng Jinjiang Environment (ZJE) for S$289.9 million, or S$0.7781 per share. The acquisition, subject to shareholder approval, would see ZZEP increase its stake in ZJE to 73.08%. The offeror has no plans to introduce major changes to ZJE's business, but retains flexibility to consider options.

site_title: UK PM to talk to EU chief as Brexit talks run out of time
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will speak with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen on Wednesday, amid a looming deadline for a post-Brexit trade deal. European ministers have warned that time is running out, with Johnson's self-imposed deadline for a breakthrough in talks set to expire. EU president Charles Michel emphasized that an agreement cannot happen "at any price," highlighting the need for a mutually beneficial deal. The call comes as the UK and EU blame each other for the stalled negotiations ahead of the EU summit.

site_title: Top Glove hires banks for potential US$1b Hong Kong listing: sources
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove maker, has hired banks to arrange a potential Hong Kong listing that could raise at least US$1 billion. The listing, managed by Citigroup, China International Capital Corporation, and UBS, is a preliminary evaluation at this stage. Top Glove reported record quarterly profit, citing "supernormal" demand for its disposable gloves during the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's shares finished trading 1.7% higher after announcing the plans, which could also raise up to US$2 billion.

site_title: Oil rises nearly 2% as robust China trade data offsets returning supply
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Tuesday as robust economic data from China offset returning supply in other regions. Brent crude futures ended up 73 cents, or 1.8%, to $42.45 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled up 77 cents, or about 2%, to $40.20 a barrel. However, forecasts for a slow recovery in global oil demand as coronavirus cases rise and a potential end to the era of global oil demand growth within the next 10 years, according to the IEA, capped gains.

site_title: Singapore companies lag Malaysian and Thai peers on integrity disclosures: study
summary: Singapore's largest listed companies lag behind their Malaysian and Thai peers in disclosing business integrity practices, according to a study by NUS Business School's Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations. The study found 64% of Singapore-listed companies scored low on anti-corruption measures, with a "definite disconnect between practice and disclosures." The overall average disclosure level for the five Asean countries improved to 63% from 56% in 2018, with Malaysia and Thailand scoring higher.

site_title: List best practices for use of macro-prudential policies in housing market
summary: Asian regulators face challenges in implementing effective macro-prudential policies for housing markets due to regional differences and global financial cycles. The region has experienced significant housing market volatility, with concerns about affordability and financial stability. Macro-prudential policies, such as loan-to-value and debt-to-income ratios, have been used to moderate house price appreciation. However, there is a need for a clear set of best practices and principles to guide regulators, and countries may need to relax measures in place when the property market declines sharply.

site_title: Oil prices rebound on strong Chinese trade data
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Tuesday, rising 0.30% to $39.55 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude futures and 0.29% to $41.84 a barrel for Brent crude futures. Strong Chinese trade data, with oil imports increasing 5.5% to 11.8 million barrels per day in September, supported the rally. However, concerns over supply resumption in Norway, the US Gulf of Mexico, and Libya, as well as resurgent Covid-19 infections in the US Midwest and Europe, weighed on the market.

site_title: America is distracted and in a global diplomatic self-quarantine
summary: The US is distracted by a major political crisis and paying little attention to global events, including the COVID-19 pandemic, economic recession, and civil unrest. President Trump's refusal to pledge a peaceful transfer of power and his handling of the pandemic have raised concerns about his mental state. Meanwhile, global threats, such as China's military expansion and Russia's diplomatic influence, continue to escalate, challenging US national security interests and those of its allies. The US's absence on the global stage could create a power vacuum, inviting other nations to fill it.

site_title: Explosive demand for PPE boosts Medtecs' Q3 top line, net profit
summary: Medtecs International Corporation, a medical products supplier, reported a surge in revenue and net profit in its third quarter, driven by explosive demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) during the pandemic. Revenue increased 636% to US$124.6 million, and net profit jumped 1,115 times to US$45.7 million. The company expects strong demand to continue, despite uncertainty over a vaccine, and expects to report record revenue and profit in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Rise in Nov-Jan COE supply
summary: The Land Transport Authority announced a 5.8% increase in COE quota for the November-January period, with 4,865 available. The breakdown includes 1,925 for smaller cars, 2,014 for larger cars, and 926 for the Open category. This slight increase offers car buyers some relief from the current market conditions.

site_title: US companies lay down rules on political spending ahead of Nov 3 polls
summary: A record 332 US companies in the S&P 500 have banned or disclosed political spending ahead of the Nov 3 election, a 9% increase from 2016. This move aims to avoid controversy and transparency issues. The Center for Political Accountability found that 162 companies implemented board oversight for political spending, up 46% since 2016. Companies like Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co and Merck & Co Inc have faced criticism for taking political stands, prompting the shift towards transparency.

site_title: HSBC out of China dollar bond deal for first time since 2017
summary: HSBC Holdings has been left off a list of banks arranging China's sovereign dollar debt sale for the first time since 2017, due to strained relationships with China. The $6 billion sale, arranged by 13 banks, follows a period of increased tensions between HSBC and China, including criticism of the bank's handling of Huawei and Hong Kong's new security law. HSBC's exclusion raises concerns about the bank's plans to expand in China, which are crucial to its CEO's strategy to revive the lender's fortunes.

site_title: Keppel T&T exits Thai associate for 827.6m baht; Keppel's associate Floatel forbearance pact extended
summary: Keppel Corp's logistics and data centre arm is selling its 24.01% stake in Thai-listed Business Online Public Company Limited (BOL) for approximately S$36 million in cash. The sale, part of Keppel's Vision 2030, aims to monetize non-core assets and seek new growth opportunities. Separately, creditors of associate company Floatel International have extended their forbearance agreement until October 31, covering nearly US$22.8 million in bond coupon payments.

site_title: UK grocery sales rise but shoppers aren't stockpiling: survey
summary: UK grocery sales rose 10.6% year-on-year in the four weeks to October 4, driven by shoppers moving eating and drinking back into the home ahead of new lockdown restrictions. Despite this, there is "limited evidence" of a new wave of stockpiling. The growth is attributed to increased demand for home delivery and online grocery shopping.

site_title: China auto sales jump 13% as shoppers return
summary: China's auto sales rose 12.8% in September, marking the sixth consecutive month of gains, with 2.57 million vehicles sold. Sales for the first nine months of the year were 6.9% lower than the same period last year. Passenger vehicle sales increased 8% and new energy vehicle sales surged 67.7% due to government support and promotional events. However, consumer confidence remains slow, and it will take time to release demand for affordable products.

site_title: IMF sees shallower recession, tough path back to full recovery
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its forecast, predicting a shallower recession this year, with global GDP expected to shrink 4.4% due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. However, the IMF expects a modest growth of 5.2% in 2021. The fund warns that recovery is uncertain until the pandemic is tamed, and economies face difficult paths back to pre-pandemic levels. The IMF also notes that policy makers must avoid prematurely withdrawing support to avoid setbacks and debt defaults in poorer nations.

site_title: Hyflux disputes several statements by suitor Utico
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water-treatment company, has disputed statements made by its Emirati suitor Utico regarding their restructuring efforts. In a regulatory statement, Hyflux disagreed with Utico's claims that various creditor groups are working together and that Utico has a firm binding offer. Hyflux maintains that Utico's statements are inaccurate and that the company is still exploring its options for restructuring.

site_title: SoftBank's Vision Fund plans to unveil blank-cheque company
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund plans to unveil a blank-cheque company in the next two weeks, combining its expertise in tech startups with a new emphasis on public stock trading. The target size of the company has not been determined, and SoftBank is expected to seek outside funds and contribute some of its own capital. The move aims to capitalize on the investor frenzy surrounding blank-cheque companies, which have raised over $40 billion this year.

site_title: Anwar meets king to prove majority support for PM bid
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim met with King Al-Sultan Abdullah to prove his "convincing" parliamentary majority to form a new government. Anwar submitted documents showing over 120 lawmakers support him, but the king will verify the claim. If the king is not convinced, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin may remain in power or a general election could be called. Anwar's bid comes amid Malaysia's economic struggles and a new surge in COVID-19 infections.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on mixed earnings
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% at 28,679.81, the S&P 500 down 0.6% at 3,511.93, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 0.1% at 11,863.90. The decline was driven by mixed earnings, particularly in the travel sector, following the pause of clinical trials for leading coronavirus pharmaceuticals. The pause has weighed on travel stocks.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks fell on Tuesday following mixed earnings as clinical trials were paused for leading coronavirus pharmaceuticals, dragging on travel stocks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Tee International's independent auditor issued a disclaimer of opinion on the group's financial statements for FY2020, citing insufficient audit evidence. The company also recorded pre-tax losses for three consecutive years. Transcorp is unable to make an exit offer to shareholders due to its financial position and is assessing asset monetization. Frasers Property expects a 60-70% decline in attributable profit for FY2020, impacted by pandemic-related factors. Raffles Infrastructure received a qualified opinion from its auditor due to unreconciled differences and deconsolidation of entities.

site_title: MAS to drill deeper into climate risks for stress test on banks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to incorporate climate-related scenarios into its annual stress test for the financial industry within the next two years. This move comes as climate change poses significant risks, with up to $20 trillion of assets globally at risk of becoming stranded by 2050. At a 2°C temperature rise, an estimated $1.7 trillion of global financial assets could be at risk of a write-down in value. The MAS aims to better assess these risks and ensure the financial sector's resilience in the face of climate change.

site_title: iFast clarifies response to SGX query; says no guidance on profit implied
summary: Singaporean wealth management platform iFast Corporation has clarified that a recent price increase of 8.46% for its shares was not a result of any new information about its upcoming third-quarter financial results. The firm, which has seen its shares rise 21.5% in the last month, attributed the price surge to "market speculation" and noted that various measures are in place to restrict access to sensitive information. iFast emphasized that it is not providing guidance on its results and has committed to releasing quarterly numbers.

site_title: STI up 15.23 points on optimism for upcoming Q3 earnings results
summary: The Singapore Stocks Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 2,567.65, driven by optimism for Q3 earnings results, particularly from Ascendas Reit and Mapletree units. China reported strong trade data, with exports rising 9.9% and imports surging 13.2%. Analysts believe the worst of earnings cuts has passed, with Ascendas Reit expected to benefit from structural tailwinds. Despite US-China tensions and the Covid-19 pandemic, investors remain hopeful for global demand improvement.

site_title: Citigroup posts biggest quarterly profit of pandemic
summary: Citigroup reported its largest quarterly profit during the pandemic, with a 18% increase in bond trading revenue to $3.79 billion and a 15% increase in stock trading revenue to $875 million. The bank set aside $2.26 billion for loan losses, lower than expected, and expressed confidence in its loan book's resilience. Despite this, Citigroup's forecast for unemployment and GDP growth worsened, and the bank faces regulatory costs and fines totaling $400 million.

site_title: Wiluan family loses bid to stop JM order on KS Energy
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted OCBC's application to place KS Energy, a Singapore-listed oil services firm, under judicial management (JM). The decision follows a second attempt by the Wiluan family to fight the bid. The JM order will allow OCBC to take control of KS Energy and its key unit. The outcome marks a significant development in the firm's financial struggles.

site_title: New global dividend fund aims for 'premium' income
summary: Aberdeen Standard Investments has launched the Global Dynamic Dividend Fund, aiming to outperform its MSCI AC World (Net) index with a dividend yield greater than 2%. The fund invests in 80-100 global stocks with a bottom-up ESG-embedded strategy, focusing on sectors like technology, healthcare, and consumer staples. Senior equities investment specialist Ben Sheehan notes that companies in these sectors have proven more resilient during the Covid-19 pandemic, offering ample opportunities for investors to find dividend-paying stocks.

site_title: Hyundai's investment could help grow Singapore EV ecosystem
summary: Hyundai has announced a S$400 million Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Center in Singapore, which could produce up to 30,000 vehicles per year by 2025. The facility, located at Jurong Innovation District, will help Hyundai pilot new manufacturing models for mass personalization of cars. Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the investment takes advantage of Singapore's strengths in advanced manufacturing and logistics. The move is expected to diversify the Republic's manufacturing base, create high-value jobs, and contribute to the growth of the electric vehicle ecosystem in Singapore.

images.alt_text: PM Lee (left) with Chung Euisun, executive vice-chairman of Hyundai Motor Group. Siting the carmaker's facility here takes advantage of Singapore's strengths, according to PM Lee.

site_title: Why are investors so eager on blank cheques?
summary: Investors are flocking to so-called blank cheque companies, also known as special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), which allow private businesses to go public without the usual IPO process. These companies raise money from investors, then search for a business to acquire and merge with. The appeal to private businesses is avoiding uncertainty and public scrutiny, while SPAC sponsors can purchase 20% of the business at a low price and make money from the deal. However, SPACs have a poor track record, with only 29 out of 313 deals producing positive returns, and investors may face significant risks, including losing money if the deal fails or if they try to redeem their shares.

site_title: China trade soars in September as economy rebounds
summary: China's economy rebounded in September with exports and imports surging 9.9% and 13.2% year-over-year, respectively, driven by strong domestic demand and global demand for medical supplies and electronics. The trade surplus reached $37 billion, and imports from Taiwan and South Korea rose significantly, driven by China's stockpiling of components ahead of US sanctions. Despite the rebound, analysts remain cautious due to ongoing global pandemic challenges and China's trade deficit with the US.

site_title: Rethinking training with arrival of new technology
summary: The International Maritime Organisation's (IMO) Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers (STCW) is set to be revised due to the rapid evolution of the maritime industry. The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) argues that the current regime is outdated and should be revised to accommodate new technologies, such as automation and alternative fuels. ICS suggests a comprehensive review of the STCW, which has not been done since the early 1990s, to ensure the industry can adapt to the demands of the 2020s.

site_title: Virus fallout: Survey points to large-scale bankruptcies and growth of asset mispricing risks
summary: A global survey by the CFA Institute found that the coronavirus crisis has heightened the need for markets and industries to adapt quickly, leading to large-scale bankruptcies and asset mispricing risks. Liquidity in equities and bonds declined globally, but central bank intervention had a stabilizing effect in some markets. The majority of respondents (96%) believe that government purchases gave rise to asset mispricing. The industry is also facing risks of misconduct, with 45% of respondents globally and 50% in Asia Pacific thinking that financial hardships could lead to unethical actions.

images.alt_text: For emerging markets equities, as much as 27 per cent of respondents in Asia Pacific observed a liquidity shock that could result in fire sales.

site_title: 27 strata office units at 20 Cecil Street up for sale
summary: A portfolio of 27 strata office units at 20 Cecil Street in Singapore's central business district is up for sale with an indicative price of S$100 million (S$3,143 per square foot). The units, ranging from 786 to 2,303 square feet, are located on four levels and can be purchased individually or in bulk. Investors are attracted to the secure cash flow and strong tenant covenants, with expected net yields of 3-3.5%. The sale is considered a rare opportunity for investors seeking Grade A offices in the CBD.

site_title: Europe's 'green China' challenge
summary: China aims to become carbon neutral by 2060, a move that could significantly impact the European Union's climate efforts. China produces nearly 30% of global carbon emissions, and its emissions are likely to increase until 2030. A carbon-neutral China could have a larger climate impact than Europe's efforts, making it crucial for the EU to follow suit. China's commitment to carbon neutrality could render the EU's carbon border tax unworkable, and the EU must consider how to address state-supported technologies from China, which could both facilitate and challenge the EU's plans.

site_title: Three Rockefellers say banks must stop financing fossil fuels
summary: Three members of the Rockefeller family have called for major banks to stop financing fossil fuels, citing climate change as a risk to the global financial system. This stance echoes the actions of John D Rockefeller Jr., who diversified his family's investments away from fossil fuels in the 1920s. A recent report by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission notes that climate change poses a major threat to the US financial system, leading the Rockefellers to advocate for a similar shift in banking practices.

site_title: S$232m fair value loss pushes SPH into the red for first time
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported its first-ever net loss of S$83.7 million for the full year ended Aug 31, due to severe disruptions from Covid-19 across all business segments, including property and media. Non-cash fair value losses of S$232 million, mainly on malls and PBSA assets, contributed to the loss. Despite operational profitability, SPH's media business remains challenged, with a 31.4% decline in media advertisement revenue. The group remains focused on improving recurring income from existing assets and will continue to invest in digitalization efforts.

site_title: Australian dollar hit as China rejects coal imports
summary: The Australian dollar fell after China halted coal imports from the country, amid deteriorating relations. The US dollar index rose 0.1% to 93.18, rebounding from a three-week low. The move by Chinese authorities appears to be aimed at curbing recent yuan gains.

site_title: Pelosi calls for Trump to revamp US$1.8t stimulus proposal
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi criticized President Trump's $1.8 trillion stimulus proposal, calling it insufficient to address the economic recovery and coronavirus battle. Pelosi said significant changes are needed to remedy the proposal's deficiencies. The proposal falls short of the $2.2 trillion bill from House Democrats and the two sides remain far apart on policy issues, including healthcare aid and tax credits. With three weeks to go until Election Day, Pelosi questioned Trump's motives, suggesting he only wants to secure a deal before the election.

site_title: TikTok rival Triller weighs going public
summary: Triller, a TikTok rival, is in talks with several companies about a possible merger that would allow it to go public on Wall Street. The app, launched in 2015, has 65 million monthly users and is advised by merchant bank Farvahar Partners. Triller's main shareholder, Proxima Media, is valued at $1.25 billion. The company's decision comes amid a crackdown on TikTok by President Trump, who has threatened to ban the Chinese-owned social media giant if it doesn't hand over control of its US business. A merger would raise capital from private investors.

site_title: Directors need to ask if they are going overboard with their various board seats
summary: Singapore-based directors of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) were arrested and released on bail for suspected disclosure breaches. The directors, who also serve on other boards, have raised concerns about the issue of multiple directorships. The arrest has led several listed companies to defend their continued appointments of directors serving on other boards. This highlights the need for directors to assess whether they are overextending themselves with multiple board seats.

site_title: BI keeps policy rate unchanged as it focuses on debt purchases
summary: Bank Indonesia (BI) kept its policy rate unchanged at 4% as it focuses on debt purchases to support the economy. The decision was in line with predictions from 23 of 25 economists surveyed by Bloomberg. The move aims to stabilize the economy despite ongoing global economic challenges.

site_title: Key inflation gauge rises at slowest pace in four months
summary: A key US inflation gauge rose 0.2% in September, the slowest pace in four months, indicating little threat of accelerating inflation as the economy recovers. The consumer price index increased 1.4% from a year earlier, after a 1.3% rise in August. This suggests that inflation remains under control, providing relief for policymakers.

site_title: Collaborative automation: Boosting industries and workforce
summary: Singapore businesses are adapting to the Covid-19 pandemic by embracing collaborative automation, a technology that enables robots and workers to work together safely and efficiently. The government has introduced measures to support domestic manufacturing, including S$450 million for companies using robotics and upskilling programs. Collaborative automation is expected to boost industries and create more jobs, particularly for smaller manufacturers and those with lower-volume production lines. The technology has already seen benefits in Singapore, with companies such as BT and Sanmatsu experiencing increased productivity and reduced production costs.

site_title: Digital transformation amid a pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated businesses' digital transformation journeys, with many companies adopting digital solutions and processes to stay afloat. According to a McKinsey study, the equivalent of five years of digital adoption was achieved in just eight weeks. This shift has also led to the virtualisation of the workforce, with many organisations now working remotely. The crisis has driven the adoption of new business models and service delivery, with online sales in Singapore increasing to 18.1% of retail sales in June 2020. As businesses navigate this new landscape, they must overcome challenges such as balancing investments with cash conservation and integrating legacy infrastructure with new digital infrastructure.

site_title: UAE says Opec+ plans to ease oil cuts from January as agreed
summary: The United Arab Emirates' energy minister, Suhail al-Mazrouei, announced that Opec+ producers will stick to their plan to taper oil production cuts from 7.7 million barrels per day in January, as agreed. The cuts are expected to be reduced by 2 million barrels per day. Al-Mazrouei expressed optimism about oil demand recovery, citing signs of improvement in China and other countries as they lift Covid-19 restrictions. This contradicts the International Energy Agency's prediction of a full energy demand rebound in 2025.

images.alt_text: The energy minister from the United Arab Emirates (UAE) said on Tuesday that Opec+ oil producers will stick to their plans to taper oil production cuts from January.

site_title: British Airways abruptly replaces CEO
summary: British Airways has abruptly replaced its CEO, Alex Cruz, with Aer Lingus' Sean Doyle, amid the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the airline industry. The move comes as the carrier cuts 13,000 jobs and plans to fly less than initially forecast. Cruz will give up his role as chairman after a transition period. IAG, the airline's parent company, has seen a record operating loss of 2.2 billion euros and expects passenger demand to return to 2019 levels until 2023 at the earliest. The airline industry faces challenges globally, with travel restrictions and economic relief debates hindering recovery efforts.

site_title: Jobs targeted at foreign labour, poor attitudes behind traineeship mismatch
summary: Thousands of traineeships are available to fresh graduates in Singapore, with the government co-funding 80% of the training allowance. However, a supply-demand mismatch has been identified, with jobs such as manicurists and kitchen hands being targeted for foreign labour, while some jobs, like those in the service sector, have poor attitudes towards trainees. Economists suggest that negative attitudes and the mismatch between job types and worker skills need to change to address the shortage of skilled workers. The SGUnited Traineeships Programme aims to support the job market amid the pandemic.

site_title: G7 voices concern about ransomware attacks; say stablecoin needs regulation
summary: G7 finance officials expressed concern over rising ransomware attacks during the Covid-19 pandemic, urging stablecoin operations to be "appropriately supervised and regulated" before launching. They emphasized that no global stablecoin project should begin operation until it addresses relevant legal and regulatory requirements. The statement also highlighted the potential benefits of digital payments in improving access to financial services and reducing inefficiencies.

site_title: Can machines 'learn' finance?
summary: AQR Capital argues that finance differs from domains where machine learning has shown positive results, citing two key differences: the high signal-to-noise ratio in finance, which is often disrupted by unanticipated news, and the complex, adaptive nature of financial markets. While early research suggests machine learning methods can deliver significant out-of-sample improvement in stock-selection strategies, the potential for machines to "learn" finance remains uncertain. AQR notes that machine learning may be better-suited for risk and transaction cost modeling, and two AI-powered funds have shown promising results, but their short listing history limits conclusions.

site_title: Struggling countries seek G20 debt freeze extension
summary: G20 countries are urging for a wider extension of the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI), which has helped over 40 countries defer $5 billion in debt payments since April. World Bank President David Malpass suggested a possible six-month extension, while Finance Minister Vera Daves of Angola expressed support for the scheme, calling for broader participation from creditors like China and Russia. Policymakers from Kenya and Costa Rica also advocated for more help, with Costa Rica's Central Bank President Rodrigo Cubero emphasizing the need for direct budget support.

site_title: Ikea to buy back used furniture to reduce waste
summary: Ikea plans to buy back used furniture from customers to resell, paying up to 50% of the original price, as part of its "Buy Back Friday" scheme running from Nov 24 to Dec 3 in 27 countries. The initiative aims to reduce waste and encourage customers to give their furniture a second life instead of making impulse purchases. The used furniture will be resold or recycled, with any unsellable items donated to community projects to help those affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Winning stocks ignited by the stay-at-home consumer
summary: During Singapore's stay-at-home period, consumer behavior shifted, benefiting companies like Peloton and Sea Limited. Fitness platforms and online marketplaces saw a surge in traffic and sales, with Peloton's revenue doubling and Sea's active gamers reaching half a billion. Gaming and online marketplaces also experienced significant growth, with Microsoft's gaming division and Shopify's revenue increasing by 64% and 119% year-over-year, respectively. Meanwhile, entrepreneurs turned to online marketplaces like Etsy to start home businesses, with the platform's revenue soaring 140% year-over-year.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fined US$16m by German prosecutors in Danske probe
summary: Deutsche Bank was fined €13.5 million (S$21.5 million) by German prosecutors for violating anti-money laundering laws related to its work with Danske Bank. The bank failed to file timely alerts about suspicious transactions over 600 times, with the majority of money laundering occurring through Danske's Estonian unit. The case is linked to over $200 billion in suspicious transfers, with some routed through Deutsche Bank. Prosecutors dropped a related criminal probe after no evidence of criminal misconduct was found. The bank emphasized that the closure of the proceedings indicates no wrongdoing.

site_title: China tech stocks seen as better bet than US counterparts
summary: Chinese internet stocks are expected to outperform US counterparts due to mounting regulatory challenges facing US technology giants. Investors believe weakening the US megacaps will boost the relative attractiveness of Chinese tech companies, which are investing in growth areas and face lower regulatory risk. Chinese tech firms trade on lower valuations with higher growth prospects, making them a more appealing bet. This trend is expected to continue in the months ahead, according to investors such as Edward Lim, chief investment officer at Covenant Capital Pte Ltd in Singapore.

site_title: Boeing reports more 737 MAX cancellations, deliveries fall
summary: Boeing reported 11 aircraft deliveries in September, down from 25 a year ago, and lost three 737 MAX orders, bringing the total cancelled orders to 436. The company's deliveries for the first nine months of 2020 fell to 98, down from 301. Boeing is working to win regulatory approval for the 737 MAX, potentially early next month, amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic's impact on the aviation industry.

site_title: US consumer prices slow in September
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in September for a fourth consecutive month, slowing from a 0.4% increase in August. The pace of inflation is easing as the US economy recovers from the Covid-19 recession. The 12-month increase in the consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.4% in September, down from 1.3% in August. Economists had forecast a 0.2% increase in September and a 1.4% year-over-year rise. The slowdown in inflation suggests the Federal Reserve may reassess its monetary policy.

site_title: Explosive demand for protective gear sends Medtecs' Q3 top line and net profit up
summary: Medtecs International Corporation reported a 636% increase in revenue to US$124.6 million in Q3, driven by strong demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) amid the pandemic. Net profit surged 1,115 times to US$45.7 million. The company expects strong demand to continue, citing uncertainty over vaccine efficacy. Revenue and net profit for the first nine months increased 4.74 and 198 times respectively. Medtecs attributes its success to leveraging e-commerce platforms and data analysis, and expects record revenue and profit in the fourth quarter and year-end.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow slip on J&J vaccine worries
summary: The US stock market opened lower on October 13, 2020, as Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine trials paused, weighing on investor sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.25% and the S&P 500 declined 0.01%. In contrast, the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.21% ahead of major events for Apple and Amazon.com.

site_title: Cecil Street Grade A office units launched for sale with S$100m indicative price
summary: A portfolio of 27 Grade A office units at 20 Cecil Street in Singapore's central business district has been launched for sale with an indicative price of S$100 million. The units, ranging from 786 sq ft to 2,303 sq ft, can be purchased individually or in bulk, with an average price of S$3,143 per square foot. The sale is expected to attract family offices, high net worth individuals, and investors due to the secure cash flow and strong tenant covenants.

images.alt_text: The 20 Cecil Street mixed-use building has 28 storeys, comprising a 26-storey office tower atop a two-storey retail podium.
20 Cecil Street features a double-volume lobby entrance. The mixed-use building has 28 storeys, comprising a 26-storey office tower atop a two-storey retail podium.
The strata area of each unit ranges from 786 sq ft to 2,303 sq ft. They can be purchased individually or in bulk.
The Grade A office units can be purchased individually or in bulk. The individual unit price starts from around S$2.4 million.

site_title: Auditor gives qualified opinion on Raffles Infrastructure's financial statements
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED Raffles Infrastructure's audited financial statements for the financial year ended June 30 have been given a qualified opinion by its independent auditor, RT LLP. The auditor was unable to confirm that opening balances were fairly stated and questioned the deconsolidation of several entities due to Raffles Infrastructure's loss of control. The auditor also flagged an unreconciled difference of 2 million yuan from the computation of loss on net assets arising from deconsolidation. The financial statements have a modified opinion due to possible adjustments made by Raffles Infrastructure.

site_title: IMF sees shallower recession, tough path back to full recovery
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its forecast for the world economy, predicting a 4.4% contraction in 2020 and 5.2% growth in 2021. The fund attributes the revised forecast to better-than-expected growth in the US and euro area, as well as a stronger-than-anticipated recovery in China. However, the IMF warns that recovery is not assured until the pandemic is tamed, with economies facing a "difficult path back to pre-pandemic activity levels." The fund also predicts a significant increase in sovereign debt, particularly in advanced economies.

site_title: Goldfinger actress Margaret Nolan dies at 76
summary: Margaret Nolan, actress known for her role in the James Bond film "Goldfinger," has died at 76. Nolan, who appeared in various films and TV productions in the 1960s and 1970s, was shot into the limelight by the film's title sequence, which projected images onto her body. She played a masseuse in the film and went on to have a varied career, including drawing and painting. Nolan passed away on October 5 at her home in London due to cancer.

site_title: Transcorp can't make exit offer to minority shareholders
summary: Transcorp Holdings, a Catalist-listed firm, is unable to make an exit offer to minority shareholders as its controlling shareholders, SG Royal Group and Cheng Mingming, have not indicated their intention to do so. The company had a deadline of a month from the delisting notification on September 14 to make an exit offer. Transcorp is currently assessing the feasibility of monetizing certain assets and aims to provide an update to shareholders by November 2020. The company is also facing a legal suit from Fuji Xerox Singapore, which has sent a letter of demand for payment.

site_title: US banks report good earnings, but warn of hit if no more stimulus
summary: US large banks reported better-than-expected earnings, citing an improving economy, but cautioned that a lack of new stimulus measures could hinder the recovery. JPMorgan and Citigroup warned of a "double-dip" recession if no additional stimulus is enacted, with potential losses of $10 billion and $20 billion, respectively. The banks attributed their improved results to massive spending from Washington, which has helped avert delinquencies, but noted that the uncertainty and lack of stimulus pose a risk to the US economy.

site_title: Delta delays US$5b of jet deliveries in blow to Airbus
summary: Delta Air Lines has delayed $5 billion in aircraft deliveries from Airbus until after 2022 due to cash strains during the COVID-19 pandemic. The delay affects planes scheduled for delivery this year and some CRJ regional jets, easing cash pressures during the next two years. The airline has already reduced spending and operations, planning to retire 400 aircraft by 2025. Delta's CEO, Ed Bastian, cited the company's cash situation as the reason for the deferrals, indicating a long-term approach to preserving orders despite weak travel demand.

site_title: EU to win right to tariffs on US$4b in US goods in WTO Boeing case
summary: The European Union is set to win the right to impose tariffs on US$4 billion in US goods in retaliation for subsidies granted to Boeing under a World Trade Organization (WTO) ruling. The decision comes after a 16-year legal battle and could stoke transatlantic trade tensions, particularly with the US presidential election approaching. The EU has signaled interest in settling the dispute, but would impose tariffs without a negotiated solution. Tariffs could target US products such as wine, spirits, and agricultural produce.

site_title: Citigroup quarterly profit tumbles on low interest rates, loan demand
summary: Citigroup reported a 34% drop in quarterly profit due to low interest rates and a slowdown in loan demand. Despite a 16% jump in trading fees, the decline in loan book revenue outweighed the gains. Bond trading revenue rose 18% and equities trading increased 15%. The company set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

images.alt_text: Citigroup reported a 34 per cent drop in quarterly profit on Tuesday, as rock-bottom interest rates and a slowdown in loan demand outweighed the boost from a surge in financial market trading.

site_title: SPH posts first full year net loss of S$83.7m for FY20
summary: SPH, a Singapore-based media and publishing company, reported its first full-year net loss of S$83.7 million for FY20, reversing a net profit of S$213.2 million the previous year. The loss was mainly due to non-cash fair value losses of S$232 million, primarily on malls and student accommodation assets. Despite a 9.8% decline in operating revenue, the company is intensifying its digitalization efforts and will continue to take a prudent approach to liquidity and capital management.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.77 points to 1,525.20, closing higher on Tuesday. The index saw a gain of 477 to 460 gainers and losers. Total volume was 5.963 billion lots worth RM3.887 billion.

site_title: Thai police and protesters scuffle on eve of big demonstration
summary: Thai police and protesters clashed in Bangkok on Tuesday, ahead of a major anti-government demonstration. At least 21 people were detained in the scuffles, which broke out near the Democracy Monument. Protesters, demanding a new constitution and the removal of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, pushed against a police line and threw blue paint over officers. The police responded by demolishing a protester-held tent. The clashes come as Thailand prepares for a significant demonstration, marking the third month of protests seeking reforms and change.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that automotive activities are becoming viable again in the country, thanks to the production of electric vehicles (EVs). Hyundai opened its first EV facility in Singapore, complementing the country's advanced manufacturing and logistics strengths. In other news, Hyflux disputed statements made by suitor Utico, IFast Corp attributed its share price jump to upcoming financial results, and Tee International's auditor issued a disclaimer of opinion on its finances. The Straits Times Index also rose 0.6% to a fresh two-year high.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the Hyundai Motor Group Innovation Centre in Jurong.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks end marginally higher
summary: Shanghai stocks ended marginally higher Tuesday, following a strong rally the day before. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.28 points to 3,359.75, while the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.65% to 2,304.19. The gains were partly attributed to a surge in Chinese imports. Hong Kong was closed due to a typhoon.

site_title: Four new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Four new COVID-19 cases were reported in Singapore, all of whom were imported and had been placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. The total number of cases in Singapore increased to 57,884. No local cases were reported, and a 64-year-old man who had a history of hypertension died from complications due to COVID-19, marking the 28th death in the country.

site_title: Indonesia's state bank merger will form US$15b entity
summary: Indonesia is merging its Islamic units from state-owned lenders Bank Mandiri, Bank Negara Indonesia, and Bank Rakyat Indonesia, forming a US$15 billion entity by 2025. The merged entity's assets could reach 390 trillion rupiah, and its scale will help it compete globally. The move aims to revive Indonesia's domestic Shariah economy and raise the country's global profile. Bank BRISyariah will be the surviving entity, with the merger set to be completed by February 2021.

site_title: COE supply to rise by 5.8% for Nov-Jan period
summary: The Land Transport Authority announced a 5.8% increase in COE supply for the November-January period, with a total of 6,649 COEs available. The increase affects commercial vehicles and motorcycles, with more COEs allocated to these categories. However, car COE supply remains largely unchanged due to a contraction in the 1,600cc category. This increase is expected to ease prices for commercial vehicles and motorcycles, while car prices may remain stable.

site_title: Frasers Property expects FY2020 attributable profit to drop 60%-70%
summary: Frasers Property Ltd. expects a 60-70% decline in FY2020 attributable profit, primarily due to the novel coronavirus pandemic and a subdued global economic environment. The company's tenant-support packages, decline in occupancies, and temporary closures of hospitality properties have negatively impacted its financials. Frasers Property will release its financial results on November 11 and has sufficient liquidity to meet its operations and financial commitments.

site_title: STI up 0.6%, building on optimism of Q3 results season
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to close at 2,567.65, driven by optimism ahead of Q3 results season. Ascendas Reit and Mapletree's trio were top performers, with Ascendas Reit's business updates set for October 26. Asian markets followed suit, with China's exports rising 9.9% year-over-year and the Nikkei 225 Index rebounding 0.18%. However, the Kospi ended its eight-day rally, down 0.02%, amid South Korea's rising coronavirus cases. Despite US-China tensions and the pandemic, economists believe the Chinese economy's opening to foreign investments will boost global demand.

site_title: Dubai's Majid Al Futtaim hires HSBC for sale of district cooling unit: sources
summary: Dubai-based Majid Al Futtaim is selling its district cooling unit, with HSBC hired to facilitate the sale. The unit, which provides chilled water to offices, industrial, and residential buildings, is valued at around 500 million dirhams (S$185.08 million). Majid Al Futtaim, which also operates Carrefour in the Middle East, has assessed its business portfolio and is exploring new opportunities. The sale is expected to attract interest from UAE district cooling firm Tabreed, which recently acquired a similar business in Downtown Dubai for 2.48 billion dirhams.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets little changed at open
summary: European stock markets remained largely unchanged at the start of trading on Tuesday, following a sluggish performance in Tokyo overnight. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 6,006.77 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index fell 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. The sluggish performance was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Australia: Financials, tech stocks drive market higher
summary: Australian shares rose for the seventh consecutive session, with the S&P/ASX 200 index increasing 1% to 6,195.70. Financials sector led the gains, up 1.7%, as optimism over economic recovery and dividend hopes boosted banks. Technology stocks also rose 1.6%, tracking US peers. The rally followed the Australian government's pledge of tax cuts and job measures, easing lending standards for banks.

site_title: Hyflux disputes several statements by suitor Utico
summary: Hyflux, a distressed water-treatment company, has disputed statements made by its Emirati suitor Utico, including claims of a firm binding offer and collaboration with creditors. In a regulatory statement, Hyflux denied being aware of Utico's discussions with banking creditors and questioned the validity of Utico's offer. The company's move comes as it navigates its restructuring efforts.

site_title: Indonesia's Wiluan family loses bid to prevent JM order for KS Energy
summary: Indonesia's Wiluan family failed to prevent a judicial management (JM) order for KS Energy, a Singapore-listed oil-services firm, after a two-hour-long hearing at the Singapore High Court. OCBC, the firm's super-majority creditor, successfully applied for the JM order, appointing Deloitte & Touche's Andrew Grimmett and Lim Loo Khoon as judicial managers. The decision is a major blow to Kris Wiluan, the firm's founder, who is separately facing 112 charges of alleged false trading and market rigging.

site_title: Retailer French Connection first-half sales halve on virus hit
summary: British clothing retailer French Connection Group Plc reported a 50% decline in sales for the first half of 2020 due to the coronavirus crisis, resulting in a threefold increase in underlying losses compared to the same period last year. Chairman and CEO Stephen Marks described it as the most difficult trading period in the company's history.

site_title: Singapore firms lag Malaysia and Thai peers on integrity disclosures: study
summary: Singapore's largest listed companies lag behind Malaysian and Thai peers in disclosing business integrity practices, according to a study by the NUS Business School's Centre for Governance and Asean CSR Network. The study found that 64% of Singapore-listed companies made disclosures, compared to 74% in Malaysia and 71% in Thailand. The average disclosure level for the five Asean countries has improved to 63% from 56% in 2018. Experts attribute the discrepancy to a "definite disconnect between practice and disclosures" among Singaporean companies, with some showing "inertia to disclose" about business integrity.

site_title: EU wins right to place tariffs on US$4b US goods in aircraft spat
summary: The European Union won the right to impose tariffs on $4 billion in US goods in response to subsidies granted to Boeing under a World Trade Organization (WTO) ruling. This decision mirrors US tariffs on Airbus jets and could lead to discussions to resolve a 16-year legal battle. The ruling threatens to stoke transatlantic trade tensions just before US presidential elections on November 3. Negotiators on both sides expressed optimism that the decision could mark a step towards resolving the dispute.

site_title: New accreditation framework promotes hiring of people with disabilities in Singapore
summary: Singapore has introduced the Enabling Mark, a new accreditation framework that encourages businesses to hire people with disabilities. The framework, launched by SG Enable, assesses organizations in six categories and awards three tiers: Platinum, Gold, and Silver. The initiative aims to promote disability-inclusive employment and follows the President's Challenge Enabling Employment Pledge launched earlier this year. Over 140 employers have already made the pledge, with some companies, like Seoul Garden Group and Adrenalin Group, expressing interest in applying for the Enabling Mark.

site_title: Amazon pitches early holiday shopping with fall 'Prime Day' event
summary: Amazon has kicked off its "Prime Day" event, a 48-hour promotion of discounts to members, as a kickoff to an earlier holiday shopping season. The event, typically held in July, now starts in October, with promotions also being held in Turkey and Brazil. This move comes as the pandemic has led to a shift in consumer behavior, with online sales expected to be critical for retailers. Amazon is marketing Prime, a fast-shipping and media-streaming service, as a key way to incentivize subscribers to shop on the platform, with rival retailers Walmart and Target also hosting promotions.

site_title: UK debt mountain to grow but don't raise taxes yet: IFS think-tank
summary: Britain's public debt is expected to rise to 110% of GDP by 2024-25, with borrowing reaching a record level due to the COVID-19 pandemic and Brexit. A think tank, the Institute for Fiscal Studies, advises against raising taxes yet, citing low debt servicing costs that could vanish with rising interest rates. The government should instead focus on long-term debt management and lock in low borrowing costs by selling more long-dated bonds.

site_title: The scramble to secure super-app status
summary: Super-apps, all-in-one mobile applications offering various services, are gaining popularity, particularly in emerging markets. China's WeChat and Alipay, owned by Tencent and Ant respectively, are leading examples, while Gojek and Grab in Indonesia and Singapore, and Kakao in South Korea, are also prominent players. Other companies, including Facebook's WhatsApp and India's Tata, are experimenting with similar services. While some super-apps generate significant revenue through advertising and partnerships, others, like Grab and Gojek, remain unprofitable. Traditional businesses are also exploring super-app potential, with Tata working on a combined consumer app and AirAsia rebranding itself as a lifestyle platform.

site_title: UK jobless rate rises by more than expected to 4.5%
summary: The UK's unemployment rate has risen to 4.5% in the three months to August, exceeding economists' expectations of 4.3%. The number of people in employment fell by 153,000, while staff on company payrolls increased by 20,000 in September. The Bank of England forecasts unemployment to reach 7.5% by the end of the year as the government scales back its job protection scheme. BOE governor Andrew Bailey warns the economy could be weaker than forecast.

site_title: More than 50 tech jobs for women at DBS virtual hiring fair
summary: DBS Bank is hosting a virtual hiring fair for women in technology, offering over 50 job openings across 11 roles. The fair aims to encourage more women in Singapore to build a career in technology. Applicants will undergo an 80-minute online assessment, with shortlisted candidates invited to an online hiring day and virtual interview. DBS managing director Soh Siew Choo emphasized the need for gender balance in the technology workforce, stating that it's crucial for developing differentiated customer experiences. The virtual hiring fair is part of the bank's efforts to nurture a more gender-balanced technology workforce.

site_title: Thousands back inquiry into Murdoch's Australian media 'monopoly'
summary: More than 180,000 Australians have signed a petition calling for a Royal Commission into Rupert Murdoch's dominance over Australian news media, citing concerns over a "monopoly" that undermines public debate and free speech. The petition, launched by former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, urges the government to establish an inquiry into News Corp's influence on Australian politics and media.
