Former Liberal leader John Hewson has also expressed support for an investigation, while News Corp has yet to respond to the petition. The petition will be submitted to parliament on November 5.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap eight-day rally as coronavirus cases jump
summary: South Korean shares ended an eight-day rally, closing 0.58 points, or 0.02%, lower at 2,403.15. The benchmark Kospi was weighed down by a triple-digit jump in domestic coronavirus cases. Foreigners were net buyers of 209.1 billion won worth of shares on the main board.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar says documents given to king show support of over 120 lawmakers
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim claims to have the backing of over 120 lawmakers, presenting documents to the king to form a new government. Anwar asserts that Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's government has lost its majority and should resign. The king, according to Anwar, will determine whether he has enough support to form a new government, with no need for a snap election.

site_title: Rolls-Royce job cuts spark rebellion in town under lockdown
summary: Aerospace company Rolls-Royce Holdings is slashing output and moving jobs to Singapore due to the travel slump triggered by the coronavirus outbreak. The move has sparked a rebellion in the town of Barnoldswick, England, where the engine plant is located, with unions balloting for strike action. The town is facing an uncertain future, mirroring the crisis in Britain as the country grapples with the pandemic and economic meltdown. Residents have taken to the streets, displaying defiance with red and white bunting and posters, in a show of resistance against corporate giant Rolls-Royce.

site_title: Maersk to lay off 2,000 in business shake-up, lifts outlook on improving demand
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, has announced plans to cut 2,000 jobs as it streamlines costs, while lifting its earnings outlook due to recovering demand. Cargo volumes have rebounded faster than expected, with a 3% decline in the third quarter compared to last year. The company now expects full-year earnings of $7.5 billion to $8.0 billion before restructuring costs. Maersk's CEO Soren Skou stated that volumes have rebounded strongly and freight rates have increased due to strong demand.

site_title: China's biggest air show postponed because of Covid-19 pandemic
summary: China's International Aviation and Aerospace Exhibition, the country's largest air show, has been postponed due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Scheduled to take place in Zhuhai in mid-November, the new dates will be announced at a later time. This decision was made by the show's organizers to ensure the safety of attendees and exhibitors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally higher, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.18% to 23,601.78, and the Topix index gaining 0.35%. Investors bought on dips after two days of decline, driven by US shares' gains, but remained cautious ahead of Japan's corporate results season. Key winners included JAL, up 3.03%, and Sony, up 1.82%. The US dollar rose to 105.37 yen, while a halt in Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine trial trimmed early gains.

site_title: Bukit Timah Plaza 17,351 sq ft ground-floor unit for sale with S$30m guide price
summary: A prime ground-floor commercial unit with 12 car-park lots at Bukit Timah Plaza is for sale with a guide price of S$30 million. Spanning 17,351 sq ft, the unit is tenanted to several businesses, including a wedding services firm and a pilates school. The asset is expected to appeal to investors seeking stable rental income and potential collective sale opportunities. With several new residential launches in the vicinity, the area is expected to experience increased vehicular traffic and footfall, potentially benefiting the commercial unit.

images.alt_text: Large commercial units above 10,000 sq ft are in limited supply and often tightly held by few owners, noted SRI's Benson Koh.

site_title: Automotive activities viable again as Hyundai opens first EV facility in Singapore: PM Lee
summary: Singapore has welcomed the return of automotive activities with the opening of Hyundai's first electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing facility in the country. The S$400 million innovation centre, located at Jurong Innovation District, is expected to produce up to 30,000 vehicles per year by 2025. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong sees this as a strategic move that leverages Singapore's strengths in advanced manufacturing and logistics. The facility is also expected to create new job opportunities and contribute to the country's economic growth, with potential collaborations with local universities and research institutes.

site_title: Shanghai-listed firm buys Zheneng Jinjiang stake for S$289.9m, plans mandatory offer
summary: Shanghai-listed thermal power generation firm Zhejiang Zheneng Electric Power's special purpose vehicle (SPV) plans to acquire a 25.62% stake in Singapore-listed waste-to-energy plant operator Zheneng Jinjiang Environment (ZJE) for approximately S$289.9 million. The SPV will then make a mandatory cash offer for the remaining 44.81% of ZJE shares at a price of S$0.7781 per share, a 44.1% premium over the last traded price. The acquisition is subject to pre-conditions, including shareholder approval and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Gold slips on US dollar rebound, investors eye US stimulus
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,910.76 per ounce due to a rebound in the US dollar. Investors remain hopeful for a US stimulus package, which could support gold prices. The dollar index rose 0.1% and Asian shares were weaker. The US coronavirus relief bill is also on investors' radar, with a potential passage potentially boosting gold prices. Gold prices have gained 26% this year, but are struggling due to uncertainty over the economic recovery and the presidential elections.

site_title: Australian firm tiptoes into battery making with country's first plant
summary: An Australian company, Energy Renaissance, plans to build the country's first lithium-ion battery factory in Tomago, New South Wales, starting with an initial production capacity of 66 MWh per year. The company aims to expand to 5.3 GWh annually within 10 years and has secured letters of intent from firms like ABB Ltd and Western Power to buy its batteries. Energy Renaissance has received an A$246,625 grant from the Australian government and has sufficient funds to begin construction, with plans to start building by the end of 2020.

site_title: Asia: Markets slip as vaccine halt dents optimism
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, following a previous day's rally, due to a halted vaccine trial and concerns over the COVID-19 pandemic. The US stock market, however, rose, driven by tech stocks. A top Democrat's comments on a potential stimulus package also dampened regional traders' spirits. Despite this, analysts expect a bigger fiscal stimulus package to be passed, citing Joe Biden's strong poll leads and the potential for a more significant economic boost.

site_title: Malaysia's Anwar Ibrahim meets king in challenge for premiership
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim met with the king on Tuesday, aiming to prove he has parliamentary support to oust Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin. Anwar claimed to have secured a "formidable" majority, but skepticism remains as no major party has offered clear support. The king can appoint a prime minister with a majority backing, and Anwar must convince him of his support. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, and the country faces an economy battered by the coronavirus surge.

site_title: China to raise US$6b via bond issue; US investors welcome for first time: sources
summary: China is set to raise approximately $6 billion through an international sovereign bond sale, allowing US-based institutional investors to participate for the first time. The Ministry of Finance has mandated 13 banks for the proposed multi-tranche Reg S and 144A offering. This marks a change from China's previous international sovereign bond sales, which were all Reg S offerings. The move is seen as a sign of China's growing economic and financial ties with the US.

site_title: Car sales in China shine as rest of world reels from virus
summary: China's car sales increased 7.4% in September to 1.94 million units, driven by demand for SUVs, as the rest of the world struggles with the pandemic. This marks the third straight monthly increase and is a bright spot for the automobile market. International and domestic manufacturers are benefiting from the resurgence in demand, with China set to be the first country to bounce back to 2019 volume levels by 2022. Wholesales of new-energy vehicles also increased, with Tesla selling 11,329 vehicles in September, and are expected to drive overall auto sales growth in the fourth quarter.

site_title: UK moves closer to infect healthy people with Covid to aid vaccine efforts
summary: The UK is moving closer to conducting human challenge trials to aid Covid-19 vaccine efforts. Thousands of volunteers, including a 20-year-old chemistry student, are ready to participate in the studies, which involve intentionally infecting healthy people with the virus to gather data. The trials, if approved, would be the first of their kind for Covid-19 and could help speed up vaccine development. However, experts raise concerns about the ethics and safety of the trials, citing the lack of long-term research on the virus and potential risks to young and healthy participants.

site_title: SGX and NZX to explore global dairy derivatives partnership
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and New Zealand's Exchange (NZX) signed a Heads of Agreement to explore a global partnership to grow NZX's dairy derivatives market. The non-binding agreement will see NZX list its dairy derivatives contracts on SGX's platforms, leveraging SGX's global market connectivity and NZX's dairy product development expertise. The partnership aims to scale growth and liquidity in the trading of dairy derivatives, with market participants expected to gain "augmented access" via current and new trading and clearing channels. The partnership is expected to be confirmed in the first half of 2021.

site_title: Johnson & Johnson pauses Covid vaccine trial as participant becomes ill
summary: Johnson & Johnson has paused its Covid-19 vaccine trial due to an unexplained illness in a study participant. The company has temporarily halted further dosing in its Phase 3 ENSEMBLE trial, which involves 60,000 patients. An independent patient safety committee will convene to investigate the incident. The pause will allow for a thorough review and ensure the safety of the remaining participants. The company will reassess the trial when the safety committee completes its investigation.

images.alt_text: Johnson & Johnson said Monday it had temporarily halted its Covid-19 vaccine trial because one of its participants had become sick.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit near two-month high as banks shine
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to a near two-month high, led by banking and technology stocks, following optimism over a US coronavirus relief package. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,193, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index hit an all-time high of 12,454.57. Australian financial stocks climbed 2.6% and IT stocks rose 1.9%. However, coal producers fell sharply due to China blocking shipments.

site_title: Trump tells fans on post-Covid comeback tour: 'I feel so powerful'
summary: President Donald Trump made a comeback tour in Florida after a 10-day absence due to Covid-19. He vowed to be in "great shape" before the election and claimed to be immune to the virus. Trump expressed confidence in his ability to win the election and even joked about kissing his audience members, sparking concerns about his handling of the pandemic.

site_title: Catching coronavirus outside is rare but not impossible
summary: Despite rare instances of outdoor transmission, experts say wearing a mask outside is justified due to the risk of infection. Most documented cases have occurred indoors, where people stand near each other and talk for long periods. A study found only one case of transmission outdoors between two Chinese villagers out of over 7,000 studies. Experts recommend wearing masks in crowded outdoor areas, such as sporting events or concerts, and keeping a safe distance between people. The risk of transmission is lower outside due to the dilution of virus-carrying aerosols through the atmosphere, and ultraviolet rays can deactivate the virus, but the effectiveness depends on the sun's intensity.

images.alt_text: Almost all documented coronavirus transmissions have occurred indoors, but experts say that wearing a mask outside is justified because there is still a risk of infection.

site_title: Exelon weighs shedding nuclear plants, other non-utility assets
summary: Exelon Corp, a Chicago-based power company, is considering a potential breakup that would separate its non-utility assets, including 21 nuclear reactors and solar, wind, and natural-gas generating assets. The move would focus the company on its regulated power market, with a portfolio of utilities in Pennsylvania, Maryland, and elsewhere. Activist investor Corvex Management estimates Exelon could be worth $60 a share, and the company may consider spinning off its non-utility assets to unlock that value. A potential buyer for Exelon's non-utility arm, Exelon Generation, is uncertain due to the complexity of its nuclear reactors.

site_title: Peru opens Machu Picchu for a single Japanese tourist after almost 7-month wait
summary: Peru has allowed a single Japanese tourist, Jesse Takayama, to enter the Machu Picchu ruins after an almost 7-month wait due to the coronavirus outbreak. Takayama had submitted a special request while stranded in Peru since mid-March, and was accompanied by the head of the park. This is the first visitor to enter the site in seven months. Machu Picchu will reopen in November for national and foreign tourists at 30% capacity, with necessary precautions in place due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Snowflake signs Goldman as customer in push for banking deals
summary: Snowflake signed a multi-million dollar deal with Goldman Sachs in its second fiscal quarter, ending in July. The renewal contract allows Goldman to use Snowflake's data-warehouse software, which helps businesses analyze information across different systems. This deal is part of Snowflake's push for banking deals, as the company competes with Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet, Cloudera, and Oracle in the cloud computing market. Representatives for both companies declined to comment on the specifics of the deal.

images.alt_text: Snowflake, a software maker whose stock debuted with the biggest US initial public offering (IPO) in 2020, signed a deal worth millions of dollars with Goldman Sachs Group earlier this year, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volume up 0.4% in September: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale volumes rose 0.4% month-over-month to 1,286 units in September, reaching a two-year high. This is a marginal increase from August, with volumes up 62.8% year-over-year and 64.5% above the five-year average. Resale prices edged up 0.1% month-over-month and year-over-year, with the core central region seeing a 0.5% increase and the rest of central region rising 0.8%. The highest transacted price in September was S$16.2 million for a unit at Le Nouvel Ardmore.

site_title: China's imports, exports surge as global economy reopens
summary: China's exports rose 9.9% in August, beating expectations, as the global economy reopened. Imports surged 13.2% in September, returning to growth. China's trade surplus for September was $37 billion, narrower than expected. Analysts warn exports may peak soon due to receding demand for protective gear and base effect of this year's declines. Despite heightened US-China tensions, trade officials reaffirmed their commitment to a Phase One trade deal.

site_title: Takeda group begins manufacturing Covid-19 plasma treatment ahead of approval
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. has started manufacturing a Covid-19 plasma treatment, known as CoVIg Plasma Alliance, ahead of approval. The treatment, a hyperimmune globulin therapy, is derived from blood plasma of recovered patients and offers a standardized dose of antibodies. The Phase III trial, which aims to enroll 500 patients, is ongoing, with results expected by the end of the year. Takeda CEO Christophe Weber believes the treatment's effectiveness is "very high" and the company plans to accelerate plasma donation to meet demand. The treatment may be slightly more costly to produce than existing monoclonal antibody treatments.

site_title: Hunting for unicorns: Japan startups see hope on horizon
summary: Japan's startup ecosystem faces significant challenges, with the country lagging behind the US and China in producing "unicorns" valued at over $1 billion. Despite having a large economy, Japan has only four unicorns, and many startups struggle to secure private funding. Industry insiders attribute this to a cautious investor culture, rigid corporate structure, and a focus on stable jobs, rather than innovation and growth. However, experts see signs of optimism, including increased government support, a growing demand for digital services, and the potential for manufacturing corporations to invest in startups.

site_title: Investors urge heavy carbon emitters to set science-based reduction targets
summary: Investors managing $20 trillion in assets are urging 1,800 heavy carbon emitters to set science-based targets for net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 to limit global warming to 1.5°C. The call comes as companies, including BT, contribute 25% of the world's total emissions. Over 1,000 companies have already set science-based targets, with around 300 aligned with the 1.5°C goal. Investors warn companies that fail to set targets risk losing out and causing greater economic damage.

site_title: Singapore Airlines adds seats, new dates for meals on A-380 restaurant
summary: Singapore Airlines has added two new dates and more seats to its Restaurant A380@Changi dining experience, following a sell-out event within 30 minutes of booking opening. The new dates are Oct 31 and Nov 1, with dinner spots added on Oct 24 and 25. The move comes after the airline sold out over 900 seats for the experience, with a waitlist reopened for interested customers.

site_title: Vietnam firm launches country's largest solar farm amid renewables drive
summary: Vietnam's Trung Nam Group launched a 450-megawatt solar farm in Ninh Thuan, the country's largest solar farm. The $604 million project aims to boost renewables and reduce dependence on coal. Vietnam plans to increase solar and wind energy to 15-20% of its power mix by 2030 and 25-30% by 2045. The solar farm, along with LNG-to-power projects, will help ease the country's imminent power shortage and diversify power sources.

site_title: White House moves forward on three arms sales to Taiwan: sources
summary: The US White House is moving forward with three arms sales to Taiwan, including a truck-based rocket launcher, long-range air-to-ground missiles, and external sensor pods for F-16 jets. The move is likely to anger China, which considers Taiwan a renegade province. The sales were notified to Congress for approval, and lawmakers are expected to support the deals due to their opposition to Chinese aggression and support for Taiwan. The sales come as the US-China relations have plunged to a low point, with the US election nearing.

site_title: Australia investigating reports that China has halted coal imports
summary: Australia is investigating reports that China has halted coal imports, with Trade Minister Simon Birmingham playing down the potential sign of escalating trade tension. Coal flows to China had been disrupted in recent years due to "domestic factors". The halt comes amid diplomatic tensions, including Australia's ban on Huawei and its call for an independent inquiry into the COVID-19 origins. China is Australia's largest coal importer, with imports expected to fall by a quarter this year due to domestic industry support. The Australian government is seeking assurances from China on the matter.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks open lower on Tuesday
summary: Mainland China stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.16% to 3,353.12, and the Shenzhen Composite Index easing 0.18% to 2,285.17. Hong Kong trading was cancelled due to a typhoon. This follows a strong rally on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.96 points, or 0.26%, to 1,514.47. The market saw a slight increase in volume, with 99.14 million lots worth RM49.91 million traded. Despite this, the market favored gainers over losers, 128 to 118. The decline comes amidst global market trends, with Europe's stocks also experiencing a downturn due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: G-20 eyeing six-month debt relief extension: World Bank's Malpass
summary: G-20 countries are considering a six-month debt relief extension, a compromise on the initial one-year suspension of debt service for the world's poorest nations, amid underwhelming participation from creditors. The World Bank reports a 9.5% increase in the debt of the 73 poorest countries to a record $744 billion last year. China, a major creditor, is holding back, with its share of debt rising to 63% by the end of last year. The G-20 meeting may result in a six-month extension that can be renewed depending on debt sustainability.

site_title: Indoor playground SuperPark Singapore has closed down
summary: SuperPark Singapore, a 40,000 sq ft indoor playground, has closed down after less than two years of operations. The closure follows the financial struggles of its holding company, SuperPark Asia Group, which is under interim judicial management with S$18 million in liabilities. The playground's landlord, Suntec City mall, has taken possession of the premises and is reviewing options for the space, including leasing it to other indoor play operators or converting it into a play area for shoppers. The closure is the latest in a series of attractions for kids to shut down in Singapore due to the pandemic.

site_title: New green finance centre in Singapore to drive Asia-focused research, develop talent
summary: The Singapore Green Finance Centre, launched by Imperial College Business School and Singapore Management University, aims to drive Asia-focused research and develop green finance talent. Supported by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and nine founding partners, the centre will offer courses, research, and co-creation projects to equip professionals with skills in climate finance and sustainable investing. The centre's goals include bridging the gap between investors and policymakers on climate change, developing strategies for policymakers and financial institutions to support Asia's transition to a low-carbon future, and catalyzing the development of green finance solutions.

site_title: The life of Ghosn: Fugitive tycoon to star in screen productions
summary: Fugitive auto tycoon Carlos Ghosn and his wife will star in a documentary and mini-series about his life, co-produced by Alef One of France and MBC of Saudi Arabia. The 66-year-old businessman, who was arrested in Japan in 2018, will share his story in a six-part series tracing his rise and fall from power. The project, set to begin in 2021, will include interviews with Ghosn and other key figures, and will be directed by Charlotte Brandstrom and supervised by Mark Goffman.

site_title: Microsoft targets malware vendor Trickbot amid US election fears
summary: Microsoft has taken down malware vendor Trickbot in an effort to thwart attempts to meddle with the US presidential election. The tech giant, in partnership with telecommunications providers, obtained a court order and executed technical action to disrupt Trickbot, which has infected over a million devices worldwide since 2016. Trickbot distributes ransomware, allowing hackers to control infected systems, and could be used to disrupt voter rolls or election-night results. The move comes amid fears that hackers could use malware to upend the November 3 vote, in which President Trump seeks a second term.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending gains seen on Wall Street, where high-tech shares led the way. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.34% to 23,639.70, while the Topix index edged up 0.39% to 1,649.84. The gains follow a strong rally on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending rallies on Wall Street, where high-tech shares led the gains.

site_title: Malaysia's GoGet raises US$2m in Series A funding to scale services
summary: Malaysian startup GoGet has secured US$2 million in Series A funding led by Monk's Hill Ventures to scale its on-demand workforce and job platform services in Malaysia, focusing on product development, team expansion, and digital marketing. The funding will support the platform's growth and user acquisition.

site_title: Auditor issues disclaimer of opinion on Tee International's finances
summary: Tee International's independent auditor Foo Kon Tan LLP issued a disclaimer of opinion on the group's financial statements for the financial year ended May 31, 2020, citing insufficient audit evidence. The audit was affected by an ongoing investigation into unauthorized remittances in the previous financial year and an ongoing probe by the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department. The auditor's report noted that the work of internal and external investigators concluded, but no further update was available. The investigation's status remains unclear.

site_title: Keppel T&T exits Thai associate for 827.6m baht; Floatel forbearance pact extended
summary: Keppel Corp's logistics and data centre arm is selling its 24.01% stake in Thailand-listed Business Online Public Company Limited (BOL) for about 827.6 million baht (S$36 million) in cash. The sale is part of Keppel's Vision 2030 plan to monetize non-core assets. Separately, creditors of associate company Floatel International have extended a forbearance agreement, covering nearly US$22.8 million in bond coupon payments, until Oct 31.

site_title: UK unions urge government to take action over Amazon workers' rights
summary: UK unions TUC and GMB have called on the government to demand improvements in working conditions for Amazon employees, citing "exploitative" practices. The report highlights "gruelling conditions," surveillance, and refusal to recognize unions. The British government has awarded Amazon £630 million in public contracts, which the unions argue should be used to improve working conditions. The unions are urging the government to "level up" working conditions at Amazon, warning that the public sector cannot ignore the company's "appalling health and safety record."

site_title: Revolut plans to apply for US banking license: CNBC
summary: Revolut, a digital banking app, plans to apply for a US banking license with the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco and California's Division of Financial Institutions within weeks. The license will allow Revolut to operate nationwide through interstate agreements. This move comes after Square Inc. received a bank charter earlier this year and San Francisco-based lender Lending Club Corp gained a national charter. Revolut raised $500 million in funding and has a valuation of $5.5 billion, becoming the latest fintech company to seek a regulated banking status.

site_title: US: Nasdaq jumps 2.6% as tech leads stocks to close higher
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with tech shares leading the way, as investors became more confident of a larger stimulus package after the November 3 election. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.6% to 11,876.26, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also advanced. Apple surged 6.4% ahead of its new iPhone launch, and other tech companies such as Facebook and Google posted big gains. Investors are shifting their focus to a blue wave, with the Democrats expected to retake the White House under Joe Biden.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund preparing blank cheque acquisition company: source
summary: SoftBank Group Corp's Vision Fund is preparing to launch a blank cheque acquisition company, a move that would see the fund join the trend of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) used to take companies public. The company's head, Rajeev Misra, confirmed the plans, which are expected to be outlined in the next two weeks. SoftBank is seeking outside investment and may contribute its own capital to the vehicle, which is undetermined in size. The move comes as SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son sells down core assets, leaving speculation over his future investment plans.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Tee International, Parkson Retail Asia, Fabchem, SGX
summary: Keppel Corp divested its 24.1% equity interest in Thailand-listed Business Online Public Company for S$36 million, and extended its forbearance agreement with bondholders covering US$22.8 million in coupon payments. iFast Corp may explain unusual share price movements with its upcoming unaudited financial results. Tee International received a disclaimer of opinion from its auditor, while Parkson Retail Asia's auditor flagged its ability to continue as a going concern. Fabchem China entered a non-binding term sheet for an Australian power plant acquisition, and SGX reported a 23% increase in market turnover value to S$24.3 billion in September.

site_title: Trump has tested negative for Covid-19: White House doctor
summary: US President Donald Trump has tested negative for Covid-19 using a rapid test, according to his White House physician, Sean Conley. The negative determination was based on consecutive days of testing and considered the president not infectious to others. The test results were announced while Trump was on board Air Force One en route to a campaign rally.

site_title: Energy companies restore US Gulf production after hurricane
summary: US energy companies have restored oil and natural gas production in the northern Gulf of Mexico after Hurricane Delta made landfall three days ago. As of Monday, crude oil production stood at 69.4% of pre-hurricane levels, down from 91% on Sunday. Natural gas production, however, remained shut at 47% of pre-hurricane levels, down from 62% on Sunday. The US Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement (BSEE) reported the progress in restoring production.

site_title: Disney revamps itself to emphasise streaming
summary: Disney revamps itself to prioritize its streaming service, Disney+, which has seen a surge in subscriptions during the pandemic. The company appoints Kareem Daniel to lead the Media and Entertainment group, aiming to make decisions based on commercial viability rather than predetermined strategies. CEO Bob Chapek emphasizes putting consumer preferences first, with Disney+ drawing 60.5 million subscribers by the end of June. The company plans to continue releasing blockbusters online, even after the pandemic, to cater to consumers' desire for home viewing.

site_title: Singapore stocks inch higher at open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) edging up 1.71 points or 0.1% to 2,554.13. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 53, with 132.6 million securities worth S$73.1 million changing hands. The positive finish in US markets overnight contributed to the slight gain.

site_title: Oil prices fall 3% as US, Libyan, Norwegian supplies resume
summary: Oil prices fell 3% on Monday as Libya's largest oilfield resumed production, Norway's strike on oil and gas output ended, and US producers restored output after Hurricane Delta. Brent crude settled at $41.62 a barrel, down 2.9%, while US West Texas Intermediate fell 2.9% to $1.17. Rising Libyan output poses a challenge to Opec's efforts to curb supply and support prices.

site_title: Protesters topple Roosevelt, Lincoln statues in Portland
summary: Protesters in Portland, Oregon, toppled statues of former US presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln, prompting President Donald Trump to call for federal intervention and arrest. The "Indigenous Peoples Day of Rage" protests, which drew around 300 demonstrators, followed similar anti-racism protests nationwide. The incident has sparked condemnation from Portland Mayor Ted Wheeler, who described the violence as "obscene." Three people have been arrested in connection with the unrest, and Trump has urged the city to call in federal authorities.

site_title: UK consumers, sensing new Covid-19 restrictions, speed up spending: surveys
summary: UK consumers are accelerating their spending ahead of possible new coronavirus restrictions, with credit card provider Barclaycard reporting a 2% year-on-year increase in spending in September. Retailers also saw strong sales, with sales values at major store chains rising 5.6% in annual terms, the largest increase since 2009. Consumers are stockpiling essentials and bringing forward Christmas shopping due to uncertainty about the upcoming winter months. Despite this, mounting job losses are expected in the coming months, posing a challenge to the UK economy.

site_title: 3,600 opportunities available in retail sector; 70% are for jobs
summary: The Ministry of Manpower in Singapore announced that over 3,600 job opportunities are available in the retail sector, with 70% being actual job postings. Of these, 2,500 are professional, managerial, executive, or technical (PMET) roles. This represents a significant increase since April this year, with companies such as more than 650 retail sector firms offering these opportunities.

site_title: Broadway will remain closed at least through May
summary: Broadway will remain closed at least through May 30, 444 days after the initial shutdown due to the coronavirus. The Broadway League has suspended all ticket sales through May 30, with reopening dates to be determined by producers and theatre owners. Shows have rescheduled opening nights, with some now set for September, December 2021, and February 2022. The shutdown is costing huge amounts of money and endangering the careers of artists, with no clear path to reopening.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based insolvent water treatment firm, has received a formal expression of interest from Strategic Growth Investments (SGI) to invest at least S$204.78 million. Senior unsecured creditors will receive S$97 million, trade creditors S$15.78 million, and PnP investors S$32 million, with S$60 million set aside for working capital and future restructuring. The proposed investment aims to address Hyflux's financial struggles and provide a lifeline to the company.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit five-week high on rebound optimism, stimulus hopes
summary: European shares rose 0.7% to a five-week high on Monday, driven by optimism over China's economic recovery and hopes for US fiscal stimulus. Despite concerns over surging Covid-19 cases, utilities, technology, and autos stocks led the gains. However, the European Central Bank warned that the euro zone economy is entering a tougher phase, and UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's lockdown measures cast a shadow over the economic rebound. The European telecoms index surged to a three-week high, while analysts expect earnings at Stoxx 600 firms to decline 38% year-on-year.

site_title: BuildTech Asia Digital Series to take place virtually on Oct 14-15
summary: The inaugural BuildTech Asia Digital Series will take place virtually on October 14-15 to showcase construction products, services, and technological innovations in the region. The event will feature over 100 global brands, free webinars, and interactive networking through an online platform. The digital series replaces the postponed annual BuildTech Asia expo, originally scheduled for March 2020, and aims to support the building and construction industry despite the pandemic. Sphere Exhibits, the organiser, will also offer an enhanced business matching programme for attendees.

site_title: Big new ETF players may renew price wars
summary: New asset managers entering the ETF market may intensify price wars, forcing existing issuers to cut costs further. Despite recent fee reductions, the competition is expected to continue, with new entrants charging low fees to compete with legacy firms. This could lead to further consolidation in the industry, as firms struggle to maintain profitability. The emergence of new ETF players may also lead to increased innovation and product offerings.

site_title: Analysts see 'balanced fundamentals' in Singapore's private property market
summary: Singapore's private home prices have increased slightly over the last two years, but the market remains "balanced" according to a UBS report. Analysts attribute the resilience to real demand, rather than low interest rates. Cooling measures, such as seller's stamp duty and loan-to-value ratio, have stabilized property prices. Experts note that the market is in "fair-valued territory" and expect prices to soften in the near term. The number of unsold units remains high, but the medium-term development pipeline is well-stocked, indicating a stable market.

site_title: Why markets won't be impressed by 'so-called' US October surprises
summary: US presidential election uncertainty may cause short-term market volatility, but investors are unlikely to be swayed by differences between Donald Trump and Joe Biden's budgets. The recovery from the pandemic is the main driver of the US economy, with both candidates offering continuing fiscal stimulus. The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain its support, and the overall impact of the election on GDP is expected to be minimal, with some estimates suggesting a 3% increase under a Biden administration.

site_title: iFast says its to-be-released financial results may explain jump in share price
summary: iFast Corp, a brokerage platform and wealth manager, attributed a 8.46% increase in its share price to its upcoming unaudited financial results for the third quarter ended Sept 30. The results, set to be released on Oct 23, may explain the unusual price movement. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) had previously queried iFast over a 13.5% increase in its share price in August, which was linked to a Bloomberg report about Hong Kong's digitalization of retirement funds system.

site_title: Virtual, hybrid shareholder meetings could be here to stay: SGX, MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) are open to allowing hybrid and fully virtual shareholder meetings as a long-term option, provided they are carried out effectively. The agencies will closely monitor the experiences of issuers and investors. Currently, companies can hold general meetings via alternate non-physical means until June next year. Measures such as live webcasting, proxy voting, and real-time communication have been implemented to facilitate informed participation. However, concerns remain over risk management policies and non-financial performance indicators, with more companies needed to disclose this information.

site_title: New business models can help raise revenue, ease fixed costs concerns
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing announced enhancements to government support schemes for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to help them recover from the pandemic. The measures include increased funding for the Market Readiness Assistance Grant and Enterprise Financing Scheme, as well as a low-cost Singapore-dollar facility for lending to SMEs. The government aims to encourage businesses to adopt new business models, focusing on service and design, and expand beyond Singapore. The goal is to help SMEs increase revenue and reduce fixed costs, with the aim of supporting the sector's challenging road to recovery.

images.alt_text: Beyond focusing on ways to reduce the high fixed costs related to the retail sector, businesses must also look at ways to improve their top line as the sector embarks on its challenging road to recovery.

site_title: Top Glove mulls HK listing; Maybank Kim Eng expects firm's ESG risks to ease
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, is evaluating a dual primary listing in Hong Kong, which could raise over US$1 billion. The company, already listed in Singapore and Malaysia, aims to diversify its investor base and provide a large fundraising platform for future growth. ESG risks, including labor concerns, have been tied to the industry, but analysts expect these risks to ease as Top Glove implements policies to mitigate them. Maybank Kim Eng has maintained a "buy" rating on Top Glove, citing the company's strong balance sheet and efforts to reduce labor dependency.

site_title: China to test whole city of 9m; Europe rolls out new virus curbs
summary: China will test its entire 9 million population in the port city of Qingdao within five days due to a tiny Covid-19 outbreak. This follows a recent surge in infection numbers in Europe, which has led to new containment efforts, including the UK's three-tiered alert system announced by Prime Minister Johnson.

site_title: Near virus-free environment vital if 'air travel bubble' is to work
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung warns that the country risks losing its status as an international air hub if borders remain closed for an extended period. With daily infections dipping to low teens, Singapore has managed to create a safe bubble at home, but is still mired in an economic crisis. To revive tourism, the government plans to establish "Air Travel Bubbles" with safe countries, but must address concerns of visitors, including quarantine and treatment protocols, to ensure the bubble's success.

site_title: Unlocking the power of outsourcing
summary: RMA Contracts, a Singapore-based small and medium enterprise (SME), is a leading provider of business process outsourcing (BPO) solutions. Founded in 1996 by managing director David Ngoh, the company offers a range of services, including digitisation, transaction processing, and human resource consultancy. With a strong track record of serving government agencies and multinational corporations, RMA Contracts has achieved significant financial growth, with S$46 million in revenue in 2019. The company's success is attributed to its "can-do" mindset, entrepreneurial spirit, and commitment to innovation, including investments in artificial intelligence and cybersecurity. RMA Contracts plans to expand internationally, with plans to set up an Offshore Development Centre in Vietnam and build a business centre in Indonesia.

site_title: STI kicks off week with 19-point gain ahead of Phase 3 'roadmap'
summary: Singapore stocks kicked off the week with a 0.77% gain, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 2,552.42. Sembcorp Industries led the gain, followed by ComfortDelGro and Venture Corporation. The country is expected to release a Phase 3 'roadmap' for reopening the economy in the coming weeks, which may boost these companies. Asian markets ended the day mixed, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 2.64% and the Hang Seng Index up 2.20%.

site_title: Resurgence of Covid-19 in Malaysia likely to weaken economic recovery
summary: Malaysia is experiencing a resurgence of COVID-19 cases, with new infections reaching a record 691 on October 6, largely attributed to the state of Sabah. The surge is weakening the country's economic recovery, which had begun to recover after a 17.1% contraction in the second quarter. The government has imposed curbs on movement and restricted sports and recreational activities to combat the outbreak. Experts warn that consumers will become more cautious, leading to a weaker economic recovery pace, and the tourism industry is expected to continue to suffer, with retail sales projected to drop 20.2% in the third quarter.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector losses, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: A strong corporate culture is a valuable asset
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued guidelines to promote individual accountability and conduct among financial institutions, emphasizing the importance of a strong corporate culture. Companies with a robust and ethical culture are better equipped to deliver superior performance and gain market confidence. A strong culture is crucial for ensuring good governance, transparency, and fairness, and can drive profitability, acquisition decisions, and ethical behavior. Regulators, investors, and companies must also prioritize establishing and maintaining a strong culture to ensure long-term survival and success.

site_title: Yuan drops on bank policy change; US dollar steady
summary: China's yuan fell 0.8% against the US dollar after the People's Bank of China lowered reserve requirements for foreign exchange forwards trading, aiming to curb recent appreciation. The move, seen as a signal to restrain the yuan's rise, follows a 6% gain against the dollar since May. The US dollar index remained steady, despite a 17-month high in the yuan reached on Friday. The yuan's decline also affected the Australian and New Zealand dollars.

site_title: Second week of jobs law protests in Indonesia
summary: Hundreds of workers in Jakarta protested against Indonesia's controversial new jobs law, which critics say undermines labor rights and weakens environmental protections. The "omnibus" law, passed last week, has sparked widespread outcry across the country, with over 6,000 people arrested and public property torched. The government has defended the law, but several groups, including Indonesia's largest Islamic association, have pledged to lodge a judicial review. Protests are expected to continue, with conservative Islamic organizations planning to protest outside the state palace on Tuesday.

site_title: Year's biggest bank merger sealed as Saudi rivals reach US$15b deal
summary: Saudi Arabia's National Commercial Bank (NCB) agreed to buy rival Samba Financial Group for $15 billion, the largest banking takeover this year. The deal values Samba at $55.7 billion and creates the Gulf region's third-largest lender with over $220 billion in assets. The combined entity will have a market capitalization of $46 billion and a 37.2% stake held by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund. The merger is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's "Vision 2030" initiative to diversify the Saudi economy, with the goal of creating local champions in industries such as finance.

site_title: Singapore's wired people+tech leadership = edge in recovery
summary: Singapore's swift adoption of digital technologies has given the country an edge in recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic. The nation's government and businesses have rapidly developed innovative digital services, including telehealth, smart chatbots, and distance learning. This digital leadership has enabled companies to build or expand products and services in days, rather than months, and has improved employee and customer experiences. With a strong focus on digital trust, security, and compliance, Singapore is poised to drive economic recovery and set national standards for connected, secure digital capabilities.

site_title: Shortage of homes in Berlin despite rent freeze
summary: Berlin's rent freeze, introduced in October 2020, has led to a significant shortage of homes available for rent, with the number of homes down 42% from last year and those built before 2014 by 59%. Prospective tenants are facing challenges, with multiple inquiries for each apartment and ads often taken down within a day. The situation highlights the difficulties in finding affordable housing in the city, despite efforts to reduce prices by up to 40%.

site_title: Governments may onshore part of biopharma supply chain, but it won't be easy: Panel
summary: Governments worldwide will reassess their biopharma supply chains to ensure supply and mitigate risks amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Policymakers are likely to increase onshoring and diversification, but the process won't be easy due to low labor costs, state subsidies, and easier regulations in countries like China and India. The economic burden of widespread onshoring is a significant issue, and it may not be economical or easy to replicate in the US on a large scale.

site_title: Shares of fruit distributor SunMoon slump amid parent's bankruptcy woes
summary: Shares of SunMoon Food Company, a Singapore-based fruit and seafood distributor, plummeted amid concerns over its parent company's bankruptcy reorganisation in China. The parent company has been under reorganisation for over two months, prompting SunMoon to flag a going concern issue and consider raising funds from investors. The company's shares tumbled in response to the news.

site_title: If SIA needs more cash, it should tap travellers instead of investors
summary: Singapore Airlines should consider selling travel vouchers to customers, allowing them to redeem deeply discounted tickets once international air routes reopen. This would benefit SIA shareholders and bondholders by eliminating dilutive funding. According to Nicolas Van Broekhoven, this idea would be "wildly beneficial" to the airline.

site_title: When doing the right thing is commercially smart as well...
summary: HSBC has set a goal to align its financed emissions to the Paris Agreement's net-zero goal by 2050 or sooner, aiming to facilitate $750-1 trillion in low-carbon finance by 2030. The bank's CEO believes this is both the right and commercially smart thing to do, as 85% of businesses surveyed see environmental sustainability as a priority. HSBC plans to expand its transition finance solutions and invest $100 million in clean technology, while launching a philanthropic program to support climate innovation.

site_title: US edtech fund Owl Ventures takes a shine to S-E Asia
summary: US-based edtech fund Owl Ventures is seeing growing interest from South-east Asian investors in education technology, driven by attractive returns and impact investing. The firm, which has backed startups like Byju's and MasterClass, is looking to invest in the region and encourage its existing portfolio companies to expand. South-east Asian investors, including family offices and sovereign wealth funds, have shown significant interest in Owl Ventures' latest fundraise, with the firm seeing a surge in activity from the region.

site_title: BOE asks banks about readiness for negative rates
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has requested information from banks on their readiness for zero or negative interest rates, following a consideration of implementing such rates if needed. Deputy Governor Sam Woods stated that the BOE aims to understand the implications of these approaches and assess technology challenges. The deadline for banks to respond is November 12. The request is part of the BOE's ongoing review of monetary policy options, which is expected to include an increase in its bond-buying program on November 5 to support Britain's recovering economy.

site_title: UK PM Johnson imposes further Covid-19 curbs on parts of England
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson imposed a tiered system of further COVID-19 restrictions on parts of England, including closing pubs and gyms in areas classified as "very high" alert level. The move aims to standardize existing restrictions and prevent a second national lockdown. Johnson emphasized the need to save lives and avoid an uncontrolled second spike in cases, citing rising infection rates and the impact on the NHS. The system includes shutting pubs and bars, gyms, and other businesses in affected areas, with lawmakers set to vote on the move.

site_title: Listings of pandemic beneficiaries to prolong Hong Kong's IPO boom
summary: Hong Kong's initial public offerings (IPOs) are expected to continue due to the pandemic's boost in research and development investments. The bourse's head of listings, Bonnie Chan, stated that companies from the tech and biotech sectors will likely fill the IPO pipeline in the near future. Listings in Hong Kong have jumped 33% this year, with the exchange anticipating a return of retail and consumer industry listings once the pandemic subsides. The bourse is also implementing changes to streamline the IPO process, including a paperless system and artificial intelligence review of annual reports.

images.alt_text: HKEX's Bonnie Chan says: "We thought 2020 would be a disappointment, but it has turned out to be a busy year. I believe the IPO rush will continue."

site_title: JD Digits hopes to ride on Ant's IPO excitement
summary: JD Digits, a fintech affiliate of JD.com, plans to raise $3 billion to fund its finance businesses and invest in emerging technologies. However, the company faces internal strife and volatile performance. Despite this, JD Digits aims to capitalize on investor excitement surrounding Ant's upcoming IPO, which could boost investor sentiment. The company's prospectus highlights its ambitions in pig-face recognition, cloud computing, and smart-city solutions, but volatility and internal clashes may hinder its success.

site_title: Warehouse landlords biggest gainers of rising e-commerce in Asean: DBS
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's logistics hubs are expected to benefit from the "China+1" strategy, driven by growing e-commerce and shifting manufacturing value chains to South-east Asia. DBS Group Research has identified Mapletree Logistics Trust, Westports, ESR Cayman, Amata, and Thai logistics Reits as "gems" to buy in the Asean logistics industry, citing rising affluence, digital connectivity, and high mobile penetration in the region. The e-commerce market in South-east Asia is expected to grow at a 34% CAGR to reach US$102 billion by 2025, with Indonesia leading the growth.

site_title: The War With Grandpa unseats Tenet from US box office perch
summary: Robert De Niro's comedy "The War With Grandpa" unseated Christopher Nolan's "Tenet" at the US box office, grossing $3.6 million from 2,205 locations. This marks the worst box office opening since 1988, with the exhibition industry facing significant headwinds due to the pandemic. The film's release was delayed after Harvey Weinstein's downfall, and it received a lukewarm response from critics. "The War With Grandpa" now holds the top spot, with "Tenet" bringing in $2.1 million domestically in its sixth week.

site_title: Asian edtech startups seize Covid-19 growth window
summary: Asian edtech startups are seizing the growth opportunity created by the pandemic, with venture capital investments in the region reaching $5.78 billion in 2020, more than three times that of 2019. While mainstream adoption remains a challenge, the pandemic has driven demand for remote learning tools, with some startups experiencing significant growth. Investors are cautiously optimistic about the sector's long-term potential, with many seeing it as a defensive sector that will remain relevant even after the pandemic. However, unit economics and infrastructure challenges remain a concern, and startups are advised to focus on refining their products and monetization models to succeed.

site_title: Age is just a number for Nadal, Federer and Djokovic
summary: Tennis' "Big Three" - Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic, and Roger Federer - continue to dominate the sport with impressive statistics. Nadal won his 13th French Open title, while Djokovic lost to Nadal in the final. Despite Djokovic's disappointment, he remains focused on achieving the historic number one ranking and Grand Slam titles. The "Big Three" have won 57 of the 69 majors since Federer's first Slam triumph in 2003, leaving the young pretenders frustrated with their inability to break through.

site_title: World's largest LNG-powered container ship arrives in Singapore on maiden call
summary: The world's largest LNG-powered container ship, CMA CGM Jacques Saade, arrived in Singapore on its maiden call, marking a new era of sustainable shipping. The 23,000 TEU vessel, the first of nine LNG-powered ships, reduces emissions by 99% for sulphur dioxide and fine-particle emissions, and 85% for nitrogen dioxide emissions. CMA CGM aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050, with plans to add 20 LNG-powered vessels to its fleet by 2022. Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Transport and Foreign Affairs Chee Hong Tat welcomed the vessel, citing the industry's resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: New York's commercial rents are far too high
summary: New York City's commercial rents remain artificially high, hindering the recovery of small businesses. The city and state need to act to lower rents, as they are "sticky" and do not reflect market conditions. Several factors contribute to this, including long-term leases, mortgages with minimum rent requirements, and tax deductions that incentivize landlords to keep rents high. To address this, the state should pass a law voiding minimum-rent terms and the city should use property taxes to incentivize landlords to rent out storefronts.

site_title: Some insurers reviewing products to facilitate stepped border reopenings
summary: Some Singaporean insurers, including NTUC Income, are reviewing travel insurance products to cover COVID-19-related claims, aiming to facilitate the gradual reopening of borders. NTUC Income is developing a travel insurance product for inbound travelers during the pandemic, while Great Eastern currently excludes coverage for the novel coronavirus. The Singapore Tourism Board is also working on a travel insurance product to cover critical coronavirus-related expenses, which could lower premiums and make it more appealing to leisure visitors.

site_title: Innovate, or exit
summary: Singaporean SMEs are increasingly recognizing the value of digitalisation and technology, seeing it as a necessity for survival in the post-pandemic economy. Industry leaders stress that innovation is no longer a luxury, but a necessity, especially with permanent changes in industries and uncertain economic outlook. To innovate, SMEs can start by diversifying into new overseas markets, expanding online channels, and leveraging data to sell digitally. Low-hanging fruits include developing new products based on existing strengths, exchanging ideas with peers, and innovating business processes and digitalising operations. Best practices include embracing collaboration, continuous learning, and customer-centric innovation.

site_title: Stocks exposed to digital economy top performers in Q3: iFast
summary: Digital economy stocks outperformed other sectors in the third quarter of 2020, with the iFast O'Shares Global Internet Giants ETF gaining 14% in Singapore dollar terms. This follows previous quarter's outperformance and is attributed to megatrends such as rising internet adoption and digital disruption. Tech investments continue to outperform, with the MSCI World IT Index up 12.4% in Q3. Despite concerns over elevated valuations, iFast cites strong fundamentals, low interest rates, and Covid-19 resilience as supporting factors.

site_title: Relief period extended for parties unable to fulfil contracts due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore extends relief periods under the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act for parties unable to fulfill contracts due to the pandemic, with extensions ranging from 1 to 5 months. The relief period for bankruptcy and insolvency remains unchanged. The extension applies to seven categories of contracts, including loans to SMEs, leases, and hire-purchase agreements. The deadline to serve a notification for relief has been extended to November 19, 2020, for loans to SMEs, and December 31, 2020, for other categories.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally at the start of the week
summary: Hong Kong shares surged on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 2.20% to 24,649.68, driven by speculation of fresh economic opening moves by President Xi Jinping. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rallied, with gains of 2.64% and 3.31%, respectively. The rally was attributed to anticipation of Xi's upcoming speech, which may include new economic initiatives.

site_title: Travellers from Sabah must serve 14-day SHN; other new measures also announced
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health announced that travellers with recent travel history to Sabah will serve a 14-day Stay-Home Notice (SHN) starting Oct 14. This measure aims to curb the risk of importation and onward local transmission. The new rule applies to all travellers entering Singapore from Oct 14 with a travel history in the past 14 days to Sabah.

site_title: Purpose is the compass for resilience
summary: A business crisis can bring out the best in people, but leadership and a return to personal and organizational purpose are crucial in shaping a shared reality of work. By embracing agility, rethinking business models, and adapting to a purpose-driven approach, companies can survive and thrive. Focusing on a balanced approach for the greater good and creating an environment for people to bring out their best can help companies weather past crises and stay resilient. Effective leadership is key to marrying personal purpose to organizational purpose, and communication, transparency, and action are essential in bringing others along and making meaning.

site_title: Court orders seizure of ransomware botnet controls as US election nears
summary: Microsoft has obtained a court order to seize control of internet protocol addresses hosting Trickbot, a notorious ransomware botnet threatening local government networks ahead of the US election. The malware infects over 1 million computers, allowing operators to install more malicious software, including ransomware, for both criminal and national governments. This move aims to disrupt Trickbot's operations and prevent potential disruption to the November election.

site_title: Stanford economists win Nobel Prize for research on auctions
summary: Stanford University economists Paul Milgrom and Robert Wilson won the 2020 Nobel Prize in economics for their research on auctions, which has been applied to various industries such as mobile-phone frequencies, aircraft landing slots, and renewable energy markets. Their theories have helped design new auction formats for goods and services that are difficult to sell traditionally. The Nobel Prize was awarded due to their innovative work, which has had a significant impact on various sectors and continues to evolve to encompass emerging markets like renewable energy.

images.alt_text: Two Stanford University academics who helped design the US auction that allocates mobile-phone frequencies will share the 2020 Nobel Prize in economics.

site_title: WP chief Pritam Singh calls for universal minimum wage with S$1,300 base
summary: Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh has called for a universal minimum wage of S$1,300 per month for Singaporean workers, citing it as a moral imperative and act of national solidarity. This comes after a workgroup was formed to study raising salaries and well-being of low-income workers, including expanding the Progressive Wage Model. Singh argues that the sectoral approach to minimum wage is too slow, while others, including former MP Walter Theseira, point to the need for more research on the topic.

site_title: India's new bridges may worsen standoff along tense China border
summary: India has opened dozens of new bridges along its disputed border with China, potentially escalating tensions. Eight bridges are in Ladakh province, where India and China have amassed troops, and eight are in Arunachal Pradesh, a region claimed by China. The bridges, built for all-weather access, could facilitate the movement of troops and artillery closer to the border. This move comes after a 2017 military standoff and a recent clash on June 15, resulting in the deaths of 20 Indian troops and an unknown number of Chinese soldiers.

site_title: Thailand to make, supply AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: Thailand has agreed to manufacture and supply AstraZeneca's experimental Covid-19 vaccine, AZD1222, in partnership with Siam Bioscience and Siam Cement. The deal aims to produce over 3 billion doses globally, with the first batch expected to be available in mid-2021. The vaccine will be produced at no profit during the pandemic, and the agreement includes Thailand's largest industrial conglomerate Siam Cement. The deal follows several similar agreements signed by AstraZeneca with companies and governments worldwide.

site_title: Hyflux receives formal expression of interest from US fund manager to invest S$204.78 million
summary: Hyflux, a beleaguered water treatment company, has received a formal expression of interest from US fund manager Strategic Growth Investments (SGI) to invest S$204.78 million. SGI proposes injecting funds as new equity to settle debts and claims, with senior unsecured creditors receiving S$97 million, trade creditors S$15.78 million, and PnP investors S$32 million. The investment also includes up to 15% equity warrants, potentially worth S$196.7 million for senior creditors and S$393.3 million for PnP holders.

site_title: Japan PM Suga's rating falls to 55% in second poll
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's approval rating has dropped to 55% in a second poll, down seven points from the previous survey. The decline comes amid controversy over his rejection of six scholars from a science advisory body, with 47% expressing doubts about his explanation. The government's handling of the coronavirus pandemic received a mixed response, with 54% having a positive view and 40% a negative one. Additionally, 59% of respondents felt the government's decision to relax foreign entry restrictions was too soon.

site_title: Fabchem China proposes acquisition that will result in reverse takeover
summary: Fabchem China has entered a non-binding term sheet to acquire Australian power plant operator Renewable Power Management, resulting in a potential reverse takeover. The acquisition consideration will be satisfied by issuing new shares to investors, with a minimum value of S$22 million. The deal aims to expand Fabchem's businesses and operations, diversifying its financial growth. The acquisition is subject to Singapore Exchange approval and shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Letting virus 'run free' to get herd immunity is unethical, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) chief, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, has warned against allowing the COVID-19 virus to spread in the hope of achieving herd immunity, calling it "unethical." He stated that herd immunity is achieved through vaccination, not exposure, and that relying on natural immunity is "scientifically and ethically problematic" due to the lack of understanding about the virus and its effects on the population. The WHO has never recommended using herd immunity as a strategy for responding to an outbreak, and Dr. Tedros emphasized that allowing the virus to spread is not an option.

site_title: Johnson imposes further Covid-19 curbs on parts of England
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson imposed a tiered system of COVID-19 restrictions on parts of England, including closing pubs and bars in areas on the "very high" alert level. The move aims to standardize restrictions across England, with gyms, leisure centers, and casinos also set to close. The restrictions are in response to rising infections across the north and some southern areas, with healthcare officials warning of an impact on critical care beds. The lockdowns are part of an attempt to save lives and prevent a second national lockdown, with lawmakers set to vote on the move.

site_title: STI begins the week with 0.8% gain
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.77% to close at 2,552.42 on Monday, driven by gains from Sembcorp Industries, ComfortDelGro, and three banks. Analysts expect further liberalization of the Chinese economy to boost regional markets. The STI has rallied for five consecutive days ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 11.92 points to 1,518.43. The market saw a significant decline in volume, with 5.975 billion lots traded at RM 3.824 billion. The losers outnumbered gainers 573 to 498, resulting in a negative market sentiment.

site_title: BOJ ready to ease more, has tools to cushion pandemic pain
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed readiness to ease monetary policies further, citing a relatively robust economy with exports, output, and capital expenditure showing "fairly robust" growth. However, consumption, particularly for services, remains weak due to the ongoing pandemic. Kuroda stated the central bank would closely monitor the pandemic's impact and take additional easing measures if necessary. This comes as Japan's economy is expected to have hit its bottom in April-June, with a general picture looking "much better" than a few months ago.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value up 23% to S$24.3 billion in September
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 23% increase in total market turnover value to S$24.3 billion in September, driven by optimism in improving market conditions and a surge in capital market fund raising. Total funds raised from equity and bond listings rose 63% year-on-year to S$40.8 billion, the highest amount since February. ETF trading also saw significant growth, with the total value reaching S$1.2 billion for the third quarter. Meanwhile, uncertainties ahead of the US presidential election boosted risk-management activity across asset classes.

site_title: Malaysia imposes movement curbs in Kuala Lumpur as virus spreads
summary: Malaysia imposes movement curbs in Kuala Lumpur, administrative capital Putrajaya, and states of Selangor and Sabah due to a surge in coronavirus cases. Restrictions include sports, recreational activities, social events, and closing schools and universities for two weeks starting Oct 14. Social distancing rules and work passes are required for travel between districts. The decision aims to contain the pandemic, with 563 new cases recorded on Monday. Economic activities are permitted as long as distancing rules are followed.

site_title: Chinese electric-car charging provider StarCharge eyes IPO
summary: Chinese electric-vehicle charging equipment provider StarCharge plans to start the process for an initial public offering (IPO), following a Series A fundraising round. The company, which has been profitable for three consecutive years, aims to list on a mainland bourse and has hired Guotai Junan Securities Co to assist. StarCharge provides a range of charging solutions for electric vehicles and has clients including Volkswagen, Hyundai, and BAIC Motor Corp. The move comes as consumer demand for environmentally friendly cars increases, with shares of Tesla and NIO Inc surging this year.

site_title: A collapse of global tax talks could cost US$100b, OECD says
summary: The OECD warned that a collapse in global tax talks could cost the global economy over $100 billion, as nearly 140 countries agreed to continue negotiations until mid-2021. The talks aim to update international tax rules for digital commerce, discouraging big companies from booking profits in low-tax countries. A failure to reach an agreement could lead to a trade war, potentially knocking global GDP back by over 1%. In contrast, new digital taxation rules could increase global corporate income tax by 1.9-3.2%, with a potential annual increase of $50-$80 billion.

site_title: ECB pushes governments to keep up fiscal support for economy
summary: European Central Bank officials urge governments to maintain fiscal support for euro-area economies as they recover from the coronavirus slump, warning against prematurely removing aid. ECB President Christine Lagarde expressed concern that measures such as debt moratoria and state guarantees should be phased out too abruptly. Executive Board member Isabel Schnabel argued that governments shouldn't worry about rising debt levels, while Vice President Luis de Guindos emphasized the need for fiscal policy to be the first line of defence. The ECB has bought large amounts of government debt through its emergency bond-buying programme.

site_title: Civmec bags multiple contracts worth A$175 million
summary: Civmec Limited has secured multiple contracts worth approximately A$175 million. The revenue from these contracts will be realized across its metals and minerals, and oil and gas segments, contributing to a solid base load of activity for its manufacturing facilities. Specific details about three contracts, including a ship loader project for BHP Mitsubishi Alliance, have been disclosed.

site_title: Cruises to nowhere: Genting Cruises get more than 6,000 bookings in 5 days
summary: Genting Cruise Lines has received over 6,000 bookings for its "cruises to nowhere" in just five days, exceeding expectations. The company, along with Royal Caribbean International, is offering round-trip cruises without port stops under a pilot program. Bookings are up 500% compared to the past two weeks, with prices starting from S$359 per person. The cruises, which will take place in November and December, will have safe distancing measures and face mask requirements in place. This move comes as the tourism industry seeks to regain revenue after the coronavirus outbreak.

site_title: Etiqa Insurance Singapore names new chief executive
summary: Etiqa Insurance Singapore has appointed Raymond Ong Eng Siew as its new chief executive officer, effective October 16. Ong, a Singaporean, brings experience as group chief risk officer at Great Eastern Life Assurance, where he oversees risk management and compliance. He succeeds interim CEO Yip Kim Chee, who took over from Sue Chi Kong after 14 years. Ong's appointment is seen as a strategic addition to bolster Etiqa's capabilities.

site_title: China's Xi to deliver speech in Shenzhen marking its 40th anniversary
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to deliver a speech in Shenzhen to mark the 40th anniversary of the city's establishment as China's first special economic zone. Hong Kong's Carrie Lam postponed her annual policy address and plans to attend the event instead. No meeting with Xi is scheduled.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend rally for eighth day on US stimulus hopes
summary: South Korean shares rose for an eighth consecutive day, with the Kospi index ending 11.77 points higher, or 0.49%, at 2,403.73. The benchmark closed at its highest level since September 18. The rally was driven by hopes of US stimulus, as the Trump administration urged Congress to pass a stripped-down coronavirus relief bill.

site_title: 64-year-old man dies of Covid-19 complications, the first such fatality in 3 months
summary: A 64-year-old Singaporean man, with a history of hypertension, has died from Covid-19 complications, marking the first such fatality in 3 months. The permanent resident, who had worked in India, returned to Singapore on September 23 and was confirmed to have the coronavirus infection on October 4. He was the 28th patient to die from the virus in Singapore.

site_title: MinLaw extends contract relief periods; OTPs for commercial, industrial properties included
summary: The Ministry of Law (MinLaw) in Singapore has extended contract relief periods under the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, providing temporary relief from certain legal and enforcement actions for various contract categories. Relief periods are being extended by one to five months, depending on the category. OTPs and SPAs for commercial and industrial properties are now covered by the Act, with updated terms for the repayment scheme for rental arrears. The extended relief periods aim to support individuals and businesses adjusting to the economic impact of the pandemic.

images.alt_text: For event and tourism-related contracts as well as OTPs with property developers, the last day to serve a notification is now Dec 31.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's MAS and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have introduced virtual shareholder meetings in the post-Covid era. Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing announced enhancements to ESG support schemes to aid business recovery in the retail sector. The retail sector faces challenges, with 40% of available jobs being PMET roles. MAS extended low-cost funding to banks and finance companies to support SME lending until September 30, 2021. Digital economy stocks outperformed in Q3, and warehouse landlords are expected to benefit from growing e-commerce in Asean. The STI closed 0.77% higher on its first day of the week.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How Gen Z youth can save and invest smartly earlier (Ep 81)
summary: A survey by SingSaver found that Singaporean Gen Z youth (18-23) are savvier with their savings habits than millennials (24-39). 85% of Gen Z respondents started saving before age 22, compared to 41% of millennials. Gen Z youth also tend to stick to their budgets "often" and "very often", with 65% compared to 56% of millennials. The survey also highlighted the ease of investing in the digital age, with robo-advisors, internet banking, and app-based stock trading making it accessible to start investment journeys earlier.

site_title: British Airways chief executive Cruz steps down: company
summary: British Airways CEO Alex Cruz steps down with immediate effect, replaced by Aer Lingus boss Sean Doyle as non-executive chairman. The move aims to emerge stronger from the COVID-19 pandemic, which has devastated air travel demand. New IAG CEO Luis Gallego praised Cruz for his efforts in modernizing the airline and securing restructuring agreements with employees.

site_title: Singapore open to virtual shareholder meetings in post-Covid times: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) are open to allowing hybrid and fully virtual shareholder meetings if they are carried out effectively, according to MAS's deputy managing director Ong Chong Tee.
