MAS and SGX RegCo will closely monitor the experiences of issuers and investors, ensuring effective shareholder engagement, proper verification of attendees and voters, and secure voting processes. Companies can continue to conduct general meetings via alternate means until June next year.

site_title: AusGroup unit awarded five-year scaffold and insulation services contract in Thailand
summary: AusGroup, a subsidiary of AusGroup Corporation, has been awarded a five-year scaffold and insulation services contract with Esso (Thailand) Public Company at its Sriracha Refinery in Laem Chabang, Thailand. The contract will utilize AusGroup's existing Laem Chabang maintenance hub, providing specialist scaffolding and insulation services. CEO Shane Kimpton described the award as a major milestone for AusGroup's South-east Asian operations, positioning the company for specialist multi-disciplinary services in the region.

site_title: BuildTech Asia Digital Series to take place virtually on Oct 14-15
summary: The inaugural BuildTech Asia Digital Series will take place virtually on October 14-15, showcasing the region's latest construction products, services, and technological innovations. The event will feature over 100 global brands across five exhibit profiles and include free webinars, tech talks, and networking through an interactive platform. Sphere Exhibits, a subsidiary of Singapore Press Holdings, is co-organizing the event with the Singapore Institute of Building Limited, aiming to support the construction industry despite the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: France must avoid general lockdown by all means, Castex says
summary: France Prime Minister Jean Castex warned against another general lockdown due to a "very strong" resurgence of Covid-19. He urged the public to wear face coverings, minimize contacts, and follow basic sanitary measures to avoid infection. Castex emphasized the importance of keeping businesses open and children in school. His comments come as France faces a growing Covid-19 crisis, but he declined to rule out additional restrictions if necessary.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: Europe's top stock markets opened mixed on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.2% to 6,004.72 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.2% to 13,082.71 and 4,955.32 points respectively. The mixed performance was attributed to rising COVID-19 cases and Brexit concerns, with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson set to announce a new three-tiered alert system for coronavirus cases in England.

site_title: UK risks losing its most robot-proof jobs to Covid
summary: The UK risks losing jobs that are resilient to automation due to the Covid-19 crisis, which has created temporary work opportunities in sectors such as supermarkets and residential care. However, these jobs face a high risk of replacement by new technology in the future. The Royal Society for Arts report highlights that technology could accelerate the disruption of the labor market, exacerbating the impact of the pandemic. The UK government has announced new support for jobs in coronavirus hot spots, but experts warn that the government's response may not be enough to mitigate the effects of automation.

site_title: Swiping right: Slim pickings for Pakistan's online daters
summary: Pakistan's online dating scene is limited due to the country's conservative culture and Islamic laws, where arranged marriages are the norm. Many women choose to remain anonymous, making it difficult for men to find serious matches. The government has also banned popular dating apps, including Tinder and Grindr, due to concerns over content moderation. Despite this, some users have found success through alternative apps and by using virtual private networks (VPNs) to bypass the ban. Many view online dating as a way to avoid arranged marriages and find love on their own terms.

site_title: SAP users face cost squeeze, pressure to digitalise -survey
summary: SAP users face significant challenges, with nearly three-quarters experiencing sharp declines in revenue and over four-fifths feeling pressure to digitally transform due to the pandemic. A survey of SAP's German-speaking user community found that cost and complexity are major deterrents to upgrading to cloud hosting. SAP's new CEO, Christian Klein, acknowledged these challenges and announced improvements to integration and flexibility in payment terms to support clients in economic difficulty.

site_title: Deliveroo to bring on more speciality stores for its new grocery service
summary: Deliveroo is expanding its new grocery delivery service in Singapore with the addition of specialty store brands, including Blu Kouzina Mart, Ryan's Grocery, and Kuriya Japanese Market. The service, launched in October 2020, aims to provide customers with easier access to grocery products amid the pandemic. Deliveroo has also partnered with Marks & Spencer to offer over 800 grocery products in the central business district, Orchard, and eastern area of Singapore.

site_title: Australian state premier had secret relationship with China-linked politician
summary: Australian NSW Premier Gladys Berejiklian revealed a secret "close personal relationship" with politician Daryl Maguire, who is under investigation for business dealings with China. The relationship began in 2015, and Maguire had once called Berejiklian his "numero uno." Despite her admission, Berejiklian said she had "not done anything wrong" and would continue to serve as premier. The NSW Independent Commission into Corruption (ICAC) is investigating Maguire's pursuit of business deals with China between 2012 and 2018.

site_title: Irish locals show their colours in Biden's ancestral home
summary: In Ballina, Ireland, thousands of miles from the White House, a pop-art portrait of US presidential candidate Joe Biden stands tall, symbolizing his ancestral roots. Biden's distant relatives, including third cousin Laurita Blewitt, proudly support his candidacy, citing their shared Irish heritage. The town's residents, who have twinned with Scranton, Pennsylvania, where Biden was born, are thrilled to see one of their own bidding for the presidency. Biden's ancestral ties to Ireland have been a long-standing tradition, with many US politicians, including John F. Kennedy and Barack Obama, claiming Irish heritage to leverage "soft power" in international relations.

site_title: Hong Kong scientists say anti-microbe drug successful against coronavirus
summary: Hong Kong scientists have successfully tested an anti-microbial drug, ranitidine bismuth citrate (RBC), against the coronavirus in Syrian hamsters, showing it to be a potent anti-SARS-CoV-2 agent that lowers viral load by tenfold. The affordable and safe drug, commonly used to treat stomach ulcers, has potential as a COVID-19 treatment. Researchers suggest other metallodrugs may also have anti-viral properties, warranting further exploration. This discovery offers a promising alternative to existing treatments, which have drawbacks such as high cost and immunosuppression effects.

site_title: Mitsui & Co to sell all stakes in coal-fired power plants by 2030: CEO
summary: Mitsui & Co, a Japanese trading house, plans to sell its remaining stakes in coal-fired power stations by 2030 to achieve its 2050 net zero emission target. CEO Tatsuo Yasunaga stated that the company will shift from coal to gas to reduce carbon emissions. This move comes as firms worldwide move away from coal to cut emissions and slow climate change. Mitsui's energy assets will decline due to the launch of liquefied natural gas projects in Mozambique and arctic Russia.

site_title: Hong Kong leader postpones policy speech to attend meeting in Beijing
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam postponed her annual policy speech due to a scheduling conflict with Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Shenzhen. The speech was originally set for Wednesday, but Lam was ordered to attend meetings with central government officials in Beijing. The decision was made to avoid a potential clash between the two events.

site_title: The threat of cyber attacks
summary: A cyber attack in Germany is suspected to have caused a patient's death due to delayed treatment, highlighting the threat of cyber attacks. A 2020 report found that 45% of APAC executives experienced a breach or failed a compliance audit, with the highest concern in Singapore. Despite this, some respondents claimed to be "not at all vulnerable" to internal threats. However, security spending has increased, with 47% of Asia-Pacific organizations planning to spend more on data security in the upcoming year, and Indonesia having the highest percentage of increased spending at 68%.

site_title: Standard Chartered seeks brokerage licence in mainland China: Xinhua
summary: Standard Chartered's Hong Kong unit has applied for a brokerage licence in mainland China, following Beijing's removal of foreign ownership caps on securities firms. The China Securities Regulatory Commission accepted the application on October 10, allowing the bank to set up a securities firm in the mainland. This move comes as the UK-headquartered bank seeks to further develop its onshore business. The application is part of StanChart's efforts to expand its presence in China despite recent political uncertainties affecting its Hong Kong operations.

site_title: More than 900 Singapore Airlines A-380 lunches sold out in half an hour
summary: Singapore Airlines' Restaurant A380@Changi dining experience sold out over 900 seats in 30 minutes, with all places taken. Customers unable to book were invited to join a wait list, now closed. The airline will reopen the wait list for a limited time starting from 6pm on October 12 for interested customers.

site_title: Gold retreats from three-week high on stronger US dollar
summary: Gold retreated from a three-week high on Monday, falling 0.1% to $1,928.06 per ounce, as the US dollar strengthened. Despite hopes for a new US coronavirus aid package, the dollar index rebounded slightly, weighing on gold. US gold futures rose 0.4% to $1,934.10. The dollar's increase was attributed to a rebound in the dollar index, according to Margaret Yang, a strategist.

site_title: Top Glove mulls dual listing on Hong Kong bourse
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, is considering a dual primary listing on the Hong Kong bourse, in addition to its existing listings in Singapore and Malaysia. The proposed listing, which could raise over US$1 billion, aims to increase the company's visibility on a larger and more active stock exchange. If undertaken, the listing will enable Top Glove to expand its global presence and liquidity.

site_title: Singapore welcomes maiden arrival of world's largest LNG-powered containership
summary: Singapore welcomed the maiden arrival of the world's largest LNG-powered containership, CMA CGM Jacques Saade, at the CMA CGM-PSA Lion Terminal. The 23,000 TEU vessel, the first of nine LNG-powered vessels, marks a new era of sustainable shipping. LNG reduces emissions by 99% for sulphur dioxide, 85% for nitrogen dioxide, and 20% for carbon dioxide. The vessel's maiden voyage amid the Covid-19 pandemic showcases the resilience of the maritime industry, with CMA CGM aiming to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.

images.alt_text: Singapore on Monday welcomed the maiden arrival of the CMA CGM Jacques Saade, the world's largest containership to be fully-powered by LNG, at the CMA CGM-PSA Lion Terminal.

site_title: Morgan Stanley gets just what it wanted in Eaton Vance
summary: Morgan Stanley has completed its acquisition of Eaton Vance for approximately $7 billion, surpassing its goal of managing $1 trillion in assets. The deal brings Morgan Stanley Investment Management to $1.2 trillion in assets under management. The acquisition fits Morgan Stanley's vision, with Eaton Vance's asset mix and culture aligning with its goals. CEO James Gorman sees the deal as a strategic move to diversify the business and create recurring income. The acquisition is part of a broader trend in the asset management industry, with consolidation expected as market forces shift towards low-fee passive funds.

site_title: Biggest North Pole mission returns from 'dying Arctic'
summary: The German Alfred Wegener Institute's Polarstern ship has returned from a 389-day mission to the North Pole, bringing back devastating proof of a dying Arctic Ocean. The team of scientists from 20 countries gathered data on the effects of global warming, witnessing the dramatic effects of melting sea ice and predicting an "ice-free Arctic" in a few decades. The mission's findings have been backed up by US satellite images showing record-low summer sea ice in 2020, and the team is now analyzing 150 terabytes of data to develop models for predicting climate-related events.

site_title: Hot stock: Fruit distributor SunMoon slumps amid parent's bankruptcy woes
summary: SunMoon Food Company, a Singapore-listed fruit and seafood distributor, saw its shares slump 17.5% to 3.3 cents after its parent company was placed under bankruptcy reorganisation in China. The board has raised concerns about the company's ability to continue as a going concern and is exploring options to raise funds from investors. SunMoon has formed an executive committee to manage the company's day-to-day operations and has taken over management from the previous team.

site_title: Novel coronavirus survives 28 days on glass, currency, Australian researchers find
summary: Australian researchers found that the SARS-COV-2 virus, which causes Covid-19, can survive on smooth surfaces like banknotes and glass for up to 28 days at 20 degrees Celsius, outlasting the flu virus, which survives for 17 days. This highlights the need for frequent cleaning and handwashing to combat the virus.

site_title: Oil prices extend slide as US producers restore output post-hurricane
summary: Oil prices dropped for a second straight session, falling 0.8% to US$42.53 a barrel for Brent crude and 0.7% to US$40.30 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate. US producers restored output after Hurricane Delta weakened, while a strike in Norway came to an end. The US energy sector added oil and natural gas rigs for a fourth week in a row, despite the storm's impact on offshore operations.

images.alt_text: Oil prices dropped for a second straight session on Monday as US producers began restoring output after Hurricane Delta weakened, while a strike that had affected production in Norway came to an end.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts like Kimly for its attractive dividends, strong food-delivery orders
summary: Singapore's coffee shop operator Kimly is a "buy" given its attractive dividends, strong food-delivery orders, and set to benefit from acquisitions, analysts say. The company's lower price point and heartland presence will appeal to customers, and its cash-generative business will allow for more acquisitions and higher dividends. Analysts UOB Kay Hian and RHB have initiated coverage with a "buy" call and target prices of S$0.36 and S$0.32, respectively, as Kimly's shares rose 5.7% to trade at 28 cents.

images.alt_text: Delivery orders have become a new core revenue stream for Kimly, and also mitigated the drop in direct outlet sales, said RHB.

site_title: Close to 3,600 opportunities available in retail sector in Singapore: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore reported that over 3,600 job opportunities were offered by more than 650 retail companies since April 2020, with 70% being full-time positions. The majority (40%) are professional, managerial, and executive (PMET) roles, while the remaining 60% are non-PMET positions.

site_title: MAS extends low-cost funding to banks, finance companies to support SME lending
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has extended its low-cost Singapore-dollar facility for six more months, from April 1, 2021, to September 30, 2021. The facility, which has disbursed S$5.7 billion since April, aims to support lending to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by banks and finance companies. The extension aims to provide continued support to the SME sector, which has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Britain's hospitality industry sets legal challenge to lockdown restrictions
summary: The UK's hospitality industry is challenging the government's lockdown restrictions, arguing that no evidence supports the measure. The Night Time Industries Association (NTIA) filed a judicial review, claiming the restrictions will have a "catastrophic impact" on late-night businesses. The move comes as British Prime Minister Boris Johnson prepares to announce new measures to contain a growing coronavirus crisis in Northern England. The NTIA claims an insufficient financial support package exacerbates the issue, and the industry will fight to prevent lockdown measures from being imposed.

site_title: Digital economy the top-performing equity exposure in Q3: iFast
summary: Digital economy stocks led the way in Q3, with the iFast Global Internet Giants ETF gaining 14% in Singapore dollar terms. Despite initial losses due to market volatility, digital economy companies continued to outperform, with tech investments up 12.4% in the MSCI World IT Index. The sector's growth is attributed to rising internet adoption, digital disruption, and sustained revenue growth. Asian markets, particularly South Korea and India, also performed well, while markets susceptible to risk-off sentiments, such as Thailand and Indonesia, lagged behind.

site_title: Broker's take: Top Glove's ESG risks to fall on strong balance sheet, automation investments, says Maybank KE
summary: Top Glove Corporation, the world's largest rubber glove manufacturer, is facing ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) risks but analyst Lee Yen Ling from Maybank KE believes these risks will decrease over time due to the company's strong balance sheet and investments in automation. Top Glove has made improvements in its labor practices and compliance with international ESG standards, including paying migrant workers and expanding their living spaces. The brokerage maintains a "buy" rating on Top Glove with an unchanged target price of RM9.53, citing record profit and revenue figures in its latest quarter.

site_title: China's Qingdao orders city-wide Covid-19 testing following new infections
summary: Qingdao, China, has ordered city-wide Covid-19 testing for its 9 million population after new cases linked to a hospital treating imported infections were reported. The city reported six confirmed cases and six asymptomatic cases on October 11. The National Health Commission reported 21 confirmed cases nationwide, excluding Qingdao. This measure aims to prevent painful lockdowns and maintain economic stability. Qingdao has already locked down the hospital and surrounding buildings, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in mainland China to 85,578.

site_title: Chinese investment bank CICC launches Shanghai offering
summary: Chinese investment bank CICC plans to sell up to 458.59 million A-shares, worth around US$1 billion, through a Shanghai offering to raise fresh capital for expansion. The secondary listing comes as China steps up restructuring its capital markets to fund economic growth and technological innovation. CICC has hired lead underwriters Orient Securities and China Galaxy Securities for the sale, which will start preliminary price consultation on October 20.

site_title: Thailand to focus on boosting consumption, liquidity: new finance minister
summary: Thailand's new finance minister, Arkhom Termpittayapaisith, has outlined the country's focus on boosting domestic consumption and liquidity to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic's economic impact. The government will introduce measures to support businesses, increase spending, and accelerate public spending. Tax breaks are planned to add 120 billion baht to the economy, and the ministry will speed up government spending, including a delayed 400 billion baht budget. Long-term measures include reopening the economy to foreign tourists to help it continue to expand next year.

site_title: AC Ventures targets new US$80m Indonesian startup fund
summary: AC Ventures, an Indonesia-focused venture capital firm, has completed the first close of a planned US$80 million technology investment fund, raising US$56 million. The fund will invest in 30 early-stage startups in e-commerce and financial technology over the next three years. AC Ventures, established in 2019, will have a strategic alliance with Indies Capital and plans to make initial investments of up to US$3 million in each startup.

site_title: Biopharma supply chain may be partly onshored, but it won't be easy: GIC event panel
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has exposed vulnerabilities in the global biopharmaceutical supply chain, prompting policymakers to review their strategy and management to ensure supply and mitigate risks. The panel discussion at GIC Insights suggests that onshoring and diversification of supply chains may be necessary, but reversing decades of globalization will be challenging due to low labor costs, state subsidies, and easier regulations in countries like China and India. The economic burden of widespread onshoring remains an issue, and companies are expected to streamline operations and strengthen supply chain processes to increase resilience in case of future pandemics.

site_title: Battery maker EVE Energy may buy more lithium, cobalt before prices lift
summary: EVE Energy, a Chinese lithium-ion battery producer, is considering purchasing more lithium and cobalt amid signs of a price recovery in China. Chairman Liu Jincheng said the company is weighing its metal purchasing plans as it seeks to expand output and narrow the gap with top battery makers. Prices of lithium and cobalt have stabilized in recent months, with forecasts indicating a potential rise in the fourth quarter. EVE Energy aims to secure future supply needs through partnerships, acquisitions, or mergers, citing industry consolidation and the need for a distinctive edge in products.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on October 12, 2020, due to profit-taking despite US rallies, as investors closely watched the US presidential election campaigns. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.14% to 23,586.13, while the Topix index fell 0.12% to 1,645.36.

site_title: Tesla battery supplier LG Chem forecasts record Q3 profit
summary: LG Chem, a South Korean electric vehicle battery supplier, forecasts a record-breaking Q3 profit of 902 billion won (S$1.07 billion), exceeding analysts' estimates by 159%. The company attributes the upbeat outlook to orders from Tesla and the coronavirus pandemic, which lifted demand for petrochemical products. Revenue is expected to rise 9% to 7.5 trillion won. Despite this, LG Chem shares fell 2.3% due to concerns over fire risks associated with its battery cells for Hyundai's Kona electric vehicles.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.26% to 23,558.69, and the Topix index slipping 0.24% to 1,643.35, driven by profit-taking despite US rallies. Investors closely watched the US presidential election campaigns. The decline was attributed to the US presidential election campaigns, with investors seeking to lock in gains before the elections.

site_title: Enhancements to ESG support schemes to bolster business recovery: Chan
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing announced enhancements to support schemes for businesses in Singapore to aid their recovery from the pandemic. Funding support for the Market Readiness Assistance Grant and Enterprise Development Grant will be increased to up to 80% until September 2021, while the Temporary Bridging Loan Programme and Enhanced Enterprise Financing Scheme for Trade Loans will be extended for six months. The government aims to help businesses pivot to new products and markets, and retailers must adjust to new consumer behavior and create unique selling propositions to be competitive.

site_title: CEOs rediscover the family dinner table
summary: CEOs have rediscovered the importance of family dinners during the pandemic, as they spend more time at home with their families. Decades of research have shown that regular family meals benefit children and parents alike, including improved vocabulary, grades, and stress management. Executives like John Foley, Homayoun Hatami, Sara Blakely, Ethan Brown, and Sallie Krawcheck have credited family dinners with helping their children become more mature, resilient, and confident. These busy individuals have adapted to the new normal by prioritizing family time, creating new routines and rituals, and sharing more of their work and personal lives with their children.

site_title: Singapore-Indonesia reciprocal green lane applications to open on Oct 26
summary: Singapore-Indonesia reciprocal green lane applications will open on October 26, allowing travel to commence shortly after. The move follows concluded negotiations between the two countries' foreign ministries. Operational details, including health protocols and application procedures, will be announced later. This development aims to facilitate smoother travel between the two nations, although specific details remain to be revealed.

site_title: World Bank still investing billions in fossil fuels, study shows
summary: The World Bank continues to invest billions in fossil fuels despite its pledge to combat climate change. A study by German environmental lobby group Urgewald found the bank spent over $2 billion on fossil fuel projects in the past two years, with $10.5 billion invested over the last five years. The World Bank claims to have stopped financing upstream investments in oil and gas in 2019, but critics argue it continues to support fossil fuel expansion. This contradicts the bank's goal to provide clean, reliable, and affordable energy to hospitals and critical health facilities.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks slip on Monday morning
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.47 points, or 0.8%, to 1,517.88 on Monday morning, with 235 losers surpassing 230 gainers. The market saw a lower volume of 571.1 million lots worth RM185.1 million.

site_title: Sustainability in the spotlight
summary: The DBS Foundation Social Impact Prize competition, held in Singapore, received almost 800 applications from 63 countries to identify sustainable business solutions addressing social problems. Four finalists were selected, with StratifiCare winning S$75,000 as the grand prize winner and Sampangan taking S$25,000 as the People's Choice winner. The competition aims to support scalable and enterprising business solutions that address crucial social issues, with the goal of promoting sustainability and social impact.

site_title: Razorpay raises US$100m in Series D round co-led by GIC: TechCrunch
summary: Razorpay, a Bangalore-based fintech startup, raised US$100 million in Series D financing co-led by Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC and Sequoia India, valuing the company at over US$1 billion. Existing investors Ribbit Capital, Tiger Global, Y Combinator, and Matrix Partners also participated in the round. This funding round follows Razorpay's growth in the payment processing industry, solidifying its position as a major player in the market.

site_title: Japan bank lending slows as easing pandemic sees big firms pay back loans
summary: Japan's bank lending rose at a slower annual pace in September, mainly due to easing pandemic-related funding strains among big borrowers. However, lending by regional banks remained high as smaller firms continued to borrow heavily. Large companies that borrowed during the pandemic's uncertainty phase are now paying back loans, according to the Bank of Japan. The data underscores the lingering economic pain caused by the health crisis.

site_title: Warehouse landlords rank among biggest gainers of growing e-commerce in Asean
summary: Warehouse landlords in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) are expected to be the biggest gainers as growing e-commerce fuels a strategic shift in manufacturing and logistics value chains to South-east Asia. A DBS Group Research report named Mapletree Logistics Trust, Westports, ESR Cayman, Amata, Hemaraj Reit, and WHA Premium Reit as "gems" to buy within the Asean logistics industry, citing the region's rising affluence, sizeable young population, and high digital connectivity as growth drivers. The e-commerce market in South-east Asia is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 34% to reach US$102 billion by 2025.

images.alt_text: Growth drivers for Asean's logistics sector include the region's rising affluence, sizeable young population, as well as high digital connectivity and mobile penetration.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking Wall Street; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.2% on Monday, tracking Wall Street's gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,536.87. The benchmark index gained 3.91 points, with 83 gainers outnumbering 40 losers. Local banks DBS and UOB rose, while OCBC increased, while Sembcorp Marine declined. The gains followed a strong week on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq registered their biggest weekly percentage gains since July.

site_title: Teo Ho Pin joins Tiong Seng board as independent director
summary: Construction company Tiong Seng Holdings has appointed 60-year-old former Singapore politician Teo Ho Pin as an independent director, effective October 15. Dr. Teo brings a strong public service leadership track record and expertise in implementing green and smart city initiatives. His appointment increases the number of independent directors to three. This move comes after the company's former CEO and executive director Pek Lian Guan and director Pay Teow Heng relinquished their roles amid corruption charges.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the week on a positive note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.41% to 24,217.25. This follows gains in New York, fueled by hopes for a new US stimulus package. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.47% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.78%. The gains come despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and concerns over the impact of new Trump threats on global stocks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Tiong Seng, Pollux Properties, Incredible Holdings
summary: UOB plans to issue A$500 million of senior unsecured floating rate notes due in 2023. Tiong Seng Holdings announced the addition of independent director Teo Ho Pin to its board. No other significant developments were reported for the mentioned stocks.

site_title: Ensuring cognitive diversity in boardrooms
summary: Singapore's corporate boards lack diversity, with most companies failing to meet the minimum diversity standards set by the Singapore Institute of Directors and Willis Towers Watson. The inaugural Singapore Board Diversity Index found that nearly half of listed companies have no women on their boards, and only 11% of board seats are held by women. The index also showed that age and tenure diversity are lacking, with a third of directors between 60-70 years old and nearly a quarter with more than 9 years of tenure. To address this, companies should focus on achieving more diverse representation, including cognitive diversity, and critically review their board compositions.

site_title: Hong Kong bankers are losing their jobs to mainland China rivals
summary: Hong Kong's investment banking industry is experiencing a shift as mainland Chinese rivals gain a majority of senior jobs, with locals now holding only about 30% of roles. Mainlanders account for 60% of investment banking jobs, and 10% are filled by overseas nationals. The trend is attributed to a reluctance among Chinese firms to hire and promote Hongkongers after anti-government protests in 2019 and a decline in pay packages for senior roles. The shift has significant implications for Hong Kong's financial hub status, with international firms considering moving operations to the mainland.

site_title: Covid and taxes eat away at diesel's edge over gasoline in India
summary: India's diesel consumption has trailed gasoline's rebound since the Covid-19 lockdowns eased, as trucks remain idle amid a softer economy. Despite diesel being double gasoline in fuel sales, the uneven demand recovery has created a challenge for refiners, who are expected to focus on producing more gasoline and petrochemicals. The government's push for cleaner fuels in public transport and the country's goal to convert its railway network to electricity by 2024 are also driving the shift. Refiners, such as Reliance Industries and Indian Oil Corp, plan to diversify and reduce their dependence on transport fuels.

site_title: US energy companies begin restoring oil and gas output after hurricane
summary: US energy companies have begun restoring oil and gas output after Hurricane Delta made landfall on the US Gulf Coast. Chevron, Royal Dutch Shell, and BHP Group are restarting operations at storm-swept production facilities, with BHP expecting to complete the return of workers to its platforms on Sunday. As of Sunday, 91% of offshore crude oil production and 62.2% of natural gas output remain shut due to the storm, affecting about 17% of US oil production and 5% of natural gas production.

site_title: White House seeks limited coronavirus relief bill, promises further talks on broader stimulus
summary: The Trump administration has proposed a limited coronavirus relief bill using leftover funds from an expired small business loan program, as negotiations on a broader package stall. The proposal aims to reopen the Paycheck Protection Program, which would enable businesses to keep employees employed. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and White House Chief of State Mark Meadows urged Congress to vote on the legislation, which would total around $130 billion. The move comes as the US economy struggles to recover from coronavirus-related shutdowns.

images.alt_text: In a letter to lawmakers, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin and White House Chief of State Mark Meadows said they would continue to talk to Senate Democratic leader Chuck Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to try to reach agreement on a comprehensive bill.

site_title: Hong Kong's bourse sees Covid firms prolonging boom in IPOs
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange expects a prolonged boom in initial public offerings (IPOs) due to the pandemic's boost in research and development investments. Companies from the technology and biotechnology sectors are expected to continue filling the IPO pipeline. Listings in Hong Kong have jumped 33% this year to HK$220 billion, with the exchange's shares surging 47% so far in 2020. Ant Group's planned dual listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai, worth US$35 billion, is expected to be approved, and the bourse anticipates a return of listings from the retail and consumer industries once the pandemic subsides.

site_title: US sanctions turn up heat but Huawei can still serve European 5G clients
summary: US sanctions on Huawei are hindering its access to semiconductors, but the Chinese telecom giant can continue to serve European 5G network clients, according to Huawei's vice-president Abraham Liu. Despite Google's ban on providing technical support for new Huawei phone models using Android, Huawei is looking for a solution to help its 90 million European users. The US is "blackmailing" chipmakers into shunning ties with Huawei, which denies US allegations of spying. Despite this, Huawei remains confident in its ability to serve European customers with advanced technology.

site_title: UOB to issue A$500m of senior unsecured floating rate notes due 2023
summary: UOB has priced A$500 million of senior unsecured floating rate notes due 2023 at a coupon rate of 3-month Australian bank bill swap reference rate plus 46 basis points per annum. The notes are expected to be rated AA- by Standard & Poor's and will not be listed. The bank secured a benchmark size for the notes with anchor investors before opening it to broader participation. UOB's head of central treasury unit Koh Chin Chin attributed the cautious investor sentiment to market uncertainties ahead of the US presidential election, citing the transaction structure as a prudent approach to the market.

site_title: China funds targeting Ant IPO rake in 60b yuan from over 10m investors
summary: China's five newly launched funds targeting Ant Group's IPO raised 60 billion yuan (S$12.1 billion) from over 10 million retail investors, selling out within days. The funds' distributor reported an average of eight investors placing orders each second, highlighting the retail frenzy despite possible US sanctions. The successful fund sales could boost Ant's growing wealth management business, which saw revenue jump 56% in the first half of 2020. Ant aims to raise $35 billion in its dual listing in Hong Kong and Shanghai's Star Market, expected in October.

site_title: TikTok rival Triller explores deal to go public: sources
summary: Triller, a social media app rival to TikTok, is in talks to go public through a merger with a blank-check acquisition company, according to sources. The deal would come as TikTok faces uncertainty over its future due to US government concerns about data access. Triller aims to capitalize on TikTok's woes, seeking to raise around $250 million in a private fundraising round. The company has secured $100 million at a valuation of $1.25 billion and is deliberating whether to proceed with the deal or SPAC negotiations.

site_title: India infections top 7m as Trump gets back on campaign trail
summary: India reported over 7 million coronavirus cases as US President Donald Trump resumed his campaign trail nine days after contracting Covid-19. Globally, governments struggle to manage a sharp rise in infections and growing public frustration over new restrictions. The pandemic enters a second deadly wave, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Thai luxury hotels opening in pandemic bet on 5-star quarantine
summary: Thailand is opening luxury hotels with a new visa aimed at attracting high-spending tourists who seek five-star quarantine. The visa, set to launch this month, will allow tourists to stay at least 90 days, including a 14-day quarantine, in luxury hotels. This move is expected to benefit luxury hotels such as the Four Seasons and Kempinski, which are set to open soon. The government hopes the plan will generate around 1.2 billion baht (S$52.5 million) in revenue, but critics argue it won't be enough to make up for lost revenue and that tax measures targeting middle- to high-income Thais would be more effective.

site_title: On-off stimulus hopes may keep markets on their toes
summary: US stocks rose sharply last week, reaching their highest levels since summer, driven by hopes for a second round of stimulus. The proposed $1.8 trillion stimulus by President Donald Trump has boosted markets, despite concerns about a potential leg down after the elections. Economists expect a second round of stimulus checks and loans by year-end, despite uncertainty over a bipartisan relief bill. The stock market's performance has been influenced by shifts in consumer behavior, including a flight from cities and a growing housing market.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines 'ready to shut down if restructuring talks fail'
summary: Malaysia Airlines is prepared to shut down if restructuring talks with leasing companies about a plan fail. The airline's CEO, Izham Ismail, stated that a "sizeable" number of creditors support the plan, but more are needed. The airline's financial situation remains uncertain, and the CEO warned that a failure to reach an agreement could lead to the airline's closure.

site_title: Beyond crisis management, SBF focuses on helping firms go digital and abroad
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) is shifting its focus from crisis management to digitalization and internationalization, aiming to help firms go digital and abroad. Under new chairman Lim Ming Yan, the SBF is launching a new business-to-business digital marketplace, setting up four regional offices, and facilitating international partnerships. The organization believes digitalization is crucial for growth in a post-Covid world, while internationalization is still possible despite rising protectionist sentiments. The SBF aims to support Singaporean businesses through its GlobalConnect@SBF initiative and build ties within the Asean region, promoting growth and job creation.

site_title: Tennis: King Nadal continues Paris reign with record-equalling 20th Slam
summary: Rafael Nadal won his record-equalling 20th Grand Slam men's singles title at the French Open, defeating Novak Djokovic 6-0 6-2 7-5 in the final. The match was one-sided, with Nadal adapting well to the indoor conditions and Djokovic struggling with his first serve and unable to come up with a Plan B. Nadal's 13th title on clay at Roland Garros was a dominant performance, with Djokovic saying "he's phenomenal" and "played a perfect match". The win ties Nadal with Roger Federer for the most Grand Slam titles, with Djokovic left to regroup after his third final loss to Nadal at Roland Garros.

site_title: Dollar drops as investors focus on probability of coming US Covid-19 relief
summary: The US dollar dropped against a basket of world currencies due to optimism over forthcoming US novel coronavirus relief, despite ongoing wrangling in Washington over pandemic aid. Investors focused on the probability of a bigger stimulus package, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi continuing talks. Markets are up on hope for fiscal stimulus, but communication from Washington has become erratic. The dollar index fell 0.58% as the euro rose 0.54% and the Japanese yen strengthened 0.40% against the greenback.

site_title: KLCI outperforms FTSE STI
summary: The FTSE Straits Times Index (FTSE STI) has been surpassed by the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCI) in terms of performance since 2008. Despite experiencing significant declines during the 1997 Asian financial crisis and 2008 global financial crisis, the KLCI has shown resilience and has outperformed the FTSE STI. The index is currently in the third wave of a supercycle phase, with a potential rebound expected after a minor correction.

site_title: Healthway Medical Corporation deputy CEO builds stake
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation's deputy CEO, Abram Suhardiman, acquired 30.5 million shares at 3.2 cents per share, increasing his stake from 0.19% to 0.86%. This follows his previous acquisition of 8.452,900 shares on September 29. Suhardiman now oversees the company's operations and corporate support functions.

site_title: Task force to study how to raise wages of low-income workers
summary: A new task force in Singapore aims to study and implement a progressive wage model to raise the wages of low-income workers, with the goal of boosting productivity growth. The task force, formed by Manpower Minister Josephine Teo and NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng, will explore partnerships with companies to achieve this goal. The initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to improve working conditions and living standards for low-income workers.

site_title: Harvard Business School, LSE grads to mentor 350 students
summary: Harvard Business School and the London School of Economics and Political Science have partnered to mentor 350 students from Singapore's polytechnics, NTU, and SIT through their initiative, which has previously benefited over 1,000 students. The program aims to provide guidance and support to students in their academic and professional journeys.

site_title: Can Razer sharpen its strategy?
summary: Razer, a gaming accessory and laptop company, is attempting to expand its audience beyond gamers to cater to those in their 20s and 30s. The company aims to offer investment and insurance products, as well as a digital bank for youth. Despite its efforts, Razer's stock has fallen 47.4% since 2017, and investors remain uncertain about its future strategy.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Oct 5)
summary: Singapore's aviation sector is facing uncertainty, with the future of Can SIA, the country's airline, hanging in the balance. The sector has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Deborah Ho, managing director and head of SEA Blackrock, is weighing in on the situation, but no specific details or conclusions are mentioned in the provided articles. The articles instead cover various financial topics, including market trends and investment strategies, but do not provide any information on the aviation sector's current state.

site_title: China aims to cool yuan's surge by reducing cost of shorting
summary: China's central bank has removed rules requiring financial institutions to set aside cash when buying foreign exchange for clients through currency forwards, aiming to cool the yuan's surge. The move, effective Monday, reduces the cost of shorting the currency and is seen as an effort to restrain the yuan's rally. The yuan surged 1.6% on Friday, its strongest level since April 2019, and is now up about 4.5% against the dollar in the past three months.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market reached new highs for the year, peaking at $34,896, before shedding value to $29,479 by the end of the week. The Panamax market gained $56 to return at $1,439, while the Atlantic market benefited from tight north Continent tonnage counts and solid demand for minerals and grains. The Supramax/Ultramax market remained subdued due to Chinese holidays, but saw increased activity in the Indian Ocean. Handysize rates declined initially but recovered in the second half of the week, while VLCC rates remained static.

site_title: News on travel talks between Singapore, Australia welcomed
summary: Australia is exploring plans to extend its travel bubble to include Singapore, following talks between the two nations. The Australian Chamber of Commerce, Singapore (AustCham) welcomed the news, citing the importance of business travel between the two countries. A recent survey found 90% of businesses polled would use a travel corridor between Singapore and Australia, with 95% considering travel to Australia essential. Meanwhile, the Johor government is reportedly working on a plan to reopen its border with Singapore.

site_title: UK data centre market continues to grow despite Brexit worry
summary: The UK data centre market continues to grow despite Brexit concerns, with record levels of construction, space uptake, and size contracts. London's data centre market added 145 megawatts of capacity in 2019 and is expected to end the year with 67 additional megawatts of capacity compared to the previous year. Industry experts say that concerns about companies relocating to Europe due to Brexit are unfounded, with demand driven by enterprise cloud and software-as-a-service utilities, e-commerce, and social networking. The UK remains the largest market in Europe for colocation data centres, and Ireland is proving competitive.

site_title: New York's luxury hotels welcome last-minute locals as jet set stay away
summary: New York's luxury hotels are experiencing a surge in bookings from local residents, as international tourists and American guests are deterred by the city's strict coronavirus measures. The Pierre, a 90-year-old hotel, has seen a significant decrease in occupancy, with only 25% of its 400 workers employed. Many hotels in the city are operating at reduced capacity, with some 200 closed and 140 converted into temporary housing for first responders and homeless individuals. The tourism downturn has been severe, with hotels generating significantly less revenue and a substantial number of workers laid off.

site_title: Saudi lender NCB agrees to buy rival Samba for US$15b
summary: National Commercial Bank (NCB) agreed to buy Samba Financial Group for $15 billion, valuing Samba at 55.7 billion riyals. NCB will offer 0.739 new shares for each Samba share, a 3.5% premium over Samba's closing price. The combined bank will have assets over $220 billion and a market capitalization of $46 billion.

site_title: ECB launches public consultation, starts trials on creating 'digital euro'
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has launched a public consultation and started trials to explore the possibility of creating a "digital euro" for the 19-nation eurozone. The digital euro would be an electronic version of euro notes and coins, allowing individuals to have deposits directly with the ECB and making payments "fast, easy and secure". The ECB aims to decide on the project by mid-2021, with estimates suggesting it could take 18 months to three years to implement. The move aims to complement cash, not replace it, and address concerns about private cryptocurrencies and the rise of digital payments.

site_title: Hawkers United divided in bitter stakeholder spat
summary: Singapore's popular hawker Facebook group, Hawkers United (HU), has split due to an internal clash over ownership and direction. The group, launched in April 2020, had amassed over 280,000 members and spawned three spin-offs. Founder Melvin Chew attempted to register HU with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) but was beaten to it by lead administrator Jill Sara. The dispute led to a bitter public fallout, with both sides accusing each other of trying to monetize the group's name. The split has left the future of HU uncertain, with options including continuing as a community effort or maximizing commercial potential under a different name.

site_title: South Korea and Jakarta to ease Covid curbs
summary: South Korea and Jakarta are easing COVID-19 curbs, starting Monday. South Korea will relax social distancing rules, allowing nightspots to reopen and spectators to attend sports events with limited capacity. Jakarta will implement a two-week "transitional" period, allowing non-essential businesses to operate at 50% capacity and dine-in customers to be limited to 50% of restaurants. The moves come as daily infections in South Korea have fallen into the double-digit range, and Jakarta seeks to ease restrictions after a surge in cases.

site_title: Trump says he now wants a bigger stimulus than Democrats offering
summary: President Donald Trump said he wants an even bigger stimulus package than the Democrats' $2.2 trillion proposal, contradicting his earlier stance. Trump's negotiators had prepared a $1.8 trillion offer, which was set to be discussed with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. The proposal faces skepticism from Republicans, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stating there isn't enough time before the election to bridge the differences. A deal's passage is uncertain, with lawmakers facing a tight schedule and Republican lawmakers expressing skepticism about a large package.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump said he wants an even bigger stimulus than what Democrats have offered so far, seeming to undercut his own negotiators, who had prepared a US$1.8 trillion offer to make to House Speaker Nancy Pelosi today.

site_title: Hyflux asks Utico to address concerns raised by various creditor groups
summary: Hyflux has asked its suitor Utico to address concerns raised by creditor groups before a virtual townhall for Hyflux's perpetual securities and preference shares investors. Utico had requested a townhall, but Hyflux's independent director Lau Wing Tat wants Utico to first clarify its plan to address concerns before the meeting. Utico claims majority P&P investors have accepted its proposal, but the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) has not endorsed the offer based on its current terms.

site_title: Suga takes the baton
summary: Japan's new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is expected to focus on digital transformation, accelerating the country's economic growth and competitiveness. Experts hope for policy changes that support small and medium-sized companies, flexible and remote work, and a more welcoming environment for foreign talent. The administration should also prioritize cyber strategy and defense capabilities, and strengthen ties with Asia, particularly China, South Korea, and India, while maintaining its relationship with the US. Additionally, there is a desire to see targeted fiscal policy to reduce Japan's high public debt and stronger structural reforms to promote investments and lift growth.

site_title: Trump got 'unusual' payments from Las Vegas hotel in 2016, NYT says
summary: Donald Trump received $21 million in "highly unusual" payments from his Las Vegas hotel in 2016, during a time his presidential campaign struggled financially, according to the New York Times. The payments, made through a company with no clear business purpose, could potentially violate tax or campaign finance laws. The discovery comes after the Times reported that Trump paid only $750 in federal income taxes in 2016 and 2017. The Trump Organization has not commented on the matter.

site_title: South-east Asian merchants embracing livestream sales
summary: Livestream sales have seen significant growth in South-east Asia, with a 306% year-on-year increase in e-commerce gross merchandise value (GMV) from January to June. In the second quarter, 67% of retailers used live-selling techniques, with the Philippines leading the pack at 60% adoption. Consumers in Vietnam and the Philippines made more frequent purchases through live-selling, with median transaction intervals of 3-3.1 days. The trend is attributed to the pandemic and mall closures, with live-selling expected to remain a key sales channel in the region.

images.alt_text: The use of livestreaming to sell products has ballooned in South-east Asia this year, according to a survey of regional businesses.

site_title: Time for independent directors to redefine themselves by standing up for investors
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust's directors were arrested on "reasonable suspicion" of breaching disclosure requirements, raising concerns about the independence of independent directors (IDs) in Singapore's Reit market. The arrests of three current and two former IDs have sparked debate about whether IDs are being used to justify transactions favoring controlling shareholders over minority investors. Sabana Reit's attempt to justify the independence of one of its IDs has also come under scrutiny, highlighting the need for IDs to redefine themselves by standing up for small investors. The incident has led to questions about the quality of Reit listings in Singapore and the need for improved corporate governance.

site_title: Winter is coming for the world's airlines
summary: The world's airlines are facing a severe crisis as winter approaches, with many struggling to stay afloat due to the ongoing pandemic. Despite initial hopes for a recovery, the industry is likely to not recover without significant help from governments. Airlines such as EasyJet and Cebu Air are seeking state support, while others are raising funds through bonds and restructuring. The International Air Transport Association predicts airlines will burn through $77 billion in cash by December, with no return to pre-Covid traffic levels until 2024. Governments may need to restructure, nationalize, or liquidate failing airlines, or loosen ownership restrictions to prevent further collapse.

site_title: Trump backs revoking tariff exemption for some solar panel imports
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a proclamation supporting the revocation of an exemption for some imported double-sided solar panels, and increasing the planned tariff rate to 18% for 2021 from 15%. The move aims to safeguard domestic production, as the domestic industry has started to increase production and market share. However, bifacial panels will not be excluded from the tariffs, which Trump believes will limit the effectiveness of the measure. The decision comes after solar farm developers sued to maintain the exemption initially granted by the Trump administration.

site_title: UK data centre market continues to grow despite Brexit worry
summary: The UK data centre market continues to grow despite Brexit concerns, with London's market adding 67 megawatts of capacity in 2020, exceeding expectations. Industry experts and firms, such as TechUK and CBRE Group, attribute this growth to record expansion in 2019 and the increasing demand for enterprise cloud and software-as-a-service utilities. The UK remains the largest market in Europe for colocation data centres, with Ireland and Dublin emerging as competitive alternatives, driven by taxation benefits and subsea cable access to the US.

site_title: Fearing Biden tax hikes, wealthy Americans rush to change estate plans
summary: Wealthy Americans are rushing to change their estate plans due to concerns that a potential Democratic win in the US presidential election could lead to tax hikes under President Joe Biden's plan. The exemption of up to $11.58 million for estate and gift taxes could be cut to $5.49 million, prompting individuals to set up trusts and revise existing ones before year-end to avoid 2021 tax consequences. The Biden campaign has stated that the candidate's intent is to benefit the middle class, but wealthy individuals remain uncertain about the outcome of the election and its impact on their finances.

site_title: 10 new Covid-19 cases confirmed, none in the community
summary: Singapore reported 10 new Covid-19 cases on Oct 11, with none in the community. Seven cases were imported, including work permit holders from Malaysia and the Philippines. Three locally transmitted cases were also reported, all linked to a worker's dormitory. The number of community cases decreased, with zero new cases for the second consecutive week. A total of 57,690 patients have recovered, with 44 still in hospital and 100 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Singaporeans mainly unconcerned with foreign workers, poll shows
summary: A majority of Singaporeans (55%) are neutral or positive towards foreigners, with almost half (47%) not mentioning any issues, according to a government poll. The poll found that those who are unemployed are more likely to feel negative towards foreigners. This comes as Singapore faces its worst recession in history and soaring unemployment, with online rhetoric against overseas workers increasing. The government has taken steps to promote hiring of locals and tightened employment pass rules for foreigners.

site_title: Task force to study how to raise wages of low-income workers
summary: A task force will be formed in Singapore to study ways to raise wages of low-income workers, with the goal of expanding the progressive wage model and increasing productivity. The Tripartite Workgroup on Lower Wage Workers will be established to partner with companies and explore other approaches to improving wages and well-being of lower-income workers. The effort is seen as beneficial, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, and aims to ensure continued wage growth in sectors with mandatory progressive wage models.

site_title: Robinhood users say accounts were looted, no one to call
summary: Robinhood users are reporting that their accounts have been looted due to unauthorized transactions, with some experiencing losses of up to $10,000. The company claims that the issue is due to cybercriminals compromising users' personal email accounts, which are associated with their Robinhood accounts. Robinhood has stated that it is actively working to secure affected accounts, but customers are frustrated by the lack of a customer service phone number and the slow response time. Authorities, including the SEC and FINRA, have been contacted, but no further information has been released.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines to shut down if restructuring plan fails: report
summary: Malaysia Airlines is at risk of shutting down if its restructuring plan fails to gain support from lessors, according to the airline's CEO. A group of leasing companies has rejected the plan, leaving the carrier with a 50-50 split on backing the proposal. The airline aims to achieve break-even by 2023 and needs a fresh cash injection from its shareholder, state fund Khazanah Nasional, to proceed. If lessors do not back the plan, Malaysia Airlines may be forced to shut down or shift its air operator's certificate to a new airline under a different name.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines will have to shut down if its lessors decide not to back its latest restructuring plan, the chief executive of the airline's parent group was quoted as saying on Saturday.

site_title: Australia reports no Covid-19 deaths for third day, hotspot faces longer lockdown
summary: Australia reported no COVID-19 deaths for a third consecutive day, but the city of Melbourne faced a prolonged lockdown due to 14 new cases in Victoria. The two-week average of new cases increased to 9.5, exceeding the target of fewer than five cases needed to ease restrictions. Premier Daniel Andrews stated it's unlikely to lift restrictions soon, citing the need for caution to avoid repeated lockdowns. Australia's nationwide tally exceeds 27,200 infections and 897 deaths.

site_title: Marks & Spencer rolls out supply chain programme to avoid excessive food waste
summary: Marks & Spencer is rolling out a supply chain programme to reduce excessive food waste, following a disappointing Christmas season in 2020 where high levels of waste impacted profit margins. The programme aims to optimize food sales and minimize waste, a move in response to the retailer's record food sales despite profit margins being dented by waste. This initiative follows a previous year's Christmas performance that was ruined by excessive food waste.

site_title: Australia in travel talks with Singapore, Japan, South Korea as coronavirus cases ease
summary: Australia is in talks with Singapore, Japan, South Korea, and South Pacific nations to reopen travel as coronavirus cases ease. The country has managed to contain the outbreak better than others but is facing a second wave in Victoria. Prime Minister Scott Morrison has spoken with counterparts in the mentioned countries, while Foreign Minister Marise Payne held talks in Singapore. Australia reported 19 new cases on Sunday, with 12 in Victoria, and one fatality, taking the total Covid-19 death toll to 898.

site_title: UK urged to do more to open up tax havens to public scrutiny
summary: The UK has been urged to do more to open up tax havens to public scrutiny, following recent developments in the British Virgin Islands and Cayman Islands. The British Virgin Islands, a major hub for money laundering and tax evasion, has finally established a public register to show the real owners of shell companies, two years after a UK anti-money laundering amendment became law. However, activists say more needs to be done, and concerns remain that the move will have little effect, with the Cayman Islands having been removed from the EU's blacklist of tax havens despite criticism from aid and development charity Oxfam.

site_title: GIC chief warns 'divisive trends' to stay for years
summary: Singapore's GIC chief Lim Chow Kiat warns that "divisive trends" in economics, technology, and geopolitics will persist for years, requiring investors to be nimble to remain profitable. He also cautions that large government interventions to combat the pandemic are not long-term solutions. This assessment comes as the world undergoes significant changes, necessitating a re-imagination of the future.

site_title: Indonesian police nab thousands protesting new law, Antara says
summary: Indonesian police detained thousands of protesters against the newly passed omnibus law, which critics say erodes labor rights and environmental protection. The law aims to boost investments by cutting red tape. President Joko Widodo defended the bill, attributing the protests to "disinformation." 3,862 people were detained, with 145 testing positive for the coronavirus. Indonesia continues to struggle with the pandemic, with over 320,000 confirmed infections and 11,677 deaths.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest nine suspected of helping 12 held in China
summary: Hong Kong police arrested nine people suspected of helping 12 Hong Kong activists who fled to Taiwan and were intercepted by Chinese authorities. The 12 are accused of crimes tied to anti-government protests in Hong Kong last year and are being detained in Shenzhen. Authorities seized HK$500,000 in cash and documents related to the boat purchase. The detainees' case has raised international concerns, with families denied access to independent lawyers. The 12 will be represented by mainland lawyers chosen by Chinese authorities.

site_title: Critics see gap in BlackRock's climate rhetoric and record
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, has faced criticism for the gap between its climate change rhetoric and actions. Despite pledging to prioritize climate change in January, the company supported only 13% of shareholder proposals on environmental issues in 2020, down from 20% in 2019. Environmentalists argue that BlackRock has failed to translate its commitment into fast-enough or bold-enough action, particularly in its voting record on climate change resolutions.

site_title: Taiwan president calls for 'meaningful dialogue' with China
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen called for "meaningful dialogue" with China, extending an olive branch amid heightened military tension. China claims Taiwan as its sovereign territory, while Taiwan seeks equal dialogue. Tsai emphasized maintaining stability in the Taiwan Strait, but prioritizes strengthening Taiwan's armed forces. The US supports Taiwan's modernization, with no formal diplomatic ties. China has cut off talks since 2016, and there was no immediate reaction to Tsai's statement.

site_title: Pompeo warns of China risks ahead of US-India talks
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo warned of China's growing threat to India, urging closer US-India ties amid diplomatic efforts. Pompeo stated that China has amassed forces against India in the north and the US has built a coalition to counter the threat. Following Tokyo meetings, Pompeo will travel to New Delhi with Defence Secretary Mark Esper to discuss defence ties. Tensions between India and China remain high following violent clashes in Ladakh in June, with India banning Chinese apps. The US and India are expected to discuss boosting defence cooperation during Pompeo's visit.

site_title: More landed homes sold in Q3 as buyers seek to guard wealth
summary: In Q3 2020, Singapore's landed home market saw its highest quarterly figure since 2018 Q2, with 544 properties sold, more than doubling the previous quarter's 212. This surge was attributed to a lower-for-longer rates environment and lockdown easing, allowing buyers to snap up landed homes. The sales figure surpassed the previous record of 775 landed homes in Q2 2018.

site_title: Microsoft to let most employees work remotely for up to half their weekly working hours
summary: Microsoft announced it will allow most employees to work remotely up to half their weekly working hours, providing flexibility even after offices reopen. The software-maker, with approximately 163,000 full-time employees, is not committing to having every employee work remotely. Returning to office is optional for most employees for now. This move is part of Microsoft's efforts to balance work flexibility with business needs.

site_title: Trump back to campaigning as his doctor says he is no longer a transmission risk
summary: US President Donald Trump returned to campaigning after a week-long absence due to COVID-19, despite his doctor stating he is no longer a transmission risk. Trump took a test on Saturday showing no evidence of the virus, but medical experts say the timeline for his return to public events may have been rushed. Trump's speech at the White House touched on election issues and sparked criticism for not wearing a mask, potentially exposing supporters to the virus.

site_title: K-pop titan BTS's online concert draws global fans
summary: BTS held an online concert, "Map of The Soul ON:E", due to South Korea's social distancing curbs, allowing fans worldwide to participate via chatroom and light sticks. The virtual event followed the group's cancellation of in-person shows and world tours. The concert featured BTS's latest English single "Dynamite", which topped the Billboard Hot 100 chart, and messages of empowerment and comfort to fans. The event highlighted the group's global influence and connection with their fans, with some fans expressing emotional connections to the music during the pandemic.

site_title: Fed's Bullard says enough resources with expected labour rebound
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis President James Bullard stated that sufficient resources are available to support the US economy through the end of 2020 as the job market rebounds. Unlike the 2008 crisis, most pandemic-era layoffs are temporary, with up to 85% being recalled. Bullard expressed optimism that unemployment levels will decrease rapidly if temporary workers are recalled, even if Congress delays fiscal stimulus. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is set to discuss a $1.8 trillion economic stimulus package with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rack up second week of gains, Pandora leaps
summary: Europe's stocks rose for a second consecutive week, with the Stoxx 600 index gaining 2.1% as companies like Pandora and Novo Nordisk reported strong sales and earnings forecasts. Investors remained optimistic about US stimulus despite rising COVID-19 cases, with global equities advancing. Key movers included Rolls Royce, British Airways, and Zalando, which rose 13.2%, 17.2%, and 3.2%, respectively. Despite concerns about economic decline, analysts believe equities will continue to rise due to loose monetary policy and global stimulus.

site_title: Chinese app to vault over Great Firewall blocked
summary: A Chinese app, Tuber browser, backed by 360 Security Technology, was blocked and removed from mobile stores in China. The app allowed users to bypass Beijing's Great Firewall and access blocked sites, including Google and Facebook, without using a virtual private network (VPN). The app's removal came after users celebrated their newfound ability to access blocked content on social media platforms. The identity of the agency responsible for the removal was unclear. The Tuber browser's functionality ceased on Saturday afternoon.

site_title: The Philippines' biggest IPO since 2016 raises 25.3b pesos
summary: Converge ICT Solutions, a Philippine broadband operator, has raised 25.3 billion pesos (S$709 million) through its initial public offering (IPO), the country's largest since 2016. The company priced 1.51 billion shares at 16.8 pesos apiece, near the low end of its marketed range. This marks a significant milestone for the Warburg Pincus-backed company, which aims to expand its services in the Philippines.

site_title: What's next for Golden Mile Complex?
summary: The 16-storey Golden Mile Complex in Singapore is proposed for conservation due to its architectural and historical significance. The URA has announced planning incentives to support adaptive reuse and commercial viability, including bonus floor area and development charge waivers. However, this may impact the building's chances of a successful collective sale, with some owners potentially reluctant to sell due to the conservation plan. Experts weigh in, citing challenges in finding space for additional development and the potential for a higher price tag, but also noting that conservation can attract buyers and make the site more appealing to developers.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: US should try to delay IPO of China's Ant Group, says Senator Rubio
summary: Senator Marco Rubio calls on the US government to delay China's Ant Group's initial public offering (IPO), citing concerns over the company's ties to the Chinese Communist Party and potential exposure of US investors to fraud. Rubio's remarks follow pressure from China hardliners in Congress and the administration to sanction Ant before its listing later this month. The IPO, worth up to $30 billion, has raised national security concerns and could give the Chinese government access to sensitive banking data belonging to US citizens.

images.alt_text: Senator Marco Rubio, who has successfully urged the Trump administration to pursue investigations of Chinese companies, called on Friday for the US government to consider options to delay an initial public offering (IPO) for China's Ant Group, the fintech arm of Chinese e-commerce firm Alibaba.

site_title: Trump to resume campaigning; second debate cancelled
summary: US President Donald Trump will resume in-person campaigning on Saturday after a COVID-19 case, but a second presidential debate against Joe Biden has been cancelled due to Trump's refusal to participate. Trump will address supporters from a White House balcony and then travel to central Florida, a crucial state in the November 3 election. The cancellation of the debate follows a similar event in 2020, where Trump also refused to participate in the first debate.

site_title: Oil prices slip over 1% after Norway oil worker strike ends
summary: Oil prices slipped over 1% on Friday after a 10-day strike in Norway ended, boosting crude output. Brent futures fell to $42.85 a barrel and US WTI crude fell to $40.60 a barrel. Despite the decline, oil prices gained 9% for the week, their first increase in three weeks. The strike had threatened to cut Norway's oil and gas output by 25%. The US also experienced disruptions due to Hurricane Delta, which halted most oil production in the Gulf of Mexico.

site_title: US dollar dips on stimulus optimism, bets on Biden victory
summary: The US dollar fell to three-week lows on Friday due to optimism over a potential US stimulus deal and increased expectations of a Democratic victory in the presidential election. The dollar index dropped 0.5% to 93.05, its lowest since September 21, as investors bet on a larger economic package. The euro rose 0.6% to $1.1825, while the Japanese yen strengthened against the dollar. A Democratic victory is expected to lead to a larger stimulus, negatively impacting the US dollar, and boosting currencies affected by the trade war.

site_title: China's Xi says intends to deepen relations with North Korea: KCNA
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has expressed his intention to deepen relations with North Korea, citing the country's efforts to engage with foreign nations despite hardships. The statement was made in a congratulatory message to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un on the 75th anniversary of the ruling Workers' Party of Korea. Xi praised North Korea's achievements in recent years, while also acknowledging the strain on its economy due to strict border closures and US sanctions. The move comes after a period of improved diplomatic relations between China and North Korea, including a meeting between Xi and Kim in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: China funds targeting Ant IPO rake in 60b yuan from over 10m investors
summary: China funds targeting Ant Group's upcoming IPO raised 60 billion yuan (S$12.12 billion) from over 10 million retail investors, selling out within days. The funds, launched on September 25, aimed to invest up to 10% of their assets in Ant's IPO shares. Despite possible US sanctions, the successful fund sales could boost Ant's rapidly growing wealth management business, which saw a 56% revenue jump during the first half of 2020.

images.alt_text: Five newly launched Chinese funds targeting Ant Group's upcoming mega stock listing raised 60 billion yuan (S$12.12 billion) cumulatively from more than 10 million retail investors, selling out within days, the funds' distributor said.

site_title: Gold jumps 1% as US dollar slides on stimulus bets
summary: Gold prices rose 1% on Friday, reaching $1,920.92 per ounce, as the US dollar slid to a near three-week low amid increased bets for US stimulus. The move is seen as a hedge against likely inflation, with investors seeking bullion as a safe-haven asset. The US dollar's decline, coupled with a widening lead for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden, has made gold cheaper for those holding other currencies, further fueling the rally.

site_title: White House blocked CDC from requiring masks on public transportation
summary: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) drafted a sweeping order requiring all passengers and employees to wear masks on public and commercial transportation in the US, but it was blocked by the White House. The order, aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus, would have applied to airplanes, trains, buses, and subways. The White House Coronavirus Task Force declined to discuss the order, with some task force officials saying that mask mandates should be left to states and localities. This decision has been criticized by public health officials and transportation workers, who argue that masks are an effective way to protect against the spread of the virus.

site_title: US: Wall Street finishes up as stimulus talks continue
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq registering their biggest weekly percentage gains since July, driven by optimism over a potential federal fiscal aid package. Despite talks between US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin failing to reach agreement, a new proposal from Mnuchin sparked market optimism. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6%, and the S&P 500 gained 0.9%, with technology shares leading the way, while the Nasdaq Composite added 1.4%.

site_title: Organisers cancel Oct 15 US presidential debate
summary: The Commission on Presidential Debates cancelled the October 15 US presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden due to Trump's refusal to participate in a virtual format. Trump had previously tested positive for the coronavirus, prompting the commission to convert the debate to a virtual event. The final debate will now take place on October 22 in Nashville, Tennessee.

site_title: No impact likely on prices for projects nearing completion from government's further relief measures
summary: Singapore property developers will not face significant price impacts from the government's six-month extension of project completion deadlines due to Covid-19 disruptions. Most projects nearing completion are already majority sold and unlikely to face completion delays, with some projects ahead of schedule. Consultants expect minimal price pressure due to rebounding demand after the pandemic and sufficient buffer time for developers to clear inventory.

site_title: Investment sales reviving for Singapore commercial property, GCBs: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's investment sales market for commercial properties and Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) is reviving, with significant transactions recorded in Q3.
