Despite a 55.1% year-on-year decline in overall investment sales to S$4.4 billion, commercial assets saw a 96.4% quarter-on-quarter increase to S$3.3 billion. The residential sector, particularly GCBs, showed resilience, with investment sales climbing 143.6% quarter-on-quarter to S$636.2 million. The market is expected to see increased demand in the coming months, driven by foreign investors and low interest rates.

site_title: US, AstraZeneca strike deal for Covid-19 antibody treatment touted by Trump
summary: The US government has awarded AstraZeneca $486 million to develop and secure up to 100,000 doses of a Covid-19 antibody treatment under Operation Warp Speed. The treatment, a monoclonal antibody cocktail, aims to prevent Covid-19 in high-risk populations. The deal comes after President Trump was treated with a similar antibody drug and has touted its benefits. AstraZeneca plans to evaluate the treatment in two studies, and the US government expects to provide over 1 million free doses of antibody treatments to Covid-19 patients.

site_title: China's services sector recovery gathers pace in September
summary: China's services sector activity recovered for a fifth consecutive month in September, with the Caixin/Markit services PMI rising to 54.8, the highest since June. Hiring increased for the second month, driven by domestic demand, while new export businesses contracted further. The services sector accounts for 60% of China's economy and half of urban jobs. Analysts expect China to be the only major economy to mark positive annual growth in 2020, at decades-low levels.

site_title: Twitter will turn off some features to fight election misinformation
summary: Twitter has taken steps to combat election misinformation by temporarily altering its features, including giving users a timeout before retweeting and adding a label to claims about election winners until authoritative sources verify them. The changes aim to slow the spread of false information and promote accuracy on the platform.

site_title: Australia central bank warns of business failures as property vacancies rise
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia warns of rising business failures, particularly in commercial property, as work-from-home arrangements lead to empty offices and retail precincts. The outlook for commercial property is bleak, with banks' impairment rates expected to climb and some indebted landlords struggling to meet debt repayments. Retail commercial property is seen as the most vulnerable sector, with economists predicting a further rise in unemployment to 10%. This follows a 7% contraction in the Australian economy in 2020 and a rise in unemployment to nearly 7%.

site_title: Reits (October 10-11, 2020)
summary: Key real estate news includes a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore prime projects, Manhattan rents reaching a record, and UK homebuyer demand rebounding to a six-month high. US mortgage rates climbed after five straight weeks of declines, while Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul. Additionally, New World Development is selling China property assets and WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore. These developments indicate ongoing market fluctuations and shifting demand for luxury properties.

site_title: Malaysian firms turn to private placements to raise funds
summary: Malaysian firms are turning to private placements to raise funds as demand for public listings of bonds and stocks wanes, with 151 deals in the first nine months of 2020, up 25% from 2019. This comes as the nation's export-driven economy contracted amid the pandemic, putting a strain on corporate earnings and cash flows. Companies such as Top Glove and Dialog Group have raised RM110.32 million and RM161.48 million respectively through private placements, while banks have cut back on lending, making private placements a more attractive option for cash-strapped corporates.

site_title: Govt boosts telemedicine, allows more approved chronic diseases to be subsidised
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Health has expanded its telemedicine scheme, allowing patients with stable chronic conditions to receive video consultations covered by government subsidies and Medisave. This move aims to reduce the need for in-person physical examinations while maintaining care. The scheme initially covered seven chronic conditions, but has now been expanded to cover all approved chronic diseases. Healthcare professionals must undergo telemedicine e-training to provide these consultations, and patients must still visit the clinic for physical consultations as needed. The temporary extension will continue until the Public Health Preparedness Clinic scheme is deactivated.

site_title: Petronas Gas, Top Oil to benefit as colder winter will raise demand for fuel: Maybank KE
summary: Malaysia's Petronas Gas and Thailand's Top Oil are expected to benefit from a possible increase in demand for fuel due to a colder winter, according to Maybank KE. Crude prices have risen by 4% on a week-on-week basis due to supply disruptions, including a Norwegian oil workers' strike and a Gulf of Mexico hurricane. This increase in demand could lead to higher profits for these companies, but the article does not provide further details on the expected impact.

site_title: ERP charges to go up by S$1 at six CTE gantries from Oct 12
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) will increase Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) fees at six CTE gantries starting Oct 12 by S$1. This decision follows monitoring of traffic conditions, which showed optimal speeds on most expressways except for the CTE during peak hours. The LTA aims to manage traffic congestion and generate revenue. The increase will take effect on October 12, affecting motorists driving on the affected CTE sections during peak hours.

images.alt_text: This comes as more people return to work, resulting in localised congestion at certain locations along the CTE during peak periods, said LTA.

site_title: PwC Singapore launches scheme to help foreign startups enter South-east Asia
summary: PwC Singapore has launched the Scale Programme to help foreign startups expand into South-east Asia. The five-day programme includes hands-on masterclasses, mentorship, and networking sessions. Participants will gain access to a pipeline of new customers, marketing channels, and professional networks. The programme aims to get startups pitch-ready, with mentors providing insights on growth strategy, sales, marketing, and fundraising. Other professional service firms in Singapore offer similar programmes, requiring startups to have a validated product and approach Series A funding.

images.alt_text: PWC Singapore has launched a five-day programme to help foreign startups expand into South-east Asia.

site_title: Gold yo-yos together with Trump's infection and awaits US fiscal stimulus package
summary: Gold prices recovered from initial declines after US President Donald Trump tested positive for Covid-19, with traders awaiting a fiscal stimulus package. However, Trump's announcement to call off stimulus talks sent prices plummeting. The news was later rescinded, and gold futures are expected to close the week on a stronger note as pandemic relief negotiations in Washington continue. Geopolitical tensions between Azerbaijan and Armenia also boosted gold prices to nearly two-week highs.

site_title: Taking pre-order route creates certainty in a pandemic
summary: Fashion designer Gin Lee's Singapore-based label, Ginlee Studio, introduced pre-orders at the start of a new season to reduce waste and become more sustainable. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the label shifted to pre-orders in early May, which accounted for 80% of orders during the "circuit-breaker" period. The strategy has been deemed effective in creating certainty and reducing uncertainty around product availability. Experts believe pre-ordering will become a trend in retail, allowing customers to configure their orders and co-create products with manufacturers.

site_title: The best animal feeds from around the world
summary: A study found that watching footage of cute animals can reduce anxiety, blood pressure, and heart rate. Various live animal feeds from around the world, such as quokkas, puppies, kittens, and wildlife, can elicit positive emotions like adoration, awe, and love. The Internet has made it easy to access these feeds, providing a connection to the natural world and promoting health and happiness.

site_title: LSE seals 4.33b euro Borsa sale to Euronext, Italian banks
summary: The London Stock Exchange (LSE) has agreed to sell Borsa Italiana to Euronext and two Italian lenders for over 4.33 billion euros, creating the largest listing venue in Europe. The deal, expected to close in the first half of next year, addresses EU competition concerns and will give Euronext a quarter of all equity trading in Europe. The sale will also allow LSE to secure EU approval for its US$27 billion Refinitiv deal.

site_title: New CPFIS fee caps should mean better investment outcomes
summary: The introduction of fee caps on CPFIS investments, effective October 1, 2020, aims to improve investment outcomes for CPF members. Sales fees are now zero, and wrap fees have been reduced to 0.4%. However, concerns remain about distributors' incentives, which may lead to higher trailer fees for lower-cost funds. To mitigate this, investors should search for diversified and low-cost funds, ask about associated fees, and consider fee-only advisers who are incentivized to serve clients' best interests.

site_title: Why (and how) I plan to die with an empty bank account
summary: A growing number of individuals, including ultra-wealthy individuals like Laurene Powell Jobs and Bill Gates, are reevaluating their financial priorities and opting to spend their money on meaningful experiences and investments in their lifetime rather than leaving a legacy. Author Bill Perkins' book "Die with Zero" advocates for prioritizing experiences over accumulating wealth, with the goal of achieving maximum fulfillment and happiness. The author's personal goal is to die with an empty bank account, but with a specific monetary goal to support personal and dependent needs, rather than accumulating for its own sake.

site_title: Unemployment support for Singaporean seafarers to be extended by 3 months
summary: Singaporean seafarers will receive extended unemployment support for an additional three months under the Seafarers Relief Package (SRP). The initial three-month cap of up to S$2,400 will be extended to six months (up to S$4,800) for those unable to secure shipboard employment between May 1 and Dec 31, 2020. The move aims to support seafarers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, with the goal of enhancing the safety net for Singaporean seafarers and supporting them to acquire new skills.

site_title: All set for the age of digital currencies
summary: Digital currencies are gaining popularity, with central banks worldwide exploring their use. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's Ubin project has successfully tested a digital representation of the Singapore dollar, while the People's Bank of China's e-yuan has facilitated over 1.1 billion yuan in transactions. The European Central Bank is also considering a digital euro. To address consumer concerns, stablecoins pegged to currency values are being used, providing a stable store of value and medium of exchange. The use of digital currencies is expected to increase, with applications extending beyond currencies to blockchain-based securities and tokenized assets.

site_title: OECD's corporate tax reform proposal gaining broad support: German minister
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has gained broad support from over 130 countries in its corporate tax reform proposal. German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz announced that the blueprint for global rules on corporate taxation will be discussed by G-20 finance ministers next week. The reform aims to make digital companies pay tax where they operate, boosting national tax revenues by an estimated $100 billion annually. The main goal is to ensure digital giants like Google, Amazon, and Facebook pay their fair share of tax.

images.alt_text: More than 130 countries have agreed on a blueprint to introduce global rules on corporate taxation to be discussed by G-20 finance ministers next week, German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz said on Friday.

site_title: Can Biden save the world?
summary: A Biden-led US administration could steer the world away from a great-power rivalry between the US and China, potentially preventing a dangerous confrontation and ushering in a new era of global cooperation. If President Trump were re-elected, he might become less hawkish toward China, but his administration's focus on transactional diplomacy could erode the US's influence and diminish multilateralism. A Biden administration, on the other hand, could forcefully pursue a strategy of multilateralism, working with traditional allies and many African, Latin American, and Asian countries to establish common rules and standards reflecting similar values.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies reported a net profit of S$154,000 for the half-year ended Aug 31, 2020, rebounding from a S$476,000 loss in the same period last year. Revenue fell 27.7% to S$18.3 million, primarily due to lower sales in HDD and precision metal stamping segments.

site_title: Momentum fizzles out; STI sheds 0.4%, up for week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended down 0.4% on Friday at 2,532.96 points, but still gained 1.48% for the week. The decline was in line with regional markets, which were affected by uncertainty over US stimulus. Singtel was the top performer, rising 0.93%.

site_title: AMD said to be in talks to buy rival Xilinx in US$30b deal
summary: AMD is in talks to acquire Xilinx in a potential $30 billion deal, which would give the chipmaker a larger share of the 5G and AI markets. The acquisition would also help AMD expand into data centers, where Xilinx's programmable chips can be used to accelerate workloads such as artificial intelligence. The deal, if completed, would follow moves by rival Nvidia, which bought Mellanox Technologies and aims to use its pending acquisition of Arm to grab more of the data center business.

site_title: Economies will recover more swiftly after lockdown: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) suggests that lockdowns to combat the COVID-19 pandemic can lead to a faster economic recovery if implemented in the short term. However, voluntary social distancing and continued community infections can hinder economic growth. The IMF recommends governments to deploy targeted measures, protect vulnerable people, and reduce contact intensity to support economic activity. Public investment in infrastructure, healthcare, and education is also seen as crucial to revive economic activity and create jobs.

site_title: Of property options and market distortions
summary: The Singapore government has clamped down on the practice of continually re-issuing options to purchase (OTPs) upon expiry, aimed at fostering financial prudence for buyers and curbing distortions in the private housing market. Before the change, developers could re-issue OTPs indefinitely, allowing buyers to defer their purchase and payment, potentially leading to forfeit of booking fees. The move is expected to reduce distortions, increase certainty of sales, and temper prices. Analysts predict moderation in developers' sales and prices, with some expecting a flattish market in the fourth quarter and potential price reductions next year. Despite economic uncertainty, factors such as high liquidity, low interest rates, and continued foreign buying interest may continue to support the market.

site_title: Tycoon running 500 hotels warns of more job cuts, closures
summary: Minor International, a Bangkok-based hotel chain, may cut more jobs and shut underperforming hotels due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic and travel restrictions. The company, which operates over 500 hotels globally, posted its largest quarterly loss in June and has already cut thousands of jobs. Thailand's reluctance to reopen its borders to foreign tourists, combined with China's booming economy, is expected to impact Minor's business. The company's chairman, Bill Heinecke, believes that Thailand's economy will be severely affected if it doesn't welcome Chinese tourists back soon.

site_title: Which non-invasive aesthetic treatment should you pick?
summary: High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound (HIFU) and Ulthera are non-invasive aesthetic treatments that use ultrasound energy to produce controlled damage to the dermis and SMAS tissue, resulting in a facelift-like effect. HIFU is a South Korean-made device, while Ulthera is an American-made device with FDA approval for non-invasive brow lift, neck, and décolleté lift. Studies have shown that both devices produce similar outcomes, with 85% of patients satisfied with HIFU and Ulthera treatments. However, Ulthera is recommended for its quality assurance, FDA approval, and stable focused ultrasound points.

site_title: A dollop of humour makes research relatable
summary: Singaporean professors Sumit Agarwal, Sing Tien Foo, and Ang Swee Hoon have launched "Kiasunomics 2: Economic Insights for Everyday Life," a book sharing research findings on everyday spending habits and economic behaviors. The book, in a light-hearted and accessible way, aims to help readers make informed decisions. Key findings include lower spending on transportation on rainy days and higher spending on air-conditioning. The book also explores regional case studies, such as e-payment adoption in India and housing market trends in Singapore.

site_title: Agents channelling a chunk of commissions to buyers
summary: Singapore property agents are channeling a significant portion of their commissions to buyers, often under the guise of "referral fees," to boost sales and inflate prices. This practice, which is in breach of guidelines set by the Council for Estate Agencies (CEA), has become more prevalent since the July 2018 cooling measures. Agents can command higher commissions, up to 8%, to clear remnant units, and developers are under pressure to drum up sales to meet their five-year sales targets and avoid additional buyer's stamp duty. The CEA has warned against such practices, and agents who breach guidelines can face disciplinary action.

site_title: Keppel O&M clinches contract valued at about S$600m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured a contract worth approximately S$600 million from an unnamed energy company for the engineering, procurement, and construction of a vessel for the offshore renewable energy industry.

site_title: Pollux Properties to acquire remaining 49.99% stake in associate company
summary: Pollux Properties has entered into a share transfer agreement to acquire the remaining 49.99% stake in associate company SFCPL for S$300,000. The acquisition aims to optimize operational efficiencies and will be funded by internal resources. SFCPL, a registered fund-management company, will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Pollux Properties. The deal is not expected to significantly impact the company's net asset value per share or earnings per share for the financial year ending March 31, 2021.

site_title: White House open to bigger stimulus bill as Mnuchin, Pelosi talk
summary: The US White House is open to a larger stimulus bill after a call between Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Mnuchin told Pelosi that President Donald Trump wants a comprehensive package, contrary to earlier statements. Pelosi has expressed skepticism, citing the President's handling of the Covid-19 crisis and opposition to a $2.2 trillion plan. Trump claimed to be open to a deal, including individual checks and airline aid, but negotiations remain uncertain due to differences over spending and the election campaign.

site_title: Suntec Reit makes London foray with £430.6m acquisition of Nova devt
summary: Suntec Reit has agreed to acquire a 50% stake in London's Nova development for £430.6 million (S$766.5 million), its first investment in the UK. The acquisition includes two Grade A office blocks and a primarily residential asset, with a net property income yield of 4.6%. The deal is subject to unitholders' approval and includes a two-year income guarantee to provide rental protection. The acquisition is expected to boost Suntec Reit's assets under management to S$11.5 billion, with the Nova properties adding high-quality office tenants and a long lease tenure.

site_title: International football transfer spending drops over 30%: FIFA
summary: International football transfer spending dropped by over 30% this year, totaling US$3.92 billion, compared to US$5.8 billion last year, according to FIFA's report. The number of transfers also decreased by 18% to 7,424, with a 25% decline in transfer fees involving a fee. European clubs were the biggest spenders, with English clubs spending US$1.25 billion. In contrast, the women's game saw a 35% increase in international transfers and a nearly doubling of transfer spending to US$822,000.

site_title: Mirach Energy gets 3-month extension to submit delisting proposal
summary: Mirach Energy has received a 3-month extension to submit a delisting proposal to the Singapore Exchange (SGX). This comes after certain shareholders expressed interest in making an exit offer to other shareholders. The company will need to appoint financial and legal advisers, establish a Singapore company, and prepare relevant documents. The extension is due to border restrictions limiting travel by potential offerors, who are mostly based outside Singapore. The company will provide an update when further clarity on the exit offer is available.

site_title: China Inc set for biggest US IPO year since 2014 amid spat
summary: China-based firms have raised $9.1 billion through US listings this year, on track for the highest annual total since 2014. The surge comes despite tensions between China and the US, with some firms choosing to list in the US due to greater flexibility and liquidity. Chinese companies can list in the US even if they are not yet profitable, unlike in their local markets. The trend is expected to continue, with several more firms filing for US listings, including budget consumer goods retailer Miniso Group Holding and fintech firm Lufax Holding.

site_title: Apple prepares to launch 5G iPhones into unready US market
summary: Apple is set to launch 5G-enabled iPhones in the US, despite the technology not being fully ready for widespread adoption. The country's major wireless carriers, Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile, have yet to roll out 5G networks that provide consistently higher data speeds or widespread coverage. Apple has ordered 80 million new iPhones, and the company expects the devices to spur a major upgrade cycle. The new iPhones will feature improved designs, faster processors, and upgraded cameras, with the first models expected to be released in the coming weeks.

site_title: Europe records 100,000 daily coronavirus cases for first time
summary: Europe has recorded its first daily coronavirus case milestone of 100,000 cases, driven by a surge in infections in the UK, Russia, Spain, and France. The UK, with over 17,000 new cases, has a high case-to-fatality rate of 7%, while France has seen its highest daily infections in two days, prompting a partial lockdown in Madrid. Eastern Europe is the worst affected region, accounting for over 33,600 daily reported cases, and Europe now accounts for nearly 22% of global coronavirus deaths.

site_title: Video consultations now allowed for more chronic conditions covered by Chas and MediSave
summary: The Ministry of Health has expanded video consultations for chronic conditions covered by the Chronic Disease Management Programme, allowing patients to use the Chas Chronic subsidy and MediSave limits for these services. This expansion, previously limited to seven conditions, aims to support safe-distancing measures amid the pandemic. Patients can now access video consultations for 20 chronic conditions, including related drugs and investigations, with no change to the subsidy and MediSave limits.

site_title: Top Glove mulls raising US$1b in Hong Kong listing
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest rubber glove maker, is considering raising over US$1 billion through a Hong Kong listing. The company, which reported a record net income of RM1.29 billion in its fiscal fourth quarter, is working with advisers on the potential share sale. Deliberations are ongoing, and details of the offering, including size, could increase based on investor feedback. The process is expected to take six to nine months, following a surge of over 460% in Top Glove's shares this year amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: London Stock Exchange in talks with Indian tech firms to list overseas
summary: London Stock Exchange is in talks with Indian technology firms to list their shares overseas, as India moves to allow companies to directly access foreign markets. The exchange sees an opportunity to list some of India's rapidly growing tech and startup companies, which are expected to grow by 12-15% annually. London Stock Exchange has held talks with several Indian companies, particularly in the tech sector, and is enthusiastic about the prospect. However, concerns have risen about the potential for companies to float shares in both India and overseas, which could split trading volumes and hurt long-term valuations.

site_title: Golden Mile Complex to be conserved, with incentives to attract developers in future en bloc sale: URA
summary: The Golden Mile Complex, a 47-year-old Singaporean building, will be conserved due to its historical and architectural significance. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has proposed the move after a two-year study, offering incentives to attract developers in a future en bloc sale. These incentives include a one-third increase in floor area, waived development charges, and the option to adjust the site boundary. To ensure the conservation, developers must retain the main building's stepped terrace and plinth-like profile, and abide by conservation guidelines.

site_title: BOJ to begin experimenting with digital currency next year
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) announced plans to experiment with its own digital currency next year, joining efforts by other central banks to develop a central bank digital currency (CBDC). The move aligns with Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's focus on promoting digitalization and administrative reform. The BOJ's efforts follow an announcement by seven major central banks, including the BOJ, on core features of a CBDC, such as resilience and a clear legal framework.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) said on Friday it would begin experimenting next year on how to operate its own digital currency, joining efforts by other central banks to catch up to rapid private-sector innovation.

site_title: Brexit deal close but EU seeks more before starting final talks
summary: European Union chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier wants Britain to make a few more concessions before entering the final phase of trade deal negotiations, which must be completed by the EU summit on October 15. Despite progress, key issues such as fishing rights, level playing field, and governance remain unresolved. The UK has set a deadline for a deal, but Prime Minister Boris Johnson's top advisers warn that Britain will not do a deal at any price, leaving the possibility of a no-deal scenario that could impact bilateral trade and the border.

site_title: Unemployment support for Singaporean seafarers to be extended by 3 months
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has announced an extension of the Seafarers Relief Package (SRP) for Singaporean seafarers. The initial three-month support period has been extended to six months, up to S$4,800, for those who lost shipboard employment between May 1 and Dec 31, 2020. This move aims to provide financial assistance to seafarers affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, allowing them to continue training and upgrading their skills. The SRP is part of the S$27 million MaritimeSG Together Package introduced in April 2020.

site_title: Corporate bonds: Getting creative for cash
summary: Corporate bonds experienced a bust-then-boom cycle during the Covid-19 outbreak. Despite record US unemployment, the US Federal Reserve's support for credit markets helped issuers secure deals. The "five Cs" - comfort, coupons, creativity, collateral, and control - played key roles in this process. Issuers used creative structures, such as coupon step-up provisions and collateral offering, to entice investors. The use of collateral, including ships and intellectual property, became increasingly common. However, not all collateral is acceptable, and investors must be cautious when evaluating its value.

images.alt_text: With the Fed's help, The Boeing Co priced a US$25 billion jumbo deal on April 30 across seven tranches at spreads on average of around 450bps above treasuries across three-year to 40-year tranches.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.92 points to 1,530.35 on Friday, driven by a gain of 717 stocks compared to 307 losers. The stock market saw a volume of 6.601 billion lots worth RM2.892 billion.

site_title: Underdog Iga Swiatek seeks trophy breakthrough
summary: Polish teenager Iga Swiatek is set to face Australian Open champion Sofia Kenin in the French Open final on Saturday. Swiatek, 20, has taken a different path to the final, with Kenin having to scrap and improvise to reach the match after losing in the opening round of the Rome clay-court tournament. Swiatek's journey to the final has been smoother, and she is looking to secure her breakthrough trophy.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte calls special Parliament sitting to seal 2021 budget
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has called a special Parliament sitting from October 13-16 to finalize the 2021 budget of 4.5 trillion pesos ($126.34 billion) to aid the battered economy's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. The budget will fund government projects to combat the virus and rebuild the economy, which is expected to shrink 5.5% this year but rebound to 6.5-7.5% growth in 2021. This would be the penultimate budget under Duterte's single, six-year term.

site_title: Swedish truckmaker AB Volvo to end pandemic furlough schemes
summary: AB Volvo is ending its pandemic furlough schemes in Sweden, affecting approximately 20,000 employees. The decision comes as market demand has rebounded since the spring. Volvo chose not to apply for a new period of furlough support, effective immediately, according to a spokesperson.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's commercial property investment sales picked up in Q3, with demand for Government-Managed Buildings (GCBs) remaining resilient. The Singapore Tourism Board and DBS launched a tourism promotion to stimulate domestic demand. PwC Singapore launched a program to help foreign startups enter South-east Asia. Suntec Reit is eyeing a £430.6m acquisition in London. Keppel O&M secured a contract valued at S$600m, while Raffles Financial and Pacific Bays Capital formed an advisory partnership. ERP charges will increase by S$1 at six CTE gantries from Oct 12, with the STI down 0.4% on Friday.

site_title: Japan may need to consider compiling third extra budget: lawmaker
summary: Japan may need to consider a third extra budget to support its economy if current reserve funds are insufficient to combat the coronavirus pandemic. The reserve fund, totaling 10 trillion yen, may not be enough to cover support for the economy in 2020, according to a ruling party lawmaker. The government has already delivered two stimulus packages this year, and some lawmakers are calling for another spending package as economic pain persists.

site_title: China to issue 10m digital yuan in first public test
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, is issuing 10 million yuan (S$2 million) in digital currency to 50,000 randomly selected consumers in Shenzhen, marking what some see as the country's first public test of the digital yuan payment system. The digital currency can be used at 3,389 retail outlets in Shenzhen, and the winners can be awarded a 200-yuan "red envelope" via a lottery. The test aims to modernize payments systems and fend off potential competition from privately issued cryptocurrencies, with the PBOC planning to expand pilot schemes and officially launch the digital currency soon.

site_title: Nokia wins Orange Belgium's 5G contract, Huawei says 'fair competition'
summary: Nokia has won Orange Belgium's 5G contract, replacing Huawei-made equipment. The decision follows US pressure on European operators to remove Huawei from their networks due to security concerns. Huawei denies spying allegations. Nokia will supply radio gear, while Ericsson will provide core infrastructure. This marks a shift in market share, with Nokia and Ericsson benefiting from challenges facing Huawei.

site_title: Indonesian Muslim and union groups to fight new jobs law in court
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's new labour law, which critics say undermines labour rights and weakens environmental protections, has sparked widespread protests and opposition. Union groups, including the KSPI and KPBI, plan to challenge the law in court, with Nahdlatul Ulama, Indonesia's largest Muslim group, also preparing to take action. Clashes have erupted in cities, including Jakarta, and at least five regional leaders have publicly opposed the law, calling for its repeal to prevent further instability amid a pandemic and economic recession.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks post biggest weekly gain in two months on US stimulus hopes
summary: Japanese stocks posted their biggest weekly gain in two months on Friday, rising 2.6% for the week, driven by hopes of US stimulus. Despite US President Donald Trump's restart of talks with Congress, some investors doubt the chances of a deal ahead of the presidential election. The Nikkei 225 Index ended 0.12% lower on Friday, while the Topix rose 2.4% for the week. The US economy's struggles with the coronavirus are expected to impact Japan's export sector.

site_title: 10 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 9 imported
summary: Singapore reported 10 new Covid-19 cases, including one locally transmitted case in a dormitory, and nine imported cases who had been placed on stay-home notices. This marks the third consecutive day with no community cases. The total number of cases now stands at 57,859. Meanwhile, 44 patients were discharged, leaving 35 in hospital, including one in critical condition.

site_title: Petronas Gas, Top Oil to benefit as colder winter ups demand for fuel: Maybank KE
summary: Malaysia's Petronas Gas and Thailand's Top Oil are expected to benefit from a potential increase in fuel demand due to a colder winter in North-east Asia. Crude prices have risen 4% due to supply disruptions in Norway and the Gulf of Mexico. Experts forecast a 70% chance of La Nina weather patterns, leading to higher power demand and fuel prices. Petronas Gas, PTT Exploration and Production, Thai Oil, and Star Petroleum Refining are among the potential beneficiaries, while PTT may experience a negative impact due to higher LNG prices.

site_title: Ryanair sees 737 MAX return in US in 'next month or so'
summary: Ryanair expects Boeing's 737 MAX to return to service in the US within the next month, paving the way for early 2021 deliveries. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued a draft report on revised training procedures, a milestone to return the plane to service. According to Ryanair's CEO, Eddie Wilson, the first deliveries are expected in early 2021, following the completion of test flights and FAA certification. This move comes after the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) also approves the 737 MAX for service.

site_title: First batch of 1,402 smart-enabled BTO flats in Punggol ready by end of year
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) has completed the first batch of 1,402 smart-enabled Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Punggol Northshore by the end of the year. The smart flats feature smart power sockets and high-tech distribution boards, allowing residents to control appliances through a mobile application. Sensors will also be deployed to analyze estate services and optimize energy usage. Punggol, a waterfront housing district, is the first district in Singapore to have smart features incorporated throughout, with the goal of creating a sustainable and eco-friendly living environment.

images.alt_text: Slightly more than 1,400 families will be the first to live in smart-enabled Housing Board (HDB) flats in Punggol Northshore by the end of this year.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open on stimulus optimism
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Friday, setting up the S&P 500 and Dow for their second straight weekly gain, driven by optimism over potential fiscal aid and a growing expectation of a Democratic victory in the presidential election. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 108.10 points, the S&P 500 gained 12.84 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 66.62 points, all at the opening bell.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Friday, setting up the S&P 500 and the Dow for their second straight weekly gain on hopes of more fiscal aid and growing expectations of a Democratic victory in next month's presidential election.

site_title: ERP charges to go up by S$1 at six CTE gantries from Oct 12
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) fees on the Central Expressway (CTE) will increase by S$1 at six gantries starting Oct 12. The changes will affect south-bound drivers from Braddell Road and the PIE slip road, who will pay S$1 during peak hours from 8.30am to 9am and 9am to 9.30am. Meanwhile, north-bound drivers will pay S$3 instead of S$2. The LTA will continue to monitor traffic speeds and congestion levels, with no changes to ERP charges on other roads and expressways.

site_title: Indonesia likely to tap private sector in Covid-19 vaccine rollout: Report
summary: Indonesia is likely to tap the private sector in its COVID-19 vaccine rollout, with analysts predicting Kalbe Farma will play a key role in distributing vaccines nationwide. Bio Farma, a state-owned player, is expected to supply 228 million vaccines, while Kalbe Farma is expected to supply 60 million. Analysts see Kalbe Farma as a proxy for Indonesia's pharmaceutical sector, benefiting from its extensive distribution network and expertise. This move is seen as good news for the country's pharmaceutical sector, with Kalbe Farma tipped for a "buy" call.

site_title: Singapore commercial property investment sales pick up in Q3; demand for GCBs resilient
summary: Singapore's commercial property investment sales picked up in Q3, with interest and activity recovering in the commercial sector. However, overall investment sales were down 55.1% year-over-year to S$4.4 billion. The government land sales programme remained inactive during the quarter, with no public sector transactions completed. Despite this, demand for Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) remained resilient.

site_title: UK's Sunak readies new jobs plan as economic recovery wanes
summary: British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak is set to announce a new jobs plan to support workers in the hospitality and other sectors hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. The plan, which will provide a wage subsidy for two-thirds of workers in affected businesses, comes as the UK's economic recovery wanes, with economic output rising only 2.1% in August, less than half the median forecast. The government's main furlough scheme is set to close at the end of the month, putting pressure on workers in the sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 0.31% lower on Friday, slipping 74.22 points to 24,119.13, amid uncertainty over US stimulus. In contrast, mainland Chinese markets rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 1.68% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumping 3.09%. The rally was fueled by investors returning from the Golden Week holiday.

site_title: They took US$645m in valuables. Then they took a taxi
summary: Thieves stole $645 million in artifacts from a Hong Kong apartment while the owner was abroad, including 24,000 vintage stamps, 10 bronze coins, and a 3-yard calligraphy scroll written by Mao Zedong. The majority of the items remain missing, but the scroll was recovered and sold for $65. Police arrested three suspects, including Wu, Tan, and Lin, and charged them with burglary, harbouring, and handling stolen goods. The stolen items are believed to have been sold through a network of buyers and auction houses.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, driven by hopes of a fresh US stimulus deal. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.4%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also rose 0.9% and 0.4%, respectively. Meanwhile, pan-European stock market operator Euronext agreed to buy the Milan bourse for 4.33 billion euros.

site_title: Australia: Shares post best week in six months, NZ hits record close
summary: Australian shares posted their best week in six months, closing unchanged at 6,102.2, after a week of gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 5.4% for the week. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record close at 12,280.54, adding 3.9% for the week. The Australian government's pledge to pull the economy out of recession and the US President's Covid-19 relief measures had mixed effects on the market. The energy sector led gains, with oil prices surging, while financials and technology stocks also rose.

site_title: Gold gains 1% on dollar retreat, US stimulus hopes
summary: Gold prices rose 1% on Friday due to a weaker US dollar, with spot gold reaching $1,907.16 per ounce and US gold futures at $1,912.40. The dollar index fell for the second straight week, bolstering gold's appeal as an inflation hedge. Renewed optimism over a new US coronavirus relief package and a widening lead for Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden also contributed to the metal's gain.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose 1 per cent on Friday due to a weaker US dollar and was headed for a second straight weekly gain, with the metal's appeal as an inflation hedge bolstered by renewed optimism over a new US coronavirus relief package.

site_title: Keppel O&M clinches contract valued at about S$600m
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured a S$600 million contract with an unnamed energy company for the engineering, procurement, and construction of a vessel for the offshore renewable energy industry. The contract is on progressive payment terms and is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year. This win aligns with Keppel Corp's Vision 2030 roadmap, which includes seeking opportunities in renewable energy solutions.

site_title: STI loses steam, down 0.4% at 2,532.96, but up 1.48% for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,532.96 points, down 0.4% on Friday, but still up 1.48% for the week. Singtel was the top performer, gaining 0.93% after launching a 5G standalone trial network. The STI's performance mirrored regional counterparts, which also lost steam after a four-day rally.

site_title: LSE agrees to sell Borsa Italiana to Euronext for 4.33b euros
summary: LSE agrees to sell Borsa Italiana to Euronext for 4.33 billion euros in cash, addressing European Union competition concerns related to LSE's US$27 billion Refinitiv purchase. The sale is contingent on EU approval and will contribute to Euronext's diversification and revenue mix. Euronext will fund the deal through a debt and equity hike, and the sale is expected to be immediately accretive to its earnings. The deal is also sensitive in Italy due to Borsa's ownership of the country's government bond market.

site_title: World Food Programme wins Nobel Peace Prize
summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for its efforts to combat hunger, improve conditions for peace in conflict-affected areas, and prevent hunger as a weapon of war. The WFP, which feeds millions of people worldwide, including those in Yemen and North Korea, was recognized for its humanitarian work during the coronavirus pandemic, which pushed millions more into hunger. The prize was awarded in Oslo, Norway, by Nobel committee chairwoman Berit Reiss-Andersen.

site_title: AMD in talks to buy rival Xilinx in US$30b deal: sources
summary: AMD is in talks to buy rival Xilinx in a potential $30 billion deal, according to sources. The acquisition would give AMD more pieces to break Intel's stranglehold on the data-centre market and expand into the 5G wireless network market. The deal, which could be finalized as soon as next week, would further industry consolidation, with Nvidia's proposed $40 billion Arm acquisition and AMD's recent surge in stock value. AMD would need to finance the deal, which could impact investor confidence, as the company has only recently shed concerns about its cash reserves.

site_title: Singapore farm industry gets new guide on regulatory landscape
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore and the Singapore Food Agency have launched an industry guide to help local companies navigate the country's regulatory requirements for setting up farms. The guide, developed in consultation with industry players, consolidates key information on regulatory approvals and approval processes for farm development. It aims to catalyze the development of a vibrant agri-food tech sector and help companies prepare their farm development plans more efficiently.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Central banks sketch out digital currency as China forges ahead
summary: Major central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, have outlined a framework for a digital currency to compete with China's digital renminbi. The core features should include resilience, low or no cost, and clear standards. The private sector's role and legal framework will also be considered. The move aims to prevent the private sector from filling the gap in unsuitable ways. China is already piloting its digital currency, with the People's Bank of China seeking a first-mover advantage.

site_title: China Inc set for biggest US IPO year since 2014 amid spat
summary: Chinese companies are on track to raise the largest amount of US dollars through initial public offerings (IPOs) in the US since 2014, amid tensions between China and the US. Firms have raised $9.1 billion so far this year, with more listings expected, including a potential $3 billion for Lufax Holding. The US remains an attractive venue for Chinese companies due to greater flexibility, liquidity, and a time-efficient listing process. Despite US regulators' threats to ban Chinese companies from listing, many firms are choosing the US over local markets like Hong Kong, where they face stricter requirements and capital-control restrictions.

site_title: Trump eyes return to rallies on Saturday after doctor says Covid-19 therapy completed
summary: US President Donald Trump may return to campaign rallies on Saturday after completing his COVID-19 therapy, according to his doctor. Trump tested positive for the virus a week ago and has been in isolation, but has shown improvement and is looking to resume public events. Trump plans to take a test on Friday and is considering a rally in Florida on Saturday and in Pennsylvania on Sunday.

site_title: HSBC eyes net zero emissions by 2050, earmarks US$1 trillion green financing
summary: HSBC aims to achieve net zero carbon emissions across its entire customer base by 2050, with a target of providing US$750 billion to US$1 trillion in green financing. The bank's CEO, Noel Quinn, outlined the ambitious goal, which is the strongest statement on climate change by a European bank. HSBC also aims to achieve net zero in its own operations by 2030 and will use the Paris Agreement's Carbon Transition Assessment Tool to track progress. The bank's pledge comes amid increasing pressure from activists and shareholders to address climate change.

images.alt_text: HSBC will target net zero carbon emissions across its entire customer base by 2050 at the latest, and provide between US$750 billion and US$1 trillion in financing to help clients make the transition, its chief executive officer (CEO) Noel Quinn told Reuters.

site_title: PlayStation inventor starts new career making robots for no pay
summary: Ken Kutaragi, inventor of the PlayStation, has become CEO of Ascent Robotics, a Tokyo-based AI startup. He aims to create affordable robots that can work alongside humans in factories and logistics centers, with a working prototype expected in about a year. Kutaragi, 70, received no salary to save capital, citing the need for more robots in daily life to achieve a new normal. He plans to achieve this through partnerships, having previously worked with Kawasaki Heavy Industries and a Japanese carmaker on autonomous driving and collaborative robots.

site_title: Evergrande's steep holiday discounts could squeeze margins
summary: China Evergrande Group completed 71% of its sales target in the two months through October, offering steep discounts of up to 800 projects, the steepest in history. The company reported contracted sales of 142 billion yuan, down from 173 billion yuan in the same period last year. Evergrande, the world's most indebted developer, is under pressure to curb leverage with $120 billion in debt, including $5.8 billion due in the next two months. The shares fell 2.7% after the announcement, amid concerns over margins and the company's ability to cut debt.

site_title: Raffles Financial, Pacific Bays Capital strike advisory partnership
summary: Raffles Financial Pte Ltd, a corporate finance advisory firm, has entered into a partnership with Pacific Bays Capital to provide advanced-stage Japanese firms with capital and public listing services. The partnership aims to help these firms list on the Singapore Exchange or Hong Kong Stock Exchange and expand into South-east Asia. Both parties will work together to secure strategic resources and investors, with Raffles Financial providing advice on exit strategies and additional services to bring foreign capital to these firms. The partnership is expected to support the growth of Japanese firms in the Indo-Pacific region.

site_title: Waymo opens robo-taxi service to the public in US city
summary: Waymo, Alphabet's autonomous car unit, launched its robo-taxi service to the public in Phoenix, Arizona, allowing anyone signed up through the Waymo One app to summon fully driverless vehicles. The service, initially tested with Chrysler Pacifica vehicles, now includes a mix of driverless and human-operated vehicles. The company aims to bolster its fleet with more self-driving vehicles and expand its service to more regions in the US. This marks the first widely available driverless ride service in the US.

site_title: Indonesia adds Microsoft, others to list of tech firms that must pay VAT
summary: Indonesia has added eight tech firms, including Microsoft and Alibaba Cloud, to its list of companies required to pay a 10% value-added tax (VAT) on sales. The list, which now includes 36 companies, was announced on October 9, 2020, and companies must start charging VAT to customers from November 1. Non-resident foreign firms generating annual sales of at least 600 million rupiah from 12,000 users in Indonesia are required to pay VAT. The move aims to increase tax revenue from the country's growing tech industry.

site_title: PwC Singapore launches programme to help foreign startups enter South-east Asia
summary: PwC Singapore has launched a five-day Scale Programme to help foreign startups expand into South-east Asia. The programme includes masterclasses, mentorship, and networking sessions, aiming to get startups pitch-ready and connect them with potential investors, customers, and government agencies. The first batch of participants will begin on October 12, held virtually due to COVID-19 restrictions, and can sign up on the PwC Singapore website. The programme is seen as an attractive opportunity for startups to tap into South-east Asia's rapid growth, particularly in Singapore's business-friendly environment.

site_title: Japan has no plan to issue digital currencies now but will deepen research
summary: Japan has no plans to issue central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) at present, but will deepen research on the possibility, according to Chief Cabinet Secretary Katsunobu Kato. This comes as major central banks worldwide study CBDCs amid the growing popularity of cryptocurrencies. Japan's cautious approach to digital currencies is due to its cash-loving population, but China's progress on issuing digital currency has prompted the government to reconsider. Japan will create a new team and conduct joint research with other central banks to scrutinize the need for CBDCs and their impact on the financial system.

site_title: Cathay Pacific union bemoans lack of information from management
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways' union is urging members to sign a petition demanding more information about a restructuring plan amid concerns of job cuts. The airline is struggling due to the pandemic, with passenger numbers down 99% and a monthly loss of HK$2 billion. The union wants the company to implement a longer unpaid-leave program and better redundancy compensation. Despite this, Cathay's shares rose 0.4% following the news, marking a sixth straight day of gains. The airline's restructuring plan is expected to be announced in November.

site_title: UK economy stumbles in August, setting back Covid recovery
summary: The UK economy expanded 2.1% in August, lower than expected 4.6% growth, marking the fourth consecutive month of growth. Despite this, the economy remains 9.2% smaller than pre-pandemic levels. The services sector grew 2.4%, while manufacturing and construction sectors fell short of forecasts. Economists warn that the British economy may struggle to grow as Covid-19 cases rise and government restrictions tighten.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift on stimulus uncertainty after Trump U-turn
summary: Asian markets drifted on Friday due to uncertainty over a fresh US stimulus package, despite a recent U-turn by President Trump. The decision to resume talks with Democrats has boosted confidence, but rising virus infections continue to impact investor sentiment. The US Supreme Court nomination and US-EU trade talks also remain in focus.

site_title: 'Ghost island' Phuket hunkers down in tourist-free Thailand
summary: Thailand's tourist island Phuket, once a major destination with over 9 million visitors last year, has become a "ghost town" due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Nearly all hotels are closed, and the main town of Patong is deserted. The island's economy is expected to contract 7-9% this year, leaving millions unemployed. Tourism, which accounts for 80% of Phuket's profits and employs over 300,000 people, has been severely impacted. The Thai government has shifted focus to beating the virus, but a return to normal is not expected for three years.

site_title: Malaysia firms turn to private placements to shore up funding
summary: Malaysia's corporates are turning to private share placements to raise funds amid a tightening funding market. The number of deals jumped 25% to RM1.41 billion in the first nine months of 2020, with companies opting for private placements due to lower valuations and reduced access to public markets. Many companies have losses and weak cash flows, making private placements an attractive option. Indonesian firms are also resorting to rights offers and private placements, highlighting a broader trend of companies seeking alternative funding sources.

site_title: Suntec Reit eyes London foray with £430.6m acquisition of Nova buildings
summary: Suntec Reit is set to acquire a 50% stake in London's Nova development from Canada's Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB) for £426 million, with the remaining half stake held by Land Securities Group. The acquisition includes two Grade A office blocks and a residential asset, with a 4.6% net property income yield. The deal is expected to be funded by loans and will provide a 4.9% accretion to distribution per unit. The Nova estate is located in London's West End and has a long leasehold tenure expiring in 3062.

site_title: DBS and STB to launch tourism promotions, digitalise local businesses
summary: Singapore's Tourism Board (STB) and DBS Bank have partnered for a three-year collaboration to boost domestic and cross-border tourism demand. The tie-up aims to digitalize local businesses, leveraging DBS's services such as travel marketplaces and digital payments. The partnership will also create promotional bundles for attractions and tours, and provide personalized itineraries for locals. The goal is to stimulate domestic tourism and drive industry development in the mid to long term, while helping local SMEs transform digitally to thrive in the post-Covid-19 environment.

site_title: Australia: Shares open higher as US stimulus talks progress
summary: Australian shares rose 0.14% to 6,102 points on Friday, driven by energy and gold stocks after US President Donald Trump revived hopes of a COVID-19 relief deal. Oil prices jumped on US Gulf of Mexico shutdowns and supply cuts, lifting energy sector stocks. Gold stocks also rose, driven by uncertainty about the US presidential election and potential stimulus. Despite mixed messages about stimulus, analysts expect choppy markets.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up, Shanghai returns with bounce
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Friday, following Wall Street's positive lead. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.62% to 24,343.81, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index jumped 1.38% to 3,262.61. Mainland Chinese investors returned from a six-day break, contributing to the Shanghai rally.

site_title: Japan household spending, real wages extend Covid-driven declines
summary: Japan's household spending fell 6.9% in August from a year earlier, marking the 11th consecutive month of decline, and real wages have been in a half-year slump. The decline in spending and wage figures pose challenges for new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's efforts to revive the economy, which is expected to pick up from the COVID-19 slump.

site_title: Japan's real wages fall for sixth straight month as pandemic bites
summary: Japan's real wages fell 1.4% in August for the sixth consecutive month, down from a year earlier, due to the pandemic's impact on the labor market. Nominal total cash earnings dropped 1.3% to 273,263 yen, with overtime pay declining 14.0% and regular pay slipping 0.1%. The economic blow from the coronavirus crisis led companies to cut costs, including summer bonuses. This marks the fifth consecutive month of declines in nominal total cash earnings.

site_title: China joins deal to get Covid-19 vaccine to poorer nations
summary: China has joined the Covax deal to distribute Covid-19 vaccines to poorer nations, committing to provide vaccines to 92 low and middle-income countries as soon as they are developed. This move aims to address concerns that rich countries may limit vaccine distribution. China, the country where the virus first emerged, has a prominent role in the global effort to share vaccines. The deal, which has a fundraising goal of $2 billion, is seen as a step to reframe perceptions of China's role in the pandemic.

site_title: Changing the business landscape with AI
summary: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming the business landscape, enhancing productivity and freeing time for human insight. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated AI adoption, with South-east Asia expected to reach $1 trillion by 2030. Singapore is a leader in AI, with a strong commitment to transform the economy. The government has implemented the National Artificial Intelligence Strategy and Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 plan, committing $500 million to fund AI activities. EDBI, a business organization, supports promising AI startups, focusing on solutions that augment human capabilities, automate routine activities, and provide financial and developmental benefits.

site_title: Instacart valuation jumps to US$17.7b in grocery investment
summary: Instacart's valuation has surged to $17.7 billion in a new private funding round, more than doubling its value since the start of the pandemic. The company plans to use the $200 million investment to develop its website, ad business, and retail store services. Founded in 2012, Instacart has seen rapid growth due to the surge in demand for home delivery during the pandemic, reaching $35 billion in grocery sales this year. The company faces competition from other startups and has implemented measures to improve worker safety and expand its services.

site_title: China's services sector recovery gathers pace in Sept: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity rebounded for the fifth consecutive month in September, with a PMI reading of 54.8, the highest since June. The sector, accounting for 60% of the economy, saw hiring increase for the second month in a row, driven by domestic demand. New export orders declined further, while firms remained optimistic about business prospects. The official PMI also showed a faster expansion in the services sector. China's economy is expected to mark positive annual growth in 2020, albeit at low levels, with many analysts predicting the country will be the only major economy to achieve this.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending Wall Street rallies on revived US stimulus hopes and a cheap yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.22% to 23,699.56, while the Topix index gained 0.02% to 1,655.79. The gains were attributed to the revived hopes for US stimulus and a cheap yen against the dollar.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.43 points, or 0.23%, to 1,516.00. Volume was 179.98 million lots worth RM39.80 million. Gainers beat losers 190 to 54.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, Tiong Woon, Prudential, HC Surgical, GS Holdings
summary: Suntec Reit to acquire a 50% stake in London's Nova development for £430.6 million (S$766.5 million). Tiong Woon Corp awarded two 5-year crane rental contracts with Shell Eastern Petroleum and Shell Chemicals Seraya. Prudential plc and HC Surgical Specialists (HCSS) entered a framework agreement for health services and HCSS to take a 20% stake in medical goods retailer Healthcare Essentials. GS Holdings inked a joint venture agreement to expand food and beverage businesses. Singtel deployed Singapore's first 5G standalone trial network.

site_title: US imposes sanctions on Iran's major banks
summary: The US Treasury Department has imposed sweeping sanctions on 18 major Iranian banks, aiming to cripple the country's economy ahead of US elections. The sanctions, set to take effect in 45 days, will largely cut off Iran from the world's financial system, citing support for its nuclear program and regional influence. Transactions in humanitarian goods like food and medicine are exempt. European diplomats warn of dire humanitarian consequences, while polls show President Trump trailing in the election. The move is part of the Trump administration's "maximum pressure" policy, which has already stopped Iranian oil exports and bolted from a nuclear deal.

site_title: Japan may push back deadline for casino host-city bids by a year: Yomiuri
summary: Japan is considering pushing back its July 2021 deadline for casino host-city bids by a year due to delays caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The government aims to boost tourism, tax revenue, and local economies with integrated resorts, but opposition to gambling and past scandals have hindered plans. Three cities have already been authorized to develop resorts: Yokohama, Tokyo, and Osaka. Las Vegas Sands Corp ended its plans for a Japan resort in May, further complicating the process. The revised deadline has not been officially announced.

site_title: Singapore equities open flat on Friday; STI inches up 0.02%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged up 0.02% to 2,543.54 on Friday, with about 141.8 million securities changing hands. The benchmark index saw a calm start amid global rallies, with Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust and Sembcorp Marine being among the top traded counters. US stocks advanced for the second straight session, while European shares hit a near three-week high.

site_title: Maersk to stop using Myanmar military ports: rights group
summary: Global shipping giant Maersk will stop using military-owned ports in Myanmar, effective October 31, following pressure from rights group Burma Campaign UK. The decision comes after the UN accused Myanmar's military of widespread human rights abuses, particularly in 2017's Rohingya crackdown. Maersk cited the UN's "due diligence" recommendations and the growing momentum of campaigns to stop international companies funding human rights violations. The move is seen as a significant step in increasing pressure on other shipping businesses to sever ties with the Myanmar military.

site_title: Icahn sees energy sector rebound but urges patience
summary: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn said the energy sector will rebound but urged patience from shareholders. Icahn, with stakes in CVR Energy, Cheniere Energy, and Occidental Petroleum, advised against buying energy stocks immediately, suggesting investors should wait until companies are out of favor to make a profit. He emphasized the importance of timing in making money in the energy sector.

site_title: Samsung Q3 profit likely at 2-year high after Huawei orders, phone recovery
summary: Samsung's third-quarter profit is expected to jump 58% to a two-year high, beating analyst estimates, driven by increased orders from Huawei and a recovery in phone sales. US restrictions on Huawei have reduced demand for its phones outside China, giving Samsung a boost. Revenue is also expected to rise 6% to 66 trillion won. Analysts attribute Samsung's strong performance to Huawei's impact on its chip business and a surge in anti-China sentiment in India.

site_title: UK's Sunak plans carbon emissions tax to help rebuild economy: The Times
summary: British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak plans to introduce a UK-wide carbon tax to encourage net-zero emissions and rebuild the economy. The tax, expected to raise billions of pounds, will replace existing EU schemes when the transition period ends. Government officials are considering extending the tax to other areas, including domestic gas and agriculture, which could raise over £25 billion by 2030. The move aims to support the UK's carbon reduction targets and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Canada announces C$590m investment in Ford electric car plant
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a C$590 million investment in Ford's electric car plant in Oakville, Ontario, with C$295 million from the federal government and C$295 million from the province of Ontario. The investment will help secure up to 5,400 Ford jobs and support Canada's goal of net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The project, valued at C$1.8 billion, will produce five new electric vehicle models and their batteries, making it the largest electric car manufacturing facility in North America.

site_title: Australian banks strong enough to withstand economic shock, support recovery: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has stated that Australia's financial system is strong enough to withstand the nation's economic contraction and support recovery, despite elevated risks. A weaker-than-expected economic recovery could exacerbate risks, particularly from further coronavirus-related setbacks or international tensions. The RBA is expected to lower its cash rate to 0.1% in its November policy meeting. This move aims to support the recovery and mitigate potential risks to the financial system.

site_title: AT&T's WarnerMedia readies job cuts: report
summary: AT&T's WarnerMedia is set to unveil significant job cuts, reportedly up to 20% of its workforce, in response to the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic on the media sector. The cuts, which could affect thousands of employees at Warner Bros. studios and TV operations including HBO, TBS, and TNT, aim to reduce costs and cope with declining revenue from cinema, cable subscriptions, and TV ads. The move follows the launch of WarnerMedia's HBO Max streaming service in an effort to compete with established rivals.

site_title: Ensuring cognitive diversity on corporate boards
summary: Singapore's corporate boards lack diversity, according to the inaugural Singapore Board Diversity Index, which assesses over 700 companies against eight dimensions of board diversity. The index found that nearly half of SGX-listed companies do not have a woman on their boards, and only 11% of board seats are held by women. The report also highlights a lack of age and tenure diversity, with a third of directors between 60-70 years old and nearly a quarter with over nine years of tenure. To improve, companies should focus on nomination committees, board renewal, and succession planning, and consider diverse directors from various disciplines.

site_title: Argentina becomes first country to approve genetically modified wheat
summary: Argentina has become the first country to approve genetically modified wheat, a drought-resistant variety developed by Bioceres. The approval was granted by the National Commission for Science and Technology (CONICET), paving the way for commercialization in the country. However, experts express concerns about the growth and marketing of genetically modified crops, citing difficulties in convincing consumers and securing approval from Brazil, the country's largest export market. The approval is seen as a significant milestone for the global value chain of wheat.

site_title: EU lawmakers break off talks with states on European recovery plan
summary: EU lawmakers have broken off talks with EU government representatives over the bloc's budget and a 1.8 trillion euro coronavirus recovery package. The talks were interrupted due to disagreements over funding key programs, including infrastructure, defense, and student exchanges. A deal is needed to adopt the EU's largest-ever financial stimulus, which could further damage the EU economy if not resolved. Talks will resume, and if a deal is reached, national parliaments will have to ratify it.

site_title: Trudeau fears 'disruptions' in event of tight US vote result
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau expressed concerns about potential disruptions if the US presidential election result is close, citing the country's polarisation and its impact on the Canadian economy. Trudeau stated that Ottawa is preparing for "any outcomes" and is closely watching the election. He emphasized that Canada views the US election with "some concern" due to its potential economic implications.

site_title: Oil jumps on supply cuts in US Gulf, wariness about North Sea, Opec
summary: Oil prices rose above $43 a barrel on Thursday, driven by supply cuts in the US Gulf of Mexico and concerns over North Sea production due to a workers' strike. Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering reversing its planned production increase, and OPEC's output cuts are being challenged by rising Libyan output. The market also gained support from Hurricane Delta, which halted nearly 1.5 million barrels of daily output. Oil prices are expected to remain positive, with analysts predicting a potential extension of OPEC's production cuts.

site_title: Democrats want panel to investigate Trump capacity to govern
summary: US Democrats proposed a commission to investigate Donald Trump's mental fitness for office, citing concerns over his health and erratic behavior amid his COVID-19 treatment. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi plans to introduce a bill related to the 25th Amendment, which allows for the vice president to take over if the president is deemed unfit. Trump and Republicans have criticized the move, with Trump calling Pelosi "Crazy Nancy" and warning of a potential coup. The bill is unlikely to lead to Trump's removal, as Vice President Mike Pence would need to sign off on such a declaration.

site_title: Singapore fintech founder silent on previous SEC probe
summary: Singapore fintech founder Ed Chin, the founder of OctiFi, is silent on his previous SEC probe in 2016, where he was accused of misleading Goldman Sachs customers and fined $400,000. Chin was fired from Goldman Sachs and barred from the securities industry for two years. He now runs OctiFi, a buy-now-pay-later fintech, which has seen a 34% increase in average order value and 20% increase in sales conversion since its launch. Chin now refers to himself as Ed Chin, downplaying his past Wall Street experience.

site_title: US dollar, yen nurse losses amid 'risk-on' mood
summary: The US dollar and Japanese yen experienced losses on Thursday due to improved investor sentiment after revived hopes for US fiscal stimulus. The prospect of negative interest rates also impacted the New Zealand dollar. US President Trump and House Speaker Pelosi seem open to a stimulus package for the airline industry, potentially boosting the economy.

site_title: US: Stocks rise again amid conflicting signs on stimulus
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 0.4% to 28,425.51, the S&P 500 climbing 0.8% to 3,446.83, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.5% to 11,420.98. Despite conflicting signs on stimulus, investors remain optimistic due to improving US election polls and President Trump's recovery from COVID-19, which could lead to effective treatments.

site_title: Bars get innovative to mitigate sales loss from earlier closing times, capacity cuts
summary: Bars in Singapore are adapting to the post-pandemic normal by offering innovative services to mitigate sales loss from earlier closing times and capacity cuts. Many are now open all day, offering food and cocktail masterclasses to attract customers. Some bars have also seen an uptick in day drinking crowds, with residents taking advantage of the stay-home measures. To manage reduced seating capacity, bars are adopting reservation systems and offering food menus to maximize space usage. Despite challenges in adhering to virus safety measures, the industry is finding new ways to stay afloat and thrive in the new normal.

site_title: Government relief measures for developers hit by construction disruptions
summary: Singapore has introduced temporary relief measures for property developers affected by COVID-19-related construction disruptions. The measures, which can be taken with immediate effect, aim to cushion the impact of slow work resumption and pandemic disruptions. The government's move is seen as a response to the industry's challenges, with market watchers expecting the measures to provide some relief.

site_title: Will upscale SoHo be site of New York's next battle over development?
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio's rezoning plan for SoHo aims to create 800 new affordable housing units in the upscale Manhattan neighborhood. The move, which could lead to taller buildings, is expected to spark resistance from wealthy residents who value the area's historic charm and high-end properties. The rezoning plan is part of the city's effort to address its affordable housing shortage.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Rich Capital Holdings, a Catalist-listed property developer, announced that PrimePartners Corporate Finance will no longer be its continuing sponsor from November 1, citing "commercial reasons" after deliberations.

site_title: Are both Pence and Harris ready to be president?
summary: The US vice-presidential debate between Mike Pence and Kamala Harris has taken on significant importance due to President Donald Trump's age and health. Trump, 77, has contracted COVID-19 and is in isolation, raising concerns about his ability to complete his term. Pence, 61, and Harris, 55, represented two different faces of America, with Pence as a conservative Republican and Harris as a liberal Democrat. Both performed well in the debate, with Harris successfully highlighting the Trump administration's handling of the pandemic and Pence successfully portraying Harris as a representative of a left-leaning agenda.

site_title: Europe: Stocks near three-week high as US stimulus talks lift global mood
summary: Europe's stocks rose 0.8% to a near three-week high, driven by hopes of US stimulus and surged airline stocks. The German DAX and London's FTSE 100 also gained, while beaten-down sectors like banks and travel & leisure rose. Tech and pharma offered support, with UK oil majors and airline stocks jumping. However, the gains came despite surging COVID-19 cases across Europe, with over 17,500 new daily cases recorded in the UK.

site_title: Singtel launches 5G standalone trial network for enterprises
summary: Singtel launches Singapore's first 5G standalone trial network, offering enterprises early access to 5G at no charge. The network uses 3.5 GHz spectrum and Ericsson's Massive MIMO technology, delivering ultra-fast speeds and low latency. Enterprises can test-bed 5G applications and technologies at Singtel's 5G Garage facility. A trial with cloud-gaming provider Ubitus demonstrated an 85% lower latency compared to 4G. The trial will inform game designs, showcasing 5G's potential for applications like remote surgery and virtual reality.

site_title: In a world with too much oil, Opec+ sweats its next move
summary: Opec+ is debating its next move amid a slower-than-expected demand recovery and a glut of oil on the market. The cartel, which includes Saudi Arabia and Russia, had initially planned to increase production by 3 phases, but now considers delaying or spreading the output hike to fine-tune the increase. Some delegates think a short delay of 2-3 months is a "realistic" possibility, while others hope the market will be stronger by early December. The upcoming US presidential election and Libya's oil production recovery also pose uncertainties, and delegates are closely monitoring oil prices and inventories for clues.

site_title: Changing the business landscape with AI
summary: Artificial intelligence is transforming the business landscape, enhancing productivity and freeing up time for tasks requiring human insight. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated AI adoption, with Southeast Asia expected to reach a $1 trillion GDP uplift by 2030. Singapore has been proactive in embracing AI, with a national AI strategy and significant investments.
