Analysts from OCBC Investment Research and Citi see a mild positive on Singapore banks, with credit cost forecasts remaining comfortable despite the extension. The relief measures, which include partial loan deferrals and reduced instalment payments, are expected to limit the sector's earnings recovery ahead, with a modest growth outlook and prolonged low interest rates.

site_title: Facebook pulls Trump post for minimising Covid-19 danger
summary: Facebook removed a post by US President Donald Trump for downplaying the danger of Covid-19, stating the flu is more deadly, a rare step against the American leader. The post was removed for spreading "incorrect information about the severity of Covid-19." Twitter also added a notice and link to reliable Covid-19 information, citing rules about spreading misleading information. This marks the first time Facebook has removed a post from Trump's page for being "dangerously incorrect."

site_title: Biden says opposed to debate if Trump still has Covid-19
summary: US President Joe Biden stated he would oppose debating Donald Trump if Trump still has Covid-19, citing health guidelines. Trump announced he tested positive for the virus two days after their first debate. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend people with symptoms stay home for at least 10 days. Biden plans to follow doctors' advice, while Trump expressed no intention of canceling the debate. The two are scheduled to debate on October 15.

site_title: Terence Loh quits BN Group amid police probe into Novena Global Healthcare
summary: BN Group co-founder Terence Loh has resigned amid a police probe into Novena Global Healthcare Group (NGHG) over allegedly forged audit signatures on its financial statements. Loh's resignation comes as his company, Bellagraph Nova, was involved in a scandal over doctored photos of Barack Obama in its marketing materials. Loh and his cousin Nelson Loh have agreed to separate their business interests, with Loh transferring shares to Nelson for $1 and resigning as director of several companies. The police investigation is ongoing, and Loh has stated he was not involved in the forgery and is cooperating with the authorities.

site_title: Centurion prices S$9.8m notes due 2024
summary: Centurion Corporation has priced approximately S$9.8 million in fixed-rate notes due 2024. These notes carry a 5.75% coupon until April 11, 2023, and will rise to 8.25% thereafter. The notes will be fungible and consolidate with existing notes. Net proceeds will be used to purchase outstanding existing notes and redeem them on Feb 1, 2021. The new notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on or around Oct 13, and certain controlling shareholders have been allocated 11.1% of the new notes.

site_title: M1, Safra among big retailers with payments disrupted due to Wirecard's exit
summary: TELCO M1 and Safra, among major retailers in Singapore, are experiencing disruptions to their payment services due to Wirecard's exit. M1's monthly recurring payment mode is temporarily unavailable, while Safra is suspending online payment services. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) had ordered Wirecard entities to cease payment services on Oct 1, citing the firm's inability to process payments for a significant number of merchants. Thousands of merchants in Singapore rely on Wirecard's payment terminals, with some having already found alternative providers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Top Glove, Wilmar, Olam, SPH Reit, Centurion
summary: Top Glove Corp will pay RM136 million (S$44.5 million) in remediation fees to migrant workers. Wilmar International's China unit listing proceeds will fund 19 investment projects. Olam International up-sized its debt facility to US$1.98 billion. SPH Reit posted a lower half-year distribution per unit due to rent waivers and capital retention. Centurion Corp priced S$9.8 million in fixed-rate notes due 2024.

site_title: The debate between DPU and NAV
summary: The Singapore real estate investment trust (Reit) market has grown to $100 billion in market capitalization over 18 years, with 43 Reits and property trusts listed. Consolidation among Reits has increased, with three mergers completed and two pending approvals. The valuation of Reits in these transactions has drawn attention, with debates over whether to use distribution per unit (DPU) or price to net asset value (NAV). While DPU yield is attractive, it may not be a reliable indicator of a Reit's quality, and investors are increasingly considering holistic views beyond just DPU and NAV metrics.

site_title: Revolut partners Income to embed micro-insurance offerings on its app
summary: Revolut has partnered with NTUC Income's micro-insurance platform SNACK to embed insurance offerings on its app. Revolut customers can purchase term life, critical illness, and personal accident insurance through accumulated spare change in their "Savings Vault". A one-time $500 complimentary insurance coverage will be provided when signing up for an SNACK account. The partnership aims to offer low-cost, flexible insurance options to Revolut users, complementing the fintech's existing money-management features.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccine may be ready by year-end: WHO's Tedros
summary: WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus stated that a Covid-19 vaccine may be ready by the end of the year. He emphasized the need for solidarity and equal distribution of vaccines when they become available. The World Health Organization's Covax global vaccine facility aims to distribute 2 billion doses by the end of 2021, with nine experimental vaccines in development. Tedros also defended the WHO's role in the pandemic response, dismissing criticism from US President Donald Trump's administration.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda calls for more digitalisation, reform in Asia
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda emphasized the need for Asia to accelerate digitalization and business reform to achieve sustainable growth. He highlighted vulnerabilities in supply chains and social infrastructure, but noted that Asia's economy has been moderate compared to other regions. Kuroda also discussed the challenges of an ageing population, citing Japan as a prime example, and emphasized the potential of digitalization to boost growth potential. The call for reform comes as Japan's new prime minister Yoshihide Suga prioritizes digitalization as a key policy issue.

images.alt_text: Asia must accelerate digitalisation and business reform to tackle challenges to achieve sustainable growth, Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Wednesday, highlighting vulnerabilities in supply chains and social infrastructure.

site_title: Oil ends up on supply issues, nixed US stimulus talks a bearish sign
summary: Oil prices rose 2% due to expected supply disruptions from a hurricane in the Gulf of Mexico and an oil worker strike in Norway. However, US stimulus talks were derailed after US President Donald Trump said he would not negotiate a stimulus package until after the Nov 3 election, causing oil prices to ease. Brent crude futures settled at $42.65 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $40.67 a barrel. The US House Speaker and Treasury Secretary had been negotiating a $1.5-$2 trillion stimulus package before Trump's tweet.

site_title: JPMorgan aims to back clients to align with Paris climate pact
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. aims to support clients in investing in clean energy and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050, aligning with the Paris climate pact. The move comes as the Trump administration prepares to withdraw the US from the Paris accord, which aims to limit global warming to 2°C and ideally 1.5°C. Despite growing adoption of lower-carbon technologies, oil and natural gas remain prominent in long-distance transportation and heavy industry, making it challenging to meet the climate pact's goals.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan Chase & Co aims to support its clients in expanding investment in clean energy and work towards net zero-emissions by 2050, a move that aligns with the Paris climate pact of cutting carbon output, the bank said on Tuesday.

site_title: Why Europe is right to push back against China and Russia
summary: European Union leaders are right to push back against China and Russia's increasing influence, according to US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. China's Belt and Road Initiative and Russia's military cooperation pose significant challenges to the continent. Pompeo urged European leaders to take action against Beijing's economic and political influence, including its growing religious persecution. The EU must defend its interests in a fast-changing landscape, and cooperation with the US on this agenda is crucial, especially if Joe Biden wins the upcoming election.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower, extending falls on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, extending falls on Wall Street, as US President Donald Trump called off talks on a new stimulus plan until after the election. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.59% to 23,295.20, while the Topix index declined 0.62% to 1,635.59. This marks the latest in a series of market downturns, with the US stock market also experiencing a decline. The decision by Trump to delay stimulus talks has sparked concerns about the US economy and its impact on global markets.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday tracking falls on Wall Street after US President Donald Trump called off talks on a new stimulus plan until after the election.

site_title: Rock legend Eddie Van Halen dies after long battle with cancer
summary: Eddie Van Halen, the legendary guitar virtuoso and co-founder of the iconic rock band Van Halen, died on October 6, 2020, after a long battle with cancer, his son Wolf Van Halen announced. The 65-year-old musician, known for his innovative "finger tapping" technique and hits like "Jump" and "Eruption," had been battling health issues for years, including cancer, hip surgery, and a near-fatal throat surgery in 2000. Van Halen sold over 75 million albums and had more number one hits on the mainstream US rock chart than any other artist, leaving behind a legacy and tributes from fellow musicians and fans worldwide.

site_title: Oil gains on Trump hospital exit, supply disruptions
summary: Oil prices rose 0.9% on Tuesday due to supply disruptions in Norway and the Gulf of Mexico, with Brent crude futures up 38 cents at $41.67 a barrel and US WTI crude futures up 34 cents at $39.56 a barrel. A Norwegian oil workers' strike cut output by 8% and another hurricane in the Gulf of Mexico could shut facilities. US President Donald Trump's return to the White House after hospital treatment also boosted oil prices, with expectations of a new US stimulus package.

site_title: iPhone delay breaks supply chain rhythm
summary: Apple's delayed iPhone release in September has caused a ripple effect through its supply chain, with major vendors such as Foxconn and Largan Precision Co reporting significant declines in sales and revenue. The delay is attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has impacted manufacturing lines globally. Largan Precision Co's camera lens sales plummeted 22% in September, while Foxconn's Hon Hai Precision Industry Co unit reported a 21% drop. The delay has disrupted the usual supply chain rhythm, making it challenging for analysts to gauge the iPhone's performance.

site_title: Europe: Banks steal spotlight, help shares erase loses
summary: European stocks rose for a fourth consecutive session, with banks leading the gains due to hopes for a US stimulus package and a Brexit trade deal. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1% higher, with the banking index reaching its highest level in almost three weeks. Sectors exposed to the economic cycle, such as travel and leisure, oil and gas, and automakers, also rose. However, technology and healthcare stocks declined, weighing on the Stoxx 600.

site_title: UK's Sunak rejects idea that eat-out scheme spread virus
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak rejected the idea that a restaurant eat-out scheme contributed to the spread of the coronavirus, citing the difficulty in pinpointing the cause of transmission. Despite Prime Minister Boris Johnson suggesting the scheme may have helped spread the virus, Sunak pointed to lower virus incidence in areas with high scheme participation. The government is now imposing new restrictions on hospitality to combat a resurgence of the virus, including a 10pm curfew on pubs and restaurants.

site_title: Q3 prompt payments hit new low: credit bureau
summary: Prompt payments in Singapore's third quarter of 2020 hit a new low of 38.4%, down from 40.1% in the second quarter and 48.8% a year ago. Slow payments accounted for 44.2% of total payment transactions, a slight decrease from 45.8% in the previous quarter. Partial payments rose to 17.5%, with the construction sector experiencing significant delays due to the COVID-19 outbreak.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks plunge as Trump ends stimulus talks
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday after President Donald Trump ended stimulus talks, citing lack of good faith from Democrats. The Dow Jones fell 1.3%, the S&P 500 1.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite 1.6%. Trump's decision came after weeks of negotiations between House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. Investors had become optimistic about a potential stimulus package, but Trump's tweet calling off talks until after the election sent markets into a tailwind. Tech and airline shares were particularly affected.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks dropped on Tuesday, falling abruptly after President Donald Trump ended talks on another round of stimulus spending to support the coronavirus-ravaged US economy.

site_title: Assessing your organisation's digital skills gap
summary: Organisations seeking to transform their finance functions must assess digital gaps and skills affecting business models. According to Ho Yew Kee, associate provost (SkillsFuture), Singapore Institute of Technology, organisations should ask key questions about their digital skills gaps. This assessment is crucial for the effectiveness of their business models in the digitalisation era. By identifying and addressing these gaps, organisations can ensure their finance functions remain competitive and adaptable to changing market conditions.

site_title: Goh Jin Hian steps down as Cordlife chairman but staying on as ID
summary: Goh Jin Hian, son of former Singapore prime minister Goh Chok Tong, has stepped down as chairman of Cordlife Group with immediate effect, citing a desire to devote more time to personal affairs. He remains an independent director and non-executive chairman of New Silkroutes Group. Dr. Goh faces a lawsuit by Inter-Pacific Petroleum's judicial managers over alleged breaches of director's duties, funded by two major bank creditors. Cordlife's nominating committee and board allow the legal proceedings to run its course, while New Silkroutes believes the allegations are without merit.

site_title: Wilmar's YKA listing to help fund 19 investment projects in China
summary: Wilmar International's China unit, Yihai Kerry Arawana (YKA), is set to list on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange's ChiNext Board, raising 13.9 billion yuan (S$2.8 billion) from its IPO. The funds will be used to fund 19 investment projects, including 7 integrated facilities, 6 edible oil processing projects, and 4 flour processing projects. YKA aims to accelerate growth in China, the world's largest consumer food market, with a "huge expansion" of its agri-commodity processing and food product businesses.

site_title: Trump's son questioned in NY probe into family's asset valuations
summary: US President Donald Trump's son Eric was questioned under oath by New York Attorney-General Letitia James' office regarding whether the Trump Organization falsely reported property values to secure loans or tax benefits. Eric Trump, an executive vice-president at the Trump Organization, was deposed via video-conference on Monday after initially refusing to provide testimony. The probe focuses on properties including Seven Springs and 40 Wall Street, and the company has denied wrongdoing. The investigation is not expected to be completed before the November election.

site_title: Temasek to form asset management group Seviora
summary: Temasek Holdings is establishing Seviora Holdings, a Singapore-based asset management group, to offer a broad range of multi-asset and multi-strategy investment expertise. The group will oversee four existing asset management companies: Azalea Investment Management, Fullerton Fund Management Company, InnoVen Capital, and Seatown Holdings International, with a total AUM of S$75 billion. The new entity aims to provide a unified platform for Temasek's investment capabilities.

site_title: Banks in Singapore tie up for digital trade finance registry to mitigate fraud
summary: Banks in Singapore, led by DBS and Standard Chartered, are creating a digital trade finance registry to mitigate fraud and boost transparency in commodity trade finance. This comes after a slump in oil prices exposed financial weaknesses and alleged irregularities in the industry. The registry will provide a secure central database of trade transactions financed in Singapore, addressing concerns over fraud and irregularities.

site_title: Malaysia to impose targeted lockdowns to halt spike in Covid-19
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced targeted lockdowns to combat a spike in Covid-19 cases, with 691 new infections reported and four deaths. The lockdowns will focus on areas with high infection rates, allowing economic and social activities to continue elsewhere under strict health protocols. The government is also considering shutting schools and limiting mass gatherings. The move aims to control the outbreak while avoiding a nationwide lockdown that could harm the economy and social systems.

site_title: Ant Group's IPO reveals how investors must pick sides
summary: Ant Group's upcoming IPO has sparked controversy among investors due to the practice of some Chinese companies requiring investors to pledge not to invest in rivals or potential rivals. This tactic, aimed at preventing conflicts of interest and sensitive information leaks, has led to investors being forced to choose sides, with some being barred from investing in companies deemed competitors. The practice has intensified rivalry between business camps, particularly between Alibaba and Tencent, and has raised questions about its effectiveness in preventing rival companies from securing capital.

site_title: Local golf clubs cracking down on first bot, first served booking
summary: Singapore's private golf clubs are cracking down on "bots" used by members to secure popular flight bookings, resulting in many being frozen out. The clubs, including Singapore Island Country Club and Orchid Country Club, have introduced new rules and regulations to prevent abuse, including publishing timesheets online and disqualifying booking forms with repeated names. The move aims to ensure "fair play" and prevent members from exploiting the system, with some clubs warning of action against those found to be abusing the system.

site_title: HDB to get powers to seize flats if misleading statements on transfer of flat ownership are made
summary: The Housing Board (HDB) in Singapore will have new powers to seize flats if flat owners make misleading statements during the transfer of flat ownership. The changes to the Housing and Development Act also allow approved banks to pledge HDB flat loans as collateral for liquidity from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Minister for National Development Desmond Lee assured HDB flat owners that their rights will not be affected and that the HDB will investigate each case thoroughly before taking action.

site_title: 2020 US elections: Uncertainty? Yes. Opportunities? Also yes
summary: The 2020 US general election is approaching, with investors paying close attention to the potential policy changes. A Biden win could lead to increased corporate taxes and fiscal spending, boosting Asian equities and the greenback. In contrast, a Trump re-election could intensify US-China relations, causing shockwaves in Asian markets. Investors should not overreact to election outcomes, as economic fundamentals and valuations remain more important. A Biden win could lead to a moderate rise in corporate taxes and federal spending, while a Trump re-election may trigger price action similar to 2016, with high-tax companies outperforming.

site_title: Lang Lang: The pianist who does too much
summary: Lang Lang's new recording of Bach's Goldberg Variations has sparked criticism for its overindulgent and expressive playing style, which some find marred by exaggerated interpretive touches. The pianist's seriousness of purpose is evident, but his approach risks making the music seem mannered and affected. Compared to other notable recordings by Jeremy Denk and Beatrice Rana, Lang's performance is deemed too flashy and lacking in subtlety, failing to strike a balance between bold personality and restraint. Despite his technical skill, Lang's playing style may not be to every listener's taste.

site_title: Reassess 2020 winners, reduce exposure to supermarkets, glove makers: DBS
summary: DBS Group Research has recommended that investors reassess their positions, particularly reducing exposure to "2020 winners" such as supermarkets and glove makers. The analysts cite the successful outcome of vaccine trials as a positive sign, which could lead to a shift in focus towards tech, logistics, and yield plays. They suggest selling into rallies for glove makers, while maintaining exposure to tech stocks like Venture Corp and real estate investment trusts (Reits) like Keppel Reit and Mapletree Commercial Trust.

site_title: The abrupt ouster of banking's sole black CEO
summary: Tidjane Thiam, the first black CEO of Credit Suisse, was abruptly ousted in February 2020 after a surveillance scandal involving his No. 2, Iqbal Khan, who was accused of spying on employees. Thiam denied knowledge of the spy games, but his name was tarnished by association. The scandal, known as "Spygate," led to a probe by the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority and a public apology from Credit Suisse's chairman, Urs Rohner. Despite his efforts to turn around the bank's fortunes, Thiam's resignation was seen as swift and remarkably little notice was given to his ouster outside Zurich, months before a global reckoning with systemic bias.

site_title: SPH Reit posts lower H2 DPU on rent waivers, capital retention
summary: SPH Reit reported a 2.8-cent decline in half-year distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.04 Singapore cents due to rent waivers and capital retention measures amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue and net property income fell 7.4% and 14.9%, respectively, primarily due to rental waivers of S$31.8 million. Despite this, the Reit's full-year result showed a 5.6% increase in gross revenue and a 1.2% improvement in net property income.

site_title: Retrenchments hit 4.9 per 1,000 local employees in H1
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo reported 4.9 local retrenchments per 1,000 local employees in the first half of 2020, with 5.2 per 1,000 for senior workers aged 60 and above. Half of the retrenched locals were women.

images.alt_text: For senior workers aged 60 and above, the incidence of local retrenchment was 5.2 per 1,000 local employees, said Manpower Minister Josephine Teo in Parliament on Tuesday.

site_title: Rules clarity a plus for Grab, Gojek in S-E Asian minefield
summary: Singapore's regulatory framework for the point-to-point (P2P) transport sector is set to be rolled out, providing clarity for ride-hailing firms Grab and Gojek. The licensing regime, which requires firms with over 800 vehicles to be licensed, may add compliance costs but is seen as friendlier than other South-east Asian markets. The regulations aim to strike a balance between innovation and maintaining a competitive playing field, and Singapore's approach is considered ahead of the curve in terms of regulatory clarity.

site_title: Becoming more agile, more resilient
summary: Companies can adapt to a post-pandemic world by rapidly adopting new technologies and dismantling hierarchical decision-making structures. Agile methods have proven effective in responding to the crisis, with companies achieving performance gains by adopting lean, fast, and agile organizational structures. Examples include a bank establishing a small team to expand online capacity, and a consumer goods company transforming its production to make personal protective equipment. The successful responses of companies have challenged commonly-held beliefs on how to run a large organization, and many now aim to retain the newfound speed by adopting a more fundamental reset of their operating model.

site_title: Covid-19 worsens crisis in world's most unaffordable housing market
summary: Hong Kong's housing market remains unaffordable despite a severe recession and rising unemployment, with rents staying high and home prices forecast to shrink 8% this year. The city's median income is just 35% that of New York's, making it difficult for blue-collar workers and those on the fringes of poverty to find affordable living spaces. The number of "street sleepers" has increased, and living conditions for some have worsened, with many forced to live in cramped, unhygienic spaces. The government is struggling to address the crisis, and the situation is seen as a major source of discontent among the population.

site_title: Transforming the finance function in the digital age
summary: Organisations need to invest in new capabilities and talent to stay relevant in the digital economy. To do this, companies must develop a strategy for digital transformation, focusing on enterprise capabilities and value creation. Data analytics is key, and business analytics should be a priority for all employees. Companies should also hire data scientists and IT graduates, and train all employees about the role of analytics in their roles. The finance department should also adopt a 'T' shape education model, combining digital skills with deep technical skills. To accelerate adoption, companies should embark on small pilot projects and digitise critical finance tasks first.

site_title: Construction in UK shows surprise acceleration in September
summary: The UK construction industry experienced a surprise acceleration in September, with the IHS Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 56.8 from 54.6 in August, exceeding economists' forecasts. This uptick was attributed to a post-lockdown rebound in the housing market. The result suggests a stronger-than-expected recovery in the sector, which had been expected to slow down.

site_title: US dollar steadies after falling on sharper risk appetite
summary: The US dollar steadied on Tuesday after weakening against most currencies, as rising optimism over potential new stimulus and reduced political uncertainty boosted risk appetite. The dollar index was last flat at 93.49, following a 1% decline from a two-month high in September. The euro and British pound were also relatively stable, while the Japanese yen fell 0.2% against the dollar. Analysts expect potential US fiscal stimulus to be negative for the dollar due to accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Trump returns to White House after three days in hospital
summary: US President Donald Trump returned to the White House on Monday after a three-day hospital stay for COVID-19 treatment. Trump received medical care including powerful medicines and an airlift to the hospital, and his condition has improved. He will stay in the White House residence and avoid the Oval Office, with aides taking precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. Trump's aides hope to keep him at the residence for a few days before returning to normal, and his doctors remain cautious about his condition.

site_title: Grade A office leasing in Singapore still sluggish in Q3 amid work-from-home trend
summary: Singapore's Grade A office leasing activity remained sluggish in Q3, with rents declining 5.1% quarter-over-quarter to S$9.84 per sq ft per month. Despite this, some firms are reevaluating their office needs, while others are seizing opportunities to expand into more attractive spaces. Chinese tech firms, such as ByteDance and Tencent, are driving new demand, with plans to establish regional hubs and expand their operations. The market is expected to remain challenging, with widespread remote work and structural impacts affecting leasing demand in the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Capital cycles provide clues on when could be a good time to invest
summary: Capital cycles can provide clues on when to invest, as they describe the ebbs and flows of economic growth. These cycles, similar to those in nature, can be seen in various sectors, including oil and gas, where a cyclical low may be imminent. In economics, debt cycles and inventory cycles also exist, influencing business and economic trends. Understanding these cycles can help investors make informed decisions and potentially capitalize on opportunities.

site_title: GIC plans to invest more than US$1b in Ant IPO
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC plans to invest over $1 billion in Ant Group's mega IPO, which could raise up to $35 billion. GIC and Temasek Holdings are considering both Hong Kong and Shanghai listings. China's National Council for Social Security Fund also plans to purchase shares in the mainland sale. Ant Group's IPO, led by Jack Ma, could be the world's largest, surpassing Saudi Aramco's record sale.

site_title: US economic recovery far from complete, says Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warned that the US economic recovery remains far from complete, citing the risk of a downward spiral if the coronavirus is not effectively controlled. He urged more help for businesses and households, stating that the risks of policy intervention are still asymmetric. Powell noted that the worst has been avoided, but the pace of improvement has moderated, with slower job growth and notable layoff announcements. He warned that prolonged slowing could trigger recessionary dynamics, potentially leading to a weaker recovery.

site_title: With no federal aid, Southwest Airlines seeks pay cuts
summary: Southwest Airlines is seeking pay cuts from unions to prevent furloughs and layoffs due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The airline aims to reduce costs and match 1970s levels of demand by scaling back flight schedules and parking jets. Non-union staff salaries will be cut by 10% until January 2022, with unions representing 83% of employees agreeing to meet and discuss cost savings. The move follows American Airlines and United Airlines' furloughs of 32,000 employees, with Southwest's CEO Gary Kelly warning of potential furloughs if a federal aid package does not pass.

site_title: Singapore plans Air Travel Bubbles for general travellers to revive Changi air hub
summary: Singapore plans to establish Air Travel Bubbles with safe countries or regions, allowing general travellers to cross borders without a controlled itinerary. This move aims to revive Changi air hub. Travellers will be required to adhere to Covid-19 test protocols to manage risks. The Air Travel Bubbles are distinct from Reciprocal Green Lanes for official and essential business travel.

site_title: Changi falls from 7th to 58th on the world's busiest airport list
summary: Changi Airport has dropped to 58th on the world's busiest airport list due to the COVID-19 pandemic, serving only 1.5% of Singapore's usual passenger volume and 6% of usual flights. Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung attributed the decline to the lack of domestic air travel. Singapore Airlines is also facing challenges, with Ong Ye Kung stating they are "far from being out of the woods".

site_title: Taking stock of 2020, and challenges ahead
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping's (ICS) Annual Review highlights the ongoing challenges facing the global shipping industry, particularly the crew change crisis caused by COVID-19 restrictions, affecting 400,000 seafarers. ICS also discusses the need for decarbonization, with ongoing negotiations at the International Maritime Organization (IMO) and a proposed $5 billion fund to accelerate zero-carbon technologies. However, the review notes that the European Union's plan to apply its Emissions Trading Scheme to shipping could undermine IMO's progress and be seen as an "extraterritorial tax" on international trade.

site_title: Blogger Leong Sze Hian made no attempt to ascertain truth when sharing article with false allegations: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong testified in a defamation hearing against blogger Leong Sze Hian, who shared a false article accusing Lee of signing "secret deals" with former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak. Lee stated that Leong made no effort to verify the truth of the allegations and that suing him was the best course of action to vindicate his reputation. Lee's lawyer argued that suing Leong was an easy way out, and that Lee should have sued the original author, Alex Tan.

site_title: Global economy 'less dire', but long climb ahead: IMF chief
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief, Kristalina Georgieva, stated that the global economy is "coming back from the depths of this crisis," with a "small" upward revision to its 2020 global output forecast. The IMF now projects a 4.2% contraction, down from 4.9% in June. Georgieva warned that the recovery will be "long, uneven, and uncertain," with a "partial and uneven" recovery in 2021. She emphasized the need for more policy support, particularly for low-income countries facing a "precarious situation" with weak health systems and high external debt.

site_title: Everything crossed over: Michael Clark's cheeky world of dance
summary: Michael Clark's comprehensive exhibition, "Cosmic Dancer," at the Barbican Art Gallery, celebrates his career as a dancer, choreographer, and art world darling. The show, which runs from October 7 to January 3, features eye-popping graphics, film installations, and high-profile collaborations with artists and musicians. Clark's provocative and inventive dance style, influenced by Merce Cunningham and the Cecchetti ballet technique, captivated young audiences in 1980s London, earning him a reputation as a trailblazer in the dance world. Despite struggling with addiction and personal issues, Clark's work continues to be celebrated for its clean lines, precision, and profound impact.

site_title: SBI Group and Sygnum target up to US$75m for early-stage fund
summary: SBI Group and Sygnum have partnered to raise a new early-stage fund targeting US$50-75 million to invest in digital-asset economy companies in South-east Asia and Europe. The fund will focus on companies developing digital ledger technology-based infrastructure, decentralized finance solutions, and regulatory tools. SBI Ven Capital will play an active role with portfolio companies, providing corporate governance, business development, and operational support. The fund aims to close during the first quarter of next year and will be tokenized.

site_title: Walmart to sell Medicare plans in latest healthcare push
summary: Walmart announced it will sell Medicare insurance plans in 50 US states and Washington D.C. through its broker, starting October 15. The company, which already operates health centers, will offer policies from Humana, UnitedHealth Group, and Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield. This move comes as health insurers face rising costs due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Walmart's entry into the Medicare market aims to provide low-cost options to Americans 65 and older, or those with disabilities.

site_title: Steering startups: From adviser to director
summary: The startup ecosystem in South-east Asia has been growing, but the pandemic has hit it hard. According to Preqin, there was a record high of 576 venture capital deals in 2019, but private equity and venture capital activity in Asia was sluggish in Q1 2020. Founders and investors tend to be optimistic, but independent directors can provide an impartial judge of what's best for the company. Strong corporate governance, diverse skill sets, and good networks are key for startups to steer through turbulent times.

site_title: Airlines warn of more bankruptcies as wage support ends
summary: Global airlines warn that the coronavirus-stricken industry will burn through $77 billion in cash in the second half of 2020, citing the end of expiring wage support programs. Airlines have already consumed $51 billion in cash in the second quarter. The industry is calling for renewed support, with Iata warning of potential bankruptcies, especially during the winter months. With cash reserves averaging 8.5 months, airlines are facing a tough winter with seasonally weak cash flows. Airlines are also pushing for pre-flight Covid-19 tests to replace quarantines and travel restrictions.

site_title: Arrests of EHT directors cast spotlight on directorship rules, responsibilities
summary: Six directors of Eagle Hospitality Trust in Singapore were arrested on October 1, 2020, on suspicion of breaches of disclosure rules. The directors, who also sit on other boards, have been released on bail. The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) is assessing their suitability to remain in their positions. Corporate governance experts express concerns, citing the lack of power to remove directors and the need for ongoing assessments. The case may have significant implications for corporate governance in Singapore, with some directors potentially facing charges.

site_title: Standard testing protocols the way to open borders: Airbus Asia-Pac chief
summary: Airbus Asia-Pac chief Anand Stanley calls for a shift from restrictive border closures to standard testing protocols to restore air travel in the Asia-Pacific region, where air traffic has been severely impacted by the pandemic. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) also advocates for systematic testing of all international travelers before departure. Implementing quarantine requirements discourages travel demand, similar to border closures, and Singapore's efforts to open up more routes within the region are seen as a positive step forward.

images.alt_text: Singapore can lead by example and bring down barriers by working with countries in the region where the rate of infection is low such as Japan, Australia and New Zealand, said Anand Stanley of Airbus.

site_title: Airbus unveils new business jet in hunt for corporate demand
summary: Airbus unveiled a new business jet, the A220 model, targeting corporate demand as the pandemic hits commercial flights. The aircraft has three times more cabin space and costs a third less to run than competitors. Six orders were announced, including two from Comlux, with deliveries expected to connect London to Los Angeles. Despite gloomy predictions for business travel, the aircraft's market appeal is seen as promising, with a rebound in global air-traffic levels expected in 2023 or 2025. This move aims to boost Airbus' corporate jet division, which has been impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: iPhone makers win nod for US$143b India manufacturing plan
summary: Apple and its primary suppliers, including Foxconn Technology, Wistron, Pegatron, and Samsung Electronics, have been approved to manufacture products in India under a $143 billion plan. The plan aims to attract investment in mobile-phone production and increase exports by 60% over five years. Local manufacturers Lava, Padget Electronics, UTL Neolyncs, and Optiemus Electronics were also approved. The move is an attempt by India to lure smartphone brands away from China due to the ongoing global trade war and Covid-19 pandemic, which has highlighted supply chain risks.

site_title: GIC plans to invest more than US$1b in Ant
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC plans to invest over $1 billion in Ant Group's IPO, considering participation in both Hong Kong and Shanghai legs. This investment, along with Temasek Holdings and China's National Council for Social Security Fund, could raise up to $35 billion, making it the world's largest IPO. Ant Group is valued at $250 billion, surpassing major US companies like Bank of America and Citigroup. The investment plans are preliminary and subject to change.

site_title: Eastern Germany has a new growth engine in EVs
summary: Eastern Germany is experiencing a surge in electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing, with Volkswagen, BMW, and Tesla investing in new production facilities. The region's high wages and recent policy announcements from the European Union and German government have made it an attractive location for EV producers. The European Green Deal and subsidies from the German government have enabled eastern German states to offer incentives to attract EV producers, potentially re-industrializing the region and generating prosperity. This marks a significant development for eastern Germany, which has struggled with de-industrialization since reunification in 1990.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's ADIA to invest US$750m in Mukesh Ambani's retail unit
summary: Abu Dhabi's ADIA invests $750 million in Reliance Industries' retail arm, Reliance Retail Ventures. The investment values the business at 4.29 trillion rupees and brings total funding to $6.9 billion. This round of investments, led by ADIA, follows successful fundraising by Reliance Industries' technology venture, Jio Platforms, which raised over $20 billion earlier this year. The move accelerates Reliance's efforts to transform into a retail and technology behemoth, driven by Asia's richest man, Mukesh Ambani.

site_title: PM Lee: Leong Sze Hian made no attempt to ascertain the truth when sharing article
summary: PM Lee Hsien Loong testified in a defamation hearing, stating that Leong Sze Hian made no attempt to verify the truth of an article he shared, which alleged PM Lee had signed secret deals with former Malaysian PM Najib Razak. PM Lee claimed this was "reckless disregard of the truth" and not a matter of courage. Leong's lawyer, Lim Tean, argued that PM Lee chose to sue Leong, a vocal critic of the government, rather than the article's originator, Alex Tan, and the publication, The Coverage.

site_title: How many firms under JM could be staring down the barrel of liquidation?
summary: JM, a Singapore-based conglomerate, may be staring down the barrel of liquidation for several firms under its umbrella. The company had previously attempted to rescue debt-hit ZenRock Commodities Trading, a crude oil and petroleum products trader, with severe financial strain caused by oil price drops and credit tightness earlier this year.

site_title: Australia to run record budget deficit as government cuts tax, boosts job support
summary: Australia's conservative government has unveiled a record A$300 billion in emergency stimulus to pull the country out of its historic COVID-19 slump. The budget includes A$17.8 billion in personal tax cuts and A$5.2 billion in new job-boosting programs, aiming to create one million new jobs over four years. The measures forecast a record A$213.7 billion budget deficit, or 11% of GDP, for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2021.

site_title: IMF chief says global economy 'less dire' but long climb ahead
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva stated that the global economy is "coming back from the depths of this crisis" but faces a "long, uneven, and uncertain" recovery. The IMF is expected to revise its 2020 global output forecast upward, with a 4.9% contraction expected to shrink global GDP. Georgieva emphasized the need for continued policy support from governments and central banks to navigate the challenging economic landscape.

site_title: Fed's Powell: Incomplete recovery could still slip into recessionary dynamics
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell warned that the economic recovery remains incomplete and could slip into recessionary dynamics if the coronavirus is not effectively controlled. The risks of policy intervention are still asymmetric, with too little support potentially leading to a weak recovery. Powell noted that government loans and enhanced unemployment benefits have supported a strong but incomplete recovery, but the pace of improvement has moderated, with slower job growth and layoff announcements. A prolonged slowdown could trigger typical recessionary dynamics.

site_title: Trump says he feels great, looking to debate Joe Biden next week
summary: President Donald Trump stated he feels "great" after a four-day stay at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center for COVID-19 treatment. He plans to debate Joe Biden next week and is considering a televised address to the nation. Trump downplayed the severity of COVID-19, likening it to the flu, despite recent polls showing him falling behind Biden. The president's deficit to Biden has widened to 16 points, with 57% of likely voters backing Biden and 41% supporting Trump.

site_title: AirAsia X proposes debt restructuring in bid for survival
summary: AirAsia X, the long-haul arm of Malaysia's budget airline, has proposed restructuring its debt of approximately RM63.5 billion (S$20.7 billion) and reducing its issued share capital by 90% to avoid liquidation. The move comes after the airline was hard hit by the coronavirus pandemic, with most planes grounded for months. The proposal includes consolidating every 10 existing ordinary shares into one share and seeking to have any remaining debt waived. The restructuring plan aims to ensure the airline's survival.

site_title: Top Glove to pay RM136m in remediation fees to migrant workers
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, will pay a revised RM136 million in remediation fees to migrant workers who joined the company before a new standard for ethical recruitment was implemented in 2019. This exceeds the previous RM53 million and will be paid over the next 10 months. The company has submitted an audit report on its labor practices to the US Customs and Border Protection, aiming for an "expeditious resolution" of a detention order related to two of its subsidiaries.

site_title: Hollywood shutdowns to cost insurer millions
summary: Allianz, Europe's largest insurer, is bracing for coronavirus-related claims from the entertainment industry, which was severely impacted by lockdowns and production shutdowns. The company has set aside 488 million euros (S$782.5 million) for claims this year, with much of it coming from Hollywood studios. The resumption of film productions is slow, and Allianz has stopped selling new coverage to protect against future losses. The company has also expanded its insurance offerings to include live music, events, and motorsports.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Dow gain on prospects of more stimulus
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Dow climbing as investors awaited potential fiscal stimulus from Washington. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 65.60 points, while the S&P 500 opened slightly higher. The Nasdaq Composite, however, dropped 17.95 points due to a sell-off in technology stocks. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and President Trump's recent threats to extend the stock market rally.

site_title: SPH Reit posts H2 DPU of 1.04 cent after distribution deferment, capital allowance
summary: SPH Reit reported a half-year distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.04 Singapore cent, down 63.7% from 2.85 cents last year, due to a 79.4% drop in income available for distribution. Revenue fell 7.4% to S$108.1 million, and net property income declined 14.9% to S$78.4 million. The Reit deferred S$14.5 million in distribution and used S$15 million in capital allowance to manage finances. Full-year results showed a 5.6% increase in gross revenue and a 1.2% improvement in net property income to S$181.9 million.

site_title: Malaysia to impose targeted lockdowns to halt infections surge
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced targeted lockdowns to combat the surge in coronavirus infections, with 691 new cases and four deaths reported on Tuesday. The lockdowns will focus on areas with high infection rates, aiming to avoid a nationwide lockdown that could harm the country's economy and social systems. This decision comes after a sharp spike in cases over the past two weeks, following an election in the state of Sabah last month.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's health ministry reported 691 new Covid-19 cases and four deaths on Tuesday, setting another new daily record in the aftermath of an election in the state of Sabah last month.

site_title: 'Big progress' in Brexit talks leaves EU seeing trade deal closer: sources
summary: Britain and the EU are close to agreement on reciprocal social security rights for their citizens after Brexit, with EU diplomats indicating that talks may continue until mid-November to avoid a "no-deal" scenario. Despite no breakthrough on contentious issues like fishing rights and competition guarantees, prospects for an overall accord appear brighter. The EU is now gearing up to negotiate until the end of the year, rather than cutting talks off earlier. This development suggests that a trade deal may be closer than initially thought.

site_title: US trade deficit jumps to largest in 14 years in August
summary: The US trade deficit surged to its largest in 14 years in August, jumping 5.9% to $67.1 billion, with imports increasing 3.2% to $239 billion and exports rising 2.2% to $171.9 billion. This widening trade gap could be a drag on economic growth in the third quarter. The closely watched trade deficit with China decreased $1.9 billion to $26.4 billion, but global trade flows are still recovering from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Axis Bank joins India's top private lenders to increase pay
summary: Axis Bank, India's third-largest private lender, has increased staff salaries between 4% and 12% from October 1, based on performance, as the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic threatens profit growth. The bank also paid bonuses to its staff. This move follows similar actions by larger rivals HDFC Bank and ICICI Bank, which boosted salaries and paid bonuses in April and July, respectively.

site_title: South Korean retail investors bid over US$50b to win coveted shares in BTS label
summary: South Korean retail investors submitted over $50 billion in bids for shares in Big Hit Entertainment, the label behind K-pop sensation BTS. The bids, valued at 135,000 won per share, exceeded 600 times the offered value. The total 58.4 trillion won (S$68.4 billion) in orders was just shy of a record for a retail IPO in September. The late bids from individual investors came on the second day of orders.

site_title: Malaysian green bonds should move beyond power projects: Report
summary: Malaysian green bond issuances reached US$1.3 billion in 2019, making the country's market the fourth-largest in ASEAN. Analysts from Maybank Kim Eng suggest issuers expand their offerings beyond power projects to cater to growing institutional investors and ESG investing. Currently, 11 out of 15 sustainable bond issuers are in the energy segment, with 70% of outstanding bonds allocated to solar and hydroelectric power plants. The analysts also highlight the need for external reviews to verify sustainable bonds and frameworks amid concerns about greenwashing.

site_title: Olam upsizes flagship debt facility to US$1.98b
summary: Olam International has upsized its flagship debt facility to US$1.98 billion, up from US$1.68 billion, after four new banks joined its multi-tranche revolving credit facility. The new banks include Bank of Baroda, Bank of China, Unicredit Bank, and Westpac Banking Corporation. The facility will be used to refinance existing loans and comprises three tranches with maturities of 364 days, two years, and three years.

site_title: Brazil soybean planting delay to affect supply in January -AgRural
summary: Brazil's soybean planting delay due to rainfall scarcity may impact supply in January, benefiting US soybean farmers. As of October 1, only 1.6% of Brazil's estimated soybean area was planted, below a five-year average. With most of Brazil's crop ready to be shipped in January, port premiums increased by 25% in February 2021, reflecting strong demand for freight in the second month. This may also affect cotton farmers who may opt to plant corn instead of cotton after soybean harvest.

site_title: Hogan Lovells hires Nick Williams as partner in business restructuring practice
summary: Hogan Lovells has hired Nick Williams as a partner in its business restructuring practice, based in Singapore. Williams, a leading figure in Singapore's cross-border restructuring and insolvency market, brings experience working with banks, financial institutions, and corporate creditors. His expertise will benefit clients on complex restructuring and insolvency matters, with the firm expecting to grow its practice in Asia and beyond.

site_title: STI extends rally upon Trump's return to White House, gains 0.5%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.48% to 2,529.26, driven by investor confidence after US President Donald Trump's return to the White House. Singapore Airlines gained 1.43% and Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung's support for the aviation sector boosted the index. Asian markets also followed suit, with the Nikkei 225 Index up 0.52% and the Hang Seng Index closing up 0.9%. The rally comes ahead of the US presidential election polls, with Democratic candidate Joe Biden polling ahead of Trump.

site_title: US business leaders reaffirm confidence in Singapore's ability to seize opportunities amid Covid-19
summary: US business leaders in Singapore reaffirmed confidence in the city-state's ability to seize opportunities and overcome the Covid-19 pandemic challenges. The affirmation was based on the Singapore government's strong commitment. Over 40 US business leaders, including top executives from various industries, attended a dialogue session with Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. The session highlighted Singapore's potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging and advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung announced continued support for the aviation sector amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The Jobs Support Scheme and Enhanced Aviation Support Package will benefit the sector. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo reported a low incidence of local retrenchment, at 4.9 per 1,000 local employees in the first half of 2020. Temasek Holdings launched Seviora Holdings, a US$75 billion asset management group. DBS and Standard Chartered led a workgroup to develop a digital Trade Finance Registry pilot. Olam International upsized its flagship debt facility to US$1.98 billion.

site_title: Tasmanian Devils set paw on mainland Australia after 3,000 years
summary: Tasmanian Devils, the world's largest surviving marsupial carnivore, have been released back into the wild on mainland Australia for the first time in 3,000 years. Conservation groups, including Aussie Ark, Global Wildlife Conservation, and WildArk, have been breeding devils and plan to release 20 more next year and another 20 the following year. The reintroduction aims to re-balance the ecosystem damaged by invasive predators and is seen as a "monumental" moment in rebuilding Australia's ecosystem, according to conservation group president Tim Faulkner.

site_title: Temasek to set up asset management group Seviora with S$75b AUM
summary: Temasek Holdings is establishing Seviora Holdings, a Singapore-based asset management group with approximately S$75 billion in assets under management (AUM). The group will oversee four existing asset management companies: Azalea Investment Management, Fullerton Fund Management Company, InnoVen Capital, and Seatown Holdings International. The new structure aims to accelerate business growth through scale, synergistic product offerings, and technology investments. Seviora's chairman is Goh Yew Lin, and Jimmy Phoon will serve as CEO-designate, holding both positions concurrently until a successor is appointed.

site_title: Telia strikes US$1b deal to sell carrier unit to Polhem
summary: Telia Company has agreed to sell its carrier unit to Polhem Infra in a deal worth over $1 billion. The 9.45 billion-krona (S$1.44 billion) deal is on a cash and debt-free basis. Following the sale, Telia plans to resume dividend payments, citing "improved visibility" and a "strengthened balance sheet" after selling stakes in Turkcell Holding and Telia Carrier.

site_title: Three share Nobel Physics Prize for black hole research
summary: Roger Penrose, Reinhard Genzel, and Andrea Ghez have shared the 2020 Nobel Prize in physics for their research into black holes, a prediction of the general theory of relativity. Penrose's discovery that black hole formation is a robust prediction of the theory, and Genzel and Ghez's discovery of a supermassive compact object at the centre of the galaxy, earned them the prize. The award recognizes their work on the nature of black holes, which were first proposed by Albert Einstein's general theory of relativity.

site_title: 11 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including two in the community
summary: Singapore reported 11 new Covid-19 cases, bringing the total to 57,830. The cases include two in the community and five from worker dormitories, with four being imported. The Ministry of Health confirmed the cases on Tuesday noon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.96 points to 1,509.47. The index saw 6.026 billion lots traded worth RM3.801 billion, with 748 losers outnumbering 315 gainers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks extended their gains for the third consecutive trading day, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.90% to 23,980.65. The surge was fueled by Wall Street's reaction to stimulus hopes and news that Donald Trump had left hospital after testing positive for coronavirus. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: South Korean search giant fined US$23m for manipulating results
summary: South Korea's search giant Naver was fined $23 million for manipulating search results in favor of its online shopping service. The Korea Fair Trade Commission ruled Naver altered algorithms between 2012 and 2015 to boost its own items' rankings, distorting market competition and deceiving customers. Naver dominates the South Korean online shopping market with a 70% share, but rejected the ruling and vowed to appeal. This is the first time Seoul has punished a search operator for making algorithmic changes for its own benefit.

site_title: Abu Dhabi to create food & beverage giant under ADQ
summary: Abu Dhabi plans to create a food and beverage giant by combining two companies, Al Foah and Agthia Group, under ADQ's state-owned holding company. Al Foah, the world's largest date processing and packaging company, will be transferred to Agthia in exchange for a convertible instrument worth 450 million dirhams. The combined entity will become a domestic champion in water, dates, flour, and animal feed, becoming one of the top 10 consumer food and beverage players in the MENA region.

site_title: Daimler to map out deeper overhaul, electric-vehicle plans at investor meeting
summary: Daimler, the world's bestselling luxury-car maker, is set to outline its electric vehicle plans and cost-cutting strategies at an investor meeting. CEO Ola Kallenius is expected to highlight Mercedes-Benz's future product plans, including accelerating electric vehicle development and streamlining its legacy combustion-engine portfolio. The company is also expected to address investor concerns over restructuring talks and job cuts. After a challenging year, investors are looking for clarity on the company's plans to meet stricter emissions regulations and improve its financial performance.

site_title: Hong Kong teacher struck off for 'pro-independence' classes
summary: A Hong Kong teacher has been struck off for allegedly promoting independence in class, marking the first time a teaching licence has been revoked due to lesson content. The Education Bureau cited "deliberately disseminating pro-independence messages" without specifying details. The move is part of a crackdown on democracy supporters in the city, following the imposition of a security law and calls for more patriotic education. The decision was hailed by Chief Executive Carrie Lam as a blow against "black sheep" in the education system, but critics fear it undermines Hong Kong's reputation for academic freedom.

site_title: Locks, chains: coronavirus puts Indonesia's mentally ill back in shackles
summary: Indonesia is experiencing a resurgence of locking up people with mental health issues due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The practice, which was once widespread but has been largely phased out, has seen hundreds of thousands of people with mental health conditions being confined for years. According to Human Rights Watch, the pandemic has exacerbated the problem, with Indonesia's health ministry reporting over 6,000 cases of "shackling" in the first half of 2020. The lockdowns have also restricted access to medication and community-based mental health services, forcing families to resort to the old methods of locking up their loved ones.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady with Trump back in the White House
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied on Tuesday with investors relieved by US President Donald Trump's return to the White House after hospital treatment for Covid-19. This lifted uncertainty over the US presidential election and potential delays. Fresh hope for a new US stimulus package also bolstered sentiment. Markets were initially down, but rebounded with London's FTSE 100 declining 0.1%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.1%, and Paris' CAC 40 up 0.2%.

site_title: Oil pipeline operators offer new discounts as demand craters
summary: US oil pipeline operators are offering discounts to encourage customers to use their networks, amid the pandemic's impact on profits. Kinder Morgan and Energy Transfer are slashing fees by 50% on certain pipelines, while Magellan Midstream Partners LP is negotiating lower tariffs. The discounts aim to combat sluggish oil consumption and a drilling slowdown in the Permian Basin. The move follows previous efforts during the 2014-2015 downturn, as US crude prices crashed due to Saudi Arabia's market flooding. The discounts reflect the industry's efforts to cover transport costs and variable charges.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS says 'relook 2020 winners', reduce exposure to supermarkets, glove makers
summary: DBS Group Research advises investors to reassess their positions, recommending a reduction in exposure to "2020 winners" such as supermarkets and glove makers. Analysts cite the impact of stay-at-home orders on the sector. With potential vaccine trials outcomes expected by October and Q1 2021, DBS suggests focusing on tech, logistics, and yield plays instead. This comes as the first vaccine trial outcome may be imminent, potentially shifting market sentiment.

site_title: German industrial orders rose at a 'remarkable pace' in August
summary: German industrial orders rose 4.5% in August, exceeding economists' forecast of 2.6%, driven by strong demand from the euro zone. The recovery in orders remains intact, with domestic orders up 1.7% and foreign orders increasing by 6.5%. The catch-up process for new industry orders continues at a remarkable pace, with the economy ministry warning that Germany must avoid another shutdown of industrial activity amid rising Covid-19 infections. This boost to hopes for a robust third-quarter is seen as a positive sign for Europe's largest economy.

site_title: Citi at ease with Singapore banks' provisions amid relief extension
summary: Citi analysts remain "comfortable" with Singapore banks' credit cost forecasts despite an extension of debt relief for certain individuals and small businesses into 2021. The banks expect 10-15% of vulnerable loans to lapse into new bad loans, below the analyst's previous projection of 12.2%. This could delay the recognition of peak non-performing loans into late 2021, adding to investor uncertainty.

site_title: Leasing volume for multiple-user factory spaces down 34.4% in July, Aug: report
summary: Leasing volume for multiple-user factory spaces in Singapore dropped 34.4% in July and August, with 1,577 transactions and S$5.7 million in sales. Median rent declined 1.4% quarter-over-quarter and 2.2% year-over-year to S$1.75 per square foot per month. Despite challenges, foreign companies continue to expand in Singapore, with new data centres and industrial space announcements. Knight Frank expects Singapore to remain a favourable destination for companies, with alternative options like business parks emerging as a response to changing office requirements.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO focused on strategy but won't rule out M&A
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing emphasized his focus on the bank's turnaround plan, which is set to be completed within the next three months. While he didn't rule out a potential takeover, Sewing stated that if the bank's valuation recovers, they would have a "better position." The bank's share price has started to recover, gaining 12% since the beginning of the year, and Sewing expressed confidence in the bank's trading revenue growth, excluding debt valuation adjustments. However, headcount reduction efforts have faced challenges due to changing employee attitudes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after Trump leaves hospital
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, extending Wall Street rallies after US President Donald Trump returned to the White House following hospital treatment for Covid-19. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.52% to 23,433.73, while the Topix index advanced 0.52% to 1,645.75. Analysts attributed the gain to Trump's discharge from hospital and Democratic presidential hopeful Joe Biden's increasing lead in weekend polls. Key stocks such as SoftBank, Toyota, and Nissan surged, while Nintendo gained 0.75% and Sony lost 0.81%.

site_title: FAA waives minimum flight requirements at some US airports through March
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has extended temporary waivers of minimum flight requirements at major US airports through late March 2021 due to the coronavirus pandemic. The waivers will benefit airlines at New York's JFK and LaGuardia airports, Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport, and four other airports with formal schedule-review processes. This move aims to ensure efficient use of aviation infrastructure and maximize benefits for both airport users and the traveling public, amid historically low bookings and consumer demand.

site_title: Billionaire Benko due big payout after real estate revaluation
summary: Austrian property billionaire Rene Benko's real estate firm Signa Prime Selection AG is set to pay out 201 million euros (S$322 million) in dividends to investors, a significant increase due to a revaluation of assets that more than doubled net income. The payment is due by the end of 2020, following a surge in net income from 838 million euros, largely driven by a 933 million euro valuation change. This comes as other retail landlords have scrapped dividends and sold assets to raise cash amid the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for fifth session as Trump returns to White House
summary: South Korean stocks rose for the fifth consecutive session, with the Kospi index climbing 7.90 points to 2,365.90, its highest close in two weeks. The gains followed US President Donald Trump's return to the White House after a three-night hospital stay for Covid-19 treatment, boosting hopes for a fresh US stimulus package. Foreign investors were net buyers of 31.1 billion won worth of shares, with analysts citing optimistic earnings forecasts as a key driver of the market's rally.

site_title: Ikea Singapore FY20 revenue falls 10.9%; hiring staff for new Jem outlet
summary: Ikea Singapore's FY20 revenue fell 10.9% to S$304 million due to pandemic-related closures, with its stores enduring the longest closures among the region. The company plans to hire 200 new staff for its Jem outlet set to open in 2021. Despite the challenges, Ikea's Singapore stores have curtailed operations even after reopening, with its food operations closed for 73 days.

site_title: Suez vows to fight Veolia's takeover project
summary: French waste and water firm Suez vows to fight Veolia's takeover project after the latter acquired 29.9% of the company and launched a tender offer on the remaining capital. Suez stated it will protect its employees, clients, and stakeholders, ensuring fair treatment of all shareholders and avoiding a takeover or de facto control. The deal, valued at 11.2 billion euros, aims to create a "world super champion" in waste and water management, but Suez's 150-year-long history will not end overnight, according to the company.

site_title: Indonesian workers stage rallies over passage of controversial jobs bill
summary: Indonesian workers staged protests across several cities on Tuesday against the passage of a controversial new jobs bill, dubbed the "omnibus" Job Creation bill, which critics view as too pro-business. The law revises over 70 existing laws to speed up economic reform and improve the investment climate. The bill removes the three-year maximum duration of contracts and cuts severance benefits, affecting 2 million workers. The government claims the law will promote formal hiring, while critics warn it will harm workers' job security and human rights.

site_title: Relief extension to smoothen out credit costs for Singapore banks: analysts
summary: Analysts view Singapore banks' debt relief extension as mildly positive, aligning with proactive industry efforts to mitigate pandemic impacts. The measure is expected to ease concerns over potential cliff effects from expiring support measures. However, analysts warn that a modest growth outlook and low interest rates will limit the sector's earnings recovery, with the credit cycle requiring time to play out.

site_title: Embattled 'Los Angeles Times' seeking new editor
summary: Los Angeles Times executive editor Norman Pearlstine plans to step down, citing a need for a new leader to continue the paper's revival. Pearlstine, 78, led the newsroom after billionaire owner Patrick Soon-Shiong bought the paper two years ago, using his financial resources to hire dozens of journalists. Despite winning three Pulitzer Prizes, the Times has struggled with sluggish digital growth and lack of diversity in its newsroom. Pearlstine will stay on as executive editor during the search for his successor, who will be tasked with addressing these issues.

site_title: Grade A office leasing in Singapore 'sluggish' in Q3: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: Grade A office leasing in Singapore remained sluggish in Q3, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The market is expecting a fraction of space to be returned vacant when occupiers renew their leases, with tenants seeking short-term renewals and firms conducting workplace strategy studies. With work from home remaining the default, office space is underutilized, and businesses are uncertain about their future office needs.

site_title: Testing capacity, control of virus spread key to restoring aviation links: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore is considering lifting border controls and stay-home notices for travel on a selective basis as increased testing capacity and advanced testing technology become available. The country's daily testing capacity has reached 27,000 and is set to increase to 40,000 by November. Minister Ong Ye Kung believes that testing is key to unlocking air travel and has plans to set up a dedicated Covid-19 testing laboratory to support aviation recovery. Singapore's efforts in controlling community spread and keeping foreign worker dorms under control also contribute to the country's readiness to restore aviation links.

site_title: Wee Hur's Adelaide student housing property to launch next January under new brand
summary: Wee Hur Holdings' wholly owned subsidiary, Wee Hur Hospitality, has announced its new PBSA brand, Y Suites, for its Adelaide student housing property. The 811-room property at 124 Waymouth Street is set to launch in January under the Y Suites brand. This marks Wee Hur's second PBSA in Adelaide and its first to be launched under the Y Suites brand.

site_title: Thai exports may drop 8-10% this year: shippers
summary: Thailand's exports may drop 8-10% this year due to a gradual recovery in global demand, according to the Thai shipping association. Exports are expected to have bottomed out, but a persistently strong baht remains a concern. This prediction is slightly better than the earlier 10% fall predicted.

site_title: Oil trader Vitol diversifying into used-car business
summary: Vitol, the world's largest independent oil trader, has launched a new venture called Vava Cars to buy and sell used cars, particularly in Turkey and Pakistan, where car prices have soared amid a shortage of new vehicles. The move is part of Vitol's diversification strategy as the energy trading giant shifts away from oil. With access to low-cost capital and expertise in exploiting price arbitrages, Vava aims to become the most trusted car transaction platform in the world. The venture is the latest example of energy traders expanding into new markets amid the transition to greener fuels.

site_title: New Silkroutes says Goh Jin Hian suitable to remain as chairman despite lawsuit
summary: New Silkroutes Group's board of directors supports chairman Goh Jin Hian to remain as director despite a lawsuit filed by Inter-Pacific Petroleum's judicial managers. The lawsuit alleges a breach of director's duties, but New Silkroutes' lawyers claim the allegations are without merit. The board believes Goh's character and integrity remain suitable for the role, and it's in the company's interest for him to continue as non-executive chairman. Goh recently stepped down as CEO, and another listed company, Cordlife Group, also announced his departure as chairman.

site_title: The pressure to be perfect turns deadly for celebrities in Japan
summary: A Japanese actress, Yuko Takeuchi, 40, died by suicide, joining a series of celebrity deaths in the country. The pressure to maintain a perfect image in Japan's competitive entertainment industry, where "gaman" or endurance is valued, may have contributed to her death. Takeuchi's passing comes less than two weeks after actress Sei Ashina, 36, and two months after actor Haruma Miura, 30, who also left behind a suicide note. The incidents highlight the potential dangers of the pressure to conform to societal expectations in Japan's entertainment industry.

site_title: Retrenchments hit 4.9 per 1,000 local employees in H1: MOM
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower reported 4.9 local retrenchments per 1,000 local employees in the first half of 2020. Half of the retrenched workers were women, and those aged 60 and above had a higher incidence of 5.2 per 1,000. The government aims to help retrenched workers return to the workforce, with programs such as job assistance and part-time re-employment grants. The government is cautious about legislating a baseline retrenchment benefit, citing concerns it may strain businesses and lead to fewer permanent contracts.

images.alt_text: The number of contracts not renewed in the first half of 2020 has remained stable compared to the second half of 2019.

site_title: Pompeo meets counterparts in Tokyo with eyes on China
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with counterparts from Australia, India, and Japan in Tokyo, seeking a united front against China. Despite the coronavirus crisis in Washington, Pompeo held talks with Japan's Toshimitsu Motegi, Australia's Marise Payne, and India's Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, focusing on promoting a free and open Indo-Pacific region. The meeting, known as the Quad, aims to enhance cooperation among the four nations, but no joint statement or press conference was expected.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia holds interest rates, signals easing ahead
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held its cash rate at a record low 0.25% and signaled further monetary easing to support the coronavirus-hit economy. The decision comes after the central bank boosted its term funding facility to around A$200 billion. RBA Governor Philip Lowe hinted at additional easing to address high unemployment, which is suffering its worst contraction since the Great Depression. The government is expected to release its budget on Tuesday, which is expected to boost spending to support jobs and growth.

site_title: Southwest seeks pay cuts from unions to avoid layoffs through 2021
summary: Southwest Airlines is seeking pay cuts from unions to prevent layoffs and furloughs through 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on air travel. The airline, which has never furloughed workers, may cut salaries, wages, and benefits to break even. If federal aid passes, pay cuts will be reversed. Southwest's CEO, Gary Kelly, is reducing his base salary to zero and implementing cost reductions, while the airline plans to open new routes and pick up clients in a market expected to see low fare competition.

site_title: Goh Jin Hian steps down as Cordlife chairman amid IPP lawsuit
summary: Cordlife Group's chairman, Goh Jin Hian, has stepped down amid a lawsuit by Inter-Pacific Petroleum's (IPP) judicial managers, who claim he breached his director's duties and allowed fictitious transactions to occur. The lawsuit, funded by IPP's bank creditors, seeks $156.5 million in debts. Goh will remain an independent director, while Ho Choon Hou takes over as acting chairman. The decision allows Goh to devote more time to his personal affairs.

site_title: Gold eases after Trump's discharge, weaker US dollar cushions decline
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,911.22 per ounce after US President Donald Trump's discharge from hospital, but were cushioned by a weaker US dollar. The market's risk-on mood, fueled by Trump's recovery and potential US stimulus package, tempered gold prices. Analysts expect gold to rise, with a critical support level at $1,910, and silver rose 0.1% to $24.37 per ounce.

site_title: Decade-long Oracle-Google copyright case heads to top US court
summary: The US Supreme Court is set to hear a decade-old case between Oracle and Google over software rights, with enormous implications for copyright in the digital era. Oracle is seeking billions in damages from Google over its use of Java programming language in its Android mobile operating system, while Google argues that extending copyright protection to code would threaten innovation.
