The case has been ongoing since 2010, with two jury trials and an appeals court ruling in favor of Oracle, prompting Google to take the case to the highest US court.

site_title: Philippine Airlines to slash jobs as virus curbs bite
summary: Philippine Airlines is cutting around 35% of its workforce, approximately 2,400 employees, due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the global aviation industry. The airline is undergoing a restructuring and recovery plan as it rebuilds its network amid the pandemic. With commercial flights grounded for over two months, PAL Holdings, the airline's parent company, reported a net loss of 20.75 billion pesos in the first half of the year. The airline is operating less than 15% of its normal daily flights, and the Philippines has one of the highest coronavirus caseloads in South-east Asia.

site_title: AirAsia to stop funding India venture as cash dwindles: sources
summary: AirAsia Group has stopped funding its Indian affiliate, AirAsia India, due to dwindling cash reserves amid the global travel slump. The airline's future now depends on its majority shareholder, Tata Group, which has provided emergency funding but has yet to commit to a full rescue. Despite initial reports suggesting an immediate risk of closure, the airline is not at risk of folding, according to sources.

site_title: Taskforce to explore other options to facilitate inbound travellers: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung announced a multi-ministry taskforce to explore alternative schemes to welcome travellers from countries with higher infection rates but are economically important to Singapore. The taskforce aims to facilitate travellers while managing virus transmission risks, particularly addressing the 14-day stay-home notice requirement in hotels, which deters many.

site_title: No overseas December holidays this year as borders stay mostly shut: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung announced that Singapore's borders will remain mostly shut for December holidays, citing the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the aviation sector. Only a handful of countries, such as the US, UK, and Turkey, allow general travellers from Singapore, while others, like Germany, only permit business travellers. Ong emphasized that Singapore can control its borders to welcome back visitors and revive its air hub, serving as a reference point for other countries in managing the risks of opening up.

site_title: Government to continue supporting aviation sector amid Covid-19 hit: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's government will continue to support the aviation sector amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung announced the continuation of the Jobs Support Scheme, Enhanced Aviation Support Package, and temporary redeployment programs for affected workers. Changi Airport is now serving 1.5% of its usual passenger volume, and 6% of usual passenger flights, with no domestic air travel in Singapore. The government's support aims to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on the aviation sector.

site_title: Oil firms begin offshore US evacuations as record-breaking storm threatens
summary: Energy companies in the US Gulf of Mexico began evacuating offshore oil platforms as Tropical Storm Delta formed in the Caribbean and threatened the Gulf Coast. Delta, the 25th named storm of the year, is forecast to strengthen into a hurricane with up to 105 mph winds. If it makes landfall, it would be the 10th named storm to do so this year, breaking a record. Offshore production accounts for 17% of total US crude oil production and 5% of total US dry natural gas production.

site_title: Toyota adds to hydrogen bet with North American fuel-cell semi
summary: Toyota is developing a hydrogen-fuel-cell-powered big rig for the North American market, with its subsidiary Hino Motors Ltd. providing the chassis based on the new XL Series. The truck is expected to debut a prototype in the first half of 2021. This move expands on a March agreement to develop a 25-ton fuel-cell semi for the Japanese market. Toyota's fuel-cell technology combined with Hino's heavy-duty truck experience aims to create an innovative and capable product, as the industry shifts towards cleaner transportation options to meet stricter emissions standards.

site_title: Newcrest CEO says primed for Americas push with Toronto listing
summary: Newcrest Mining Ltd, Australia's largest gold producer, has won conditional clearance to list on the Toronto Stock Exchange, positioning itself for growth in the Americas. CEO Sandeep Biswas attributed the move to renewed investor appetite for gold equities and the company's focus on expansion in the region. Newcrest has spent over $1.3 billion acquiring mines in Canada and Ecuador, and has seen a surge in interest from North American investors as gold prices rose to a record. The Toronto listing increases the company's optionality for growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend rally on stimulus hope, easing uncertainty
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq surging over 2% on hopes for a new US stimulus package and growing expectations for a Joe Biden presidency. The rally followed a day of gains in the US, as President Donald Trump returned to the White House after hospital treatment and US lawmakers revived talks on a new rescue package. Analysts believe a Biden win would increase the likelihood of a fiscal package and reduce uncertainty, boosting stocks.

site_title: ST Engineering corporate VC unit invests in cloud startup
summary: ST Engineering Ventures, the corporate venture capital unit of ST Engineering, has made an undisclosed investment in CloudSphere, a cloud management and governance provider. The investment, along with growth equity firm Atlantic Bridge, closed a strategic investment round for CloudSphere. ST Engineering will gain access to CloudSphere's hybrid multi-cloud management and governance software and expertise, enhancing its current cloud portfolio and driving long-term growth. The partnership aims to provide greater value to customers and enhance visibility and control of multi-cloud inventory, performance, and costs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.00 points, or 0.33%, to 1,517.43, with gains beating losses 242 to 49. Volume was 153.97 million lots worth RM53.15 million.

site_title: EV startup Faraday Future in talks to go public through SPAC merger
summary: Faraday Future, an electric vehicle startup, is in talks to go public through a reverse merger with a special-purchase acquisition company (SPAC). CEO Carsten Breitfeld said the company is working on a deal, which could announce something "quite soon." Faraday aims to raise $800-850 million to launch its luxury SUV, FF 91, with volume production starting 12 months after securing funding. The company has struggled in the past, but Breitfeld aims to prove stability after the departure of founder Jia Yueting, who filed personal bankruptcy.

site_title: Japan's Kioxia to seek listing as early as Dec after delay: paper
summary: Japan's Kioxia Holdings Corp, the world's second-largest maker of flash memory chips, plans to reapply for a Tokyo Stock Exchange listing as early as December, after initially delaying its plans due to a market outlook. The company, formerly known as Toshiba Memory, will reassess the timing for its listing. A Kioxia spokesman stated that the company aims to consider the "best timing" for the listing.

site_title: Sen Yue unit receives another letter of demand from SP Group
summary: Sen Yue Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary SMC Industrial (SMCI) received a second letter of demand from SP Group, seeking payment of an aggregate balance of nearly S$7.5 million, including accrued interest, for late payment. The demand was dated Oct 2, with SMCI expected to repay immediately. Sen Yue is in talks with SP Group on repayment proposals, with the company set to provide further updates when material developments occur. This comes after SMCI received a similar letter last week for S$7.9 million.

site_title: Razer Fintech, Visa to launch virtual prepaid card for youth in January
summary: Razer Fintech, in partnership with Visa, will launch a virtual prepaid card for youth in Singapore in January. The Razer Card, integrated with Razer Pay, offers contactless payment technology and rewards through a gamified system. Users can receive cashback up to 5% on select purchases and track rewards through the Razer Pay app. The card will be made available to 1,337 selected users via a beta testing program before its official launch, with plans to expand to other countries where Razer Pay is available, subject to local regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: The Razer Card, co-created with Visa, will be integrated into Razer's e-wallet platform Razer Pay.

site_title: Taiwan says military under pressure from China as missions mount
summary: Taiwan's military has scrambled aircraft 4,132 times this year, a 129% increase from last year, as China escalates its military activities near the island. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has stepped up fighter jet incursions into Taiwan's airspace. The rapid development of China's military has been accompanied by "targeted" military actions against Taiwan, increasing pressure on the island's air defences. Taiwan is modernizing its military to counter the threat, with Vice-Defence Minister Chang Guan-chung calling for enhanced US cooperation to bolster its defence reform.

site_title: UK's Johnson pitches wind-driven recovery from pandemic
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson plans to boost Britain's offshore wind energy capacity to 40 gigawatts by 2030, quadrupling current capacity, as part of a "green industrial revolution" to recover from the pandemic. The £160 million investment aims to create hundreds of thousands of jobs and help the country reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050. Johnson's announcement comes as the government faces pressure over its handling of the pandemic and rising unemployment. The plan includes building floating wind farms, delivering 1 GW of energy, and creating 60,000 new jobs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Tuesday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.54% on Tuesday, following a surge on Wall Street, as US President Donald Trump left hospital after coronavirus treatment. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,895.21. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. The rally comes as traders brush off new Trump threats, with stocks extending their recent rally.

site_title: Last orders for Paris bars - for now at least
summary: Bars in Paris were forced to close on Monday evening after the French government's latest COVID-19 restrictions took effect, marking the end of a brief reopening period. The closures are expected to remain in place until further notice. Bars and restaurants in the city were allowed to reopen in June after a lockdown, but the government has since reimposed restrictions to slow the spread of the virus. Empty bottles and fridges were seen at closed bars, with staff preparing for the shutdown.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher tracking Wall Street; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 2,529.77. Gainers outnumbered losers 116 to 30, with 54.1 million securities worth S$55.5 million changing hands. The positive news about US President Donald Trump's health contributed to the gains.

site_title: Exxon's plan for surging carbon emissions revealed in leaked documents
summary: ExxonMobil's leaked internal documents reveal plans to increase annual carbon-dioxide emissions by up to the output of Greece, despite international efforts to curb warming. The company's US$210 billion investment strategy projects a 17% rise in yearly emissions by 2025. Exxon has never made a commitment to lower oil and gas output or set a carbon neutrality goal, and internal figures reflect only some of the measures it would take to reduce emissions. The company's plans come as some rivals, such as BP and Royal Dutch Shell, are moving to curb oil production and zero-out emissions.

site_title: US House panel to seek breakup of tech giants, GOP member says
summary: US House antitrust panel, led by Democratic Representative David Cicilline, is set to propose sweeping reforms to block tech giants like Amazon and Apple from owning marketplaces and selling their own products on them. The recommendations, known as a "Glass-Steagall law for technology platforms," would prohibit tech companies from entering different lines of business and amount to a breakup of the companies. The proposal would also require tech companies to allow users to easily move their data from one website to another and shift the burden of proof in merger cases to the tech companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall ahead of central bank decision, federal budget
summary: Australian shares fell 0.38% on Tuesday, driven by financial and healthcare stocks ahead of the federal budget and Reserve Bank of Australia's policy review. The government is expected to forecast a record budget deficit and include provisions for tax breaks and infrastructure spending. Financials and healthcare stocks declined, while gold stocks surged 3% on US stimulus hopes. The central bank is likely to hold key rates, according to a Reuters poll.

site_title: Indonesia reforms a step in the right direction, but hurdles remain: Reports
summary: Indonesia's ongoing reforms aim to support smaller banks and ease foreign business entry. The passage of a job creation law relaxes import licensing rules, lowers labor costs, and develops industry investment frameworks. Analysts Citi, Nomura, and Moody's note that while the reforms are a step in the right direction, hurdles remain. Smaller banks may face liquidity crunches, and high credit costs are expected to increase for Indonesian banks during the pandemic-led downturn. Capitalization is expected to strengthen in Indonesia due to strong profitability. However, the impact on foreign direct investment and credit costs may take time to materialize.

images.alt_text: Police outside the Indonesian Parliament, Oct 5, 2020.

site_title: Cases rise in Australia's virus hotspot, but most linked to known outbreaks
summary: Australia's coronavirus hotspot, Victoria, reported 15 new cases and one death, its largest daily rise in five days. The cases are predominantly linked to known outbreaks, according to Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton, who urged authorities to focus on these outbreaks to drive down numbers. Despite the slight increase, Sutton sought to reassure the public that the situation remains under control.

site_title: Pandemic boosts child porn, cybercrime: Europol
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has boosted child porn and cybercrime in Europe, according to Europol's annual cybercrime report. The pandemic's increased internet usage and fears about the virus encouraged criminals to shift towards new forms of illegal services, including child sexual abuse and ransomware attacks. Europol Commissioner Ylva Johansson warned that organized crime exploits vulnerable individuals, including newly unemployed people and children. The pandemic has accelerated online criminal activity, with lockdowns leading to a spike in child sexual abuse and exploitation through dark web forums.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Cordlife, ThaiBev, UG Healthcare, MLT
summary: DBS and Standard Chartered formed a workgroup to create a digital Trade Finance Registry to enhance lending practices and transparency in commodity trade. Cordlife Group's chairman Goh Jin Hian left his post amid a lawsuit. ThaiBev formed a new joint venture to produce nutritious food and beverages. UG Healthcare's shares jumped after the Employees Provident Fund Board of Malaysia acquired a 5.29% stake. New Silkroutes Group requested a trading halt due to declining shares.

site_title: About 200 single family offices in Singapore managing estimated US$20b assets in total
summary: Singapore has around 200 single family offices (SFOs) managing approximately US$20 billion in assets, with each typically managing assets in excess of US$100 million. This estimate was made by Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Trump leaves hospital
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on October 6, 2020, as US President Donald Trump returned to the White House after hospital treatment for Covid-19. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.44% and the Topix index advanced 0.43%. The positive market sentiment was attributed to Wall Street rallies.

site_title: Prompt payments hit new low in Q3: Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau
summary: Prompt payments in Singapore declined to 38.4% in Q3, a new low, with slow payments accounting for over two-fifths of total payment transactions, rising to 44.2%. The construction sector saw significant deterioration due to cash flow woes, while the retail sector saw a visible improvement in slow payments. Despite this, partial payments increased to 17.5% in Q3, indicating businesses are making efforts to fulfill debt obligations. Experts expect this trend to continue, with the construction sector still facing challenges.

site_title: Kuroda warns pandemic will keep Japan's economic uncertainty 'very high'
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that Japan's economic uncertainty will remain "very high" due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The country is emerging from a severe downturn, but a moderate recovery is expected. Kuroda stated that the central bank is prepared to maintain its measures to ease corporate funding strains and provide additional support if needed. Consumer prices are expected to fall initially but rebound as the economy recovers, and the BOJ will closely monitor the pandemic's impact and take further easing steps if necessary.

site_title: Australian gold miner Northern Star offers to buy Saracen Mineral in S$5.57b deal
summary: Australian gold miner Northern Star Resources is offering to buy Saracen Mineral Holdings in a deal worth S$5.57 billion, creating a global top-10 gold miner. The proposal, recommended by both companies' boards, would see Saracen shareholders receive 0.3763 new Northern Star shares and a special dividend of 3.8 Australian cents per share. The deal would give Northern Star 64% ownership and Saracen 36%, with pre-tax synergies expected to be worth A$1.5-2.0 billion over the next 10 years. A shareholder meeting on the proposal is set for January 2021.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit obtains S$40m revolving credit facility from UOB
summary: Starhill Global Reit has secured a S$40 million three-year revolving credit facility from UOB, its manager. The agreement allows UOB to require repayment if the Reit's sponsor YTL Corporation Berhad ceases to own 51% of the manager's issued share capital. The facility provides UOB with protection in case of changes in the Reit's management or ownership structure. This deal will support Starhill Global Reit's financial stability and operations.

site_title: Investing in a Covid-plagued economy
summary: Thomas Rupf, head of investment advisory & treasury Asia for VP Bank Ltd, advises clients to diversify out of credit risk due to low central bank commitment to taking credit losses. He recommends income-oriented clients invest in insurance-linked securities, private markets such as renewable energy, and high-quality technology stocks. Rupf warns that valuations are stretched, with earnings growth not justifying current prices, and regulatory risks, particularly in the digitalisation sectors, must be considered. He is positive about digital transformation emerging as a major theme for investors with a mid to long-term horizon.

site_title: UK blames software after 16,000 virus cases go missing
summary: UK Health Minister Matt Hancock blames outdated software for missing 15,841 Covid-19 cases from official figures, affecting contact tracing efforts. The glitch, in a legacy computer system at Public Health England, was reported on Friday night and has been partially addressed, with 51% of affected cases contacted. The incident has raised concerns about the government's test and trace programme, with opposition Labour party leader Jon Ashworth calling it a "shambles" and "putting lives at risk".

images.alt_text: Matt Hancock said the "legacy computer system" at the Public Health England (PHE) agency that processed lab results caused 15,841 cases between September 25 and October 2 to be absent from reported daily case numbers.

site_title: Brazil economy to shrink by 5.8% in 2020: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its forecast for Brazil's economy, projecting a 5.8% contraction in 2020, down from a previous 9.1% contraction. The economy is expected to partially recover to 2.8% in 2021. The IMF praises the government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic, but warns of high risks, including a second wave of the pandemic, high public debt, and vulnerability to confidence shocks. The country has experienced significant job losses and a rise in unemployment, with over 12 million jobs lost and 13.8% unemployment rate.

site_title: Golden Agri incorporates Brazilian sugar subsidiary
summary: Golden Agri-Resources incorporated its fully-owned sugar subsidiary in Sao Paolo, Brazil, called Golden Agri-Resources Brasil Sociedade Limitada Unipessoal. The new subsidiary aims to provide a low-cost, asset-light niche contribution to the company's business, leveraging Golden Agri's extensive palm oil distribution capabilities. The move is seen as a logical extension of Golden Agri's current sugar activities in Brazil, one of the world's biggest sugar exporters.

site_title: DBS, StanChart lead industry workgroup to develop Trade Finance Registry pilot
summary: DBS and Standard Chartered led a workgroup of 12 banks to develop a proof-of-concept for a digital Trade Finance Registry (TFR) to enhance lending practices and improve transparency in commodity trade. The registry aims to create a secure central database for trade transactions financed across banks in Singapore, reducing duplicate financing and increasing trust among banks and traders. Developed in three months on a blockchain network, the POC was supported by Enterprise Singapore and will be implemented as an industry utility to enhance trade financing practices in Singapore before expanding globally.

site_title: Ascott launches app for rewards members
summary: Ascott Limited, a lodging business unit of CapitaLand, has launched a mobile app called Discover ASR for its Ascott Star Rewards loyalty programme. The app allows members to search for deals, book stays, manage reservations, and redeem e-vouchers at over 200 participating properties in 25 countries. The app is part of Ascott's digital ecosystem transformation to drive global customer growth, with enhanced features planned, including digital keys and pre-arrival requests. The launch comes after an increase in ASR membership following the introduction of a points purchase feature and elite status match programme.

site_title: ThaiBev forms JV to produce nutritious food and beverage products
summary: ThaiBev forms a 51:49 joint venture with Thai Union Ingredients to produce nutritious food and beverage products. The new company, Food and Beverage United, was incorporated in Thailand with a registered capital of 10 million baht. ThaiBev funded the investment with internally generated funds, which is not expected to impact its earnings per share or net tangible assets.

site_title: Plexiglass to separate Pence, Harris at VP debate
summary: Plexiglass will separate US Vice-President Mike Pence and Senator Kamala Harris at Wednesday's debate, a campaign aide said, amid changes to protect against the spread of the coronavirus. The decision comes after President Donald Trump announced contracting Covid-19, and reflects a compromise between the two camps. The Cleveland Clinic is helping set debate health protocols, and the Commission on Presidential Debates has reportedly approved the plans.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux, a troubled water treatment firm, reported that potential investor Pison Investments has accepted approximately 140 tender application forms from noteholders and eligible creditors. This follows 164 applications received as of September 25. The group had filed for a judicial management order in August due to concerns over Hyflux's management. Pison's advisers informed the unsecured working group on October 2 about the progress. The banks involved in the restructuring efforts include Mizuho, KfW, and others.

site_title: Australian job advertisements rise 7.8% in Sept: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements rose 7.8% in September, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth, despite being 25% lower than the previous year. The increase, to an average of 118,424 ads, suggests a positive sign for the economy after reopening from coronavirus lockdowns earlier than expected. However, economists warn that to sustain a solid labor market recovery, job ads and vacancies may need to remain at higher levels for some time, and unemployment could spike towards 10% in coming months.

site_title: Trump tweets he'll be 'back on the campaign trail soon' after leaving hospital
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he would return to the White House after a hospital stay for COVID-19, tweeting he'd be "back on the campaign trail soon". Trump was hospitalized on Friday and announced his departure from the Walter Reed Medical Centre on Monday morning. The tweet comes as Trump's hospitalization coincides with the US presidential election campaign.

site_title: Twitter bans Trump death wishes, sparks debate
summary: Twitter has removed tweets wishing for the death of US President Donald Trump, following his Covid-19 hospitalization, amid criticism of inconsistent enforcement of its abusive behavior policies. The platform stated that such content, including wishes for serious harm or fatal disease, violates its rules. The move sparked debate, with some lawmakers, including Democratic Representatives Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Rashida Tlaib, expressing frustration over the company's inconsistent application of its policies, while Twitter pledged to improve consistency. The decision has reignited concerns about the platform's handling of hate speech and harassment.

site_title: UK residential property: A window of opportunity
summary: UK residential property is seen as a safe and secure asset, attracting foreign investors amid low interest rates and a weak sterling. The UK General Election in 2019 brought stability, and the Conservative party's control of the legislative agenda until 2024 has made the situation more favorable. The temporary increase in the nil-rate threshold for Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) to £500,000 has catalyzed a significant increase in activity, particularly from sophisticated Asian investors. However, foreign investors must consider issues such as UK inheritance tax and seek professional advice to maximize investment returns and reduce tax exposure.

site_title: Pelosi, Mnuchin continue US stimulus negotiations
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi resumed negotiations on a stimulus package, aiming to boost the economy after the CARES Act provisions expired. The two sides have been discussing a follow-up package, with Democrats seeking $2.2 trillion and the White House proposing $1.6 trillion. The talks, revived last week, will continue with phone calls and in-person meetings. The stimulus package, which includes weekly payments to the unemployed and loans for small businesses, is crucial for the US economy ahead of the presidential election.

site_title: Raffles Education and the bane of Covid-19 meetings
summary: Raffles Education Corporation held a virtual Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) on September 30, 2020, to consider a proposed 35.9% share acquisition in Langfang Hezhong Real Estate Development Co Ltd. The acquisition, valued at 254 million yuan (S$49.987 million), was made by REC's 99%-owned subsidiary, Langfang Tonghui Education Consulting Co Ltd. The transaction is part of REC's efforts to expand its presence in the real estate sector, despite the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on virtual meetings and remote communications.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty, while the US stock market edged down from record highs due to tariff threats. The NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Pandemic has renewed push to future-proof Singapore
summary: Singapore is refocusing its economic strategy in the post-pandemic era, prioritizing three areas: remaking the country as a "global Asia" node of technology, innovation, and enterprise; upskilling and reskilling the workforce to address labor market vulnerabilities; and investing in economic resilience and sustainability. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat outlined these plans in a ministerial statement, aiming to boost the country's resilience and competitiveness in a rapidly changing world.

site_title: A new era for construction services
summary: QXY Resources, a Singapore-based construction services company, is embracing new technology to take its operations to the next level. With a focus on urban renewal and sustainability, QXY has handled over 120 projects and worked on more than 200 buildings in Singapore. The company has received several awards, including the Enterprise 50 award, and has been named one of 2020's Fastest Growing Companies by The Straits Times. QXY is now leveraging digital solutions and technologies such as cross-laminated timber, prefabricated steel systems, and building information modelling to enhance productivity and reduce costs. The company aims to expand overseas and establish quantity surveying companies in Malaysia and the Philippines.

site_title: Dedicated digital venues amp up the virtual event game
summary: Local event management firms have developed digital venue solutions to rival on-site events, addressing low-quality video, technical issues, and limited customization options. Companies like Unearthed Productions and MacGyver Consultants International have created integrated platforms and virtual reality capabilities, offering high-definition video, interactive features, and immersive experiences. These solutions, such as Online XP and Constellation Live, aim to provide a comparable online event experience to on-site counterparts, with features like 3D visual aids, motion tracking, and custom branding options.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher despite Trump virus uncertainty
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.7% to 28,148.64, despite US President Donald Trump's ongoing battle with Covid-19. The S&P 500 jumped 1.8% to 3,408.60, while the Nasdaq surged 2.3% to 11,332.49. Positive economic developments, including a potential bipartisan fiscal stimulus agreement and Joe Biden's lead in the presidential election, reassured investors. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi continued to negotiate a stimulus package, with the Institute for Supply Management reporting a growth acceleration in the US services sector.

site_title: Phillip SGD money market ETF debuts on SGX with initial AUM of S$100m
summary: The Phillip SGD money market ETF, managed by Phillip Capital Management, has debuted on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with an initial assets under management (AUM) of S$100 million. The ETF invests in short-term, high-quality money market securities to generate returns comparable to Singapore-dollar savings deposits. It tracks the FTSE SGD three-month Singapore dollar swap offered rate (SOR) Index. Market observers have mixed views, with some seeing it as a low-risk option for retail investors and others considering it more suitable for institutional investors due to low brokerage commission rates and minimal retail interest.

site_title: New bill to ease hassle for small firms seeking to restructure or wind up
summary: Singapore is introducing the Simplified Insolvency Programme (SIP) to help micro and small enterprises restructure or wind up their businesses. The program, set to be introduced in Parliament this month, will enable eligible companies to restructure debts or wind up through two temporary processes adapted from the existing Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act. The program aims to simplify and expedite the process for companies with annual revenue of under S$1 million and S$10 million, with a six-month pilot period.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 5.7% in August
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 5.7% year-on-year in August, a slight improvement from July's 8.5% drop. Strong demand for cars, including new and used vehicles, contributed to the better performance. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales fell 8.4% year-on-year. Online transactions accounted for 10.9% of total retail sales value. Economists expect a full-year retail sales contraction of 15% and 14% respectively, with some optimism for recovery in the medium term.

site_title: Trading in ultra-luxe homes slows
summary: Trading in ultra-luxe homes in Singapore has slowed amid the pandemic, with 23 bungalow deals worth S$474.31 million recorded between January and September 2020, compared to 40 deals worth S$782 million in 2019. Buyers have become more selective, with prices remaining resilient due to the pandemic's impact on the economy. The most expensive deal so far this year is a GCB sold for around S$93 million, while prices for new non-landed condos in the core central region have risen, with Chinese buyers leading the market.

site_title: Scaled-down Orchard Road Christmas light-up to bank on domestic shoppers
summary: Singapore's Orchard Road Christmas light-up will be scaled down this year due to the pandemic, with virtual elements added instead of street activities. The event, typically drawing 4.5 million visitors, will feature a 14-meter-high arch and require 10,300 man hours to set up. Organisers are banking on domestic shoppers to boost sales, with hopes of reaching 70-80% of last year's visitorship. The event will be live-streamed and held in a closed-door ceremony at Ion Orchard shopping mall.

site_title: Britain open to Australia-style EU trade deal but Canberra wants more
summary: Britain is open to a trade deal with the EU similar to Australia's, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said, as negotiations near a deadline. However, Australia wants a full trade agreement to access EU markets, citing tariffs and quotas that limit its exports. The country is seeking to eliminate EU tariffs on industrial goods and agricultural exports, and reduce red tape. If no deal is reached, Britain could trade with the EU on similar terms to Australia, but critics say this is a euphemism for a no-deal scenario, with Britain regaining full control over its laws and rules.

site_title: All eyes on property
summary: Singapore's private residential property prices have shown a 0.8% uptick in the third quarter, surpassing the 0.3% rise in the second quarter and a 1% drop in the first quarter. Despite the worst recession on record and job cuts, demand for properties is driven by record low interest rates and ample liquidity. The outlook for luxury properties and real estate investment trusts is also expected to improve as Singapore moves into Phase three of its reopening.

site_title: Looking out for the environment
summary: Top International Holding, a Malaysian commodities trading firm, aims to prove that mining can be sustainable through its triple bottom line discipline. Founded by Victor Tan in 2014, the company has an export capacity of 1.8 million metric tons of bauxite per month and generated annual revenues of US$140 million in 2019. Top International operates mines in Guinea and runs trading operations in Malaysia and Indonesia, prioritizing safe and environmentally friendly mining practices. The company also commits to uplifting the Guinea community, including building infrastructure and rehabilitating mined land.

site_title: Regional indices rebound on hopes of new US stimulus, Trump recovery
summary: Regional stock markets rebounded on Monday, driven by hopes of a new US stimulus package and President Donald Trump's signs of recovery from COVID-19. The Straits Times Index rose 0.85%, with Australia's S&P/ASX 200 leading the gains at 2.59%. Hong Kong, South Korea, and Tokyo shares also posted significant gains, while Frasers Centrepoint Trust was among the worst performers, shedding 3.09%.

site_title: Quarantine for Muhyiddin after exposure to virus
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will self-quarantine for 14 days after a minister who attended a high-level government meeting tested positive for Covid-19. The move comes as the country experiences a steady climb in cases following the recent election in Sabah. The decision aims to mitigate the spread of the virus, but the article does not provide further information on the minister's condition or the government's response to the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Muhyiddin was at a meeting on Saturday with Religious Affairs Minister Zulkifli Mohamad Al-Bakri, who has now tested positive for Covid-19.

site_title: Germany frets about future on milestone anniversary
summary: Germany marks its 30th anniversary of unification with increased focus on US presidential election, which may impact transatlantic relations. Donald Trump's potential re-election threatens post-war normalcy, with possible NATO withdrawal and US troop cuts in Germany. Germany's trade surplus and defense spending also pose concerns, with Trump's tariffs and 2% GDP target. Angela Merkel's chancellorship ends next year, leaving uncertainty about Germany's future leadership. If Trump wins, it could undermine the centreground internationalist agenda and secure a populist victory, while a Biden win may restore post-war normality.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit two-week high as Trump update lifts global mood
summary: European shares closed at a two-week high on Monday, driven by positive updates on US President Donald Trump's health, a US stimulus package, and dealmaking activity. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.8% with oil majors surging and telecom stocks rising. Despite Cineworld's 36.2% plunge due to theater closures, investors took heart from Trump's improving health, lifting investor spirits and boosting the market. Market experts warn that uncertainty about the US election and vaccine front may continue to affect the market.

images.alt_text: European shares closed at a two-week high on Monday, as positive updates on US President Donald Trump's health, a US stimulus package and a spate of dealmaking activity lifted investor spirits.

site_title: Share of perps in bond issues hits 6-year low as demand, yields dip
summary: Perpetual bond issuances in Singapore have hit a six-year low, making up just 10% of total bond issuances year to date, down from 30% in 2019. The decline is attributed to lower demand and yields due to the pandemic's impact on growth and investors' wariness of defaults. Cheaper funding options have reduced the need for financing, and stronger companies have opted for bank loans instead of perps. The market has also shrunk 37% this year, with only S$13.4 billion raised compared to S$21.2 billion in the previous year.

site_title: Paris bars to close as Covid-19 cases spike
summary: The French government plans to shut down bars in the Paris region for 15 days to contain a spike in new coronavirus cases, as the country struggles to avoid a second nationwide lockdown. The measures, which will go into effect on Tuesday, are part of a maximum alert zone declaration for Paris and its inner suburbs. France reported a record number of new cases on Saturday and monthly deaths tripled in September, with virus cases increasing the most in Europe over the past two months.

site_title: Saudi Arabia scraps VAT for home buyers to keep boom rolling
summary: Saudi Arabia has scrapped a 15% VAT on property sales, replacing it with a 5% real estate sales tax, to maintain its mortgage boom amid a push to expand residential ownership. The government will also cover the cost of taxes for first-time home buyers of properties up to 1 million riyals. This move aims to boost home construction and lending, with the goal of increasing home ownership among citizens to 70% by 2030. The decision is seen as a positive step for the kingdom's economy, which has been affected by the global pandemic and lower oil prices.

site_title: UEM Sunrise's major shareholder UEM Group proposes merger for it and Eco World
summary: UEM Sunrise Bhd, a major property developer in Malaysia, received a proposal from its shareholder UEM Group to merge with peer Eco World Development Group Bhd. The proposed merger was suggested for consideration and discussions. No further details were provided about the proposed terms or potential outcomes of the merger.

site_title: Covid shows Trump who's the real boss
summary: President Donald Trump has been infected with Covid-19, just a month before the US presidential election, after boasting about his administration's progress in fighting the pandemic. The virus has infected Trump, the First Lady, and several White House aides and Republican politicians, including some who were scheduled to participate in the upcoming debate and vote on a Supreme Court nomination. The incident is likely to shift the focus of the campaign to Trump's handling of the pandemic, which has already been a major issue. The president's refusal to take precautions, including wearing a mask, has been widely criticized.

site_title: Japan bullet trains firing blanks as pandemic hits
summary: Japan's bullet trains are firing blanks as the pandemic continues to impact domestic travel, with traveller volumes plummeting due to fear of Covid-19 infection. The normally crowded section of Tokyo Station serving regional destinations is now nearly deserted, with more cleaning staff than passengers. The lack of passengers is attributed to the national campaign to spur domestic travel, which has not been effective. As a result, businesses relying on the trains, such as bento-box stores, are struggling to stay afloat.

site_title: The limits of American recovery
summary: The US is experiencing a high number of Covid-19 deaths, accounting for 21% of global confirmed cases, despite having only 4% of the world's population. The country's recovery from the pandemic-induced depression is around 60% complete, with employment rates near pre-crisis levels. However, this recovery may be limited due to the lingering effects of the 2008 financial crisis and the lack of productivity growth. The US government's ability to serve as an engine of recovery is hindered by President Trump's handling of the pandemic and the country's high risk of contracting Covid-19, which will continue to deter consumer spending and business investment.

site_title: Philippines lets malls, businesses reopen further
summary: The Philippines has allowed malls and businesses to reopen further, despite a rise in coronavirus deaths last month. The task force against the virus outbreak has approved the reopening of essential shops in malls, miners, and money exchanges, as well as restaurants operating round-the-clock and salons running at 75% capacity. The economic contraction is projected to be 6.6% this year, potentially reversing the country's poverty reduction gains. The government aims to balance economic revival with controlling the outbreak, with current quarantine classifications expected to remain in place.

site_title: New York City will close schools and non-essential businesses in 9 hard-hit areas
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the closure of non-essential businesses, public and private schools, and day care centers in nine hard-hit neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens due to high testing positivity rates over the last seven days. The affected areas will experience a "rewind" of the city's reopening plan, with closures taking effect immediately. The move aims to slow the spread of COVID-19 in these areas.

site_title: Perceived split in ECB sends mixed messages to investors
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is struggling to convey its intentions to investors due to a perceived split among its top policymakers. President Christine Lagarde and chief economist Philip Lane appear to have differing views on policy, with Lagarde's press conferences and Lane's blog posts sending mixed messages. This disconnect may impact investors' confidence in the ECB's ability to respond effectively to the coronavirus recession. The unclear messaging raises concerns about the bank's ability to make decisions and implement policies.

site_title: Bigger is better for Singapore home buyers
summary: In Singapore, larger condos have seen a surge in sales, with 582 units over 1,200 sq ft sold in August, a two-year high. This trend is attributed to the work-from-home trend, with buyers opting for more space. The median unit price of large units rose 3.5% from the same period in 2019 and 29.2% from five years ago. Developers may need to consider reconfiguring their unit mix to include more large units or facilities to support the culture of work from home, according to OrangeTee & Tie's head of research.

site_title: IT access controls to be automated, public officers held accountable: Indranee
summary: Singapore's government plans to automate access controls in over 2,000 IT systems to reduce human error and address lapses, Second Finance Minister Indranee Rajah announced in Parliament. The move aims to improve accountability among public officers and address deficiencies highlighted in the Auditor-General's reports. The Smart Nation and Digital Government Group is developing solutions to automate processes, with interim fixes already implemented. Training initiatives will also be stepped up in key areas, including procurement controls, to address lapses and ensure compliance with guidelines.

site_title: Targeted credit relief measures unveiled for SMEs, individuals
summary: Singapore banks have unveiled targeted credit relief measures for individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to help them cope with the economic fallout from the pandemic. The measures include extending the debt moratorium expiry to 2021 and providing additional support for sectors hit hardest. SMEs in Tier 1 and 2 sectors can defer up to 80% of principal payments on secured loans, while individuals can apply for reduced monthly instalments pegged at 60% of their monthly instalment for up to nine months. The measures aim to help businesses and individuals "tide through the current economic difficulties" and emerge with a sustainable debt burden as the economy recovers.

site_title: How will Trump's October surprise affect election results in Nov?
summary: US President Donald Trump has tested positive for COVID-19 and was hospitalized for treatment, sparking concerns about his condition and its potential impact on the upcoming presidential election. Despite receiving oxygen and treatment, Trump appeared on Twitter and staged a drive-by to wave to supporters, raising questions about his health and judgment. Trump's doctors described his condition as "very concerning" but also optimistic about his recovery. The incident has sown confusion in the markets and raises questions about Trump's physical and political health as the election approaches.

site_title: HSBC's wild ride pushes hedging costs close to highest in a decade
summary: HSBC Holdings has seen its shares become nearly three times more volatile than Hong Kong's benchmark, with investors betting on continued volatility. Options traders in Hong Kong are pricing in a volatile October, with the cost of one-month contracts tied to HSBC's Hong Kong shares nearing the highest level since 2009. The bank's shares rose 5% in Hong Kong, outperforming the 1.7% rise in the Hang Seng Index. Despite recent concerns, Ping An Insurance Group's 8% stake in HSBC remains unchanged, with the bank's dividend payments suspended due to pandemic and low interest rates.

site_title: Pay-TV needs more than live sports to survive
summary: Singapore's pay-TV operators, StarHub and Singtel, are struggling with declining subscribers due to the shift to over-the-top video services like Netflix and Amazon. As of end-March 2020, their subscriber numbers had dropped from 528,000 and 423,000, respectively, in 2016. The decline in pay-TV subscribers poses a threat to the industry's survival, as live sports events are no longer the primary draw. The operators must adapt to changing viewer habits and find new revenue streams to stay afloat in the competitive market.

site_title: Local firms mixed on impact of debt moratorium extension
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, the Association of Banks in Singapore, and the Finance Houses Association of Singapore jointly announced an extension of the debt moratorium programme, allowing SMEs in sectors hit hard by the pandemic to defer 80% of principal payments on secured loans until June 30, 2021. The move was met with mixed reactions from local firms, with some concerned about accumulating interest while others welcomed the reprieve. The Extended Support Scheme - Standardised is intended to support SMEs in sectors such as aviation and tourism.

site_title: Google delays India payment rules as Paytm offers alternative
summary: Google has delayed planned changes to its in-app payment rules in India by six months, allowing developers until March 2022 to integrate with its Google Play billing services. The move comes after Indian startups, including Paytm, opposed the 30% fee structure, which would have given Google control over the country's startup ecosystem. Paytm has launched an Android Mini App Store offering free app distribution and zero-per-cent payment fees, aiming to drive self-sufficient India and retain consumer spending.

site_title: RHB 'overweight' on Singapore property sector
summary: Singapore-listed real estate developers are trading at deep discounts to their book values and revalued net asset values, offering "good value" at current levels, according to RHB analyst Vijay Natarajan. The sector has rebounded strongly since the economy reopened, with transaction volumes and prices remaining stable. RHB has maintained its "overweight" rating on the sector, with top picks including CapitaLand and City Developments Limited, which are expected to benefit from the market's recovery. The analyst forecasts a modest 2-5% decline in book values and no significant asset value write-downs.

images.alt_text: Since the economy reopened, the Singapore property market has surprised with a strong rebound in transaction volumes and stable prices.

site_title: Tenet tops US$300m globally, but movie industry still in crisis
summary: Christopher Nolan's Tenet grossed over $300 million globally, with $2.7 million earned in the US and $14.2 million internationally last weekend. Despite this, the US box office appears to be on the verge of collapse due to high coronavirus infection rates and theater reopenings in major markets. The film's poor performance in the US is attributed to hesitant audiences and a lack of major blockbusters. The situation for theaters remains dire, with potential closures and job losses looming.

site_title: UG Healthcare soars 7% after Malaysia EPF Board raises stake
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation shares rose 7% on Monday after the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) Board of Malaysia increased its stake to 5.29% with a direct interest. The EPF Board acquired 605,000 shares at an average price of S$2.55, totaling S$1.5 million. This comes after the EPF Board also became a substantial shareholder of Riverstone Holdings, UG Healthcare's glove-making peer. The stock reached an intra-day high of S$1.04 before finishing at S$1.

site_title: AirAsia ceases operations in Japan
summary: AirAsia has ceased operations in Japan, citing a need to reduce cash burn amid the coronavirus outbreak. The move, effective as of Monday, will help the parent company conserve cash. AirAsia Japan will follow applicable laws and regulations, including the Japan Civil Aeronautics Act, in making further decisions. This is the budget carrier's second-largest market, following Thailand.

site_title: The new battleground in brand defence
summary: A new battleground in brand defense has emerged, with the impact of falsehoods on brand reputation and value in the market becoming a major concern. According to a study, disinformation causes US$78 billion in annual losses in the US alone, with financial disinformation and fake news attacks costing companies billions in stock losses and damage. Threat actors have increased their sophistication, making it harder to detect and remove manipulated content. To combat this, early warning systems that detect deception and surface disinformation threats early are needed, allowing brands to take a proactive approach to detecting threats and managing their narratives.

site_title: Blazing a trail for impact
summary: Union Bancaire Privee (UBP), a family-owned bank, has established a commitment to build an impact franchise, focusing on sustainable and impact investing. Since 2018, the bank has expanded its professionals, established an impact advisory board, and partnered with the Cambridge Institute for Sustainability Leadership. As a result, UBP's impact assets reached $193 million by end-September. The bank aims to make sustainable and impact investing accessible to everyone, with a focus on emerging markets. With the global impact investing network forecasting $715 billion in growth by the end of the year, UBP believes impact investing will become a core allocation of clients' portfolios.

site_title: New chapter in Asia's water story
summary: The United Nations' goal of providing clean water and sanitation for all by 2030 is proving challenging in Asia, where rapid urbanization poses a significant obstacle. Despite progress in improving access to safe drinking water and sanitation, one in four healthcare facilities globally still lacks clean water and soap, and 673 million people practice open defecation. The UN has launched a Global Acceleration Framework to address these challenges, leveraging financial resources, technology, and governance improvements to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal 6. Various countries, including China, Indonesia, and Vietnam, have successfully implemented initiatives to improve water and sanitation access, offering hope that the region can deliver clean water and sanitation for all.

site_title: Trump hospital-release more likely on Tuesday: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump's hospital release is more likely to occur on Tuesday, according to sources. Trump's condition improved over the weekend and he is eager to leave Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows said a decision will be made after consultations with medical staff, with a possible release by Tuesday afternoon. Trump has been hospitalized since Friday after being diagnosed with Covid-19.

site_title: More companies make disclosures on directors involved in investigations
summary: Several Singapore companies disclosed information about directors involved in ongoing investigations, primarily related to Kelvin Tan, an independent non-executive director of Eagle Hospitality Trust. The disclosures were made in response to queries from the Singapore Exchange. The events highlight increased transparency and compliance among listed companies in Singapore.

site_title: More billion-dollar equity deals expected in Asean with markets rebound: Citi
summary: Citi expects more billion-dollar equity deals in South-east Asia's markets over the next 12 months as the region rebounds from the Covid-19 crisis. The tech, household consumer, and healthcare sectors are likely to lead the way, with companies looking to raise fresh equity for growth. The first billion-dollar deal, SCG Packaging's IPO in Thailand, marks the start of a pipeline of large transactions. Citi's pipeline includes a mix of high-growth industries and traditional sectors, with real estate investment trusts (Reits) expected to remain a key component.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.13 points to 1,512.43 on Monday, with 727 gainers outnumbering 344 losers. Total trading volume was 6.344 billion lots worth RM4.593 billion.

site_title: Election jitters keep US dollar in tight range
summary: The US dollar index slipped against a basket of currencies, down 0.2% at 93.658, amid uncertainty surrounding US President Donald Trump's health and fiscal aid talks in Washington. Trump's Covid-19 diagnosis has sparked investor flight to safer assets, but his surprise appearance outside the hospital improved risk appetite. The Australian dollar rose, while the Japanese yen fell, suggesting an improvement in risk appetite. Analysts await developments in Washington on a Covid-19 relief package and its impact on the election.

site_title: Exxon to cut 1,600 jobs across Europe as oil rout weighs
summary: US oil giant ExxonMobil plans to cut up to 1,600 European jobs by the end of 2021 as part of its global review, amid the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and low oil prices. The cuts will be country-specific and dependent on local business conditions. ExxonMobil has already announced voluntary layoffs in Australia and plans to continue cutting jobs globally into 2021. The move is part of oil majors' efforts to save cash amid a lackluster energy market outlook.

site_title: Social, dining group size: 5-person cap may be reviewed
summary: Singapore's government has started piloting larger-scale events, such as trade exhibitions and conferences, with a larger number of attendees. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong announced that the social and dining group size limit of five persons may be reviewed to allow more large-scale events and gatherings. The government will provide more details on its Phase Three roadmap in the coming weeks, which includes expected timelines and changes to current regulations. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat also confirmed that Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung will discuss air connectivity plans in Parliament.

site_title: Kenzo Takada, who brought Japanese fashion to the world, dies at 81
summary: Kenzo Takada, a renowned Japanese fashion designer, died on Sunday at 81 due to complications from the novel coronavirus. He spent 56 years in Paris, where he revolutionized the French fashion world with his bold, exuberant prints. Takada's designs, which combined East and West, influenced a generation and opened doors for other Japanese designers. He is remembered for his joyful, chaotic aesthetic, sense of fun, and commitment to diversity and inclusivity. His legacy continues through his eponymous brand, which has been carried on by various designers.

images.alt_text: Japanese fashion designer Kenzo Takada at a photo session in his home in Paris on Jan 9, 2019. The founder of the Kenzo fashion house, Kenzo Takada died from the novel coronavirus.

In the fresh air of the inner city garden amid the sounds of the fountain at Kenzo's show at the Institut National de Jeune Sourdes on Sept 30. It was a hybrid Paris Fashion Week's Women Spring/Summer 2021 ready-to-wear fashion show. Large umbrellas, just in case it rained, were placed among the rose bushes and marked out the show seating. There were little wooden stools to ensure social distancing.

site_title: Oil jumps 6% on Trump health update, Norway shutdowns
summary: Oil prices surged 6% on Monday, with Brent up 5.6% to $41.48 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 6.4% to $39.42 a barrel. The increase was driven by news that US President Donald Trump may be discharged from the hospital soon, improving market sentiment. Additionally, a workers' strike in Norway shut six offshore oil and gas fields, cutting output by about 8%. Analysts also cited hopes for a US stimulus package and rising Libyan oil production as supporting factors.

site_title: Not a zero-sum game
summary: GuocoLand group managing director Cheng Hsing Yao emphasizes that real estate development is not a zero-sum game, where all parties must benefit. He believes that integrated mixed developments can create synergy and value, and that community and sustainability are key aspects of his business strategy. GuocoLand's flagship development, Guoco Tower, and its upcoming project, Guoco Midtown, showcase the company's focus on livability, density, and community. Cheng emphasizes the importance of design from the "inside out," green spaces, and public areas, and notes that the company's commitment to sustainability has helped it navigate the COVID-19 crisis.

site_title: Trump's Covid-19 status unclear, could return to White House Monday
summary: US President Donald Trump is being treated for COVID-19 at a military hospital, where his condition remains unclear. Despite treatment with a steroid and an intravenous antiviral drug, his medical team says he may return to the White House as early as Monday, with a normal quarantine period of 14 days. Critics and medical experts have blasted Trump's decision to leave the hospital and hold a motorcade, potentially exposing others to the virus. Trump's case may be severe due to his age and health status.

site_title: Bristol Myers to buy heart drug developer MyoKardia for about US$13b
summary: US drugmaker Bristol Myers Squibb agreed to buy MyoKardia for approximately $13 billion, expanding its heart drugs business. The deal, valued at $225 per share, represents a 61.2% premium to MyoKardia's closing price. Bristol Myers gains access to mavacamten, a potential treatment for a chronic heart disease affecting 200,000 people. MyoKardia plans to submit a marketing application for mavacamten to the US health regulator in 2021, and Bristol Myers aims to explore additional indications and develop MyoKardia's pipeline.

site_title: J&J to pay more than US$100m to end over 1,000 talc suits
summary: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to pay over $100 million to resolve more than 1,000 lawsuits claiming its baby powder caused cancer. The settlements come seven months after the company last faced a jury review of cancer risks from its talc product. J&J maintains its product is safe, despite replacing it with a cornstarch version in the US and Canada. The company has settled the bulk of a plaintiffs lawyer's cases for the first time, with 20,000 lawsuits still pending. The deals were reached during a pandemic-induced hiatus in litigation.

site_title: Scientists who helped identify Hepatitis C virus win 2020 Nobel Medicine Prize
summary: Two Americans, Harvey Alter and Charles Rice, and a Briton, Michael Houghton, won the 2020 Nobel Medicine Prize for identifying the Hepatitis C virus, which causes cirrhosis and liver cancer. Their discovery led to blood tests and new medicines, saving millions of lives. The prize is a significant step forward in eradicating the virus, and the winners are eligible to celebrate alongside the 2021 laureates, assuming the pandemic has eased by then. The Nobel Foundation has adapted this year's ceremony due to the pandemic, cancelling the traditional banquet and instead hosting a televised event.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's response to COVID-19 will shape the country's growth over the next 5-10 years, according to Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. A new bill will be introduced to help micro and small firms restructure debts or wind up businesses. Larger gatherings may soon be possible as the government pilots activities with more attendees. Retail sales dropped 5.7% in August, but the government plans to expand the Progressive Wage Model to more sectors.

site_title: US service sector activity rises above pre-pandemic level in September
summary: US service sector activity surpassed the pre-pandemic level in September, according to the Institute for Supply Management. The non-manufacturing activity index rose to 57.8, above the 50 growth threshold, driven by increases in new orders and employment. This improvement fits expectations for a record rebound in economic growth in the third quarter. However, growth is expected to slow as businesses exhaust government loans and new coronavirus cases rise, potentially leading to restrictions on the services sector.

site_title: Indonesia passes law to cut corporate tax, simplify labour rules
summary: Indonesia's parliament has passed a law to cut corporate tax and simplify labor rules, aiming to create jobs and attract investments. The law, which simplifies over 70 existing regulations, lowers corporate income tax to 20% from 22% and exempts some dividend taxes. The passage of the law was met with opposition from labor unions and politicians, who rejected the reduction in severance pay and introduction of indefinite labor contracts. The move is seen as a bid to boost the economy, which is expected to contract this quarter due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US: Wall St gains on stimulus hopes, hints of Trump hospital discharge
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as investors anticipated President Donald Trump's potential discharge from the hospital and hopes for a new fiscal stimulus bill. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.52%, 0.56%, and 0.85%, respectively. The increases were driven by optimism about Trump's recovery and the possibility of a stimulus package, which lifted market sentiment and led to a record high in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: AirAsia shuts Japan operations
summary: AirAsia is ceasing its Japanese operations immediately due to the highly challenging operating conditions in Japan aggravated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The airline's majority-owned subsidiary AirAsia Japan (AAJ) has been reviewing its business since last month and has decided to cease operations with immediate effect. This decision aims to reduce cash burn and follows a 98% decline in passengers in April-June compared to the same period last year. The airline employs around 300 people and operates three planes for domestic and international flights from Chubu Centrair International Airport.

site_title: US evictions surge amid pandemic despite ban
summary: US evictions have surged despite a federal ban amid the pandemic, with thousands of filings occurring in the weeks leading up to and following a nationwide moratorium. Private equity firms and large corporate landlords have been accelerating eviction filings, according to a nonprofit group and Princeton University's Eviction Lab. The CDC moratorium, which protects nearly all renters, has been met with exemptions and requirements, and some landlords have not been proactive in informing tenants about the option. The National Low Income Housing Coalition is urging federal agencies to change this, citing concerns that corporate landlords are violating the intention of the order.

site_title: Japan's Nomura to start new grads in call centre as sales change: sources
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, will send new-graduate employees to work at its call center for their first year, shifting from traditional face-to-face sales due to the rise of online brokerages. The move, effective April, is Nomura's first major change in this approach. The company aims to strengthen its online service and build up its call center to maintain customer contact. However, some may view a call center role as less desirable for recent graduates expecting a high-flying career in financial services.

site_title: S-Reits in the spotlight
summary: Singapore Reits have staged a strong rebound since the March trough, despite ongoing sector-specific challenges. Experts attribute the recovery to resilient demand and improved investor sentiment. OCBC Investment Research's Head, Carmen Lee, expects a near-term stable market environment. The sector's recovery is expected to be sustained, with data centre investments offering opportunities for growth. However, sector-specific challenges persist, and investors should remain cautious. Overall, the market outlook is positive, with a stable environment expected in the near term.

site_title: Israeli baby formula maker Else to complete share offering this week
summary: Israeli baby formula maker Else Nutrition plans to complete a C$25.7 million private placement of its shares this week, with 11.6% of shares bought by H&H International Holding and the rest by Canaccord Genuity. Else's plant-based infant formula, made from almonds, buckwheat, and tapioca, is organic, vegan, and gluten-free, catering to babies allergic to cow's milk and soy-based formula.

site_title: Sunseap to supply Facebook with solar energy for Singapore operations
summary: Singapore-based solar energy firm Sunseap Group has partnered with Facebook to supply the tech giant with renewable energy for its Singapore operations, including a custom-built data centre. The agreement is a first-of-its-kind virtual power purchase agreement (VPPA) between Sunseap and Facebook, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 75% and support Facebook's goal of 100% renewable energy in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.32% on Monday, driven by hopes for a new US stimulus package and Donald Trump's improving health after testing positive for coronavirus. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,767.78, closing above pre-weekend levels. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. The gains came despite US tariff threats and ongoing trade talks with the EU.

site_title: Regional key indices rebound on hopes of new US stimulus and Trump's recovery
summary: Regional key indices rebounded on Monday following President Donald Trump's signs of recovery and hopes for a new US stimulus package. The Straits Times Index rose 0.85% to 2,517.23, with the S&P/ASX 200 in Australia posting the biggest daily jump since July at 2.59%. Hong Kong, Seoul, and Tokyo shares also gained over 1%, while the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.81%. The gains were driven by optimism over Trump's recovery and potential US stimulus, offsetting concerns over the Golden Week holiday in Mainland China.

site_title: Sheng Siong supermarket in Tanglin Halt visited by Covid-19 patient while infectious
summary: A Sheng Siong supermarket in Tanglin Halt, Singapore, was visited by an infectious Covid-19 patient on September 27 between 6:05pm and 6:35pm. The patient's visit was listed by the Ministry of Health (MOH) to inform close contacts to monitor their health for two weeks. Meanwhile, one new community case and one imported case were announced, bringing the total to 57,819 cases. The number of unlinked cases remains stable, and 22 cases were discharged, with 42 patients still in hospital.

site_title: UK growth slowed less than thought in September: PMI data
summary: The UK's services sector growth slowed less than initially thought in September, with a PMI reading of 56.1, down from August's five-year high of 58.8. This was smaller than the initial estimated drop of 55.1. Despite the government's "Eat Out to Help Out" scheme being withdrawn, business activity continued to grow solidly. However, other consumer services activities showed a decline, and the composite PMI fell to 56.5 from August's six-year high of 59.1.

site_title: Thailand seeks Red Bull heir extradition after Interpol 'red notice'
summary: Thailand is seeking the extradition of Vorayuth Yoovidhya, the heir to the Red Bull fortune, after Interpol issued a global "red notice" due to a 2012 hit-and-run incident that killed a policeman. Vorayuth missed eight court summons and disappeared before authorities sought his arrest in 2017. A new arrest warrant was issued after evidence suggested he was driving at a higher speed and had cocaine in his system. Interpol will help locate Vorayuth, paving the way for his extradition to Thailand for further legal action.

images.alt_text: Vorayuth Yoovidhya, whose whereabouts are unknown, was accused of crashing his Ferrari into a policeman in 2012 and dragging his body at high speed before fleeing the scene.

site_title: Data analytics firm GeoSpock raises US$5.4m in funding
summary: GeoSpock, a US-based data analytics firm, has raised US$5.4 million in funding to accelerate its database technology development and adoption. This brings the total funding to over US$32 million, extending the firm's Series A funding. The company has offices in Cambridge, UK, Singapore, and Tokyo.

site_title: AirAsia's problems grow as India Minister hints at local shutdown
summary: AirAsia Group is closing its affiliate operations in India, with local aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri stating the company's parent is experiencing problems. The airline has struggled to break even in India, where high fuel taxes and cut-throat fares make operations unprofitable. AirAsia India has a market share of 6.8% and employs over 3,000 people. The airline is seeking to raise $817 million by the end of the year as the coronavirus disrupts travel globally. Tata Sons is reviewing the joint venture with AirAsia and may buy out the Malaysian firm's 49% stake.

site_title: Singapore in 'stable' position but fight against Covid-19 continues: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore is in a stable position in its fight against Covid-19, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat said in Parliament. The government is focusing on four key areas: vaccination, testing technologies, contact tracing, and safe management measures. Singapore is an early supporter of the Covid-19 Vaccine Global Access Facility and is procuring vaccines from pharmaceutical companies. The government is also increasing testing capacity and evaluating new technologies to help resume activities. A roadmap to Phase 3 is expected to be released in the coming weeks, outlining the timeline and changes to regulations.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says economic uncertainty to remain 'very high' due to pandemic
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that economic uncertainty remains "very high" due to the ongoing pandemic, affecting Japan's moderate recovery. The central bank is prepared to maintain its measures to ease corporate funding strains and adjust support as needed. Consumer prices are expected to fall initially but rebound as the economy recovers, while Japan's economy is expected to emerge from its severe downturn caused by the pandemic. The BOJ has kept its policy steady since expanding stimulus in March and April.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain ground
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose in opening trade on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.8%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.7%, and Paris's CAC 40 also up 0.7%. The gains came after US President Donald Trump signaled his health is improving after contracting the coronavirus, providing relief from pandemic-related concerns. The markets are now cautiously optimistic for the week ahead.

site_title: Public officers to be trained, held accountable: Indranee
summary: Singapore's government plans to upgrade IT systems and procurement capabilities to address deficiencies highlighted in this year's Auditor-General Office report. Public officers will be held accountable for their actions, and training initiatives will be stepped up in key areas. The report identified technical misconfigurations and inadequate security measures in multiple agencies, including the Republic Polytechnic. The government's efforts aim to improve accountability and address IT and procurement lapses.

site_title: Nvidia building UK supercomputer to boost Covid-19 research
summary: US chip giant Nvidia is building Britain's most powerful supercomputer, the Cambridge-1, to aid in Covid-19 research. The 400 petaflop AI system, expected to launch by the end of the year, will be used by pharmaceutical companies like GSK and AstraZeneca. The Cambridge-1 will be available to researchers from industry and academia, serving as a hub for collaboration and innovation in critical healthcare and drug discovery. This move is part of Nvidia's plans to create an AI Centre of Excellence in Cambridge, featuring an Arm-based supercomputer.

images.alt_text: US chip giant Nvidia said on Monday it is building Britain's most powerful supercomputer, which will use artificial intelligence to help researchers solve pressing medical challenges, including those related to Covid-19.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher on White House reports of Trump's improving health
summary: South Korean shares closed at a two-week high, driven by White House reports of US President Donald Trump's improving health, which boosted mood and led to gains in Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors. The Kospi index rose 1.29% to 2,358.00, extending its winning streak to a fourth session. Hyundai Motor jumped 4.8% and Kia Motors rose 7.7% after reporting strong US retail sales. The won and benchmark bond yield also rose, while a private survey showed South Korea's factory activity shrank at the slowest pace in eight months.

site_title: Luxury brand Mulberry forecasts reduced losses on improving sales trend
summary: Mulberry, a British luxury brand, reported a year-to-date loss of £14.2 million (S$25.07 million) but forecast reduced current year losses due to an improving sales trend since store re-openings. Revenue fell 10% in the year to March 28, but online revenue rose 69%. The company faces challenges in its home market due to the pandemic, high rents, and business rates. Shares are down 42% this year, and the company will not pay a full year dividend due to the uncertain outlook.

site_title: Tata taking on Ambani could be India's Alibaba-Tencent
summary: Tata Sons, the 152-year-old conglomerate, may be taking on Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries in India's e-commerce battle, potentially creating a two-horse race for control of the country's vast data market. Tata is reportedly in talks with Walmart for a $25 billion investment in a "super-app" combining retail, lifestyle, and electronics, similar to Alibaba's Alipay wallet and WeChat Pay. With Ambani's Reliance Industries already raising $20 billion from investors, the competition could become a major player in India's emerging online commerce market.

site_title: Citigroup backs fintech company Genesis
summary: Citigroup has made a strategic investment in Genesis Global Technology, a London-based fintech startup that develops low-code application platforms for financial institutions. The investment aims to make it cheaper and faster for banks to build applications, with Genesis' technology potentially changing the financial industry's application-building process.
