The deal is part of Citigroup's growing trend of partnering with young technology companies to improve efficiency and reduce costs, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: New term of government starts from 'challenging fiscal position': DPM Heng
summary: Singapore's new government term begins in a challenging fiscal position, with revised revenue estimates showing a 16% decrease to S$63.7 billion for the current financial year, compared to the initial S$76 billion. Goods and services tax collections are expected to be 14% lower. Expenditure will rise with continued support for households and businesses. Despite drawing on past reserves, the government aims to maintain a "prudence, not austerity" approach, investing in national priorities while funding sustainably through higher taxes and effective spending.

site_title: Singapore to expand Progressive Wage Model to more sectors
summary: The Singapore government plans to expand the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) to more sectors, aiming to raise skill levels and create better jobs. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the move in Parliament, stating it will help slow down the growth of the foreign workforce in these sectors. The PWM, currently covering cleaning and security sectors, will be expanded to other sectors using a "four-in-one framework" that includes career ladders, skills upgrading, productivity improvement, and wage enhancement. The government will also provide support for the transition, acknowledging potential higher business costs.

site_title: 'Gilded cage': private pools, fancy meals in Thailand's luxury quarantine
summary: Thailand is reopening its borders to a small number of tourists, with the first batch arriving in Phuket for 14-day compulsory quarantine. The 300 tourists from China and Scandinavia will have to undergo two coronavirus tests daily, with a "war room" of doctors and security guards overseeing the process. To add to their luxury experience, they will also have access to private pools and gourmet meals. The move marks a significant step for Thailand's tourism industry, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore wants to be Asia's carbon services hub: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore aims to establish itself as a carbon services hub in Asia, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced. The move is driven by growing demand for sustainable development and the need to limit carbon emissions. The government will invest in research and development of energy and resource efficiency technologies, such as hydrogen and carbon capture, to support the transition to a more sustainable economy. This initiative complements Singapore's existing plans for a circular economy and increased deployment of renewable energy sources.

site_title: Singapore digital trade documentation framework to combine with global Swift network
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has partnered with global financial messaging network Swift to accelerate digital trade by combining Singapore's TradeTrust framework with the Swift community. The goal is a more efficient, cost-effective, and paperless trade system, reducing the need for multiple bilateral linkages and siloed systems. This partnership aims to benefit over 11,000 financial institutions and corporates in 200 countries and territories, enhancing cross-border trade digitalisation.

site_title: Temporary bridging loan programme for firms extended until Sept 2021
summary: The Singapore government has extended the Temporary Bridging Loan Programme for firms until September 2021, providing working capital support for viable businesses. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the extension in a Ministerial Statement, citing the need to maintain support for businesses as the economy recovers. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will also extend the MAS Singapore Dollar Facility for Enterprise Singapore Loans until September 2021, with additional details on payment moratoriums to be announced.

site_title: Cineworld suspends operations at UK, US theatres, impacting 45,000 jobs
summary: Cineworld, the world's second-largest cinema chain, has suspended operations at its 536 Regal theatres in the US and 127 Cineworld and Picturehouse theatres in the UK, impacting 45,000 jobs, due to the coronavirus crisis. The temporary shutdown, starting October 8, will be closely monitored, with future plans to resume operations pending concrete guidance on reopening status.

site_title: UK technical failure in Covid-19 testing data system now fixed, minister says
summary: The UK's Covid-19 testing data system experienced a technical failure that delayed the reporting of 15,000 test results, including for contact tracers. The issue has been fixed, according to Work and Pensions Secretary Thérèse Coffey, who assured that similar problems will not occur again. The UK reported a record 22,961 daily Covid-19 cases on Sunday.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump ahead of budget, Trump's improving health signs add to cheer
summary: Australian shares rose 2.6% on Monday, the largest daily gain in two-and-a-half months, ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia policy meeting and federal budget. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,941.6 points, driven by optimism over US President Donald Trump's improving health. This comes after a 2.9% drop last week.

site_title: Singapore's last village proves nostalgic tourism hit in pandemic
summary: Singapore's last traditional village, Kampong Lorong Buangkok, has seen a surge in local tourism since the COVID-19 pandemic. The village, home to 26 single-story wooden houses, has been attracting visitors who crave nostalgia and a glimpse into the country's past. Authorities have supported local tourism with campaigns and cash vouchers for staycations. Tour operators offer unique experiences, such as learning traditional crafts and interacting with residents, for a fee of around S$200-S$250 per visit. The village's low rents, averaging S$6.50 per month, also make it an attractive option for locals and tourists alike.

images.alt_text: Hidden between the skyscrapers of Singapore's urban jungle sits Kampong Lorong Buangkok - the only surviving traditional village in this modern city-state of 5.7 million people.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on Trump health
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday as investors reacted positively to US President Donald Trump's health update. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.23% to 23,312.14, while the Topix index advanced 1.74% to 1,637.25. The positive response was attributed to Trump's improved health after contracting the coronavirus, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Hot stock: UG Healthcare up 9% after Malaysia EPF Board raises stake
summary: UG Healthcare Corporation's shares jumped 9.1% after the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) Board of Malaysia increased its stake to 5.29% by acquiring 605,000 shares at S$2.55 each. The stock traded at S$1.02, with 38.8 million shares changing hands. This move follows the EPF Board's acquisition of a stake in Riverstone Holdings, a glove-making peer. The stock split took effect on Friday, enhancing trading liquidity and broadening the shareholder base.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on Trump health, stimulus hope
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday following reports of US President Donald Trump's improving health after a week-long hospital stay due to COVID-19. The news boosted stimulus hopes, with traders expecting lawmakers to reach a deal on a new economic package. Analysts say the episode could increase pressure on Congress to act, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin holding talks on a potential $2.2 trillion package. Markets in Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Seoul rose, while Shanghai remained closed for a public holiday, with riskier assets and higher-yielding currencies benefiting from the positive outlook for Trump's health.

site_title: Singapore SMEs, individuals given more time to resume full loan repayments
summary: Singapore has extended its debt moratorium program for SMEs and individuals until June 30, 2021, providing more relief from the COVID-19 fallout. The Extended Support Scheme - Standardised (ESS-S) allows SMEs in Tier 1 and 2 sectors to defer 80% of principal payments on secured loans until June 30, 2021. Individuals can also opt for reduced monthly instalments pegged at 60% of their monthly instalment on residential, commercial, and industrial property loans. The measures aim to help borrowers tide through the current economic difficulties and emerge with a sustainable debt burden as the economy recovers.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse proposes expanding DAX to 40 companies
summary: Deutsche Boerse has proposed expanding the DAX index to 40 companies, with tougher membership conditions, including quarterly financial submissions and profitability requirements. The mid-cap index MDAX would decrease to 50 companies from 60. Companies failing to submit figures would be excluded, while profitable companies would be prioritized for membership. These changes aim to increase transparency and reflect the market's dynamics more accurately.

site_title: Google defers Indian in-app commission fees after startups complain
summary: Google has deferred its 30% commission fee for in-app purchases in India, extending the deadline to March 31, 2022, in response to complaints from startups. The move comes after Indian developers protested the fee, citing it as excessive compared to credit card payment processors. Google stated the policy applies only to apps charging for downloads or digital items, and it will hold listening sessions and policy workshops to address concerns. The company maintains the fee covers app security and marketing benefits, but the move aims to ease tensions with Indian developers.

site_title: State premier Armin Laschet is frontrunner to succeed Merkel: party sources
summary: Armin Laschet, the premier of North Rhine-Westphalia, is emerging as the frontrunner to succeed Angela Merkel as the Christian Democrats' candidate for chancellor in Germany's federal election next year. With the support of over 40% of the party's delegates, Laschet is seen as the most likely winner of the internal party leadership vote, which is set for December. His centrist views and ability to negotiate a possible coalition government with the Greens make him a strong contender, and he has also been building his international profile by meeting with French President Emmanuel Macron and other EU leaders.

site_title: New bill to help micro, small firms in Singapore wind up, restructure in a faster way
summary: Singapore is introducing a Simplified Insolvency Programme (SIP) to help micro and small companies restructure debts or wind up operations more quickly and cheaply. The program, set to be introduced in October, will provide two temporary processes adapted from the existing Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Act. Key features include a lower creditor approval threshold and a simplified winding-up process, which will be voluntary and not court-ordered. The program aims to support companies financially distressed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Three priorities in Singapore's refreshed economic strategy post-Covid-19: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced Singapore's refreshed economic strategy post-Covid-19, focusing on three priority areas: remaking the country as a "global Asia" node of technology, innovation, and enterprise; fostering inclusive growth; and investing in economic resilience and sustainability. This strategy is built on the Industry Transformation Maps (ITM) framework and aims to improve productivity, median income, and employment rates, while addressing vulnerabilities in the labor market. The refreshed strategy aims to drive growth for individuals, industries, and the nation.

site_title: The unusual couple: how data privacy and GDPR can advance CSR efforts
summary: The introduction of EU GDPR has set a global standard for data protection, driving transformation in enterprise information management. Companies are now focusing on data privacy as a key aspect of corporate social responsibility (CSR). By associating data privacy with CSR, businesses can enhance operational efficiency, generate new insights, and rebuild reputations after data breaches. Despite challenges, this shift is expected to close the gap between CSR and data privacy, offering benefits for enterprises, customers, and business partners. Effective data management will become a crucial part of CSR efforts, contributing to a better world.

site_title: Swiss duty free operator Dufry to enlist Alibaba as shareholder
summary: Swiss duty-free operator Dufry is set to enlist Alibaba as a shareholder, with Alibaba planning to acquire a stake of up to 9.99% in the company. The joint venture aims to develop the travel retail business in China and enhance Dufry's digital transformation. The deal will provide Dufry with 700 million Swiss francs, up from 500 million previously, to fund a buyout of its Hudson unit and other corporate purposes. Alibaba will hold a 51% stake in the joint venture, while Dufry will retain the rest.

site_title: Oil rises more than 1% after upbeat signals from Trump doctors
summary: Oil prices rose more than 1% on Monday after US President Donald Trump's doctors suggested he could be discharged from hospital as soon as Monday, easing political uncertainty in global markets. Brent crude rose to $39.79 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose to $37.64 a barrel, driven by improved health signals for Trump. However, analysts noted that rising coronavirus case numbers and stalled US fiscal stimulus plan could still dampen global economic recovery and impact oil demand.

site_title: Multi-ministry taskforce studying how to revive Singapore's air hub
summary: Singapore's multi-ministry taskforce is studying ways to revive the country's air hub and restore air connectivity as part of broader reopening plans. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the effort, while Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for a safe and calibrated approach to overseas travel. Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung will provide more details on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore retail sales down 5.7% in August; F&B dragged by caterer sector
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 5.7% in August, an improvement from July's 8.5% drop, due to strong demand for cars. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales fell 8.4% year-over-year. F&B sales, particularly from the food caterer sector, were significantly impacted, with a 28.6% year-over-year decline. Online sales accounted for 10.9% of total retail sales value.

site_title: Singapore's O&M, aviation, retail, tourism firms to get course fee subsidies till next June
summary: Singapore is extending the Enhanced Training Support Package (ETSP) for another six months until June 30, 2021, providing 90% course fee subsidies for firms in hard-hit sectors. The package now includes the offshore and marine (O&M) sector, starting October 5. The government aims to encourage upskilling and position companies for recovery and growth. The ETSP has already supported over 121,000 training places since its enhancement in the Resilience Budget.

site_title: Parents of newborns to get one-off support to help with expenses: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that parents of newborns will receive one-off additional support to help with expenses, in addition to the Baby Bonus cash gift of up to S$10,000. The new support aims to alleviate income uncertainty during the coronavirus pandemic. Minister Indranee Rajah will share more details on the additional support soon.

site_title: Singapore's response to Covid-19 today will shape next 5 to 10 years of growth: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that Singapore's response to COVID-19 will shape the country's growth over the next 5 to 10 years. In a ministerial statement, he announced extensions to existing schemes and support measures, with a focus on preparing for the next lap of growth. The refreshed economic strategy prioritizes remaking Singapore as a global-Asia node of technology, fostering inclusive growth, and investing in economic resilience and sustainability. The government committed S$100 billion in support measures, which will help mitigate the economic impact of COVID-19 and pave the way for future growth.

site_title: Capability-building grants boosted; those with disabilities to get 50% wage support
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the extension and enhancement of capability-building grants to support businesses in internationalising, transforming, and digitalising. The government will also provide a 50% wage support of up to S$5,000 per month for 12 months to new hires with disabilities under the Jobs Growth Incentive scheme. The enhanced support aims to boost growth, support workers, and build new skills, with the grants and wage support to be announced in the coming weeks.

site_title: More than half of jobs saved in Singapore are due to Jobs Support Scheme: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that support measures introduced during the coronavirus pandemic have "substantially cushioned" the economic damage, saving about 155,000 jobs over two years. More than half of these jobs, approximately 77,500, are attributed to the Jobs Support Scheme. The combined Budgets are expected to prevent a 5.6% contraction in GDP in 2020 and 4.8% in 2021, with total support measures amounting to close to S$100 billion.

site_title: Suez warns 'hostile' Veolia bid could cost up to 10,000 jobs
summary: French water and energy giant Suez has expressed strong opposition to a potential hostile takeover bid by Veolia, warning that the deal could result in up to 10,000 job losses worldwide. Suez's board has rejected Veolia's proposal to buy a 29.9% stake in the company, which is currently held by Engie, and has urged Engie to reconsider its support for the deal. Veolia has stated that it will not launch a hostile bid, but Suez remains skeptical, citing concerns over job losses and the potential for a full takeover of the company.

site_title: Argentina president hopes for IMF deal 'as soon as possible'
summary: Argentina President Alberto Fernandez hopes to reach an agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to refinance a $44 billion loan "as soon as possible." The announcement comes ahead of an IMF mission's arrival on Tuesday to focus on the country's debt restructuring. Fernandez believes an agreement is necessary for economic predictability and has had conversations with IMF Chief Kristalina Georgieva. He aims to continue working with the IMF to find quick answers to their concerns and reach a new credit program agreement.

site_title: Broker's take: Singapore property developers trading at discount, RHB keeps 'overweight'
summary: Singapore-listed real estate developers are trading at deep discounts to their book values and revalued net asset values, offering "good value" at current levels, according to RHB analyst Vijay Natarajan. Despite the sector index being down 28% in the year to date, analysts expect modest declines in book values and stable prices. RHB keeps its "overweight" rating on the sector, with top picks including CapitaLand and City Developments Limited, citing strong rebound in transaction volumes and demand from HDB upgraders.

images.alt_text: The research team's top pick is still CapitaLand, with a target price of S$3.75.

site_title: Larger gatherings may soon be possible; Phase Three roadmap in the works: Gan
summary: Singapore is considering a Phase Three roadmap, which may allow for larger gatherings and more relaxed social and dining group size limits. The government has begun piloting activities with more attendees, including trade exhibitions and religious worship sessions, and plans to review the current social gathering limits. Minister for Health Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for caution and continued vigilance, citing the risk of a resurgence of cases if restrictions are lifted prematurely. A flexible work-from-home arrangement will remain the default, with employers and employees encouraged to work out mutual arrangements.

site_title: Australia's Victoria state to boost testing on path to easing restrictions
summary: Victoria, Australia's second most-populous state, plans to increase COVID-19 testing to ease lockdown restrictions. New daily infections have fallen to nine cases, down from 12 previously. The state aims to ease restrictions when the 14-day rolling case average falls below five, potentially in late October. Premier Daniel Andrews emphasized the importance of testing for those with symptoms to protect the community. Australia has conducted over 2.7 million tests and has one of the world's highest test-to-population ratios.

site_title: Wildfires raze dozens of homes in New Zealand
summary: Wildfires in New Zealand's South Island village of Lake Ohau have destroyed up to 50 homes, forcing residents to flee for their lives. The blaze, fueled by strong winds, has burned 4,600 hectares of land and left a "war zone" of burned-out cars and gutted homes. Authorities said it was a miracle no one was hurt, but warned that the fire's unpredictability made it challenging to contain. The fire is attributed to climate change, with warmer temperatures and droughts expected to lead to more frequent and intense wildfires.

site_title: Britain open to Aussie-style EU trade deal but Australia wants more
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson suggests his country could trade with the EU on similar terms to Australia if a post-Brexit trade deal isn't reached. However, Australia is seeking a fully-fledged trade deal to improve market access and reduce tariffs on its exports. Britain's aspirations for a trade deal have been gradually whittled down due to disagreements with the EU, with Johnson citing an Australian-style arrangement as a possible model. Australia wants to eliminate EU tariffs on industrial goods and agricultural exports, while also aligning regulatory systems to enable business to flow.

images.alt_text: As Britain's negotiations with the European Union on a post-Brexit trade deal go down to the wire, Prime Minister Boris Johnson says his country could trade with the bloc on similar terms to Australia, if no agreement is reached.

site_title: Gold holds steady as market eyes Trump's health
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Monday, with spot gold at US$1,896.21 per ounce, as investors awaited updates on US President Donald Trump's health amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The US dollar fell 0.1% against rivals, while stock markets rose, and gold futures were down 0.3%. Economists believe uncertainty surrounding Trump's condition will keep investors hesitant to sell gold, and a new coronavirus relief aid package is needed to boost gold prices, which have risen 25% this year.

site_title: Singapore Airlines launches digital version of Star Alliance Connection Service
summary: Singapore Airlines has launched the digital version of the Star Alliance Connection Service, allowing passengers to access optimized routes, distance, and time information for connecting flights. The digital service is embedded in participating airline's mobile apps, providing airport maps and intuitive navigational services. The initial release focuses on London Heathrow Airport Terminal 2, with plans to roll out the service to more airports and adopt by other member airlines in the future. The digital connection service aims to provide a seamless and frictionless experience for customers.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump 2% on jobs stimulus, Trump's health progress
summary: Australian shares rose 2.3% on Monday, driven by plans to provide additional wage subsidies to stimulate employment. US President Donald Trump's health progress remains uncertain, with conflicting signals from doctors treating him for COVID-19. Despite Trump's health concerns, investors are hopeful for a swifter recovery.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic trials pre-flight Covid testing for air crews
summary: Virgin Atlantic Airways has launched a trial of pre-flight Covid-19 testing for its cabin crew and pilots, with plans to expand the program to test every operating crew at least once a month. The trial, launched on September 30, aims to instill confidence in flying amid rising coronavirus cases in the UK and globally. Virgin Atlantic is also calling for a wider coordinated passenger testing regime to enable healthy flyers to avoid mandatory quarantine measures. The airline's chief customer and operating officer, Corneel Koster, stated that a passenger testing regime is crucial for the UK's economic recovery and tourism.

site_title: Shares of Japanese startup surge 300% on demand for cloud-based accounting
summary: Shares of Japanese startup Freee KK surged 300% after going public, valuing the company at $3.7 billion, despite not yet showing a profit. The company's cloud-based accounting service has seen significant demand, with over 220,000 subscribers, and aims to outpace market growth to become the dominant player. Founder Daisuke Sasaki prioritizes acquiring new users over near-term earnings, seeing the pandemic as an opportunity to accelerate digitalization. Market experts have mixed views, with some analysts cutting their ratings due to short-term challenges.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.85 points to 1,501.15. A total of 206.84 million lots were traded, worth RM138.51 million. Gainers outpaced losers 212 to 113.

site_title: Japan struggles to save beloved bullet trains from running out of passengers
summary: Japan's bullet trains, known for their high passenger volumes, are struggling due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The country's two largest railway companies, East Japan Railway Co and West Japan Railway Co, are forecasting their deepest losses since the country's rail network was privatized in 1987. With travel restrictions and people's reluctance to take short breaks, the industry is expected to experience an L-shaped recovery, rather than a V-shaped one. The "Go To" campaign, aimed at spurring domestic travel, has failed to provide the desired impact, and the industry faces steep discounts and high fixed costs, making it challenging to return to profitability.

site_title: Green electricity provider to create 1,000 new jobs in UK
summary: UK clean energy company Octopus Energy Ltd plans to create 1,000 new jobs by the end of 2021, doubling its workforce. The new positions will mainly be for graduates and will be spread across its sites in London, Brighton, and Manchester. The company's cloud-computing platform, Kraken, aims to simplify the way consumers buy electricity and make renewable energy more accessible and affordable. Prime Minister Boris Johnson welcomed the announcement, stating that it will help the UK build back greener and create skilled jobs.

site_title: Saudi scraps VAT for home buyers to keep boom rolling
summary: Saudi Arabia scrapped a 15% value-added tax on property sales, replacing it with a 5% real estate sales tax, to maintain its mortgage boom. The government will also cover taxes for first-time home buyers of properties up to $362,900. This move aims to boost home ownership among citizens, reaching 62% in March, with a target of 70% by 2030. The decision is expected to maintain momentum in the mortgage market, with most home purchases falling within the tax-free threshold.

site_title: Line Corp gears up for food fight in Thailand
summary: Line Corp's food delivery business in Thailand is preparing for a battle with competitors like Grab, following its merger with restaurant listings site Wongnai and a capital injection. The company aims to leverage its 47 million Thai users for an edge in the market. Despite growing demand due to the pandemic, the sector faces questions over profitability. Line Man's expansion hopes to capitalize on its fast-growing delivery business, but the competition and market uncertainty pose significant challenges. The company's success will be crucial in the Thai food delivery market.

site_title: Chipmaker SMIC says US placing export restrictions on suppliers
summary: US export restrictions are being imposed on suppliers of Chinese chipmaker SMIC, potentially impacting its production and operations. The US Bureau of Industry and Security has issued letters to SMIC's suppliers, and the company is evaluating the effects. SMIC dropped 5% in Hong Kong, adding to its 27% slump in September. China's Foreign Ministry vowed to protect its businesses' rights and interests amid escalating tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Fujitsu still investigating causes of Tokyo stock bourse outage: CEO
summary: Fujitsu is still investigating the causes of the Tokyo Stock Exchange's (TSE) worst-ever outage last week, with CEO Takahito Tokita vowing to find the causes and prevent recurrences. The outage, which occurred due to a hardware problem and failure to switch to a back-up, was the first full-day suspension since the exchange switched to all-electronic trading in 1999. The TSE has confirmed the glitch was caused by a hardware problem at its "Arrowhead" trading system.

site_title: New three-tier lockdown planned for England: The Guardian
summary: The UK government is planning a new three-tier lockdown for England, with leaked documents suggesting tougher measures including pub closures and social distancing bans. The plan aims to simplify existing local restrictions and improve compliance with rules. However, the measures have not been finalized, and some may be relaxed. The lockdown is intended to address rising Covid-19 infection rates, particularly in major cities. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson denied the effectiveness of current local restrictions.

images.alt_text: A new three-tier lockdown is being planned for England, The Guardian reported, citing leaked government documents which revealed tougher measures that could be implemented locally or nationally if the government fails to get Covid-19 cases under control.

site_title: Food companies urge Britain to adopt tougher rules to protect tropical forests
summary: Food companies in Britain, including Tesco and Unilever, have urged the government to strengthen plans to stop tropical forest deforestation by tightening supply chain oversight. The companies, which supply cocoa, palm oil, and soy, welcomed the existing plan but said it is not enough to halt deforestation. They called on the government to go further to address the issue, following growing scrutiny over the industry's environmental impact.

site_title: Malaysia's UEM Sunrise's major shareholder proposes merger for it and Eco World
summary: UEM Sunrise Bhd, Malaysia's largest property developer, has received a merger proposal from its major shareholder UEM Group. The proposal, made via a letter, suggests combining UEM Sunrise and peer Eco World Development Group Bhd to "strengthen performance and sustainability" amid subdued macro-economic conditions. The proposed merger aims to consolidate resources and capabilities to drive performance and sustainability.

site_title: StarHub, U Mobile complete 5G cross-border video call trial
summary: StarHub and U Mobile have completed a 5G cross-border video call trial, marking the first multi-party, roaming video conference call over 5G standalone technology between Singapore and Malaysia. The trial achieved download speeds of over 1.3 gigabytes per second and a latency of under five milliseconds. The successful trial aims to pave the way for consumers and businesses to enjoy crystal-clear communication and entertainment experiences, regardless of location. The companies plan to collaborate to establish the best 5G roaming experience when 5G becomes commercially available in both countries.

site_title: Kenzo Takada, who brought Japanese fashion to the world, dies at 81
summary: Kenzo Takada, a renowned Japanese fashion designer, has passed away at 81 due to complications from the novel coronavirus. Born in 1939, Takada shook up the French fashion world with his vibrant prints and mix-and-match aesthetic, influencing generations of designers, including Yohji Yamamoto and Rei Kawakubo. Known for his joyful and chaotic designs, Takada also introduced menswear and perfume to his brand, but stepped away from fashion in 1999. He continued to explore other creative avenues, including opera costumes, painting, and homewares design.

site_title: Trial to begin of suspects in UK migrant truck tragedy
summary: Four men are set to go on trial in the UK in connection with the 2019 deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants found in a refrigerated lorry in southeast England. The victims, including 10 teenagers, died from lack of oxygen and overheating. The trial begins after a post-mortem examination revealed the cause of death. The case highlights the plight of migrants desperate to reach Britain, and the UK government has been criticized for its handling of the tragedy.

site_title: US takes stake in battery-metals firm to wean itself off China
summary: The US government has invested $25 million in TechMet Ltd, a battery-metals company, to develop a Brazilian nickel and cobalt mine. This move aims to reduce dependence on China for cobalt, a key material used in electric vehicle batteries. The investment supports US foreign policy and development of critical materials for advanced technology. The US International Development Finance Corporation will hold an equity stake in the company, marking a significant step in the US's efforts to diversify its supply chain and reduce its reliance on Chinese materials.

site_title: 'More modest' Christmas light-up on Orchard Road amid pandemic
summary: The Christmas light-up on Orchard Road will take place on a "more modest scale" this year due to the pandemic. The display, from Nov 13 to Jan 1, 2021, will include a 360-degree virtual tour and a closed-door light-up ceremony at Ion Orchard shopping mall, live-streamed on Facebook and YouTube. This move aims to minimize crowds and ensure a safer experience for attendees amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 15.32 points to 2,511.43, driven by gains in local banks and other actively traded counters. This follows a weak jobs report and President Trump's COVID-19 announcement in the US, which led to losses in US stocks. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.1% and the broader Topix index advanced 1.2%.

site_title: Australia business conditions, confidence pick up but sentiment still gloomy
summary: Australia's business conditions index rose 6 points to 0 in September, the highest level since the pandemic in April. Despite the improvement, the index remains below its long-run average of +6. Business confidence also picked up to -4 from -8 in August, but remains in negative territory. The economy is showing signs of recovery, with rising trading, profitability, and forward orders, but employment remains stagnant, and capex stays in negative territory. Overall, the improvement in conditions suggests the economy is slowly opening up, but still faces challenges.

site_title: Frasers Property Australia wins build-to-rent project in Queensland
summary: Frasers Property Australia won a bid to join the Queensland government's build-to-rent (BTR) pilot, creating 354 apartments in Brisbane. The 25-level building will include affordable key-worker housing options, with 144 units subsidized by the state government. The development will feature amenities like rooftop dog parks, pools, and co-working offices, and is expected to be carbon neutral upon completion, starting construction in mid-2021 and finishing by 2024.

site_title: UK supermarkets want tougher regulations to stop deforestation
summary: UK's top supermarkets, including Tesco and Nestle, have urged the government to strengthen regulations to ban products linked to deforestation. The companies, along with fast food chains and food manufacturers, want laws to apply to all deforestation, not just illegal cases. They argue that current laws are insufficient, citing the vast majority of deforestation being caused by agricultural commodities. The companies also want laws to consider the impact on deforestation rather than just turnover. The move comes as deforestation accounts for 11% of greenhouse gases, with the majority caused by agricultural commodities.

site_title: Phillip SGD money market ETF debuts on SGX with initial AUM of S$100m
summary: The Phillip SGD Money Market ETF debuted on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on October 5, 2020, with an initial assets under management (AUM) of S$100 million. The ETF, managed by Phillip Capital Management, invests in short-term money market securities and deposits to generate returns comparable to Singapore-dollar savings deposits. It tracks the FTSE SGD three-month Singapore dollar swap offered rate (SOR) Index and aims to provide liquidity management tools for fund managers and individual investors, attracting strong interest from investors in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Trump health
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday as investors reacted positively to US President Donald Trump's health improving after contracting the coronavirus. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.06% to 23,273.36, while the Topix index gained 1.19% to 1,628.32. The positive sentiment followed Trump's recent statements indicating his health was improving, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Klopp shocked by Liverpool collapse to concede seven at Aston Villa
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp expressed shock and disappointment after his team's 7-2 loss to Aston Villa, becoming the first reigning English champions to concede seven goals in a league match since 1953. Ollie Watkins scored a hat-trick, and the Reds' high line was torn apart by Villa's counter-attacks. Klopp attributed the collapse to mistakes and a lack of cohesion, but has little time to make corrections before their next match against Everton.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at Monday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.47% at the start of trade on Monday, driven by improving news about US President Donald Trump's health after a coronavirus test. The Hang Seng Index rose to 24,039.39. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. The rally comes despite US-EU trade tensions and global economic concerns.

site_title: Djokovic eyes Paris payback for Khachanov as Kenin aims higher
summary: Novak Djokovic advances to the French Open's last 16 for a record 11th consecutive year, seeking an 18th Grand Slam title. He faces 15th seed Karen Khachanov, who beat Djokovic in the 2018 Paris Masters. In the women's draw, top seeds Sofia Kenin and Petra Kvitova continue their quests, with Kenin aiming higher than ever before. Only four seeds remain in the women's draw, setting the stage for a wide-open tournament.

site_title: US refiners look to cash in on Canada's greener fuel standard
summary: US oil refineries are aggressively producing renewable diesel to capitalize on Canada's planned greener fuel standard, which aims to cut 30 million tonnes of emissions by 2030. Canadian companies have been slow to prepare, with only three projects publicly announced, while at least five US refiners have announced plans to produce the fuel. US states like Colorado and Washington are also moving towards similar standards, creating a sufficient market for renewable diesel. Canadian refiners face longer regulatory delays, putting them at a disadvantage, and strict crop criteria may limit the use of local feedstocks.

site_title: UK launches scheme to help new Covid-19 jobless back into work
summary: The UK government has launched the Job Entry Targeted Support (JETS) scheme to help those left jobless due to the Covid-19 pandemic get back into work. The £238 million programme will provide tailored, flexible support, including specialist advice and coaching on CVs and interviews. The scheme aims to boost employment prospects for over 250,000 people. However, economists warn that unemployment risks rising sharply, with the jobless rate expected to jump to 7.5%. The opposition Labour Party has criticized the scheme as "piecemeal" and "too little, too late".

site_title: Norway oil strike expands, 8% of output at risk
summary: Norwegian oil workers have expanded their strike, affecting up to six offshore fields, with the potential to reduce oil production capacity by 330,000 barrels per day (8% of total output). The strike, which began on September 30, has escalated after a group of 43 workers organized by the Lederne union went on strike. The Norwegian Oil and Gas Association warned of a significant reduction in production, with energy firms expected to take measures to shut down production. The strike's impact on global oil markets is expected to be significant.

site_title: Tottenham hit 10-man Man Utd for six on Mourinho's return
summary: Manchester United suffered its worst home defeat since 2011, losing 6-1 to Tottenham at Old Trafford. Anthony Martial's red card in the first half contributed to the rout, with Son Heung Min and Harry Kane scoring twice each. Tottenham's attack exploited a disorganized United defense, and Jose Mourinho's return to the stadium was marked with a dream win. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer described the defeat as the "worst feeling in 15 years" for the club.

site_title: After Trump tests positive, Biden campaign seeks to keep focus on Covid-19 response
summary: President Donald Trump is undergoing treatment for Covid-19 at a military hospital, shifting the focus of the presidential campaign from the election to the nation's response to the pandemic. Democratic challenger Joe Biden's campaign is capitalizing on Trump's illness, highlighting the contrast between their approaches to the virus. Biden has consistently worn a mask and emphasized the need for caution, while Trump's campaign has portrayed him as a "warrior" fighting the virus. As Trump's health situation is unclear, Biden's campaign remains focused on the pandemic, with Biden scheduled to resume in-person campaigning in Florida.

site_title: Cerberus repackaging near-junk CMBS into top-rated securities
summary: Cerberus Capital Management has restructured commercial mortgage bonds into top-rated securities, leveraging low-quality commercial mortgages to create triple-A debt. The investment firm has packaged interest-only strips from delinquent mortgages into notes with AAA ratings, offering high yields and short-term maturity. Hedge funds are attracted to the high ratings and yields, despite the commercial real estate market facing challenges due to the pandemic. Experts warn that the resecuritisation may pose a risk of principal loss for investors, particularly those with lower-rated mortgages.

site_title: Poll finds Biden widening lead over Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden has widened his lead over incumbent President Donald Trump in the presidential election, according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll. Biden now leads Trump by 10 points, with 51% of likely voters backing him, while 41% support Trump. Most Americans believe Trump could have avoided infection if he had taken the virus more seriously, with 65% agreeing that he probably wouldn't have been infected. Trump's hospitalization has sparked a split-screen response, with many Republican leaders testing positive for COVID-19.

site_title: Heeton plans to balance cost cuts with discount purchases
summary: Heeton Holdings, a Singapore-listed property group, is exploring cost-cutting measures and potential acquisitions to balance its revenue streams amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Chief Operating Officer Ivan Hoh mentioned diversifying into student accommodation and logistics, which could provide stable income and less management. The company has 14 managed hotels, with 10 in Britain, and posted S$12.7 million in revenue for the first half of 2020, with hospitality accounting for almost two-thirds of its top line. Heeton aims to balance its portfolio, with a potential revenue split of three-fifths from hotels and the rest from development.

site_title: Manhattan home sales echo 2009 with supply pile-up
summary: Manhattan home sales have echoed the 2009 market, with 9,319 unsold listings in the third quarter, the highest since the global financial crisis. It would take 20.3 months to clear the inventory. Closed sales are slow, with average buyer discounts reaching 8.9% and luxury sales receiving 12% reductions. Despite this, median prices for all and luxury sales rose 7.3% and 23%, respectively, as buyers seek bargains.

site_title: ISOTeam says independent director in EHT probe can still perform duties
summary: ISOTeam's independent director, Ng Kheng Choo, can continue performing her duties despite being involved in an ongoing probe into Eagle Hospitality Trust's (EHT) directors and officers. The probe, led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department, concerns suspected breaches of disclosure requirements. Ng had joined EHT's board in 2019 but resigned in 2020. ISOTeam's nominating committee and board have stated that Ng's involvement does not compromise her duties, with her abstaining from decision-making until the probe's outcome is known.

site_title: Debt cancellation needed to help poorest countries: World Bank president
summary: World Bank President David Malpass warned that the Covid-19 pandemic could trigger a debt crisis in some countries, prompting investors to consider debt relief or cancellation. Malpass emphasized the need to reduce debt levels, particularly through restructuring, to prevent debt crises. This statement comes as the World Bank faces growing concerns about the debt burden of the world's poorest countries.

site_title: South Korea's Sept factory activity shrinks at slowest pace in eight months
summary: South Korea's factory activity in September showed the slowest pace of contraction in eight months, with the IHS Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 49.8. This is the highest reading since January, but still below the 50-mark threshold. Output returned to growth, but employment contracted for the 17th straight month. The data suggests improving demand conditions, but subdued domestic and foreign demand pose a threat to the economic recovery, with the pandemic remaining a concern.

site_title: Doctors monitoring Trump's lungs, giving steroid to fight Covid-19
summary: President Donald Trump is being treated at Walter Reed National Military Medical Centre for COVID-19, with a medical team monitoring his lung condition. Trump received supplemental oxygen and the steroid dexamethasone, and has taken the antiviral drug Remdesivir. His condition has been described as improving, but he had previously run a high fever and experienced low oxygen levels. The White House initially downplayed Trump's illness, leading to confusion among supporters and the public. Trump's campaign vows to continue its aggressive schedule despite his health concerns, with a presidential debate scheduled for Wednesday.

site_title: Argentine peso slides after central bank abandons crawling peg
summary: Argentina's central bank abandoned its crawling peg strategy, allowing the peso to fluctuate more freely, leading to a 0.91% decline to 76.95 per US dollar. The black market peso plummeted to a record low 149 per dollar. The move aims to stimulate growth and support the peso, but analysts question its effectiveness in stabilizing the currency. Argentina is facing an estimated 12% economic contraction this year, its third consecutive year in recession, after restructuring US$100 billion of foreign debt.

site_title: NEC to buy Swiss financial software firm Avaloq for 2.05b francs
summary: NEC Corp agreed to buy Swiss financial software company Avaloq Group AG for 2.05 billion Swiss francs (S$3 billion), entering globally into digital finance software. The deal, expected to be completed by April 2021, will spearhead NEC's expansion into digital finance. This move aims to strengthen NEC's presence in the global market and enhance its digital finance capabilities.

site_title: New York mayor announces shutdown plan for nine neighbourhoods
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan to shut down nine neighborhoods in Brooklyn and Queens due to rising COVID-19 cases, particularly among Orthodox Jewish communities. The shutdown will include closing non-essential businesses and schools, and is pending approval from Governor Andrew Cuomo. This marks a setback for the city's efforts to control the pandemic, which has claimed nearly 24,000 lives. The decision comes after a recent spike in cases coincided with the Jewish High Holidays.

site_title: Pandemic sharpens US Senate struggle over Trump's high-court nominee
summary: US Senate struggles to confirm Trump's Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The nomination was announced in a White House ceremony attended by over 150 people, with at least seven participants testing positive for the virus, including President Trump. The confirmation process is complicated, with two Republican senators, Mike Lee and Thom Tillis, currently self-quarantining. Democrats are pushing for a delay in the vote, citing safety concerns, while Republicans are exploring alternative options, including holding a vote from the Senate balcony. The Senate majority leader has postponed floor action for two weeks, but confirmation hearings are set to begin on October 12.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Property, HC Surgical, AsiaPhos, Heeton, OKH, IReit
summary: Frasers Property won a bid to join the Queensland government's build-to-rent pilot, and shares remained flat at S$1.17. HC Surgical Specialists' surgeon Julian Ong won his defamation lawsuit appeal and obtained an injunction against the plaintiff, Serene Tiong. No specific trading updates were mentioned for the other listed companies.

site_title: Rocky week expected with new wave of uncertainty
summary: US stocks are expected to face uncertainty this week due to President Donald Trump's Covid-19 diagnosis and ongoing negotiations on a stimulus bill. Trump's doctors initially reported a mild case, but White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows contradicted this, suggesting a serious illness. The president's health could impact his campaigning and debates, and potentially the chances of a stimulus deal before November. The Federal Reserve's warnings about a flagging recovery may be confirmed, with job losses and furloughs continuing due to the pandemic.

site_title: Changing economy and climate hit Austria's Alpine pastures
summary: Austria's traditional Alpine pastures are facing threats from economic changes and climate change, which are causing thousands of cows to disappear and pastures to revert to nature. The small-scale farms in Tyrol state are becoming economically unviable, forcing farmers to pivot to more reliable sources of income. As a result, the pastures are being overgrown with shrubs and trees, altering the landscape and threatening the future of the tradition. Climate change is accelerating this effect, with warmer temperatures and increased precipitation causing more intense vegetation growth, making it difficult for cows to graze.

site_title: Dollar and yen gain as Trump's positive Covid-19 test sparks haven buying
summary: President Donald Trump tested positive for Covid-19, sparking a haven buying surge in the dollar and yen, with the yen reaching a one-week high of 104.95 against the dollar. The news added uncertainty to the already volatile US presidential election season, but market reaction has since calmed down. The dollar rose 0.1% against a basket of six major currencies, while the euro fell 0.3% against the dollar. The news had little impact on US nonfarm payrolls, which rose less than expected but saw a drop in the unemployment rate.

site_title: Risk of debt shortage seen shaking German bonds out of slumber
summary: Germany's bonds are expected to face increased volatility, with benchmark yields potentially falling to minus 0.6% in the fourth quarter, according to Citigroup. A shortage of bunds, driven by reduced government debt sales and continued European Central Bank purchases, is expected to push yields downward. The November US election and coronavirus resurgence may also spur haven buying, further reducing yields. Monthly debt issuance in Germany is projected to average 10 billion euros, leaving investors scrambling for the euro area's safest asset. Bund shortages are expected to persist for years due to self-imposed borrowing limits.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize 5TC index reached near new highs for the year, surpassing $30,000 due to firm trading activity. This upward momentum is expected to continue, indicating a positive outlook for the tanker and dry bulk market.

site_title: Oil exploration up in the air for energy majors as prices dive
summary: Energy majors are scaling back oil exploration due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on oil demand and prices. Despite diversifying into greener energies, the sector's core business remains oil and gas. Exploration projects in UK North Sea waters and Norway have been slashed by 70% and 30% respectively. US oil giant ExxonMobil has cut its exploration plans by 30%, while European rivals ENI, BP, and Equinor have also made similar moves. The sector faces significant challenges, with over 30 US oil exploration and production companies filing for bankruptcy this year, and an estimated 150 more by 2022.

site_title: Continuation of falling wedge formation for USDJPY
summary: The USDJPY pair has formed a falling wedge pattern, indicating a possible reversal in its downward trend. The pair peaked at 111.65 in March and has since been descending. The stochastic oscillator shows an overbought condition, suggesting a potential move lower before a breakout occurs. The pattern is typically a reversal pattern, but a further downturn is possible before the breakout.

site_title: Investors should diversify into Hang Seng Tech index: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock's head of Asia Pacific iShares Investment Strategy, Thomas Taw, recommends investors diversify into the Hang Seng Tech index, which tracks 30 top Chinese tech names listed offshore, due to US tech stocks being over-bought. The new iShares Hang Seng Tech ETF offers exposure to Chinese tech giants like Alibaba and Tencent. Taw advises reaching for risk and growth through thematic ETFs, taking tactical risk through value investing, and diversifying with inflation hedging.

site_title: Goldman CEO finally sells Aspen home after dividing it
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon has sold his Aspen estate, a 83-acre property in Colorado, after nearly three years of trying to find a buyer. The estate was divided into two parts: a 13,000 sq ft house on 45.6 acres sold for $19.5 million and a vacant 38 acre lot sold for $7 million, totaling $26.5 million. The sale represents a 26% discount from its initial asking price of $36 million in 2017, reflecting a surge in record-breaking sales in the Colorado resort town.

site_title: Spain's Unicaja moving closer to Liberbank takeover
summary: Spain's Unicaja Banco is moving closer to a potential takeover of Liberbank, a rival Spanish bank, with informal talks having restarted between the two banks and their respective advisers. Liberbank is working with Deutsche Bank to facilitate the discussions. This development is part of a broader trend of consolidation in Spain's financial institutions.

site_title: New VAT on tech companies a big boost for Indonesian government
summary: Indonesia has introduced a 10% value-added tax (VAT) on tech companies operating within its jurisdiction, aiming to boost government revenue collection. The move is expected to generate over $1 billion annually, with digital transactions growing rapidly due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Tech companies such as Google Indonesia and Shopee International Indonesia have begun applying the VAT, stating it will not impact their business. The government has appointed 28 tech companies to collect VAT, with the first payment expected at the end of September.

site_title: Most Integrated Shield insurers improve underwriting results in 2019
summary: Most Integrated Shield (IP) insurers in Singapore improved their underwriting performance in 2019, with Prudential and Income showing significant profits. However, policyholders should expect premium hikes following the review of MediShield Life, which may lead to further claim cost increases and upward pressure on IP premiums. The government has proposed a $2.2 billion support package to cushion premium hikes. Insurers are studying the MediShield Life Council's recommendations, which include reducing the proration factor for private hospital claims to better reflect actual charges.

images.alt_text: In 2019, Prudential showed the most dramatic results. It is the only one of the insurers with a system of "claims based pricing" which rewards healthy policyholders with 20 per cent lower premiums.

site_title: Malaysia's EPF becomes UG Healthcare substantial shareholder
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) has become a substantial shareholder of UG Healthcare Corporation, acquiring 605,000 shares at a consideration of S$1,541,843. This increases the EPF's direct interest in UG Healthcare from 4.99% to 5.29%. The move follows the EPF's acquisition of a substantial stake in Riverstone Holdings. UG Healthcare reported record revenue and net profit of S$144.2 million and S$13.4 million, respectively, for its FY20.

site_title: Parsing the challenges for Shield insurers: higher premiums are not a panacea
summary: Insurers of Integrated Shield plans reported mixed 2019 underwriting results despite measures to control escalating claims. Four insurers, including Prudential, posted profits or reduced losses, while three others suffered worse performance. Prudential's profit rose 21% to S$51.99 million, thanks to its "claims-based pricing" scheme, which rewards policyholders who don't make claims with lower premiums. However, a proposed MediShield Life enhancement, including a higher annual claim limit and lower proration factor for private hospitals, may increase IP premiums. Insurers attribute poor performance to higher claim rates and private hospital costs, which are about double those of public hospital costs.

site_title: Australia to expand first-home buyer assistance to lift economy
summary: Australia is expanding its First Home Loan Deposit Scheme to provide 10,000 additional places to help first-home buyers, aiming to support the economy's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The expanded program will offer 5% deposit loans until June 30, 2021, with the goal of driving more construction and job creation. The move is part of the government's plan to restart the economy, which is expected to see a widening budget deficit of 11.6% this fiscal year.

site_title: UK warehouse demand doubles in a year
summary: Demand for UK warehouses surged to a record in the third quarter, with 13.3 million square feet leased out, more than double the previous year. Online retailers accounted for a third of demand, while traditional merchants also ramped up their internet businesses. The growth is driven by consumers changing their shopping habits due to the pandemic and Brexit. This trend is expected to continue, with occupying existing warehouses becoming more common.

site_title: Australia to spend A$1.2b on jobs in budget based on Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The Australian government plans to allocate A$1.2 billion in wage subsidies for jobs in the 2020/21 budget, aiming to create up to 100,000 apprenticeships. The move is based on the assumption that a Covid-19 vaccine will be available next year, according to Treasurer Josh Frydenberg. The government has also set a record deficit of A$200 billion in the upcoming budget and plans to roll out a free coronavirus vaccine to citizens, with the first batches possibly arriving in January.

site_title: Corporate America chips away at a US$350b debt problem
summary: Several US blue-chip companies, including Target and CVS Health, are repaying their US$350 billion in pandemic-era debt. AT&T plans to further reduce its debt using excess cash. This trend is partly driven by high debt-to-Ebitda ratios, which worry investors. Companies in stable industries like technology, telecom, and healthcare are more likely to pay back debt, while those in travel and industrials may wait until the economy recovers. Experts expect more companies to join in, as the Federal Reserve's support for credit markets slows down.

site_title: OCBC webinar series to benefit 3,000 SMEs by year-end
summary: OCBC Bank's webinar series, the OCBC Virtual SME Campus, has benefited over 3,000 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) by the end of 2020, with more than 30 webinars held since its launch in April. The series, created in partnership with Enterprise Singapore, Amazon, Google, and Shopee, has equipped SMEs with digital skills and knowledge on topics such as e-commerce, digital marketing, and post-pandemic resilience. By the end of 2020, over 6,500 employees from more than 3,000 SMEs were expected to have attended the sessions.

site_title: Singtel should take a leaf from Keppel's book when it comes to investor communications
summary: Singtel's new CEO faces a daunting task to turn around the company's depressed stock price. Despite appointing a new leader, Singtel's financial woes persist, including lower earnings, increased debt, and a decline in dividend payments. The company's balance sheet is burdened with S$12.5 billion in net debt, and its profit growth has outpaced its debt accumulation. In contrast, Keppel Corp, another Singaporean conglomerate, has taken steps to address its problems, identifying S$17.5 billion worth of assets to monetize and planning a strategic review of its O&M business. Singtel's new CEO must address the market's concerns, strengthen the balance sheet, and prioritize investing in its 5G network to maintain market position and profitability.

site_title: Paytm, other Indian startups vow to fight Google's clout
summary: Indian tech startups, including Paytm, are planning to challenge Google's dominance in the country by lodging complaints with the government and courts. The move comes after Google removed Paytm from its Play Store, citing policy violations, and introduced a 30% commission on payments made within apps on the Android store. Executives from various startups, including IndiaMART, Dream Sports, and ShareChat, discussed forming a new association to protest Google's practices. The companies aim to counter Google's control over app distribution on Android phones, which runs on Google's Android mobile operating system, home to nearly 99% of India's smartphones.

site_title: UK's Johnson bids to woo restive party members
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces mounting questions about his leadership as the country struggles with a deadly and worsening coronavirus pandemic. The Conservative party's annual conference, now held virtually due to the crisis, has sparked disquiet among party members and the public, with some favouring a Sweden-style approach to social distancing. Johnson's personal approval ratings trail those of the government, and he faces opposition from lawmakers and the finance minister, Rishi Sunak, who has gained popularity for his handling of the economy. Johnson's leadership is under scrutiny, with some lawmakers calling for him to step down.

site_title: Turkey's wealth fund in talks over urgent support for hard-hit Turkish Airlines: sources
summary: Turkey's wealth fund is in talks to provide emergency funding to struggling Turkish Airlines, one of the country's hardest-hit companies due to the pandemic. The airline, which flies to more destinations worldwide than any other airline, could receive capital or financing support. Turkish Airlines posted a loss of 2.23 billion lira in the second quarter, but has agreed to cut wages by 30-50% until the end of 2021. The Turkey Wealth Fund's potential bailout could be similar to Germany's Lufthansa's US$10 billion government bailout.

site_title: Bond movie's delay shows plight facing theatre chains
summary: Movie-theatre operators are facing a second reckoning due to the ongoing pandemic. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer cancelled the November debut of James Bond movie "No Time to Die", rescheduling it for April 2021, a year after its original premiere date. This delay highlights the struggles of the film industry during the pandemic, with many big movies still on hold. The delay also underscores the challenges faced by theatre chains, which were initially optimistic about a return to normalcy. The move reflects the prolonged impact of the pandemic on the entertainment industry.

site_title: India's Reliance says GIC, TPG to invest 73.5b rupees in retail arm
summary: Reliance Industries Ltd has secured investments of 73.5 billion rupees from Singapore's GIC and global private equity firm TPG Capital in its retail arm, Reliance Retail Ventures Ltd. The investments value the company at 4.285 trillion rupees. GIC will hold a 1.22% stake, while TPG Capital will own a 0.41% equity stake. This is TPG Capital's second investment in Reliance, following a US$598 million investment in June. Reliance has also recently acquired rival Future Group's retail business for US$3.38 billion.

site_title: Britain to leave EU without a deal if no decision reached by Oct 15: Boris Johnson
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned that the UK will leave the EU without a deal by October 15 if no agreement is reached, but commentators believe this is an empty threat as both sides need a trade pact. Economies on both sides are in recession, and a no-deal scenario would worsen economic woes with tariffs and trade impediments. Johnson and EU President Ursula von der Leyen agreed to close significant gaps in negotiations, with talks set to continue in London and Brussels before the EU leaders meet on October 15.

site_title: Oil exploration up in the air as prices dive
summary: Oil exploration is being scaled back due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on demand and prices. Energy majors are diversifying into greener energies, and finding new oil deposits is becoming less profitable. Exploration projects have been slashed by 70% in UK North Sea waters and 30% off Norway's coast. US oil giant ExxonMobil has cut its exploration plans by 30%, while European rivals ENI, BP, and Equinor have also reduced their plans. Many oil exploration and production companies have filed for bankruptcy, with estimates suggesting 150 more could be lost by 2022 if oil prices remain stuck around $40 per barrel.

site_title: Hard-drinking Japan's teetotallers emerge from the shadows
summary: In Japan, a growing market of teetotallers, estimated to be around 5% of the population, is emerging. Despite the country's drinking culture, non-drinkers like 54-year-old fund manager Hideto Fujino are speaking out and finding support. A Facebook group for non-drinkers has attracted over 4,000 members, and "sober curious" individuals are increasingly cutting back on alcohol. The rise of non-alcoholic cocktails in trendy Tokyo bars, such as "0%", is helping to cater to this growing market. Japan's new Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, a rare high-profile teetotaller, has also sparked interest and discussion among non-drinkers.

site_title: Firms notify shareholders of independent directors' involvement in EHT investigations
summary: Several Singapore Exchange-listed firms have notified shareholders of investigations involving independent directors who are also current or former directors of the Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT). The EHT's managers stated that all former and current Singapore-based directors were arrested and released on bail on October 1 on "reasonable suspicion" of breaching disclosure requirements. The investigations are ongoing, and none of the individuals have been charged. The arrests do not necessarily mean charges will be filed.

site_title: Developing skills for today's workplace
summary: Singapore's universities are urged to revamp their curricula to better prepare graduates for the new economy and future of work. Experts recommend incorporating entrepreneurial skills, practical training, and core life skills such as critical thinking, communication, and adaptability. A hybrid learning model combining in-person and virtual delivery is also suggested, with a focus on modular content and industry partnerships. To succeed, graduates must possess a growth mindset, be adaptable, and possess uniquely human skills like creativity, empathy, and collaboration. The goal is to equip graduates with skills that are not replaceable by machines, enabling them to thrive in a fast-changing world.

site_title: Airbus executive says aviation outlook worse than expected
summary: Airbus chief operating officer Michael Schoellhorn stated that the aviation industry's outlook has worsened due to rising coronavirus infections and travel restrictions. The company has slowed aircraft deliveries and plans to cut 15,000 jobs worldwide. Schoellhorn noted that the situation in early autumn was worse than expected, and the planned job cuts would be the minimum. However, he ruled out shutting down entire locations in Germany, citing that none are currently at risk.

site_title: Former Chinese diplomat worked on TikTok content policy: FT
summary: A former Chinese diplomat, Cai Zheng, worked on TikTok's content policy until early this year, according to the Financial Times. Zheng, who joined ByteDance in 2018, wrote guidelines for acceptable videos on TikTok and other apps. However, TikTok denies he was involved in policy development, stating he worked on regional teams. ByteDance says Zheng moved to its gaming team, but his role remains unfilled. This raises concerns about China's influence on the social media platform's content moderation policies.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including two in the community
summary: Singapore reported 12 new Covid-19 cases on Sunday, including two in the community and six imported cases, bringing the total to 57,812. Both community cases are work pass holders. The increase is attributed to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Coming soon: a central platform for SME loans?
summary: PwC is developing a central platform for SME loans, aiming to cut paperwork and save time for Singapore's 270,000 SMEs. The platform, expected to launch early next year, would allow SMEs to apply for loan quotes from multiple banks with one application, reducing the loan application process from 7 weeks to 2 weeks. This would enable SMEs to track their status online, improving efficiency and transparency.

images.alt_text: "Once two or three (banks) sign up and they see the benefit, then others would not want to lose out," says Sam Kok Weng of PwC Singapore. "With more changes, there will be a tipping point."

site_title: Former White House counselor Kellyanne Conway tests positive for Covid-19
summary: Former White House counselor Kellyanne Conway announced on Friday that she has tested positive for Covid-19, stating her symptoms are mild and she is feeling fine. Conway began a quarantine process in consultation with physicians.

site_title: Australia to spend more on jobs in budget based on Covid-19 vaccine
summary: The Australian government has announced a $1.2 billion wage subsidy in the upcoming budget to create up to 100,000 apprenticeships, aiming to support job creation and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The budget also assumes a novel coronavirus vaccine will be available by next year, influencing fiscal considerations. The government plans to roll out a cost-free vaccine to citizens, with the first batches possibly arriving in January. The overall jobless rate fell to 6.8% in August, but unemployment for those aged 15-24 remains near 20%.

images.alt_text: The Australian government said on Sunday it will earmark an additional A$1.2 billion (S$1.17 billion) in wage subsidies in the 2020/21 budget and that its frameworks assume that there will be a novel coronavirus vaccine next year.

site_title: Lufthansa's Swiss unit plans 1,000 job cuts over two years through attrition
summary: Swiss International Air Lines, a unit of Lufthansa, plans to cut approximately 1,000 jobs over two years through voluntary measures such as hiring freezes, part-time models, and early retirement. The airline has received over 1 billion euros in loan guarantees from the Swiss government to cope with the pandemic's impact on air travel. The job cuts are part of the airline's efforts to shrink its staff and fleet. The airline's current crisis is expected to last three to five years, with job cuts dependent on the market's recovery.

site_title: No new round of Covid-19 support measures in Monday's ministerial statement: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that no new round of COVID-19 support measures will be announced in his upcoming ministerial statement. Instead, he will focus on allocating resources to fund existing measures, totaling S$8 billion. The measures aim to support businesses and workers affected by the pandemic, with a commitment of S$100 billion over four budgets and additional support. Heng emphasized the government's commitment to supporting workers and businesses, and will discuss the allocation of resources for the measures in his statement on Monday.

site_title: Japan's Sony and Kioxia seeking US approval to supply to Huawei: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Sony and Kioxia Holdings have applied for US approval to supply Huawei Technologies, despite US efforts to squeeze out the telecom giant due to concerns over data transfer for espionage. The move comes after other tech companies, such as Intel, received licenses from US authorities. If approved, Sony and Kioxia would face the risk of lower earnings if denied. US-China tensions have clouded the global chip market, prompting Kioxia to shelved a multi-billion dollar listing.

site_title: Trump says 'real test' ahead in his Covid fight after mixed messages from White House
summary: President Donald Trump said the next few days will be the "real test" of his treatment for COVID-19, after a series of conflicting messages from the White House about his condition. Trump's condition was initially described as improving by White House officials, but later assessments suggested a more serious situation. Trump received supplemental oxygen before being hospitalized and is receiving treatment with an experimental drug and other medications. The diagnosis comes as the presidential election approaches, with Trump trailing Democratic rival Joe Biden in opinion polls.

site_title: US oil refiners look to leapfrog Canadians in making renewable diesel
summary: US oil refineries are aggressively producing renewable diesel, partly to capitalize on Canada's upcoming greener fuel standard, which aims to cut 30 million tonnes of emissions by 2030. Canadian refiners have been slow to prepare, with only three projects announced, leaving them at a disadvantage. At least five US refiners have plans to produce renewable diesel, with greenhouse gas emissions from the fuel being 50-80% lower than conventional diesel. The US market is developing, with states like Colorado and Washington moving towards similar standards, potentially leaving Canadian refiners behind.

site_title: How Evergrande's billionaire founder skirted his latest crisis
summary: China Evergrande Group's billionaire founder Hui Ka Yan avoided a potential $13 billion repayment by sealing a deal with investors that waived their right to force a repayment. The agreement, reached last week, provides a reprieve for the company, which has $120 billion in debt and $5.8 billion maturing in two months. Hui leveraged his connections with wealthy friends and the government to secure the deal, which includes a majority of investors signing off on the agreement. The accord highlights Hui's ability to navigate the complex web of China's financial system and avoid financial instability, despite the company's significant debt burden.

site_title: Cineworld to close all UK, Ireland screens: Sunday Times
summary: Cineworld, the world's second-largest cinema operator, plans to close all its screens in the UK and Ireland as soon as the coming week due to the unviability of the industry amid the coronavirus pandemic. The decision comes after film studios postponed big-budget films, including the new James Bond movie "No Time To Die." The move could put about 5,500 jobs at risk. The company cited the ongoing pandemic and the need for governments to strengthen restrictions on social gathering as reasons for the closure.

site_title: Risk of debt shortage seen shaking German bonds out of slumber
summary: German bonds are expected to face increased volatility as a shortage of bunds amid slowing government debt sales and ECB purchases could push benchmark yields below recent ranges in the fourth quarter. Citigroup strategists predict the 10-year German yield could fall to minus 0.6% by year-end, driven by uncertainty over the US election and a resurgence of the coronavirus. This would add downward pressure on yields, with haven buying of bunds further reducing yields.

site_title: Indonesia's Widodo defends Covid-19 record, chides 'polemics'
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo defended his handling of the Covid-19 pandemic, stating it has been "quite good" despite criticism over prioritizing economic concerns. The country's Covid-19 caseload has risen to 299,506, with 11,055 deaths, amid criticism of insufficient spending and protection for health workers. Widodo urged no "polemics" and emphasized that prioritizing health does not mean sacrificing the economy, as sacrificing the economy equals sacrificing lives. The government is set to enter its first recession since the 1998 Asian financial crisis due to the pandemic.

site_title: Money FM: Podcasts of the week (Sept 28)
summary: The article discusses various podcasts from Money FM, including "The Magical Rule of Three" and "BT Podcasts." It highlights market trends and analysis, such as the impact of private equity on regular investors, the reaction of Asia's markets, and the potential of structured notes. The article also touches on the fluctuation of the US dollar and the resurgence of gold in uncertain times. Overall, the content provides insights into global market trends and the role of finance in driving socially responsible consumerism.

site_title: Johnson 'optimistic' over Brexit deal ahead of talks with EU chief
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson expressed optimism about a Brexit deal ahead of talks with EU chief Ursula von der Leyen. Johnson stated that a year-end deal to avoid an abrupt Brexit separation "are very good if everybody just exercises some common sense."
