summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra), Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), and Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) have updated a checklist for listed and non-listed entities on conducting general meetings. The checklist encourages issuers to hold meetings via electronic means until June 30, 2021, to minimize Covid-19 transmission risks. Issuers must also provide shareholders with the option to participate remotely and implement safe-management measures for physical attendance. The updated checklist covers various aspects of general meetings, including notices, voting, and minutes.

site_title: Avenue 87 takes the mod-Asian route
summary: Avenue 87, a new restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique take on traditional mod-Asian cuisine. Chefs Alex Phan and Glen Tay, former colleagues at Tippling Club, have reinterpreted hawker fare with creative twists. The menu features dishes like crispy deep-fried yam squares, spicy curry foam, and a signature sambal octopus. The restaurant's soups, including black chicken broth and fish soup, are also standouts. While some dishes are hit-or-miss, the overall experience is satisfying and promising, with a rating of 7 out of 10.

site_title: Virus-hit Rolls-Royce boosts finances with £5 billion plan
summary: Rolls-Royce, a British aerospace giant, has announced a £5 billion plan to boost its finances amid the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the air transport crisis. The package includes a £2-billion share rights issue, a £1-billion bond offering, a £1-billion loan facility, and state support. The company aims to reduce its cost base and improve its financial position, with plans to complete 5,000 out of 9,000 planned job cuts by the end of the year. Rolls-Royce expects to return to strong cash generation in 2022, but faces uncertainty over the recovery of international air transport.

site_title: Outage shuts down Tokyo bourse for entire day
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange halted trading for the entire day due to a hardware breakdown, which caused a failed switchover to backups. The exchange aims to resume trading on Friday, but the outage dampened investor sentiment following positive US stock market performance and closures in other major markets. The issue is the first all-day stoppage since the exchange shifted to an electronic system in 1999, and it may impact Japanese stocks, particularly the benchmark Topix index, which dropped 2% yesterday.

images.alt_text: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) halted trading for the entire day on Thursday, freezing buying and selling in thousands of companies in the worst outage for the world's third-largest bourse.

site_title: Lion Air's founders planning to launch new airline in Indonesia
summary: The founders of Indonesia's Lion Air, which suffered a deadly crash in 2018, are planning to launch a new airline, PT Lion Mentari Airlines. The new carrier is a project started by Lion's founders, including Rusdi Kirana, aiming to aid the carrier's efforts to move beyond the disaster. The transport ministry is processing an application for an air operator certificate, and the move could give the founders a fresh start, potentially allowing them to grab a bigger share of Indonesia's growing air travel market when the pandemic subsides.

site_title: Thai tycoon bets on data centre demand boom from pandemic
summary: Thai billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi is investing 7.3 billion baht in a new data centre in Bangkok, driven by demand from online shopping, video conferencing, and food delivery. The pandemic has accelerated digital transformation, boosting data centre demand at a higher pace than expected. The new centre, set to begin operation early next year, will benefit from 5G mobile services and cater to companies and individual consumers. Demand for data centres in Thailand is projected to grow over 20% annually, with every application relying on data centres.

site_title: Japan brewers bet on tax cut to revive pandemic-hit sales
summary: Japanese brewers, including Asahi Group Holdings and Kirin Holdings, are expecting relief from the pandemic's impact on sales due to tax cuts on beer. The government has revised the liquor tax system, making taxes more uniform and lowering taxes on high-malt beer by seven yen. This change aims to make some beers more affordable for consumers, who have shifted to lower-malt beers during the pandemic. Beer sales fell by 26% in the first half of the year, while new genre beers increased 6%. The changes may help brewers regain lost revenue, but experts warn that it may be too late to change consumer habits.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong sues Raffles Education over proposed stake purchase
summary: RAFFLES Education Corp, a Singapore-listed private education provider, is being sued by substantial shareholder Oei Hong Leong over its plan to raise its stake in a Chinese property firm. Oei, who owns 13.05% of REC, has commenced an originating summons in the High Court of Singapore, seeking a declaration to inspect certain documents related to the proposed stake purchase. The lawsuit aims to determine the plaintiffs' entitlement to inspect these documents.

site_title: Presidential debate? More like a rocky horror show
summary: US President Donald Trump's first presidential debate with Democratic candidate Joe Biden was widely criticized as chaotic and divisive. Trump's aggressive behavior, including interrupting and personal attacks, overshadowed the debate. Biden struggled to keep up with Trump's rapid-fire responses, with some critics labeling him as out of touch and lacking new ideas. The debate's tone and Trump's behavior were seen as reflective of his presidency, sparking concerns about the nation's ability to navigate the ongoing pandemic and economic recession. The debate's outcome was seen as a blow to Biden's campaign.

site_title: SocGen, Maybank cleared to fund potential suit against IPP ex-director
summary: Singapore's High Court has approved Societe Generale and Maybank's bid to fund Inter-Pacific Petroleum's (IPP) lawsuit against former director Goh Jin Hian, seeking to recover US$156 million in losses due to alleged negligence. The funding arrangement allows IPP to file legal claims against Dr. Goh, who is also facing investigations by the police and allegations by insolvency professionals that he breached his duties as a director. The lawsuit claims Dr. Goh signed off on fictitious transactions, which would have been uncovered if he had discharged his duties with care and diligence.

site_title: Singapore stocks lose 2.7% of value in September; STI sees another monthly decline
summary: Singapore's stocks lost 2.7% of their value in September, marking the third consecutive monthly decline, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 3% to S$432.1 billion. The market was weighed down by Catalist-listed counters, while mainboard-listed stocks slipped 2.7% to S$729.5 billion. Top gainers included Hutchison Port Holdings Trust and SGX, while Singtel emerged as the biggest loser, shedding S$2.94 billion. Analysts attribute the weak performance to the lack of "technology powerhouses" on the SGX and low interest rates weighing on traditional lending facilities.

site_title: Bold minimalism
summary: Banker Chan Ee Tat, a self-proclaimed minimalist, commissioned interior designer Terence Neo to create a bold yet tasteful home in River Valley. Neo experimented with brass elements, grey and blue hues, and bespoke terrazzo to add character to the 1,800 sq ft apartment. The result is a functional and practical space with a unique blend of minimalism and bold design choices, perfect for Chan's three-generational home, where he can entertain and relax with his family.

site_title: Saving cinema
summary: Singapore's film industry is struggling to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, with many productions delayed or canceled due to theater closures. However, film producers like Nelson Mok and Fran Borgia are working to revive the industry by producing high-quality content with broad appeal. Mok's upcoming films, including a sequel to Taiwanese horror film "The Bridge Curse" and Indonesian music-drama "Backstage," will be released with new marketing strategies, including virtual film markets and social media promotions. Meanwhile, Borgia's production company Akanga Film Asia is also pushing forward with its projects, despite revenue losses and challenges in selling independent films. Despite the challenges, there are glimmers of hope, with some producers optimistic that the industry will return to normal in the next year.

site_title: 9,000 professional services opportunities offered since April
summary: Singapore's professional services sector has seen over 9,000 job opportunities offered since April, with 1,400 jobseekers placed in various positions. The sector is expected to remain high-growth, with Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing noting its potential as a global hub for services. Despite the COVID-19 impact, the accelerated pace of digitalisation has benefited firms in consultancy, design, and marketing services. The government plans to strengthen its free trade agreements and build a digital economy network to support the sector's growth.

site_title: MyRepublic adds M1 as MVNO partner
summary: MyRepublic has partnered with M1 as its mobile virtual network operator (MVNO) partner, in addition to its existing partnership with StarHub. The move aims to strengthen its mobile offerings and improve network quality.

site_title: Parallels between Covid-19 and climate change
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has drawn parallels with climate change, highlighting the importance of science, public policy, and international cooperation to address both global health and environmental concerns. The pandemic's impact on greenhouse gas emissions, deforestation, and wildfires underscores the need for governments to take action. While some argue that the pandemic's economic impact will slow global warming, others see opportunities for reforming energy subsidies and reducing emissions from airplanes. A post-pandemic focus on fiscal stimulus, a phased-in carbon tax, and respect for scientific expertise could lead to a more sustainable future.

site_title: Private home purchases at odds with headline economic toll
summary: The Singapore property market is experiencing a surge in demand for private residential homes despite the economic toll of the Covid-19 pandemic, economists attribute this to low interest rates and optimism among those unaffected by the pandemic. This disconnect is evident in the rising demand for private homes, which contrasts with grim news of job retrenchments and recession.

site_title: A tale of two Britains: housing boom deepens social divide
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a boom, with prices rising 3-4% above pre-pandemic levels, driven by a post-lockdown rush for bigger homes outside urban areas. The surge is exacerbating social and wealth inequality, making it difficult for first-time buyers like 28-year-old Claire Tomlinson to afford homes. The government's decision to suspend taxes on residential property purchases until April 2021 has fueled the market, and the impending reduction in a state support scheme for first-time buyers is further pricing them out.

site_title: Bayer's Singapore R&D lab helps Asian farmers
summary: Bayer's Singapore crop science seeds laboratory serves as the regional hub for Asia Pacific, contributing to the development of new crop hybrids that help smallholder farmers manage the challenges of growing food sustainably. The lab, established in 2008, uses cutting-edge genetics and data science to improve crop yield, climate resilience, and disease resistance. Since its inception, around 1.7 million smallholder farmers have benefited from Bayer's pioneering work on hybrid rice, helping to combat malnutrition and support the United Nations Zero Hunger Challenge.

site_title: Li Ka-Shing sells world's priciest skyscraper and shows who's on top
summary: Li Ka-Shing has sold his stake in The Center, the world's priciest skyscraper, for US$5.2 billion, marking a significant loss for investors who purchased the building in 2017. The skyscraper, which was valued at nearly US$7 billion at the time of the sale, has seen a sharp decline in rents and office demand due to the anti-government protests, coronavirus pandemic, and escalating US-China tensions. Vacancies have surged to 19% and rents have dropped by 20% from last year, leaving investors with significant financial losses.

site_title: German businesses still keen on Singapore despite pandemic
summary: Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, German businesses remain keen on doing business in Singapore, citing the city-state's strategic location, stable legal environment, and excellent infrastructure. Recent investments by German companies, such as Evonik's methionine plant and DB Schenker's warehouse, demonstrate the ongoing commitment to Singapore. However, a majority of German businesses in Singapore see the pandemic as severely disruptive, with travel restrictions and work-from-home regulations affecting sales performance. The German-Singapore Chamber of Industry and Commerce is working to support its members and provide online events to facilitate information exchange.

site_title: High debt. Low growth. Are we all Japanese now?
summary: Japan's economic strategy, marked by low growth and high debt, has garnered attention as a potential model in the current pandemic-induced economic crisis. The country's "job-for-life" culture and government support have allowed many businesses to maintain employment, but at the cost of productivity and innovation. Meanwhile, low-paid workers, like single mother Tatsumi, struggle with job insecurity. Experts question whether Japan's approach will leave businesses and households better positioned for a modest recovery, or if it merely postpones structural reforms needed to boost productivity and economic growth.

images.alt_text: A Ricoh employee works on the production line at the company's printer components factory in Kanagawa prefecture. Thousands of companies in Japan were able to keep their doors open and employees on their books this year thanks to cheap loans and the jobs-for-life culture.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux, a troubled water treatment firm, received a revised offer from Utico but was rejected by unsecured lenders. Utico has not responded to an invitation to revise its offer. Meanwhile, Keppel Corp's forbearance agreement with bondholders was extended to Oct 15. New Silkroutes Group appointed Darrell Lim as lead independent director, while Lendlease Global Commercial Reit acquired a stake in Jem shopping mall.

site_title: China's pig herd rebounds after swine fever, but pork supply will take time to recover
summary: China's pig herd has rebounded after African swine fever, but the country's pork supply is expected to take time to recover due to the low quality of the new herd. The herd grew by 31% in August, but most of the increase comes from breeding females kept back for breeding, rather than market pigs. These females produce smaller litters and have lower fat reserves, affecting productivity. Experts estimate it will take two to three years to return to optimal levels, even with a normal replacement rate.

site_title: IndoAgri JVs propose reorganisation of sugar assets, operations in Brazil
summary: INDOFOOD Agri Resources' joint ventures in Brazil, Companhia Mineira de Açúcar e Álcool Participações (CMAA) and Canápolis Holding, have proposed reorganizing their sugar assets and operations. The goal is to consolidate assets and allow for greater access to funding. CMAA and Canápolis will combine their sugar assets and land under one structure, with the aim of future expansion. The reorganization, if successful, will see IndoAgri Brazil owning a 36.21% stake in CMAA and Strebinger Participações.

site_title: Singapore, Germany keep in touch during virus outbreak
summary: Singapore and Germany have maintained close contact during the COVID-19 pandemic, with regular online meetings between their foreign ministers and ambassadors. German Ambassador Dr. Norbert Riedel says that both countries are working to strengthen their business relations, particularly in areas like digitalization and trade. Despite the pandemic, Germany is seizing the opportunity to promote sustainable processes and expand trade with Singapore, which is its largest export trading partner in ASEAN. The two countries aim to build on their existing relationship and broaden their exchange, including through face-to-face meetings and increased travel connections.

site_title: How to read a wine label
summary:
Wine labels can be confusing for consumers, but understanding the key elements can help. Key types of wine labels include:

- Burgundy labels (Ghislaine Barthod Chambolle-Musigny Premier Cru Les Gruenchers): feature a producer's name, region, and vineyard rating.
- French labels (Château Simone Palette): emphasize the producer's name, region, and vineyard.
- Alsace labels (Domaine Zind Humbrecht Alsace Grand Cru): list grape variety, region, and vineyard rating.
- German labels (Willi Schaefer Mosel Graacher Domprobst): feature grape variety, region, and ripeness level.
- Italian labels (Monteraponi Chianti Classico): emphasize the appellation and producer.
- Mosel labels (Weiser-Kunstler Mosel Steffensberg): provide basic information on the vineyard site, vintage, and producer.

Understanding these elements can help consumers navigate the world of wine and make informed purchasing decisions.

site_title: Germany to focus on Indo-Pacific
summary: Germany is shifting its focus to the Indo-Pacific region, marking a significant step in its foreign policy. The country has adopted policy guidelines to engage with Europe, Asia, and the region, with Singapore being a key partner. Germany's new ambassador to Singapore, Dr. Norbert Riedel, expects to build on existing bilateral relations, focusing on areas like multilateralism, climate change, human rights, and security policy. The Indo-Pacific region is seen as crucial for shaping the 21st century, with Germany aiming to strengthen ties and expand cooperation in various fields.

images.alt_text: "The policy guidelines' aim is to strengthen our ties and to further expand in particular in the areas of multilateralism, climate change mitigation, human rights, rules-based free trade, connectivity, digital transformation and security policy." Dr Norbert Riedel, Germany's ambassador to Singapore.

site_title: Positive signs for SGX's new China bond product
summary: Singapore Exchange-listed exchange-traded fund (ETF) ICBC CSOP FTSE Chinese Government Bond Index ETF has seen strong demand, with over US$30 million in new capital raised in its first week of launch. The ETF tracks the Chinese bond market, offering exposure to fixed-rate Chinese sovereign bonds, and is expected to benefit from increasing investor interest in China-focused ETFs. International inflows into China's debt market have jumped 40% a year since 2017, and China's bond market is projected to double in size to US$30 trillion by 2030, driven by its inclusion in global bond indices and increasing investor appetite for yield and portfolio diversification.

site_title: MAS orders Ayondo to provide documents for investigation
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has ordered Ayondo, a Catalist-listed company, to provide documents for an investigation into a possible offence under the Securities and Futures Act. Independent director Foong Daw Ching and non-executive director Foo Fatt Kah have attended interviews with MAS and the Commercial Affairs Department. The companies involved, including Anchor Resources and Travelite Holdings, have stated that the investigation is unrelated to them and will not affect their business operations. Ayondo will cooperate fully and provide updates as necessary.

site_title: US dollar falls, yuan rises to year-and-a-half high
summary: The US dollar fell to a nine-day low, reaching 93.56 against a basket of currencies, as investors sought riskier currencies due to robust US data and hopes for fiscal stimulus. The Chinese yuan rose to a year-and-a-half high, while the Australian dollar also increased. The euro and British pound also gained against the US dollar, driven by optimism over a potential US stimulus package and Brexit agreement.

site_title: What will Singtel's new CEO mean for its share price?
summary: Singtel's new CEO, Yuen Kuan Moon, has been appointed amid investors' desire for a change in management direction. The company's earnings have declined by 10 years, its balance sheet is heavily geared, and its debt servicing capacity has deteriorated. Its digital investments have not yielded expected returns. The appointment comes after Singtel's shares hit a 12-year low.

site_title: 'No space . . . for that': US businessmen on debate
summary: US President Donald Trump and former VP Joe Biden's presidential debate heightened market concerns about a chaotic November election. Companies, from big to small, have experienced market volatility due to rising US coronavirus cases and lack of confidence in pandemic relief measures from Washington policymakers.

site_title: August visitor arrivals pick up, but floodgates still shut
summary: Singapore's tourism sector showed a mild recovery in August, with 8,910 visitors, a 30.3% increase from July, but still down 84.9% from the year-ago period. Gazetted hotels saw a combined S$58 million in room revenue, up from S$35.1 million in July, but 84.9% lower than August last year. Analysts expect a mild year-end staycation boost for the hotel sector, but warn that reopening to low-risk countries will likely yield only a trickle of increase due to cautious conditions.

site_title: Covid-19 calls for re-design of HR and workplace practices for employee safety
summary: Corporations and governments worldwide are re-designing HR and workplace practices to ensure employee safety amidst the COVID-19 pandemic. This overhaul requires the use of technology, including data analysis, artificial intelligence, and machine learning, to monitor safe distancing and identify potential infection risks. Key areas to focus on include staff segregation, split shifts, and real-time location tracking, as well as automated contact tracing and regular testing for employees. The shift towards a more intelligent and data-driven approach is crucial to protect employee health and cohesion, while also promoting productivity and economic recovery.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 1.4% in Q3 despite economic gloom
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore increased 1.4% in Q3, reaching a resale price index of 133.7, according to the Housing and Development Board. Analysts attribute the rise to stimulus measures and past property curbs, which may have prevented buyers from over-leveraging and selling flats at low prices. This performance has "outperformed" expectations, with the HDB resale market emerging stronger than expected despite economic gloom.

site_title: US junk bonds set another sales record with busiest September ever
summary: US junk bonds set a record for the busiest September on record, with over $47 billion in sales in September, surpassing the annual record set in the same month. This surge in issuance was driven by refinancings, which are expected to continue into October due to uncertainty around the presidential election and a possible second wave of Covid-19. Junk bonds posted their first monthly loss since March, but still outperformed the S&P 500, which had negative returns of 3.8% in September.

site_title: PAP still most credible party, but its credibility seen to have dipped: IPS survey
summary: A post-election survey by the Institute of Policy Studies (IPS) found that the People's Action Party (PAP) remains the most credible party in Singapore, but its credibility has dipped compared to the 2015 polls. The Workers' Party (WP) gained ground, especially among seniors and younger voters, with a significant increase in credibility ratings among Malay voters. The survey also revealed that concerns over livelihoods influenced support for the PAP and WP, with lower-income households and those in HDB flats showing increased support for the WP.

site_title: SP Group launches 'green credits' for households
summary: SP Group, Singapore's national utility, has launched "My Green Credits" to allow households and individuals to offset their monthly electricity consumption by matching it to renewable energy produced by green projects. Consumers can buy these credits, which are accessible through the SP Utilities mobile app. This initiative aims to promote sustainability and reduce carbon footprint.

site_title: Exxon flags further losses that add to pressure on dividend
summary: ExxonMobil is likely to report its third consecutive loss in the last quarter, further pressuring its ability to pay its $15 billion annual dividend. Refining margins took a negative hit of up to $600 million, while chemicals made a small profit. The company's reliance on debt to fund its operations raises concerns about its ability to cover its dividend and capital expenditures. Analysts predict a loss of about 30 cents per share, which may lead to a dividend cut, a seismic shift for Exxon after 37 years of making a rising payout a key investment strategy.

site_title: Private home prices may end 2020 in positive territory despite economic malaise: analysts
summary: Singapore private home prices may end 2020 in positive territory, with a 0.8% quarter-on-quarter increase in Q3, according to analysts. This follows a 0.1% year-to-date increase and reverses previous expectations of a 5% decline. Market sentiment is expected to improve as more sectors of the economy reopen, with demand driven by low interest rates, sensitive pricing, and the sanguine long-term outlook for the property market. Analysts project a 0.5% to 1.5% increase in private residential property prices for 2020.

site_title: Lingering questions as Wirecard ends payment services in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has directed Wirecard to cease its payment services in Singapore, requiring all related entities to return customers' funds by October 14. Wirecard, which collapsed into insolvency in June due to a massive accounting scandal, had been a prominent player in the Singaporean payments market with over 20,000 merchants. However, the MAS has left many questions unanswered, including the number of merchants affected and the extent of disruption. The Wirecard debacle has also highlighted the need for businesses to diversify their payment options and has raised concerns about regulatory loopholes.

site_title: Bundesbank fully supports a greener financial system
summary: Germany's central bank, the Deutsche Bundesbank, is actively supporting the transition to a greener financial system. The bank considers climate-related risks a source of financial risks and is part of the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), a global network of central banks and supervisors. The bank encourages financial institutions to disclose climate-related financial risks and evaluate the financial system's ability to deal with potential climate-related asset devaluations. The Bundesbank also has a long track record in sustainable investments, with 14 out of 16 fiscal clients investing sustainably or planning to do so.

site_title: Pinnacle@Duxton five-room flat sets resale record at S$1.26m
summary: A five-room flat at The Pinnacle@Duxton HDB in Singapore has set a resale record at S$1.258 million, surpassing the previous record of S$1.23 million. The 107 sq m flat on the 43-45th storey has a remaining lease of 89 years and four months. This sale marks a significant increase in resale prices, with the resale price index reaching 133.7 in the third quarter of the year, up 1.4% from the previous quarter.

site_title: AFP launches fact-checking programme with TikTok
summary: AFP has launched a fact-checking initiative with TikTok to combat misinformation on the platform. The initiative, which began in October 2020, involves AFP fact-check teams verifying potentially false and misleading videos in countries such as the Philippines, Indonesia, and Australia. The partnership aims to reduce the spread of misinformation on TikTok, a key step in addressing the growing concern of fake news.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala agrees 62.48b rupees deal with India's Reliance Retail
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment has agreed to invest 62.48 billion rupees (S$1.16 billion) in Reliance Retail, India's retail division, taking a 1.4% equity stake. This marks Mubadala's second significant investment in Reliance Industries, following a US$1.2 billion investment in Jio Platforms earlier this year. The deal comes as Reliance Retail seeks additional funding, having secured around US$1.8 billion in recent weeks from KKR & Co and Silver Lake Partners.

site_title: A record 3 trillion euros looking for a home
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has reached a record 3 trillion euros in excess cash in the euro area's economy, driven by emergency stimulus measures to offset the economic damage from the coronavirus pandemic. Financial institutions have increased their deposits with the ECB by a trillion euros in under six months, with the central bank issuing cheap loans to banks and snapping up bonds. This marks a significant increase in liquidity in the euro area, and comes as policymakers face pressure to address slowing economic growth in China and the impact of US tariffs.

site_title: Britain report says Huawei security failings pose long-term risk
summary: Britain's government-led board overseeing Huawei's vetting in the UK found the company's engineering and security practices pose a long-term risk to UK networks. Despite limited progress addressing previous issues, the board can only give "limited assurance" that risks can be mitigated. The report, released after a year of vetting Huawei equipment, identified significant vulnerabilities, including one deemed of "national significance". The findings increase pressure on Huawei, which has denied allegations of Chinese state interference in its products. The UK's decision to purge Huawei's equipment from national networks by 2027 remains unchanged.

site_title: Tesla Autopilot scores low for driver engagement in European safety rating
summary: Tesla's Autopilot ranked sixth in a European safety assessment, scoring 36 out of 100 for driver engagement. Despite this, it received the highest marks for performance and emergency response, earning an overall score of 131. In contrast, Mercedes' system received a top rating of 'very good' with a score of 174 for driver engagement. The assessment found that most vehicles scored 70 or above for driver engagement, with Tesla's Autopilot falling short.

site_title: Burj Khalifa builder Arabtec set to fall into liquidation
summary: Arabtec Holding PJSC, the UAE-based construction company behind the Burj Khalifa, voted to dissolve due to its "untenable financial situation". The move, approved by shareholders, is expected to impact 40,000 employees and thousands of suppliers and subcontractors. The company cited tight liquidity and limited new projects, with losses totaling $216 million in the first half of the year. Liquidation proceedings will be initiated within two months, with the goal of maximizing value for stakeholders.

site_title: Eurozone banks must brace for profit hit: ECB
summary: Eurozone banks face a rapid deterioration in balance sheets due to the pandemic-induced recession, with guaranteed loans and moratoriums set to expire. ECB supervisor Andrea Enria advises banks to quickly recognize soured loans, set aside risk provisions, and improve profitability by possibly undergoing consolidation. He emphasizes the need for orderly market exits to facilitate a swift recovery, while defending the Basel III regulatory framework. The ECB may lift a moratorium on bank dividend payments after December, pending a clearer picture of asset quality.

site_title: Germany plans Oct 8 full inquiry on Wirecard collapse
summary: Germany plans a full parliamentary inquiry on October 8 into the Wirecard collapse, described as the "biggest scandal in post-war Germany." The company's former CEO and top executives were arrested on fraud charges after admitting a 1.9-billion-euro hole in its balance sheet. Finance Minister Olaf Scholz is under pressure, and the scandal has embarrassed Chancellor Angela Merkel's coalition ahead of next year's general election. A full inquiry will clarify the case, which has raised concerns about regulatory oversight and auditing in the sector.

site_title: STI advances 1.4% on positive data releases
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.38% to 2,500.74 on Thursday, driven by positive data releases, including modest improvement in international visitor numbers and Chinese official Purchasing Manager's Index numbers. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin also announced negotiators will attempt a fiscal stimulus deal, boosting equities. Most STI constituents finished in the black, with Dairy Farm International and UOL being the top performers.

site_title: Japan considering making promotion of paternity leave mandatory for companies: Nikkei
summary: Japan is considering making companies mandatory to recommend employees take paternity leave, aiming to boost the country's low birthrate. Currently, only 7% of eligible fathers take childcare leave, despite a national target of 30% by 2025. The proposed changes would require companies to inform employees of paternity leave options and confirm their willingness to take leave. The move aims to end the stigma around men taking paternity leave, following the example set by Environment Minister Shinjiro Koizumi.

site_title: Ford's new CEO shakes up senior management team
summary: Ford's new CEO, Jim Farley, has shaken up the automaker's senior management team, naming John Lawler as his new CFO and introducing a plan to offer a full lineup of electric vehicles, expand commercial-vehicle services, and create businesses utilizing the self-driving system of its autonomous affiliate Argo AI. Farley aims to allocate capital to Ford's strongest businesses, target an 8% operating margin, and put the company on sounder financial footing. Initial reactions from Wall Street were positive, with shares rising 0.7% to $6.70.

site_title: US airlines rise as Trump's proposal revives bailout hope
summary: US airlines rose as the Trump administration proposed a $20 billion aid extension in a new stimulus plan, reviving bailout hopes. The proposal comes after American Airlines and United Airlines began furloughs of over 32,000 workers due to the expiration of the previous aid package. The Trump administration's plan is seen as a positive step by analysts, who believe it will prevent further job losses and support the industry's recovery. Shares of major airlines like American Airlines, United, Delta Air Lines, and Southwest Airlines rose between 1.3% and 2.8% in pre-market trading.

site_title: PepsiCo sees strong annual profit as snacks, sodas thrive in pandemic
summary: PepsiCo reported strong annual profit in Q3 2020, driven by a rebound in soda sales and increased demand for snacks during the pandemic. The company's Frito-Lay North America unit saw a 7% rise in snack sales, while its Quaker Foods business saw a 6% rise in breakfast food sales. The company forecast full-year core earnings of $5.50 per share, beating expectations, but warned that pandemic-related costs may continue to weigh on earnings next year. Overall net revenue rose 5% to $18.09 billion, beating analysts' expectations.

site_title: Evonik gets first woman regional chief in Singapore
summary: Evonik, a German specialty chemicals company, has appointed Shirley Qi as its first woman regional chief in Singapore, overseeing major business, investment, and R&D projects in South East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Qi, 38, is also head of Nutrition & Care division for Asia Pacific and started her new role on October 1. Evonik has invested over 1 billion euros in Singapore, including a 500 million-euro methionine plant, and has over 700 employees in the country. Qi aims to drive innovation and sustainability, focusing on six growth fields, including additive manufacturing, healthcare solutions, and tissue engineering.

site_title: Healthcare, alternative energy drove best US stock funds in third quarter
summary: Top-performing US stock funds in the third quarter focused on healthcare technology and alternative energy, posting gains of 40% or more. The WP Small Companies fund led the way with a 45.9% gain, followed by the Baron Partners Retail fund with a 45.4% gain. The Shelton Green Alpha fund, which invests in environmental, social, and governance factors, posted a 29.7% gain. The S&P 500, however, declined 3.9% in September, its first monthly drop since March, amid concerns about the coronavirus pandemic and stimulus measures.

site_title: US: Wall Street jumps at open on stimulus hopes
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.57% to 27,940.63, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.68% and 1.11% respectively. Investors bet on more fiscal stimulus after data showed a cooling recovery in the labor market.

site_title: New York becomes the first big US city to reopen all schools
summary: New York City has become the first major US city to reopen all its public schools after a hiatus since March, with approximately 500,000 students returning to classrooms. Despite significant planning challenges and opposition from the teachers' union, Mayor Bill de Blasio has successfully reopened the city's 1,400 school buildings, with roughly half a million students now attending in-person classes. However, concerns remain about the effectiveness of hybrid learning, staffing shortages, and ongoing safety questions amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; consumer spending solid in August
summary: US initial jobless claims fell to 837,000 for the week ended Sept 26, remaining at recession levels. This is below the 873,000 claims in the prior week, but above the 665,000 peak during the 2007-09 Great Recession. Consumer spending was solid in August, but economists still emphasize the need for another government rescue package for businesses and the unemployed.

site_title: Google to pay publishers US$1b over three years for their news
summary: Google plans to pay US$1 billion to publishers globally over three years for their news content. This move, led by CEO Sundar Pichai, aims to address regulatory scrutiny and win over publishers worldwide. The new product, Google News Showcase, will initially launch in Germany and Brazil, partnering with prominent newspapers such as Der Spiegel and Folha de S.Paulo. This deal may help Google improve its relationship with publishers and increase its credibility in the face of increased competition from other search engines.

site_title: US manufacturing sector slows in September: ISM
summary: US manufacturing activity unexpectedly slowed in September, with the Institute for Supply Management's index falling to 55.4, the lowest level since November 2018. Despite a fourth consecutive month of growth, the slowdown supports views that the recovery from the Covid-19 recession is losing steam. Economists forecast a record 32% annualized GDP growth in the third quarter and a 2.5% rate in the fourth quarter, down from earlier estimates.

site_title: India startups join effort to break Google, Facebook dominance
summary: Indian startups gathered on a Zoom call to discuss forming a collective to counter Big Tech dominance, including Google and Facebook. The group aims to shape digital policy, lobby for the country's digital enterprises, and potentially create an alternative to Google Play Store. Billionaire Vijay Shekhar Sharma, founder of Paytm, emphasized the need for a unified voice to protect India's digital dreams from global corporations. The collective seeks to give the government and global tech giants a platform to listen to the concerns of India's digital startups.

site_title: US tech venture investing gets a boost from pandemic
summary: US venture capital investments surged in the first nine months of 2020, reaching $88.1 billion, a 7% increase from the same period in 2019. The pandemic has driven investors to put cash to work, with tech investments making up 78% of venture capital investments in 2020. Firms are betting on the digitalization of sectors and investing in startups that aim to enable this shift, with fintech, digital health, and AI startups receiving significant funding. The enthusiasm for tech IPOs also picked up, with 16 companies going public in September alone.

site_title: HDB mortgage late payment charges suspended till March 2021
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced the extension of HDB mortgage late payment charges suspension to March 2021, providing relief to households struggling with the economic impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. Families living in public rental flats will also have their rent slashed by half for three months. Additionally, households can extend their loan repayment period up to age 65 if needed. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will also provide support measures for HDB flat owners on bank loans.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic storms to 70th win at Roland Garros
summary: Novak Djokovic achieved his 70th win at Roland Garros, defeating Ricardas Berankis 6-1, 6-2, 6-2. The top seed tied Roger Federer for career victories at the tournament, falling 25 behind Rafael Nadal's record. Djokovic, seeking an 18th Grand Slam title, will face Daniel Elahi Galan in the next round. Djokovic expressed satisfaction with his performance, citing a strong first round and a desire to continue playing well.

site_title: Booming crypto market a potential haven for money laundering
summary: A new report by CipherTrace warns that the booming decentralized finance (defi) market, which has seen over $11 billion in cryptocurrency transactions, may be vulnerable to money laundering due to weak "know your customer" (KYC) controls. 56% of digital currency services globally have inadequate KYC procedures, allowing potential money launderers to exploit the lack of regulation. Regulators are taking notice, and CipherTrace CEO Dave Jevans predicts that defi projects will be subject to increased scrutiny, with many likely to fall under the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

site_title: MyRepublic adds M1 as MVNO partner
summary: MyRepublic has partnered with M1 as a mobile virtual network operator (MVNO), expanding its mobile services using M1's infrastructure. The partnership aims to offer an enhanced suite of mobile services, as confirmed by MyRepublic and M1 in a joint statement. This move follows MyRepublic's existing partnership with StarHub.

site_title: Thailand's sluggish August indicators point to fragile recovery: BofA
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to experience a fragile recovery due to sluggish indicators in August. Foreign tourism revenues remain missing, and the economy operates below its capacity. The private consumption index fell, mainly due to a decline in services and non-durable consumption, while exports contracted by 8.2% year-on-year. Private investment indicators also contracted, and the manufacturing sector is expected to operate below its capacity throughout the year. The fading fiscal support and loss of incomes during the high tourism season may pose additional risks to employment and debt serviceability.

site_title: Ayondo ordered to provide information for investigation in possible Securities and Futures Act breach
summary: Ayondo, a CATALIST-listed company, has been ordered by the Monetary Authority of Singapore to provide information and documents in an investigation into a possible breach of the Securities and Futures Act. Independent directors Foong Daw Ching and Foo Fatt Kah have also attended interviews with the MAS and CAD. Ayondo stated it will cooperate fully and provide updates as necessary. The company is investigating the matter, but no further details have been disclosed.

site_title: Pinnacle@Duxton five-room flat sets resale record at S$1.26m
summary: A five-room flat at The Pinnacle@Duxton HDB in Singapore has set a resale record at S$1.258 million. The 107 sqm unit on the 43-45th storey surpassed the previous record of S$1.23 million for a similar unit on the 40-42nd storey. This sale comes as resale prices for HDB flats rose 1.4% in the third quarter, reaching an index of 133.7.

site_title: Nam Cheong's creditors to withhold proceedings against its unit
summary: Malaysian offshore support vessel builder Nam Cheong announced that its creditors will withhold proceedings against its unit, Nam Cheong Dockyard (NCD), following an application to the Corporate Debt Restructuring Committee. This six-month standstill allows NCD to submit a debt restructuring proposal within 60 days. The move aims to provide temporary relief and facilitate a restructuring process.

site_title: Swiss Axpo to open Singapore office to expand LNG trading in Asia
summary: Swiss renewable energy producer Axpo is set to open an office in Singapore by the end of the year to expand its liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading activities in Asia. The new office, led by Sophie Ducoloner, will focus on the growing LNG market in the region. Ducoloner brings over 20 years of experience in Asian and international LNG markets from companies such as JERA Global Markets and Gazprom marketing and trading. This move aims to capitalize on the increasing demand for LNG in Asia.

site_title: Trump signs bill averting US government shutdown
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a spending bill averting a government shutdown, extending funding until December 11. The bipartisan bill, which Trump signed in the early hours of Thursday, adds $8 billion in nutrition assistance and extends funding for community health centers. The measure comes weeks before the presidential election and allows lawmakers to avoid a partial shutdown, which would have occurred if Trump hadn't signed the bill by the deadline. The short-term legislation was seen as a temporary solution, with a broader relief package still being negotiated.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singtel's group CEO Chua Sock Koong is retiring after 31 years with the company. Yuen Kuan Moon will take over as the new CEO.

site_title: Taxpayer losses could hit £23b on UK's Covid loans
summary: The UK government estimates it could lose up to £23 billion on loans guaranteed to support businesses during the pandemic, with the worst-case scenario being the highest loss. The estimate is based on historic losses from similar programs and combines credit and fraud losses. The figure is a significant blow to taxpayers, with the government already facing financial strain. The estimated range of losses is between £13 billion and £23 billion.

site_title: Rolls-Royce raising £5b, ends talks with GIC and Kuwait fund
summary: Rolls-Royce plans to raise £5 billion to rebuild its balance sheet amid the coronavirus travel crisis, which has significantly impacted its cashflow. The company will issue a 10-for-3 heavily discounted rights issue at 32 pence per share, a 41% discount to the closing price, to raise £2 billion from shareholders. The remaining £3 billion will be raised through debt options, including a potential £1 billion loan from the UK government's UK Export Finance. Rolls-Royce expects to return to positive cashflow in the second half of 2021 and target £750 million of free cashflow in 2022, pending long-haul travel recovery.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. However, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case.

site_title: Boeing courting Delta, others to take 737 MAX 'white tails': sources
summary: Boeing is seeking buyers for dozens of 737 MAX jets, known as "white tails," that were built for clients who have scrapped their orders or gone bust. The 737 MAX has been grounded for 18 months due to fatal crashes and the COVID-19 pandemic has significantly reduced air travel demand. Delta Air Lines is among the airlines Boeing has approached to purchase the unsold jets. Boeing is looking to find new buyers for the aircraft to help recover from the losses caused by the pandemic and the grounding of the 737 MAX.

site_title: Bang & Olufsen sales growth boosts shares
summary: Bang & Olufsen's shares rose 13% after the company reported its first revenue growth in a year, with sales increasing 10.3% to 462 million Danish crowns in the third quarter. The company attributed the growth to its revamped strategy, which includes boosting online presence and digital sales in key European and Asian markets. EBIT losses narrowed to 41 million crowns, and CEO Kristian Tear stated that the company has a solid strategy in place, despite acknowledging that there is still work to be done to create a profitable business.

site_title: Four BP Singapore oil traders leave after probe on disputed deals
summary: Four BP Singapore oil traders, including a manager, left the company after over two months of internal investigations into disputed deals. The departures come amid intense scrutiny of opaque practices in Singapore's oil-trading hub. The oil major began internal investigations after being mentioned in court filings by banks against two other companies. The staff involved held portfolios focused on oil sales to Chinese customers and were also asked to stop using China's WeChat app on work phones as a communication method. Details of the findings remain unclear.

site_title: SP Group launches 'green credits' for consumers to offset emissions
summary: SP Group, Singapore's national utility, has launched a "green credits" feature on its mobile app, allowing consumers to offset their monthly electricity consumption with renewable energy certificates. The feature, accessible through the My Green Credits app, enables users to purchase RECs, which deem them as consuming renewable energy, and support local and overseas renewable energy projects. The initiative aims to make green practices more affordable and convenient for Singaporeans, with SP Group covering 100% of its headquarters' electricity consumption with RECs.

site_title: Centre for Seniors partners FastJobs to improve job matching for seniors
summary: The Centre for Seniors (CFS) has partnered with FastJobs to improve job matching for senior jobseekers. The SilverJobs portal, launched by CFS, now allows users to upload resumes and apply for jobs listed on the platform using their existing FastJobs profiles. This partnership aims to enhance job opportunities for seniors, providing a more streamlined and efficient job search experience.

site_title: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit acquires stake in Jem
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit has acquired a 5% stake in Jem shopping mall through a private fund, Lendlease Asian Retail Investment Fund 3, at a purchase consideration of around S$45 million. The acquisition provides Lendlease Reit with pre-emptive rights to potentially increase its stake in the fund and Jem over time. The deal was financed through internal resources and debt facilities, and the total estimated cost is approximately S$46.3 million. The acquisition will not affect Lendlease Reit's gearing, which remains 36.9% as of June 30, 2020.

site_title: US election a boon for bookmakers with bets at US$1b
summary: The US presidential election is generating significant betting activity, with over $1 billion placed on the winner globally before polling day. This is double the amount from the 2016 election, with Republican candidate Donald Trump favored by 70% of bets despite being the underdog. Bookmakers attribute the high betting activity to Trump's unique personality and a "social media bubble" that influences betting decisions. Polls and betting markets show Trump with a 35-45% chance of winning, significantly higher than the 10% chance predicted by polling forecasts.

site_title: How to hold onto your pay cheques in this IPO frenzy
summary: Hong Kong's IPO market is experiencing its best performance in a decade, with investors applying for large sums of money to buy shares in hot listings. However, this market can be unpredictable, and investors should exercise caution. Borrowed money can lead to significant losses, and valuation doesn't always matter until it does. Retail investors should be aware of the risks and consider their options carefully, as a bet on an IPO pop is a bet on momentum, which can be volatile.

site_title: In China, Big Tech isn't the enemy. It's the strategy
summary: China is strengthening its domestic technology industry as part of its five-year plan, aiming to build self-reliant tech giants and reduce reliance on foreign companies. The government will provide more money, policy favoritism, and support to domestic chip and software firms, potentially freezing out overseas competitors. Foreign companies, especially in semiconductors and software, should expect limited access to the Chinese market, with only those supplying crucial products and services having a chance at sustained market access.

site_title: Qatar to prosecute those behind invasive airport searches
summary: Qatar has referred those responsible for invasive gynaecological searches of women passengers at Doha airport for prosecution. The searches, which targeted women on 10 flights in October, were in response to the discovery of a newborn baby found abandoned in an airport bathroom. Qatar's Prime Minister and Minister of Interior apologized for the measures, which were deemed "completely unacceptable" by New Zealand and "appalling" by Australia. France, Britain, and Australia reported affected citizens, with a total of 26 people subjected to the examinations.

site_title: Ant and Covid-19 have made the humble QR code a hit
summary: A humble QR code, invented by Japanese engineer Masahiro Hara in 1994, has found its moment in the Covid-19 pandemic. Initially used to track components in car factories, the QR code has become an all-purpose tool, used by governments for tracing apps, shops for contactless payments, and restaurants for online menu browsing. Its versatility and flexibility have made it a crucial innovation, enabling mobile payments in China and now being adopted globally. The QR code's rise demonstrates that simple, adaptable inventions can be powerful, and Hara's creation has a fine future ahead.

site_title: Prayuth says coup unlikely even as rumours swirl
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha said a coup is unlikely, despite rumors and suggestions from protesters. He emphasized that no one wants to stage a coup and urged those making the comments to reflect on their intentions. Protests calling for his ouster have been expanding in Thailand, with demonstrators demanding a revised constitution and reforms to the monarchy. Prayuth has refused to resign, and a coup would grant the army sweeping powers to crack down on the protests.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust malls experience rise in sales, footfall for Q3
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 25.8% quarter-on-quarter increase in sales and a 34.7% rise in shopper traffic for Q3, driven by easing Covid-19 restrictions. The trust's total portfolio occupancy rate stood at 93.7% as of September 30, with 331 leases up for renewal this year. CRCT plans to rejuvenate its offerings, focusing on lifestyle essentials, sustainability, and healthy living products, and will explore opportunities to extract value from its Rock Square mall.

site_title: US consumer spending beats expectations in September
summary: US consumer spending increased 1.4% in September, exceeding expectations of a 1% rise, according to the Commerce Department. This marks a slight increase from the 1% gain in August. However, a resurgence in Covid-19 cases may slow spending in the fourth quarter. Consumer spending accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, indicating a positive trend for the economy.

site_title: Mercedes Benz A180 saloon review: A baby Benz for the star-struck
summary: The Mercedes-Benz A 180 Saloon is a luxury car that defies traditional notions of premium vehicles. It's a compact, affordable option with a 1.3-litre turbo engine and a price tag of S$151,888. Despite its modest specs, the car is pleasant to drive, with a firm ride and agile handling. Its interior features bright digital screens, customizable ambient lighting, and striking front-end styling, making it a desirable choice for those seeking luxury without the premium price. The A 180 Saloon is perfect for those who want a Mercedes without the hefty price tag.

site_title: Exxon Mobil reports US$680m Q3 loss on low oil prices
summary: Exxon Mobil reported a Q3 loss of $680 million, its third consecutive quarterly loss, due to low oil prices caused by economic weakness. The US oil giant's profits plummeted from $3.2 billion in the same period last year. The company has also been cutting 14,000 jobs globally amid a weak demand outlook.

site_title: People fear a market crash more than they have in years
summary: Investors are at their most fearful of a market crash in years, with record-low confidence levels in stock market sentiment and valuations. The Crash Confidence Index and Valuation Confidence Index show that nearly all investors believe a catastrophic market crash is likely within the next six months. Despite this, the stock market is trading near a record high, raising concerns about the risk of a crash. Experts warn that a psychological sense of risk could be triggered by future events, and investors should remain cautious, considering diversification to mitigate potential losses.

site_title: Employment-related claims, new default notices emerge at Eagle Hospitality Trust
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) is facing fresh troubles with employment-related claims and new default notices. The trust discovered pending claims related to the Queen Mary Long Beach hotel, which was signed by the master lessor before EHT's IPO in May last year. The claims cover union-represented employees. The managers of EHT announced the issues in their latest update, citing a number of pending claims. This news comes as the trust navigates its portfolio of assets.

site_title: China's banks facing persistent bad loan pressures after Q3 earnings drop
summary: China's largest state-owned banks face persistent bad loan pressures after Q3 earnings dropped. Five top banks, including ICBC, posted declines in third-quarter profits, with some borrowers facing difficulties in repaying loans. Analysts warn that soured debts will continue to emerge, with corporate loan repayment pressure peaking around mid-2021. The government's policies to combat the COVID-19 shutdowns' impact on the economy are set to expire, and banks are expected to see rising non-performing loan ratios in the coming months.

site_title: Firm home sales lure bidders out in post-CB government land sales
summary: In Singapore, a strong demand for homes led to reduced property developers' inventory, boosting their appetite for land. The top bids for two 99-year leasehold sites at state land tender closings were stronger-than-expected, with developers attracted to the relatively palatable price quantum. This trend follows the Phase 2 re-opening of Singapore's economy after the Covid-19 lockdown. The increase in demand is seen as a positive sign for the housing market, but it may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: ExxonMobil to hold review before confirming Singapore job cuts
summary: ExxonMobil has announced plans to cut 15% of its global workforce over two years, affecting approximately 14,000 employees. This includes 1,900 positions in the US, where ExxonMobil is headquartered. A local spokesperson for ExxonMobil in Singapore stated that a review would be conducted before confirming the impact of these job cuts on the local workforce of 4,000 employees. The company has not yet specified how many positions in Singapore will be affected.

site_title: Mahathir denies promoting violence with 'right to kill French' posts
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad denied promoting violence after posting on social media that Muslims have a right to "kill millions of French people for past massacres." He criticized Facebook and Twitter for removing his posts, saying they should allow freedom of expression to defend his position. Mahathir's remarks sparked international condemnation, with several Muslim-majority countries denouncing French officials' defense of publishing cartoons of the Prophet Mohammad. Twitter removed the tweet, citing its rules on glorifying violence, while Facebook deleted the post for violating its hate speech policies.

site_title: NTUC assistant director-general Ang Hin Kee to helm SNCF
summary: NTUC assistant director-general Ang Hin Kee will become the chief executive of the Singapore National Co-operative Federation (SNCF) on November 1, succeeding Dolly Goh. Ang brings over 15 years of experience in addressing employment and employability concerns, most recently serving as a Member of Parliament. In his new role, Ang aims to steer the cooperative movement, which has been in Singapore for over 95 years, to benefit members and improve lives, particularly during challenging times like the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: More V-shaped recovery in Singapore and Vietnam than rest of Asean
summary: Singapore and Vietnam are expected to experience more "V" recovery than the rest of Asean due to factors such as government subsidies, low interest rates, high household savings, and work-from-home policies. Singapore's semiconductor production and exports have rebounded sharply, while property transactions and sales of discretionary items have also increased. Vietnam's economy is also expected to benefit from its trade agreements and low interest rates. These countries' recovery is attributed to a combination of favorable economic conditions and government support.

site_title: New ways to make money: The alternative alternative assets
summary: New alternative assets, made possible by the internet, are emerging, including cryptocurrency, peer-to-peer lending, celebrity index, and digital collectibles. Platforms like Flippa and Empire Flipper enable buying and selling of businesses, mobile apps, and domain names. Peer-to-peer lending in South-east Asia allows individuals to invest small amounts in loans to companies. Tokenisation, a process that creates blockchain security tokens, is gaining popularity, offering greater liquidity and transparency. Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) represent ownership of unique digital assets, such as art and collectibles. However, new assets and alternative platforms raise concerns about regulation, cybersecurity, and governance, and investors should be cautious of potential risks.

site_title: Japan household spending seen tumbling y-o-y as pandemic lingers: poll
summary: Japan's household spending likely fell by nearly 11% in September from the previous year, a Reuters poll showed, amid a lingering pandemic. This data contradicts hopes for a robust economic rebound. Meanwhile, factory output rose and job availability hit a 2013 low, highlighting the challenge for policymakers to revive economic activity while preventing a resurgence of infections. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga is set to announce extra stimulus steps next week.

site_title: Indonesia businesses fear surprise US manoeuvres if Trump re-elected
summary: Indonesian businesses are concerned about potential US trade policies if Donald Trump is re-elected, fearing unilateral decisions that could harm their exports. Despite this, experts expect Indonesia-US trade relations to remain relatively stable. A Biden victory is seen as beneficial for Indonesia, offering a brighter and more positive partnership, including continued GSP status for certain exports. In contrast, Trump's unpredictable policies and actions are expected to increase external pressure on Indonesia's economic growth, leading to greater uncertainty for investors.

site_title: Ezion's JV Terasea placed under creditors' voluntary winding-up
summary: Ezion's joint venture, Terasea, has been placed under creditors' voluntary winding-up following a resolution at an extraordinary general meeting and confirmation by its creditors. BDO Advisory has been appointed as the liquidators. The winding-up is not expected to significantly impact Ezion Holdings' net tangible assets or earnings per share. Terasea's default on a US$27.6 million debt last year triggered a cross-default, but Ezion Holdings' effective interest in the joint venture is 25%. Trading in Ezion shares has been suspended since March 2019.

site_title: HK recession shows sign of easing in Q3
summary: Hong Kong's economy showed signs of easing its recession in the third quarter, with a 3.4% contraction in July-September compared to a year-on-year contraction of 9.0% in April-June. The improvement was attributed to a gradual relaxation of anti-virus measures, stronger financial market activity, and a solid recovery of the Chinese mainland economy. The government expects economic activities to continue recovering this year if local Covid-19 infections stabilize. However, consumption and investment remain weak, and the global financial hub's economy was also hit by anti-government protests and the US-China trade war.

site_title: Singapore stocks edge up despite Wall Street retreat; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Thursday, closing at 2,528.41, despite Wall Street's retreat amid US presidential election and stimulus uncertainty. Investors are awaiting a fiscal stimulus package, leading to "stimulus talk exhaustion", according to AxiCorp's Stephen Innes. Venture Corporation fell 2% after a buy downgrade, while City Developments Limited slid 1.1% following the resignation of a director. The top gainers were Jardine Matheson Holdings, Jardine Strategic Holdings, Wilmar International, and Sembcorp Industries.

site_title: Lufthansa says 30,000 jobs at risk over pandemic
summary: Lufthansa warns that 30,000 jobs are at risk due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with the airline scaling down its winter schedule to levels not seen since the 1970s. The airline aims to preserve at least 100,000 of its 130,000 current jobs. Lufthansa will ground 125 more planes and reduce administrative functions to 30% as it anticipates a significant decline in passengers. The airline's board says the road to recovery will be long and arduous, with travel warnings and environmental concerns weighing on the industry.

site_title: On the green power train
summary: Mitsubishi Power Asia Pacific, led by Managing Director and CEO Osamu Ono, is driving Japan's transition to a carbon-free energy future. Seven years after the Fukushima nuclear disaster, the company is building the world's most advanced thermal power plants, employing cutting-edge technology to reduce carbon emissions. Ono, a 60-year-old Mitsubishi lifer, has been instrumental in the company's growth and expansion in the Asia-Pacific region, overseeing the firm's planning and execution of growth strategies. The company aims to electrify its green pitch, contributing to the region's push for a carbon-free energy future alongside the rise of renewables, with a focus on innovative technologies such as hydrogen, ammonia, and solar power.

site_title: Whether Trump or Biden wins, infrastructure will be a safe bet
summary: Prediction markets favor Biden, indicating a 51-43% advantage. A Biden win is expected to benefit companies in green energy, infrastructure, healthcare, and technology. Conversely, a Trump win would favor oil and gas companies, US tech firms, and infrastructure projects focused on 5G networks. Both candidates have infrastructure plans, with Biden aiming for a carbon-neutral US by 2050 and Trump focusing on a 5G national wireless broadband network.

site_title: Bridging the skills gap: Is education the key?
summary: Singapore's education system is being reevaluated to bridge the skills gap among local workers. Employers cite the need for on-the-job training, such as internships, to equip graduates with the technical and soft skills required for in-demand sectors. Companies like Serl.io and Shopee have taken steps to groom talent through initiatives like training programs and competitions. The government has rolled out work-study programs since 2015, modeled after Germany's vocational education training system, but industry-wide collaboration is lacking. Employers emphasize the need for interdisciplinary learning, international experience, and entrepreneurial mindsets to prepare students for the rapidly changing job market.

site_title: WeWork default is a real possibility, warns Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded WeWork's long-term issuer default rating to CCC, indicating "substantial credit risk" and warning that default is a real possibility due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its business model. WeWork's cash burn is estimated to reach $1.5 billion in 2021 and 2022, and the company may need to seek additional liquidity, which is uncertain. Despite SoftBank's support, Fitch questions whether further funding would be available in a distressed scenario, raising concerns about WeWork's financial stability.

site_title: Thai PM preparing to lift emergency amid protests
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha is preparing to lift emergency measures imposed last week to curb protests in Bangkok, which demanded his removal and reforms to curb the monarch's powers. The measures, which included banning political gatherings and publication of information deemed threatening security, were met with tens of thousands of protesters. Prayuth said disputes should be resolved in parliament, but protesters are demanding his resignation and reforms. The protests, the biggest challenge to Thailand's establishment in years, have drawn open opposition to the monarchy despite lese majeste laws.

site_title: White Beehoon Restaurant, Nam Ho Travel among SMEs in new leadership programme
summary: Singapore has launched the Enterprise Leadership for Transformation (ELT) programme, a one-year leadership development initiative for 38 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with a revenue of at least S$5 million. The programme, costing S$30,000 per participant, aims to train 900 SME leaders over three years and provide opportunities for transformation, including market immersion trips and coaching on growth plans. The government hopes to support local enterprises in creating new goods and services, selling in new ways, and achieving a "real breakthrough".

site_title: Serving the Asian woman
summary: Procter & Gamble's president for Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa, Magesvaran Suranjan, emphasizes the Asian consumer's high standards, citing her need for high-quality products and packaging. He attributes the company's success in this region to its ability to adapt to local markets, conducting human research to design products tailored to specific consumer needs. Suranjan highlights the growth of e-commerce, which now accounts for 8% of P&G's global sales, and notes that the company is investing in digital capabilities, including its iFuture initiative, to stay ahead in the industry. Despite the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, Suranjan reports that P&G has maintained its supply chain and delivery capabilities, with no reported shortages in its markets.

site_title: Budget airline AirAsia X out of money, needs RM500m for restart: report
summary: AirAsia X, the long-haul arm of AirAsia Group, has run out of money and needs to raise up to RM500 million to restart operations. The airline plans to restructure RM63.5 billion of debt and slash its share capital by 90% to continue as a going concern. It has actual liabilities of RM2 billion, including lease payments and plane orders, and needs to convince lessors of its business plan. The airline plans to liquidate its Indonesian subsidiary and has written down its stake in Thai AirAsia X.

site_title: Over S$5.5b in Jobs Support Scheme payouts to be disbursed from Oct 29
summary: Over S$5.5 billion in Jobs Support Scheme payouts will be disbursed to over 140,000 employers in Singapore starting from Oct 29, supporting 1.9 million local employees' June to August wages. The latest payout brings total JSS support to S$21.5 billion, with varying support tiers for different sectors. Employers can opt for earlier payouts through PayNow Corporate, and the third JSS payout is the third out of five.

site_title: Rotimatic-maker flips ownership in trade sale
summary: Singapore-based Rotimatic-maker Zimplistic has been sold to Light Ray Holdings in a trade sale. Founded in 2008, Zimplistic, which developed the Rotimatic machine, had attracted funding from prominent investors. However, the company was burning cash at a rapid pace, with losses of $23.6 million in 2018 despite revenue of $21.2 million. Light Ray Holdings, a special-purpose vehicle, will now run and fund Zimplistic after the trade sale.

site_title: Round-up of our pieces on the impact of Covid-19 on the region
summary: Covid-19's impact on the region's economies is being closely monitored. In Indonesia, corporate demand is drying up, while Thailand's economy is expected to contract 8-10% this year due to lockdowns, political unrest, and export concerns. In Malaysia, a two-week lockdown may have limited economic impact, but volatility in markets is expected. Vietnam's economy is recovering, with foreign investors returning after sweetened trade terms. Meanwhile, Malaysia's central bank has cut interest rates to shield the economy from tariff threats and support Muslim-owned enterprises in Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Chinese banking regulator fines China Construction Bank $1m for violations
summary: The Chinese banking regulator fined a branch of China Construction Bank (CCB) $1.5 million for rule violations, including hiding risks, using loans for unauthorized purposes, and misallocating funds. The Shenzhen branch was also fined four individuals for breaching rules in connection with real estate loans and bills. The regulator confiscated over $1 million of ill-gotten gains.

site_title: Julius Baer warns of full-year goodwill hit as 9-month profitability rises
summary: Swiss wealth manager Julius Baer reported a 9-month profitability rise despite warning of a full-year goodwill hit due to its ailing Italian company Kairos. The bank will book a 177 million-euro goodwill charge and retain a 70% stake in Kairos' asset and wealth management unit. Assets under management rose 3% to 413 billion Swiss francs, driven by fresh client inflows and a recovery in stock markets. Gross margins remained consistent, and the bank's adjusted cost-income ratio improved to 66.1%. Its shares rose 5% after the market opened.

site_title: Zambia heading for showdown with bondholders
summary: Zambia is at risk of defaulting on its debt, with bondholders rejecting a proposed six-month interest-payment holiday. If investors refuse, it would be the first African nation to default since the coronavirus outbreak, setting a precedent for how governments treat private and Chinese creditors. The government's lack of transparency and willingness to skip a $42.5 billion coupon payment have raised doubts about its ability to tackle its debt problems. With the next general elections in August, Zambia faces a tumultuous path of negotiations with creditors and the IMF.

site_title: Japan to tap budget reserves worth 549b yen to protect jobs, supply chains
summary: Japan's cabinet has decided to tap emergency budget reserves worth 549 billion yen (S$7.1 billion) to support supply chains, farmers, and provide job subsidies amid the Covid-19 pandemic. This leaves 7.28 trillion yen in reserves out of a total 11.5 trillion yen originally earmarked. The move aims to cushion the economic impact and protect jobs and supply chains.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower on fading stimulus prospects
summary: US stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 indices dipping 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.5% amid growing uncertainty over a new stimulus package ahead of the US presidential election. Despite a boost from President Trump's signal of favoring a rescue package, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin reiterated the need for bipartisan support, dampening market sentiment.

site_title: Finance teams must adopt forward-looking analytics, a key to stay competitive
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of forward-looking analytics in the finance industry, making data-driven insights crucial for business survival and competitiveness. To remain relevant, finance teams must adopt predictive and prescriptive analytics, which uses existing data to forecast future performance and suggest courses of action. Despite this, many finance professionals still rely on traditional rearward-looking analytics, hindering their ability to provide forward-looking insights. Companies must invest in developing skills in predictive and prescriptive analytics to stay ahead in the market.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia's auditor flags going concern
summary: Parkson Retail Asia's auditor, Ernst & Young, has flagged the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to significant financial challenges. The auditor noted a net loss of S$85 million, current liabilities exceeding current assets by S$117.4 million, and total liabilities exceeding total assets by S$66 million. The company's operations were impacted by the pandemic, and its ability to continue as a going concern depends on generating sufficient cash flows and continued support from suppliers and creditors.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at over seven-month high as restrictions ease in Victoria
summary: Australia's shares ended at a seven-month high on Monday, gaining 0.9% to 6,229.40, driven by gains in financial and healthcare stocks as Victoria eased months-long movement restrictions. The state's government plans to reopen restaurants and retail stores by November 1. Global sentiment improved after US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi raised hopes for a coronavirus relief package. China's economic recovery accelerated in the third quarter, despite missing expectations.

images.alt_text: Australian shares ended at their highest in more than seven months on Monday after the state of Victoria, the country's coronavirus outbreak epicentre, eased months-long movement restrictions.

site_title: Genting lines looking to hire Singaporeans as cruises restart
